title: Already a Cinema Veteran at 19
description: Here, touch it, Julia Garner instructed, offering up her wild mane of springy blond curls. Its not a big deal. Were girls.

title: Finding Fulfillment in a Smaller Spotlight
description: Jean Butler, the choreographer and dancer, remembers the moment she taught herself how to jump higher. She was around 13 and had been, she said, jumping for hours with no success. And then she realized the trick.

title: A Virtuoso, at Least in His Spare Time
description: LONDON  Pianists can be bells-and-whistles showmen (Lang Lang, Liberace, Liszt) or soberly remote (Sviatoslav Richter, Rachmaninoff). But by tradition they are the mavericks of the music world, who spend long hours in small rooms poring over solo repertory that turns them into either thinkers or eccentrics. Maybe both. And an example of the thinking pianist (make up your own mind about the eccentricity) is Stephen Hough, whose thoughts take center stage Monday evening in a recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Sacrifice at the Altar of Intolerance
description: Two girls grow up together, friends and allies, in a decrepit Dickensian orphanage. When they turn 18 and have to leave, one goes abroad in search of work, while the other, after drifting for a while and out of other options, enters a monastery led by a charismatic monk and becomes a nun. After a few years the migr returns to visit her friend and finds her changed, a bit distant.

title: Automakers Work to Achieve Zero-Waste Goals
description: On Wednesday, Ford announced that it would increase its environmental strategy with a five-year plan to cut the waste it sent to landfills globally by 40 percent per vehicle from 2011 levels. In 2016, the company said, Ford would be producing just 13.4 pounds of waste a vehicle at its operations around the world, down from 38 pounds in 2007, 22.7 pounds in 2011 and 20.3 pounds this year.

title: Obama Jokes of Jedi Mind Meld
description: Speaking to reporters after meeting with Congressional leaders, President Obama playfully talks about negotiating with Republicans on the automatic spending cuts.

title: Hollywoods Priceless Sounding Board
description: When the action hit Cloverfield thrilled audiences in 2008, few in theaters could have guessed that they were, at least in part, under the creative stewardship of Steven Spielberg. Thats because Mr. Spielberg has no credit on the production. But that didnt stop him from giving the movies director, Matt Reeves, and its producer, J. J. Abrams, advice on how to improve the film.

title: Royal Pedigree Infuses Collective Beats
description: LOS ANGELES  In 2010 Raul and Mexia Hernndez set up a camera and a keyboard in their living room in San Jose, Calif., to sing a song about immigrant rights. Mexia rapped about cooks and domestic workers and Latinos being on the rise like blood pressure. Raul crooned the Spanish-language hook (I just want to succeed/And now they want to deport me). Their brother, Giovanni, played a beat on a trash can. They called the song Todos Somos Arizona (We Are All Arizona) and uploaded the video to YouTube as a direct response to the states passage of a strict anti-immigrant law. The song quickly racked up thousands of views and earned the siblings a publicist.

title: A Symbol of Liberty, Strength and Budget Fights
description: WASHINGTON  In April 2011, just before a midnight deadline to avert a government shutdown, President Obama celebrated a budget agreement between Congressional Democrats and Republicans.

title: Kimchi Radish Pickle
description: Have you run out of ideas for root vegetables? Melissa Clark adds one more possibility with kimchi radish pickles.

title: The Limits of Executive Power
description: President Obama is obviously sick and tired of the widely peddled notion that the sequester and all other budget failures are ultimately his fault because hes the president. His frustration made for a surprisingly lively news conference this morning, and gave the public a brief reminder that there are real limits to the power of the White House.

title: Before a Tourists Body Was Found, Rebuffed Efforts to Report Her Missing
description: Li Junyun, 46, arrived in New York last month with a tourist visa and a single suitcase, hoping to see what America was like, a friend said.

title: New Orleans Snowball Wars Come to an End
description: Snowballs are as integral to New Orleans life as beignets. But hard-core loyalties have cleaved the community of shaved-ice enthusiasts and vendors, as seen by the three decades of lawsuits that have just come to an end. Channel 4 in New Orleans has the story. The lawsuits involved disputes over trademarks and patents for the equipment used to make the snowballs, and also which companies could use which names for flavors like King Cake, Cajun Red Hot, Orchid Cream Vanilla and Hurricane.

title: German Copyright Law Targets Google Links
description: BERLIN  German lawmakers approved legislation on Friday that grants publishers the right to charge search engines and other online aggregators for reproducing their content but continues to allow the free use of text in links and brief summaries.

title: A Rainbow of Root Vegetables
description: This weeks Recipes for Health is as much a treat for the eyes as the palate. Colorful root vegetables from bright orange carrots and red scallions to purple and yellow potatoes and pale green leeks will add color and flavor to your table.

title: With The Bible, the Mini-Series Goes Back to the Beginning
description: For as long as there has been filmed entertainment there have been producers and directors retelling the dramatic stories from the 66 books of the Old and New Testaments. But the cable channel Historys coming 10-hour mini-series, The Bible, might be the first to include an angel skilled in Chinese martial arts.

title: A Day of Watching TV at Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Jane Campion has spent decades traveling the festival circuit, listening to countless audiences react to her films, like The Piano or Bright Star. Still, nothing prepared her for the response during a showing in the Egyptian Theater during the Sundance Film Festival in January.

title: Spains Paradors Face an Uncertain Future
description: We crisscrossed Europe in the family car when I was a child. My father, a sports columnist based in Paris in the 1960s, was always testing tips he had gotten from Grand Prix racecar drivers. My mother, no surprise, was constantly telling him to slow down. In the back seat, my sisters and I were usually hungry, tired or fighting. But we saw amazing things: castles, cathedrals, villages slapped up against cliffs to protect them from Roman invaders, beaches still scarred with the wreckage of World War II battles.

title: A Crunchy End to Winter
description: By March Ive had my fill of root vegetables. All winter long, I gratined them, pured them, roasted and sauted them. I savored them in soups, blanketed them with cheese and cream and shaved them sensibly into lean, crisp salads.

title: Model Diary | Daria Strokous
description: It was no surprise that Daria Strokous, a face in Christian Diors current advertising campaign, was on the runway today in a Raf Simons-designed frock. The 22-year-old Russian model lives in New York and is currently bopping around Paris to hip-hop music on her iPod.

title: Getting Comfortable With the New Vail
description: In the late 1950s, Pete Seibert, who dreamed of building a major ski resort in Colorado, spent seven hours hiking to the top of what is now Vail Mountain. At the crest of the obscure, unpopulated hill, he glimpsed a rare landscape of largely treeless bowls, a vast panorama of seemingly boundless, perfect skiing terrain.

title: Vail at 50
description: As the resort celebrates a milestone anniversary, see how skiing there has evolved.

title: 9 Spring Breaks, From Budget to Beyond
description: When it comes to my childrens school vacations, the only one that has always produced an overwhelming need to get away as a family is spring break. Falling in March or April, depending on the school, the week punctuates the endless stretch between January and schools end, providing a chance for rest and adventure after a long period of burrowing.

title: Safekeeping a Relic of the Punk Era
description: Every day, we upload and unload, migrating more and more of our hard stuff to the digital realm. Films, music, photos, magazines, even tools like levels, flashlights and thermometers are now mushed into megabytes. Yet there is one object we remain ambivalent about letting go of, and that is that much-loved portable media-holder known as the book.

title: Shooting Vacation Video Like a Pro
description: No longer is travel programming the sole territory of television and big budgets. A younger generation of filmmakers like Daniel Klein is producing Web travel series pretty much on their own, thanks largely to new digital cameras that are (relatively) small in size and price.

title: Bonnie Franklin, Steadfast Mom on One Day at a Time, Dies at 69
description: Bonnie Franklin, whose portrayal of a pert but determined Ann Romano on the television show One Day at a Time in the 1970s and 80s spun laughter out of the tribulations of a divorced woman juggling parenting, career, love life and feminist convictions, died on Friday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 69.

title: Now Hear This: Works by Chinese Sound Artists
description: Colgate University is mounting an exhibition of sound-art installations by Chinese artists whose work has never been displayed in the United States.

title: Tip Bankers Like Waiters
description: Forget Europes bonus caps for bankers. It might make for good publicity for the politicians, but wags in the City, Londons financial district, are already joking about ways to get around it.

title: Global Event Succeeds Where It Needs To
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: Statistics Guru Settles In With the Grizzlies
description: It was a coup for basketballs stats geeks when one of their own, John Hollinger, was hired away from ESPN to be the vice president of player personnel for the Memphis Grizzlies in December. Hollinger, who created the Player Efficiency Rating metric, a single number to measure a players overall value, is enjoying himself as the Grizzlies are riding high for the moment. So he will presumably be feeling pretty good on Friday as he heads to the Sports Analytics Conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the highlight of the sports geeks calendar.

title: 10 Questions for the Red Bulls
description: The Red Bulls, the ever-underachieving Red Bulls, open their 2013 season at Portland on Sunday evening. And the schedule makers in Major League Soccer must have a perverse sense of humor because Game 2 will also be on the West Coast, at San Jose. That makes it coast to coast to coast to coast to coast in the space of a couple of weeks. Here are some questions to ponder before the opener, and beyond:

title: March 3  March 9
description: Creativity on the Road

title: Ireland Seeks Easing of Its Debt Terms
description: DUBLIN  Ireland has been widely praised as the good pupil of the euro zones austerity school of thought. Now it wants to be rewarded.

title: Italian Lender Sues Deutsche Bank and Nomura
description: LONDON  In a first attempt to retrieve some of its losses, the Tuscan lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena sued Deutsche Bank and Nomura on Friday over certain financial transactions that went bad.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Batman Battles the Owls
description: New on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, at No. 1, is Batman: Night of Owls, written by Scott Snyder and illustrated by Greg Capullo.

title: Sharp Memory Yields Perils and Payday
description: What are the elements that make us human, that make us ourselves? Our memories, our ability to feel and to empathize? Or perhaps our capacity for cruelty?

title: Maison Martin Margiela: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: It Helps to Lift the Bride Off Her Feet
description: After a decade-long courtship, Nicholas Keefe was as ready as one could be to wed Claire Lieberman, his high school sweetheart. Yet as their wedding day approached, there was one detail about it that sparked nervousness in Mr. Keefe, a former high school football, basketball and baseball player: the first dance.

title: Smash Getting Only a Little Help From DVR Numbers
description: Sure, the ratings for the second season of NBCs Smash have been low. The most recent episode fell to 3.3 million total viewers and it barely cleared the 1 million threshold in viewers between the ages of 18 and 49, the demographic most important to advertisers. But DVR viewing was crucial to buoying Smash in its first season. Will that be a help this time around?Probably not.

title: A Snapshot of Drilling on a Parks Margins
description: More on the fracking front:

title: Dior: A Comfortable Embrace
description: People left the Dior show today on a high, or I had the feeling they did. What is it about the sight of those huge Mylar bubbles hovering near the ceiling that made people feel giddy? The self-reflecting possibilities of the silvery surfaces were intriguing, as was the background music: a neurotic recording by Laurie Anderson of a visit to her Greenwich Village vet to see why her dog was so fat. Or was it that Raf Simons had once again changed peoples expectations about Dior and, by association, fashion?

title: Countdown to Sequester Links
description: Some potential consequences of the sequester:

title: Vanessa Bruno: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Cleveland TV Station Celebrates Andy Griffith After Oscars Snub
description: Andy Griffith received little love from the Oscars last Sunday, as the producers decided to leave him off the list of actors honored in the yearly obituary reel.

title: Blogging Her Life With Cancer
description: When I called on readers to submit the blogs they loved for the Motherlode blogroll, one name came up more than any other: Lisa B. Adams. And I can understand why. The best personal blogs come from people on a journey through something that is as intense as anything theyve ever experienced, and Lisa is on a journey none of us want to be on. She has breast cancer, and last fall she learned that the cancer had metastasized to her bones, becoming Stage 4 breast cancer.

title: Breaking Free of Fashions Hamster Wheel
description: PARIS  As I said in a previous post, Alber Elbaz saw the problem of all these fashion shows, running like a hamster wheel, each format virtually the same, and in his own way did something about it. But now Ive seen Raf Simonss Dior show, and also Undercover (by the amazing Jun Takahashi), and they all express a similar attitude  which is freedom. It sounds silly to say that of talented and well-paid designers, but theres a reason you leave their shows feeling good.

title: The Donut District
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Week in Pictures for March 1
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gun rally in Albany; a demolished home in Roxbury, Queens; and a flash mob in Times Square.

title: Church, State and Bible Class in Texas
description: It may be a little late for the holiday of Purim, but on Tuesday, in Eastland, Tex., Gay Hart will be baking hamantaschen  the traditional doughy, triangle-shaped pastries accented with dollops of prune, Nutella or some other delectable paste  for the mostly Protestant students in her class on the Bible at Eastland High School. Her curriculum also includes latke recipes for Hanukkah, challah-days and the Hebrew melody Hava Nagila.

title: Q and A: The Angry Economist
description: Dieter Helm has long been frustrated that, despite more than two decades of international negotiations, the world has failed to tackle climate change. So he got angry, he said, and decided to write a book about it: The Carbon Crunch: How Were Getting Climate Change Wrong  and How to Fix It.

title: An Exuberance Is Bustin Out All Over, Under the Loving Gaze of a Father
description: Tiler Peck, wearing a pale pink dress with her brown hair streaming around her shoulders, dashes across the stage at Avery Fisher Hall with her arms open wide and her heart exposed. As Louise, Billy Bigelows daughter in Carousel, Ms. Peck is a vulnerable spitfire  and just about as transcendent as the music.

title: Two Composers Jaunts to Latin America
description: The Collegiate Chorale had logical reasons to pair the pieces it performed in its concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, Philip Glasss  Symphony No. 7 (Toltec) and Osvaldo Golijovs  Oceana. Both are substantial statements by well-known, popular living composers. Both deal with Latin American culture, though in disparate ways. And, on the evidence offered here by the chorale with the conductor James Bagwell, the American Symphony Orchestra and other guests, both works recall stronger efforts by these important, distinctive composers.

title: Week in Review: Sizable Pay for the Wall St. Survivors
description: The Heinz case may have involved a side bet in London. | Mary Jo White is trying to allay skepticism ahead of her Senate confirmation hearing. | Bonus pay on Wall St. rose 9% last year. | Andrew Ross Sorkin warns that shareholder democracy can mask abuses. | Banks fear a court ruling in Argentinas bond debt.

title: For 3 Weeks, Eating Like Jews of Baghdad
description: Update, March 4 | Many readers asked for a kubbeh recipe. A reader, VM, shared her mothers recipe. Thanks, VM!

title: Judge Cuts Sum Owed to Apple Over Patents
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 1
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Bill Cunningham | Right on Red
description: A standout theme at the recent New York fashion shows, black and white, leaves the jelly-bean colors to youngsters. But don't forget red and black, which was popular in the late 1930s and early '40s.

title: Mom Always Said to Share
description: From the time they were middle-school students in Manhattan, Arielle Patrick and her brother, Andrew, had an agreement: come college graduation, if they werent married they would share a bachelor/bachelorette pad in the city. They were serious enough about the matter to put the pact in writing on a piece of loose-leaf paper and, with great earnestness, to sign their names at the bottom.

title: Movie Review | 'Leviathan'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Leviathan.

title: Guest Post: Constitutional Revenge
description: It has been a while since the last post on this blog, but my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, who heads our Law and Public Affairs program, is still tracking the unraveling of democracy in Hungary, and has a new, disturbing report after the jump:

title: Teams Begin Using Franchise Tag
description: With the N.F.L. salary cap finally set at $123 million, teams began Friday to make some of their most critical off-season decisions. Three teams used the franchise tag  Buffalo on safety Jairus Byrd, Cincinnati on defensive end Michael Johnson and Indianapolis on punter Pat McAfee  essentially halting the players opportunities to test the free-agent market when it opens March 12.

title: Movie Review | 'Stoker'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Stoker."

title: Teenagers in The Times | February, 2013
description: Connor McDavid, a 16-year-old star in his first season in the Ontario Hockey League, is an early favorite to be selected first in the 2015 N.H.L. entry draft.

title: Fairway Market Reopens in Brooklyn
description: The scene in Red Hook as a neighborhood anchor welcomed customers for the first time since Hurricane Sandy.

title: Movie Review | Jack the Giant Slayer
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Jack the Giant Slayer.

title: Noodles With No Need to Dress Up
description: The first time I tasted fresh egg pasta, back in the 20th century, it was cooked by a bunch of Italian hippies in a dilapidated Victorian house in San Francisco, and it was an event. These expatriates may have been sharing a house on the cheap with their counterculture pals, but they were not about to eat bland brown rice and steamed vegetables if they could help it. Having been raised to appreciate a tastier form of communal eating, they invited a bevy of friends to a Sunday meal. The only thing on the menu was handmade pasta, and part of the experience was observing the process.

title: In Like a Lion: Knicks Face Tough Road in March
description: WASHINGTON  It is probably an oversimplification to say that a single month can make or break a teams season. But the month of March just might make or break the Knicks.

title: Report May Ease Path for New Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department issued a revised environmental impact statement for the 1,700-mile Keystone XL pipeline on Friday that makes no recommendation about whether the project should be built but presents no conclusive environmental reason it should not be.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 1
description: More photographs.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A Connecticut ranch overlooking a pond and bird sanctuary and a Westchester home with leaded glass windows throughout.

title: Wilson to Obama: March Forth!
description: THERE has been a change of government, declared Woodrow Wilson in his first sentence as president of the United States, one hundred years ago this Monday. Until 1937, when the 20th Amendment moved Inauguration Day to late January, chief executives took their oaths of office on March Fourth, a date that sounds like a command.

title: Past Forward: What Good Is Amtrak?
After Further Review...
description: The not-all-new 2013 Honda Civic is a sharper, better-focused, user-friendlier version of the Civic, even though its fundamentally the same car.

title: It Pays to Look Like a High Roller
description: Parked in front of a Century 21 real estate office in Upper Montclair, N.J., the regal automobile drew glances from people in passing cars and on foot.

title: Friday Night Music: Elephant Revival, Remembering a Beginning
description: Yes, its still afternoon, but Im going to go be human for a few hours, then do Ed Schultz. ER  which describes their music as transcendental folk  is performing at Joes Pub in NYC this Sunday:

title: Poll Finds Record Support for Same-Sex Marriage in California
description: The same week the Obama administration filed a brief urging the Supreme Court to strike down Californias ban on same-sex marriage, a new Field Poll was released showing that support for same-sex marriage in the state has increased drastically since the ban was passed there a little more than four years ago.

title: The Holocaust Just Got More Shocking
description: THIRTEEN years ago, researchers at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum began the grim task of documenting all the ghettos, slave labor sites, concentration camps and killing factories that the Nazis set up throughout Europe.

title: A Pickle With Different Roots
description: A few weeks ago, I found a bag of watermelon radishes in my Community Supported Agriculture box. So I took them home and pickled them for this weeks column, flavoring the roots with traditional kimchi seasonings. But the same recipe would work well with other juicy root vegetables, too, including carrots, kohlrabi, celery root and turnips. Feel free to experiment with whatever you happen to have on hand  or whatever your C.S.A. box gives you.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An upper East Side Co-op with a wood-burning fireplace, a Brooklyn six-bedroom Victorian, and a Chelsea pre-war walkup.

title: Teams Trailing Late in Games Play More Efficiently, Paper Suggests
description: This year marks the seventh installment of the M.I.T. Sloan Sports Analytics Conference. Held in Boston, the conference  which is expected to draw in excess of 2,500 attendees  represents the cutting edge of statistical, economic and technological information in the world of sports, with dozens of papers, panels and presentations giving attendees a first-hand look at the future of our most cherished pastimes.

title: A Blogs Adieu
description: The Times is discontinuing the Green blog, which was created to track environmental and energy news and to foster lively discussion of developments in both areas. This change will allow us to direct production resources to other online projects. But well forge ahead with our aggressive reporting on environmental and energy topics, including climate change, land use, threatened ecosystems, government policy, the fossil fuel industries, the growing renewables sector and consumer choices.

title: New Jazz Vocabularies, a Bit of Elegance and Big Ideas
description: THIEFS

title: Obama on the Budget Cuts
description: President Obama speaks to reporters following a meeting with Congressional leaders in the Oval Office about the automatic spending cuts.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Nigeria, West Bank and India.

title: Save That MetroCard! A New One Will Now Cost $1
description: They are the subways plastic yellow orphans.

title: Sonia Rykiel: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: An Addendum
description: Were moving, but well only be a mouse-click away.

title: Big Ticket: Heat, Light and Height, Sold at $8.15 Million
description: A sun-glazed floor-through penthouse with a modernist mind-set in a Costas Kondylis-designed condominium tower at 279 Central Park West sold for $8.15 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Living In | Bronxville, N.Y.
description: A square-mile chunk of the town of Eastchester 15 miles from Midtown Manhattan, looks much the way it did 75 years ago.

title: Excerpt: 'Red Widow'
description: The new ABC series stars Radha Mitchell as the titular widow.

title: Traditions Change, Even Here
description: Seven years ago, when Irina Sher, a native of Yerevan, Armenia, first set foot in the southern Westchester suburb of Bronxville and saw its wooded hillsides inset with substantial Tudor, Shingle-style and Victorian homes, she was captivated. When she learned about its top-rated public school, her decision was made: I knew right away I had to raise my children here, whatever the cost.

title: Fairway Market Comes Back After Sandy
description: In another sign that the region is recovering from Sandys devastation, the Fairway Market and other businesses in Red Hook on Brooklyns waterfront reopened today. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Senator Charles E. Schumer were some of the first customers to order from the Fairway deli counter.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Chalayan
description: Hussein is doing something very elevated with his collection, so I wanted the girls to appear very pure, said the makeup artist Aaron de Mey backstage at Chalayan. To accomplish this, he first worked M.A.C. Mineralize Charged Water Moisture Gel onto the skin to lay the groundwork for a dewy complexion. He then mixed together two shimmery hues of M.A.C. Cream Color Base, Pearl and Luna, and applied them where the sun hits your face  cheekbones, bridge of nose, cupid bow, chin  to give the face dimension. The look was stark and clean but not severe thanks to the iridescence in the product.

title: Adam Selman Dresses Rihanna for the Stage
description: Rihannas costume designer, who worked with her on the Rihanna for River Island collection, is sharing the spotlight.

title: Insurgent St. Patricks Day Parade Comes Into Its Own
description: Brendan Fay pointed to an e-mail on his computer screen from the New York Fire Departments Emerald Society Pipes and Drums corps confirming that it would be marching in the St. Patricks Day parade in Queens, on Sunday.

title: A Well-Done Do-Over Raises the Final Grade
description: The 2012 Honda Civic was a goof: a dull all-new car that wasnt better, in any significant way, than the one it replaced. Goofs are fixable, however  just ask NASA.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 1 from Business
description: The trial against BP over the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico began in New Orleans, Marissa Mayer ordered Yahoo workers back to the office, and Jacob J. Lew was confirmed as Treasury secretary.

title: The Secret Weapon Behind Rihannas Look
description: After the Rihanna for River Island presentation during London Fashion Week, its namesake designer, the biggest pop star on the planet, came out for a bow. Accompanying her was a boyish, mustachioed fellow. Most of the audience had no clue who he was. Beaming, he turned to Rihanna and applauded.

title: With Rodman Stunt, American Reality TV and North Korean Propaganda Fuse
description: Updated, Sunday, 11:21 p.m. Elements of American show business and North Korean propaganda briefly fused on Friday, when the former basketball star Dennis Rodman told reporters in Pyongyang that North Koreans love their new leader, Kim Jong-un. And guess what? the athlete turned reality TV star added, I love him  the guys awesome.

title: 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational
description: The 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational took place last weekend. Twenty pairs played a round robin of eight-board matches. The scoring method was Butler. Each pairs results were scored by international match points against the average on a board, with the extreme results being eliminated from the calculation of the average.

title: How to Overcome a Gaffe: Two Contemporary Case Studies
description: There is a formula emerging for solving that most contemporary of political problems: when a silly gaffe  propelled and amplified by Twitter  distracts from the substantive message.

title: Plumbing the Deep
description: Vrna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor talk about their new film Leviathan, a documentary about commercial fishing without interviews, voice-over, narrative or a traditional point of view.

title: Not Enough Inflation
description: Yes, we have low inflation: The Commerce Department reported Friday that prices rose just 1.2 percent over the 12 months ending in January.

title: A Comedian as Nice Guy Next Door?
description: John Mulaney seems like the kind of stand-up comic you could take home and introduce to your parents.

title: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: You Plunder, Ill Pillage, Maybe Well Find England
description: Vikings is a mini-series about a band of professional pillagers with a disregard for human life and a relentless focus on gratifying material desires. So it is somewhat surprising that it is also a refreshing study in restraint.

title: England Develops a Voracious Appetite for a New Diet
description: LONDON  Visitors to England right now, be warned. The big topic on peoples minds  from cabdrivers to corporate executives  is not Kate Middletons increasingly visible baby bump (though the craze does involve the size of ones waistline), but rather a best-selling diet book that has sent the British into a fasting frenzy.

title: The No-Limits Job
description: Every generation has its own anthem of making the journey from youthful navet to adult reality, whether its Neil Youngs Old Man, Nirvanas Smells Like Teen Spirit or most recently, perhaps, the Taylor Swift song 22.

title: Let Your Body Sing
description: As video concepts go, it was pretty simple: hit the streets and parks of New York with a boombox playing a dance remix of your bands song and ask passers-by of all ages, races, shapes and sizes to move to it. Film the results.

title: Manuela Frey Transforms Backstage at Maison Martin Margiela
description: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper557 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

title: A Brazilian Menu Inspired by Mom
description: A blast of warmth hits you as soon as you enter Samba Montclair, a tiny Brazilian restaurant in the heart of Montclair, though its not a matter of temperature, even if the place does offer a blessed respite from a frigid winter evening. Its a subtler, enveloping glow: the soothing Latin music, the weathered rustic dcor, the low lighting, the young, easygoing staff. That, and the large chalkboard toward the back that offers up bits of homespun wisdom, like The torch of love is lit in the kitchen.

title: Drawn Into Crime, Trying to Get Out
description: In the Twilight series Bella Swan holds out until the fourth movie before being forced to transform from young human bride into vampire. In Red Widow Marta Walraven makes a parallel jump  from Marin County suburban homemaker to Russian mobster  before the end of Sunday nights two-hour premiere. Thats television, always in a hurry.

title: Open Exploring, With Skill for a Net
description: In the saxophonist Ravi Coltranes new album, Spirit Fiction (Blue Note), he works with two different groups, destabilizing the idea that he has a current group sound, or maybe enlarging it. In his Jazz Standard run hes pushing the idea further, playing with three different bands over the course of a six-day week. The third one, playing this weekend, is as close as it gets to his latest going concern.

title: A Strong First Impression
description: David Michael Leedy says his 1975 Rolls-Royce helps him stand out in a crowded real estate market.

title: The Devil Wants a Sequel
description: Poor Nell cant catch a break. In The Last Exorcism (2010) this Louisiana teenager was possessed by the demon Abalam and ultimately bore his progeny, only to have their unholy offspring disposed of by solemn hooded attendants. In The Last Exorcism: Part II she has survived that ordeal, unlike her father (or so it appears), the documentary crew filming her and the minister of lapsed faith who attempted to coax out her tormentor.

title: Selections From the Sea on a Refreshed Menu
description: One cold, windy evening, I found myself yearning, somewhat perversely, for a seafood dinner served on a deck overlooking the water. Though thats really a summertime treat, I went in search of the closest thing I could find in these waning weeks of winter.

title: With Friends Like These . . .
description: Theres a line early on in 21 & Over about your oldest friends always being your strangest ones. That may be true, but there is a bigger theme here: After four years of college lifelong friendships can become forced, resulting in awkward attempts to reconnect and relive the good old days.

title: In Nigerias Largest City, Homeless Are Paying the Price of Progress
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  The young man with the crowbar stood on a heap of rubble  planks, pallets, remains of pots, bits of cardboard, wisps of clothing, chunks of concrete  indistinguishable from every other pile in a field of debris stretching far into the distance.

title: A High-Dollar Debutante Ball
description: A glittering bumper crop of million-dollar babies will be shown at the 83rd International Motor Show in Geneva, where press previews begin on Tuesday.

title: Compressing Gas for a Cheaper, Simpler Hybrid
description: PARIS  Whats that car that just breezed past?

title: Expressionisms Sooty Anomaly
description: Franz Kline established himself as a major Abstract Expressionist painter almost overnight. In 1950, the year he turned 40, he had the first solo show of his career, at the Charles Egan Gallery on 57th Street in Manhattan. There he unveiled the dynamic abstractions, with their jutting, intersecting beams of black embedded in dense fields of white that would earn him a place in the Abstract Expressionist pantheon and rank among the styles most emblematic motifs.

title: Gunfight at the Universal-International Corral
description: Western Horizons

title: Rich Tastes on Small Plates
description: Im going to be harshly critical of Vinted: in my expert opinion, no restaurant should have a past participle for a name.

title: The Daily Do | Maison Martin Margiela
description: There are certain tools necessary to keep ones mane from becoming too unruly  the ponytail holder, Aqua Net, bobby pins. Several of the jackets sent down the Margiela Fall/Winter 2013 runway came complete with a built-in, barrette-like flap where the hair was tucked in, securing the hair so it was never out of place.

title: A Time of Transition in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Homeless Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: From Sure Hands, a Smooth Riesling
description: Roman Roth, Wlffer Estate Vineyards winemaker since 1992 (he was recently named a partner), has released an unusual riesling under his personal label, the Grapes of Roth.

title: Bright Lights, Big City (Redux)
description: Gavin Doyle went from fresh-faced kid to night-life fixture in the time it took the doorman to lift the velvet rope.

title: Bright Lights, Big City (Redux)
description: When Gavin Doyle moved to New York from Miami in 2006, he knew only one person, Abby Hofeldt, a classmate from Miami Country Day whod come here to study fashion. On Halloween night they presented themselves outside the Beatrice Inn in the West Village, a speakeasy-turned-restaurant-turned-low-key bar with a tough door policy.

title: Using Walls to Talk Back to Unwelcome Compliments
description: Shorty. Sweetie. Sweetheart. Baby. Boo. If youre a woman, youve probably heard it.

title: Fighting the Insurer Over Hurricane Sandy Damage
description: With Hurricane Sandy moving in, Andrea and Stephen Kondaks gathered candles, water and flashlights, and then put on their fishing waders. There was nothing left to do but wait, and watch, as the oily water slowly seeped into the hallway of their house, two and a half blocks from the bay in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

title: Too Fat to Enlist
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Does Your Hurricane Sandy Claim Stand?
description: This weeks Your Money column tells the tale of Andrea and Stephen Kondaks, a couple whose Brooklyn home took in nearly eight feet of water during Hurricane Sandy. Dealing with the trauma and physical clean-up after the storm was hard enough. But Mrs. Kondaks has spent the last four months trying to convince the couples flood insurer that its estimate for the cost of repair was woefully inadequate.

title: Cruise Ship Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Voyage to Thailand, by Land or Sea
description: Long before Pan-Asian palaces were the rage, Thai food had already won many fans on Long Island. Some of the best Thai food around is served at an attractive storefront in Massapequa Park, Thai Taste, which opened eight years ago.

title: Run Airlines as a Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: French and Chad Forces Strike Militants in the Mountains of Mali
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The French military struck at Islamist militants dug in along the remote, rocky mountain ranges of northern Mali over the last week, killing scores, a French military spokesman said Friday.

title: State Department Again Sees No Environmental Barriers to Keystone Pipeline
description: The State Departments revised supplemental environmental impact statement on the proposed 1,700-mileKeystone XLpipeline is out, and offers very little that Secretary of State John Kerry or President Obama might use as a reason to reject the plan.

title: The Daily Shoe | Sonia Rykiel
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Under Fire, the Mayor of Pittsburgh Quits Race
description: Luke Ravenstahl, who at 26 became Pittsburghs youngest mayor ever, abruptly dropped his bid for re-election Friday amid a federal investigation of the citys Police Department and the forced resignation last month of the police chief.

title: Joe Johnson Back for Nets
description: Nets guard Joe Johnson returned to the lineup Friday against the Dallas Mavericks after a three-game absence caused by a left heel injury.

title: Tasting Freedom at Dior and Lanvin
description: PARIS

title: The Week in Pictures for March 1
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gun rally in Albany; a demolished home in Roxbury, Queens; and a flash mob in Times Square.

title: Lawyers Go to Cambodia Over Statue
description: Two lawyers from the United States Attorneys Office in Manhattan traveled into the Cambodian jungle this week to inspect an ancient, crumbling temple as part of their offices effort to seize a 10th-century Khmer statue that Sothebys hopes to sell at auction.

title: Old Tricks Up New Sleeves
description: PARIS

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Florida Man Lost in Sinkhole
description: An enormous sinkhole opened beneath a central Florida house on Thursday night, sucking down and burying a man who was in his bedroom.

title: Argentinas About-Face on Terror
description: ON July 18, 1994, a van filled with explosives blew up outside the Jewish community center in Buenos Aires, killing 85 people and injuring hundreds. It was the worst terrorist attack ever in Argentina, which has Latin Americas largest Jewish population, and one of the deadliest anti-Semitic attacks since the Holocaust.

title: In His Annual Letter, Buffett Plays Up Newspapers
description: Over the last half-century, Warren E. Buffett has built a reputation as a contrarian investor, betting against the crowd to amass a fortune estimated at $54 billion.

title: Equality First, Guns Afterward
description: When recruiting began in February 1863 for the 54th Massachusetts  one of the first regiments in the Union Army composed of Northern free blacksmany Bostonians expected Robert Morris to be among its strongest boosters. A key figure in the citys black leadership, Morris had spent much of the previous decade demanding a place for his black military company in the Massachusetts Volunteer Militia. He passionately believed that the spectacle of black men arrayed in the states uniforms, marching in disciplined ranks, would force a change in how most whites perceived them, replacing inchoate fears of slave rebellion with admiration for the newest members of the citizen-soldiery.

title: Touring the Source of a Writers Vaunted Words
description: Philip Roth turns 80 on March 19, and in his hometown, Newark, bus tours and an exhibition of photographs are among the events planned for the occasion.

title: Homeless in an Instant
description: As Lagos aims to become a premier business center, the citys poor and homeless are becoming the governments enemy.

title: Frisky Comedy and Hotel-Room Farce
description: One of the nicest features of the Broadway revival of Ken Ludwigs Lend Me a Tenor back in 2010 was John Lee Beattys creamy rococo hotel suite where the operatic characters dashed about.

title: Questions Emerge About the Mold That Hurricane Sandy Left Behind
description: At a mayoral debate in January, candidates vied to outdo one another in their dire warnings of a growing threat to public health that they said was hurting families all over New York City. Soon afterward, public and private groups pledged that millions of dollars would be spent to fight the scourge. And last month, Congressional representatives from New York called upon the federal government to help resolve what they called this emerging crisis.

title: Wet Conditions Raise Issue of Lift-Clean-and-Place Rule
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Like Rory McIlroy, Camilo Villegas is a former Honda Classic champion. Like McIlroy, Villegas began his second round Friday on the back nine at PGA National Resort and Spa and was seven over par for the day when he finished.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Capitalists for Preschool
description: IN his State of the Union address, President Obama called for making preschool available to every 4-year-old in America, opening a welcome discussion on whether and how to make the investments needed to realize this vision.

title: At Planetarium, Its Not the Same Old Sky
description: CENTERPORT, N.Y.  Standing behind the complex instrument panel that controls the gleaming Konica Minolta GeminiStar III projection system, Lorraine Vernola looks as though she could easily launch a spaceship, what with all the buttons, switches, computer screens and flashing lights in front of her. And in a sense, she can, at least virtually, for audiences inside the newly refurbished planetarium at the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum, the 43-acre former estate of William K. Vanderbilt II.

title: And the Oscar Doesnt Go to the Oscars
description: Well, here we are again. Oscar has come and gone.

title: Obama Pardons 17 Felons, First in His Second Term
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama issued pardons on Friday to 17 convicted felons, making the first use of his clemency powers in his second term. Their offenses were largely small-scale crimes many years ago, and 12 of the people had not been sentenced to serve time in prison.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Publisher Pulls a 2nd Book by Lehrer, How We Decide
description: Troubles for Jonah Lehrer, journalist wunderkind turned plagiarist and disgraced author, will not abate.

title: Singing the Sequester Soap Opera
description: THERE are cracks in time when history bends and for an instant it seems as if the world itself stops turning, from that Sunday afternoonwhen our parents learned Pearl Harbor hadbeen bombed to the football drill I was in the middle of coaching in Pensacola, Fla., when I first got the news that the Challenger had exploded. We may not agree on many things in this era of reflexive polarization, but here is one: nobody will remember where they were and what they were doing when the Great Sequester of 2013 kicked in.

title: As the Cuts Hit Home
description: House Republicans were elated this week when their leader, John Boehner, made it clear that deep, automatic spending cuts would begin as scheduled on Friday. Incredibly, some consider the decision a victory.

title: Ex-College Quarterback Is Acquitted of Rape in Montana
description: HELENA, Mont.  A former quarterback for the University of Montana was acquitted Friday of rape in a trial that riveted the city of Missoula.

title: Another Try at Nuclear Talks
description: Negotiations this week between the major powers and Iran on its nuclear program achieved only an agreement to hold technical talks in March and then another meeting in April. The outcome was frustratingly incremental, but it keeps alive the slim possibility of a diplomatic solution.

title: Way to Reach Kim Jong-un? Follow the Ball
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Landing an audience with Kim Jong-un, the leader of one of the worlds most reclusive countries, is not easy.

title: Longing to Escape From the Debt and the Dirt
description: The lamb gets laughs.

title: Soldier to Face More Serious Charges in Leak
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  Military prosecutors announced on Friday that they had decided to try Pfc. Bradley Manning on the most serious charges they have brought against him and seek a sentence that could be life without parole, despite his voluntary guilty plea to 10 lesser charges that carry a maximum total sentence of 20 years.

title: Penneys and Macys Battle Over Martha Stewart Products
description: Two of the biggest names in retail are fighting over Martha Stewart.

title: Better Care for Young Offenders
description: It took four years. But the Obama administration has finally filled an important post at the Justice Departments Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention, which oversees juvenile justice policy and distributes federal grants to encourage reform at the state and local levels.

title: Surrendering His Front-Row Seat
description: LONDON  From the moment last Saturdays Premier League game between Arsenal and Aston Villa began, goalkeeper Brad Guzan was in constant motion.

title: More Cameras for New York City Streets
description: The Bloomberg administration has been working to combat a deadly problem in New York City: drivers who speed or run through red lights.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 2, 2013
description: The Chinese hold the key to the elephants future. If things continue the way they are, many countries could lose their elephants altogether.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Changing Minds After Newtown
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: Concern and Canceled Flights as Airlines Wait for 787
description: Facing continued uncertainty over the fate of the Boeing 787 and its batteries, airlines are canceling more flights and adjusting their routes out of concern that it could be several more months before they can fly passengers on the planes again.

title: Space Station Astronauts Will Get Their Fruit, After a Bit of a Scare
description: At lunchtime on Friday, things were not looking good: a rocket carrying cargo to the International Space Station was having problems with its thrusters, imperiling its ability to get where it was going.

title: From Elephants Mouths, an Illicit Trail to China
description: PUZHAI, China  Chinese investors have anointed it white gold. Carvers and collectors prefer the term organic gemstone. Smugglers, however, use a gruesomely straightforward name for the recently harvested African elephant tusks that find their way to this remote trading outpost on the Vietnamese border.

title: Skin and Earth, Suddenly Unrecognizable
description: Despite the name, Terra Incognita, a new exhibition at Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle, is not a show that limits itself to depicting unknown lands.

title: On Revis, the Jets Can Best Afford to Wait and See
description: Either Darrelle Revis will play for the Jets in 2013, or he wont. The simplicity of that statement obscures a complicated problem, one that will lord over the team until it is resolved, be it in six days, six weeks or six months.

title: France: Le Monde Picks First Woman for a Top Post
description: Natalie Nougayrde, 46, was chosen Friday as the first woman to serve as both director and editor of Le Monde, Frances most prominent newspaper, and its Web site. Ms. Nougayrde, the diplomatic correspondent and former Moscow bureau chief for the newspaper, was elected by the staff after being nominated by the principal owners. She succeeds rik Izraelewicz, who died suddenly in November and who had first combined the jobs of director and editor. Sylvie Kauffmann was the first woman to serve as editor of Le Monde, under the director ric Fottorino.

title: Soccer in the Blood, Pork on the Platter
description: With its smoky aromas, rough-hewed picnic tables and numerous bourbons poured straight from the barrel, the Strand Smokehouse, at 25-27 Broadway, brings a hint of down-home flavor to the traditionally Greek precincts of Astoria, Queens. Half barbecue joint, half beer garden, the Strand, which opened two months ago, serves a pan-regional mash-up of ribs, smoked chicken and pulled pork accompanied by local craft beers and a whiskey selection that could easily make a transplanted good old boy nostalgic for home. While the large backyard was still closed for the season last week, the cavernous main room was filled with an assortment of sticky-fingered families, curious local residents and at least one heterogeneous party of first-time visitors.

title: Corrections: March 2, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Things Worth Waiting For
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Holy moly, this one by Barry C. Silk took my breath away. I feel energized and beaten up at the same time, and as the Top Gear host Jeremy Clarkson once said, the last time I had this much fun, furniture got broken. This one got me RARIN TO GO.

title: More Reasons to Enter Arena
description: Bigger and clearer televisions keep bringing couch-bound sports fans closer to the action, while tickets to live events are hardly getting any cheaper. This prompts the question: When will it make sense just to stay home?

title: Classic Toys Redesigned to Traverse Generations
description: To Hasbro, no one is too young or too old to play with a Transformers robot, watch a Transformers television show or play a Transformers video game.

title: Poison Pill Politics
description: The deadline has passed. The sequester is in effect. And Congress is not in session.

title: A Divide on Voting Rights in a Town Where Blood Spilled
description: McCOMB, Miss.  In the refined air of the United States Supreme Court, the questions posed by justices on Wednesday seemed so big as to be unanswerable: Are parts of the Voting Rights Act an unfair infringement on state sovereignty? How different is the South these days from other regions, and from itself in bloody years past?

title: A Good Night for Fishnets
description: Ron Maxwell has done over 1,000 performances as Brad in The Rocky Horror Picture Show in Chelsea.

title: World Baseball Classic Explained
description: The three-round tournament starts with 16 teams divided into four pools.

title: Gaza: Gunfire Erupts Along Border With Israel
description: Palestinians fired at an Israeli military jeep along the Gaza border on Friday, hitting the vehicle but causing no injuries, and three Palestinian protesters were wounded by Israeli fire during disturbances along the border fence, the Israeli military said. The confrontations erupted three days after Gaza militants fired a rocket into Israel for the first time since a cease-fire agreement took hold in November. In addition, hundreds of Palestinians held rallies in several locations across the West Bank to protest the death of a Palestinian prisoner in an Israeli jail last weekend. The prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Salam Fayyad, was hustled away from a protest in Bilin after he inhaled tear gas fired by Israeli soldiers, and two Palestinians were injured elsewhere, according to Palestinian reports. The military said that it had used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse rioters and that one soldier had been injured by a rock.

title: Doing the Time Warp, Again
description: Dammit, Janets getting tough to lift.

title: A Recruiter at Heart Is Able to Build a Winner at Any Level
description: When the Tennessee mens basketball team arrived in Atlanta for the Southeastern Conference tournament in 2011, its season was spiraling out of control. The Volunteers had limped to an 8-8 record in league play, and the N.C.A.A.s Committee on Infractions had recently released a 26-page notice of allegations regarding the basketball program.

title: Death of Russian Adoptee Was Accidental, Texas Says
description: Texas officials investigating the death of a 3-year-old boy who had been adopted from Russia said Friday that they had found no evidence to support the filing of criminal charges against the boys parents. The death of the boy, Max Alan Shatto, prompted outrage in Russia, which late last year banned adoptions by American citizens. Russian leaders had accused the boys adoptive mother of fatally beating him. Two Ector County officials  Sheriff Mark Donaldson and District Attorney Bobby Bland  said that after an autopsy, the medical examiner had ruled that Maxs death was accidental. They said that he had been treated for a behavioral disorder that caused him to injure himself and that the bruising that had been found on his body was consistent with the kind of self-injury associated with the disorder. The boys adoptive mother, Laura Shatto, told investigators that she had left Max and his brother playing outside unattended and returned to find Max lying on the ground, unresponsive. He died later that day at a hospital. The United States Embassy in Moscow called the boys death a tragedy, but added that Texas officials worked diligently and professionally to examine the evidence concerning Maxs death.

title: Testimony Outlines Workday of Officer Accused of Grisly Plot
description: It would be an innocuous enough question in most criminal trials:

title: Argentina: U.S. Court Orders Debt Repayment Plan
description: A United States court of appeals gave Argentina until March 29 to submit a plan for the repayment of $1.33 billion in debt that the country defaulted on 11 years ago. N.M.L. Capital, a subsidiary of the New York-based hedge fund Elliott Management, is leading a lawsuit among bondholders who refused Argentinas 2005 and 2010 debt swaps. Ninety-three percent of creditors agreed to the restructuring in which debt stemming from Argentinas $100 billion default was exchanged for new issues at 35 cents on the dollar. A judge ruled last fall in favor of creditors, saying that Argentina could not service only some of its debt, and that it had the financial wherewithal to pay in full. Speaking to Congress on Friday, President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner said Argentina would pay these vulture funds but only according to the same terms and conditions agreed upon for the other creditors. A spokesman for Elliott Management declined to comment.

title: When Fans Flood Floor, Ritual Trumps Peril
description: There is no known provenance for the phrase storming the court, but for as long as there have been basketball courts, there have been faithful fans itching to celebrate significant wins on them with one another and their conquering heroes.

title: Ruses Used by F.B.I. Are Recounted in Cannibal Case
description: Last October, as agents with the Federal Bureau of Investigation prepared to arrest Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, they decided to use a ruse  a standard and legal law enforcement technique. He was, after all, a trained officer and had a gun. Agents arrived at his apartment complex in Queens, and one called him on the phone, saying that his car had been hit on the street.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 1, 2013

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. I heard there used to be a monorail running out to City Island. Whatever happened to it?

title: License for Operator of Chinatown Buses Is Pulled
description: The shutdown of the Fung Wah bus service between the Chinatown neighborhoods of Manhattan and Boston may have become permanent on Friday when federal officials revoked the companys license to operate.

title: White Gold in China
description: High Chinese market demands leads some to wonder if the only way to curb ivory poaching in Africa is to ban ivory.

title: Knicks Start Busy Stretch by Handling the Wizards
description: WASHINGTON  On a night of change and midseason tinkering, the Knicks leaned on their one constant and avenged one of their most humiliating defeats of the season.

title: Flacco and Baltimore Agree on a Long-Term Contract
description: Joe Flacco, who turned down a contract offer last summer because he believed he was worth more than the Baltimore Ravens were offering  and then led them to a Super Bowl championship  cashed in Friday when he agreed to terms on a new long-term deal, the team said.

title: Officer Stabbed in Head in 12 Gets Praise and a Promotion
description: Eder Loor approached the podium slowly on Friday, his gait tentative. Moments later, he raised a white-gloved hand as he was sworn in as a New York City police detective. Behind him, a crowd of officers, in freshly pressed blue uniforms, erupted in applause and rose to their feet. His wife wiped tears from her eyes.

title: Taking Cookies (and Hugs) to the Theater
description: Even on Sundays, the theater takes center stage for the Tony Award-winning producer Daryl Roth. With her newest production, the musical Kinky Boots, starting previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater this Sunday, a visit with its cast and crew is a priority. But Ms. Roth, 68, who has produced seven Pulitzer Prize-winning plays and serves as artistic director of her two Off Broadway theaters, also makes time for the other joys in her life, which include her grandchildren and her dog. She lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Steven, 71, the chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, and their 14-year-old Lowchen, Lucy.

title: Safety Board Calls Copter in East River Crash Overloaded
description: The pilot of a helicopter that crashed into the East River in 2011 failed to properly account for the weight of his passengers, three of whom died after being trapped underwater, federal safety officials concluded in a report released on Friday.

title: Down by 20, Nets Cant Quite Close the Gap
description: Deron Williams opened and closed Fridays game against Dallas playing like a motivated superstar, one the Mavericks openly coveted and the Nets paid handsomely to keep this past off-season.

title: The Lower East Side, in 1980 and 2010
description: Toward the end of 1979, Brian Rose and Edward Fausty began roaming the neighborhood, carrying a Japanese view camera attached to a tripod. Mr. Rose revisited the area 30 years later.

title: Former Dot-com Millionaire Guilty of Selling Drugs
description: At the height of dot-com mania 13 years ago, Jennifer Sultan and a few colleagues sold their small technology company for $70 million in stock and cash. She and her boyfriend rented a large house in the Hamptons for the summer and bought a spacious loft near Union Square.

title: A 30-Year Time Lapse of the Lower East Side
description: Toward the end of 1979, Brian Rose and Edward Fausty began roaming the Lower East Side of Manhattan with a Japanese view camera attached to a tripod. New York Citys fiscal crisis was a fresh memory, and gentrification had not yet arrived. Tenements seemed to burn daily. But the frontierlike nature of the neighborhood and the availability of cheap rent encouraged an explosion of creativity.

title: Guard Said She Was at Post Before Truck Killed Boy, 6
description: A school crossing guard who was not at an intersection in East Harlem when a truck hit and killed a 6-year-old boy had called into the police station just before the accident to report being on the job, the police said on Friday.

title: Something New for Yankees: Few Victories, Little Panic
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There may be nothing as meaningless as the results of spring training games, especially only one week into the exhibition schedule. And there is no proven correlation between wins and losses at this time of year and what happens in October, so Yankee fans do not need to panic. At least not yet.

title: Outside Box, Federal Judges Offer Addicts a Free Path
description: Federal judges around the country are teaming up with prosecutors to create special treatment programs for drug-addicted defendants who would otherwise face significant prison time, an effort intended to sidestep drug laws widely seen as inflexible and overly punitive.

title: Venezuelan Official Confirms Chvez Receiving Cancer Treatments
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez is receiving chemotherapy or radiation treatments in the aftermath of his most recent cancer surgery, a government official said for the first time on Friday.

title: Remember Misogyny?
description: If you spent any time in Manhattan during the 1980s, particularly on the Upper West Side, you are likely to recall a recurrent vignette of dissent  the presence of a thin, wiry woman with hair that made emphatic her seriousness, who colonized the sidewalks in what appeared to be a full-time avocation as a crusader against pornography and other forms of sexual degradation. To make her point, she would often have with her a blowup of a notorious Hustler cover that featured an image of a woman who had been plunged headfirst into a meat grinder. Her approach was hardly solicitous; she demanded of those who passed by, Sign the petition!

title: Battle for the Soul of a Park
description: In the grand dream of Hudson River Park, the five-mile greensward stretching down Manhattans West Side from 59th Street to Battery Place, Pier 40, a hulking structure at the foot of West Houston Street, was supposed to be a cash cow, providing millions of dollars annually in revenue from parking and commercial development.

title: Mets Publicist Embraces Social Media With Fervor and Occasional Typo
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Think of the stories Jay Horwitz could tell if he ever decided to write a memoir.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 2
description: NEWS To the growing outrage of international conservation groups and the embarrassment of Chinese law enforcement agencies, the international ivory trade is booming, with much of the smuggled ivory ending up as statuary and jewelry in Chinese showrooms and private collections. Critics say the Chinese government is not doing enough to stem the illicit ivory trade, which has exploded in the five years since conservationists and governments agreed to a program of limited ivory sales intended to stifle poaching and revive a centuries-old handicraft. In the past year, more than 32,000 elephants have been illegally killed, according to the Born Free Foundation, a wildlife organization, and conservationists say the vast majority of ivory sold in China is of questionable origin. Dan Levin reports from Puzhai, China.

title: Rising Star in Nascar Is Calm After Wild Crash
description: Mike and Janet Larson were sitting in the upper deck of the front-stretch grandstand at Daytona International Speedway last Saturday afternoon when they saw a 12-car crash in the final lap of a Nascar Nationwide Series race. The crash began almost right in front of them.

title: Right to Play Is a Victory for a Texas School
description: When he woke up Friday, Zachary Yoshor, 17, a senior at the Robert M. Beren Academy in Houston and a star player on the schools basketball team, said he was not nervous about the state semifinal game looming for his team that afternoon in Fort Worth.

title: Late Night With Ben Bernanke
description: The Federal Reserves chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, picked an unusual time to offer his most recent defense of the Feds campaign to stimulate the economy: 7 p.m. on a Friday night in San Francisco, 10 p.m. back home on the East Coast.

title: Division III Postseason Changes Create Long Wait Until Championship Game
description: David Hixon, the coach of second-ranked Amherst, had mixed emotions when he saw the draw for the Division III mens basketball tournament, which begins Saturday.

title: The Crime of His Childhood
description: On an October afternoon 40 years ago, on a beautiful block in Park Slope, Brooklyn, a crime occurred in a split second that was as permanent as it was cruel. Grown-ups tried to make sense of it, even use it as a cautionary tale for their children, but in the end, many just put it out of their minds. How could they not? It was just too awful, its lessons too hard to fathom.

title: N.H.L.s Request for Video Rights Creates Quandary for Olympics
description: Talks between the N.H.L. and the International Olympic Committee over whether the league will send its players next year to Sochi, Russia, hinge on one overarching issue: if the I.O.C. grants the N.H.L. concessions for shutting down its business at midseason, other leagues that send players to the Olympics may ask for the same.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE AMAZING SPIDER-MAN (2012) Five years after Spider-Man 3, the director Marc Webb rebooted the franchise with new stars  Andrew Garfield, above, as Peter Parker; Emma Stone as his girlfriend, Gwen Stacy; and Martin Sheen and Sally Field as Uncle Ben and Aunt May  and an updated origin story centered on a bioengineering company, Oscorp. And along comes a spider. The latest post-atomic-age Spider-Man has been updated with a skateboard and a hoodie, but its unclear whom he speaks to (beyond Sonys shareholders), and for what reason, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Garfield and Ms. Stone are by far the movies greatest assets and when theyre together on screen, they add warmth and a believable closeness to the industrial mix. Still, this Spider-Man feels like one of those unnecessary software versions, more Spider-Man 1.5 than Spider-Man reborn, she said. Spider-Mans ethos remains  with great power comes great responsibility  but these days you cant see his superhero heart and soul for his branding.

title: Philippine Leader Calls for Surrender of Group in Malaysia
description: HONG KONG  The Philippine president, Benigno S. Aquino III, called on Saturday for the surrender of an armed Muslim clan that took over a Malaysian village, making the plea a day after the group lost several members in a violent clash with Malaysian police officers.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Demands for a discussion over the recent execution of Muhammad Afzal, who was convicted in a deadly attack on Indias Parliament, rocked the state legislature on Friday, according to an IANS report on the NDTV Web site. The call for debate was initiated by the opposition Peoples Democratic Party, and it found support from the governing National Conference party in the state.

title: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Environmental Warning Fatigue Sets in
description: Record levels of industrial smog? A dwindling number of fish in the worlds oceans? A 4 Celsius warming in global temperatures by the end of the century?

title: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Piece Goods and Misty Irreverence
description: PARIS  Junya Watanabes shows are always held on Saturday morning, prompting the usual sullen greeting, Hello, and wheres the coffee? Mr. Watanabe provides. He also gave his customers a nice bunch of clothes along familiar Watanabe story lines. These included couture-shaped dresses and loose-back jackets that combined leather and tweed, motorcycle jackets mixed with knitting, and cute, low-riding patchwork jeans. Among the fresher looks were skimmy dresses made from oblong scraps of plaid wool and silk, and worn over black tights.

title: The Gun Report: March 2, 2013
description: March 1 marked the 19th anniversary of the shooting death of Ari Halberstam, a 16-year-old Brooklyn Yeshiva student, who was traveling by van on the Brooklyn Bridge with his fellow students when an anti-Semite whod been following them fired 18 bullets into the van, using a Cobray submachine gun and a Glock. Halberstam was killed. The gunman, Rashid Baz, admitted last year that he targeted the boys because they were Jews. The FBI classified the act as terrorism.

title: Viktor & Rolf: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Across-the-Board Cuts Take Effect, but Their Impact Is Not Immediately Felt
description: WASHINGTON  University officials, city managers, day care providers and others spent Saturday assessing how they would absorb their part of the across-the-board cuts in federal spending that began taking effect over the weekend.

title: A Farewell to Green
description: 12:08 p.m. | Updated |With the posting Friday evening of A Blogs Adieu, The New York Times shut down the Green blog, which, through 5,364 posts, had been an excellent aggregator of environmental news and analysis that didnt fit in the flow of conventional articles.

title: Self-destructive Europe
description: I just wanted to flag two important articles on Europe. First, Simon Wren-Lewis reminds us that while extreme austerity is being imposed on Europes periphery, the core has also pursued contractionary fiscal policies. Heres the IMFs estimate of the cyclically adjusted primary balance  a measure of what the non-interest budget balance would have been at full employment:

title: Israeli Premier Gets Extension to Form a Coalition but Faces Turmoil
description: JERUSALEM  Israels president on Saturday granted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu a two-week extension to form a governing coalition, a task complicated by mathematics and chemistry.

title: Viktor & Rolf in Black and White
description: PARIS  Continuing in the restrained direction of their last collection, the designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf presented a fall show on Saturday that was minimal on tricks, and also minimal on lengths. The only thing that caused a ruckus was the arrival of the actress Jessica Chastain in the front row.

title: Welfare for the Medical-Industrial Complex
description: Stephen Brills long piece about medical costs has brought forth a mixture of praise and annoyance from health-care economics experts, including Aaron Carroll and Uwe Reinhardt; theyve been screaming for years that our medical system charges too much, and so theyre both gratified and annoyed to see a major-media piece confirming what theyve been saying all along.

title: Sequestrations Impact
description: Virginias economy will be among the hardest hit by the federal governments $85 billion in spending cuts to military and domestic programs.

title: Mets Outfield Prospect Builds a Highlight Reel
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Though he has yet to play an inning of major league baseball for the Mets, Matt den Dekker has already begun to make a name for himself among the teams fans.

title: For Yankees Suzuki, Spring Challenges Include Alligators
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For each of his previous 12 years in major league baseball, Ichiro Suzuki made his spring training home in Peoria, Ariz., where the dry desert air allowed balls to carry, and his familys house made it a most comfortable experience.

title: Experts Want More Studies of Diets Role for the Heart
description: This is a watershed moment in the field of nutrition, medical experts say. For the first time, researchers have shown that a diet can have an effect as powerful as drugs in preventing what really matters to patients  heart attacks, and strokes and deaths from cardiovascular disease.

title: With Bernard Lagat
description: Bernard Lagat has been so successful on the track for so long that he has been able to delay running road races, a transition that Mo Farah of Britain and other middle-distance specialists have been making. In February, Lagat, 38, set an American indoor two-mile record at the Millrose Games, adding to his many national records. But days later, Lagat announced that he would run his first long-distance road race, the 13.1-mile NYC Half, on March 17. He spoke recently by telephone from his home in Tucson, where he trains with the distance runner Abdi Abdirahman. KEN BELSON

title: Pitchers Stare Is Menacing, but Fastball Is Feared More
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  It cannot be detected by a radar gun, and it would not make sense to a physicist. But to the sharpened eyes of a major league hitter, one pitchers 98-mile-per-hour fastball can behave much differently from anothers. And when that pitcher is Craig Kimbrel of the Atlanta Braves, it does not seem fair.

title: Variety: Takeaway Crossword
description: Administrivial Note Pad Alert! One letter of the alphabet has been removed from each clue every time it appears in the clue. If you remove this letter from the clues answer, the remaining letters will themselves spell a word, which is to be entered in the grid. For example, the clue Be a sni*ch would suggest Be a snitch with a missing T, leading to the answer TATTLE, which, with the Ts removed, would be entered in the grid as ALE. Every answer in the grid is a regular word or name except as indicated.

title: Francis Lieber and the Law of War
description: The philosopher and legal scholar Francis Lieber was born in 1798 in Germany, and as a young man was wounded in the final skirmishes of the Napoleonic wars. He emigrated to the United States in 1827, after twice being imprisoned by Prussian authorities for his pro-reform political activities. A respected jurist in his home country, he eventually became a professor at Columbia, a few years before the outbreak of the Civil War.

title: Two Afghan Boys Accidentally Killed by NATO Helicopter
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two boys out collecting firewood with their donkeys were killed by weapons fired from a NATO helicopter, Afghan and American military officials announced Saturday.

title: Nothing Mid About Gonzaga
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Trophies cover most of Mark Fews office. They rest behind the desk, on bookshelves, near the black leather couches and the photographs of Few with fishing rod in hand. When available space shrank, he simply lined them on the floor.

title: Coaches Who Have Been There Before
description: Thierry Henry flashed his Cheshire cat grin when asked about playing for a rookie coach.

title: Kerry Is Hoping to Nudge Egypt Toward Reforms
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry told Egypts political and business leaders on Saturday that it was urgent their country institute economic reforms and satisfy the conditions the International Monetary Fund has set for a $4.8 billion loan.

title: Veronique Leroy: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Chinese Hackers and Accusers
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Players May Again Reject N.H.L. Realignment Plan
description: For the second time in 14 months, the N.H.L. has drawn up a plan to realign its clubs and devise a new playoff format. It is quite possible that, for a second time, questions raised by the Players Association will prevent its implementation.

title: Hungary Tries a Dash of Taxes to Promote Healthier Eating Habits
description: BUDAPEST  Gizella Beres Devenyi, who works behind the cash register at the delicatessen Zena in a working-class neighborhood here, says it is easy to see Hungarys new salt tax at work.

title: For the Sabres, Vanek Is Behind the Wheel While Hodgson Navigates
description: Thomas Vanek drives the Buffalo bus.

title: Are There Any Europeans Left?
description: PARIS

title: Spill in China Underlines Environmental Concerns
description: HANDAN, China  The first warning came in the form of dead fish floating in a river.

title: Walking the Country as a Spiritual Quest
description: KEN ILGUNAS, who is 29 years old, arrived at the Gulf Coast town of Port Arthur, Tex., last month after hiking 1,700 miles from Alberta, Canada, crossing through the American heartland.
