description: BHANDARA, Maharashtra As the police investigate the deaths of three young sisters in a small village in central India, they are certain of one thing: someone killed the girls, ages 6, 9 and 11, sometime after they were last seen on Feb. 14 in Murmadi, in the Bhandara district of Maharashtra, and then dumped their bodies into a well in a rice field, where they were found on Feb. 16.

title: Givenchys Layers of Emotion
description: The Paris collections are giving women  and anyone who monitors fashion as closely as the Vatican and the N.F.L. draft  a lot to obsess over. Thats quite a change from Milan, where many of us were wishing the Italians could get their shows done in fewer days. (When people are discussing the schedule, and not the clothes, you know theres a problem.)

title: The Last All-Nighter
description: The first time I took Adderall I didnt think twice. It was 2007. I was in my last year at U.C.L.A., where I had come down with a bad case of senioritis, and found myself cramming for finals. I bought it from a gangly kid with yellow skin and bags under his eyes who lived in the dorms. His hair was stringy. There were papers on the floor and piles of clothes on all the furniture in the room. Above his desk was a poster of John Belushi from Animal House, chugging a bottle of Jack Daniels and wearing a sweatshirt that read COLLEGE.

title: Behind the Story: Nathaniel Rich on Kooky Train Travelers and Why He Always Shaves Before Reporting
description: Nathaniel Rich wrote a feature article in this past weekends Voyages issue about long-distance train travel. Rich is the author of the novel The Mayors Tongue; his second novel will be published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux this spring. Last year he wrote cover stories for the magazine about a Japanese scientist who studies jellyfish and the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans.

title: This Week in Small Business: Its On
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | March 4, 2013
description: Update: Mar. 5

title: Kerry Says Syrian Opposition Can Handle Military Aid
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the Syrian opposition is capable of properly handling the military support it receives.

title: Opinion Report: Payday Lenders
description: From the editorial page

title: Stella McCartney: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Sacai: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Q&A: Making a Phone-to-PC Bluetooth Connection
description: Q.

title: A Pale Reflection of Reality
description: MOSCOW  The press materials called it political theater. Last Friday through Sunday, three of the most important Russian political trials of the last decade were to be re-enacted in compressed form by people who had either taken part in them or might have taken part in them. Staged by the Swiss director Milo Rau, the Moscow Trials series was being performed at the Andrei Sakharov Museum and Public Center, itself a contested space. It would be filmed, for airing on television, presumably anywhere but in Russia, where a Western view of these trials could hardly be broadcast to a wide audience.

title: Temasek Increases Stake in Spanish Energy Concern
description: LONDON  Singapores sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings said on Monday that it had increased its stake in the Spanish energy company Repsol in a deal worth around 1 billion euros, or $1.3 billion.

title: Big Data Done Cheap
description: Some new products impress for what they say about the future. Win or lose, they show where the world is going with near certainty.

title: What Betting Markets Are Saying About the Next Pope
description: In Vatican City on Monday, the College of Cardinals will gather to decide on when to hold the papal conclave to select the next pope. There are no polls of the 115 cardinals who will vote in the conclave, and FiveThirtyEight is not making any predictions. But plenty of others are  notably, bookies and bettors.

title: Obama Announces 3 Cabinet Nominations
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday made three cabinet nominations  for budget, energy and environmental policy  hours before his first cabinet meeting of his second term.

title: Banks Find More Foreclosure Problems
description: Big banks discovered they wrongfully foreclosed on more than 700 military members during the housing crisis and seized homes from about two dozen other borrowers who were current on their mortgage payments, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in The New York Times. The banks  Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo  found the foreclosures after regulators ordered them to examine mortgages as part of a multibillion-dollar federal settlement, according to people with direct knowledge of the findings.

title: Green Groups Decry Sequesters Effects
description: Weeks after President Obama promised to develop sustainable energy and green jobs and to fight climate change  first in his second Inaugural Address, and then in his State of the Union Message  the realities of American politics have set in.

title: Monday Reading: Spring Breaks, From Budget-Oriented to Beyond
Hess to Sell Gas Stations as Part of a Shift in Strategy
description: 8:55 p.m. | Updated  The Hess truck may be going in a yard sale.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: How Rodman Wound Up in North Korea, and AMC Lurches Ahead in Ratings
description: Vice, a print magazine that is producing a TV newsmagazine that will debut on HBO in April, made international news by arranging a basketball game featuring flamboyant former N.B.A. player Dennis Rodman and three Harlem Globetrotters players before Kim Jong-un, in North Korea, Brian Stelter writes. Mr. Rodman and Vices film crew are the first Americans to meet the North Korean ruler since he inherited power from his father in 2011. Pundits debated on television and online over who gained more from the interaction, Vice or the North Korean government, and reporters at the State Department wanted to know why Mr. Rodman, who has returned to the United States, was not debriefed about his visit with Mr. Kim, whom he called a friend. Vice had no assurance that Mr. Kim would watch the game, but were familiar with his love of basketball, especially the Chicago Bulls.

title: Massacre of Syrian Soldiers in Iraq Raises Risk of Widening Conflict
description: BAGHDAD  More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq from rebel fighters along the border were killed on Monday in an attack by unidentified gunmen as the Iraqi military was transporting the soldiers back to Syria in a bus convoy, the Iraqi government said.

title: Sitting Pretty | The Poltrona Frau Museum
description: To coincide with its 100th anniversary, Poltrona Frau, the manufacturer known for its luxurious leather furniture, has officially inaugurated its museum in the central Italian town of Tolentino, its headquarters since the early 1960s. Designed by Michele De Lucchi, the Milan architect who was a key figure in radical design movements like Memphis, the Poltrona Frau Museum presents both the companys history and the processes involved in making its products.

title: Brits Off Broadway Adds Bull to Slate
description: Bull, a drama about office politics by the British playwright Mike Bartlett (The Cockfight Play), will have its New York premiere in the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, the theater is to announce on Monday. The play, which is to begin performances on April 25, recently completed a run at the Crucible Studio in Sheffield, England, where it received good reviews.

title: Calls to Charge Driver Grow After Couples Newborn Dies
description: Minutes before the crash, they were strangers inhabiting vastly different Brooklyns.

title: Heeeeeres Napoleon: Spielberg Developing Kubrick Script as TV Miniseries
description: While another collaboration between Stanley Kubrick and Steven Spielberg would seem to require a time machine, a Ouija board or some sort of interdimensional extraterrestrial monolith, plans are nonetheless underway for these two celebrated filmmakers to work together again.

title: The Gun Report: March 4, 2013
description: As these things go, the incident was prettybenign. In Des Moines, Iowa, a 13-year-old boy, Jesse Guevara, along with his friend Alec Osborn, were visiting a third friend at the friend s godfathers house. They found several guns that were loaded, and Guevara accidentally shot Osborn in the shoulder. The shooting was recounted in our February 25 Gun Report, linked to a lengthier account in the Des Moines Register. Our brief encapsulation ended by reporting that Osborn had been released from the hospital. And that appeared to be that.

title: American Wont Join South Korea Cabinet
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean-born American business executive who was nominated by President Park Geun-hye to be the minister of future creation and science withdrew on Monday, blaming political gridlock that has delayed his confirmation hearing in the National Assembly.

title: Winners of Hefty New Literary Prizes Announced
description: Yale University announced on Monday the inaugural winners of the Windham Campbell Prizes, which are given to writers for outstanding achievement in fiction, nonfiction and drama.

title: Giambattista Valli: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: What Were Reading
description: The Journal News: Some of the towns and villages north of New York City are experimenting with banning the disposable plastic bags that are common at grocery stores.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Fantasy Baseball: First Base Preview
description: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich Brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

title: Sustainable Seafood  Seas Optional
description: My colleagues at the Room for Debate blog have initiated a valuable discussion around this question:

title: A Growing Divide
description: As federal budget cuts begin, high productivity and low interest rates help corporations but not job seekers.

title: PMS Symptoms Linked to Diet
description: A 10-year study of more than 3,000 women has found that dietary iron may reduce the risk for premenstrual syndrome, while potassium intake may increase it.

title: CVC Hires Ex-C.E.O. of Lloyds Banking
description: LONDON  CVC Capital Partners, a European private equity firm, has tapped a former chief executive of the Lloyds Banking Group, Eric Daniels, to be a senior adviser for its banking team.

title: Wild Buzzer-Beater Leaves 2 Teams Celebrating
description: If you spent the weekend looking for a sports highlight fix, you did not have to search hard. On Sunday alone the highlights came fast and furious and from many of the usual suspects. You could have chosen LeBron James breaking the Knicks hearts  although yes, that has happened enough times to qualify as a dramatic series  or the Blackhawks pulling another victory out of thin air. You had Danica Patrick slamming into a wall. You could have gone back and replayed Rory McIlroy hitting a proverbial wall as he melted down at the Honda Classic and walked off the course.

title: New Programmer at Film Society Steps Down; Replacement Named
description: Robert Koehler, who last fall was named the year-round director of programming at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, is resigning that position, the organization said Monday. Taking over for him will be the critic and journalist Dennis Lim.

title: When Software Vendors Take Their Time
description: At the last meeting of the She Owns It business group, Susan Parker talked about the frustrating process of switching to new software to run her company, Bari Jay. After more than a year, the project, which was supposed to take three months, is still unfinished  although she hopes the new software will be live within a month. Although she likes the software, with hindsight she says that she would never work with this particular software development company again. But where does that leave her now?

title: Daily Report: Web Privacy Becomes a Business Imperative
description: Privacy is no longer just a regulatory headache, reports Somini Sengupta in Mondays New York Times. Increasingly, Internet companies are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.

title: Pregnant Without a Policy in Graduate School
description: Is a pregnant medical student  or a pregnant law or other graduate student  not a bad idea?

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Akris
description: I definitely think that the no makeup makeup look is around, said Diane Kendal of the trend on fall runways. Backstage at Akris, Kendals minimalist beauty look featured light foundation, M.A.C. Powder Blush in Tenderling on the apples of the cheeks, and nude lips. The one bit of glamour? The eyes, which were painted with grease shadows in a mix of brown and gray to give a dewy feel on the lids, lined with M.A.C. Pro Sculpting Cream in Coffee Walnut on the lash line, and finally veiled with finely netted bandeau, like a chic (and discreet) Zorro.

title: President Announces Choice for Budget Chief
description: WASHINGTON  In picking Sylvia Mathews Burwell to be his budget director, President Obama on Monday again enlisted a Clinton-era veteran for his economic team as it deals with fiscal and partisan challenges that make the earlier time seem like the good old days.

title: Miners in Australia Fired Over Harlem Shake Video
description: Several miners in Australia were fired from their jobs after filming a Harlem Shake video underground, a performance that the owners of the Agnew gold mine apparently considered unsafe, The Associated Press and Reuters reported.

title: A Boy Saved by Oskar Schindler: Memoir Will Tell the Story
description: Leon Leyson, one of youngest of the Jews saved by Oskar Schindler from the Holocaust, completed a memoir just before he died in January, and the book will be released in August, his publisher said on Monday.

title: Racist Incidents Stun Campus and Halt Classes at Oberlin
description: OBERLIN, Ohio  Oberlin College, known as much for ardent liberalism as for academic excellence, canceled classes on Monday and convened a day of solidarity after the latest in a monthlong string of what it called hate-related incidents and vandalism.

title: Street Style: Animal Inspired Clothing
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Feb. 25.

title: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: Kenyan Voters Speak
description: The Times's Jeffrey A. Gettleman talks with citizens about their election choices and hopes for the new term.

title: Image of the Day: March 4
Video of Cardinals Arriving to Choose Benedicts Successor
description: More than 100 cardinals from throughout the world arrived at Paul VI Hall in Rome on Monday to prepare for the conclave, the process used to select the successor to Pope Benedict XVI, who stepped down last week. Not all of the cardinals have yet arrived in Rome, officials said, so the date for the start of the conclave is not expected to immediately be set.

title: Buffett Picks His Bear for Annual Meeting
description: Warren E. Buffett has found his bear.

title: Chinas Wen Warns of Inequality and Vows to Continue Military Buildup
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China entered his final days in power on Tuesday with a warning that the nation remained troubled by divisions between the urban rich and rural poor and unbalanced economic growth, and he vowed that the government would continue building up its military, which received a 10.7 percent increase in spending for 2013.

title: Former Greek Defense Minister Convicted in Corruption Case
description: ATHENS  A former Greek defense minister, Akis Tsochatzopoulos, was convicted and sentenced on Monday to eight years in prison for concealing assets from the authorities. It was the second high-profile corruption conviction in a week in Greece, a country where prosecutions of senior political figures are very rare.

title: The Gambling Machine Puzzle
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by mathematician Nelson Blachman, who began his research and teaching career at the Underwater Sound Laboratory at Harvard University 70 years ago. Dr. Blachman continues to produce original mathematical research today, a feat of endurance made even more remarkable because of a quality rare among mathematicians: Dr. Blachman is blind.

title: For Flavor and Versatility, Add Bulgur
description: Ana Sortun, a Cambridge-based chef who loves the cuisines of the Eastern Mediterranean and Turkey in particular, was doing a cooking demonstration recently at the Worlds of Healthy Flavors retreat at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa, Calif., a collaborative effort between the institute, the Harvard School of Public Health and the foodservice industry. As she filled chard leaves with a mix of bulgur, sauted onions, hazelnuts, red pepper paste and dried mint she said: I think bulgur should be the next quinoa.

title: A Stealth Tax Subsidy for Business Faces New Scrutiny
description: The last time the nations tax code was overhauled, in 1986, Congress tried to end a big corporate giveaway.

title: In Doctors Account of Scene, Boys Blood Pooled in Street
description: Melanie M. Canon, a family doctor who lives and works in East Harlem, happened upon the scene last Thursday moments after a 6-year-old boy, Amar Diarrassouba, was struck by a turning truck and tried to save his life. She sent us this account.

title: Chinas Push to Cool Down Housing Raises Questions
description: Chinese shares fell the most in two years on Monday as the Shanghai stock exchanges property index tumbled 9.25 percent. Late on Friday, Chinas State Council had announced a new set of policies designed to cool down the housing market.

title: Ask Well: Exercises for Shoulder Pain
description: Question:

title: The Envelope, Please: Bryan Stromer
description: After getting accepted to college, I realized I didnt want to slow down. I wanted to explore my passions and interests.

title: Student Advocate Finds an Antidote to Senioritis
description: Getting accepted to Vanderbilt felt like crossing the finish line of a four-year marathon.

title: Whole Wheat Irish Soda Bread With Bulgur
description: If you have ever been to Ireland you have tasted soda bread, a moist, easy to make bread that is rich and nutty tasting when made with whole wheat flour. It is a very quick and easy bread to make as long as you are willing to get your hands sticky. When you pull the bread from the oven wrap it loosely in a kitchen towel and allow to cool. This softens the crust and makes it easier to cut.

title: Threes a Trend | Skirts and Sweaters
description: In Paris, designers modernized their approach to ladylike hemlines with skirts hitting just at the calf. Pairing them with bulky knits appeared fresh instead of frumpy.

title: Bulgur Bowl With Spinach, Mushrooms and Middle Eastern Nut and Spice Seasoning
description: This is a simple skillet supper, a bowl of bulgur topped with a savory mixture of mushrooms and spinach. It gets a final flourish of dukkah, a Middle Eastern seasoning made with toasted nuts (or in some places chickpea flour), seeds and spices that is as much a snack as it is a seasoning; a favorite way to eat dukkah is to dip vegetables or bread into olive oil and then into the dukkah. There are many versions of the mix. Ana Sortun, a chef at Oleana in Cambridge, Mass., and the author of Spices: Flavors of the Eastern Mediterranean, adds coconut to hers. The recipe for the dukkah makes more than you will need for this meal, but it keeps well (I keep mine in the freezer) and it is great to have on hand.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Bento Boxes

title: Tips for Disputing Credit Report Errors
description: Checking the accuracy of your credit report is important, given recent reports that 5 percent of consumers may have errors in their reports that can result in higher interest rates on a loan.

title: Northern Exposure
description: The essay that accompanies Simon Norfolks photographs of the northern lights in this past weekends Voyages issue was written by the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard. A beautiful, meditative piece, it suggests nothing of the controversy that surrounded the publication of Knausgaards six-volume autobiographical novel in Norway. Lauded by critics as a literary feat (the first volume appeared in English last summer), the book played less well among Knausgaards own family members. Part fiction, part memoir, Min Kamp, or My Struggle as it is known in English, included not just unflinching descriptions of his fathers alcoholism and grandmothers incontinence but also revealing details about his ex- and his current wife. Some took revenge (the ex made a radio documentary); others sued (the uncle succeeded in getting his family members names changed before publication). As The Guardian noted last March, the question of whether Knausgaard had crossed a line became a national obsession:

title: Viewing World War II Through a Soldiers Camera Lens
description: Tony Vaccaro wanted to become a foreign correspondent, but after being raised in Italy, he returned to the United States less than proficient in English. One of his teachers at Isaac E. Young High School in New Rochelle, N.Y., suggested he become a photographer instead. (He joined a camera club begun by his science teacher, Bertram L. Lewis.) He worked as a caddy to afford a $47.50 American-made Argus C2 camera, intent on taking it with him when he went to war.

title: Are You a Member of the Military Who Illegally Lost Your Home to Foreclosure?
description: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess have a shocking story in the Times today about how, in the course of their foreclosure review, the big bank servicing departments discovered they had foreclosed on at least 700 members of the military, in clear violation of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act.The story also reported that some two dozen homeowners lost their homes in foreclosure proceedings despite being current on their mortgages.(The story also describes, in damning detail, the pathetically weak settlement recently negotiated  if you can call it that  by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the nations top bank regulator.But lets leave that for another day.)

title: Cardinals Start to Ponder Subtleties of a Big Task
description: VATICAN CITY  Like first-year seminarians, they walked through the glass doors on Monday carrying briefcases. Some arrived in chauffeured cars and taxis. Wearing long black coats and red caps, they took their assigned places in maroon lecture-halls seats, flipped through the assigned reading, recited prayers and swore on the Bible to maintain rigorous secrecy about their task.

title: Monday Motorsports: Edwards Wins Phoenix Sprint Cup Race
description: Carl Edwards held off strong challenges by Jimmie Johnson and Denny Hamlin to win the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Phoenix International Raceway on Sunday.

title: Bond Giveaway
description: The Timess Louise Story on corporations that enjoy billions of dollars in tax-free financing.

title: Report Blames Climate Change for Extremes in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Climate change was a major driving force behind a string of extreme weather events that alternately scorched and soaked large sections of Australia in recent months, according to a report issued Monday by the governments Climate Commission.

title: Fortress of Solitude Musical to Open in Dallas
description: The Fortress of Solitude  a new musical which its composer, Michael Friedman, once described as a history of soul music on a particular block in Brooklyn  will have its world premiere in Dallas before landing closer to home, at the Public Theater in Manhattan.

title: Pro Lacrosse Team Hopes It Can Gain a Foothold
description: The owners of the New York Lizards, who had the second-lowest attendance in Major League Lacrosse last year, are hoping that playing games at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island will attract new fans.

title: New Estimates Question Savings from Farm Bills
description: Farm bills passed by the full Senate and the House Agriculture Committee in 2012 would cost billions more this year if they were enacted without changes, according to a new estimate from the Congressional Budget Office.

title: For a Hospice Pioneer, Still a Tough Call
description: Family, friends, colleagues and parishioners said goodbye to Paul Brenner on Monday. He served as the associate pastor of St. Marks Lutheran Church in San Francisco, where his funeral service was held.

title: False Modesty in Decline in European Bank Bonuses
description: European banks were asking for a slap when new rules on pay were unveiled last week. Just consider this years bonus round. Lower payouts had been predicted, reflecting the relative weakness of the business environment. In fact, pay for the average investment bank employee at Europes top four firms fell just 2 percent last year, to $313,000. Deferred awards cloud the picture, but theres little sign of pay restraint.

title: Ex-Governor Hopes a Lively House Race Is His Comeback Trail
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Mark Sanford, the former Republican governor of South Carolina, who turned the phrase hiking the Appalachian Trail into a euphemism for having an affair, sat in a coffee shop here on a recent morning and wept.

title: Restless Shareholders May Force Buffetts Hand on Dividends
description: Warren E. Buffetts stance against paying Berkshire Hathaway shareholders a dividend looks to be wearing thin.

title: Sundance Plans a Mini-Festival in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  The film festival arms race continues: Robert Redfords Sundance Institute, having established an offshoot of its signature Utah event in London, now plans to expand into the movie capital.

title: Return of the Romneys
description: Mitt Romney, and his wife, Ann, have had four months to reflect on the 2012 presidential campaign and what it all meant. But time doesnt always breed wisdom. In an interview with Chris Wallace of Fox News on Sunday, the couple seemed detached from reality.

title: The New Beltway Icebreaker: What Episode of House of Cards Are You On?
description: Welcome back to the House of Cards recap where Ashley Parker and David Carr chat about the media and political dimensions of the show. This week, episode four is under the microscope. You can catch up on recaps of episode one, two or three, as well, but please know spoilers are everywhere, so watch first, then read.

title: N.C.A.A. Advises on Sexual Orientation Issues
description: The N.C.A.A. released an 82-page guide Monday intended to help its constituents  administrators, coaches and students  navigate the broadening world of gay, lesbian and transgender athletes amid its myriad sports.

title: Developing Education Initiatives for Citys Young Mexican Immigrants
description: The numbers alone were stark and worrisome: About 41 percent of all Mexican immigrants 16 to 19 years old in New York City have dropped out of school, according to census statistics  more than double the rate of any other major immigrant group and more than four times the citys overall rate.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Kim Corrigan joined the New York office of Rosetta, part of the Publicis Groupe, in a new post, partner in the health care vertical. She had been executive vice president and group management director at the New York office of DraftFCB, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: The Higgs, From Theory to Reality
description: The long road to find the Higgs boson is littered with subatomic particle discoveries and canceled colliders, but it ends with a discovery and a theory validated nearly 50 years after the idea was born. (Related Article)

title: Samsungs New Smartphone Will Track Eyes to Scroll Pages
description: Samsungs next big smartphone, to be introduced this month, will have a strong focus on software. A person who has tried the phone, called the Galaxy S IV, described one feature as particularly new and exciting: Eye scrolling.

title: Being Human (Personal and Trivial)
description: Sorry about silence this morning, but I was actually trying to have a life, briefly. As some readers of my last Friday Night Music post might have guessed, I went to see Elephant Revival at Joes Pub Sunday. I uploaded a snippet (its an mp4) that I recorded on my smartphone; sorry, I dont have a YouTube channel, but if someone else wants to post it, feel free.

title: Craft Beers Larger Aspirations Cause a Stir
description: Time was, beer came in one size: whether bottle or can, the stuff inside measured a reliable 12 ounces. But walk into a craft-beer store these days and youll see shelf after shelf taken over by giants: 22-ounce bombers, 750-milliliter wine bottles, even three-liter jeroboams.

title: A Boston Building for People, Not Cars
description: The 44-unit apartment building with ground-floor storefronts, proposed for Bostons Allston neighborhood, is a fairly bold and modern design under development by the studio of Sebastian Mariscal, the architect. But the most radical thing about it is what is missing  parking.

title: Cockroaches at the European Commission
description: Ive written several times about cockroach ideas in economics  ideas that you try to flush away, but keep coming back. (Are cockroach ideas the same as zombie ideas? Not quite, I would say; I think of cockroach ideas as misconceptions held because the people holding them are just unaware of basic facts, while zombie ideas are held by people who refuse to acknowledge contrary evidence).

title: Biden and Netanyahu Stress Points of Unity in Speeches to Pro-Israel Group
description: WASHINGTON  The thundering ovations, slickly produced videos and legions of lawmakers were the same as ever. But something was missing as the American Israel Public Affairs Committee convened here this week for its annual conference: tension.

title: With Nieuwenhuis on Crutches, Mets Outfield Prospects Grow Dimmer
description: 2:33 p.m. | Updated A magnetic resonance imaging exam confirmed Kirk Nieuwenhuis has a bone bruise. He said he would be out about a week.

title: Houston, We Have an Opportunity (to Attract More Tourists)
description: A campaign to attract visitors to Houston has undergone a makeover, shifting from celebrities to people who are celebrated locally for achievement in the arts and cuisine.

title: Fill-In | Its a Worldwide Dance Craze, but Its Not the Real Harlem Shake
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article Its a Worldwide Dance Craze, but Its Not the Real Harlem Shake by Kia Gregory.

title: Ask Ben Brantley About London Theater
description: This week Ben Brantley, chief theater critic for The New York Times, will be reporting on the London theater scene. Among the shows hell be writing about are Ian Ricksons West End production of Harold Pinters Old Times, starring Rufus Sewell and Kristin Scott Thomas, and a revival of the Stephen Sondheim and George Furth musical Merrily We Roll Along at the Menier Chocolate Factory.

title: Rapping About Saving Money
description: Reagan Elkins, 19, of Chickasaw, Okla., has this advice for other young Americans: Save your clams.

title: Spurned Apartment Buyers Still Long for the One
description: Do you ever think about the ones that got away? Has time worn away their good looks? Are they being cared for and treated well?

title: Photos of The Moment | Giambattista Valli
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Dealing With the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
description: The pressure is only increasing on companies that get caught up in bribery cases, making it unlikely that efforts to soften United States laws will occur anytime soon.

title: A New Italian Spot? Youve Been There Before
description: For Italian-Americans, it was the moment when the meatballs got big.

title: We Are Definitely Continuing, Says Living Theater Executive
description: 2:09 p.m. | Updated The Living Theater closed its production of Here We Are, a spirited audience-participation piece by its founder, Judith Malina, on Saturday evening. But though the performance was the companys last at the Clinton Street theater that had been its home since 2007, Brad Burgess, the executive producer, said that recent reports that the esteemed experimental company was shutting down for good are incorrect.

title: Conjuring a Lively Night Downtown, Circa 1958
description: An early look at Carbone, the Italian-American restaurant that pays tribute to the abundance of a bygone era.

title: Why Carried Interest Is a Capital Gain
description: Steve Judge is the president and chief executive of the Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

title: Halloween on Coney Island
description: Oleg Boksner, also known as Alec Fly, shares a story of celebrating Halloween in the Russian neighborhoods on Coney Island.

title: Walkabout  3/4: Alaska Airlines Leads the Way, and BBC Sells Lonely Planet
description: Ahead of the Curve Alaska Airlines satellite guidance, a navigation technique that allows the carrier to reach towns like Petersburg, above, is now at the heart of the Federal Aviation Administrations plan to modernize the nations air-traffic system. (The New York Times)

title: Peplum People | A Fendi Film
description: Karl Lagerfeld's exclusive new video for Fendi, which features the brand's spring collection, stars Kati Nescher, Saskia De Braw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Giambattista Valli
description: The makeup artist Val Garland created a subtly futuristic eye for todays Giambattista Valli show. Using a M.A.C. No. 212 brush, she applied M.A.C. Pro Eye Gloss from the outer corner of the eye outward toward the temples, in a thick stripe that tapered toward the hairline, for a high-gloss finish. To add a bit of unexpected sparkle, Garland dabbed the same gloss lightly upon the cupids bow, following the M of the upper lip. You dont really see it, but its making the mouth feel fuller, she said.

title: Obamas All of the Above Energy and Environment Nominees
description: 7:06 p.m. | See addendum for sample of Twitter commentary |

title: Behind the Poster: Hit the Wall
description: Frank Fraver was 19 when he heard about an outbreak of violence between patrons of the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar on Christopher Street in the West Village, and New York City police over the course of several June and July nights in 1969.

title: What Economists Think About Raising the Minimum Wage
description: 5:29 p.m. | Updated  As Christina D. Romer wrote in a column on Sunday, there is some disagreement among economists about the prudence of raising the minimum wage. The Initiative on Global Markets at the University of Chicagos Booth School of Business recently queried a panel of 38 economic experts on the subject, and the responses were mixed, particularly about the effect on low-skilled job seekers. (Nancy Folbre mentioned this survey in passing in her weekly post; here are the fuller findings.)

title: Geneva Notebook: The Ruined Surprise Edition
description: GENEVA  Despite stern warnings to the media against premature release of information about Lamborghinis Veneno supercar before its official unveiling on Tuesday at the Geneva motor show, the surprise was ruined anyway.

title: Another Testing Ground for a Resurgent Nadal and His Injured Knee
description: Until only a week ago, Rafael Nadal still did not feel free to run to every ball. His left knee injury, which forced him to take a seven-month hiatus from competition, was still causing enough trouble that three tournaments into his return, he termed his status day to day.

title: Britain Takes On Brussels in Fight Over Bank Pay
description: BRUSSELS  The British finance minister, George Osborne, is expected Tuesday to urge his European Union counterparts to water down proposed rules restricting the size of bankers bonuses.

title: Miami Imam Sent Money to Terrorists, Jury Finds
description: MIAMI  The imam of a small mosque in a working-class neighborhood here was found guilty in federal court on Monday of providing thousands of dollars of support to the Pakistani Taliban.

title: Support for Israel
description: The Timess Mark Landler reports from the Aipac conference, where attendees offer thoughts on President Obamas scheduled visit to Israel.

title: Caesarean Deliveries Vary Widely, Study Finds
description: The rate of Caesarean deliveries, the most common operating-room procedure performed in the United States, varies drastically among hospitals across the country, a new study has found, ranging from 7 percent of all births at the hospital with the lowest share of Caesarean deliveries to 70 percent at the hospital with the highest rate.

title: Theaters Add Dates for Vandal, Belleville, Passion, Really Really
description: Three Off Broadway theaters announced on Monday that their current productions would add performances because of audience demand after positive reviews from critics, while a fourth theater, the Flea, said that its recent and highly praised production of The Vandal would return for an encore run later this month.

title: The Deficit Reduction We Deserve
description: Over the weekend, my colleague Jackie Calmes noted the peculiar reality that Washington has come close to achieving its short-term deficit reduction goals, but the real drivers of our long-term debt havent been touched:

title: Jeb Bushs Change of Heart
description: In late January, Jeb Bush wrote an op-ed for the Wall Street Journal in which he seemed to endorse a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants and criticized members of his own party who think illegal immigrants should return to their native countries and wait in line like everyone else. He argued that, for most illegal immigrants  those without a relative in the country and without access to the limited number of work-based visas  no line exists.

title: Wrinkles of the City: Cuba
description: Two artists, Jos Parl and JR, interviewed 25 of Havanas oldest residents for their 26-minute documentary.

title: In Berlin, a Protest to Keep What Remains of the Wall
description: BERLIN  In November 1989, the Berlin Wall opened, and soon after was being torn to pieces by jubilant crowds from both sides. Almost a quarter of a century later, Berliners again took to the streets over the wall  only this time to protect what is left of it.

title: Herding a Photo Crew, and Swimsuit Models, on 7 Continents
description: I NEVER stepped foot on a plane until I was a freshman in college. But once I took a trip to Chicago on a plane, I never wanted to stop flying. Ive worked on the last 14 issues of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, and Ive been very fortunate to see most of the world. I generally fly in business class, but occasionally coach. In my life outside of work, I seem to always fly coach. Nothing much bothers me, and thats really helpful because flying with a crew and models can be an adventure.

title: Canseco, a Former Steroid User, Backs Ban on Stimulant in Diet Pills
description: ALBANY  He was a head taller than any of the elected officials in the room. He wore a bedazzling pinstripe sport coat and sunglasses. And he absolutely did not want to talk about the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Saint Laurent Show Produces Conflict, Both the Usual and Bizarre
description: Here are some of the things overheard on my way out of the Saint Laurent show Monday night at the Grand Palais, while being trampled by photographers who were trying to get a shot of Catherine Deneuve.

title: Photos of The Moment | Stella McCartney
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bumpy Start for a Court Cloaked in Grandeur
description: Sandra Day OConnor or, as she likes to call herself, the Fwotsc  the First Woman on the Supreme Court  is the author of one wonderful book: Lazy B,  an evocative memoir about growing up among old-time, long-suffering, good-natured cowboys on a cattle ranch on the Arizona-New Mexico border. Written with her brother, H. Alan Day, that book not only did a magical job of conjuring an isolated and now vanishing world of big skies and wide-open plains, but it also underscored how the frontier values of her childhood  self-reliance, competence and dependability  shaped her pragmatic judicial philosophy.

title: Omega-3s May Lead to Healthier Babies
description: Pregnant women who took daily supplements of DHA, a type of omega-3 fatty acid, had longer gestations, bigger babies and fewer early preterm births, according to a new clinical trial.

title: Malhotra and Canucks Remain at Odds
description: Weeks after his season was ended when Vancouver management placed him on injured reserve and seemed to declare his career over, Manny Malhotra and Canucks General Manager Mike Gillis seemed to be on entirely different wavelengths.

title: A Poet at the French Laundry
description: Marie Howe, the state poet for New York and the author of such books as What the Living Do, specializes in vibrant, bracing, haunting work that stops you in your tracks. Ms. Howe, 62, lives in Manhattan; she spoke about the lyrical and occasionally comic role food has played in her life.

title: Xi
description: Joe Wong, a Chinese-American comedian, spoke about the common mispronunciations and misinterpretations of his family's last name of "Xi."

title: Chinese Firecrackers
description: Joe Wong, a Chinese-American comedian, shared a story of setting off fireworks inside his family's home.

title: Elliott Calls Hess Plan Incomplete and Lacking Accountability
description: Despite the multitude of proposals that the Hess Corporation unveiled on Monday to unlock its shareholder value, it appears that the oil companys most outspoken investor isnt satisfied.

title: Clip: 'Stoker'
description: A scene from "Stoker," directed by Park Chan-wook.

title: Saint Laurent: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: A Fast Start for Lucky Guy on Broadway
description: The new Tom Hanks play Lucky Guy posted some big box office numbers by Broadway standards in its first weekend, as did the long-running musical Mary Poppins during its final week of performances, according to ticket sales data released on Monday by the Broadway League of theater owners and producers.

title: The 911 at 50: More Power, Performance and a Higher Price
description: GENEVA  The first Porsche 911, introduced in 1963, boasted 128 horsepower.

title: The Right to (Look for) Work
description: Arizonas crudely drafted and unconstitutional immigration law, already battered in its journey through the federal courts, had yet another setback today. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled that its provisions forbidding day laborers to look for work violate the First Amendment.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, Syria, Pakistan and Kashmir.

title: Eight Teams Use Franchise Tag
description: Just eight N.F.L. teams used their franchise tags by the Monday afternoon deadline, a steep drop from the 21 players who were tagged last season. The decline is likely an indication that even with a modest rise in the salary cap this year, most teams  many of which have gone on a wave of restructuring contracts in recent days to create cap space  found it too expensive to use the tag on any but the most critical players. This came a year after tag numbers that were reduced from the pre-lockout years were considered more palatable.

title: For Daring Yankees G.M., Sky Diving Proves Undoing
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Brian Cashman has often said that being the general manager of the Yankees is much harder than any of the high-altitude, thrill-seeking challenges he has undertaken in recent years.

title: Independent Women Celebrate Genres That Never Went Away
description: From a distance they looked polite, the attendees of the Indie Pop Prom, which took over 285 Kent on Thursday night. Most of the young women wore shimmery dresses, most of the young men had on suits that could have used a little tailoring. You couldnt turn your head in any one direction without spying a tiara clinging to a head of hair.

title: Improving Security Checks to Help the Disabled
description: THERE is clearly no good security purpose served in traumatizing a 3-year-old girl in a wheelchair and upsetting her parents at an airport security checkpoint. Having a security agent take away the crying childs beloved stuffed doll while the mother records it all on her smartphone can lead to what the Transportation Security Administration, in an apology to the family, gingerly referred to as an unfortunate incident.

title: Singing as if Prizes Depended on It
description: A singing competition is no ideal biosphere for music to flourish.

title: Albums by Kris Davis and Ingrid Laubrock
description: INGRID LAUBROCK ANTI-HOUSE

title: Hunting the Higgs and a Diet Weve Grown to Love
description: The human story behind the search for the hidden fabric of the universe and the Mediterranean diet  an old standby, back in the the news.

title: The Roving Runner: Theres the Steeple
description: Pleasing scenery can punch up a routine run, and one recent Sunday I was treated to a majestic view of the Calvary-St. Georges Episcopal Church at Park Avenue and East 21st Street.

title: Last Dances, Celebrating Last Tour
description: The joy of self-congratulation filled the Barclays Center on Sunday night, where Swedish House Mafia was playing the penultimate New York City show of its One Last Tour. For Swedish House Mafia  the disc jockeys and producers Axwell, Sebastian Ingrosso and Steve Angello, of Stockholm  it was one of four arena-size valedictory shows in New York City, on the way to a final farewell on March 15 at the Ultra Music Festival in Miami.

title: (Real) Cats on Broadway
description: Meet the felines that could play the part of Holly Golightlys cat in the coming production of Breakfast at Tiffanys.

title: For Manchester United and Real Madrid, a Cordial Clash
description: MANCHESTER, England  The emotion around this city ahead of Tuesdays Champions League match between Manchester United and Real Madrid is every bit as intense as the feeling outside White Hart Lane on Sunday, when Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur faced off in the North London derby. That doesnt mean, however, that there is a similar amount of nastiness.

title: Maybe Stuffy, Certainly Sumptuous
description: Orchestras everywhere these days are feeling pressure to find new ways of reaching audiences, to loosen up stuffy concert protocols and, especially, to enliven programming.

title: Urk, Charlie Rose Edition
description: Well, well see how it comes out after editing, but I feel that I just had my Denver debate moment: I was tired, cranky, and unready for the blizzard of misleading factoids and diversionary stuff (In 1997 you said that the aging population was a big problem! When Social Security was founded life expectancy was only 62!) Oh, and I wasnt prepared for Joe Scarboroughs slipperiness about what he actually advocates (hes for more spending in the near term? Who knew?)

title: Back and Forth Along an Ancient Trade Route
description: The Mogao caves near the oasis of Dunhuang, in the deserts of the northwestern Chinese province of Gansu, are one of the worlds great sites of Buddhist art. By a junction of the ancient Silk Road, they are testament to Chinas engagement with cultures to its west. Silk Road, the dance drama presented by the China Gansu Dance Theater at the David H. Koch Theater last week, is an example of the specific way that some Chinese artists can turn their great culture into kitsch.

title: Photos of Oberlin College Students Rallying Against Hate Incidents
description: As my colleague Richard Prez-Pea reports, Oberlin College in Ohio canceled classes Monday for a day of solidarity after a person wearing what appeared to be a Ku Klux Klan-style white hood and robe was spotted on campus early Monday near the colleges Afrikan Heritage House.

title: The Daily Do | Stella McCartney
description: Armed in a voluminous overcoat with pinstripes and baseball cap, the Stella McCartney woman is unleashing her inner tomboy for fall. The borrowed from the boy look is complete with hair that requires zero effort  a simple low ponytail. The message in hair this week is: the less maintenance, the better.

title: Like Herding Cats? Well, Try It on Broadway
description: Four days before previews, the cast and crew of the new Broadway version of Breakfast at Tiffanys were putting the finishing touches on the shows blocking, lighting and costumes. But on this final day of February, there remained one gaping hole: the director still hadnt cast the role of Holly Golightlys cat.

title: Scaling Everest and Conquering More Peaks
description: The six unaccompanied Sonatas and Partitas for violin that Bach composed during the first two decades of the 18th century have long represented an Everest that every serious violinist feels compelled to climb. The challenges are considerable, not least because Bach provides few explicit interpretive directions. And for some players, Bachs monumental set is less a peak to be surmounted than a journey that warrants return excursions and encourages consideration of manifold paths.

title: Photo Replay: March 4
description: A day of races  dogs in Alaska, bikes in France  and Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman before his painful landing in Florida.

title: Justices to Take Up Case on Generic Drug Makers Liability
description: The injuries that Karen Bartlett suffered after taking a mild pain pill are enough to make anyone squeamish.

title: Meanwhile, From Alan Blinder
description: Joe Scarboroughs accuracy deficit.

title: Senate Judiciary Committee Likely to Vote on Bipartisan Guns Bill
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote Thursday on a bipartisan gun safety measure designed to curb illegal gun trafficking and purchasing.

title: Elite Status on Airlines Loses Some of Its Appeal
description: Travelers with elite status in an airlines frequent-flier program used to be rewarded with perks unavailable to the masses, like access to better seats, priority boarding and faster security lines.

title: The Bible on History Reaches 13.1 Million Viewers
description: The record pace being set by cable programming continued Sunday night as The Bible, a series on the History network, reached 13.1 million viewers, the biggest audience for an entertainment show on cable television this year.

title: Free Access to Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Breast Cancer Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring a Force of Nature, in Computers and Networks
description: As a brilliant Israeli-born math student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the 1960s, Danny Cohen was known as a force of nature. And when he learned that Ivan Sutherland, the inventor of the seminal Sketchpad computer interface system, was teaching a small graduate seminar on computer graphics at Harvard, he was determined to take the course.

title: Czech Senate Accuses Outgoing President of High Treason
description: The Czech Senate voted on Monday to accuse the outgoing president, Vaclav Klaus, of high treason. The vote was a largely symbolic rebuke of Mr. Klaus, a vociferous euroskeptic who has often polarized Czech society.

title: Monitoring Juveniles
description: To the Editor:

title: Inequity on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Hip Replacement Device
description: To the Editor:

title: Stoker Storyboards
description: A look at storyboards for a scene from Stoker, with commentary from Park Chan-wook.

title: Jeb Bush Appears to Support Middle Ground on Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants
description: As Congressional Republicans stake out an approach to overhauling the nations immigration system, a high-profile voice has emerged in support of a middle-ground option for the 11 million immigrants already in the country illegally.

title: ABC Networks Will Offer Guarantees to Advertisers Across Platforms
description: The Walt Disney Company will take a significant step toward equalizing the business of advertising on television and online this spring when three of the networks owned by the company, ABC, ABC Family and ESPN, offer advertisers guarantees for video programming distributed both on television and online.

title: Taking Comfort in Looser Tailoring
description: PARIS

title: Collision Course
description: It was the longest, most costly manhunt in science for an elusive particle that was said to be key to the workings of the universe. For a generation of physicists, it was an appointment with history.

title: Kenzo Is Feeling Young Again
description: PARIS

title: Israelis Divided Over Separate Bus Lines for Arabs and Jews in Occupied West Bank
description: Israels transportation ministry introduced Monday what it billed as improved service for nearly 30,000 Palestinians who live under Israeli military occupation in the West Bank and commute to work daily in Israel: two new bus lines designated for their use.

title: Eight Seek to Be Los Angeles Mayor
description: LOS ANGELES  With the mayors office up for grabs for the first time in nearly a decade, voters here will go to the polls Tuesday in the first step to choose a successor to Antonio R. Villaraigosa. But the mayoral primary is drawing far less enthusiasm than the election eight years ago, when Mr. Villaraigosa rode a wave of enthusiasm and became the citys first Latino mayor in more than a century.

title: Fearing Deluge of Litigation, Supreme Court Works the Floodgates
description: WASHINGTON  February was flood season at the Supreme Court.

title: Bondholders and Mexico Glass Maker Reach Deal
description: MEXICO CITY  The giant Monterrey glass maker Vitro said Monday that it had reached an agreement with bondholders, ending a dispute among powerful financiers that had ricocheted between Mexican and American courts.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Microsoft Backs Off, and YouTubes TV Dollars
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Chinas Premier Admits Failings, but Defends Image
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China, well known for baring his emotions in public, has displayed a blend of defeatism and defensiveness as he winds down his decade in office. During a visit last month to a Muslim neighborhood here, Mr. Wen lamented that he fell short in some tasks to improve peoples livelihoods. In my heart I feel guilty and constantly blame myself, he said.

title: Virginia Pastor Sentenced for Aiding Parental Kidnapping
description: A Virginia pastor who said that his actions flow out of my faith in Jesus, was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison for abetting the international parental kidnapping of a girl in a high-profile case involving a same-sex union and the condemnation of homosexuality by conservative Christians.

title: Glossary: A Guide for the Perplexed
description: ATOMS The basic units of ordinary matter consist of one or more electrons circling a tiny, dense nucleus of protons and neutrons.

title: Read On: Books About the Higgs
description: Some recommended reading, with comments from Dennis Overbye.

title: Particle Physicists in U.S. Worry About Being Left Behind
description: Are the glory days of American physics over?

title: All Signs Point to Higgs, but Scientific Certainty Is a Waiting Game
description: In their bones, physicists feel it is the long-lost Higgs boson, but in science, feelings take second place to data. So these same physicists admit that it will take more work and analysis before they will have the cold numbers that clinch the case that the new particle announced on July 4 last year is in fact the exact boson first predicted by Peter Higgs and others in 1964 to be the arbiter of mass and cosmic diversity. Personally, I have no problems calling this a Higgs boson, said Joe Incandela, a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and spokesman, or leader, of one of the teams, known as CMS, that reported the new particle last July. If its not, I wont mind eating my words, because it would be so much more interesting.

title: Chasing the Higgs
description: Meyrin, Switzerland  Vivek Sharma missed his daughter.

title: Texans Rebut Gov. Rick Perry on Expansion of Medicaid
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Hundreds of activists and uninsured Texans plan to rally at the steps of the Capitol here Tuesday, increasing the pressure on Gov. Rick Perry and other Republican leaders to switch their stance on expanding Medicaid, a major provision of President Obamas health care overhaul.

title: Mississippi: Candidate Beaten and Burned, Family Says
description: A mayoral candidate in Clarksdale was beaten and burned before his body was found by a river levee last week, his family said Sunday. The authorities have charged Lawrence Reed, 22, with murder in the death of Marco McMillian, 34, but they have not released the cause of death pending toxicology tests. We feel that this was not a random act of violence based on the condition of the body when it was found, Mr. McMillians family said in a statement.

title: Obama Faces Political Risks in Emphasizing Effects of Spending Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  As the nations top Democrat, President Obama has a clear imperative: to ratchet up pressure on Republicans for across-the-board spending cuts by using the power of his office to dramatize the impact on families, businesses and the military.

title: Fire in Senegal Kills Child Beggars Trapped in House
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A childs sandal, a charred begging bowl, some fire-singed tin plates. Little else but cinders remained Monday of the house here where 60 children were crammed in by a Muslim holy man to study the Koran  and beg.

title: Heinz Sale Could Yield a Big Payday for Chief
description: How will William R. Johnson console himself if hes dismissed as H.J. Heinzs chief executive following the ketchup titans sale to Warren E. Buffett and a Brazilian investment firm?

title: Come Home, America
description: SAN DIEGO

title: Geneva Notebook: Heavy Hauler Edition
description: GENEVA  One of the faster-growing segments in todays transportation industry is commercial vans, like the handy new Transit and Transit Connect vehicles made by Ford. At this years Geneva auto show Volkswagen reveals it is a hand-raiser in the segment also, with its e-Co-Motion concept.

title: African Trial of H.I.V. Drugs Fails
description: Scientists on Monday reported failure in a large African trial of three different ways to protect women against H.I.V.

title: Debate Over Guns Now Colors a Buyout Bid
description: A takeover. Private equity. Politics. And guns.

title: In Diverse City, Audiences Where Every Joke Translates
description: In the Bronx you hear that old side-splitter from Zambia about the reluctant debtor trying his best to hide from the neighborhood loan shark behind the short curtain that divides traditional one-room homes, his toes poking out.

title: The Effects of the Federal Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Backs Consumers in Unlocking of Cellphones
description: WASHINGTON  For a decade consumers have been able to keep their cellphone numbers even if they switched their wireless carriers. On Monday, the Obama administration and the Federal Communications Commission said consumers should also be able to switch carriers and keep their actual phones.

title: High Hopes for Cuban Baseball, but Challenges Ahead
description: HAVANA  On Sunday, the morning after Cubas 5-2 triumph against Brazil in Fukuoka, Japan, its opening game in this years World Baseball Classic, Sigfredo Barros ventured to the tree-lined Central Park here to partake in the musings of La Pea del Parque Central, a group of men who gather each day to debate baseball.

title: A Liberal Party Faces Inquiries Without End
description: It is a backhanded tribute to the power of the left-leaning Working Families Party that it keeps being subjected to the legal equivalent of a full-body scan.

title: Prosecution Rests in Cannibalism Case; Defense Asks for Officers Acquittal
description: After offering grisly images and revealing Internet searches into evidence, federal prosecutors in Manhattan rested their case on Monday in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York City police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women.

title: Inquiry on C.I.A. Detentions to Be Unveiled
description: A United Nations investigator whose report on the Central Intelligence Agencys use of secret detentions and interrogation techniques is to be released on Tuesday called on the United States to publicly account for the policy and said that failure to prosecute those responsible would breach international law. The investigator, Ben Emmerson, whose report was to be presented to the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva, added that although President Obama had clearly repudiated the unlawful actions carried out by the Bush-era C.I.A., many of the facts remain classified and no public official has been brought to justice. Mr. Emmerson, a British human rights lawyer working for the United Nations, also called for the publication of a report by the Senate Intelligence Committee on rendition and interrogation programs to the fullest extent possible. The C.I.A. declined to comment.

title: F.D.A. Panel Advises Against Two Medicines to Treat Hot Flashes
description: Menopausal women looking for an approved alternative to hormones to treat hot flashes will probably not be getting immediate relief.

title: Mali: More Weight to Reports of Militants Death
description: On Monday, there were further indications that Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, a leader of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, had been killed last week in northern Mali, in the Adrar des Ifoghas mountains, where French and Chadian troops were hunting down Islamist fighters. A Mauritanian news Web site, Sahara Media, which has close contacts with Abu Zeids group, cited an Islamist source as confirming that he had been killed in a French airstrike. But the same unnamed Islamist source denied reports of the death of Mokhtar Belmokhtar, another militant leader, who Chads military said had been killed by its soldiers in Mali last week. The source claimed that Mr. Belmokhtar was alive and operating to the southwest, close to the Malian town of Gao. Frances chief of the defense staff, Adm. douard Guillaud, told Europe 1 radio Monday morning that it was probable that Abu Zeid had been killed. It is likely, but only likely, he said. We dont have any certainty for the moment. It would be good news. Abu Zeid is said to have abducted more than 20 Western hostages since 2008 for ransom, some of which went to Al Qaeda. He is believed to have killed a British hostage, Edwin Dyer, in 2009, and a 78-year-old Frenchman, Michel Germaneau, in 2010.

title: Speaking Fees Bring Booker $1 Million; He Says He Kept Very Little of It, if Any
description: NEWARK  Mayor Cory A. Booker has earned about $1 million from public speaking engagements during his seven years in office, as he has built his position at City Hall into a national brand.

title: Senate Report Said to Fault JPMorgan
description: While a trader known as the London whale has come to represent a multibillion-dollar blowup at JPMorgan Chase, Congressional investigators have discovered that the problems involved more senior levels of the nations largest bank.

title: Residents Sue FreshDirect Over Move to the Bronx
description: After months of protesting FreshDirects move to the Bronx, a coalition of residents and community groups took their fight to a Bronx courtroom on Monday to accuse New York City officials of systematically understating the traffic problems and other impacts on their neighborhoods.

title: Dont Touch That Remote: TV Pilots Turn to Net, Not Networks
description: In the television pilot that Cheyenne Jackson taped recently, he played an aggressive young news anchor whose ascendancy threatened an older colleague. It was a fitting metaphor for the industry itself, because while Mr. Jackson had taped pilots for ABC, NBC and USA before, this was his first time doing one for a new challenger to those alphabet networks: Amazon.com.

title: Egypt Needs to Act
description: President Obamas decision to provide $250 million in aid to Egypt is a vote of confidence in a country that is critical to stability in the region but is also teetering on the edge of economic disaster. It is now up to Egypts government  and its opponents  to create the political and economic consensus that can leverage the American money to turn around their failing state.

title: Father Gets 5 to 15 Years in the Death of a Baby Girl
description: A Chinese immigrant convicted last month of manslaughter in the death of his 2-month-old daughter was sentenced on Monday to 5 to 15 years in prison.

title: A First Amendment Storm
description: House Republicans and Democrats do not agree on much these days, but they managed to join together last month to breach the proper separation between church and state. By a 354-to-72 vote, the House approved a measure sponsored by Representatives Christopher Smith, a New Jersey Republican, and Grace Meng, a New York Democrat, that would authorize the Federal Emergency Management Agency to make direct grants to churches, mosques, synagogues and other houses of worship without regard to the religious character of the facility or the primary religious use of the facility.

title: Caught in North Korea, Sold in China, Crabs Knit Two Economies
description: YANJI, China  At the Red Sun restaurant, a short-order joint on Crab and Beer Streets, live crabs with plump legs wriggle in a cooled tank, fresh from the North Korean coast just two and a half hours away by road.

title: Long Stuck in Obscurity, Bay Bridge Will Go From Drab Gray to Glowing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For decades the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge has been considered, when it is considered at all, as a headache for commuters and a place not to be in an earthquake.

title: The Intriguing Case of a Baby Cured of H.I.V.
description: Doctors have apparently cured a baby infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, with an aggressive treatment of drugs starting a day after the baby was born. If confirmed by further analysis, this would be the first time a person has been cured with simple drug treatments, making a lifetime of antiviral therapy unnecessary.

title: Timid Use of the Pardon Power
description: Last week, President Obama pardoned 17 people who had been convicted of felonies. An Na Peng, a Chinese citizen living in Hawaii, is the first person convicted of an immigration crime to be pardoned in many years. With the pardon, she can now become an American citizen. Lynn Marie Stanek, convicted in a minor drug deal, told her Oregon newspaper that the pardon would allow her to move beyond my past in a tangible, legal and personally meaningful way.

title: Cabinet Picks Could Take On Climate Policy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday named two people to his cabinet who will be charged with making good on his threat to use the powers of the executive branch to tackle climate change and energy policy if Congress does not act quickly.

title: Big Shot on Campus, and Everywhere, After Buzzer-Beater
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Out of breath and strength, but not luck and determination, she pushed herself through the curves, up craggy paths and past tree-lined corridors. She was 14.

title: Old Homosexuality Laws Still Hang Over Many in Germany
description: BERLIN  Klaus Born vividly recalls his first brush with the law, which took place along a quiet street in West Berlin in the 1960s, when being gay carried a prison sentence on both sides of the Berlin Wall.

title: Maj. Thomas C. Griffin, Doolittle Raider, Dies at 96

title: Donald Glaser, Nobel Winner in Physics, Dies at 86
description: Donald A. Glaser, who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1960 for inventing, at 25, an ingenious device called the bubble chamber to trace the paths of subatomic particles, died on Thursday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 86.

In effect, the statement said there were no environmental impediments that would prevent President Obama from approving the pipeline.

Im also impressed that Dr. Bain has taken the time to learn the art of constructing American-style crossword puzzles (he lives and works in South Africa), and because he talks to the animals, so to speak, I would not be surprised if three of the theme entries in todays puzzle were inspired by his chosen profession.

title: Venezuela: Chvezs Condition Worsens, Official Says
description: President Hugo Chvez has taken a sharp turn for the worse, nearly 12 weeks after undergoing cancer surgery, a government official said Monday. There is a worsening of the respiratory function related to the state of immunodepression corresponding to his clinical situation, said Information Minister Ernesto Villegas in a 10 p.m. broadcast. He added that Mr. Chvez was suffering from a new and severe infection. Officials previously said the president had overcome a lung infection, and it was not clear from the statement whether the new infection was also in the lungs. Mr. Villegas said Mr. Chvez had been receiving chemotherapy of strong impact and characterized his condition as very delicate. Mondays health update was one of the bleakest since Mr. Chvezs surgery.

title: One Detroit Prospers as the Other Struggles
description: Private industry is blooming in Detroit, even as the citys municipal finances have descended into wreckage.

description: DETROIT  Private industry is blooming here, even as the citys finances have descended into wreckage.

title: Bobby Rogers, Sang in the Miracles, Dies at 73
description: Bobby Rogers, who was born on the same day in the same Detroit hospital as the Motown crooner Smokey Robinson, with whom he harmonized in high school and eventually in the Hall of Fame singing group the Miracles, died on Sunday in Southfield, Mich. He was 73.

title: John Wilpers Dies at 93; Captured Tojo
description: John Wilpers, the last known surviving member of a team of Army intelligence officers who captured the former Japanese prime minister Hideki Tojo after World War II, foiling his attempted suicide so he could be brought to trial for his role in the attack on Pearl Harbor and other war crimes, died on Thursday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 93.

title: Real Madrid Alights, and City Shifts to Edge of Its Seat
description: MANCHESTER, England  The white scarves of Real Madrid were everywhere Monday as Spanish fans buzzed around St. Peters Square. Latecomers looking for lodging, though, were out of luck; there was nary a room to be had in the city. And out near Old Trafford, a pair of drivers idling at a red light on Sir Matt Busby Way waved over two ticket scalpers before sending them back almost immediately after hearing the asking prices for tickets to the game everyone is talking about.

title: Lax Policing of Doctor and Pharmacy Conflicts Is Found in Medicare Coverage Decisions
description: WASHINGTON  Deciding which drugs will be covered by Medicare can influence huge amounts of spending, but government officials do little to police conflict of interest among doctors and pharmacists who make those decisions, federal investigators said Monday.

title: Russias Concerns About Afghanistan After NATO
description: As the United States winds down its combat mission in Afghanistan, Russia is looking on, not with Schadenfreude but with extreme concern.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2010) Michael Nyqvist stars as a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Sven-Bertil Taube) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier. Noomi Rapace, above with Mr. Nyqvist, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery in this original Swedish film adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by Niels Arden Oplev. Though Ms. Rapace is a fine professional scowler, with cheekbones that thrust like knives and a pout thats mostly pucker, she tends to register as an intriguing idea instead of a thoroughly realized character, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She more or less looks the part that the filmmakers dont let her fully play. Ms. Dargis added: The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo was originally published as Men Who Hate Women, which apparently wasnt sexy enough for English-language bookshelves. The title change certainly spices things up, no matter how commonplace body art is, at least outside of Stockholm, and it plays down its overarching theme, which the movie only does further. Just as significant is the substitution in the title of girl for women, a categorical displacement (and diminution) that also shifts the emphasis from the crime (and criminals) and places it on Salanders slender back. Its an attractive back in the movie, as is the tattoo adorning it, even if, like all the prettily photographed winter landscapes, the dragon covers up something the filmmakers seem loath to reveal and simultaneously eager to exploit.

title: Brahmaputra Dams Promise Prosperity But at a Big Cost
description: ROTTUNG, Arunachal PradeshIm standing, weak-kneed, midway across the gorge of the Siang River, one of the three tributaries that converge to form the Brahmaputra River. Treading slowly over a bamboo suspension footbridge 300-odd meters long and just a meter wide, I marvel at this premodern engineering by the Adi Minyong tribe that dominates this section of Arunachal Pradesh.

title: News Quiz | March 5, 2013

title: Malaysia Attacks Filipino Rebels With Jets and Mortars

title: U.N. Resolution to Aim at North Korean Banks and Diplomats
description: The United Nations Security Council moved closer on Tuesday to expanding sanctions on North Korea for its nuclear and ballistic missile activities. The United States and China introduced a resolution that would target North Korean bankers and overseas cash couriers, tighten inspections of suspect ship and air cargo, and subject the countrys diplomats to invasive scrutiny and increased risk of expulsion.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 5

Jeffrey Gettleman reports from Nairobi.

title: Kenyan Accused by Rights Court Is Leading Vote
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Confusion and anxiety rose in Kenya on Tuesday as results from the presidential election were delayed by electronic breakdowns and officials announced a late-night change in tabulating votes, leading several observers to predict that a runoff might follow.

title: Spains Crisis Sparks Another Revolution
description: Faced with an unrelenting economic crisis, Spaniards have been getting creative with their housing arrangements. In the southern Spanish state of Andalusia, a network of urban squatters operating under the umbrella name of Corrala Utopia has started occupying some of the more than 130,000 homes and spaces made vacant by the countrys housing crisis.

description: MOSCOW  Police officials here on Tuesday detained a dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet and two suspected accomplices in connection with an acid attack in January on the companys artistic director, Sergei Filin, a crime that gripped Moscow and left one of Russias most revered institutions in turmoil.

title: In Britain, the Enemy Was Just Like Me

title: How Economics Can Help You Lose Weight
description: Last month, I visited the southern New Jersey plant of the Robard Corporation, a company that makes meal-replacement products for dieters. Robards president, Robert Schwartz, took me to the factory floor, where huge vats of powders  proteins, flavoring ingredients, vitamins  are poured into a 450-gallon V-shaped industrial mixer. The ingredients are then spun together and turned into protein shakes that sell for around $3.50 a serving. As I watched this process, it seemed as if Robard were in the worlds easiest business: take dirt-cheap raw materials, mix them together and sell them at a huge markup to Americas tens of millions of desperate dieters, like me.

title: Gordon Parkss Harlem Family Revisited
description: In March 1968, Gordon Parks published a portrait of an African-American child with disheveled clothes in Life magazine. His lips were swollen and cracked from eating plaster, in a futile attempt to ward off hunger. His eyes were plaintive and haunting.

title: Fear of Falling

She has Parkinsons disease, and the flog (fall log) of her spills has helped her doctors monitor her disease progression and adjust her therapy.

title: What Makes This Radio D.J. Roll?
description: Carol Miller, who is 62, began her New York radio career as a disc jockey at WNEW-FM in 1973. These days she can be heard weeknights on Q104.3 FM and on Sirius/XMs Classic Rewind channel. Get the Led Out, her widely syndicated show chronicling the history of Led Zeppelin, began in 1984. (Thats not a misprint; its Ms. Millers commitment to rock n roll forever) In her recently published memoir titled "Up All Night: My Life and Times in Rock Radio" (Ecco/Harper Collins), she describes her relationships with some of the greatest rock stars of the time. Paul McCartney and Robert Plant dropped by the studio to chat; she dated Aerosmiths Steven Tyler and Paul Stanley of Kiss. And through it all, she has battled cancer  for 40 years now. This interview has been condensed and edited.

This process is meant to yield viable candidates for a position.

So Chanel rules.
