description: When a motorcycle rider rammed his car from behind in peak Bangalore traffic some weeks ago, Nagaraju Mariankiah, a 37-year-old cab driver, responded as he usually did when he got into an accident. He immediately stopped the car on the busy street and got out to inspect the damage.

title: Wednesday Reading: Visiting Downton Destinations
Starbucks Barista Gets Creative With a New Yorker
description: Dear Diary:

title: Dell Board Committee Insists Sale Was Best Outcome
description: The special committee of Dells board that supervised the companys $24.4 billion sale to its founder reiterated on Wednesday that the deal was the best option for shareholders.

title: What the Mullahs Are Mulling
description: ISTANBUL  Midday in Istanbuls historical Beyazit district and the air suddenly fills with the call to prayer from the many royal mosques nearby. It is a reminder that a part of the city that now bustles with shoppers, university students and tourists was once the heart of a great Islamic empire.

title: Mama Whales on the Run
description: Rachel Cartwright teaches biology at California State University Channel Islands and is studying trends in habitat use in humpback whale mother-calf pairs in Hawaiian waters.

title: If You Like the Animals, Try the Rubens
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Crowdfunding Clean Energy
description: If you wanted to get large numbers of people actively engaged in helping to solve global warming, how might you go about it? For years, the main approach in the environmental movement has been to sound the alarm bell and implore people to consume less, switch to green products, recycle, and speak up to companies and politicians. It hasnt always been an easy sell. However, if the approach of a promising Oakland-based start-up takes hold, there may be another line of action that could become available to ordinary people: directly financing renewable energy.

title: Paris Street Style | Birds of a Feather
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Americans on the Catholic Church
description: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Catholics in the United States.

title: Moncler: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: The Breakfast Meeting: News Corp. Wants a Place in School, and Upfronts Are Not Just for Spring Anymore
description: Joel I. Klein, the former chancellor of New York Citys schools, will introduce News Corporations Amplify, the companys fledgling education division coupled with a new tablet of the same name, at the SXSWedu conference in Austin, Tex., on Wednesday, Amy Chozick reports. The tablet, a 10-inch Android made by Asus, will run Amplifys curriculum and provide storage for students data. It couples a touch screen with education-specific features, like an eyes on teacher warning when attention wanders and quizzes that use sad and smiley emoticons so teachers can ascertain whether students grasp new material. It will also have education-based games for students when theyre not in class, including one in which Tom Sawyer battles the Bront sisters.

title: Chvez Transformed the Way Venezuelans View Themselves
description: LA GUAIRA, Venezuela  Ever since her home was washed away in the devastating mudslides that killed thousands along Venezuelas coast in 1999, during President Hugo Chvezs first year in office, Graciela Pineda waited for him to carry out his vow to rebuild.

title: Paul Capital Takes Stake in Brazilian Venture Fund
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Paul Capital, a private equity firm focused on secondary market transactions, has acquired 18.2 percent of a fund managed by the Brazilian technology venture capital firm Ideiasnet, paying 79 million reais ($40 million).

title: What Were Reading
description: Fast Food Forward: Two new waves of food activism are rising in New York: one, a movement to raise wages for fast-food workers   Julia Moskin

title: Bye-Bye, Bumbo and Boppy (With Reservations)
description: It seems like an instant ago, that sweltering summer I spent scouring Craigslist and tag sales, possessed by a frenzied, pre-baby urge to nest. I scooped up gently used Ergos and Bjorns  words that were foreign to a first-time mothers tongue but promised parental salvation. Eventually, all the essential gear was acquired, along with a few items that in hindsight (yes, that would be you, wipes warmer) were anything but.

title: David Bowie Through the Years
description: After a career of five decades, Mr. Bowie has a new album.

title: Endangered or Not, but at Least No Longer Waiting
description: Perhaps it does not seem cause for celebration that the Oregon spotted frog, a four-inch-long amphibian that prefers the Pacific Northwests dwindling marshy spots, is to be considered this year for federal protection as an endangered species.

title: Sporting Goods
description: Athletic gear, from bright cross-trainers to sleek canvas backpacks, is edging in on fashions turf. See our interactive feature ->

title: Crowds Throng Caracas Streets to Salute Chvez
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In a modest brown wood coffin covered in a Venezuelan flag, President Hugo Chvez was carried through the capital, Caracas, on Wednesday morning as crowds thronged the streets, cabinet ministers and top military officials walked alongside his black hearse, while hundreds of soldiers in green fatigues and other supporters followed in the yellow, blue and red caps of the national colors.

title: Toyota Brings a GT-86 Convertible Concept to Geneva
description: GENEVA  Almost lost in the hype around the introduction of the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray convertible at the Geneva motor show here on Tuesday was the unveiling of another, nearly as significant convertible.

title: Brave Girls
description: Books about girl power are easy to find in March, National Womens History Month, though not all of them feel timeless or universal. Two new picture books, both with origins in Israel, tell stories about young girls whose bravery and endurance reap great rewards, in ways that transcend the specific circumstance of a people and place.

title: Threatened Species Have a Chance for Protection
description: As many species facing extinction have waited for years to be protected by the United States, the Fish and Wildlife Service has pledged to decide the fates of all the backlogged candidates by 2018.

title: The Gun Report: March 6, 2013
description: Last night, Jon and Rebecca Bond, the founders of Evolve, which I wrote about in Saturdays column, were on Piers Morgans CNN interview show. Their emphasis was about how they hope their new organization will become a bridge that links gun owners and non-gun owners, and how they hope it can help bring about the same kind of cultural change with guns that we have already made with two other dangerous behaviors: smoking and drunk driving. Here is the link to their appearance.

title: Report From Venezuela
description: After President Hugo Chvezs death, The Timess William Neuman surveys the scene in Caracas and the president of the Inter-American Dialogue examines American relations going forward.

title: The First Strike in the Roger Ailes Book Wars
description: The Roger Ailes book wars have begun.

title: Fantasy Baseball: Top 10 Second Basemen
description: Question marks abound among the top 10 second basemen. Justin Sablich makes his picks.

title: Elliott Criticizes Hess Chief as Unaccountable
description: The battle over the board of the Hess Corporation has become a tiny war of words.

title: Clothing Companies Trying to Find More Direct Paths to Customers
description: When Joanne and Tim Medvitz founded an outdoor clothing company, Pop Outerwear, in San Francisco in 2009, they were sure of one thing. They were going to sell their clothing directly to consumers, whether online, through their own store or through consumer ski and snowboard shows.

title: New Card Offers Cash Back for Paying on Time
description: Bank of America this week introduced a new credit card aimed at rewarding customers who paid on time and who paid more than the minimum amount due each month.

title: High Speed, Lower Price
description: The French national rail company SNCF is starting an economy high-speed rail service called Ouigo on April 2. It will operate between the Paris suburb Marne-la-Valle (home to Disneyland Paris) to points south, including Lyon, Marseille and Montpellier. Fares for the single-class, no-frills service (with no food or drink) range from 10 to 85 euros (about $12.50 to $107).

title: Sam Mendes Says He Wont Direct Next James Bond Movie
description: With any luck, the next James Bond movie will have a better title than Skyfall  yes, Skyfall  the 23rd official entry in that long running spy-thriller franchise, which featured an Academy Award-winning title song performed by Adele, the detachable jaw of Javier Bardem and Albert Finney in a supporting role that seemed almost surely designed for Sean Connery.

title: Former Defense Officials Urge Using Budget Cuts to Shape Military Strategy
description: With the across-the-board spending cuts now a reality, a group of five former deputy defense secretaries has written to the new Pentagon chief, Chuck Hagel, urging that he make the best of a bad situation by using the budget cuts as an opportunity to re-examine military strategy, personnel numbers and weapons purchases.

title: Threes a Trend | Beaver Fur
description: If theres one type of fur you need next season, its beaver: Chloe kept its Parisian girl cool in a vest; Givenchy had its girls slink around in a bomber; and Haider Ackermann added subdued glamour to his monochromatic look.

title: Venezuelans Recall Leaders Love of Game
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Luis Sojo, manager of Venezuelas national team, likes to sleep in. But on mornings after games he expected a call from Hugo Chvez, the countrys president, who died on Tuesday.

title: 2 Burned Bodies Found After Fire in Queens Marshland
description: There is little to lure visitors into the weeds and moldering woods that stretch for miles along Jamaica Bays northern edges, near where Brooklyn dissolves into Queens. It is a place well out of sight for most New Yorkers, and therefore out of mind.

title: Thats Quite a Guest List at Buckingham Palace
description: LONDON  A faint but palpable discomfort rippled through the audience at the Gielgud Theater on Tuesday night when a uniformed Equerry announced that Her Majesty had taken ill.

title: Campbell Sports Center
description: The center is Columbia Universitys new $30 million athletic building in Inwood.

title: Image of the Day: March 6
Harpers Ferry, Redux
description: A raid into the South was afoot. So reported The New-York Tribune, which sketched out a few details of a plot to surprise Southerners not with the phantom, but the reality of servile insurrection. At the behest of a radical white abolitionist, a group of free African-Americans had laid the groundwork for the clandestine incursion by preparing enslaved populations, who waited, ready to rise in thousands. After capturing a Southern town, the abolitionist and his colleagues, black and white, planned to establish a base from which to organize and arm a force of escaped slaves. The raid would be the opening salvo in a war on slavery.

title: Miu Miu: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: With Legal Reserves Low, Bank of America Faces a Big Lawsuit
description: Bank of America has been underestimating its legal risks for years, and brazenly so, according to its critics. Is that strategy about to pay off with the Federal Reserve?

title: Ahmadinejad Says Chvez Will Rise Again
description: Last Updated, 3:44 p.m. In a letter of condolence to the people of Venezuela, Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, struck a note of interfaith harmony on Wednesday, expressing confidence that the late Hugo Chvez would eventually be resurrected, along with Jesus and the Hidden Imam, a messianic figure in Shiite Islam.

title: Photos of The Moment | Chanel
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: For Obama and Senate Republicans, an Opportunity to Dine and Deal
description: As President Obama ratchets up his outreach effort to Congressional Republicans on Wednesday with a dinner date at the Jefferson Hotel, his guests will include some of his fiercest critics in the Senate, some conciliators and some lawmakers who hardly have made a ripple in the public debate over how to tackle the federal debt.

title: Schools, and Syllabuses, Designed With the Environment in Mind
description: Schools can play an important role in fostering environmental and energy awareness not only through how they teach, but also their physical structures and grounds. Ive been getting familiar with the remarkable, and growing, range of green school designs and initiatives around the country. Heres an initial survey, spurred in part by invaluable input from Veronique Choa Pittman of the Green Schools Alliance and from my visit last week to the engaging new Green Schools exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington.

title: City Life Takes a Toll on Chinas Children
description: BEIJING  Life in China isnt cheap any more, despite its reputation as a low-cost center. While many families have prospered from economic liberalization, others struggle to get by. And that includes many considered to be doing fairly well.

title: Targeted Killing in the U.S.A.
description: The Obama administration finally answered a simple question today: Does the president think he has the power to authorize lethal force, such as a drone strike, against an American citizen, in the United States, without trial.

title: WGBH to Partner on Childrens Pilot for Amazon
description: One of the biggest suppliers of programming for PBS, WGBH, is the latest to climb aboard Amazons television pilot process.

title: Dysons Bladeless Fan: A Little Cooler
description: The Dyson AM05 bladeless fan and heater is much cooler than its predecessor. Its new motor spins 33 percent faster, moving more air, hence: cooler.

title: As You Travel, Making Money Work for You
description: When the travel blogger Matt Kepnes, a k a Nomadic Matt, set off on a six-and-a-half-year backpacking trip that would take him to a staggering 70 countries, the relative merits of his bank account and credit card were an afterthought, he said. Two years into his journey, he realized he was needlessly racking up bank fees and missing out on free flights, so he sat down and figured out how to manage his personal finances abroad. These tips and others he shares in his new book, How to Travel the World on $50 a Day: Travel Cheaper, Longer, Smarter. Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Kepnes on which bank accounts and credit cards help you stick to your budget.

title: Photos of The Moment | Valentino
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Hotel Review: Gradiva in Istanbul
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Brindillas in Vistalba, Argentina
description: In Argentina, the peso is written with a dollar sign. So when we were presented with the menus at Brindillas, an unassuming but highly touted little restaurant about 20 minutes from downtown Mendoza, and saw a five-course tasting menu for what looked like $135, or seven courses for $175, we felt ambushed but undaunted. But after our meal  which cost about $100 (thats U.S. dollars) for two, wine included  we were pleasantly surprised, a feeling enhanced by food that had a sophisticated, modernist outlook that went well beyond the borders of Argentina.

title: Unreported Side Effects of Drugs Are Found Using Internet Search Data, Study Finds
description: Using data drawn from queries entered into Google, Microsoft and Yahoo search engines, scientists at Microsoft, Stanford and Columbia University have for the first time been able to detect evidence of unreported prescription drug side effects before they were found by the Food and Drug Administrations warning system.

title: Musical Version of Beaches Finds a Home
description: The wind beneath the wings of the musical adaptation of the film Beaches has landed the show a home. This week the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., announced that it would produce the show as part of its 2013-14 season. Eric Schaeffer, Signatures artistic director, will direct the production, which has been talked about for a Broadway run. Casting is still to be announced.

title: Talking N.C. State and the M.A.A.C. Tournament
description: Thirty years ago, Dereck Whittenburg won a national basketball championship as a player at North Carolina State. More recently he coached at Wagner and Fordham, where he was fired midseason in December 2009. Whittenburg still lives in the New York area and works for ESPN as a television analyst. Among the games he covers are those played in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

title: Warner Music Owner Bets on Competing Digital Services
description: Len Blavatnik, the Russian-born billionaire investor who bought the Warner Music Group two years ago, has placed big bets on multiple digital music services as the streaming model grows around the world.

title: McIlroy Says of Midround Withdrawal, I Should Have Stayed Out There
description: DORAL, Fla.  The public apology thinly veiled as a news conference opened Wednesday as the moderator turned to Rory McIlroy and said, Just go straight into the heart of the matter here. Pause. How disappointed were you with Manchester Uniteds score yesterday?

title: German Rieslings Turn in the Spotlight
description: La Paule de New York, Daniel Johnness adaptation of the Meursault harvest festival, begins this week, signifying the apogee of a remarkable month of wine in the city. La Paule, a mlange of seminars, discussions and tastings culminating in a grand dinner in which producers and collectors share precious bottles, has been so successful that it has inspired similar events celebrating other wines.

title: Fantasy Baseball: Second Base Preview
description: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

title: Recalling a Writers Paper as a Name Fades
description: Ghostly vestiges of the gothic Herald Tribune logo still survive on the eastern facade of 230 West 41st Street in Midtown Manhattan, camouflaged by a faded Group Health Insurance emblem, and, more recently, dwarfed by the towering headquarters of The New York Times next door.

title: Rangers Claim Hamrlik Off Waivers
description: The Rangers claimed the veteran defenseman Roman Hamrlik off waivers from Washington, the team confirmed Wednesday. It was unclear whether the acquisition indicated a long-term injury to defenseman Marc Staal, who was struck in the right eye by a shot in a game Tuesday.

title: A Government LGBT Site
description: The State Department created a Web portal for LGBT travelers last month that includes advice and links for gay people traveling abroad. In addition to steering travelers to country-specific pages that outline which governments give gay travelers legal protections, and which criminalize same-sex relations, the portal also suggests precautions, like carrying documents verifying custody of any children.

title: The Small Picture: Grab a Shovel
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Time Warner Ends Talks With Meredith and Will Spin Off Time Inc. Into Separate Company
description: 9:14 p.m. | UpdatedWhat do you do with a group of celebrated magazines that no one seems to want?

title: The Sequester App
description: Gail Collins: David, Ive been pretty calm about all the fiscal-cliff crises, but now Im really getting ticked off. I hate this sequester thing.

title: Back in Brooklyn | Karkula
description: The design store Karkula has returned to its Brooklyn roots: its new home in Williamsburg officially opens tomorrow, at 98 South 4th Street, with an exhibition of chandeliers by Michelle James and jewelry by Monica Castiglioni. The stores owner, the designer John Erik Karkula, co-founded the Brooklyn design object shop Breukelen in 1996 before moving to Manhattan and opening Karkula, where he was an early supporter of emerging talent like Jim Zivic and Lindsey Adelman, first in the meatpacking district, and later in TriBeCa. The new shop, which was designed by Karkula and the Brooklyn-based architect Philipp Mohr, now represents European brands like e15, Bocci and Nanimarquina, as well as its owners designs. Karkula maintains that he has always kept a low profile on New Yorks design scene. I thought it was cool to be under the radar, he said. But that might not be so easy now.

title: Senators Press Holder on Use of Military Force
description: WASHINGTON  Senators of both parties on Wednesday criticized Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for the secrecy surrounding the Justice Department legal memorandums justifying drone strikes aimed at American citizens, while pushing him to say more about when the Obama administration believes it can use military force on United States soil.

title: Syrian Rebels in Golan Region Hold U.N. Peacekeeping Team
description: Insurgent fighters from Syria seized a group of United Nations troops on patrol in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel on Wednesday and threatened to treat them as prisoners of war, an abrupt escalation in the Syrian conflict that entangled international peacekeepers for the first time.

title: Rodriguez, Set to Face Mets, Hopes for Return
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. - When Francisco Rodriguez was traded to Milwaukee midway through the 2011 season, he left the Mets with the label of overpriced failure on his back. He notched 83 saves in 165 appearances over two and a half years, but also suffered through injuries and an ignoble tantrum in which he punched his father-in-law after a blown save.

title: Software and Side Effects
description: Scientists find that analyzing online queries provides valuable insight into drug interactions.

title: A Young Womans Choice, and Its Consequences
description: Not since that incident at Boston Harbor in 1773 has tea been as central to a dispute as it is in Katie Roche, the third Teresa Deevy play to be examined in recent years by the Mint Theater Company, whose mission is to shine new light on neglected works.

title: With Worries for Its Economic Future, Cuba Bids a Sad Goodbye to a Generous Ally
description: HAVANA  The death of Hugo Chvez sent a ripple of sadness and uncertainty across this island on Wednesday as Cubans mourned the loss of an ideological son and generous ally, and worried about the economic pain that could lie ahead if the new Venezuelan leadership cut off hefty oil subsidies.

title: Smash Ratings Hit a New Low on NBC
description: Can Smash stay on the air? The enormously publicized  and enormously expensive  NBC drama crashed to a new ratings low Tuesday night, hitting a level that only a few weeks ago caused another NBC drama, Do No Harm, to be yanked off the air.

title: Stranger Than We Can Imagine: David Toomey Talks About Weird Life
description: In Weird Life, David Toomey writes about the search for life that is not just strange, but in fact, like nothing weve discovered. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Toomey discussed the origins of life on Earth, the porous line between science and philosophy, his favorite science fiction and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Anthony Questionable for Game Against Pistons
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  The Knicks Carmelo Anthony remains questionable for tonights game against the Detroit Pistons, because of stiffness and soreness in his right knee.

title: Sallie Mae Lowers Top Loan Rates for Graduate Students
description: Graduate students may now be able to qualify for private student loans at lower interest rates from Sallie Mae, the education finance company announced on Wednesday.

title: The Nets' Ongoing Identity Crisis
description: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks' shadow. It hasn't exactly worked out that way.

title: Video: The Nets Continuing Identity Crisis
description: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks shadow. It hasnt exactly worked out that way.

title: Content Lives On, Even if Web Site Doesnt
description: 11:01 a.m. | Updated Some journalists just cant stop working.

title: Familiar Names Join the List for the Tribeca Film Festival
description: New movies from Richard Linklater, Neil Jordan, David Gordon Green, Mira Nair, Neil LaBute and Clark Gregg; and documentaries about Elaine Stritch, Richard Pryor, Gore Vidal and  from Whoopi Goldberg  Moms Mabley were among the latest announced for the Tribeca Film Festival by its organizers on Wednesday.

title: Last Stop Before the Outlet Center
description: Everything you love will eventually become a mall. It will be unearthed, polished, commodified and disseminated. It will be silver-platter-delivered to the next generation in a way that will make your earnest passion and curiosity seem infantile. Remember when? you will say, and nobody will.

title: Subscribing to Office, Now and Forever
description: It must be tough to be on the Microsoft Office team. Year after year, youre given the same assignment: add new features to Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Outlook. New features that people will pay for, but that wont turn Microsofts cash cow into a bloated, sloshing mess.

title: Rand Paul Leads Filibuster of Brennan Nomination
description: 4:59 p.m. | Updated Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, began an old-school, speak-until-you-can-speak-no-more filibuster on Wednesday just before noon, and was still going strong hours later.

title: With Positions to Fill, Employers Wait for Perfection
description: American employers have a variety of job vacancies, piles of cash and countless well-qualified candidates. But despite a slowly improving economy, many companies remain reluctant to actually hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.

title: The Roots of Dennis Hoppers Style
description: Its a peculiar brand of American voodoo, a mix of Pabst Blue Ribbon and white Stetson hats and weather-beaten Levis. And a gas mask. It has a lot to do with being dirty.

title: Skiing Kashmirs Snow-Swept Peaks
description: On a frigid night in Gulmarg, a Himalayan outpost deep in Kashmir, a friend and I sipped sweet tea and warmed ourselves next to a wood stove while a local ski guide named Javed stood in front of us, roaring like a bear. Baah! Baah! he shouted, his hands outstretched like claws. I thought it was going to kill us, Javed said of the Asiatic black bear he had encountered a few days before while skiing in the backcountry.

title: Where Skiing Is Only Part of the Adventure
description: A journey to rugged Kashmir.

title: Honey, We Barely Shrunk the Financial System
description: The global financial system isnt dead. But it might be shrinking.

title: A Weather Report Thats Colorful, With a Chance of Fun
description: Ill bet that one of the first apps you downloaded onto a smartphone or tablet was for weather. These apps are more appealing than weather forecasts on television, because they provide interactive weather reports you can hold in your hand.

title: Suspect in Crash That Killed 3 Turns Himself In
description: The manhunt ended at a roadside minimart.

title: A Call for a National Strategy on Veterans
description: Stand on the corner of H Street and Vermont Avenue in Washington, D.C., and in every direction youll see the ways and means of American government  the White House in front, the Treasury to the left and the huge Office of Management and Budget building down the street and to the right. This vista is both symbolic of  and essential to running  our system of governance by the people, for the people.

title: German Museum Returns Painting to Jewish Estate
description: A German museum has returned a 15th-century Renaissance painting to the estate of a Jewish art dealer who was forced to sell it under duress in 1935.

title: Scouting Report
description: Hitting the Racks

title: Grooms Letter to Parents, Remembered After Fatal Hit and Run
description: Updated, Monday, March 11 | The young groom took some moments on his wedding day to write a letter thanking his parents for never sparing time or money if he needed, say, a tutor or an eye doctor, and for sending him to yeshiva to learn your values, religious and worldly, until I reached to this current lucky moment.

title: Artist Quits Superman Project After Outcry Over Writers Marriage Views
description: Adventures of Superman, a digital anthology from DC Comics, is scheduled to begin on April 29. But it will not feature the work of Chris Sprouse, an artist who has decided to drop out of the project because of a controversy surrounding the opposition to gay marriage by the novelist Orson Scott Card, one of the writers.

title: Ask Well: Keeping Knee Arthritis in Check
description: Question:

title: Young Poets Society
description: Each year, the Lilly fellowships offer five young poets prestige, publicity and  most elusive of all  money. The latest crop of winners represents how important, and how controversial, these awards have become.

title: Bruno Mars, Discounted Online, Tops Album Chart
description: Never doubt the selling power of a deep, well-publicized sale.

title: Arkansas Adopts a Ban on Abortions After 12 Weeks
description: Arkansas adopted what is by far the countrys most restrictive ban on abortion on Wednesday  at 12 weeks of pregnancy, when a fetal heartbeat can typically be detected by abdominal ultrasound.

title: New Bruce Norris Play Will Be Part of Steppenwolf Season
description: New plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Bruce Norris (Clybourne Park) and Mona Mansour (Urge for Going) are among the productions in the 2013-14 season at Chicagos Steppenwolf Theater, the company announced on Wednesday.

title: Shopping Snapshots: March 7
description: Carson Street Clothiers, a new mens store in SoHo; Chlo celebrates 60 years; and the casual wear of 194t makes being comfy look good.

title: Free Throws and High-Fives: A Routine Within a Routine
description: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times sports blogs.

title: The Benefits of Working in the Office
description: Yahoos chief executive, Marissa Mayer, inspired much debate and rebuke when she recently abolished Yahoos work-at-home policy. In academia, working from home is a treasured euphemism for heading home after your morning class to have lunch, read the newspaper and take a nap. I hate to see anything that would endanger this hallowed tradition.

title: Northwesterns Road to Success Getting Tougher
description: EVANSTON, Ill.It can be lonely at the top.

title: Theyre Not Quite N Sync
description: Muscles, Mozart and marketing: following the strippers dictum from Gypsy, You Gotta Have a Gimmick, the four stars of Well-Strung: The Singing String Quartet present themselves as a buff, gay, pop-classical hybrid of juicy boy band and staid chamber group with a vocal component.

title: Obstruct and Delay
description: As of 3:30 p.m. Wednesday, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been speaking on the Senate floor for about three-and-a-half hours, self-indulging in an old-school filibuster against John Brennan, President Obamas choice to run the C.I.A. At 3 p.m., Senator Mike Lee of Utah jumped in to help him, asking Mr. Paul questions so he could keep the floor. Then Ted Cruz of Texas and Jerry Moran of Kansas joined in the tirade. Its a C-Span spectacle, but make no mistake: this isnt the real filibuster of Mr. Brennan.

title: A Marble-Floored Contemporary With a Garden
description: A minimalist house in a suburb of Athens is on the market for $4.4 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Greece
description: A MARBLE-FLOORED HOUSE NORTH OF ATHENS

title: Europes Carmakers Look Forward to U.S. Trade Pact
description: GENEVA  As the industry convenes here for the Geneva auto show amid the worst European car market slump in decades, there is at least one ray of hope: the green light President Barack Obama recently gave to negotiations for a U.S.-E.U. free-trade pact.

title: Sequencing the Stages: Understanding H.I.V. Infection at the Molecular Level
description: The Complicated AIDS Battle: There is some (qualified) good news in the fight against H.I.V. infections around the world. Go to related article

title: Why Vodafone Should Head for a Verizon Exit
description: Vodafone should dash for a United States exit if its open. Shares of the British telecommunications company soared on Wednesday on hopes that Verizon Communications could buy it out of their $250 billion-plus joint venture. Ending a long standoff while American assets are at high valuations makes sense  as long as Vodafone doesnt squander the proceeds on a costly makeover.

title: A Traveling Violation?
description: Call it basketball diplomacy or stunt journalism. But the bromance between former National Basketball Association star Dennis Rodman and Kim Jong-un,the repressive leader of North Korea, was simply bizarre. Mr. Rodmans less-than-eloquent appearance on ABCs This Week did little to shed light on the North Korean trip. Twitter users, luckily, had more to say.

title: If a Rabbit Wore a Mini
description: THIS HAS BEEN the season of the fur skirt.

title: Is Poetry Good For Pigs?
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Vionnet
description: It was all about M.A.C. Silver Dusk Iridescent Powder for extra sheen on the fresh-faced models at Vionnet. The makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury dusted some over the T-zone, taking one brush and literally going straight down from the bridge of the nose to the cupids bow, and then lightly over the lips. The iridescent powder was also used as a highlighter in the corner of the eyes.

title: On ABC Family, an Episode in Sign Language
description: On Monday night, ABC Family did something that no commercial television outlet in the United States had ever done: it broadcast an entire episode of a show in sign language, with closed captioning turned on by default.

title: The (Historical) Clothes Make the Reality Show
description: Other fashion-related reality shows tart themselves up with the histrionics of designer competitions or workplace friction, formats that now seem tired. So purists might find L.A. Frock Stars to be a refreshing change. In this engaging series, which begins Thursday on the Smithsonian Channel, the clothes really are the main attraction.

title: Open Houses on Sunday Afternoons Long Ago
description: After the members of the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra strolled onstage at the American Academy of Arts and Letters on Sunday afternoon, they arranged themselves into a formation that mirrored the image projected overhead  an early-18th-century painting by Marco Ricci called Rehearsal of an Opera.

title: Lessons From the Stratosphere, and How to Get There
description: Fifty years after The Feminine Mystique identified the depression and stir-craziness of suburban housewives, another rallying cry for women has come along. It was written by Sheryl Sandberg, a mother of two who works outside the home. Ms. Sandberg addresses 21st-century issues that never entered Betty Friedans wildest dreams, and she is a walking advertisement for womens empowerment. As a former vice president of Google who is now chief operating officer of Facebook, she writes about how women can best rise to the top of the corporate world.

title: At Shooting Site, Giffords Urges Lawmakers to Act on Gun Safety
description: TUCSON  Fight, fight, fight were the first words by Gabrielle Giffords during a news conference on Wednesday from the same supermarket parking lot where a gunman opened fire on Jan. 8, 2011, wounding her and 12 others and taking six lives.

title: Bolshoi Intrigue
description: The Timess Ellen Barry offers the latest updates from Moscow regarding the acid attack on a ballet companys artistic director.

title: Sandberg Takes Her Message to Wall St.
description: Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, is heading to Wall Street with her message about women in the workplace.

title: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
description: GERMANTOWN, N.Y.

title: Photos of The Moment | Alexander McQueen
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Disney Shareholders Endorse Pay of Chief Executive
description: LOS ANGELES  As expected, two shareholder resolutions challenging how the Walt Disney Company is managed were defeated on Wednesday at the entertainment conglomerates annual meeting in Phoenix.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google and the F.B.I., and HTC Falters
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: French Ministry Posts Online Full File on Dreyfus Affair
description: PARIS  The entire secret military file that was used to wrongly convict Capt. Alfred Dreyfus of spying for Germany in 1894 has been posted online by the historical department of the French Ministry of Defense.

title: Homes for $1.1 Million
description: A three-bedroom house built in 1841, in Germantown, N.Y.,; a house on a golf course in Durham, N.C.; and a midcentury ranch house in Oklahoma.

title: Icahn Is Said to Have a Growing Stake in Dell, and No Taste for Buyout
description: 11:17 p.m. | Updated

title: Stalking the Light
description: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

title: Follow Our Environmental Coverage
description: As we wind down this blog, readers have asked how best to follow The Timess ongoing coverage of the environment.

title: The Republican Partys Donorism Problem
description: Politicos Jonathan Martin has a good piece today about the divide between conservative policy writers and Republican politicians, and the absence (which Ive touched on recently) of any actual G.O.P. elected officials willing to champion the various reformist ideas that have been floating around right-of-center journals and magazines and blogs recently (and really for years now). I agree with most of the people quoted in the piece and particularly Bill Kristol and Ramesh Ponnuru, who both bemoan the absence of domestic policy entrepreneurism among the partys backbenchers. But Martins conversation the American Enterprise Institutes Jim Pethokoukis seemed particularly worth highlighting:

title: Scene City: A Parisian Ball with Fashion Week MVPs
description: Carine Roitfeld and Stephen Gan hosted a black-tie ball for CR Fashion Book.

title: After the Shows, Its Shangri-La
description: It was half past midnight when Kate Moss landed with a thud right next to my feet.

title: Republicans Block Judicial Nominees Confirmation for a Second Time
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked the confirmation of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to become a federal appeals court judge in the District of Columbia, the second time in two years Republicans have filibustered her nomination.

title: Rehearsals for the Revolution
description: Neva may be set in a Russia on the verge of explosion, but the Chilean playwright Guillermo Caldern still calls it my American play because it was born here. As a graduate student in film at the City University of New York a decade ago he prowled Manhattans bookstores, where he found Janet Malcolms Reading Chekhov, which stimulated an interest in Russian culture and politics that led him to A Peoples Tragedy: The Russian Revolution 1891-1924 by Orlando Figes.

title: House Tells Postal Service to Keep Six-Day Delivery
description: WASHINGTON - A spending measure passed by the House on Wednesday to keep the government operating through September requires that the Postal Service maintain a six-day mail delivery schedule, a potential setback for the agency, which announced last month that it planned go to five-day deliveries to cut costs.

title: Ford Recalling 196,500 Minivans for Corrosion Problem
description: 4:44 p.m., March 7 | Updated Ford is recalling about 196,500 of its 2004-7 Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans to fix a corrosion problem that prevents the fold-down third-row seats from locking safely into place, Kelli Felker, a spokeswoman for the automaker, said today.

title: Going Once, Going Twice
description: If you are one of the many individuals who has been mourning the loss of Charlotte Mosss treasure trove of design gems ever since she shuttered her Upper East Side town house store in 2008, you can now rejoice a bit. On Thursday at 10 a.m., Doyle New York will auction off The Charlotte Moss Collection, which includes over 400 objects belonging to the Southern decorator, including leftover inventory from the retail space as well as other design items shes collected along the way. Pieces range from signed 18th-century art to a set of De Gournay hand-painted Indian tea paper wallpaper panels with an estimated price tag somewhere between $2,000 and $4,000, and the comprehensive catalog is available at doylenewyork.com leading up to the auction.

title: Were Through. Check the App.
description: Breaking up has always been excruciating, but at least in the old days lovers could split, move on and retain their dignity. Now, in the age of social media, extrication is nearly impossible. The pain of a breakup is nourished by an endless real-time stream of Facebook status updates, Instagram photos and tweets about ones ex.

title: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 6
description: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

title: Exhuming the Last of Hendrixs Studio Sessions
description: When Jimi Hendrix died in September 1970, he left hundreds of session tapes behind. Over the last three decades producers have mined that trove of recordings, putting out a dozen posthumous studio albums, selling millions of copies.

title: Witches Lose the Warts
description: Lena Duchannes is new in town, exotic and seductive to a handful of bored locals in the Southern community where she lives. But if that werent enough to turn her into man bait, her pallid good looks would do the trick.

title: Reactions to the Death of Hugo Chvez
description: After the death of Hugo Chvez, the Venezuelan president whose views and policies were controversial both inside and outside his country, readers discussed his legacy as an economic populist and diplomatic provocateur. Below is a selection of their comments.

title: Witches Have a Fashion Moment
description: Witchcraft and its moody expressions  long weedy hair, peaked hats and pointy boots  have attained a strange cachet of late.

title: Gadgets You Need, Even if You Have a Smartphone
description: After I bought my first iPhone, something changed. When I bought a new electronic device, I was often filled with regret rather than joy.

title: Copenhagen Bridge Invitational
description: At the 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational, played two weeks ago, the most famous am in the preliminary pro-am event was the husband of Queen Margrethe II of Denmark, Henrik, the prince consort.

title: Mannequins, Then and Now
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Order and Disorder, as Dawn Casts a Glow Over a Funereal March
description: Paul Taylor has often seemed the greatest of todays choreographers, the most imaginative and disconcerting in any genre. Tuesdays opening night gala of his dance companys three-week season at Lincoln Center didnt demonstrate enoughof that top quality, but its four works  spanning from 1956 to a world premiere  represented an intelligent retrospective. They showed his diversity, from offbeat idiosyncrasy to poetic orthodoxy and from comic pratfalls to dark, wild force. They also included costumes and designs by Alex Katz and Robert Rauschenberg, and scores from jazz to Offenbach. The season that follows contains 17 other works, many of which are among Mr. Taylors most singular masterpieces.

title: Paul Taylor Dance Company at Lincoln Center
description: The company presented its opening night gala of its three-week season on Tuesday.

title: A Paris Quartier Surges
description: New cafes, bars and boutiques are enlivening a stretch of the 10th Arrondissement.

title: Yanks Lose Another Big Bat to Injury
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Sitting in a wheelchair parked in the middle of the Yankees clubhouse, with his broken right leg in a cast, General Manager Brian Cashman delivered the details about the latest injury to befall the Yankees, and it was not his own.

title: A New Look at What Used to Be Chic
description: Extraordinary dresses have a way of finding William Banks-Blaney. Dresses like the mint condition 1970s Ossie Clark he discovered, along with a floor-length, silk velvet Art Deco cape, in a random little store on Waiheke Island, off the coast of Auckland, New Zealand, when I was there for Christmas last year, he said recently, sipping a cappuccino in the lobby of the Maritime hotel in Manhattan. You just never know where a dress will travel to.

title: Boxers HK
description: In recent years, the center of LGBT night life has shifted from Downtown to Midtown, with 13 gay bars now clustered in Hells Kitchen. The newest one is Boxers HK, the northern branch of the popular Chelsea sports bar, that opened its frosted glass doors in January.

title: Art-Shopping for Stars, So They Dont Have To
description: For Maria Brito, the Armory Show, the contemporary art fair that starts Thursday at Piers 92 and 94 on the Hudson River in Manhattan, is kind of like a Stop & Shop. Acting as purchasing proxy for clients like Sean Combs, (His friends call him Puffy, but I call him Sean, she said) and Gwyneth Paltrow, Ms. Brito will be looking for works by established, midcareer and emerging artists, she said, though her voice ticked up a notch when mentioning younger ones: Christa Joo-Hyun DAngelo, Andrea Mary Marshall, Caragh Thuring and Angel Otero.

title: Painting Music, and Listening to Art
description: On Monday, Jan. 2, 1911, at half past 7 in the evening, Wassily Kandinsky attended a concert at a hotel ballroom in Munich. The next day he painted it.

title: The Daily Shoe | Alexander McQueen
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Creative Class Is in Session
description: It was a hot Saturday night last summer, and a pack of scruffy kids, many toting skateboards and backpacks, spilled out onto Canal Street from a shoe-box-size storefront Buddhist temple.

title: In the Bronx, Where Art Is Still Free
description: How did the Bronx Museum of the Arts, an institution on the Grand Concourse that is far removed from the tourist precincts of Manhattans Museum Mile, boost its attendance by 50 percent last year?

title: Suit Says Sherlock Belongs to the Ages
description: Devotees of Sherlock Holmes are a famously obsessive bunch, and in the 126 years since Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his coolheaded detective they have certainly had plenty of real-world intrigues to ponder alongside fictional ones like The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle.

title: Parsing Motives in Bolshoi Attack
description: MOSCOW  Prosecutors have yet to lay out a possible motive in the January attack on the Bolshoi Ballets artistic director, Sergei Filin, but the revelations of the past few days suggest that it may boil down to a ballerina.

title: Accessories From Paris Fashion Week
description: A selection of accessories from the Parisian runways.

title: Pursuing the Men Who Destroy Majestic Lives
description: Sometimes even a dumb show can contain something important. Thats the case with Battleground: Rhino Wars, a three-part mini-series that starts Thursday night on Animal Planet.

title: Past Forward: Hugo Chvez as a Shock Therapist
Sacrament, With Birds
description: Two estimable figures have hovered over the Manton Memorial Organ at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village since that tremendous instrument was inaugurated in May 2011. One is Olivier Messiaen, the visionary 20th-century Frenchman who made the organ a staple of his lifes work as a composer and performer. The other is Jon Gillock, a superb organist born in Oklahoma and based in France who played Messiaen and more to christen the Ascension organ in 2011.

title: Photo Replay: March 6
description: A look at the day in sports from spring training camp and World Baseball Classic games to the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race.

title: The New Seats of Power
description: On a recent Monday, Gary Ginsberg, a senior executive at Time Warner, walked into an unremarkable office building on the corner of 57th Street and Sixth Avenue and took the elevator to the eighth floor, entering a windowless door for a 2 p.m. appointment. A couple of hours later, Kenneth Lerer, a founder of The Huffington Post, followed.

title: Looking for the Right Solution to Hearing Problems
description: This is the second set of answers to reader questions from Neil J. DiSarno, chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, and a former chairman of the department of communication sciences and disorders at Missouri State University. Dr. DiSarnos first set of answers can be found here. Because more than 200 people wrote in, not all questions can be answered individually; Dr. DiSarno selected representative questions on similar topics. This feature is closed to new questions.

title: Say, Youre Not the Brother I Thought I Was Marrying
description: There is no missing the sheer effort involved in the Metropolitan Operas revival of Riccardo Zandonais Francesca da Rimini, which opened on Monday evening for its first Met run in close to 27 years. From the moment the curtain rises you are awed by Ezio Frigerios towering, grandly detailed sets, designed for a 1984 resurrection of a work neglected since 1918. Franca Squarciapinos costumes delight your eyes. Zandonais luxuriously orchestrated music caresses your ears.

title: Beauty Spots
description: Spring Awakening

title: Boeing Plan to Test Fixes on 787 Nears Approval
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is close to approving tests of Boeings approach to fixing the batteries on its 787 jets, and the tests could begin next week, federal and industry officials said Wednesday.

title: Lean, Unfold, Affix or Fold: A Desk for Tight Spaces
description: With Appunto, the Belgian-born designer Laurent Corio has created a versatile piece of furniture for small spaces. His modern escritoire for the French company Eno works as a writing or computing desk: the surface measures 19 by 24 inches to support a laptop. It can also do duty as a ledge for storing items in a kitchen, bathroom, childrens room or foyer. When Appunto is closed, its solid beech legs serve as a place to hang shopping bags, scarves or backpacks, and its reverse side, which is washable, also functions as a message board.

title: In Brooklyn, Tripping the Plastic Fantastic
description: The latest evidence that Brooklyn is a hotbed of progressive design comes from Souda (pronounced SOH-duh), a Japanese word that translates to oh, yeah or aha! Thats the name of a design group started by three 2012 graduates of Parsons the New School for Design: Isaac Friedman-Helman, Shaun Kasperbauer and Luft Tanaka.

title: Basic Zebra Commands: Sit, Stay, Roll Over, Sleep
description: Since 1945, when Flora Scalamandr designed a red zebra wallpaper for the New York restaurant Gino of Capri, the pattern has migrated to umbrellas, china and tote bags. Now it can be found on bedding for people and pets alike. In December Scalamandr introduced a dog bed in the perky stripes, and next month it will follow with a zebra bed skirt and pillow shams for humans.

title: A Bird in the Hand Is...a Knob
description: The San Francisco-based designer Ted Boerner has teamed up with Rocky Mountain Hardware to create four drawer pulls in the shape of bird heads: a finch, grosbeak, cardinal (shown) and woodpecker. Each one is cast in bronze at the Rocky Mountain foundry in Blackfoot, Idaho, using the centuries-old lost-wax method. (Wax molds are dipped into a liquid ceramic slurry multiple times and hardened. Then the wax is melted out of the shell, liquid bronze is poured in to replace it, and the ceramic shell is cracked off after the metal cools.)

title: The Daily Do | Louis Vuitton
description: At Louis Vuitton today, Marc Jacobs sent his boudoir-clad ladies out from hotel room doors at the start of the runway. In short, brown Clara Bow-inspired wigs that looked slept-in, the models all appeared to play the same role of a woman in love, or lust.

title: Sales at Property and Kartell
description: During Propertys sale from Friday through March 23, some furniture and accessories will be up to 60 percent off, and most new orders will be 20 percent off (the Cubica leather lounge chair by Lievore Altherr Molina, which was originally $4,560, will be $1,800; the Booknest pullout sofa by Carlo Colombo, originally $11,070, will be $5,500); 14 Wooster Street (Grand Street), (917) 237-0123, propertyfurniture.com.

title: A League of One
description: PARIS  One day last week, David Beckham clogged foot traffic on the Champs-lyses when he made a promotional appearance at the Adidas store. Wearing bright yellow sneakers and his seemingly indefatigable smile, Beckham was like catnip for tourists and locals alike as they walked past the majesty of the nearby Arc de Triomphe and crowded a cramped storefront instead, hoping to snap a camera-phone picture of soccers perpetually coifed superstar.

title: In Defense of Collisions in the Office
description: The latest progressive office playground can be found in the old Stuyvesant Polyclinic, a stately red brick building on Second Avenue near Ninth Street that was once a medical clinic. Inside, its three stories and basement have been reimagined by ?What If!, a self-described innovation company that works to expand the markets of businesses like PepsiCo, Pfizer and Virgin.

title: Pictures of the Day: Venezuela and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Venezuela, Kenya, Myanmar and the Vatican.

title: Carter Murray Named as Chief of DraftFCB
description: The search for a new leader for the global advertising agency DraftFCB Worldwide, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, ended on Wednesday afternoon with the selection of an outsider from a rival agency owned by WPP.

title: A House Built for a Family of Individuals
description: A honeycomb of rooms in bold colors in Kansas City, Mo.

title: It Has Its Points
description: As you approach the Nicol House, you might not realize those are Italian glass ashtrays embedded in the front door or tiny hobby-store mirrors glinting among the shingles. But you would know you were in for something out of the ordinary.

title: Japans New Leader Takes On Old Order to Jolt Economy
description: TAHARA, Japan  Just two months into office, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is showing an increasing willingness to take on some pillars of Japans establishment  the central bank and the countrys politically influential farmers  in an aggressive attempt to finally breathe some new life into Japans listless economy.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. We have an enclosed, uninsulated porch that we use for storage. Should we renovate to turn it into a usable living space before selling our house?

title: Casting a Wide Net
description: A new show at MoMA looks at all that design can be.

title: And to Think I Saw It @ MoMA!
description: Posted above the doorway of an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is a question raised in 1911 by the painter Wassily Kandinsky: Must we not then renounce the object altogether, throw it to the winds and instead lay bare the purely abstract?

title: Clues Sought in Burning of Bag Holding 5 Dogs
description: Animal protection authorities are looking for the people who set fire to a bag containing five pit bulls behind a beverage distribution warehouse in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

title: Engineering Serendipity
description: Why do some parties, companies and cities work, while others dont? It takes some social engineering to foster serendipity and creativity.

title: Housewares Through an 8-Year-Olds Eyes
description: New products from the International Home and Housewares Show.

title: Robots, Ducks and Awesome Swag
description: CHICAGO  There are few phrases in the English language that bore an 8-year-old more than trade show. Agricultural field trip might qualify, or maybe indoor summer camp. But to draw a truly blank stare, tell a second grader that the two of you are headed to an expo on kitchen, bath and living-room accessories.

title: The DNA of Cool
description: Michelle Harper has made herself so ubiquitous a subject of the street fashion photographers that she was finally forced to reverse herself and declare street style so over.

title: Michelle Harper, a Woman of Mystery
description: Its definitively established that in the Age of Instagram and Twitter metrics, it is possible to become pretty darn famous for omnipresence. Case in point: Michelle Harper, an eccentric and modish figure whose image over the last several years has seemed to be everywhere, in both real life and, possibly more important, in the parallel universe that is the Web.

title: Model Diary | Edie Campbell
description: Edie Campbell wraps up this seasons Model Diary series for T. If you missed her in todays Louis Vuitton show, you may find the 22-year-old British model and equestrian hanging out around the March des Enfants Rouges market before she catches a plane back home to London.

title: Two Men Scale New York Times Building
description: Alain Robert, a stunt man famous for scaling monuments, hung a bright green banner: Global warming kills more people than 9/11 every week. Hours later a copycat also made the climb.

title: Trend Report: Fur Skirts
description: Fur skirts offer a way for designers to explore wider, and wilder, proportions in their fall 2013 collections.

title: Alberto R. Gonzaless Tenure
description: President Bush had repeatedly stood by Mr. Gonzales, even as he faced increasing scrutiny for his leadership of the Justice Department.

title: Helping Immigrants Warm to Winter
description: PORTLAND, Me.  Charlene Masengu left the Democratic Republic of Congo late last year, hoping to get asylum status in the United States after a wave of political violence made life at home unbearably dangerous. She made it to this coastal city last month, just before it was covered in more than 30 inches of snow, and she wondered, briefly, whether she had made a mistake.

title: A Poetry Reading by Alfred Brendel
description: Mr. Brendel, a pianist, read two selections from his poetry collection, 'Cursing Bagels.' Recorded by James Barron of The New York Times.

title: Sears and Penney Respond to SNL Sketch Complaint
description: So did a comedy sketch on the Feb. 16 edition of Saturday Night Live called Djesus Uncrossed really lead two companies to ask NBC not to place their ads in future editions of the show?

title: Where Everything Smells Bad
description: PARIS

title: Stage Scenes: Alice Ripley
description: A look at some of the actresss stage performances.

title: Posters on Teenage Pregnancy Draw Fire
description: The curly-haired baby looks out from the poster with sad eyes and tears dripping down his tawny cheeks.

title: When Arkansas Travels, Success Doesnt Follow
description: When Mike Anderson left Missouri to become the mens basketball coach at Arkansas in March 2011, he said he was going home.

title: Clothes Worthy of Their Label
description: PARIS  You sometimes think, at the bleary end of a runway season, that fashion would be better off if companies didnt have labels to sell.

title: Televisions C.S.I. Gets New Financial Partner to Replace Goldman
description: LOS ANGELES  Crime continues to pay, at least where the C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation television franchise is concerned.

title: Egypt Court Cancels Parliamentary Elections
description: CAIRO  A top court on Wednesday canceled pending parliamentary elections and referred the election law to the Supreme Constitutional Court, adding to the mounting uncertainty about a vote that had been scheduled to begin as early as April 22.

title: Video of Syrians With Seized U.N. Vehicles in Golan Heights
description: Updated, Thursday, 9:07 a.m. As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Alan Cowell report, 30 armed rebel fighters kidnapped a group of 20 United Nations peacekeepers in the Golan Heights on Wednesday and gave a 24-hour deadline before they would treat the peacekeepers as prisoners of war.

title: The Struggle for Jihad
description: Two opposing groups battle to define the word jihad on public buses and subways.

title: In Upgrade, Google Adds to Model for Mobile Marketing
description: GOOGLE executives, declaring themselves pleased with the results of an unusual advertising initiative last year, are bringing out a Version 2.0, again teaming with agencies and marketers to try demonstrating that technology is not incompatible with traditional Madison Avenue sales strategies like emotional storytelling.

title: A Nascar Drivers Deeds Fail to Match Her Words
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Nascar, which has long struggled to develop minority and female participants, seemed to have a barrier-breaking athlete in its ranks in recent years: Tia Norfleet, a 20-something driver from Georgia. With a savvy marketing campaign, Norfleet garnered attention in several national publications while promoting her accomplishments as the first African-American woman to race in Nascar.

title: Using Billboards to Stake Claim Over Jihad
description: CHICAGO  There is an advertising war being fought here  not over soda or car brands but over the true meaning of the word jihad.

title: A Locust Plague, Shy of Biblical Proportions, in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  For many Israelis, the biblical comparisons were irresistible: locusts were swarming across the border from Egypt three weeks before Passover, like a vivid enactment of the eighth plague visited upon the obdurate Pharaoh. Others with a more modern sensibility said it felt more like Hitchcock.

title: Killer of Girlfriend and Her Son Is Sentenced to 50 Years to Life
description: A man convicted of strangling his pregnant girlfriend and killing her 2-year-old son in a fire he set at her Queens apartment was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison on Wednesday, the Queens district attorney said.

title: A Shift Toward Higher Job Vacancy Rates
description: There has been a fundamental shift over the last several years toward more unfilled jobs, even as the unemployment rate has fallen.

title: Officers Trial Has a Jury That Appears Tech-Savvy
description: One day last month, as Judge Paul G. Gardephe was overseeing jury selection for the trial of a New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, he asked prospective jurors about issues that could call their impartiality into question.

title: Security Council Loosens Somalian Arms Embargo
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Wednesday to temporarily rescind part of a 21-year-old arms embargo on Somalia, the East African country once considered synonymous with warlordism, piracy and anarchy, portraying the easing as part of an effort to strengthen the fragile Somalian governments authority by permitting it to purchase light weapons.

title: Global Slavery, by the Numbers
description: Here are some chilling statistics: The lifetime profit on a brickmaking slave in Brazil is $8,700, and $2,000 in India. Sexual slavery brings the slaves owner $18,000 over the slaves working life in Thailand, and $49,000 in Los Angeles.

title: Guns and Congress
description: The Times's Mike McIntire on the close relationship between members of Congress and a sportsmen's charity pushing gun rights.

title: Despite Rangers Eye Injury, Union Rejects Calls for Mandatory Visors
description: The puck may have been flying about 75 miles per hour when it exploded off the stick of Flyers defenseman Kimmo Timonen and deflected into the face of Marc Staal near his right eye Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. Staal, a 26-year-old Rangers defenseman, went down as if shot, hands covering his face as he squirmed on the ice and bled profusely.

title: Microsoft Is Talking About the Future, a Lot
description: REDMOND, Wash.  There are technology companies that wont say anything about the futuristic inventions theyre tinkering with in their labs  Apple, for instance.

title: Latin America After Chvez
description: SO PAULO, Brazil

title: Pakistan, Under Cultural Siege, Is Buoyed by Book Festivals
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Assailed by jihadist attacks and the moral cudgels of religious conservatives, Lahores celebrated cultural vitality has waned somewhat in recent years. A famous kite-flying festival is no more; a performing arts festival vanished after being attacked; and music concerts take place in restricted circumstances.

title: Latest Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: President Obama travels to Connecticut Monday, where lawmakers last week approved stricter gun laws nearly four months after 20 children and six educators were shot and killed in Newtown, Conn.

title: What Young Republicans Want
How to Start a Good School Day
description: Breakfast is served every weekday morning to 12 million students across the country, courtesy of the Department of Agriculture. Free breakfast reduces hunger and can improve academic performance, but in New York City, too many students do not get the meals they need.

title: Proposed Dam Presents Economic and Environmental Challenges in Alaska
description: At a time when large dams are being taken down, not put up, the state of Alaska is proposing to construct one of the tallest and most expensive hydroelectric dams ever built in North America.

title: Face-Lift at Facebook, to Keep Its Users Engaged
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook plans to announce on Thursday a substantial redesign of its News Feed  a makeover aimed at both keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.

title: Charity Takes Gun Lobby Closer to Its Quarry
description: On a Monday evening in early February, two months into a national debate over gun violence after the massacre at a Connecticut elementary school, representatives of the firearms industry were wining and dining lawmakers in Washington.

title: Hugo Chvez
description: Hugo Chvez dominated Venezuelan politics for 14 years with his charismatic personality, populist policies and authoritarian methods before his death this week. His redistributionist policies brought better living conditions to millions of poor Venezuelans. But his legacy is stained by the undermining of democratic institutions and the embrace of malevolent foreign leaders like Bashar al-Assad of Syria and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

title: Death in the Forests
description: Day after day, the slaughter of the elephants continues at a record pace  25,000 killed in 2011, conservationists say, and more than 30,000 last year. A study from the Wildlife Conservation Society shows that 60 percent of all African forest elephants (a slightly smaller subspecies of the African savanna elephant) have been killed in the last decade for their ivory, leaving about 80,000 in their primary habitats in Western and Central Africa.

title: From One Budget Fight to the Next
description: Unable to stop the sequesters job-killing spending cuts, President Obama now says he wants to move past the endless wars of budget attrition. Though he still wants a long-term deficit deal, he said last week, it is time to turn to immigration, gun control, universal preschool, a higher minimum wage and voting reform.

title: Newly Discovered, Nearly Extinct
description: ITHACA, N.Y.

title: A Big New Power
description: Years from now, when the Supreme Court has come to its senses, justices then sitting will look back on the spring of 2013 in bewilderment. On what basis, they will wonder, did five conservative justices, professed believers in judicial restraint, reach out to grab the authority that the framers of the post-Civil War 14th and 15th Amendments had vested in Congress nearly a century and a half earlier to enforce, by appropriate legislation the right to equal protection and the right to vote. How on earth did it come to pass that the Supreme Court ruled a major provision of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 unconstitutional?

title: Cry About the Real Wolf
description: The White House horribly botched its messaging on the sequester.

title: Talk of the Town
description: Senator Rand Paul has his faults. Who among us can forget the time he ranted at a representative of the Department of Energy about the inadequacy of his bathroom plumbing? (You busybodies always want to do something to tell us how we can live our lives better. ... Ive been waiting for 20 years to talk about how bad these toilets are.)

title: The Good, Racist People
description: Last month the actor Forest Whitaker was stopped in a Manhattan delicatessen by an employee. Whitaker is one of the pre-eminent actors of his generation, with a diverse and celebrated catalog ranging from The Great Debaters to The Crying Game to Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai. By now it is likely that he has adjusted to random strangers who cant get his turn as Idi Amin out of their heads. But the man who approached the Oscar winner at the deli last month was in no mood for autographs. The employee stopped Whitaker, accused him of shoplifting and then promptly frisked him. The act of self-deputization was futile. Whitaker had stolen nothing. On the contrary, hed been robbed.

title: On Campus, Costly Target of Brazen Thefts: Nutella
description: This has all the makings of a tempest in a Nutella jar, which may not be as appealing as a Nutella milkshake, Nutella fudge or Nutella-stuffed French toast. Or stolen Nutella, which, apparently, has mouthwatering appeal at Columbia University.

title: Wall Street Ties in a Prospect for Deputy at the S.E.C.
description: Mary Jo White, who appears set to become a top Wall Street regulator, is seeking to allay skepticism about her spins through the revolving door between government service and private practice.

title: In the Streets of Venezuela, Bidding Farewell to Chvez
description: As Venezuela begins to adjust to life without President Hugo Chvez, questions abound, including how the nation will be run in the coming weeks and when a new election will be scheduled.

title: Aid After the Storm: Where Is the Church-State Line?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving Childrens Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Indias Economic Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Cardinals
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Bridge the Mideast Divide
Citys New Drink Rules Add Wrinkle to Coffee Orders
description: Call it the coffee conundrum: What to do when new sugary drink rules come between a harried, half-awake New Yorker and a morning cup?

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Mar. 7, 2013
description: After they call you back after the sixth interview, theres a part of you that wants to say, Thats it, Im not going back, but then you think, Hey, maybe seven is my lucky number."

title: New to the Neighborhood
description: Jennifer Dady and Samantha Kubler, who are sisters, are moving into a renovated apartment in Ocean Village, Queens, which, after decades of neglect, is being repaired under new management.

title: New Life Takes Hold After Hurricane and Blight
description: Jennifer Dady was not there when Hurricane Sandy sent ocean water into the courtyards of Ocean Village, an apartment complex on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens. She had never visited the place, though it is just a short distance from her own home in Broad Channel, where she spent the storm on her second floor, watching as seawater lapped across her living room.

title: A Leader Cries, I Am Chvez, as U.S. Seeks Policy Clues
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In the weeks leading up to his mentors death, Vice President Nicols Maduros imitations of President Hugo Chvez became ever more apparent.

title: In South Bronx, Memories of Chvez and the Aid He Gave
description: Lucia Solano became something of a stalker when Hugo Chvez visited the South Bronx in 2005.

title: Means of Divination
description: Administrivial Leaving For the A.C.P.T. Alert! Im off to cover the gathering of the word nerd tribe at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. If you arent planning on joining us, you can still register to solve online or by mail. Not only that, but you can follow along as I post about the tournament here in between puzzle posts, and if youd like to ask a question or give a shout out to anyone at the tournament, Tweet to me at @nytimeswordplay. Enjoy your weekend, and keep on solving!

title: A Respite in Efforts by Wal-Mart in New York
description: After losing a battle in September to open its first store in New York City, Wal-Mart Stores appears to have scaled back its efforts to gain a foothold in the nations largest city.

title: Wambach Nears Hamms Record
description: Abby Wambachs goal did not really matter in the outcome of the game.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 6, 2013

title: France: Sarkozy Dips a Toe Back In
description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy has sent a strong signal, through friends quoted in an article to be published on Thursday, of his supposedly reluctant willingness to return to politics out of duty, and only because it is for France. His remarks will be published in a center-right magazine, Valeurs Actuelles, whose editors said they had not spoken directly with Mr. Sarkozy but with close associates, who presumably did so with his encouragement. Mr. Sarkozy, 58, who narrowly lost his attempt at re-election in May, said that politics bores him to death, but that sadly, there may come a moment when the question is no longer, Do you want to? but, Do you have a choice? He predicted a social crisis and a financial crisis of an uncommon violence. Mr. Sarkozys comments were greeted with pleasure by his supporters and derision by his critics.

title: Corrections: March 7, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: High School Detention Was Never This Creepy
description: The bewildered high school student made to cool his heels in the vice principals office may not be the only one feeling hes been given a raw deal in The North Pool, the disappointing play by Rajiv Joseph that opened on Wednesday night at the Vineyard Theater. The audience too may come to feel it has been unjustly condemned to an afternoon of detention as this contrived drama moves through its sluggish paces.

title: Republicans, Led by Rand Paul, Finally End Filibuster
description: 1:27 a.m. | Updated WASHINGTON  A small group of Republicans, led by Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, stalled the Senate on Wednesday by waging a nearly 13-hour old-school, speak-until-you-can-speak-no-more filibuster over the governments use of lethal drone strikes  forcing the Senate to delay the expected confirmation of John O. Brennan to lead the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Amid Cuts, Does a President Dare Tee Off?
description: WASHINGTON  Fair or not, the extracurricular lives of American presidents are often measured by how they compare with the everyday pursuits of the people they lead.

title: Knicks Beat Lowly Foe, but Without Anthony, Its a Struggle
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  Carmelo Anthony stepped off the team bus, made the 30-yard walk to the visitors locker room and disappeared into the trainers area, out of sight, out of the cross-fire and out of the lineup.

title: Against the Bobcats, the Nets Receive Another Chance to Start Over
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Charlotte Bobcats have appeared on the schedule at fortuitous times for the Nets.

title: Michigan: Detroit Council Resists State Plan for Emergency Manager
description: Detroits City Council voted on Wednesday to challenge state plans to assign an outside emergency manager to shore up the citys troubled finances, even as Mayor Dave Bing announced that he would take no part in a challenge. We need to end the drama and infighting and understand that whether we like it or not, an emergency financial manager is coming to Detroit, Mr. Bing said. In a hearing planned for Tuesday, the City Council, which would lose authority with state intervention, is expected to argue that although Detroits financial circumstances are indeed dire, the city has a plan for repairing them. Gov. Rick Snyder, who last week deemed an outside manager a necessity for the city, would be asked to reconsider, a possibility Mr. Bing and others view as remote.

title: Amid Suffering, Animal Welfare Legislation Still Far Off in China
description: BEIJING  About animals, The question is not, Can they reason? nor, Can they talk? but, Can they suffer? So wrote Jeremy Bentham, the English philosopher, more than 200 years ago.

title: G.O.P. Senators Give Obama Dinner Thumbs Up
description: For Washington-watchers looking for positive signs from President Obamas unusual dinner with Republican senators on Wednesday night, there was this: Senators John McCain of Arizona and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma each gave waiting reporters a thumbs up as lawmakers exited the private dining room.

title: C.I.A.s History Poses Hurdles for an Obama Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  John O. Brennans first difficult challenge at the C.I.A. may not be confronting the agencys future, but its past.

title: Allan Calhamer Dies at 81; Invented Diplomacy Game
description: Allan Calhamer, a Harvard-educated postman who invented Diplomacy, which for more than half a century has been a favorite board game of calculating, caffeinated intellectuals, died on Feb. 25 in La Grange, Ill. He was 81.

title: Alvin Lee, British Blues-Rock Guitarist, Dies at 68
