description: Sometimes, thankfully, the most horrible seeming things are not what they appear to be.

title: Spare Times for March 8-14
description: Around Town

title: For White-Collar Defense Bar, Its Happening in Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  In 1986, Raymond Banoun, a Washington lawyer, organized an annual meeting for the white-collar criminal defense bar. He picked a warm-weather locale for the event, reserving conference facilities at the Boca Raton Resort and Club in Florida.

title: Egyptian Activist Subjected to Virginity Test Dropped From U.S. Honors List for Tweets
description: Last Updated, Friday, 10:43 a.m. The State Department dropped an Egyptian activist from a list of women to be honored in Washington on Friday after comments celebrating attacks on Israelis in Bulgaria and the American Embassy in Cairo were discovered in her Twitter feed, along with an anti-Semitic quotation from Adolf Hitler.

title: Wines of The Times: California Sauvignon Blancs
description: The panel tasted sauvignon blancs from California and overall found them to be a delight, easy to drink and easy to enjoy.

title: Wines of The Times: Paso Robles Zinfandels From California
description: The panel tasted 20 bottles of zinfandel from Paso Robles, Calif.

title: Wines of The Times: Pinot Noirs From the Russian River Valley
description: California pinot noirs that are approachable and well made  but not inspiring.

title: Rape and Murder, Precisely Like a Crime Years Ago
description: The Silence, Baran bo Odars first feature, begins in 1986, with the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl, who is attacked as she rides her bicycle near a field of summer wheat. The identity of her killer  and of his panicked accomplice, a younger man named Timo (Wotan Wilke Mhring)  is known to the audience, but the case is never solved. Then, 23 years later, it happens again: not just a copycat crime but an eerily precise duplicate.

title: Missing Nutella, Part 2: Columbia Puts Consumption Far Below Report
description: Columbia University on Thursday issued what a spokesman called a tongue-in-cheek university statement about the cost of Nutella that students have been eating in  or stealing from  campus dining halls.

title: A Blunt Instrument in the Climate War
description: As the title suggests Greedy Lying Bastards sees more value in urgency than in subtlety. For that reason alone this propulsively single-minded attack on climate-change deniers by Craig Scott Rosebraugh may just be the feel-good documentary of the year.

title: Pratt Students Talk About Fires Cost to Them
description: Two weeks after a fire at Pratt Institute ravaged the Brooklyn art schools historic Main Building and destroyed thousands of student artworks, The Local blog checked in with a handful of students who came by a makeshift dispensary to pick up donated art supplies.

title: He Just Wants a Woman to Settle Down With
description: Although Language of a Broken Heart, a romantic comedy written by and starring Juddy Talt, eventually drowns in clichs and predictability, it has a few decent moments of humor and some appealing performances that make it marginally better than most vanity projects.

title: For International Students, College Checklists for March
description: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselors Calendar, intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: This Weeks Movies | March 8, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on Oz the Great and Powerful, Beyond the Hills and The We and the I.

title: Syrian Rebels Interview Captured Government Officials
description: As our colleagues Duraid Adnan and Rick Gladstone reported, Syrian rebels seized the capital of the northern province of Raqqa on Wednesday, driving government forces from the town and capturing two high-ranking prisoners, the governor of Raqqa Province and the local chief of the ruling Baath Party.

title: The Dog Stays. Well See About the Stuff.
description: When Matt Kroll moved to the city after graduating from Colgate University, he lived with roommates in a three-bedroom duplex in the East 70s, paying $1,250 a month for a large bedroom with an en-suite bathroom and four closets. The situation, as well as the vast amount of space, worked out seamlessly, Mr. Kroll said.

title: Bailout Official at the Treasury to Leave Post
description: After more than two years of long train rides and selling off more than $120 billion in assets, the chief investment officer of the Treasury Departments bailout program is stepping down.

title: Justice Orders Mediation in Martha Stewart Case
description: After almost three weeks of testimony, the judge overseeing the lawsuits that Macys brought against J. C. Penney and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has sent the parties into mediation.

title: The Power of an Educated Woman
description: If Girl Rising is wholly a vehicle furthering the cause of girls education across the globe, its more of a multicolored bus to worthy destinations than a pace car. In this twist on the social-issue documentary, girls act out stories adapted from their own lives by writers from their own countries, including Edwidge Danticat, Aminatta Forna and Manjushree Thapa. The hybrid results feature occasional bold strokes alongside ad-pitch eye candy and sleeve-tugging.

title: Anthony to Miss Game Against Thunder
description: The Knicks will play without Carmelo Anthony on Thursday in their nationally televised game against the Oklahoma City Thunder. Coach Mike Woodson said he was told earlier in the day that Anthony would not be available.

title: The Time, and Place, to Buy
description: As both mortgage rates and housing prices head higher, home buyers may be wondering whether they ought to settle for whatever property they can get now, rather than risk paying more later.

title: 26 Ways to Die Gruesomely
A Brick-Watchers Favorites
description: Stone leaves me cold. Yes, Connemara green marble can be luscious, and the fossils in Indiana limestone may be mesmerizing, but the setting of stone  massive hunks of rock, which must be derricked into place  removes all sense of handwork. A stone wall is the creation of machines.

title: Report Suggests a Digital Divide Among Latinos
description: A digital divide between Latino Americans and white Americans may be closing, but a divide still exists between native- and foreign-born Latinos, according to a report issued Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: Chief Executive at Pandora Media to Step Down
description: The chairman and chief executive of Pandora Media, the company behind the popular Internet radio service, announced on Thursday that he would be leaving the company after nine years, on a day when Pandora reported growth and better-than-expected earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter and full year.

title: Net May Sit Despite His Strong Suit
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  With his shiny bald head, scraggly beard and Bunyanesque build, Reggie Evans is a physical oddity in the N.B.A., a 6-foot-8 power forward with shoulders rounded like bowling balls and wrists as thick as fire hoses.

title: Billionaires Club Is Set to Grow
description: Watching a ballet, you cannot help but marvel at the power of the movement, and the ability of the dancers to soar through the air, time and again, as if there were no limits to their stamina.

title: Neighborhood Joint: The Bay-Gull Store
description: The Bay-Gull Store, known for its cheese bagels, became a meeting place, kitchen and supply distribution center for the community in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Hopes, Maybe Misguided, That Food Will Breed Productivity in Capital
description: WASHINGTON  For all they fail to agree on, Republicans in Congress and President Obama have come to see eye to eye on at least one thing: four years of relatively little contact is no way to run the country.

title: Cals Win Over Stanford in Pac-12 Swimming Is Not Last Word
description: When Californias mens swimming and diving team won the Pac-12 championship on Wednesday night, ending rival Stanfords 31-year conference-title streak, the Bears received their trophy, and their banner, in a somewhat sour mood.

title: Regulator Expresses Doubts About an Auditors Procedures
description: The regulator for American auditing firms said on Thursday that it had found serious problems with procedures at PricewaterhouseCoopers and that the firm had failed to remedy them.

title: Plucked From Obscurity, and Now a Star!
A Cannery Row in Maine
description: All those daunting economic numbers that tabulate how many Americans are unemployed and how many factory jobs have been lost in the last 30 years can seem abstract until you run into a documentary like Downeast. This modest film by David Redmon and Ashley Sabin looks at one small effort to save a handful of jobs in Gouldsboro, Me. Its a tale of hope, frustration and disappointment that reminds us that behind all those big numbers are real human beings.

title: Obama Signs Expanded Anti-Violence Law
description: Standing with survivors of domestic abuse and sex trafficking, President Obama on Thursday signed into law a renewal and expansion of the 19-year-old Violence Against Woman Act, a long-sought victory made possible last month when House Republicans quit blocking the measures passage.

title: Cooped Up in a Trawler With Dad
description: Sometime during The Other Side of the Ice, Sprague Theobalds documentary log of his voyage through the Northwest Passage with his adult children, one family member impatiently describes his companions as a bunch of spoiled sourpusses. Thats not far off the mark. This tedious chronicle has the interest level of a home movie of a vacation with bickering and yammering left intact.

title: Hicks Nix Climate Fix
description: Everybody loves a farmer, judging by the popularity of this years hit Super Bowl ad about the virtues of those who coax food from dirt. And yet nobody wants to be one, with less than 1 percent of the population claiming it as an occupation.

title: Clinton Urges Court to Overturn Marriage Law He Signed
description: Former President Bill Clinton, who signed the Defense of Marriage Act in 1996 barring federal recognition of same-sex weddings, called on the Supreme Court on Thursday to overturn the law.

title: Serving Solace, One Bagel at a Time
description: Broad Channel is a marshy sliver of land nestled between mainland Queens and the Rockaways, a roughly 20-block string of one- and two-story houses often circled by white picket fences. People here drop their Rs when they speak about their mothas, their brothas, their neighbas. They are police officers and firefighters, often of Irish descent.

title: Justin Bieber Collapses During Show
description: Justin Bieber collapsed after becoming short of breath during a performance at Londons O2 arena on Thursday night, but finished his performance after being given oxygen backstage, Reuters reported.

title: China and the U.S. Join Forces on North Korea
description: David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, and Marcus Mabry, editor of Rendezvous, discuss North Koreas nuclear strike warnings and whether a new round of sanctions, written by China and the United States, can work.

title: After Chvez, a Chance to Rethink Relations With Cuba
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.

title: A Longtime Comedian, Still Without a Break
description: A rough-hewed and admiring portrait of the 54-year-old comedian Eddie Pepitone, The Bitter Buddha will, like its subject, struggle to appeal to a wider audience than comedy geeks and professional dyspeptics.

title: A Budget Delayed, to Little G.O.P. Sympathy
description: WASHINGTON  After a year-end fiscal crisis and protracted deficit-cutting negotiations between the White House and Congress scrambled the governments accounting, the president was more than a month late in meeting a deadline set by law for getting his annual budget to Capitol Hill in the new year.

title: Chvez Lives On
description: Throngs of supporters of the deceased Venezuelan president Hugo Chvez gathered in Caracas to see his embalmed body, which will be on permanent display.

title: Debating Chvezs Legacy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Heads of state from around Latin America flocked to Venezuela for the funeral on Friday of Hugo Chvez, a tribute to the undiminished drawing power of the charismatic leftist leader, although perhaps not to the lasting influence of his socialist-inspired policies.

title: Now a Little Spray Will Quickly Moisturize You
description: BODY lotion is used by 96 percent of women, according to the market research firm Mintel, and for moisturizer marketers hoping to increase sales, that, fittingly, is the rub. There are, after all, so few nonusers to sign on as new customers.

title: Our Wait-and-See Culture
description: JUST as the captain of the Rachel in Moby-Dick searched for his lost son and instead found Ishmael, doctors routinely reveal the unexpected while scanning for something else. What to do with this acquired information and how to follow up is becoming an increasingly vexing problem for physicians and their patients.

title: Its About the Work, Not the Office
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: The Orthodox Surge
description: In Midwood, Brooklyn, theres a luxury kosher grocery store called Pomegranate serving the modern Orthodox and Hasidic communities. It looks like a really nice Whole Foods. Theres a wide selection of kosher cheeses from Italy and France, wasabi herring, gluten-free ritual foods and nicely toned wood flooring.

title: The Market Speaks
description: Four years ago, as a newly elected president began his efforts to rescue the economy and strengthen the social safety net, conservative economic pundits  people who claimed to understand markets and know how to satisfy them  warned of imminent financial disaster. Stocks, they declared, would plunge, while interest rates would soar.

title: Arkansass Attack on Abortion
description: Republican-controlled legislatures have been working for many years to limit womens access to legal abortion care, but the Republican-led Legislature in Arkansas took the campaign to a new extreme on Wednesday when it overrode the veto of Gov. Mike Beebe, a Democrat, and ignored the Supreme Court to adopt the most restrictive abortion ban in the country.

title: Shareholders in Europe Demand Control
description: Voters in Switzerland this week overwhelmingly approved a referendum to give shareholders a binding say on executive pay. The Swiss measures are the latest and most far-reaching of various say-on-pay policies now in place or under consideration in many European nations. Denmark, Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands all have some form of voting on binding pay.

title: Next Step for Rivera: Closing a Career
description: PHOENIX

title: Angry at Public and Officials, Security Forces Strike in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Thousands of Egyptian security officers went on strike on Thursday in cities around the country to protest conflicting pressures from the government to crack down on street demonstrations and from the public to exercise restraint.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Mar. 8, 2013
description: Politics really understands a couple of things  votes and dollars. My father always used to tell me, No peso, no say-so.

title: Polar Bears Go to Court
description: The polar bear, whose long-term survival is threatened by the loss of Arctic sea ice because of global warming, got a welcome judicial assist this month, but a broader effort to protect it suffered defeat at an international conference on trade in endangered wildlife on Thursday.

title: Kenyan Election May Offer U.S. Tough Choice
description: The presidential candidate Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenyas first president, is accused of using a vast fortune to bankroll death squads that slaughtered women and children.

title: Mr. Brennans Excuse
description: John Brennan, the newly confirmed chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, has been at the agency for most of 25 years. He had two counterterrorism jobs during the administration of George W. Bush. In one, he compiled intelligence reports from 20 agencies (including the C.I.A.) for Mr. Bushs morning briefing. He was President Obamascounterterrorism adviser in his first term and an architect of the Obama administrations targeted killings policy.

title: Conservatives Revive Proposals for Term Limits
description: Texas conservatives were pushing for term limits 20 years ago, in an effort easy to dismiss as an attempt to flush Democrats out of the Legislature, the Congressional delegation and even some executive offices.

title: The Cellphone Records, Officer? You May Soon Need a Warrant
description: Seeking to regulate the use of cellphone records in investigations by law enforcement, Texas lawmakers are considering a bill that would require police officers and prosecutors to have a warrant before obtaining such records.

title: McIlroy Struggles, but Woods Soars at Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  The featured group at the Cadillac Championship on Thursday was like a marquee with one light burned out and another flickering. In a grouping of the top three players in the world, only one posted a luminous score.

title: Bronx Offers Case Study Over Future of Voting Act
description: Emerging from the bloody protests in Selma, Ala., the Voting Rights Act was initially heralded as a declaration that the federal government would no longer tolerate the open racism of the segregated South. But this narrow mandate to monitor elections in six Southern states grew quietly over the years, extending to unexpected corners of the country, including the Bronx.

title: Corrections: March 8, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Global Temperatures Highest in 4,000 Years
description: Global temperatures are warmer than at any time in at least 4,000 years, scientists reported Thursday, and over the coming decades are likely to surpass levels not seen on the planet since before the last ice age.

title: Shot After a Break
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This was a fun one, with a tantalizing mix of just easy enough to get it entries and Bald Mountain ranges like UINTA that most of us, and by that I mean me, needed to look up. Also, BEER GOGGLES. You can look it up.

title: In a Spinoff of Time Inc., Evolution Is Complete
description: The sprawling media conglomerate that Steven J. Ross joined together, Jeffrey L. Bewkes has put asunder.

title: Fiery, Salty and Brash, This Rose of Texas
description: She was a memorable figure even before she opened her mouth  that sculptured meringue of hair seemed to enter the room before she did  and an unforgettable one when she opened it, as salty wisecracks poured forth like popcorn from a machine. She was politically as blue as they come, but managed to win the leadership of a state as red-trending as any in the land. She acquired a national political profile without holding national office, and openly discussed her alcoholism before this became a rite of passage for famous figures from across the political spectrum.

title: As Fracking Increases, So Do Fears About Water Supply
description: CARRIZO SPRINGS, Tex.  In this South Texas stretch of mesquite trees and cactus, where the land is sometimes too dry to grow crops, the local aquifer is being strained in the search for oil. The reason is hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, a drilling process that requires massive amounts of water.

title: Is That a Movie or Video Game?
On Egypt, Focus on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Combating Cyberattacks
description: To the Editor:

title: A Police Program to Keep Tabs on At-Risk Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Pope and the Future Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Hit-Run Suspect Charged With Felonies
description: The suspect in a hit and run that killed a young pregnant woman, her husband and, later, their newborn son was returned to New York on Thursday and charged with three felony counts of criminally negligent homicide.

title: GTT
description: FORT WORTH

title: Stompin Tom Connors, Canadian Singer, Dies at 77
description: Stompin Tom Connors, a Canadian country-folk singer whose odes to the vast country he had roamed as a hitchhiking troubadour made him a beloved figure from the Maritime Provinces to British Columbia, died on Wednesday at his home in Halton Hills, Ontario. He was 77.

title: Diplomat Calls for End to Drunkenness During U.N. Negotiations
description: UNITED NATIONS  When the United Nations began renovating its Manhattan headquarters in 2009, one of the first casualties of the construction was the storied Delegates Lounge, where for decades the delicate work of diplomacy was aided by a good stiff drink.

title: Pope Wanted. Must Possess Magnetic Charm. And Grit.
description: ROME  No candidate for pope can have it all. But the cardinals who will elect the next pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church seem to be looking for someone who combines the charisma of Pope John Paul II with the grit of what one Vatican analyst called, only slightly tongue in cheek, Pope Rambo I.

title: Opposition Emerges to Cuomos Plan to Cut $120 Million for the Disabled
description: ALBANY  A plan by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to cut $120 million in financing for nonprofit organizations that serve people with developmental disabilities is emerging as a flash point in this years budget negotiations.

title: For a Baseball Traveling Man, an Unexpected Stop
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Pedro Valdes stepped inside the batting cage at Hiram Bithorn Stadium on Thursday morning and took cut after cut, each swing a perfect reproduction of the last. His mechanics were distinctive: the high leg kick and the way he whipped the bat across the plate, his left hand releasing after impact.

title: Cooper Union Board Delays Tuition Decision
description: Students, faculty and alumni of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art eager to learn the fate of the colleges distinctive no-tuition policy have been told to wait, again.

title: Lillian Cahn, Creator of the Coach Handbag, Dies at 89
description: Lillian Cahn, who founded the Coach Leatherware Company in a Manhattan loft in 1961 with her husband, Miles, and went on to help produce the shopping bag tote and other handbags that have become ubiquitous accessories in the wardrobes of well-heeled American women, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Nash and Gaborik Fuel a Late Surge for the Rangers
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Rangers left wing Rick Nash does not quite look all of his 6 feet 4 inches and 200-plus pounds without his equipment. On the ice, he looms much larger  as the Islanders found out Thursday night.

title: Joseph Kelner, 98, Dies; Led Kent State Lawsuit
description: Joseph Kelner, a lawyer who took on the sitting governor of Ohio, a former university president and the National Guard in a suit on behalf of the student victims of the Kent State shootings in 1970, died on Monday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 98.

title: New York City Says It Erred by Not Telling Parents of School PCB Leak
description: New York Citys Department of Education has apologized to parents of an Upper West Side elementary school for failing to inform parents that a faulty light fixture in a classroom leaked a toxic chemical in December.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 7, 2013

title: Closing Arguments Made, Jurors at Cannibal Trial Get Case
description: For much of his two-week trial, it had become clear that Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kill and cannibalize women, had become immersed in a bizarre fantasy world that revolved around a fetish Web site and his electronic communications with others.

title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Cab-Hailing by Smartphones
description: A State Supreme Court justice on Thursday blocked New York Citys plans to allow taxi riders to hail yellow cabs using smartphone apps, preventing the Bloomberg administration from beginning the program on Friday as scheduled.

title: Injuries Like Teixeiras Can Linger
description: JUPITER, Fla.  When Jose Bautista took the fateful swing that injured his left wrist on July 16, the Yankees hitting instructor, Kevin Long, winced along with Bautista from inside the dugout and told Yankees Manager Joe Girardi that Bautista would require surgery.

title: Philadelphia Officials Vote to Close 23 Schools
description: PHILADELPHIA  Officials on Thursday night approved closing 23 public schools, about 10 percent of the citys total, largely backing a plan by the school district to erase a huge budget deficit and reduce the number of underused schools.

title: Trial of Courier Tied to Terror Plots Ends, Putting Pressure on Hezbollah
description: VIENNA  For days after his arrest by the Cypriot police, Hossam Taleb Yaacoub kept to the cover story he had spent years building: He was a Lebanese businessman looking for import opportunities, not an operative for the Shiite militant group Hezbollah scouting potential targets for terrorism.

title: Grounding a Romance in Memories
description: Audiences familiar with the films of the Japanese animation house Studio Ghibli may be surprised to find no witches, forest spirits, wolf-goddesses or dragons in its latest production. From Up on Poppy Hill follows a more reality-based narrative  a budding romance between high school students, Umi (voiced by Sarah Bolger in the English-language version) and Shun (Anton Yelchin)  reflecting a place and time in Japanese history: the port city of Yokohama in 1963, as preparations for the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo are under way.

title: In Myanmar, Pro-Democracy Party Meets in Bid to Revitalize
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Nearly a quarter century after it was founded, members of the long-repressed pro-democracy party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi gathered here for their first party congress, an attempt to revitalize a political organization that some of its own members say lacks competence, efficiency and effective midlevel leadership.

title: N.H.L. Realignment Plan Gains Unions Approval
description: The N.H.L. Players Association announced Thursday its approval of the leagues realignment proposal, which would begin next season pending a vote next week by the Board of Governors.

title: Syria Opposition Leaders Delay Trip to Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders of the Syrian opposition have put off a visit to Washington for a series of high-profile meetings, including an expected stop at the White House, administration officials said Thursday, underscoring the challenge the United States faces in cultivating a still-evolving political movement.

title: A Letter to the University of North Carolina
description: The education department responds to a discrimination complaint filed with the D.C. Office for Civil Rights.

title: Students Initiate Inquiry Into Harassment Reports
description: The federal government has begun an investigation into claims that the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill routinely botched sexual assault and harassment complaints and mistreated victims  the latest in a series of similar allegations against high-profile colleges and universities.

title: Depth Puts the Blackhawks on Top
description: At 21-0-3, the Chicago Blackhawks have roared through half of their schedule without a regulation loss. Their 24-game run has shattered the previous N.H.L. record for longest season-opening point streak (16 games, by Anaheim in 2006-7) and is second to the overall single-season mark (35 games, by Philadelphia in 1979-80).

title: Knicks Spark Vanishes in a Flash
description: J. R. Smith is not Carmelo Anthony. He is a little shorter, a little lighter, slightly younger. He does not have the All-Star credentials or the gold medals or the fame. Where Anthony celebrates his dominance with a megawatt smile, Smith prefers a well-timed snarl.

title: Visualizing Poppy Hill
description: Images from the latest Studio Ghibli feature, From Up on Poppy Hill.

title: New Proposal to Merge Art Museums in Los Angeles
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which has been battered in recent months with defections of board members, criticism of its direction and precarious finances, would merge with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art under a proposal by the latter museum.

title: Half of New York City Marathon Entrants Opt for a Refund
description: About half of the runners registered for last years New York City Marathon, which was canceled after Hurricane Sandy, chose to have their entry fee refunded, and the other half chose to run in a coming marathon or half marathon, New York Road Runners said in a letter to runners.

title: Looming Budget Cuts Add to Problems at Nuclear Site
description: RICHLAND, Wash.  Here in the place where plutonium production for the nations bomb arsenal was elevated to industrial scale, in the rolling scrub country of south-central Washington, dangerous industrial pollutants are still getting into the soil only a few miles from the Columbia River.

title: N.F.C. Free Agency Preview
description: In the N.F.C., the 49ers returning weapons and 15 draft picks should help them maintain their dominance, with the Falcons at their heels if Tony Gonzalez returns. On the other side of the 2012 standings, the Eagles are looking to reboot with a new coach, and the Saints with a familiar one in Sean Payton, following his bounty-induced suspension.

title: Postal Service Looks to Sell Historic Buildings
description: Preservation groups say some of the buildings, which are for sale or being considered for sale, are architecturally significant and that their design elements and historic features should be protected.

title: Post Office Buildings With Character, and Maybe a Sale Price
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The lines are often long inside the Art Deco post office here under the palm trees. But few people complain these days when they visit that New Deal-era building.

title: On the Set With Matthias Schoenaerts
description: As the rain poured down on the drive from downtown Miami to the Ocean Queen Motel in Hollywood, the actor Matthias Schoenaerts, marking his first visit to Florida, said this isnt how he imagined the Sunshine State. Schoenaerts was right on time for a 7:30 a.m. pickup from the Eden Roc Hotel, despite having arrived from Brussels only hours before. Once everyone got to the motel, to shoot the Mens issue cover, the photo crew worked tirelessly to keep the breakfast catering out of the rain, while Schoenaerts stood on the motel balcony smoking hand-rolled cigarettes and taking iPhone photos of the Atlantic.

title: In From the Cold
description: The British establishment is a notoriously tough guard to crack particularly for the wave of oligarchs who have been making London their home. So how come Evgeny Lebedev makes it look so easy?

title: The Dark Side
description: Lightweight summer suits  traditionally in pale neutrals  get a sophisticated remake in deep navy and charcoal hues. The rising actor Max Irons steps into the picture.

title: The Gardeners House
description: For the peripatetic Madison Cox, home is a simple Moorish refuge in a city that has captivated like-minded wanderers for centuries: beloved books and plants share his view of the deep blue Strait of Gibraltar.

title: Good Morning, Matthias Schoenaerts
description: After a breakout performance in Rust and Bone, Hollywood is waking up to the raw magnetism of this Belgian import.

title: Breaking the Silence on Sexual Abuse
description: The man who was my abuser was a fine host, a good husband, a caring father, a respected elder whose generosity and kindness were as genuine as the fact of the abuse, Nilanjana S. Roy wrote in The Opinion Pages. These qualities were important, because they helped him conceal the abuse he carried out over a period of four years.

title: Advocacy Group to Monitor Reform Efforts in Public Schools
description: Diane Ravitch, the historian and former assistant education secretary who has become an outspoken critic of those who favor high-stakes testing, tenure reforms and other controversial measures aimed at the public schools, has joined with other education advocates to form a group that will grade and endorse political candidates.

title: Word of the Day | frond
description: frond \frnd\ noun

title: A.F.C. Free Agency Preview
description: In the A.F.C., active teams in free agency could be the Dolphins, who need receivers; the Colts, who need offensive linemen; and the Jets, who need, well, almost everything.

title: The Hunt for N.F.L. Players Is About to Begin
description: Twelve months ago, the N.F.L. universe was waiting for Peyton Manning to pick his landing spot and for Andrew Luck and Robert Griffin III to find their first professional homes. It was one of the most transformative off-seasons in recent years. Those, though, happen rarely.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) FASHION STAR Thirteen aspiring fashion designers, including a team of two, display their wares for buyers from Macys, Saks Fifth Avenue and, new in this second season, Express. The buyers will bid  or not  on the right to carry the creations exclusively. After each episode viewers can buy the winning clothing as well. At the end of the season one designer (or designer pair) will receive $3 million in orders from the three retailers. Jessica Simpson, Nicole Richie and John Varvatos return as celebrity mentors; Louise Roe, replacing Elle Macpherson, who is an executive producer, joins the show as the host.

title: App Smart Extra: Unusual Weather Apps
description: This week in App Smart, I wrote about a rather unusual class: Weather prediction apps designed to be simple or beautiful, and almost the antithesis of a brash TV weather report. Unlike watching a weather report on TV or reading one in a paper, an app of this type places interactive weather data in your hands, and can even make learning about coming rain or windstorms a very interesting experience.

title: News Quiz | March 8, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Nightmare Noir and Giddy Farce
description: Ministry of Fear

title: Long Island Landmark: Scary Since 1974
description: AMITYVILLE, N.Y.  Its a splendid day for a stroll past a haunted house: dark, damp, forbidding. A thin mist rises like a mourners veil above the gambrel roof, and low-slung clouds bathe the grounds in perpetual gloom.

title: After U.N. Vote on Sanctions, 2 Koreas Ratchet Up Threats
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The governments of North and South Korea escalated their hostile warnings to the highest level in years on Friday, with each threatening to annihilate the other a day after the United Nations Security Council unanimously imposed tightened sanctions on the North for its nuclear test last month.

title: Meet the Captain of Indias Womens Cricket Team
description: When she was a child, Mithali Raj, the Indian womens cricket team captain, trained in the art of Bharatanatyam, a genteel pastime for a proper young Indian girl. She loved performing and considered a career in dance.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 8
description: NEWS Ignoring threats of retaliation, the United Nations Security Council ordered new economic sanctions against North Korea on Thursday for its third nuclear test last month, unanimously approving a resolution that the United States negotiated with China, the Norths greatest protector. Rick Gladstone reports from New York, and David E. Sanger from Washington.

title: Syrian Rebels Agree on Deal to Release Peacekeepers
description: The United Nations said Friday that an agreement had been reached to secure the release of the 21 Filipino peacekeepers seized two days earlier by Syrian insurgents in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel. But it was unclear when the captives, the first international troops to become entangled in Syrias civil war, would be freed.

title: Cardinals Balloting for a New Pope Will Start on Tuesday
description: VATICAN CITY  The identity of the new pope fuels enormous anticipation, but the next most breathlessly discussed topic here has been when the cardinals will actually get down to choosing him.

title: With New Round of U.N. Sanctions, North Korea Threatens Pre-emptive Nuclear Strike
description: In U.N. Security Council Passes New Sanctions on North Korea, Rick Gladstone and Choe Sang-Hun write about the new sanctions imposed on North Korea this week and the increasingly harsh words coming from that countrys leaders.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, March 8, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: One Cat, Three Lives
description: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: Have You Ever Taken Something You Werent Supposed To?
description: Maybe you ate some cereal or candy from the stores self-serve bin before weighing it. Or, maybe you snagged a pack of gum without paying. Perhaps youve even done something more serious.

title: Kenya Race Is Said to Have Winner, but Rival Wont Concede
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenyas first president and a divisive political figure who has been accused of bankrolling death squads, appeared to have secured enough votes to win the race for Kenyas presidency early Saturday. But no official announcement was made, and the other top contender indicated that he would not concede defeat, raising worries of violence and chaos.

title: Contractor Killed on a U.S. Base in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A civilian contractor was killed on an American base Friday afternoon when three men wearing Afghan National Army uniforms stormed the gate and began firing, military officials said, in what appeared to be the second insider attack on Western troops this year.

title: Subaru Recalling 47,000 Vehicles That Could Start Themselves
description: Subaru is recalling about 47,000 of its vehicles with remote starters because the vehicles could start themselves, raising a concern about carbon-monoxide poisoning for vehicles parked in garages.

title: The Sequester and Fiscal Policy
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

title: Dynamo Gaining Blue Chip Approval
description: BBVA Compass Stadiums opening last May helped the Houston Dynamo toward its fourth Major League Soccer conference title in the past seven years, more than any other team during that period.

title: Is Europe Trying to Ban Pornography?
description: Europeans dont mind sunbathing topless or in the nude, in fact they rather enjoy it, and have for as long as anyone cares to remember. But if the European Parliament follows a recommendation soon to come before them, nudity of the sort you might see on a beach in Cannes could soon be illegal if its found on the Internet, construed as porn.

title: The Early Word: Exposition
description: In Todays Times:

title: Democrats Cry Foul Over Wednesdays Other Filibuster
description: 11:07 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.Senator Rand Paul may have staged a Senate-shaking filibuster Wednesday, but his was actually only the second most significant Republican filibuster of the day.

title: Killings Stir Fears of Ethnic Tensions in Chinese Region
description: BEIJING  At least four people were killed and eight injured in what appeared to be a knife fight in the city of Korla, a center of oil production in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, regional officials said on Friday.

title: Daily Report: Government Takes Legal Action Over Phone Spam
description: The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had recently filed eight lawsuits in federal courts around the country against companies it accused of ordering or engineering the sending of hundreds of millions of spam text messages to mobile phone users, Edward Wyatt reports on Friday in The New York Times.

title: The Professor, the Bikini Model and the Suitcase Full of Trouble
description: In November 2011, Paul Frampton, a theoretical particle physicist, met Denise Milani, a Czech bikini model, on the online dating site Mate1.com. She was gorgeous  dark-haired and dark-eyed, with a supposedly natural DDD breast size. In some photos, she looked tauntingly steamy; in others, she offered a warm smile. Soon, Frampton and Milani were chatting online nearly every day. Frampton would return home from campus  hed been a professor in the physics and astronomy department at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for 30 years  and his computer would buzz. Are you there, honey? Theyd chat on Yahoo Messenger for a while, and then hed go into the other room to take care of something. A half-hour later, there was the familiar buzz. It was always Milani. What are you doing now?

title: Q&A: Dumping the Windows Jump List
description: Q.

title: After Caregiving, Comfort in Having Helped
description: Caregiving is so all-consuming, it can seem impossible to imagine life after, when all of those responsibilities are suddenly gone.

title: British Insurer Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The British insurance firm Esure set the price range for its pending initial public offering on Friday that could value the company at up to $2 billion.

title: Easy A on Bank Stress Tests?
description: EASY A ON BANK STRESS TESTS? | Federal regulators found that banks, four years after the financial crisis, are better prepared to weather future financial shocks, according to the results of the so-called stress tests that the Federal Reserve released on Thursday. But the big question raised by some analysts was whether the Fed was too lenient in the tests, which now pave the way for the healthiest institutions to return money to shareholders, DealBooks Peter Eavis and Ben Protess write.

title: Friday Reading: Subaru Recalls Cars That Could Start Themselves
Seats of Power
description: The Dutch designer Sebastian Brajkovic deconstructs the historical elements of his tables, chairs and lamps while giving them a surreal, extruded quality that is only possible with high-tech machinery. He was barely out of school when pieces from his Lathe furniture series began to appear at design fairs and in the collections of major museums. The furniture, inspired by Brajkovics childhood interest in things that turned, like reel-to-reel tape decks, is the subject of an exhibition that opens on March 18 on the European campus of the Savannah College of Art and Design in Lacoste, France. Several of his pieces are available for purchase through the Carpenters Workshop Gallery in London and Paris.

title: Where is Indias Feminist Movement Headed?
description: On the night of June 28, 2012, the sarpanch, or the elected head of the village council, of Singar village in rural Haryana, his nephew and two other men allegedly abducted a 15-year-old girl. According to the official complaint, The Hindu reported, the four men beat her up and then took turns repeatedly raping her.

title: Unemployment at 4-Year Low as U.S. Hiring Gains Steam
description: The economy picked up speed in February, creating jobs at a pace that would substantially lower the unemployment rate. But Washington could put a stop to that.

title: Istanbul Museum Stroll: At the Pera
description: ISTANBULMany of the artists whose works are being shown at the Pera Museum these days might say they owed a debt of gratitude to the 75-year-old cubist painter Muhanna Durra of Jordan.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: New Ways to Swap E-Content and Time Warners Spinoff Trend
description: Apple and Amazon, the two largest purveyors of digital media, are working to create a kind of online swap meet where consumers can exchange music, movies or e-books, David Streitfeld writes. Buyers basically rent iTunes songs or Kindle books under the current system, with no way to transfer the content. The exchanges would allow users to trade content without reproducing it  when a song is traded, it disappears from its original owners library. Publishers and music companies are against this kind of trading, as they believe it could devalue their products, while libraries, which have not been able to dispense e-books very openly, are generally in favor.

title: Wunderman, Big WPP Agency, Gets a Major Makeover
description: Wunderman, one of the largest agencies inside the WPP agency holding company empire, is being overhauled to better respond, executives say, to the significant shifts in how marketers are seeking to reach consumers.

title: The Gun Report: March 8, 2013
description: Yesterday, the Senate Judiciary Committee passed a bill that would make it a felony for someone to illegally buy a gun on someone elses behalf.Stunninglyat least to meonly one Republican senator supported the bill, Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa.Heres what I dont understand: how can this bill be even remotely controversial?Straw purchasing, as it is called, is usually needed by people whose historya criminal record, perhaps?would make it impossible for them to pass a background check.Are Republicans really taking the position that convicted felons should be able to buy guns through intermediaries?What am I missing here?

title: From the Department of Things That Are Just Too Perfect
description: Limited time this morning, so light blogging. But I cant resist posting this. Jonathan Chait finds James K. Glassman, co-author of Dow 36,000  a 1999 book that argued, based on some creative double-counting and other innovations, that 36,000 was the right value of the Dow at the time of publication  claiming that this weeks Dow high vindicates his ideas. But thats not whats so perfect.

title: Opinion Report: Brennan and Torture
description: From the editorial page

title: K.K.R. to Buy Gardner Denver for $3.9 Billion
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Friday to buy Gardner Denver for $3.9 billion, ending a sales process of months for the maker of industrial equipment like blowers and compressors.

title: Waiting for Radiation Treatment, an Inspiration
description: Dear Diary:

title: Friedkin Retrospective Coming to Brooklyn Academy of Music in May
description: The filmmaker who taught moviegoers to be terrified of the New York City subway system (and also made Georgetown seem like a pretty horrific place) will be getting a warm welcome from Brooklyn. William Friedkin, the Academy Award-winning director of The French Connection and The Exorcist, will be the subject of a six-film retrospective in May at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was announced on Friday.

title: A Bad Year in Britain for Banks, Not Bankers
description: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

title: Eight Years Later, Failing Doping Tests
description: Six track and field athletes who competed at the 2005 world championships in Helsinki have been cited for doping after their samples were reanalyzed and found to contain banned substances, the sports international governing body said Friday.

title: In Filing, News Corp. Says It Will Provide $2.6 Billion to Its New Publishing Company
description: News Corporations new publishing company will receive a $2.6 billion infusion of cash and have no debt when it separates from the companys higher-growth cable channels and Hollywood studio this summer.

title: The Risks of Expanding Into Australia
description: In 2012, TerraCycle had $15 million in sales with operations in 22 countries, primarily in North and South America as well as in Europe and a little bit of the Middle East. A few months ago, we embarked on opening in our 23rd market, Australia.

title: Riveras Goodbye Tour
description: It seems we have entered a new era in athlete retirements. It has suddenly become boring to have a news conference to say your career is finished. No, now the in thing is to have a news conference to announce the impending retirement. Or even more humorously, leak to the news media that you are having a news conference on Saturday to announce your retirement after the season, as the Yankees Mariano Rivera has.

title: Cristian Mungiu on 'Beyond the Hills'
description: The Romanian director Cristian Mungiu discusses his latest film.

title: What Were Reading
description: Jeremiahs Vanishing New York: Big meatballs, you say? At least one change-resistant New Yorker has a beef with Carbone, the new restaurant from the Torrisi Italian Specialties team.  Jeff Gordinier

title: This Weeks Movies: March 8
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on on Oz the Great and Powerful, Beyond the Hills and The We and the I. Read all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Fire Damages Chez Panisse
description: 3:12 p.m. | Updated

title: At the S.E.C., a Revolving Door That Helps the Public
description: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.Both Mary Jo White, President Obamas nominee for chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and her likely enforcement deputy, Andrew J. Ceresney, had lucrative careers as white-collar criminal defense lawyers after leaving their jobs as federal prosecutors in Manhattan. Now that it appears that they are likely to rejoin the government, people have wondered, here and elsewhere, whether we should worry about picking law enforcement officials from the ranks of those whose rsums include stints prosecuting and defending the same sorts of people.

title: The Unequal Time Rule
description: LONDON  On Sunday a bombing in Abbas Town, a predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Karachi, killed 48 people and injured almost 200. Although it was just the latest incident in a sinister trend of sectarian violence in Pakistan, the attack prompted a swifter political response.

title: Solar Cells May Supplement Smartphone Batteries
description: Why dont power-thirsty smartphones incorporate solar cells, to reduce the reliance on batteries? Because in general, the kind of solar cell that can be fabricated in a lightweight, flexible and durable form does not capture enough energy per square inch to make it worthwhile.

title: Upbeat Jobs Report
description: The Times's Nelson D. Schwartz on a falling unemployment rate just as federal budget cuts begin.

title: Bin Laden Relative Pleads Not Guilty in Terrorism Case
description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment on Friday morning in federal court in Manhattan, where he was charged with conspiring to kill Americans.

title: Focus on the Family Works to Change Its Message
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  One Wednesday afternoon last month, Jim Daly drove a couple of miles from his office at Focus on the Family to a classroom building on the University of Colorados local campus. Short as the trip was, it carried Mr. Daly beyond his theological and political comfort zone. Such disorientation was the whole point.

title: Reality TV for the Red Planet
description: PARIS  As Wernher von Braun, the rocket scientist, used to say, the most overwhelming obstacle to exploring the cosmos isnt gravity. Its the paperwork.

title: Dignitaries Pay Chvez Tribute, as Venezuelans Express Grief and Misgivings
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  While dignitaries from around the world attended the funeral of Hugo Chvez on Friday, Anglica Rodrguez stood in a line that stretched close to a mile in hopes of getting a glimpse of him lying in state. But her older brother, Gustavo, was much farther away, geographically and politically, having moved to Panama over a year ago because he believed there was no future in a Venezuela run by Mr. Chvez.

title: Storm Damage Prompts Return of Old Subway Stop
description: Over its nearly 109 years, the New York subway system has inspired many questions. Why do pigeons ride the A train in Queens? What becomes of a failed MetroCard swipe, curdling at the turnstiles?

title: Open Arms for Daring Dance
description: What is New York Live Arts? Thats been a question in the dance world since an announcement in late 2010 that Dance Theater Workshop, a cherished institution that had been presenting and supporting experimental artists for 45 years, was merging with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. New York Live Arts became the name of the hybrid.

title: Common Core Practice | Environmental Issues in the Humanities Classroom
description: As regular readers know, our partner for this series is a ninth-grade humanities class at a high school in New Jersey recognized as one of the top S.T.E.M. schools in the nation.

title: A Senate of Prostitutes? Now Thats Opera!
description: Heliogabalus was a third-century teenage Roman emperor who dressed in womens clothes and prostituted himself in the imperial palace, appointed an all-female senate and put a dancer in charge of the praetorian guard. According to the historian Lampridius, he traveled with 600 chariots full of his male prostitutes, bawds, harlots and lusty partners in depravity and referred to one blond charioteer, Hierocles, as his husband. He also married and divorced five women. When he was 18 and had ruled for nearly four years, he was murdered by his own guard.

title: Into the Mystic
description: Why are tens of millions of people gathering by the Ganges?

title: A Public Apology for My Sofa
description: Dear Residents of 208 East 7th Street: Sorry for leaving that couch outside our door on the fourth-floor stairwell for two weeks.

title: Should I Pay for a Gas-Station Attendants Mistake?
description: When I go to the local gas station, I always give the attendant $20 and request that he provide me with that specific value of fuel (which always changes because of fluctuating gas prices). I repeat my request three times and show the attendant the $20 in my hand. During a recent visit, I glanced over to the pump to see that the attendant had made a mistake and exceeded our $20 agreement. I beeped my horn and waved my arms. Once I got out of my car, he came forward and realized his error. Because the amount of $20 was stated before the gas being pumped, should I stand my ground and agree to pay only $20? Or should I pay the difference (because I will obviously use the extra gas at some point in the future)? VINCENT MAZZOLLA, NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J.

title: The 2.24.13 Issue
description: THE EXTRAORDINARY SCIENCE OF ADDICTIVE JUNK FOOD

title: Harmony Korines Spring-Break Intentions Are Pure
description: You actually used real spring breakers in your new film, Spring Breakers, about a group of young women who commit armed robbery, do drugs and get into trouble. Did you feel like it was wrong to be filming these people half your age, cavorting naked?  I never really feel wrong while making movies. I know myself and I know that my intentions are pure and Im on the side of righteousness.

title: Who Made That Fishing Lure?
description: In the early 1960s, word spread of a fishing lure with seemingly mystical powers. In the lake country of Finland, an artisan named Lauri Rapala had handcrafted artificial minnows out of balsa wood that zipped around with realistic movements. Life magazine described the product as a lure fish cant pass up. Desperate to obtain the lures, anglers in America hunted for a way to buy them, usually with no luck. Imports were few, and bait shops often required a $20 deposit (about $160 in todays dollars) to rent a Rapala lure for the day.

title: Sons of Opera Moms Go Far Afield
description: On the closing track of their new album, Small Constructions, Ben Wendel and Dan Tepfer switch instruments, improvising a dialogue from scratch. That exercise in uncertainty revealed something essential about the personalities of Mr. Tepfer, a pianist by training, and Mr. Wendel, usually a saxophonist.

title: Tenor From the Dark Side of the Moon
description: This is the house of God. You cant turn me away.

title: The Rise of Part-Time Work
description: One of the more unsettling trends in this recovery has been the rise of part-time work.

title: One Hundred Seconds of Solitude
description: Recently, I found myself in a cabin in the snow-dusted New Hampshire woods of the MacDowell Colony working on a book thats due in few enough months to cause concern. It was a four-week residency, and wildly productive: without social distractions, the Internet or even decent cellphone reception, I churned out pages in record time, hitting and then exceeding my regular word count on a daily basis.

title: Inside the List
description: STRIKE I: Fifty years ago this week, there was no New York Times Book Review  there was, indeed, no proper New York Times at all, as the 1963 newspaper strike was limping to the end of its four-month run. When the Book Review returned on April 7 of that year, its front cover featured a cartoon of a despondent bearded man slumped in an armchair, his concerned wife soothing him: Cheer up, Harry. Youre not the only author who came out during the strike. And he wasnt: the first quarter of 1963 saw the arrival of big books from Gnter Grass (The Tin Drum), Betty Friedan (The Feminine Mystique), Anthony Burgess (A Clockwork Orange) and Alexander Solzhenitsyn (One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich), among many others. The Book Review did what it could to catch up  all four of those books received respectful reviews in the April 7 issue, and both The Tin Drum and The Feminine Mystique went on to become hardcover best sellers. But Burgess and Solzhenitsyn had to defer their gratification. A Clockwork Orange finally turned up on the paperback fiction list in 1972, after Stanley Kubrick had turned it into a hit movie. And Solzhenitsyn (like Grass) eventually won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: Editors Choice
description: STICKS AND STONES: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy,  by Emily Bazelon. (Random House, $27.) This intelligent study presents profiles of affected children and synthesizes current scholarship.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MAN WITHIN MY HEAD,  by Pico Iyer. (Vintage, $15.) This is a deeply felt meditation on the dual influences Iyers father and Graham Greene exerted upon him. Iyer, a novelist, essayist and travel writer, follows Greenes trail from his first novel, The Man Within, to classics like The Quiet American, exploring ideas of love, faith and divided identity.

title: In Praise of Rivera, Whats the Limit?
description: As Tyler Kepner writes of Yankees closer Mariano Rivera, who is expected to announce his retirement on Saturday, it is the postseason that has distinguished him from every other reliever, before or since: His regular-season earned run average is 2.21. His postseason E.R.A.  in 96 games against the best competition, under the most pressure  is 0.70.

title: Rising Stars
description: At first glance the protagonists of these two middle-grade novels, Better Nate Than Ever and I Represent Sean Rosen, have a lot in common: theyre both 13-year-old boys; they both have blue-collar parents and white-collar aspirations; they both have intelligent and original voices; and theyre both in the process of doggedly pursing their lifes passion to be in show business. And yet. . . .

title: Two Against the World
description: When I began reading contemporary fiction in high school, I remember feeling that each book was an absolute revelation. Whether I was reading Michael Crichton or Amy Tan or Tom Robbins, there had never been anything like it before in my life. The novels novelty passes, of course. Im 35 now. Ive read a dozen we brought back the dinosaurs and they are mad books. Ive seen the conventions, and Ive seen them interrogated.

title: South Side Story
description: Langston Hughess poem Dreams inspired the title of Blue Ballietts Hold Fast, which opens with clear signals of the distress to come  and of the effort people require to stay hopeful through hardship. Before the novel even begins, Balliett offers dictionary definitions of the words home, lost and time, as well as a brief, sobering statement about the thousands of homeless children in Chicago. She also describes a 2003 diamond heist, at the time the biggest in history, in which the thieves were caught but the gems never found. All these elements play a part in the story that lies ahead.

title: Thats Life?
description: It's life, Jim, but not as we know it. The familiar phrase, apocryphally attributed to Star Trek, encapsulates David Toomeys study of the search for species flourishing in places where life was thought to be insupportable. Weird Life is a breakneck tour through natural history, encounters of an impossible kind, researchers as weird as the organisms they pursue that leads the reader to wonder where science ends and fantasy begins.

title: Youre Special
description: How odd, I sometimes think, that so many picture books aimed at our youngest readers emphasize the same theme. You are special, they inform us in voices loud and soft. Celebrate your individuality, your uniqueness, your youness! The message is a fine one, I suppose, but I cant help wondering if the constant refrain contains a wee bit of adult projection. After all, the problem among young children is rarely that of mindless conformity. As all parents know, toddlers and early readers do not conform nearly enough, certainly not at mealtime. Or bath time. Or, really, any time.

title: Prayers for the Dying
description: A novelist once told me that he had given up writing journalism on the side because in journalism they only let you tell one story: Something Has Changed.

title: Brides Revisited
description: One morning recently, for 37 minutes, my husband talked to me about light bulbs: how their life expectancy is woefully overcalculated, why they have become so expensive, how the new efficient models are a cunning plot by manufacturers to make us spend still more. Knowing this would not even be the most boring conversation Id face that day, I nodded and tried to look interested. At some point it occurred to me that if I were to make a movie about marriage, its title might well be: Nodding and Trying to Look Interested.

title: Home and Exile
description: Ambitious is one of those words that shift shape as they cross the Atlantic, as Taiye Selasi is certainly aware. Born in London of Nigerian and Ghanaian parents, and raised in Massachusetts, Selasi has written an ambitious first novel  and I mean that in the best, American sense of the word.

title: Bodies for Hire
description: Thriller fans are not to be trifled with. We know what we want  clever protagonists, cunning killers, white-knuckle action and endlessly inventive variations on the fundamental strategies of a deadly cat-and-mouse game.

title: First Dibs on Warhols Photographs
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Love Knots
description: We dont, in America, have any writers quite like the Scottish novelist A. L. Kennedy. Her nearest local relative, perhaps, is Richard Ford in his Bascombe novels, with that funny, dark, vituperative voice that serves equally well for tragic and comic moments. Ford, though, possesses an underlying conviction about continuity  of character, of place, of history  while in Kennedys world everything is up for grabs, all the time. One might view her work as surreal, if that didnt imply a divorce from our own felt reality; one might call her sensibility ironic, except shes profoundly attached to what she describes. Kennedys novels repeatedly take on dark subjects (alcoholism, familial despair, sexual betrayal, loneliness), but they do so in a chatty, engaging manner that can sometimes make you laugh out loud. I wasnt surprised to learn that she has a sideline as a stand-up comic  though, again, this isnt something a serious American novelist would do. And A. L. Kennedy is as serious as they get.

title: Image of the Day: March 8
Well, Cheerio, Old Bean
description: By most measures, P. G. Wodehouse, arguably the greatest writer of comic prose ever, hardly had a life. That was what enabled him to be so productive. In the course of his very long career, he published close to 100 books, worked on more than 30 Broadway shows, put in a couple of highly paid stints as a Hollywood screenwriter and corresponded with practically anyone who sent him mail. Writing and doting over his beloved Pekingese lapdogs was pretty much all he did.

title: Shaky Foundations
description: In Wendover, Mass., a regular is a coffee with cream and two sugars. Wicked generally means very. And the word townie is not an insult, but a badge of honor.

title: Nasty Bits
description: North American readers care inordinately that fictional characters be likable. This preference is strange, given that few real people are thoroughly nice and that those few arent interesting. Surely what actually matters is that characters clear this vital hurdle: that they be interesting.

title: That Old-Time Irreligion
description: Susan Jacoby, whose previous books include Freethinkers and The Age of American Unreason, begins The Great Agnostic by asking why some people famous in their own time become part of our national memory and others fade into oblivion. A case in point is the orator Robert Green Ingersoll: a celebrity in his heyday at the end of the 19th century, he is almost utterly unknown today, even by those who would admire him if they knew more.

title: Brooklyns New Gentrification Frontiers
description: The subway commute to Manhattan is longer, and organic markets and stylish boutiques are fewer. But those are the trade-offs as the search for more affordable real estate in Brooklyn pushes deeper into neighborhoods that for some New Yorkers still evoke images of burned-out buildings, riots and poverty.

title: London Theater Journal: The Young and the Restless
description: LONDON  A cruel virus is gnawing at the entrails of James McAvoy, who is delivering a star turn that sears in the title role of Jamie Lloyds production of Macbeth at Trafalgar Studios. Among the symptoms: coughing, vomiting, gagging, falling down while hallucinating and smiling in the midst of dire situations, as if at some torturous private joke.

title: The Shrinking Government
description: For the 31st consecutive month, the number of government jobs in February was less than it had been a year earlier. There is an employment recovery, but it is confined to the private sector.

title: Mar. 10  16
description: The Foxy Lady Packs a Wallop

title: Adding Absurdity to Tragedy
description: MEXICO CITY  Its one of the trendiest, most expensive and nicest pieces of land around. Its in Polanco, the citys most expensive neighborhood, and on a corner of Paseo de la Reforma, the capitals most important avenue. Less than two kilometers away from the presidents residence and just five blocks from Masaryk Street, our own Park Avenue. It occupies 1,500 square meters of Chapultepec, the park in the middle of Mexico City.

title: Ras al-Khaimah, the Quiet Emirate
description: On a blistering day in Ras al-Khaimah, I hiked a small, winding staircase to reach an ancient fort, sun hat no match for the rays that beat down, mercilessly. At the top, I rested my legs and took in the valley below where green date palm farms stretched to meet jagged brown and black mountain crags.

title: Coughlin Makes Daily Show Appearance
description: The Daily Show with Jon StewartGet More: Daily Show Full Episodes,Political Humor & Satire Blog,The Daily Show on Facebook

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jeanine Basinger discusses marriage in the movies; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Charles McGrath talks about the letters of P. G. Wodehouse; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Off the Charts: A Dow Record, if You Ignore Inflation
description: The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks rose to a new record this week, but is still below its 2000 and 2007 highs when adjusted for inflation.

title: Do You Pay the Baby Sitter if You Cancel?
description: Once in a while, everyone cancels on the sitter (and once in a while, the sitter cancels on us). This weeks quandary: If you cancel on the sitter, should you pay her for her time, and how and when? I baby-sit this wonderful 2-year-old once a week, the questioner wrote. There have been issues in the past where theyve canceled on short notice (12 hours, and there was an emergency) and Ive been really accommodating.

title: On Set | Matthias Schoenaerts
description: With a string of movies on the docket, one of Hollywoods men of the moment kicks back with T.

title: A Long Road Back for the Dow Industrials
description: MORE than five years after the stock market began to slide in the fall of 2007, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered all of the ground lost in the recession and rose to new highs this week.

title: A State Backs Guns in Class for Teachers
description: South Dakota became the first state in the nation to enact a law explicitly authorizing school employees to carry guns on the job, under a measure signed into law on Friday by Gov. Dennis Daugaard.

title: The Case of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith
description: The Timess Mark Mazzetti discusses the details behind the capture and arraignment of Osama bin Ladens son-in-law.

title: Disney Stars Throw Off Their Past in Spring Breakers
description: LOS ANGELES  Selena Gomez got her start in Barney & Friends and became a cherub-cheeked teen idol on Wizards of Waverly Place, a Disney Channel series that has its final hurrah on Friday. But Ms. Gomez was not at a trendy hotel here to discuss Disney. (Eye roll: As if.) On her mind was her new movie  a druggy, violent, hypersexualized tale of innocence squashed called"Spring Breakers.

title: Environmental Expo Coming to MoMA PS1
description: Klaus Biesenbach, the chief curator at large at the Museum of Modern Art, and the director of MoMA PS1, the museums outpost in Long Island City, will devote the next six months to EXPO 1: New York, a sprawling exploration of the current state of the environment and social and political change.

title: The Male Bond
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Gosh, Were Bad Now!
description: On a sweltering night in Florida four bikini-clad girls sit outside a restaurant, drinking and smoking and singing... Baby One More Time, Britney Spearss salacious 1998 debut single and theme song for aspiring femmes fatales everywhere.

title: How to Stop a Home Invasion When the Intruder Has Four Legs
description: A FEW weeks ago, around 3 a.m., we heard some glass knocked over downstairs. In a daze  and not wanting to get out of bed  I thought it was our cats fooling around. But my older son, who was closer to the action, raced upstairs shouting that a raccoon was sitting on the mantle.

title: Money Advice for People in Boom-or-Bust Fields
description: MORE financial advisers are focusing on a single clientele, say, doctors or athletes. That would seem to make sense, since concentrating on a single group of people gives advisers greater insight into the needs of those people. And if the advisers do a good job, they will get that clients colleagues as clients.

title: A Freaky Fund-Raiser for a Storm-Ravaged Freak Show
description: Sideshows by the Seashore in Coney Island  home to some of New York Citys finest sword swallowers and contortionists  was battered last fall by Hurricane Sandy, as water from the ocean and from Coney Island Creek inundated its gift shop, its theater and its on-site watering hole, the Freak Bar, causing nearly $400,000 in damage.

title: New Defense Chief Visits Reality of Combat in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In his first overseas trip as defense secretary, Chuck Hagel landed on Friday in Afghanistan, a country fast fading from political debate and public interest at home, but where 66,000 American troops continue to experience what he described as the ugly reality of combat and the heat of battle.

title: Ready to Share a Life of Front-Page News
description: KILGORE, Tex.  Michael Morton and Cynthia May Chessman politely told the approximately 200 guests invited to their wedding on Saturday to resist giving them gifts. Instead, they asked relatives and friends to donate to the Innocence Project, the nonprofit group founded at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University that uses DNA evidence to free the wrongfully convicted from prison.

title: Londons Odd and Empty Corners
description: You know, guv, that really gets on my goat, Billy Allardyce said from the front of the taxi, his amplified voice a warble of Abbey Road reverb.

title: New Mexico Confronts Drunken Driving
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  For years, New Mexico has had one of the highest rates of alcohol-related traffic deaths in the nation. And during each legislative session, it seems, lawmakers wrestle with how to make the states highways and rural roads safer, usually spurred by the latest horrific accident.

title: She Set the Job Requirements; He Got Hired
description: The ad that appeared in the Personals section of Craigslist in February 2008 contained a list of its own, a long one: requirements for anyone wishing to go out with Jessica Delfino, a comedian and singer in New York.

title: The Obamas Hosted the Clintons at the White House
description: President Obama has been quite the social butterfly lately, dining with Senate Republicans and hosting bipartisan lunches. Now comes word that the president and the first lady had their first double date with Bill Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, over dinner at the White House last Friday.

title: The Headache in Housewares for J.C. Penney
description: Ron Johnson, the former head of retail at Apple and now the chief executive of J. C. Penney, testified this week that hed never ask anyone to breach a contract. He said he believed in perfect integrity as a matter of principle, and he readily agreed with the premise that its important to honor contracts even if the terms are unlikable at the time.

title: Gridlock Plagues the New Online-Only SimCity
description: Releasing a video game that paying customers cant play is about as consumer-friendly as selling the next Jonathan Franzen novel exclusively on the moon. But thats what Electronic Arts accidentally did this week with SimCity, an attempted revitalization of its 24-year-old franchise of city-building strategy games.

title: Book Review Podcast: Matrimony in the Movies
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Judith Newman reviews I Do and I Dont, Jeanine Basingers new book about the history of marriage in the movies. Ms. Newman writes:

title: Singled Out (for the Single Supplement)
description: Single supplement.

title: Fatal Fiscal Attractions
description: Oh, my. David Greenlaw, James Hamilton, Peter Hooper, and Rick Mishkin have published an op-ed in the WSJ (where else?) based on their recent paper on debt, deficits, and interest rate spreads. They really shouldnt have  the argument in that paper collapsed under scrutiny almost the moment it was released.

title: A Journey Into Films, Beginning at a Bronx Community Center
description: After three weeks in upstate New York, Alex Barrios was excited about coming back to the city. The sight of the Empire State Building, its shiny spire peeking over the jagged suburban landscape, set his heart racing.

title: In the End, No Substitute for Anthony
description: With Carmelo Anthony injured, out of the lineup and unable to carry them through crunch time, the Knicks had an opportunity to explore a few alternatives on offense in the final minutes of their 1-point loss to the Oklahoma City Thunder on Thursday night.

title: The Small Picture: Working Nights
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Noise Clash in Gowanus Pits New Hotel Against Arts Buildings Drummers
description: The Gowanus Arts Building and the Fairfield Inn & Suites, neighbors in a fast-changing industrial corner of Brooklyn, are separated by only the hotels parking lot.

title: Harlem Shake and the New Meaning of No. 1
description: For the third week running, Baauers trap novelty Harlem Shake takes the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, largely because of the magazines new tabulating system that takes into account Youtube views. Jon Caramanica talks with host Ben Ratliff about trap, listening, appropriation, memory, impotent rage and disembodied dance crazes.

title: Will He Retire? Rivera Wont Say, Yet
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mariano Rivera went through a normal workout Friday and said he was ready to pitch Saturday, but didnt give any indication about his other planned activity for that day: announcing his retirement.

title: Does This Ad Make Me Fat?
description: OBESITY is a problem everywhere, with significant consequences for personal health and public spending. People weigh more than ever  but why? If we can find the causes of obesity, we can try to eliminate or counter them.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Austin, Tex.; London; Eisenach, Germany
description: Moontower Comedy and Oddity Festival, Austin, Tex. Not too long after recovering from the hangover left by the commercial debauchery of South by Southwest, Austin will play host to a smaller, funnier festival. The Moontower Comedy and Oddity Festival, April 24 to April 27, will feature more than 90 comedians, from Bill Hader to Reggie Watts (above) to Maggie Maye. The event not to miss: an air sex competition. Remember when air guitar was cool?

title: Champions Leagues German Accent
description: By the middle of next week, there is a good chance that for the first time since 1998 there will be three German teams, of the eight remaining, in the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League.

title: Big Social Costs Tallied in Regions With Scant Energy Access
description: After reading this Guardian article  Energy poverty deprives 1 billion of adequate health care, says report  I dug into the underlying analysis this morning. The report, by the British nonprofit group Practical Action, is a valuable effort to assess the full costs of inadequate energy access through indirect impacts on hospitals, schools and the like. Click here forthe executive summary.

title: Federal Austeritys Bite on Job Growth
description: The latest jobs report could have been even better. Employers added 236,000 jobs in February, evidence that the economy is gaining strength, but analysts generally agree that the number would have been higher if the federal government had not increased payroll tax rates in January.

title: J.&J. Loses First Case Over Faulty Hip Implant
description: A jury in Los Angeles on Friday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay more than $8.3 million in damages to a Montana man in the first of more than 10,000 lawsuits pending against the medical products maker in connection with a now-recalled artificial hip.

title: Weekend Fare
