description: Drawing on Jewish traditions and ingredients from the farm, Joan Nathan, the acclaimed cookbook author who is also a regular contributor to The Times, will lead a Passover Seder cooking class on Saturday from 1 to 2:30 p.m. at the Stone Barns Center for Food & Agriculture, 630 Bedford Road, in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. Tickets are $40 per person and include a tasting of the holiday meal.

title: Pennsylvania and Virginia, Where the Nation Was Shaped
description: You can almost see them, spectral figures moving through thick forest, ragged, rugged men who endured astonishing hardship just to get here, creeping with their muskets in the sticky haze of a July morning in central Pennsylvanias Appalachian Mountains. They wouldnt even know the name of this place, Gettysburg. Yet their blood would become the ink that sets down the towns name for history.

title: Service Problems
description: What if you threw a war and no one came?

title: North Koreans Fond of Leader, State TV Suggests
description: As The Lede has reported previously, displays of official joy are quite common in North Korea, even before Rodmania swept the nation. On Thursday, though, the producers of state televisions news bulletins appeared to outdo themselves with a long report on the frenzied reaction from the populace as the nations young leader, Kim Jong-un, inspected military units deployed near the countrys disputed maritime border with South Korea.

title: Video of Preparations Inside the Sistine Chapel for Conclave
description: Vatican officials announced Friday that the 115 cardinals from around the world will officially begin their conclave, the official process used to elect the successor of Pope Benedict XVI, on Tuesday.

title: Nanny Charged With Murder Appears in Court
description: Yoselyn Ortega, a nanny charged with fatally stabbing two children she cared for on the Upper West Side last October, appeared in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Friday for the first time since her arrest. Ms. Ortega, 50, who had been unable to attend several prior court dates, was taken to court from the prison ward for psychiatric patients at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens. A psychiatric exam to evaluate her fitness to stand trial has not been completed. A large scar on her throat could be seen above the gray jumpsuit she wore. The authorities have said she turned a knife on herself after attacking Lucia Krim, 6, and Leo Krim, 2, in the bathtub of their apartment.

title: Wheelies: The Can Crime Get More Dull? Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Fitch Downgrades Italian Debt, Citing Political Turmoil
description: ROME  The Fitch ratings agency cut its assessment of Italys sovereign credit by a notch on Friday, citing the abrupt emergence of fresh political turmoil that could push one of the euro zones most pivotal economies, already in a deep slump, into a further slowdown.

title: Bulgur: A Wheat to Remember
description: Looking for a new staple for your pantry? Try bulgur, suggests Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Umami Burger to Open in Williamsburg
description: Umami Burger, the Los Angeles burger chain that has drawn a cult following, has already stirred some excitement in New York by announcing it will open in Greenwich Village this spring, and in the World Financial Center early next year. Now it has revealed plans for a third location, in Brooklyn.

title: The Mets New Home
description: Two panoramic views of Citi Field, the Mets new ballpark in Queens, with audio from Mets executive Dave Howard.

title: Popcast: Harlem Shake and the New Meaning of No. 1
description: For the third week running, Baauers trap-music novelty Harlem Shake takes the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, largely because of the magazines new tabulating system, which takes into account YouTube views. (Baauer is also the cover story in the magazines current issue, which tells you something about how a publication can make itself a large part of its own story.)

title: Bookshelf: Bats and Baskets
description: New picture books include a look at baseball in Japan and biographies of Willie Mays and Babe Ruth.

title: The Week in Pictures for the New York Region for March 8
description: Subjects include the reopening of Fairway in Brooklyn, a brightly painted school in the Bronx and the St. Patricks Day Parade in the Rockaways.

title: Bookshelf: Bats and Baskets
description: TAKE ME OUT TO THE YAKYU  Written and illustrated by Aaron Meshon.  40 pp. Atheneum. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)

title: A Bin Laden Son-in-Laws Video Messages
description: As my colleagues Marc Santora and William Rashbaum report, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda, was charged with conspiracy to kill Americans in federal court in Manhattan on Friday.

title: Timberwolves Still Hoping to See What They Can Do
description: This isnt the season the Minnesota Timberwolves thought they were going to have. With nearly three-quarters of their games played, they should have been on the road to the playoffs. The new additions Andrei Kirilenko, Chase Budinger and  they hoped  Brandon Roy were supposed to shore up the wing rotation and keep things on track until the return of Ricky Rubio from last seasons anterior cruciate ligament injury.

title: Beef, Pepper and Parmesan: Its Italian
description: Italians enjoy going out for a good steak, but a steak in Italy isnt necessarily an individual slab. Yes, there is the famous Florentine bistecca, a large T-bone steak served blood rare. But just as often, restaurants offer a sliced steak, called tagliata, essentially a nice thick piece of beef that is grilled, then carved. Its simple and delicious but impressive nonetheless, and you really dont have to go to a restaurant to enjoy it. In fact, it is quite easily prepared at home, year round. Tagliata is what I make for dinner whenever a fuss-free meal is required.

title: A Magazine, a Plan, a Contest  Symmys!
description: Awards season isnt over quite yet. On Sunday the winners of the first annual Symmys awards, for outstanding palindrome achievement, will be announced in Portland, Ore. The name of the awards is a palindrome, of course, and so is the date on which theyre being handed out: March 10, or 3/10/2013.

title: Meet Memoto, the Lifelogging Camera
description: AUSTIN, TEX.,  Facebook and Instagram have conditioned people into sharing photos of their most memorable moments  vacations, parties, weddings, meals and outings with friends.

title: The Porch Is Gone, the Memories Remain
description: To encounter the remains of a destructive fire, like the one that ravaged a portion of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., early Friday morning, is a traumatic experience, even if no one was injured. As a longtime member of the Chez Panisse family I was the chef there on and off from the mid-1980s through 2011  my heart goes out to Alice Waters and the staff. It is especially traumatic for those who know the history of the place. In the wake of such an accident, memories are everywhere.

title: Dressing for Travel to Any Hemisphere
description: Miguel Jontel Pimentel, 27, a recording artist known professionally as Miguel, won the Grammy this year for best R&B song with his single Adorn. A native of Los Angeles, he currently lives in the citys Playa Vista section.

title: Mejia Is Back in Mets Camp
description: Jenrry Mejia returned to the Mets facility in Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Friday morning ready to resume what has been a troublesome spring training camp for him thus far.

title: In New Euro Boss, a Hard-Line Future
description: LONDON  When George Zannakis, a Greek sound engineer, heeded his investment advisers guidance in January by plowing half of his life savings into a high-yield bond issued by the Dutch bank SNS Reaal, he did not consider it a high-risk proposition.

title: More Units Going Up in a Snap
description: A vacant lot on Broadway between Academy and 204th Streets in Inwood is littered with rubble and concrete pilings. But in a matter of weeks, this 50-foot-wide sand pit will be transformed into a seven-story apartment building, with finished bathrooms, maple cabinetry and 10 terraces. It is not a magic trick, but rather the result of modular, or prefabricated, construction.

title: Bill Cunningham | Upfront
description: Paris is the center of high style during its Fashion Week, when buyers, journalists, design students and designer friends gather.

title: A Deadly Blizzard, and Then Some Lullabies
description: On Tuesday evening the Oratorio Society of New York presented a concert of American choral music at Carnegie Hall, built around a new work by Paul Moravec, The Blizzard Voices. This oratorio about the Childrens Blizzard of 1888 had originally been scheduled to receive its New York premiere last November, but in a case of nature dislodging art imitating nature, that concert was canceled because of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Finance Remains a Complex, Interconnected World
description: Bankruptcy professors are known for their exciting social lives, and thus the previous weekend found me flipping through the annual reports of several bond funds to see what was happening in the spicy end of debt investing.

title: Astoria Park, 1:49 P.M.
Crane Collapse
description: A crane collapsed onto a high-rise apartment on East 91st Street on Friday morning.

title: How to Read Like a Culinary Entrepreneur and Cocktail Pundit
description: Mario Batali writes the weekly What Im Drinking Now minicolumn for The One-Page Magazine.

title: Energy and Climate on the White House Agenda
description: President Obama hosted a casual off-the-record meeting with a diverse group of energy and climate change experts at the White House on Thursday evening, officials and participants said Friday.

title: The Ratings Behind the Renewals
description: Amid what has been a dire winter for many broadcast programs, Fox renewed four shows this week: The Following, New Girl, The Mindy Project and Raising Hope.

title: Photo Replay: March 8
description: A look at the day in sports, including freestyle skiing in Voss, Norway, and the World Baseball Classic in Japan.

title: Red Bulls on the Road Again
description: 7:11 p.m. |Update

title: Piranesi as Designer
description: A new show at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum introduces us to the full sweep of the Venetian artist's career.

title: In China, Checklist for a Home Seller: First, Get a Divorce
description: SHANGHAI  When the Chinese government announced new curbs on property prices this month, homeowners bombarded social networking sites with complaints. They formed long lines at property bureaus to register to sell their homes before the restrictions went into effect.

title: Mayor Bloomberg on Meet the Press
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urges President Obama to lead the national discussion on gun violence in America today on Meet the Press.

title: Debating the Merits of the Boom in Merger Lawsuits
description: Shareholder merger litigation is everywhere these days. And recent developments, including a decision in Delaware over the now completed acquisition of Transatlantic Holdings, show not only that merger litigation is here to stay, but also that courts still dont know what to do about the proliferation of suits.

title: Mayor Bloomberg on Meet the Press
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg shares his views on the solution to the spate of gun violence in America and how hes applied them in governing New York City.

title: Re-examining Board Priorities in an Era of Activism
description: Ira M. Millstein is the co-chairman of the Millstein Center for Global Markets and Corporate Ownership at Columbia Law School and a senior partner at the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges.

title: Crane Collapse in Manhattan
description: An interactive look at what happened in Fridays crane collapse.

title: Mayor Bloomberg on Meet the Press
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on the issue of gun control.

title: For Parents-to-Be, a Few Financial and Legal Tips
description: Once you hold your new baby in your arms for the first time, the last thing on your mind is all of the money-related tasks and decisions you have to make.

title: Week in Review: In Stress Tests, No Bank Left Behind
description: Banks pass Feds tests; critics say it was easy. | Wall St. ties in a prospect for deputy at the S.E.C. | Senate report said to fault JPMorgan on loss. | Banks find more wrongful foreclosures among military members. | Selling the home brand: a look inside an elite JPMorgan unit.

title: Joy Behar Leaving The View
description: Joy Behar, an original member of the 16-year-old ABC talk show The View, says that she has decided to leave the show at the end of its current season.

title: For Kentucky, a Painful Fall From the Peak
description: ATHENS, Ga.  The dismantling, for the time being, of Kentucky Coach John Caliparis mystique came in a well-lighted hallway inside Georgias Stegeman Coliseum on Thursday night. The scene resembled a politician offering a mea culpa at a news conference, except this was a basketball coach acknowledging he had squandered talent.

title: Mayor Bloomberg on Meet the Press
description: New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg talks with NBCs David Gregory about gun control in America and how he believes gun violence should be addressed politically.

title: Russians Bring Dashcam War Reporting to Syria
description: As much of the world first learned last month, when so much extraordinary footage appeared of a meteor screaming across the sky above the Urals, Russians are unusually fond of mounting cameras on the dashboards of their cars to record the many bizarre things that happen on their roads.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Tony Starks Struggles
description: With Iron Man 3, starring Robert Downey Jr., out on May 3, the arrival of the Iron Man Omnibus to our hardcover graphic books best-seller list couldnt be better timed. The book, at No. 3 on the list, offers 944 pages of intrigue following the hero and the man under the armor, Tony Stark. These stories include Starks fight against alcoholism as well as a time-travel clash with Doctor Doom, a throwdown with the Incredible Hulk and a cadre of supervillains (Madame Masque, Whiplash, the Titanium Man and more).

title: Looking to Others for Investing Lessons
description: Paul Sullivan this week begins a short series of Wealth Matters columns about financial advisers who focus on a single clientele, like doctors or lawyers, and what they have learned about the behavioral tendencies of that group.

title: CTIA Wireless 2009: New Cellphones
description: The new crop of cellphones on display this year at the CTIA Wireless Show in Las Vegas.

title: Skiing Kashmirs Peaks
description: One of the worlds most remote and troubled regions offers remarkable ski conditions to intrepid travelers.

title: When the Pope Is Chosen, His Tailors Will Be Ready
description: For a select group of Catholics, the news most eagerly awaited from the conclave of cardinals gathering in Rome to elect a new pope is less about who that man is than how big. They are the craftsmen of Ditta Annibale Gammarelli, papal tailors since the 18th century.

title: Examining the Conclave
description: The Timess Daniel J. Wakin reports from Rome, where the voting process to elect a new pope is set to start on Tuesday with no clear front-runner.

title: Irish Soda Buns
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make an American version of a St. Patricks Day classic.

title: 92nd Street Y Announces New Concert Season
description: The 92nd Street Y will open its 2013-14 concert series in the Kaufmann Concert Hall on Oct. 19 with a program of late-19th- and 20th-century piano sonatas by Russian composers. Or with a program of Liszt compositions and arrangements. Or with a program of Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Shostakovich. As part of the Masters of the Keyboard series, Valentina Lisitsa, a Ukrainian pianist who has recently gained a big following on YouTube, will make her New York recital debut playing one of three programs to be chosen by the general public and the audience through online voting. Three other programs in the Masters of the Keyboard series each feature single programs, to be played by Olga Kern, Yefim Bronfman and Peter Serkin.

title: The Sweet Spot | Lets Go to the Movies
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the ups and downs of experiencing films in a theater: enjoy the popcorn, mind your manners and please share the armrest.

title: Big Ticket | A Marble Marvel For $9.46 Million
description: The Marble House, the eccentric and extravagant TriBeCa triplex that embodies one mans ode to all of the design possibilities inherent in marble, especially the Carrara variant, sold for $9,466,099.64 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Welcome to Deadwood
description: The National Rifle Associations noxious dictum about guns  that the answer to too many gun deaths is more guns, always more guns, whether for soldiers, police officers, wilderness hikers, mall shoppers, moviegoers or schoolteachers  should be dead and discredited by now.

title: Death Toll Rises After Cyclone in Myanmar
description: A major international relief operation was being mobilized as the government raised its estimate of the death toll.

title: Obama Speaks at Tucson Memorial Service
description: President Obama spoke at a memorial service for those affected by the shooting in Tucson.

title: The Sweet Spot: Lets Go to the Movies
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the ups and downs of experiencing films inside a theater  enjoy the popcorn, mind your manners and please share the armrest.

title: How Did You Prepare for Your Baby?
description: Once you have figured out how to put your baby to sleep, and even if you have managed to get some sleep yourself, youll probably still be too exhausted to address the many ways your little one is likely to affect your financial life.

title: Movie Review | 'Oz'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Oz the Great and Powerful."

title: Pictures of the Day: Jordan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Jordan, Mexico, Kenya and India.

title: Echoes of the 30s, Inflation-Adjusted
description: GENEVA  The 83rd International Motor Show, which opened here last week, features the world premieres of 130 vehicles. These include an unprecedented number of models with seven-figure prices, including the $1.3 million LaFerrari supercar, the $1.15 million McLaren P1, the $1.6 million Koenigsegg Hundra and a trust-fund-busting Lamborghini, the $4 million Veneno.

title: An Embarrassment of Riches
description: Jerry Garrett offers a look at some of the highlights at this years International Motor Show in Geneva.

title: For Demi Lovato, No Airbrushing Required
description: LOS ANGELES  On a recent sunny afternoon, Demi Lovato emerged from a black tractor-size SUV and made her way onto a stage set up at the Grove, an upscale outdoor mall here, where she was to perform at the opening of a new Topshop. As screaming Lovatics (as Ms. Lovatos fans proclaim themselves) flashed iPhones and waved Magic Marker signs at the pop star, she looked a little sheepish. This was understandable: her right foot was encased in a black silver-studded cast that resembled a giant ski boot.

title: Major Grocer to Label Foods With Gene-Modified Content
description: Whole Foods Market, the grocery chain, on Friday became the first retailer in the United States to require labeling of all genetically modified foods sold in its stores, a move that some experts said could radically alter the food industry.

title: Sycamore Turns Heads With Its Retail Shopping Spree
description: A private equity deal maker is turning heads in the fashion world.

title: Looking Back at the Fall 2013 Collections
description: Despite the number of shows, its easy to pick out the winners.

title: Those Who Nailed It for Fall 2013
description: ITS OVER. You can rest now. No more volleys of pencil skirts and models in static-fuzz wigs (easily the hottest accessory during the four-week run of fall fashion shows).

title: Wallets Disappear, Followed by Cash via A.T.M.s
description: The not-at-all-disreputable-looking grand larcenist has struck again.

title: Its Valentinos Name, but Their Vision
description: PARIS  The setting was a white-paneled reception hall in the stately Salomon de Rothschild mansion, where a long dining table had been set with blue-and-white Delftware candelabras and vases filled with irises and hydrangea blossoms. Among them, silver platters were piled, obscenely high, with unblemished raspberries, blackberries, strawberries and red grapes.

title: Sugar Added, Fairies Optional
description: Ive had real Irish soda bread, and Ive had ersatz Irish soda bread. Despite my usual preference for foodstuffs rooted in authenticity, in this case I like the fake version better.

title: Suicide, With No Warning
description: TO his large, loving family and many friends, Kerry Lewiecki was an optimist and problem-solver, with a big laugh and impressive hugs. Early in the summer of 2010, he graduated from the University of Oregon with dual degrees in law and conflict resolution; invitations went out for his August wedding to his longtime girlfriend.

title: Greek Yogurt Touts Appeal of the Real Thing
description: Chobani, the Greek yogurt brand that has enjoyed explosive growth, is opening wide its corporate wallet to rapidly expand a marketing initiative that began last month during the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards.

title: A Design for the National Museum of African American History and Culture
description: The winning design for the new museum in Washington, by a team led by the architect David Adjaye, as well as other entries to the competition.

title: The Prince of Ballet, Leaping Onto a New World Stage
description: David Hallberg, the statuesque ballet star who is a principal dancer at both the storied Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow and American Ballet Theater in New York, is theoretically the type of front-row coup that warrants a fit of camera flashes.

title: In Florence, Food Gets Its Fashion Week
description: Much of what makes Florences annual artisanal Italian food fair, Pitti Taste, more enjoyable than say, its sibling, the mens fashion week, Pitti Uomo, is the simple fact that participants are encouraged to eat. In its eighth year, Pitti Taste opens on Saturday for three days and has become something of a gastronomic fashion show, where more than 250 of Italys standout producers show what they are made of with craft beer and grappa, ballooning panettone, enormous wheels of unctuous cheese and peppery and delicate olive oils. Over the last several years, the event has catapulted small beer brewers like 32 Via dei Birrai into stardom. Buyers and foodies alike descend to see where the culinary barometer is tilting. The fair includes on-site chats and presentations, like this years colloquium about grandiose cake design led by the expert pastry chef Roberto Rinaldini of the famed Pasticceria Rinaldini di Rimini, and discussions about how to encourage your childs inner foodie presented by Vogue Bambini. The event is held in Florences impressive Leopolda train station, but there are more than 100 supplementary food events all over the city at hotels, restaurants and cultural sites like the Gucci museum, where the house chef will be teaching the secrets of cookie-making.

title: Not Just a Fashion Statement
description: What kind of man wears a bow tie?

title: I Guess Its a Form of Flattery
description: OK, I guess I have to say something about this Sachs and Scarborough piece. Lets do it by numbers.

title: The Falcons Will Get a New Stadium
description: After years of negotiations, the Falcons will get what they wanted: a new stadium to replace the Georgia Dome, which is barely two decades old.

title: Toyotas Bottom Feeder Finally Makes Some Waves
description: Considering Toyotas expertise in democratic, affordable transportation  Corolla, Camry, Prius  youd think it would rule the realm of entry-price cars.

title: Movie Review | 'The We and the I'
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "The We and the I."

title: Movie Review | 'Beyond the Hills'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Beyond the Hills."

title: A Fun-Size Car, Made Fun
description: With the improved Yaris, Toyota seems to recognize that an ultra-affordable car can play a small but important supporting role in its lineup.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath home in a converted 18th-century Dutch barn on 7.5 acres, in Belle Mead, N.J.

title: Packing 123 Horsepower Into 3 Cylinders
description: DETROIT  Craig Daitch needed to fly to Los Angeles on short notice, and he had more than the usual amount of baggage.

title: Calling Off Those False Alarms
description: Out-of-line Chrysler steering wheels and misbehaving Subaru transmission sensors are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A home in a converted Carroll Gardens church, a Soho co-op with an expansive living/dining area and a West Village Condo with floating staircases and exposed iron beams

title: Gentle Viola, Breathless Violins
description: It is always inspiring to see a group of musicians enjoying themselves, and the Ensemble Matheus was clearly having a good time at its concert on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall. The members of this early-music group, based in Brittany, France, and led by the conductor and violinist Jean-Christophe Spinosi, smiled and laughed at one another throughout the show.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Fighting Facebook Ads, and Chinese Surveillance
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Big East Agrees to Sell Name to Breakaway Group of 7
description: The wrenching realignment that has turned the Big East Conference inside-out has meant not only the loss of members but now a divorce from its name. On Friday, the Big East announced an agreement to sell its name to the seven Catholic universities that are breaking away this summer to form a basketball-only conference.

title: For Love Bugs or Sundered Couples, Choreography That Lasts
description: Its no fluke that one of Paul Taylors most profound gifts is his ability to create choreographic structures enduring enough to withstand generations of dancers. But at the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which is in residence at the David H. Koch Theater this month, there are performers so embedded in the fabric of his work that its becoming impossible to imagine the stage without them.

title: Butler Heading Into Home Finale
description: Butler holds a 23-7 record heading into the last weekend of the regular season, including a 73-62 win over Massachusetts on Thursday night. The team is 10-5 in Atlantic 10 play and is currently in fourth place in the league, which would earn Butler a first-round bye in next weeks Atlantic 10 Tournament at Brooklyns Barclays Center.

title: Pace to Recognize the Legacy of Jule Styne
description: They will be playing a lot of composer Jule Stynes best known songs at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University on Saturday night  selections from Broadway shows like Funny Girl and and Gypsy and Peter Pan.

title: For Purists, a Classic Version of Irish Soda Bread
description: Despite the red hair, I havent a drop of Irish blood in my veins. But every March I look forward to St. Patricks Day, because its an occasion to bake soda bread.

title: Tunisia Includes Independents in New Cabinet
description: CAIRO  Tunisias prime minister announced a new cabinet on Friday, handing over key ministries previously headed by members of the ruling Islamist party to independent figures in an effort to calm the worst political crisis since the countrys revolt more than two years ago.

title: Remembering the 320th
description: The 320th Anti-Aircraft Barrage Balloon Battalion, the only all-black unit in the D-Day landings, were among those being remembered on invasions anniversary.

title: Honoring the Soldiers Who Fought at Normandy
description: President Obama led a solemn tribute to the valiant Allied soldiers who stormed the beaches at Normandy 65 years ago.

title: The Week in Pictures from Culture for March 8
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Book Tries for Balanced View on Roosevelt and Jews
description: For decades, it has been one of the most politically charged questions in American history: What did Franklin D. Roosevelt do  or, more to the point, not do  in response to the Holocaust?

title: Students in Hazing Case Make Court Appearance
description: The three teenage boys sat up straight, eyes ahead, in a criminal courtroom in the Bronx on Friday morning. They wore dress shirts and ties. On a wooden bench behind them sat their supporters: More young men, in khakis, corduroys and other preppy attire; one wore brown leather boat shoes with no socks, even though it was snowing outside.

title: Norman, Show Our Guest His Room
description: ALDERGROVE, BRITISH COLUMBIA  Say what you will about Norma Batess notorious motel and her unusually vigilant child-rearing practices. The woman makes a darn good breakfast.

title: Freak Folk Courts the Plain Folk
description: On his latest release, Mala, the hippie-redux singer-songwriter Devendra Banhart can still be as loopy as he was on his first albums a decade ago. He calls himself a low-bottom bottle-fed baby and sings about a nun who quits an abbey to work as a V.J. (For those who dont recall when MTV played videos, that abbreviation stands for videodisc jockey.) Reflecting his mothers Venezuelan background and his time spent there as a child, Mr. Banhart croons two songs in Spanish.

title: In the Company of Men
description: It is a particular pleasure, as a woman, to get to edit a mens issue. In fact, it is the great pleasure of journalism  and by extension of being a reader  to be able to step outside ones own world and dive into another as an interested outsider. This month we feature a wonderfully diverse array of men, all admirable in distinct and varied ways.

title: George Shultz Presses Congress to Act on Climate Change
description: George P. Shultz, a former Republican cabinet secretary, seems an unlikely figure to fight for climate change, which is largely the political turf of Democrats.

title: Commodity Futures Agencys General Counsel to Depart
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced on Friday that its top lawyer would soon retire, a departure that comes after the agencys recent legal crackdown on Wall Street.

title: Dianne Wiest on Stage
description: A look at some of the actresss stage roles in New York.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 8
description: More photographs.

title: Bicyclist Riding Against Traffic Dies After Being Hit by 2 Cars
description: A bicyclist traveling the wrong way in a lane on New Utrecht Avenue in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was killed early Friday morning after two cars struck him near the intersection at 58th Street, the police said.

title: A Rapper, His DJ and the Sounds of Bompton
description: Its consistently thrilling how much DJ Mustard makes from so little.

title: The Climate Scientist and the Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroit Metal Largely Absent at Swiss Show
description: GENEVA  The evolution of the American automakers in Europe, and their presence at the motor show here, is a study in contrasts. To Chrysler, Ford and General Motors, Europe no longer presents a great opportunity to sell American cars in foreign markets. Not so long ago, those attending the Geneva show could see, touch and kick the tires of a much wider array of American iron than they can today.

title: Border Enforcement and Immigration Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Evading State Lending Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Americas Global Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Bipartisan on Child Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Updating a Rentals Kitchen

title: Cuomo Voices Mixed Optimism for Chances of Campaign Finance Proposals
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that he was cautiously optimistic that he could push through the Legislature this spring an overhaul of the states campaign finance laws, one of the top priorities in Albany for government reformers and progressive groups.

title: T Mens Fashion Spring 2013
description: The actor Matthias Schoenaerts, photographed by Bruce Weber, is the cover subject of the spring mens fashion issue of T. Learn how the Belgian import is dealing with becoming an American sensation. Inside: read Guy Trebays essay about how the average male is shedding schlumpiness for style, meet five exceptionally talented young poets (and read their work) and visit the Stockholm studio of the perfumer Ben Gorham. Additional highlights from the magazine include Sporting Goods, a round-up of athletic gear, The Male Bond, in which Andrew OHagan ruminates on male friendships, and The Modern Man, a primer on the frank irony to dressing stylishly today. See all from the issue >>

title: A Restaurant Built on Chickpeas
description: Even though Hummus Elite is mostly about hummus and has only 10 tables, a friend urged me to try it. I did, and was enchanted by almost every dish I ate. In the hummus category, these dishes included hummus with beef, hummus with eggplant, plain hummus and hummus with mushrooms and truffle oil. In the nonhummus category, they consisted of silky, roasted eggplant; ground beef-and-lamb kebabs fragrant with coriander; and, most surprising of all, an eight-ounce hamburger that, like the best backyard burgers, tasted as if it had been cooked over charcoal instead of just gas.

title: Pango Says Its App Can Cut Waiting Time at Parking Garages
description: For drivers who regularly face the challenges of parking in Manhattan, the age of technology has provided precious few options. The automated, robot-operated garage holds promise down the road and may ease the pain. For now, though, theres a smidgen of help. Its called Pango.

title: The Week in Pictures From Business for March 8
description: The Dow Jones industrial average topped its nominal record high, Martha Stewart took the stand in a trial over sales of her products, and employment data for February suggested the recovery was gaining speed.

title: A Spot to Sample the Mediterranean Diet
description: In light of recent research showing that a Mediterranean diet  one rich in vegetables, fish and olive oil  lowers the risk of heart disease, Greek restaurants look more appealing than ever these days. Opa Grille, which opened in October in Williston Park, has its share of meat and cheese on the menu, but diners seeking healthful fare can find plenty to enjoy here.

title: Aiming for the Red Planet
description: Several private companies have plans in the works for missions to Mars.

title: Florida: Guilty Plea Expected in Hazing Death of Drum Major
description: One of a dozen Florida A&M University students now charged with manslaughter in the hazing death of a drum major plans to plead guilty in the hope of receiving a more lenient sentence, his lawyer said Friday. The student, Caleb Jackson, 24, who is in the Leon County Jail on a probation violation, was on the bus where the drum major, Robert Champion, was beaten in 2011. Mr. Jackson is expected to plead guilty next month in an Orlando court. Chuck Hobbs, his lawyer, said Mr. Jackson was not one of the students who beat Mr. Champion, 26. The guilty plea comes in response to a decision by Jeff Ashton, the newly elected state attorney for Orange and Osceola Counties, to add manslaughter charges to existing felony hazing charges.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of Fairway in Brooklyn, a brightly painted school and a St. Patricks Day parade in the Rockaways.

title: Old World Dcor, and a Cosmopolitan Menu
description: Its position along the Aspetuck River on a remote stretch of Route 202 in Marbledale, Conn., a few miles north of New Milford, makes the White Horse very much a country pub.

title: Ohio: F.B.I. Enters Inquiry at Oberlin
description: The F.B.I. is investigating racist and antigay messages left around Oberlin College in the past month and the possible sighting of someone wearing a Ku Klux Klan-type outfit, a college spokesman said on Friday. A student newspaper, The Oberlin Review, reported that the college removed two students last week in connection with the vandalism; Oberlin would not comment on that report. The newspaper also reported that the recent incidents were probably linked to online racist messages dating back almost a year.

title: Indian Flavors, Cool, Minimalist and Modern
description: In these days of trendy fusion this and fusion that, diners often have to guess what lies ahead when a restaurant claims modernity. In the case of Coriander, in Larchmont, several factors combine to create a modern feel. The dcor is low key: a contemporary beige and charcoal color scheme, brightened by a row of charming white lanterns in the aisle that leads to the dining room. A small handful of cross-legged mustachioed Rajasthani figurines and a dramatic Shiva as Nataraja the cosmic dancer set the Indian theme.

title: Honoring Prince at Carnegie Hall
description: Performers from Questlove to Elvis Costello celebrated the music of Prince.

title: Howard Has Broken Bones in Back; Likely Out for Qualifiers
description: Goalkeeper Tim Howard has two broken bones in his back, his English club, Everton, announced Friday, an injury that will almost certainly rule him out of two important World Cup qualifiers for the United States national team later this month.

title: When Each Stylized Flourish Proclaims Itself
description: On Wednesday night Ballet Flamenco de Andalusia opened a short season at City Center. When the music was live, it was wretchedly overamplified; often the dancers and singers performed to a taped orchestral accompaniment that sounded less like Andalusia than like a Hollywood idea of Spanish sounds. Two star dancers, Pastora Galvn and Rubn Olmo, exuded absurd mannerism far more than they did flamenco rhythms. And the third, Roco Molina, though a marvelous dancer, performed in an idiom that came across as pretentious.

title: For a Night, at Least, Nothing Compares to Prince
description: One concert could hardly contain the multiplicity of Princes enormous songwriting catalog over the 35 years since he released his debut album, For You, in 1978. The Music of Prince, a tribute concert on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, tried hard. The program strove to capture a broad swath of Princes work, through funk and rock and pop, from lust to spirituality to apocalypse to partying. It included hits, rarities and even some of Princes dance moves (but alas, no leaping splits). It was the ninth annual Music of concert produced by Michael Dorf, the owner of City Winery, to benefit music programs for underprivileged children.

title: The Drone Question Obama Hasnt Answered
description: THE Senate confirmed John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency on Thursday after a nearly 13-hour filibuster by the libertarian senator Rand Paul, who before the vote received a somewhat odd letter from the attorney general.

title: Rules of Order Dictate Pitching at World Classic
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Tony Pena likes to be involved in the flow of games. He was involved during his major league career as a catcher, and he remains involved as the manager of the Dominican Republic team at the World Baseball Classic. He refuses to be confined to the dugout; that much is clear.

title: Teaching Viewers to Hear the TV With Eyes Only
description: This week ABC Family did something that no commercial television channel in the United States had ever done: It broadcast an entire episode of a show, Switched at Birth, in American Sign Language, with next to no oral dialogue.

title: Night of the Stars
description: The Night of the Stars tournament was held on Feb. 28 at the Richmond Bridge Club in London.

title: Almost Certainly, the Thief Didnt Know What Was in the Box
description: Ring! Ring! Ring! The man pushed buzzer after buzzer outside the building on Prospect Park West on a February afternoon. Either he knew someone in every apartment and had picked the wrong day to visit, or he was doing some homework for his Burglary 101 class.

title: The Darkness of an Irish Morning
description: MY father came from Ireland and he had the gift of the gab. Part of the reason the Irish developed the gift of the gab was simple. They lived on an island. They had to get along. Not that they did get along. But they had to try. So a style of speaking developed that allowed them to say awful things. With charm.

title: A Small Stables Bridge to the Derby
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The bloodlines that are part of the Kentucky Derby contender Verrazanos story run deep, and not just with the horses.

title: Visions of Drones Swarming U.S. Skies Hit Bipartisan Nerve
description: WASHINGTON  The debate goes to the heart of a deeply rooted American suspicion about the government, the military and the surveillance state: the specter of drones streaking through the skies above American cities and towns, controlled by faceless bureaucrats and equipped to spy or kill.

title: A Former Hostage Worries for Those Left Behind in the Desert
description: NMES, France

title: An Entry Reserved for Those With Guns
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  At the State Capitol here, a legal concealed gun is the equivalent of an E-ZPass.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Italy Uneasy as Government and Vatican Drift, Rudderless
description: ROME  The leader has resigned. There are scandals over sex and corruption. Finances are in disarray. And no one knows who will step in to try to clean up the mess.

title: Blocked Bids to Fill Judgeships Stir New Fight on Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON  A fresh feud over federal judgeships has again begun to agitate the Senate, with Republicans so far blocking President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nations most prestigious and important appeals court.

title: A Lifetime of Portraits and Shots of Graffiti
description: TRENTON  Preparing to lead a reporter through the exhibition Jon Naar: Signature Photography at the New Jersey State Museum here, Mr. Naar paused before starting into what he called a fast-forward through his life.

title: Off the Path to Recovery
description: The February employment report shows some notable improvements that, if sustained, would herald a real recovery. Partly boosted by increased employment in the construction industry, the number of new jobs jumped to 236,000 last month, continuing a gradual upward trend.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: As Police Strike, Egypt Tensely Awaits Verdicts in Soccer Riot
description: As my colleague in Cairo David Kirkpatrick reported, a quickly spreading strike among the police force has added to a growing sense of chaos and lawlessness in Egypt, where opposition to President Mohamed Morsi has been newly energized in recent days by anticipation of a second round of verdicts over the deaths of more than 70 soccer fans in a stadium riot in Port Said last year.

title: Congress Gets in the Way
description: If there is any hope for a peaceful resolution of the nuclear dispute with Iran, President Obama needs Congress to support negotiations. But negotiations and compromise are largely anathema in Washington, with many lawmakers insisting that any deal with Iran would be unacceptable  a stance that would make military action by Israel and the United States far more likely.

title: Doubling Back for the Roadkill
description: Squirrel gravy is such a delicacy in Appalachia that there is a RoadKill Cook-off each year in the hollows of West Virginia. Lawmakers in Montana get the drift. The lower house of the Montana Legislature recently approved a measure that would allow citizens to salvage fresh roadkill and take it home for dinner.

title: One Way to Cheer Up: Cheer Harder
description: You probably think rabid sports fans are a bunch of lonely, disoriented souls who try to fill the holes in their lives by attaching themselves to a team. And youre probably wrong.

title: Curtains, and Hope for Renewal, Going Up
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  When the Suffolk Theater opened as a movie house in 1933, it was heralded by one local newspaper as a splendidly designed structure, beautifully and modernly equipped and furnished.

title: Miles to Go Before He Sings
description: David Steinberger, 41, is the chief executive of ComiXology, sometimes called the iTunes of comics, which has about 33,000 comics in its library and adds about 300 a week. A classically trained singer, he has a masters degree in performance from the Manhattan School of Music and an Advanced Certificate in performance from Juilliard, as well as an M.B.A. from New York University. Mr. Steinberger, who moved to New York from Kentucky in 1994, lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Kittson, a graphic designer, and their two cats, Buddy and Sweetheart. On Sundays, he often sings in church and runs with his wife in Central Park; they plan to run the NYC Half on March 17.

title: Setback to Boeings Hopes for Longer Range for 787
description: With the technologically advanced 787, Boeing offered airlines big fuel savings and better comfort for passengers. It also promised something else: the ability to reach just about any airport on the globe without having to stop.

title: Cautious Approval for a Plan to Merge a Citys Museums
description: LOS ANGELES  For many people in the philanthropic and cultural swirl of Los Angeles, the proposal seems a welcome response to a conflict that has riveted this citys art world for five years: A merger of its two biggest museums, ending a long-simmering feud, combining two arts collections, and rescuing one of them, the Museum of Contemporary Art, from a spasm of personnel turmoil and fiscal decline.

title: Saving the Day
description: One way to appreciate the conceptual oddness of daylight saving time is to imagine it as a new idea just cooked up by the Obama administration. An individual mandate to change your clocks twice a year, every year, to enable a government redistribution of sunshine. Or, put another way, the feds confiscation of more than 300 million privately held American sleep hours, taken for eight months without interest payments or a penalty. All to make the nation healthier, wealthier and wiser, and for somewhat dubious energy savings. House Republicans would not be pleased  would you? Would you reset the clock radio, or would you demand that the government stay out of your bedroom and leave your dream life alone?

title: A Dangerous New Normal in College Debt
description: We are reaching a crisis point in this countrys higher education system.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Man Who Helped Image of Wal-Mart Steps Down
description: The chief burnisher of Wal-Mart Stores reputation is leaving the company as its image is under new strains.

title: In Cannibal Case, Deliberations Go On
description: The jury in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, rape and cannibalize women, was sent home on Friday after competing its first full day of deliberations without reaching a verdict.

title: Exercise May Help Protect Children From Stress
description: Physically active children generally report happier moods and fewer symptoms of depression than children who are less active. Now researchers may have found a reason: by one measure, exercise seems to help children cope with stress.

title: McIlroy Finds His Comfort Zone, but Woods Is Long Gone by Then
description: DORAL, Fla.  Making 17 birdies in the opening 36 holes is a first for Tiger Woods in his PGA Tour career, but it is not the neatest trick he has pulled off at the Cadillac Championship this week. On Friday on the ninth hole of Dorals Blue Monster, Woods made the thousands of fans following him essentially disappear.

title: An Installation of Dirty Politics and Illusion
description: In the simplest sense, Deb Sokolows Some Concerns About the Candidate at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford is a clever installation driven by a single conceit: a fictional narrative in which a Congressional candidate hires a campaign consultant to help him get elected. The protagonist, referred to throughout the exhibition as you, is a campaign worker who falls under the candidates spell  but ends up documenting an unfolding tale of intrigue and deceit.

title: Queens Congressman Attends Chvez Funeral
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Gregory W. Meeks, a New York Democrat who developed a little-known but significant relationship with President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela over the last decade, attended Mr. Chvezs funeral on Friday as part of a small United States delegation.

title: In Parts of Syria, Lack of Assistance Is a Catastrophe
description: SAWRAN, Syria  The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 8, 2013

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow at Tiny Desk
description: Wow  almost forgot to post tonight. Anyway, this is the best performance Ive seen yet by this group; no frills, just the three of them, and almost Civil Wars levels of perfection.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 9, 2013
description: "Theres no government, theres no pope. And now it is snowing in Rome.

title: Little Relief in North Syria, Where Need Is Acute
description: International donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on aid for Syrians, but the money has brought anger and resentment in some areas.

title: Senators Bearing Arms
description: Whenever talk turns to gun control in Congress, lawmakers feel compelled to mention their love of weaponry.

title: Mets Gee Encouraged Despite an Uneven Outing
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Despite looking uneven during his second game facing major league hitters since being shut down last summer, Dillon Gee said he felt that he was near his optimal form for the start of the season.

title: Pope Material or Not, a Charming, Cheerful Cardinal Gains Notice in Rome
description: VATICAN CITY  He keeps a set of vestments here, at the American seminary, so he does not have to lug the red robes back and forth to New York. He is a practiced frequent flier; last fall, he flew a round trip in a day, borrowing a billionaires jet so he could preside at a dinner in Manhattan without missing a meeting in Rome.

title: Corrections: March 9, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Gets in a Lather
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  This was a very interesting puzzle on quite a few levels: for one thing, with todays puzzle, co-written by David Steinberg and Barry C. Silk, Mr. Steinberg has hit for the cycle after only his ninth puzzle published in The New York Times. Mr. Steinberg, who is in his mid-teens, has had at least one puzzle published in The Times on each day of the week.

title: Finding Lovable Humanity in a Bitter Artist
description: Most people dont like Malcolm Raphelson. Even in his 70s, he is a menacing, arrogant, womanizing, narcissistic artist who has never forgiven Jackson Pollock and the other Abstract Expressionists for stealing his thunder in the 1940s and 50s. Raphelson has an appetite for destruction, including his own.

title: Paintings From Garage Find Appreciation in Gallery
description: For years, they languished in a Long Island garage, old canvasses piled in a stack. Then they came close to being thrown into a garbage truck.

title: As Brodeur Sits, Devils Try to Get Back on Their Feet
description: NEWARK  A back injury to the 40-year-old goaltender Martin Brodeur, a mainstay during the Devils three Stanley Cup triumphs, is providing the franchise a glimpse of what life could be like without him. It may not be pretty.

title: Dwindling Production Has Led to Lesser Role for Venezuela as Major Oil Power
description: HOUSTON  President Hugo Chvez relished using Venezuelas oil wealth to project power internationally, nudging OPEC to raise oil prices when he could, showering allies like Cuba and Nicaragua with subsidized oil shipments, and mocking the United States while selling it his crude.

title: A Restaurant Was Popular; Its Closing Was Celebrated
description: For years, Saigon Grill on Amsterdam Avenue at 90th Street was an Upper West Side fixture. Its spring rolls and Vietnamese soups were staples of quick dinners, celebratory lunches and takeout meals. Its deliveries were prompt, its waiters happy to take care of small children.

title: Are Bicycles Allowed in the Subways?
description: Q. Are bicycles allowed in the subways?

title: Mosbys Sneak Attack
description: On the bed we saw the general sleeping, recalled the memoirist. There was no time for ceremony, so I drew up the bedclothes, pulled up the generals shirt, and gave him a spank on his bare back, and told him to get up. This brief description captured the apex of one military career, and the nadir of another.

title: Swedes on Both Ends of Ice End Rangers Streak
description: Brad Richards made a successful return from injury and Rick Nash scored again, but it was Swedes Night at Madison Square Garden as the Ottawa Senators defeated the Rangers, 3-2, on Friday.

title: Treasure in the Air Up There
description: Robert A. King, 67, architect, checked in on one of his renovation jobs, a town house on Garfield Place in Brooklyn, and then spent the rest of Wednesday afternoon walking the neighborhood looking up.

title: Rational Decisions and Heartbreak on School Closings
description: When it comes to school closings, the arguments may make sense on paper, but the reality is much messier.

title: Filling the D.C. Appeals Court
description: Republicans in the Senate have so far blocked President Obama from filling vacant judgeships in the District of Columbia Circuit of the Unites States Court of Appeals.

title: Argentina: Ex-President Is Convicted
description: An appeals court in Argentina convicted former President Carlos Sal Menem on Friday of smuggling contraband weapons in the 1990s. Weapons and munitions officially destined to Panama and Venezuela ended up in Ecuador during its brief war with Peru, violating a bilateral peace agreement, and in Croatia during the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia amid an international weapons embargo. The ruling overturned a lower courts 2011 acquittal of Mr. Menem, left, whose 1989-1999 presidency was marred by accusations of corruption and graft. Mr. Menem, who denies being part of the arms conspiracy, served six months on house arrest on the same charges in 2001, but was freed following a Supreme Court ruling. As a senator, Mr. Menem, 82, is shielded from further imprisonment and may appeal the conviction before the Supreme Court.

title: Williams Electrifies From Long Distance
description: Deron Williamss night began quietly, with a 3-pointer from the left wing that whipped through the net about 90 seconds after the opening tip. Fans were still settling in their seats, and the Nets main concern was stopping Washingtons John Wall, a pesky guard who could cause them headaches.

title: Germany: Airport Project Reorganized
description: A tough manager who turned around Germanys national railway and second largest airline took over the company behind the construction of Berlins new international airport on Friday. We will do everything to speed up the completion of the airport, said the new leader, Hartmut Mehdorn, 70. Embarrassing budgetary and technical problems have repeatedly pushed the opening of the Berlin-Brandenburg Willy Brandt Airport further from its original target of last June, pushed costs to $5.2 billion, turned the project into a national joke, and cost the last manager, Rainer Schwarz, his job. Mr. Mehdorn brought the national railway, Deutsche Bahn, into profitability as its head from 1999 to 2009 and then helped return Air Berlin to competitiveness before leaving as its chief executive in January.

title: Three Men at Work, Quietly, While Yankees Are Elsewhere
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A team of aspiring Yankees played in a spring training game on the other side of Florida on Friday. Meanwhile, three of the most revered Yankees in team history had their run of the teams quiet complex, preparing for what is likely to be their last season together after two immensely successful decades.

title: Britain: 4 Plead Guilty in Selling Information to Tabloids
description: In the latest of dozens of criminal cases stemming from the phone-hacking scandal that led to the closure in 2011 of Rupert Murdochs News of the World tabloid, four former public officials pleaded guilty Friday to illegally selling information to another Murdoch-owned tabloid, The Sun. One, Alan Tierney, a former police constable, admitted to selling information in 2009 about the shoplifting arrests of the mother and mother-in-law of the soccer star John Terry. He also admitted selling another story that year about how the Rolling Stones guitarist Ron Wood had been arrested on suspicion of beating up a girlfriend. Mr. Tierney, who prosecutors said was paid $2,600, will be sentenced on March 27. Another defendant, Richard Trunkfield, a former prison officer at a high-security facility, admitted to receiving $5,000 for information about a high-profile prisoner in 2010. The two other defendants cannot be named because their alleged co-conspirators have yet to face trial.

title: After Over a Century at Sea, 2 Sailors Are Laid to Rest
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Older women in hoop skirts and petticoats came together with youthful sailors in their dress blues for a rare public double interment at Arlington National Cemetery on Friday.

title: In a Private School, Seeds of Dissent
description: No wonder they called it the Little Red School House.

title: Sailors From the Ironclad Warship Monitor Interred
description: The unidentified remains of two of the 16 men who went down with the ship on Dec. 31, 1862, during the Civil War were interred in Arlington National Cemetery on Mar. 8.

title: Iraq: Security Forces Open Fire on Sunni Demonstrators in North
description: Security forces fired on stone-throwing Sunni demonstrators in the northern city of Mosul on Friday, killing one and wounding five, according to Iraqi officials. The demonstrators were demanding the release of Sheikh Hussain al-Jubori, a local leader of antigovernment protests that have been going on in Iraq for two months. He was arrested early in the day on suspicion of links to Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the homegrown terrorist group. After the shootings, members of the mainly Sunni Iraqiya bloc held a news conference to denounce the government as reckless, and the minister of agriculture, Izzeddin al-Dolah, resigned, the second high-profile Sunni to do so this month.

title: Colorado Takes Up Gun Limits in Senate
description: DENVER  After months of emotional debate, an effort to tighten gun laws in a state haunted by two mass shootings moved toward an uncertain climax on Friday as Colorados State Senate began a marathon session on a range of new firearms restrictions.

title: Capitol Redux
description: A visual tour of the New York State Capitol in Albany. Its renovation was completed in 2012.

title: Local Stop: 68th and Lexington
description: At Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, Hunter College represents the architectural history of the area as well as the addition of modern amenities.

title: Modernity Among Classics
description: The corner of Lexington Avenue and 68th Street is beyond busy: the subway and the crosstown bus shuttle students to school, deliver staff to hospitals nearby and take locals home from Lincoln Center. A few blocks east, residents of apartments, town houses and tenements suffer equally from the Second Avenue subway project. Closer to Central Park, the atmosphere quiets, and the streets are rich with cultural and architectural history.

title: Down the Rabbit Hole in a Rental War
description: On a Sunday night not long ago, my roommate and I were sitting in our apartment in Harlem when we were interrupted by frantic knocking. We opened the door to find our upstairs neighbor standing there, a pink notice in her hand.

title: Vows: Marguerite and Sean
description: When Sean Anderson heard Marguerite Daniels was a good cook, he invited himself over for Singaporean chili crab. He got more than he bargained for when her cat was sick on their very first date.

title: U.S. Cancels Transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A ceremony in which the American military had planned to hand over full control of the Bagram Prison to Afghanistan was canceled Saturday, throwing into doubt an agreement between the two countries on custody of the remaining Afghan prisoners still being held by American forces.

title: The Orthodox Fringe
description: At age 6, he was a budding yeshiva student, in white shirt and black hat, with little contact outside the Orthodox Jewish world. At 16, he discovered some things he liked better, punk rock and drugs: marijuana, LSD, eventually crack and heroin. At 26, on the Thursday before the holiday of Purim last month, he was back among the faithful, sort of: side curls flailing, knees jackknifing up around his torso, leaping, crouching, shouting a Scriptural message from the Book of Ramones: Avraham was a punk rocker.

title: Is It Safe to Cross?
description: On a Friday afternoon last month, Martha Atwater went to buy cookies at a bagel shop on Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street in Brooklyn and was struck by a Honda sport utility vehicle that careered onto the sidewalk as she was leaving. According to the Police Department, the driver, John McKinney, lost control when he experienced a blackout related to diabetes. By the time Ms. Atwater was taken to Long Island College Hospital around the block, she was dead, leaving behind a husband, two young daughters and a closely bound community of mourners in Brooklyn Heights, where she had been a vibrant presence.

title: Thousands Say Farewell to Chvez
description: The death of President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela prompted a mass outpouring of grief at his funeral, which also attracted dignitaries from around the world.

title: A Jewel in Albany Regains Its Luster
description: ALBANY  The Capitol Building here has always been as much a symbol as a building. Soaring, ornate and hand-built over a 32-year span during the industrial heyday of the late 19th century, the Capitol was a testament to the states architectural might and the moxie of New Yorkers and their government. It also, of course, spoke to the tendency, sometimes still in evidence, to overspend and procrastinate on big projects. The Capitols $25 million price tag, a figure that translates to more than half a billion dollars today, made it one of the most expensive public-works projects in the nations history.

title: Blasts Hit Afghanistan After Arrival of Hagel
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A bomber wearing a vest packed with explosives struck outside the Afghan Defense Ministry on Saturday, killing at least 10 people in a blast just hours after Chuck Hagel, the new United States defense secretary, arrived here.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: LONG WEEKENDS Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why Edmund Gouldings Grand Hotel (1932), about guests linked by varying forms of desperation at a luxurious Berlin hotel  where, a resident complains, life is always the same. People come,people go. Nothing ever happens  is required viewing. Among the reasons: The pioneering use of ensemble star power (Greta Garbo, John and Lionel Barrymore, Wallace Beery and Joan Crawford), promoted by the MGM studio as the greatest cast ever assembled. And the words I want to be alone, the signature line of the fading, suicidal ballerina played by Garbo, which became synonymous with the mysterious image of the actress throughout her life. Week-End at the Waldorf, the 1945 Grand Hotel remake starring Ginger Rogers and Walter Pidgeon, above, follows at 10.

title: United States Cant Recover After Dickey Struggles Early
description: PHOENIX  R. A. Dickey pitched for the United States at the 1996 Olympics, winning both his starts. Yet he left with a bronze medal and a lingering sense of what could have been.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 9
description: NEWS The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible. David Kirkpatrick reports from Sawran, Syria.

title: Video of Police Beating in Fiji Prompts Ire
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The nine minutes of shaky cellphone footage are hard to watch, not because of the quality but because of the content. A young man lies handcuffed on the bed of a pickup truck, wailing as he is beaten repeatedly with a thick baton. Later, his assailant switches to a metal rod. A snarling dog drags another victim past his laughing attackers, who punch the man relentlessly.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Punjab: Ram Singh, a national level boxer, has told the police that he and Vijender Singh, a 2008 Olympics bronze medal-winning boxer, bought heroin from a drug dealer who was arrested near Chandigarh, Punjab, last week, NDTV reported. The interrogation was part of the drug bust that led to the seizure of 26-kilograms of drugs worth 1.3 billion rupees, or $23 million.

title: The Weekend Word: School Supplies
description: Todays Times

title: As Crisis Deepens in Egypt After Ruling on Riot, Calls for a Military Coup
description: PORT SAID, Egypt  Just months ago, demonstrators here and around Egypt were chanting for the end of military rule. But on Saturday, as a court ruling about a soccer riot set off angry mobs, many in the crowd here declared they now believed that a military coup might be the best hope to restore order.

title: Never Too Many I Love Yous for This Couple
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Kenyatta Is Declared the Victor in Kenya, but Opponent Plans to Appeal
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyas election commission on Saturday declared Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenyas first president and one of the prime suspects in a case involving crimes against humanity, to be the winner of the countrys presidential race amid growing allegations of vote fraud and a refusal by the other leading contender to concede.

title: Gone Deficit Gone
description: So says the CBO, although not directly.

title: The English Prisoner
description: If this plan is working, what would a failing one look like? So asks Martin Wolf in response to David Camerons speech insisting that his austerity policy was right, is right, and is succeeding. Simon Wren-Lewis goes through Camerons assertions in some detail, among other things catching him more or less lying about what the Office of Budget Responsibility  roughly speaking the counterpart of the CBO here  ha actually said about the impact of austerity on growth.

title: Attack on Christians Follows Claim of Blasphemy in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An enraged Muslim crowd attacked a Christian neighborhood in Lahore on Saturday, setting fire to more than 150 houses and 2 churches, in a new display of religious intolerance as Pakistan reels from violent persecution against other minorities.

title: For Some, Owning Guns Doesnt Necessarily Mean Liking Them
description: The national debate over firearms regulation is often presented as a battle of extremes: those who view any effort to tighten gun laws as an infringement of rights versus those who see guns as a menace to society.

title: Unforced Error Is Unloved Statistic Among Tennis Players
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  The term unforced error has become a staple of the popular vernacular since its introduction in tennis three decades ago. And though the phrase is still largely identified with the sport, players and coaches have little regard for the statistic. Nor do they care much for the statistical identification of shots as winners or unforced errors, considering them misleading reflections of the flow of a match.

title: High Tension on the Mountain
description: I was suspended 40 feet in the air on a broken chairlift for 80 bitterly cold minutes last month. My brother-in-law and I had been riding up Mount Snow in Vermont, looking forward to a morning on the slopes without our children, when the lifts steel cable slipped off its track.

title: A.C.P.T. 2013: Getting Started
description: SPECIAL POST  The buzz of excitement begins as you stroll down the hallway outside the ballroom. On Saturday at the A.C.P.T., the Market is home to vendors of all sorts of puzzle-related products, including The New York Times, which is giving away pencils, pens and stickers, as well as a raffle to win one of the New York Times puzzle cookie jars. Those who have filled their arms with puzzle swag mill into the ballroom and find a strategic seat behind one of the many yellow barriers placed around contestants to guard their answers.

title: Rowdiness Becomes a Business Strategy for the Tour
description: DORAL, Fla.  A color depiction of how the Doral Resorts Blue Monster will look, post-op, was spread before Donald J. Trump, who could not contain his excitement as he outlined all the spots where the countess of courses will go under the architects bulldozer shortly after Sundays conclusion of the Cadillac Championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: As Big East Basketball Tournament Fades, a Block Remains Fresh
description: The game ended 27 years ago, half a lifetime ago, a few pounds ago, yet Dwayne Washington, known to all as Pearl, cannot forget. He will not forget. It still hurts, still stings, the way his Big East career ended, at the 1986 conference tournament finale, in the final seconds.

title: Rebels in Syria Release U.N. Peacekeepers to Jordan, Easing Crisis in Border Zone
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  Syrian rebels released 21 detained United Nations peacekeepers to Jordanian forces on Saturday, ending a three-day standoff that raised new tensions in the region and new questions about the fighters just as the United States and other nations were grappling over whether to allow more arms to flow to the rebel movement.

title: Variety: A Timely Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The author of todays quote is someone to admire, in my opinion. Nina Berberova was a published writer who chronicled the lives of Russian migrs in Europe, and while this alone was an accomplishment for a woman of her time, she also made some very brave life choices. Ms. Berberova had a spirit and level of self-awareness that I find intriguing. Here is another quote from the same book that sparked todays puzzle:

title: U.S. Again Delays Transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghan Forces
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The promised American transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghan control collapsed once again on Saturday amid misunderstandings and recriminations between the two allies, punctuated by a deadly bombing outside the Afghan Defense Ministry.

title: Snow in Colorado. Really?
description: If you happen to be a member of Costa Ricas national team preparing for the World Cup qualifying match against the United States that will be played outside Denver in less than two weeks, a glance at Saturdays weather forecast for the area might fill you with dread.

title: At 43, Yankees Rivera Confirms That Hell Retire in Fall
description: For much of the past 18 years, the Yankees have relied on Mariano Rivera to pitch in the late innings with games on the line.

title: Yahoos Next Big Play: South by Southwest
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A quick spin through the South by Southwest lineup reveals the usual suspects: young start-ups vying to become the next big thing, up-and-coming musical acts, talks by Internet luminaries, and technology meet-ups on topics as varied as learning how to be an angel investor and workshops in 3-D printing.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Science and Politics
description: Is anti-science sentiment threatening public health policy?

title: China Says It Wont Forsake North Korea, Despite Support for U.N. Sanctions
description: BEIJING  Chinas foreign minister said Saturday that Beijing would not abandon North Korea, reiterating Chinas longstanding position that dialogue, not sanctions, is the best way to persuade the North to abandon its nuclear weapons.

title: Dutch Seek to Extend Their Record of Upsets
description: TOKYO  The Netherlands quietly took batting practice at Tokyo Dome on Saturday. Its sluggers, in orange jerseys and caps, casually peppered balls into the blue seats in left, seemingly unaware that their team was once again sending shock waves through the baseball world.

title: What Hath Rand Paul Wrought?
description: THE Republican Party built an advantage on foreign policy across generations, and then began demolishing it 10 years ago this month. What the cold war made, the invasion of Iraq largely unmade: beginning in 2003, a party that had long promised  and mostly delivered  peace through strength became identified with an intelligence fiasco, a botched occupation and the squandering of American resources, credibility and lives.

title: Nets Make Full Effort to Fit Into Brooklyn
description: When a team is about to play its first game of the season, and the owner publicly states that anything less than a trip to the Eastern Conference finals would be a disappointment, pressure is created that is hard to live up to. For the Brooklyn Nets, who invested heavily in putting together a winning team in their first season since their move from New Jersey, the pressure created by the teams owner Mikhail Prokhorov has seemingly distracted from what has otherwise been a successful move for both the Nets and Brooklyn.

title: After Rancorous Debate, Colorado Senate Advances Strict New Measures on Gun Control
description: DENVER  Colorado took a major step late Friday toward enacting some of the toughest new gun measures that have been introduced since the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut touched off a national debate about gun control.

title: No to Keystone. Yes to Crazy.
description: I HOPE the president turns down the Keystone XL oil pipeline. (Who wants the U.S. to facilitate the dirtiest extraction of the dirtiest crude from tar sands in Canadas far north?) But I dont think he will. So I hope that Bill McKibben and his 350.org coalition go crazy. Im talking chain-themselves-to-the-White-House-fence-stop-traffic-at-the-Capitol kind of crazy, because I think if we all make enough noise about this, we might be able to trade a lousy Keystone pipeline for some really good systemic responses to climate change. We dont get such an opportunity often  namely, a second-term Democratic president who is under heavy pressure to approve a pipeline to create some jobs but who also has a green base that he cant ignore. So cue up the protests, and pay no attention to people counseling rational and mature behavior. We need the president to be able to say to the G.O.P. oil lobby, Im going to approve this, but it will kill me with my base. Sasha and Malia wont even be talking to me, so Ive got to get something really big in return.

title: As Time Goes Bye
description: AUSPICIOUS my debut at Time was not.

title: Calmness of Seattle Inspires Second Chances
description: PEORIA, Ariz.

title: Geraldine Knatz
description: Geraldine Knatz is executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, the nations busiest. Encompassing 7,500 acres on 43 miles of waterfront, the port handled more than $273 billion in cargo last year and is responsible for 3 million jobs.

title: The Dow Jones Emotional Average
description: The Dow Jones closed at a record high last week, leaving investors both richer and further perplexed by a market that continues to exhibit textbook signs of bipolar personality disorder. Herewith, a psycho-diary chronicling the many moods of the Dow Jones.

title: A Presto, Change-O Opening Night at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Magic was on the streets and on the screen here in Austin on Friday at the opening night of the South by Southwest film festival. This years selection, The Incredible Burt Wonderstone, featured a starry cast in telling its story about a Vegas-performing magic duo (Steve Carell and Steve Buscemi) and a new kind of magician (Jim Carrey) who threatens to steal their thunder. Olivia Wilde also stars as a magicians assistant aspiring to be a bigger part of the act.

title: Yankees Counting Injuries and Pennies
description: These are not George Steinbrenners Yankees. Several injuries in spring training, and the teams response to them, have served to drive home that point.

title: At Global Showcase, a Blowout and a Brawl
description: PHOENIX  When players stand on the baselines before games in the World Baseball Classic, they hold caps from their countries to exchange with members of the other team. That spirit of good will crumbled Saturday under a tangled pile of players from Canada and Mexico.

title: Of Fraud and Filet
