description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.

title: Daily Report: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering the Web
description: Computer algorithms are trading stocks, targeting ads, steering political campaigns, arranging dates, besting people on Jeopardy and even choosing bra sizes.

title: NELL Is a Computer That Reads the Web  With a Little Human Help
description: The clever code of computing  the algorithmic empire  is on the march across business and society, but human help still has a role to play. And that role is increasingly apparent as algorithms try to do more work that was once the realm of human intelligence.

title: Decision Looms on Trade Status of 5 Shark Species
description: HONG KONG  Delegates at a major international meeting on wildlife trade voted on Monday to add several shark species to a list of plants and animals whose international trade is regulated. The vote was welcomed by conservationists, though it is still subject to final approval by the conference later this week.

title: Indictee for President!
description: NAIROBI  When the International Criminal Court was established in 2002 it had many lofty ambitions. Ending impunity for crimes against humanity, genocide and war crimes. Delivering justice to those abandoned by their national courts.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | March 11, 2013
description: Update: March 12, 2013

title: India Rape Suspects Family Says His Death Wasnt Suicide
description: NEW DELHI  The case of a fatal gang rape aboard a bus here in December, which set off an uproar across India, took a surprising turn on Monday when the body of a suspect in the attack was found hanging from a bedsheet noose in his jail cell. Officials called the death a suicide, but the suspects family insisted that he had been killed.

title: Competing Interests in an I.P.O.
description: When it comes to hot initial public offerings, there is a long-running debate over the obligations of the underwriter. In one classic case, the 1999 I.P.O. of eToys, a cache of documents newly unearthed by Joe Nocera of The New York Times offers insight into the way one Wall Street firm, Goldman Sachs, has approached these deals. In a lawsuit that is still going on, lawyers for an eToys creditors committee claimed that Goldman purposely set a low price to create a first-day pop in the stock for institutional investors, at the expense of the company itself.

title: Monday Reading: Avoiding Single Surcharge While Traveling
Opinion Report: No to Keystone
description: From the editorial page

title: Behind the Cover Story: Melanie Thernstrom on Untangling the Mystery of Food Allergies
description: Melanie Thernstrom wrote this weeks cover article about a doctor who is trying to cure children of their dangerous food allergies. Thernstrom is the author, most recently, of The Pain Chronicles. She last wrote for the magazine about twiblings.

title: Divining Whats Next for Video Games
description: Since helping to invent the modern video-game industry in 1981 with his design of Donkey Kong, Nintendos Shigeru Miyamoto has repeatedly reinvented it, most notably with the Nintendo Entertainment System in the 1980s  it introduced Super Mario Bros. and the Legend of Zelda to American households  and in the 2000s with the Wii, whose arm-waving motion controls started yet another widely imitated video-game craze.

title: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If Its Existentially Violent
description: Faced with a recent spate of high-profile incidents of violence, Nelson Mandelas wife, Graa Machel last week broke the usual silence of the former first couple and said that South Africa was an angry nation.

title: Q&A: Importing Camera Photos to an iPad Mini
description: Q.

title: A More Opaque British Government
description: LONDON  British governments sometimes seem inclined to offer unrequested advice to countries in the so-called developing world about their commitment to Western democracy. But in recent weeks, the question could be inverted: how open is British society itself?

title: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 Soldiers in Pakistan Tribal District
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A roadside bomb attack killed three soldiers and wounded at least three others in Pakistans tribal belt on Monday, Pakistani security officials said.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: The Bachelor Draws Viewers, and Martha Stewarts Need for Privacy
description: ABCs romance reality show The Bachelor has experienced a rare resurgence after a downswing that lasted several seasons, Amy Chozick and Bill Carter report. The show, which pairs a hunky man with dozens of heavily made-up women until he picks one as his fiance, has become the unlikely exception in a television season when almost every other show on ABC and its competitors has declined. The audience has increased to 8.8 million viewers, 3.3 million of whom are 18 to 49 years old, the most attractive group for advertisers. The show is especially popular among women, particularly those in households that make more than $100,000 a year.

title: The Gun Report: March 11, 2013
description: On February 27, we included in our gun reportthe murder of two officers in Santa Cruz, Calif., who were shot while following up on a sexual assault claim. The gunman, Jeremy Goulet, who was killed by police, was an Army veteran who had been accused of raping two military officers in 2006. Instead of jail time, a plea bargain allowed him to walk away with a less than honorable discharge. Former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who once represented Santa Cruz in Congress, spoke at the slain officers memorial service and suggested that this slap on the wrist paved the way for Goulets final, horrific crime.

title: Dell Agrees to Open Its Books to Icahn
description: Dell Inc. has agreed to open its books to the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, signaling a possible truce on one front in the battle over the computer makers proposed $24.4 billion buyout.

title: Breitbarted
description: OK, Im an evil person  and my scheming has paid off.

title: Leave Iran to Its Own Devices
description: Iran should be left alone with its nuclear ambitions. Sanctions do nothing more than hurt those who have nothing to say about anything in their own country. Just tell the Iranians this: If you detonate one of the weapons outside of your country, your country will cease to exist.

title: Massive March for Yamuna River Nears Delhi
description: NEW DELHI Tens of thousands of villagers are marching toward Delhi to pressure the central government to save the Yamuna River, in one of the biggest protests against river pollution in India.

title: After Lehman, Callan Speaks Out on a Proper Work-Life Balance
description: Erin Callan, former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, has kept mostly to herself after leaving Wall Street during the financial crisis.

title: At 64 Percent, Cuomos Favorability Rating Hits a New Low
description: Heading into this years budget negotiations, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo remains popular with New York voters, but he is no longer drawing the sky-high ratings that he enjoyed for most of his first two years in office, according to a poll released Monday by Siena College.

title: Online Betting Site Intrade Is Shut After Audit Queries
description: The online betting site Intrade announced late on Sunday that it had halted trading and frozen customer accounts after the company said it had discovered potential financial irregularities.

title: Author of Michael Haneke Twitter Account Reveals Himself
description: While there is still plenty of time for the real Michael Haneke, the Academy Award-winning filmmaker of Amour, to become a master of social media, the creator of a satirical Twitter account that (sort of) imitated him will not be carrying on the comedic impersonation well into his autumn years.

title: What Were Reading
description: National Geographic Traveler: Costas Christ on spending each spring farming blueberries in Maine.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Insider Attack Kills Several in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An Afghan police officer fired on American Special Operations troops and Afghan forces Monday morning, killing two coalition soldiers in the second insider attack in three days, Afghan officials said.

title: With a New Web Site, Betting on Brooklyn
Schapiro Is Nominated to G.E. Board
description: Mary L. Schapiro is starting to get a taste of opportunities in the private sector after stepping down as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in December.

title: Ukraine Gets Its Own Vogue
description: PARIS  Masha Tsukanova is the new face on the front lines of fashion. As the editor in chief of Vogue Ukraine, which made its debut this month as Vogues 21st international edition, she attended shows in Milan and made a brief appearance in Paris. She seemed to be fitting right in.

title: Market Milestones Can Lead to False Assumptions
description: Any time the stock market hits a new milestone, whether its going up or down, we start to hear a lot of noise. And the chatter seems to be focused on this idea of what it all means.

title: For the Tech Crowd, a Taste of Newspaper Talk
description: Here in Austin, Tex., where Im attending the digital media extravaganza known as South by Southwest, or SXSW, the arrival of the local newspaper at the hotel room door each morning seems almost otherworldly. Amid this gathering of techie (not to say geeky, because that would be a bit unfair), mostly young, mostly male participants, where plaid flannel is the de rigueur fashion note and Google glasses are the accessory of choice, The Austin American-Statesman feels like an unfamiliar visitor from the distant past. (Its a good paper, by the way, with Pulitzer Prizes in its history and a lively local report each day.) To put it mildly, this is not a print newspaper kind of crowd.

title: Reasonable Representation
description: The Times's Adam Liptak on the growing advantage less populated states enjoy in the Senate.

title: Talking Talent | Serena Williams
description: At 31 years old, Serena Williams is ranked the No. 1 female tennis player in the world, for the sixth time. Williams is arguably one of the most exciting athletes to ever grace tennis  with her lightning speed serve, her festive fashion and her fierce determination, Williams defines power. Although her life is virtually a hamster wheel of 24/7 tennis, Williams joined the Nike president and C.E.O., Mark Parker, and the first lady, Michelle Obama, on Feb. 28 in Chicago to announce Nikes investment of $50 million in the United States to increase the physical activity of children in schools and communities, a portion of which will benefit the Lets Move! Active Schools program. En route to the airport following the event, Williams discussed the first lady, the Miami Dolphins and her Chris Evert fantasy.

title: A Poker Puzzle From the Logic Olympics
description: Congratulations to everyone who competed in the 36th annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament this past weekend! Check out Deb Amlens last few posts, including A.C.P.T. 2013: The Finals, for the ultimate winners and complete adventure.

title: Monday Motorsports: Kenseths Vegas Gamble Pays Off
description: Matt Kenseth celebrated his 41st birthday on Sunday by winning the Las Vegas stop on the Nascar Sprint Cup circuit.

title: North Korea Declares 1953 War Truce Nullified
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea declared the 1953 Korean War armistice nullified on Monday, following through on a longstanding threat that it renewed last week amid rising tensions with South Korea.

title: Former Mayor of Detroit Guilty in Corruption Case
description: DETROIT  Kwame M. Kilpatrick, a former mayor of Detroit, was found guilty on Monday of a raft of charges, including racketeering, fraud and extortion, capping a five-month public corruption trial against him and two co-defendants.

title: The Heights of Hype
description: Now that we are well into March, its time to brace for the coming onslaught. No, were not talking about college basketball tournament madness. That is actually the enjoyable part, so fun we manage to block out reality and overlook the whole N.C.A.A. morass for a few minutes. No, the onslaught comes courtesy of CBS, which broadcasts both the N.C.A.A. tournament and the Masters golf tournament, a fact drilled into our heads so often by Jim Nantz every year that mental health counselors should consider setting up a hot line. Mute buttons everywhere quiver in anticipation of angry thumbs.

title: Your Guide to New Yorks Soda Ban
description: Update, 3:30 p.m. | A state Supreme Court judge in Manhattan invalidated the citys sugary-drink ban on Monday afternoon. Read the article.

title: Abraham Lincoln, War President
description: Throughout the Civil War, the federal courts made little attempt to curb the wide executive war powers claimed by President Abraham Lincoln. Judges issued few pronouncements on the legality of the presidents most controversial measures, one way or the other. This included the Supreme Court  with one critical exception: the ruling in the so-called Prize Cases in early 1863, involving the blockade of Southern ports. The justices, along narrow lines, validated Lincolns broad claim, under the war powers, to confiscate goods found aboard blockade runners, in perhaps the courts most important decision during the entire war.

title: S.B.A. Proposes Rule Changes to Lure Borrowers
description: Concerned, apparently, that not enough businesses are taking advantage of government-guaranteed loans, the Small Business Administration recently proposed changing some of its lending rules. If adopted, the new rules could make the agencys loan programs accessible and popular enough that they could reach their legal limits on lending  something the programs have seldom ever done. Oddly enough, this is happening at the same time the prospective sequester budget cuts may force the agency to make fewer loans.

title: The Race Is On
description: The Times's Michael M. Grynbaum on Christine C. Quinn's bid to be New York City's first female and openly gay mayor.

title: Cutting the Worlds Most Expensive Military
description: Mandatory budget cuts are forcing the United States military to trim down after a decade in which its budget has nearly doubled.

title: 'Downton': The Original
description: The hit series is popular all over the world.

title: Tenants Worried by Plans to Build Near City Projects
description: When Hassan Adam was growing up in public housing on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, his playground was a nearby recreational yard in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, where residents have long played basketball and neighbors hold an annual family day. Mr. Adam still lives in the project, and he taught his daughter to ride a bike in the play area.

title: The Legitimizing of Rand Paul
description: My Sunday column argues that the great Rand Paul filibuster represented an important step in the Kentucky Senators quest to widen the Republican conversation on national security beyond the strength good, appeasement bad rhetoric that the party had fallen back on (though not as completely as some Republicans would like) in the aftermath of the Bush presidency. The most persuasive counterpoint to my interpretation is that the rights rally around Pauls drones-on-American-soil stand is sui generis, with no wider implications for the G.O.P. foreign policy debates: Many of the Republican Partys hawks have always been skeptical of drone warfare (preferring boots on the ground, more prisoner-taking, etc.), and the fact that Paul was making a reductio ad hellfirum argument about drones taking down latter-day Jane Fondas made it that much easier for them to leap on the partisan bandwagon and #standwithRand.

title: Cutting Down on the Meat, but Not the Taste
description: There are many ways to cut down your meat intake and increase your vegetable consumption without becoming a vegetarian. Culinary traditions around the world are filled with dishes in which meat is used sparingly, for flavor and substance, but is not at the center of the plate. Think stir-fries, and some of your favorite pastas that have a little bit of pancetta but are really all about the tomatoes.

title: A Headset for Professional Gamers (and Amateurs, Too)
description: Turtle Beach wants to be the go-to brand of gaming headsets.

title: Harvard Explains Why Staff E-Mails Were Searched
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Harvard and its president on Monday made their first public comments on the universitys searching of staff members e-mail accounts, and offered a qualified apology for keeping the searches secret from most of the employees involved.

title: Who Studies Abroad, Who Stays Put and Why
description: American students are twice as likely as their British counterparts to consider foreign study, according to a new report.

title: Senate Offers Immigration Blueprint
description: A group of senators has drafted a set of principles that includes a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants that hinges on increased border security and enforcement measures.

title: The New Acropolis Museum
description: The new home for some of Athens most famous antiquities, one of the highest-profile cultural projects undertaken in Europe in this decade, opened on June 20.

title: A Right to Unlock Cellphones Fades Away
description: In October the Library of Congress decided to invalidate a copyright exemption that allowed users to unlock their cellphones. This exemption expired Saturday.

title: Mushroom, Bulgur, Spinach and Turkey Fritters With Yogurt Sauce
description: These are smaller than burgers and are served without buns, with a pungent garlic sauce. The recipe is inspired by a turkey and zucchini burger in Jerusalem, a Cookbook, by Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi.

title: Walters Says There Are No Plans for Hasselbeck to Leave The View
description: In a bid to tamp down talk about changes at The View, Barbara Walters said on Monday that we have no plans for Elisabeth Hasselbeck to leave the long-running ABC talk show.

title: Vegetable Soup With Any Root
description: Whats for dinner?

title: Yankees Tell Reporters to Reach Out to Jones
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With his sagging ship of a team listing in uncertain waters, General Manager Brian Cashman sent an S O S to an iconic Atlanta Braves player Monday.

title: In Performance: Elrod & Harris
description: Carson Elrod and Jenn Harris in The Universal Language, part of All in the Timing, David Ivess collection of offbeat sketches. The show is being revived by Primary Stages at 59E59 Theaters.

title: Electronic Arts Addresses Anger Over SimCity
description: The creators of the new SimCity computer game stopped short of giving the troubled game an all-clear on Sunday night, but the period of near-inoperability appeared close to an end.

title: A Barclays Banker Bets on a Fat Cat
description: President Obama irked Wall Street bankers a few years ago by calling them fat cats. But one banker has embraced the name.

title: Painterly Fashion
description: For his second womens collection at Saint Laurent in Paris last week, Hedi Slimane sent out invitations in the form of an artist book called 49 Paintings by Theodora Allen. Fashion houses teaming up with contemporary artists is nothing particularly new  there were actual Yayoi Kusama mannequins in Louis Vuittons windows when those two paired off  but to tap someone still in graduate school feels the riskier proposition. Allen is currently in her second year at U.C.L.A.s M.F.A. program and has no gallery representation. Im looking at various 19th- and 20th-century bohemian countercultures  from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, to the early California Arts and Crafts movement, to singer-songwriters living in Laurel Canyon in the late 1960s, she said of her inspiration.

title: London Theater Journal: Well-Seated Performers
description: LONDON  Rupert Everett and Rowan Atkinson are very good at sitting. This is more challenging and less boring than it sounds. I, for example, sat for nearly five hours watching these actors sitting in different West End revivals one day recently. But I seriously doubt that anyone focusing on me, or on any of my fellow audience members, during those hours would have been held in thrall.

title: Really? Acupuncture Can Reduce Symptoms of Hay Fever
description: THE FACTS

title: Image of the Day: March 11
Conclave Smokes Recipe Is a Mystery
description: During the papal conclave in the Sistine Chapel, progress will be measured in black and white  the colors of the smoke that will emerge after the voting, coming from a copper flue jutting from the chapel roof. But just how those colors are created remains a bit of a mystery.

title: Nieuwenhuis on Schedule to Return to Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Outfielder Kirk Nieuwenhuis and the Mets are still targeting Wednesday for his return to outdoor baseball activities.

title: Ritual and Secrecy Surround Conclave
description: VATICAN CITY  It begins with prayers chanted in an ancient language and ends with a tiny figure on the balcony of St. Peters Basilica unveiled as the supreme pontiff of more than a billion Catholics. The conclave to elect a pope, which starts Tuesday, unfolds with elaborate ritual, deep secrecy and politicking that would warm the heart of a machine politician.

title: An Elaborate Ritual to Elect a Pope
description: The Timess Daniel J. Wakin reports on planning behind the conclave beginning on Tuesday. Its a process that goes back centuries.

title: Bieber and Rihanna Cancel Shows
description: It may be that the promoters of Justin Biebers two scheduled concerts in Portugal this week were overly ambitious: the Web page for the Pavilhao Atlantico in Lisbon, where Mr. Bieber was scheduled to perform tonight and Tuesday, limits ticket purchases to six a customer.

title: Airport Screening Concerns Civil Liberties Groups
description: Aviation security leaders are moving forward with plans to shift toward a risk-based system of passenger screening  an idea supported by the travel industry and government officials who want screeners to focus on travelers who may present a security threat.

title: Family Ties
description: More photos from the Broadway play "August: Osage County."

title: Estelle Parsons on Stage
description: A look at some of the actresss theatrical performances.

title: Tournament Watch: Which Teams Need a Strong Showing
description: As every regular season ends and conference tournaments begin, a batch of college basketball teams can breathe easily, knowing that they will soon be one of 68 teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament. This has become a steady truth for usual juggernauts like Duke, Michigan State and Kansas, which will soon seal its 24th consecutive appearance in the tourney, the third-longest streak in tournament history behind North Carolinas 27 straight from 1975-2001 and Arizonas 25 from 1985-2009.

title: Obama to Address Gathering of Donors and Activists
description: President Obama will speak Wednesday night at a dinner for donors and activists at the first gathering of Organizing for Action, the nonprofit group created by former campaign officials to help advance the presidents agenda, according to officials with the new organization.

title: Chronic Insomnia Affects Heart
description: Insomnia may be linked to an increased risk of heart failure, according to a large new study, and the more insomnia symptoms, the greater the risk.

title: Q. and A. With Thea Goodman, Author of The Sunshine When Shes Gone
description: Its unusual for me to interview the author of a novel, rather than a nonfiction book on parenting. But then, The Sunshine When Shes Gone, by Thea Goodman, is an unusual book. Ms. Goodmans main characters, the new parents Veronica and John, find themselves in that strange, sleep-deprived dream state of new parenthood, and then act on escape fantasies that will seem familiar to anyone who has been there.

title: Van Jumps Curb in Queens, Killing Boy
description: A 16-year-old boy was killed and four other pedestrians were injured on Monday morning when a van jumped a curb outside LaGuardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Koch Willed Secretary $100,000 From $10 Million Estate
description: She was his fiercely loyal and unwaveringly discreet personal secretary for nearly 40 years, and he credited her for helping him achieve professional acclaim. And so former Mayor Edward I. Koch rewarded his secretary, Mary Garrigan, with a $100,000 bequest, according to his will.

title: Edward I. Kochs Will
description: Read the full will of Former Mayor Edward M. Koch.

title: The Curse of EconoSisyphus
description: Jeff Frankel participates in a discussion of Chinese currency policy  and finds many of the participants subscribing to the doctrine of immaculate transfer. As he says, I thought I had definitively disposed of that doctrine 25 years ago. But it keeps coming back.

title: Ino Helped Usher In Simpler, Freer Fare
description: In a Facebook post on Sunday, ino announced that it had closed. When the shoebox-shaped and nearly shoebox-size panini shop opened on Bedford Street 15 years ago, there was nothing quite like it in New York, a restaurant that kept things simple and kept prices low, serving flavorful food in a room that was just adorable enough that you could decide, midmeal, that maybe the two of you squeezed into the counter were there on a date, and not just grabbing a bite.

title: The Junk-Food Pile
description: What emerged from the 1,300-plus comments posted by readers in response to Michael Mosss article, The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food, was not only a debate over the tactics of food-industry giants (sentimentsexpressed on this past weekends letters page) but also a series of confessions about the processed foods thatreaders find most tempting.

title: Illinois Is Accused of Fraud by S.E.C.
description: For the second time in history, federal regulators have accused an American state of securities fraud, finding that Illinois misled investors about the condition of its public pension system from 2005 to 2009.

title: Bolshoi Theater Director Contends Acid Attacks Mastermind Yet to Be Found
description: The web of intrigue around Russias Bolshoi Theater continued to grow over the weekend after Anatoly Iksanov, the theaters general director, told Russian television that he doesnt believe that the mastermind behind the January acid attack on Sergei Filin, the ballet companys artistic director, has been found.

title: Left Behind, UConn Ponders Starting Over Again
description: Connecticut is not eligible to play in the Big East mens basketball tournament, which begins Tuesday, nor can it qualify for next weeks bigger national show. It would still be fitting for the Huskies to be at Madison Square Garden for the conference finale Saturday night, if only for the purpose of turning out the lights.

title: Street Style: Plaid
description: The best of readers photos from the week of March 4.

title: Fill-In | For Demi Lovato, No Airbrushing Required
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article For Demi Lovato, No Airbrushing Required by Nicole LaPorte.

title: Recording Williamsburgs Latest Transformation, and Raging Against It
description: Gut Renovation is a documentary that tells a familiar tale. It chronicles buildings torn down, communities elbowed out, and new residents ushered in as a tidal wave of gentrification swept through Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Free Festival to Offer Plays With New York Themes
description: Plays with New York themes written by John Patrick Shanley, Amiri Baraka, Edward Albee, Lorraine Hansberry and more than a dozen others will be featured in a free festival of readings and panel discussions led by members of the Labyrinth Theater Company starting next Monday and running through March 24, the organization has announced.

title: Hedge Fund Donates $30 Million to Imperial College
description: LONDON  Brevan Howard, the London-based hedge fund, agreed Monday to donate 20.1 million, or $30 million, to the Imperial College to set up a finance research center in its name.

title: High Cotton
description: Q. Why are clouds white?

title: Feng Shui Fries
description: A fast-food joint designed for good luck.

title: The Netherlands Eliminates Cuba at World Baseball Classic
description: TOKYO  Kalian Sams hit a ninth-inning sacrifice fly to cap a come-from-behind, 7-6 win over Cuba on Monday night at Tokyo Dome that sends the Netherlands to the World Baseball Classic semifinals in San Francisco next week.

title: The Shelf Life of Donor Blood
description: How long should blood be stored?

title: British Politician and Ex-Wife Sentenced to Prison
description: LONDON  A sensational trial that featured a leading politician, his extramarital affair, a speeding ticket, his now-divorced wife and her decision to wreak her revenge ended on Monday with a judge sending both of them to prison.

title: Giants Shore Up Defensive Line, Sign Jenkins
description: 4:49 p.m. | Updated With the N.F.L. free agency signing period starting Tuesday, the Giants have already made their first move to bolster their defensive line, signing former Eagles defensive tackle Cullen Jenkins, the team confirmed on Monday.

title: In Search of Energy Miracles
description: At a legendary but secretive laboratory in California, Lockheed Martin is working on a plan that some employees hope might transform the worlds energy system: a practicable type of nuclear fusion.

title: From Medea to Winnie
description: A look at the stage work of actress Fiona Shaw.

title: Cheers and Fears: Audience Reactions at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Watching genre films and comedies with a South by Southwest audience makes a strong case for the power of the theatrical experience and the value of its preservation. The crowds in Austin dive into festival films with enthusiasm and vigor, which makes them ideal for filmmakers eager to see how their films play to genre-loving fans, giving some indication of how the films might be met by audiences around the country.

title: Photo Replay: March 11
description: A look at the day in sports, including U.S. womens soccer, a dramatic Netherlands baseball victory and skaters preparing for the world championships.

title: In First Overseas Trip, Hagel Offers a Terse Review: Its Complicated
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel left Afghanistan at dawn on Monday, his anonymous Air Force cargo plane making a grand sweep of the ice-covered peaks that encircle the capital, ending a three-day visit punctuated by attacks.

title: Seeing, and Thinking, Like Sherlock
description: Arthur Conan Doyles novels and short stories about the incomparable detective Sherlock Holmes have never been out of print since their first publication in 1887. Holmes collections abound, as do movies, TV series, video games, hats, pipes, T-shirts and calendars, not to mention nonfiction books dissecting the Holmesian method.

title: Celebrities Help Unicef Turn On Taps for Clean Water
description: This year the Unicef Tap Project is harnessing social media in a big way to raise funds for clean water for children worldwide.

title: U.S. Demands China Block Cyberattacks and Agree to Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The White House demanded Monday that the Chinese government stop the widespread theft of data from American computer networks and agree to acceptable norms of behavior in cyberspace.

title: For Vince Carter, Happiness as a Sixth Man
description: Back in the day, I didnt really care, said Dallass Vince Carter, in the visitors locker room after a game at Minnesota. Im suffering now.

title: Lumire | They Eat Horses, Dont They?
description: Last October, the super-starred French chef Alain Ducasse invited Dan Barber, of the Blue Hill restaurants in New York, to the Plaza Athene to cook for some special guests. American Ambassador Charles H. Rivkin and his wife, Susan Tolson, showed up, as did dozens of Paris luminaries. The Americans were wowed by Barbers inventiveness, including his use of charcoal made from pig bones to roast a whole pig. The French, by contrast, were horrified.

title: Even Without Intrade, Billions Will Be Bet on 2016 Race
description: The popular prediction market Intrade, which in November shut down its markets to United States residents after a complaint from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, announced on Sunday that it was closing down entirely.

title: New Optimism on Resveratrol
description: A cloud has long hung over the intriguing thesis that resveratrol, a minor ingredient of red wine, activates cellular proteins known as sirtuins that promote longer life in laboratory worms, flies and mice.

title: Nominee for S.E.C. Chief Pledges to Keep Focus on Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON  Mary Jo White plans to strike a hard line against Wall Street wrongdoing at a Senate confirmation hearing on Tuesday, as she deflects concerns over her ability to regulate the same banks she recently defended.

title: With Few Details, Lucasfilm Signals Star Wars Plans for TV
description: LOS ANGELES  Now that Lucasfilm is moving full steam ahead on a new Star Wars trilogy, the company  now owned by Disney  is starting to get its TV universe in order. On Monday came word that Lucasfilm has decided to pursue a new direction in animated programming.

title: Ai Weiwei Is Making a Rock Album
description: When Chinese authorities jailed the dissident sculptor Ai Weiwei for 81 days in 2011, they may have created a monster, of sorts: now Mr. Ai has announced that he is recording a heavy metal album, and he has traced the roots of his interest in music to his incarceration, when his guards asked him to sing, and he realized that he knew only Chinese revolutionary songs.

title: Mixing Scripture Into the Batter
description: CAMBRIDGE, N.Y.  At first, the prep work for 200 four-pound cheesecakes in the sunny, commercial kitchen seemed familiar, unremarkable. An elderly woman in a bandanna wielded a cheese cutter, slicing through fat bricks of cream cheese. Another woman with silvery bangs poured heavy cream into the mixer, dipped a tasting pinkie into the batter and grinned. Rich vanilla perfumed the air. As containers from Florida were opened, bright bursts of Key lime scent escaped.

title: Disruptions: Thank You for Your Thank You Comments
description: In my column this week I argued that there is a new type of digital etiquette where asking for directions, leaving a voice mail message and saying thank you in an e-mail can be considered rude.

title: In a Break for Senate Democrats, Durbin to Run for Re-election in Illinois
description: After a half-dozen senior senators have announced their retirements, it now passes as news when a Senate veteran up for re-election in 2014 decides to try to stick around for another six years. Senator Richard Durbin of Illinois, the Senates second-ranking Democrat, has decided to do just that, according to Senate officials familiar with his decision.

title: In Harlem, Voting for Guinea
description: Guinean immigrants in New York voted this weekend in their first democratic presidential elections since independence from France in 1958.

title: Former Massachusetts Senator to Join Nixon Peabody
description: The tried-and-true tradition of law firms serving as homes for ousted and retired politicians is alive and well.

title: Some Resilience Seen in Northern and Tropical Flora in a Warming Climate
description: Separate comprehensive studies published in the last couple of days in Nature Climate Change and Nature Geoscience find that from the northern tundra to the tropical forests, plant communities are showing substantial capacity to tolerate global warming.

title: Intriguing New Restaurants Outside of New York
description: Frank Bruni's coast-to-coast ranking of 10 of the country's top new restaurants.

title: Judge Blocks New York Citys Limits on Big Sugary Drinks
description: A judge struck down New Yorks limits on large sugary drinks on Monday, one day before they were to take effect, in a significant blow to one of the most ambitious and divisive initiatives of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs tenure.

title: 2009 Frankfurt Motor Show
description: At the show in Frankfurt, automakers showcased their newest green technologies, as well as some over-the-top luxury and performance models.

title: New York State Supreme Court Decision on Bloombergs Limits on Sugary Drinks
description: Read the full decision from New York State judge Milton Tingling.

title: Graphic Novel Tackles H.I.V./AIDS in the South
description: Young men in a state prison for juveniles and professors of library science from the University of South Carolina have joined forces to fight AIDS with a graphic novel.

title: Can I Have a Round of Applause?
description: Campaigning in Iowa, Fred D. Thompson displayed little drive to distinguish himself from his opponents.

title: Uprising at N.Y.U.
description: The Timess Ariel Kaminer sits down with John Sexton, the president of New York University, who is facing a vote of no confidence from increasingly disenchanted faculty members.

title: South African Meat Snacks Often Mislabeled
description: Biltong, the strips of cured meat that are a popular snack in South Africa, is often not what it appears to be.

title: Ancient Strait Is Clue in Falklands Wolfs Origin
description: The Falkland Islands wolf, long extinct, is the only land-based mammal native to the islands. European explorers in the 17th century were puzzled by the presence of this lone mammalian species, as was Charles Darwin.

title: Williamsburg: Not What It Was
description: On a walk around Williamsburg, Su Friedrich discusses her movie Gut Renovation, which documents the transformation and gentrification of the Brooklyn neighborhood over recent years.

title: How to Shoot a Backlit Photo
description: If you use your flash only when it automatically pops up on your camera, you are missing a great opportunity to improve your portraits.

title: Fantasy Sports and Gambling: Line Is Blurred
description: Government crackdowns have discouraged many potential gamblers in the United States from using online poker and sports betting Web sites. But an increasing number of people have found a legal way to play the odds online through daily fantasy Web sites.

title: Checking Your Home Buyer Tax Credit Status
description: The Internal Revenue Service no longer mails reminders to those who must repay the first-time home buyer tax credit. But it does offer an online tool to help you determine whether you need to repay it, and how much you should pay.

title: Ukrainian Blogger Escapes Her Syrian Captors
description: MOSCOW  A Ukrainian blogger and journalist captured by a Syrian rebel group five months ago announced that she had escaped her captors on Monday but offered little detail, telling a Russian radio station that she just walked out and left.

title: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: N.F.L. to Consider Rule on Runners Lowering Helmets
description: N.F.L. owners will consider a significant rule change at their annual meeting next week that would prohibit players  runners and defenders  from using the crown of their helmets to initiate contact and deliver a forcible blow.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Noodles to Slurp

title: A Scientific Milestone
description: To the Editor:

title: McConnell Stands With (and Raises Money Off) Rand Paul
description: After opposing his bid for Kentuckys Republican Senate nomination in 2010, Senator Mitch McConnell is ready to Stand with Rand, Paul that is. Oh, and hed like you to join Team Mitch while youre at it.

title: Delusions, Anger and Violence
description: Some studies have suggested that the risk factors for violence by people with mental illness are the same as those in the general population. But a new study finds that anger, coupled with psychotic delusions, may be the most significant factor in violence committed by people with mental illness.

title: Giants Give Cruz First-Round Tender
description: The Giants president John Mara acknowledged that the team is taking a risk, but it gave receiver Victor Cruz, a restricted free agent, a first-round tender Monday after the sides failed to reach an agreement on a long-term deal.

title: On the Brink in Italy
description: GUIDONIA, Italy   Emanuele Tedeschi wiped sawdust from his hands and gestured around the cavernous woodworking factory that has been in his family for two generations. The big machines, which used to run overtime carving custom furnishings for private homes, Roman palazzi and even the Vatican, sat idle on a shop floor nearly devoid of workers.

title: Barroso Urges Europe to Keep Cutting Debt
description: BRUSSELS  The president of the European Commission on Monday called on E.U. leaders to stay the course on debt reduction and economic overhauls, as he sought to head off a rancorous debate on those issues when the leaders hold a summit meeting here this week.

title: Mental Illness and Vulnerability
description: Compared with the rest of the population, people with mental illness may be at sharply increased risk of dying by homicide, a new study has found.

title: Health Care Costs (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Quest for Energy in Darkest Siberia
description: Gazprom is the worlds largest natural gas producer and Russias largest company.

title: A Firm Grasp on Comfort
description: Wheres your baby? said the mother to her sobbing 3-year-old daughter. You need your baby!

title: Listed as Probable, Anthony Says He Is Certain to Play
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Carmelo Anthony will be back in the Knicks lineup Monday night to face the Golden State Warriors after missing three games because of a stiff right knee.

title: Connecticut Schools Production of Sweeney Todd Sparks Protest
description: March 12 | Updated

title: Q. and A. on the Papal Transition
description: As 115 cardinals prepare to elect the next leader of the Roman Catholic Church, Times reporters covering the papal transition answered readers questions on the conclave process, the future of the church and the retirement of Pope Benedict XVI.

title: Q. and A. on the Papal Transition
description: As 115 cardinals prepare to elect the next leader of the Roman Catholic Church, Times reporters covering the papal transition answered readers questions on the conclave process, the future of the church and the retirement of Pope Benedict XVI.

title: Wheelies: The Eye Candy Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Billion-Dollar Banker
description: Which bankers services are worth $1 billion?

title: Ticket Prices Raised by Knicks and Rangers
description: Knicks and Rangers fans will have to pay more to see their teams in person next season.

title: Pi Parties and Mind Games
description: Book

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, India, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: Christine Quinn Spanish-Language Ad
description: Christine Quinn produced a shorter and slightly altered Spanish-Language video announcing her candidacy for mayor.

title: The Small Picture: Capturing the Soul of Your Business
description: Here at Youre the Boss weve started a new feature intended to help people understand what it means to run a small business. We asked readers to send us a photograph that captures the soul of their businesses, and so far, the submissions  which you can see here  have included photographs of a very lucky pig, the first shipment of the season, a restaurant ready for Valentines Day, and an owner shoveling out her business after a heavy snow storm.

title: Mornhinweg Is Assessing Jets Quarterbacks
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J.  Mark Sanchez threw four interceptions in a must-win December game at Tennessee. He committed 26 turnovers overall, and for the second straight season. He was also benched twice. But it seems increasingly apparent that Sanchez will begin training camp as the Jets starting quarterback, regardless of how the team addresses the position through free agency and the draft, or in a potential trade.

title: Glib Voices in a World of Madness
description: One of the more sulfurous characters in Sam Lipsytes gonzo new short-story collection has a madness factory full of blast furnaces and smokestacks for a mind. So shes a chip off the Lipsyte block, as are most of the characters who run through this authors feverish imaginings.

title: Spring Reading: Books of Style
description: Dont let cool temperatures fool you. Spring is just a short while away and with warmer weather comes spring cleaning. Here is a selection of new coffee table books to help refresh your home.

title: A Slip-Up Is Just One Difference Between English and Spanish Videos for Quinn
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, is a granddaughter of Irish immigrants, according to a splashy video released Sunday officially announcing her mayoral campaign.

title: Its Not the Rhetoric
description: In his Monday morning column, Greg Sargent of the Washington Post wondered rhetorically whether we had actually had an election last November, since the Republicans are still putting forward the ideas that voters rejected in 2012. Representative Paul Ryan, who was on the G.O.P.s losing presidential ticket, is about to issue yet another draconian budget plan that would start the process of killing Medicaid and turning Medicare into a voucher program.

title: New BlackBerry Phone Nears U.S. Debut
description: Just over six weeks after the BlackBerry Z10 phone went on sale in Britain, the handset, which will very likely determine the fate of the company formerly known as Research In Motion, will start arriving in the hands of American customers.

title: Video: Bloomberg Discusses Ruling on Sugary Drink Regulation
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke from City Hall about a judges ruling that invalidated New York Citys ban on large sugary drinks, one day before it was to go into effect.

title: Palindrome Prize Winners Announced in Oregon
description: The first annual Symmys awards, honoring achievement in the creation of palindromes, were handed out on Sunday in Portland, Ore. The panel of celebrity judges included the singer Weird Al Yankovic and Will Shortz, The New York Times crossword editor.

description: Inside the studio of Brian Burton, a k a Danger Mouse.

title: Coming Soon: Version 2 of the Article Search API
description: Were in the process of bringing you a new and improved NYTimes Article Search API. This spring, well be releasing version 2 of Article Search, featuring better performance, simpler queries and greater flexibility. For a short time version 1 will still work, and we will be providing support as you update your code to take advantage of version 2.

title: Two Receivers Head to N.F.C. West
description: The N.F.C. West, which only two seasons ago produced a division champion with a losing record, could now be the most competitive division in the N.F.L. On Monday, the two best teams in the division  the Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers, both of whom made the playoffs with 11 victories  moved to acquire wide receivers just one day before free agency began.

title: Airport Lounge Perks Become a Priority
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Science Whiz Kids, Butterfly Biomimicry and Bloods Shelf Life
description: This week: a look at a few of the young finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search, delving into the puzzles of mimicry in nature and disturbing news about donated blood.

title: From Six Victors, Steady Nerves in Bravura Arias
description: Competitions, despite their flaws and biases, highlight new talent and reveal who can perform well under nerve-rattling circumstances. Having a beautiful voice clearly isnt enough unless a singer can conquer opening-night jitters and nail those high notes.

title: Gossip Girl Style
description: Scenes from a trend-setting series.

title: Albums by Bon Jovi, Pedrito Martnez and Jaleel Shaw
description: BON JOVI

title: The Greatest Show Ever?
description: Since the Grateful Dead formed in 1965, it has inspired an obsessive following, and fans continue to debate which of the original bands 2,350 or so shows was the best.

title: Walkabout  3/11: Delta C.E.O. Criticizes T.S.A.s Looser Restrictions
description: Carry-On Controversy Delta Air Lines C.E.O. objects to the Transportation Security Administrations move to allow small pocketknives on airplanes, loosening some of the restrictions created after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. (CNN)

title: Putting a Value to Real in Medical Research
description: When medical researchers report their findings, they need to know whether their result is a real effect of what they are testing, or just a random occurrence. To figure this out, they most commonly use the p-value.

title: Asked and Answered | The Terroir Two
description: Andrew Mariani, the 30-year-old founder of the artisanal winery Scribe, in Sonoma, Calif., is paving his way into wine culture via a dusty, palm-tree-lined path that winds up to a shabby chic hacienda, two farmhouses and a 200-acre vineyard estate, all of which he and his younger brother, Adam, acquired, renovated and unveiled to the public in 2007.

title: Historians Issue Report on Vienna Philharmonic
description: The three historians commissioned by the Vienna Philharmonic to carry out an independent study of its Nazi past announced their findings on Sunday. In preliminary materials furnished to The New York Times last month, Oliver Rathkolb, the lead historian, said he had learned, from a highly trustworthy and well-informed witness, the identity of a shadowy presence and promised to reveal it with the entire study. That has now been posted on the orchestras Web site, in German, with a promise of an English translation to follow. The person served as an emissary, official or not, of the orchestra in delivering a replacement of the orchestras ring of honor that had been bestowed on Baldur von Schirach in 1942. Schirach, the Nazi governor of Vienna who lost the ring after World War II, spent 20 years in prison for his part in deporting tens of thousands of Viennese Jews to extermination camps in Nazi-occupied Poland. In late 1966 or early 1967, after he was freed, the replacement ring was tendered by  it is now revealed  Helmut Wobisch, a trumpeter in the orchestra. Wobisch joined the Nazi party and the SS early on, spied on and denounced fellow musicians, was fired by the orchestra after the war, rejoined it in 1947, became its executive director in 1953 and played in it until 1968.

title: Reaping Connections Paul Taylor Has Sown
description: The foyer at the David H. Koch Theater, happily stripped of recent clutter, is one of this citys great interiors. Large, calm and elegant, with its vast window space filtered by pearl-rope curtains, it opens onto a balcony that faces over Lincoln Centers plaza. Now, during the Paul Taylor Dance Companys annual three-week season at the Koch, this space proves the perfect place in which to let the dances add up after the curtain falls, and to mull over the connections between one work and another.

title: City Suspends Pension Payments for Arts Institutions
description: New York City is withholding payment into a pension system that covers some employees at many of the citys day care centers as well as some of its best known cultural institutions, including the American Museum of Natural History, the Brooklyn Museum, the Studio Museum in Harlem and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: City Announces New Goal for Public Housing Repairs, but With Big Caveat
description: The New York City Housing Authority said on Monday that it had made substantial strides in catching up on repairs at its buildings, fulfilling 73,000 work orders since January.

title: A Scary Superbug, Caffeinated Bees and More
description: The word birefringence hasnt appeared in this newspaper since 1995  hard to believe, isnt it?

title: A Midwife for Harrowing Memoirs
description: Many writers have specialties: mystery, romance, true crime, even vampires. But Lisa Pulitzer has developed a curious subgenre that she has nearly all to herself: the escape story.

title: Medicaid Expansion Is Rejected in Florida
description: MIAMI  Rebuffing Gov. Rick Scotts support of Medicaid expansion, a Florida Senate committee on Monday rejected the idea, all but ending the possibility that the state would add more poor people to Medicaid rolls.

title: A Rousing Pasin, This Time Spanning Generations as Well as Cultures
description: For all of its popularity since its triumphant premiere in Stuttgart, Germany, in 2000, Osvaldo Golijovs Pasin Segn San Marcos (The St. Mark Passion) is not likely to become a standard repertory work. Reimagining the Bach Passions, Mr. Golijov tells the story of the Crucifixion as it has been lived and felt every day in Latin America. This heady, polystylistic, genre-blurring work blends Brazilian, Afro-Cuban and other styles of Latin American folk and pop music into a 90-minute theatrical score that includes elements of ritual and dance. Any presentation requires performers steeped in the musical traditions from which Mr. Golijov draws.

title: The Parents of These Teenagers Must Be Tempted to Throw the Good Book at Them
description: Those who argue that media representations have no impact on how certain groups of people are perceived might want to cover their ears when Taylor Coleman speaks. Ms. Coleman is one of the three teenagers at the center of the docu-series Preachers Daughters, which has its premiere on Lifetime on Tuesday, and boy, does she believe what she hears.

title: Widespread Flaws Found in Ovarian Cancer Treatment
description: Most women with ovarian cancer receive inadequate care and miss out on treatments that could add a year or more to their lives, a new study has found.

title: Todays Scuttlebot:  Online Etiquette in Flux, and Facebook Hacking Defense
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Solving the Puzzles of Mimicry in Nature
description: Perhaps no destination has attracted and inspired more great naturalists than Brazil. Charles Darwin, on his epic voyage on the H.M.S. Beagle, first made landfall at Bahia in 1832; two fellow Englishmen, Alfred Russel Wallace and Henry Walter Bates, arrived at Par in 1848. Wallace roamed the Amazon for four years, and the indefatigable Bates for 11.

title: Intel Finalist: Jamie
description: Jamie Lee Solimano, a high school student from New York City, is among 40 finalists in the nationwide Intel Science Search.

title: Intel Finalist: Mayuri

description: Daniel McQuaid, a high school student from Ossining, N.Y., is among 40 finalists in the nationwide Intel Science Search.

title: Republican State Senators Indicate New Openness to Raising Minimum Wage
description: ALBANY  Republicans in the State Senate, who have resisted a push by Democrats to raise the states minimum wage, said on Monday that they were open to including a wage increase in the state budget proposal that lawmakers are negotiating.

title: Oppenheimer Settles S.E.C.s Accusations It Misled Investors
description: Oppenheimer & Company will pay nearly $3 million to settle accusations by federal and state regulators that it misled investors about the performance of one of its private equity funds, in a case that signals stepped-up scrutiny of the buyout industry and how it values its holdings.

title: A Laboratory Grows Young Scientists
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  During lunch hour, the hallways of Ossining High School have a kind of barely contained chaos. Whistles bleed from the gym, students squeeze every last minute of freedom before theyre due back in class. Even the library, where Dan McQuaid sat with two of his science teachers two weeks ago, buzzes and hums.

title: Ahead of the Class
description: For three young finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search, there were some big questions that needed answering before the end of high school.

title: Not My Igloo
description: This afternoon, I helped my oldest son (who is 11) and my youngest daughter (7) build an igloo.

title: Mexican Leaders Propose a Telecom Overhaul
description: MEXICO CITY  President Enrique Pea Nieto and leaders of Mexicos three main political parties on Monday presented a sweeping overhaul of the laws regulating telecommunications, the most serious effort yet to rein in the countrys dominant telephone and television companies.

title: The Best Nuggets From Klinsmanns Twitter Q & A
description: 8:48 p.m. | Updated Below United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann answered questions from fans on Twitter on Monday afternoon. Among the usual entreaties for memories (most dominant player you ever faced: Maradona) and fitness tips (No junk food!) were a few nuggets of news.

title: Quinn Video Announces Her Candidacy
description: Christine Quinn announced her candidacy using a 5-minute web video, focusing on biographical facts.

title: A New York Times Column on Climate and Energy
description: I was excited tonight to see that Justin Gillis has launched a monthly column on climate change, the energy challenge and related issues in Science Times (his new home) . The column, taking the By Degrees name from the papers 2009 series on responses to global warming, wont capture everything that the closed Green blog covered, but demonstrates the papers (and of course Justins) commitment to this super wicked issue.

title: Tavis Smiley Tonight
description: One more discussion.

title: New Big East and Fox Team Up
description: No sports network loves college football and college basketball more than ESPN.

title: Turner May Broadcast 2014 Mens Final Four
description: Turner Sports, CBSs partner in carrying the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, could carry the Final Four and national championship game in 2014, instead of 2016 as originally envisioned. The two are paying $10.8 billion to share coverage of the tournament from 2011 to 24, with the games being broadcast on CBS, TBS, TNT and truTV.

title: Image of Ahmadinejad Clasping Hands With Chvezs Mother Angers Clerics, So His Supporters Turn to Photoshop
description: To Mahmoud Ahmadinejads critics in the West, the image of him clasping hands with the grief-stricken mother of Hugo Chvez at her sons funeral last week in Caracas might have seemed like a rare glimpse of a firebrand politicians softer side. But the clerics who rule Iran saw something very different: proof that the Islamic Republics official representative had flouted that nations absolute ban on physical contact between unrelated men and women.

title: Arkansass Abortion Ban and One Mans Strong Will
description: CONWAY, Ark.  The adoption by Arkansas last week of the countrys strictest abortion ban  at 12 weeks of pregnancy, when a fetal heartbeat is typically detected  gave a new jolt of energy to a loose band of abortion foes who are pushing similar measures in several states.

title: Boeing Seeks Approval for Updated Jet
description: Boeing is likely to seek approval from its board as early as next month to start taking orders for an updated version of its 777 passenger jet, industry officials said Monday.

title: Hungary Tests the E.U.'s Norms
description: For Hungary, still seeking national accord on what constitutes democracy, and for Europe, still uncertain how to treat governments deemed to have strayed from European Union norms, Monday produced a symbolic moment in the annals of protecting civil rights.

title: Inspiration in an Imperfect Tournament, by Way of Europe
description: PHOENIX

title: Responding to  Financial Crisis, Britain Overhauls Its Regulators
description: LONDON  After the financial crisis, countries like the United States adopted wide-ranging changes to their banking regulation.

title: Gun-Rights Allies Rally in Hartford Against New Rules
description: HARTFORD  More than 1,000 supporters of gun rights, most wearing red stickers reading N.R.A. Stand and Fight, packed the atrium of the State Capitol on Monday as Connecticuts protracted negotiations on new gun laws seemed to be lurching toward a resolution.

title: Arizona: Most of Law on Ethnic Studies Is Upheld
description: A federal judge has upheld all but one aspect of an Arizona law prohibiting school districts from offering courses taught from a specific racial or ethnic perspective, which targeted the Mexican-American studies program at some Tucson public schools. The ruling Friday, by Judge A. Wallace Tashima of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, came in a lawsuit brought by teachers and students at the Tucson Unified School District against Arizonas school superintendent, John Huppenthal, and other state officials. The plaintiffs say the law is too broad to be constitutional. The law, signed in 2010, prohibits public schools from offering courses that promote the overthrow of the United States government, advocate ethnic solidarity and foster resentment toward a race or class of people. In Tucson, students studied history and literature from a Mexican-American perspective. Opponents said the curriculum encouraged students to resent white people. Judge Tashima ruled, however, that banning classes tailored specifically to students of a particular ethnicity is unconstitutional.

title: For U.S. Seminarians, a Ringside Seat
description: ROME  Morning prayers, chanted in Latin, had just ended at the Benedictine monastery in France, where a few American seminarians were on retreat. A monk quietly approached one of them, James Platania, who was walking through the cloister to the refectory, and asked if he had heard the news.

title: Hagel to Open Review of Sexual Assault Case
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is beginning an internal review of a decision by a senior Air Force commander to overturn the sexual assault conviction of an Air Force fighter pilot, he said in a letter to top lawmakers made public Monday.

title: U.N. Ties Gaza Babys Death to Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  A United Nations report has suggested that a Palestinian infant who died in the fighting in Gaza last November may have been killed by an errant Palestinian rocket rather than by an Israeli airstrike as was widely believed at the time. The infants death quickly became a powerful symbol of the conflict.

title: Home of the Lion That Hercules Slew
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Im blogging this from the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, and one of the nice things about solving puzzles in the midst of all this intelligence is that there is always help around when you need it. For example, there I was, sitting in the Marriott lounge, regretting the fact that I wept through most of my college calculus class because of the clue at 14 Down, when the constructor Byron Walden walked by. Mr. Walden is a math professor with a Ph.D. in some mathy subject, so it was a serendipitous moment to stick out my arm, grab him by the lapel, and scream What is a four-letter word for calculus calculation? Now thats what I call using your resources.

title: Defining Bullying Down
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Notre Dame and UConn Roll to Final
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut, which has reeled off five consecutive Big East tournament titles in womens basketball, will face a Notre Dame team eyeing its first such crown in Tuesday nights championship game at XL Center.

title: As Rats Persist, Transit Agency Hopes to Curb Their Births
description: They have thwarted the poisons. They have evaded the traps.

title: The Conclaves Fixed Ways
description: And now the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church retreat into the Sistine Chapel, hordes of journalists flitting breathlessly around St. Peters Square, one question above many others hanging in the air. Will the next pope chart a course of truly significant change for the church, which could certainly use some changing?

title: Lowes Campaign Keeps Eye on the Weather
description: LOWES is introducing a new round of advertising to promote home improvement projects in the spring, its prime revenue-generating period. The ads, which began appearing on Sunday, reflect an effort by Lowes to take advantage of the rebounding housing market and catch up to Home Depot, the countrys most profitable national home improvement company.

title: The Grim Backlog at Veterans Affairs
description: A new report based on previously unreleased data from the Department of Veterans Affairs paints a distressing portrait of an agency buried helplessly in paperwork  with a claims backlog that has gotten far worse in the past four years. The average wait to begin receiving disability compensation and other benefits is 273 days, and up to 327 days for veterans making claims for the first time. Those in big cities wait far longer  up to 642 days in New York. The total number of veterans with backlogged claims is about 600,000.

title: Toxic Threats to Grassland Birds
description: Ornithologists agree that in the United States no group of birds is declining faster than the grassland species that live in or migrate through agricultural areas. These include, among others, various sparrows, eastern and western meadowlarks, bobolinks, horned larks and at least two kinds of owl. Scientists have generally agreed that the major cause is the fragmentation and loss of prairie habitat, the conversion of grassland to farmland as well as alterations in established farmland.

title: Unholy Alliance
description: Some horrific events over the past few months, including the shooting of a Pakistani schoolgirl and the rape and murder of a young Indian physiotherapy student, should have been an alert for the world to unite in preventing violence against women.

title: The Axis of Ennui
description: Because I have to generate two columns a week for you, Dear Reader, I spend some time hunting for new ideas on the conference circuit. When you are on that circuit, you are perpetually under the illusion that you are hearing from the exciting, fresh people who are about to change history.

title: Politics by Intimidation
description: Three days before the December massacre in Newtown, Conn., a 22-year-old gunman named Jacob Tyler Roberts opened fire at the Clackamas Town Center, a suburban shopping mall in Portland, Ore. He killed two people before killing himself, though it could have been much worse. His stolen semiautomatic AR-15 rifle jammed early in his shooting spree.

title: In China, Cinematic Flops Suggest Fading of an Icon
description: BEIJING  It has been five decades since Mao Zedong decreed that the altruistic, loyal soldier Lei Feng should be a shining star in the Communist Partys constellation of propaganda heroes. But last week, on the 50th anniversary of that proclamation, came unmistakable signs that despite the Chinese governments best efforts, Lei Fengs glow is fading.

title: Trapped Next to a Chatty 8-Year-Old, All the Way to Beijing
description: IM a 24-year-old entrepreneur in mobile technologies. I havent been flying for business all that long, but its really important to my companys growth. I almost always leave home without doing much in terms of checking on my flight, having ground transportation or a hotel reserved. That may sound irresponsible, but Ive found that mobile apps can do almost everything for me when Im on the road.

title: Realities Behind Prosecuting Big Banks
description: Are banks too big to jail?

description: To the Editor:

title: A Universal Right to Vote
description: Last months Supreme Court arguments over the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act served as a reminder of the long history of racial voting suppression in this country. Many of the states covered by Section 5 of the act, particularly in the South, spent decades trying every method they could think of to keep blacks and other minorities from the polls, or to reduce their voting strength.

title: Anthony Returns to Lineup in Time for Pivotal Road Trip
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Carmelo Anthony has been primed for his return: to the city he shunned, to the lineup that needs him, to a Knicks season that is teetering uncomfortably beneath his feet as it enters the home stretch.

title: House and Senate Work Simultaneously to Create Budgets, a Rarity
description: WASHINGTON  Congress this week will begin taking the first steps toward a more structured and orderly budget process, beginning what both parties hope is a move away from the vicious cycle of deadline-driven quick fixes.

title: Qaeda Group in Iraq Says It Killed Syrian Soldiers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Sunni militant jihadist group in Iraq claimed responsibility on Monday for killing dozens of Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety on the Iraqi side of the border last week, boasting about the massacre in an Internet posting that used demeaning references to Shiites and President Bashar al-Assads Alawite sect.

title: Penny-Pinching in Pinstripes? Yes, the Yanks Are Reining In Pay
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees, the sports franchise known almost as much for lavish spending as winning 27 World Series titles, are turning fiscally conservative.

title: To Prevent Overpass Hits, New Rules for Truckers
description: Tractor-trailers and other commercial vehicles are prohibited from using parkways in New York, like the Jackie Robinson Parkway in Brooklyn and Queens and the Saw Mill River Parkway in Westchester County.

title: In Presidents Outreach to G.O.P., Past Failures Loom
description: WASHINGTON  For all the attention to President Obamas new campaign of outreach to Republicans, it was four months ago  on the eve of bipartisan budget talks  that he secretly invited five of them to the White House for a movie screening with the stars of Lincoln, the film about that presidents courtship of Congress to pass a significant measure.

title: In Bullpen Competition, a Track Record Matters
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets bullpen represents one of the teams weakest areas, and at first glance, visions of how it might be constructed for opening day can appear muddled.

title: Kenyan Reaction to Disputed Election Is Far Calmer Than Last Time
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In the Kibera slum, where the sun beats down mercilessly on the metal shacks and ribbons of raw sewage snake across the dirt, people are about as angry as they have ever been.

title: The Reaction in Kenya
description: Jeffrey Gettleman reports from Kibera, a part of Nairobi that was a flashpoint of violence during Kenyas last presidential election. This time, things are tense but there has been no violence so far.

title: Barcelona Facing an Early Ouster and Much Analysis
description: Barcelona has become the pre-eminent club team in soccer in recent years but now stands on the brink of being ousted from Europes annual Champions League without even making it to the quarterfinals. It trails A.C. Milan by two goals as it prepares for the second leg of their matchup, on Tuesday, before a stadium full of Barcelona fans who cannot quite believe their mighty team is in such a hole. Can they escape? Are they not as good as they used to be? Four of The New York Timess soccer writers weigh in with their thoughts.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Mar. 12, 2013
description: Ive got to defend my children, and yours, and do whats right to save lives. Obesity kills. Theres no question it kills.

title: Corrections: March 12, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Self-Absorbed, With Chekhov as a Backdrop
description: I am beginning to think that all an aspiring (or established) dramatist needs to do to draw notice is to billboard some connection to Chekhov in his or her work, so august has the Russian authors name become. Neva, a new play written and directed by the Chilean writer Guillermo Caldern that is having its English-language premiere at the Public Theater, is a turgid and repetitive meditation on love, theater and politics, but it has already been widely seen on international stages, possibly because Olga Knipper, Chekhovs widow, has a central role.

title: Intersection: L Train Inspiration
description: Yani Aviles, a Brooklyn native, explains the ebbs and flows of the Williamsburg neighborhood, as well as how she mixes patterns and textures to create her own style.

title: Judge in Soda Ruling Is Wary of Governments Power
description: He ended a state policy of routinely shackling even nonviolent offenders on their way to and from the courthouse. He stopped, at least temporarily, a new city rule limiting the number of art vendors in the parks.

title: A Hobbled Cashman Goes Fishing for Infielders
description: TAMPA, Fla.  General Manager Brian Cashman sat in the teams dugout Monday morning with his broken leg perched on the bench, discussing his desire to entice first baseman Derrek Lee out of retirement to help save the Yankees from their numerous injuries.

title: Cheering a Setback to the Citys Drink Limits
description: It would have amounted to a tax on the poor, said some. It would have had little effect anyway, noted others, because people would still have been allowed free refills. It was un-American, said others still, for was this not the country of freedom, more or less, of choice?

title: Lax Nets Allow the 76ers Offense to Come to Life
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Nets have effectively flexed their muscles against the weaker teams in the Eastern Conference all season long, but on Monday, they were outhustled and outplayed by the flailing Philadelphia 76ers for almost a full 48 minutes.

title: Trial of a Therapists Killer Will Hinge on Frame of Mind
description: One evening five years ago, David Tarloff lurked in the stairwell of an Upper East Side building, waiting to rob his former psychiatrist after the last patient left his office.

title: Russian Judge Delays Trial of Dead Lawyer
description: MOSCOW  Justice delayed is justice denied, of course, but for a corpse?

title: U.S. Expels 2 Venezuela Envoys
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The United States said Monday that it had expelled two Venezuelan diplomats in response to the ouster last week of two American military attachs by Venezuela.

title: Iran Blocks Way to Bypass Internet Filtering System
description: TEHRAN  Irans powerful Ministry of Information and Communications Technology has blocked the most popular software used by millions of Iranians to bypass an elaborate official Internet filtering system, stepping up a campaign to gain more control over the way Iranians use the Internet.

title: Yankees Embrace Frugality as New Business Model
description: Since 2003, the Yankees have paid dearly for routinely exceeding the guideline for payroll set by Major League Baseball.

title: Google Shows Off Sample Apps for Glasses
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Google glasses are everywhere here at South by Southwest. But ask a wearer to try them on or take a photo and youre quickly rebuffed.

title: Jury Still at Work in Cannibal Case
description: The jury in the trial of the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women was sent home on Monday after deliberating for a second full day without reaching a verdict.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 11, 2013

title: 2 Afghan Sisters, Swept Up in a Suicide Wave
description: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan  On the surface, the Gul sisters seemed to have it all: they were young, beautiful, educated and well off, testing the bounds of conservative Afghan traditions with fitted jeans, makeup and cellphones.

title: In Fighting Teenage Pregnancy, the Folly of Shame and Blame
description: It is well past time when anyone can afford to be value-neutral when it comes to teen pregnancy.

title: Lilian Craig, Beloved of Prince Who Could Be King, Dies at 97
description: If I were to sum up my life, everything has been about love, Princess Lilian of Sweden once said.

title: For Detroit, a Crisis of Bad Decisions and Crossed Fingers
description: DETROIT  This city was already sinking under hundreds of millions of dollars in bills that it could not pay when a municipal auditor brought in a veteran financial consultant to dig through the books. A seasoned turnaround man and former actuary with Ford Motor Co., he was stunned by what he found: an additional $7.2 billion in retiree health costs that had never been reported, or even tallied up.

title: William Moody, 58, Pro Wrestlings Paul Bearer, Dies
description: William Moody, better known as the professional wrestling manager Paul Bearer, who could summon supernatural powers from an urn of cremated ashes whenever his 6-foot-10, 299-pound client, the Undertaker, was in trouble, died on March 5 in Mobile, Ala. He was 58.

title: My Mothers Mink
description: One day my mom simply put the mink coat in a plastic bag, stuffed the bag into a box and shipped it to me. She lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., where she has no needof a calf-length fur in the eight weeks that pretend to be winter, and the mink had become something of a reprimand: Why did she no longer live the kind of life that required a fur coat?

title: Whither Barcelona?
description: With Barcelona needing to overcome a 2-0 deficit against visiting Milan on Tuesday to remain in the Champions League, four Times soccer writers took brief looks at the state of the team as it stands on the brink of elimination.

title: Sybil Christopher, Nightclub Founder, Dies at 83
description: Sybil Christopher, a theater producer, former actress, famous ex-wife and founder of Arthur, one of Manhattans most popular celebrity nightclubs in the 1960s, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Falkland Islanders Vote to Remain Part of Britain
description: BUENOS AIRES  All but three voters in the Falkland Islands, the south Atlantic archipelago, cast ballots Sunday and Monday in favor of remaining an overseas territory of Britain.

title: Vigil for Brooklyn Teenager Fatally Shot by the Police Turns Violent
description: A vigil for an armed Brooklyn teenager who was fatally shot by police officers turned violent Monday night when a small group broke off from the gathering and began throwing bottles at a local police precinct station house and knocking food off a bodega stand, the authorities said.

title: Word of the Day | unimpeachable
description: unimpeachable \n-im-pe-ch-bl\ adjective

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 1:15 P.M. (MoreMax) LOLA VERSUS (2012) After Lola (Greta Gerwig, above), a graduate student in New York, is dumped by her fianc, Luke (Joel Kinnaman), as her 30th birthday approaches, she tries to pull her life together with the help of her best friends, the wacky Alice (Zoe Lister-Jones) and the sensitive Henry (Hamish Linklater). But somehow Luke cant let go of Lola entirely, and she cant help longing to get back together with him. Debra Winger and Bill Pullman play Lolas mostly supportive parents.
