description: To the Editor:

title: California Bill Seeks Campus Credit for Online Study
description: Legislation will be introduced in the California Senate on Wednesday that could reshape higher education by requiring the states public colleges and universities to give credit for faculty-approved online courses taken by students unable to register for oversubscribed classes on campus.

title: Colorado Student Receives $100,000 Intel First Prize
description: A high school senior who cultivated populations of algae under her loft bed won first place and $100,000 in the Intel Science Talent Search on Tuesday night.

title: Mary and the Zombies: Can Science Explain Consciousness?
description: We trust science because its claims are based on experience. But experience itself is a subjective reality that seems to elude the objectivity of scientific understanding. We know that our experiencesof seeing red, feeling pain, falling in love and so forthdepend on physical systems like the brain that science can, in principle, exhaustively explain. But its hard to make sense of the idea that experiences themselves could be physical. No doubt experiences correlate with objective physical facts, but, as subjective phenomena, how could they be such facts? When I feel intense pain, scientists may be able to observe brain-events that cause my pain, but they cannot observe the very pain that I feel. What science can observe is public and objective; what I feel is private and subjective.

title: Arthur J. Mirante II
description: Mr. Mirante, 69, is a principal of the Canadian commercial real estate company Avison Young and the president of its Tri-State division, which was established last year in New York.

title: Honest Tea Creates a Business Guide as a Comic Book
description: WHEN it was building its brand, the beverage maker Honest Tea stayed off the conventional marketing grid, opting for samplings, recycling events and word of mouth to reach its audience. Now the companys founders are taking an alternate route to telling a button-down corporate history and are instead laying out their story, warts and all, in the pictorial form of a comic book.

title: Rains or Not, India Is Falling Short on Drinkable Water
description: CHERRAPUNJI, India  Almost no place on Earth gets more rain than this small hill town. Nearly 40 feet falls every year  more than 12 times what Seattle gets. Storms often drop more than a foot a day. The monsoon is epic.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Providence Is Top City in Contest of Ideas
description: When Angel Taveras, the mayor of Providence, R.I., got wind of a lucrative contest among mayors over ideas for improving their cities, his mind turned immediately to children.

title: Sudans Sign Agreement to Resume Oil Exports
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Sudan and South Sudan, moving to reduce the hostilities that have severely weakened both of their economies, signed an agreement early Tuesday morning that could lead to the resumption of oil production in two weeks.

title: Map of the Dispute in Syria
description: An analysis of news reports and videos posted online indicates that rebels are stronger in Syrias north and northeast.

title: Corrections: March 13, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Down in the Basement, Family Tensions Stir
description: The streets are aflame with conflict in Dominique Morisseaus play Detroit 67, but the temperature in the basement recreation room where the action takes place never rises much above a mild simmer. An overly tidy drama that uses the riots that roiled the title city as the background to formulaic stories about a brother and sister at odds and an interracial romance, Ms. Morisseaus play blends sentiment and social history in roughly equal parts, with results that feel studied and disappointingly bland.

title: Written Promises
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  I am by no means an expert on opera, but I know what I like. I like most of the theme in Joe DiPietros punny take on operas.

title: At This Movie House, the Drama Is Off Screen
description: Love, friendship and the daily grind all take on a distinctly sticky quality in The Flick, the moving, beautifully acted and challengingly long new play by Annie Baker that opened on Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan. Ms. Baker, one of the freshest and most talented dramatists to emerge Off Broadway in the past decade, writes with tenderness and keen insight about the way people make messes of their lives  and the lives of people they care about  and then sink into benumbed impotence, hard pressed to see any way of cleaning things up.

title: Conflict in Northern Borneo Seems Poised to Escalate
description: MANILA  The leader of a band of armed Filipinos seeking to revive a historical territorial claim on the eastern Malaysian island of Borneo said on Tuesday that his group was evading that countrys forces and was trying to observe a unilateral cease-fire, but would not surrender.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Mar. 13, 2013
description: We have found a habitable environment that is so benign and supportive of life that probably if this water was around and you had been on the planet, you would have been able to drink it.

title: Balanced Budget Dispute Is Fiscal and Philosophical
description: WASHINGTON  What is so special about a balanced budget?

title: Ailing Anthony Is Probably Probable
description: DENVER  The stiffness in Carmelo Anthonys right knee lingered through another day, another flight and another city, threatening to put a crimp in his anticipated homecoming.

title: N.B.A. Says Smith Shouldnt Have Been Ejected From Mondays Game
description: DENVER  Upon further review, J. R. Smith should not have been ejected from Monday nights loss against the Golden State Warriors.

title: Report Finds Political Splits and Unprofessionalism in Voting Agency
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments independent inspector general on Tuesday portrayed its voting rights section as torn by deep ideological polarization and the harassment and marginalization of employees and managers by both liberal and conservative factions dating to the Bush administration and continuing into the Obama era.

title: Notre Dame Exits With a Title
description: HARTFORD  Notre Dames womens basketball team left the Big East in style, winning the conference tournament for the first time when Natalie Achonwas basket with 1.8 seconds left provided a 61-59 victory over Connecticut on Tuesday night.

title: A History of Deficits
description: Economists generally agree that the government should narrow its budget deficits, but most argue that eliminating them altogether is not necessary to stabilize the debt.

title: Lackluster Loss Puts an End to Tortorellas Era of Good Feeling
description: BUFFALO  Just when John Tortorella was feeling good about the Rangers and their run of five victories in six games, they lost to the struggling Buffalo Sabres, 3-1, Tuesday night. Afterward, Tortorella erupted, the veins pulsing in his forehead.

title: Big Easts Final Act Gets Off to a Halting Start
description: The players from Seton Hall and South Florida were ready go, all 10 of them gathered around the center circle for the tip-off of the 2013 Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night. But the referee Jeff Clark had not received the cue from television to begin.

title: No Division Required in This School Problem
description: BOSTON  While school officials and parents here were debating how to assign students to Bostons public schools, a lanky young man was quietly observing their public proceedings.

title: Election of a Pope Tests Betting Markets
description: Intrade may have shut down, but the election of a pope still offers a good chance to study the predictive value of betting odds. Eight years ago, when Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger ascended to St. Peters throne, the oddsmakers looked prescient: he was the favorite, or a co-favorite, in several places. Thirty-five years ago, the bookies  and, by extension, the wisdom of crowds  did much less well: Cardinal Karol Jozef Wojtyla, soon to become Pope John Paul II, was nowhere among the favorites.

title: Ewald-Heinrich von Kleist, Anti-Hitler Plotter, Dies at 90
description: Ewald-Heinrich von Kleist, believed to be the last surviving member of an elaborate plot to kill Adolf Hitler during World War II, died on Friday at his home in Munich. He was 90.

title: John J. Byrne Dies at 80; Turned Around Geico
description: John J. Byrne, who became an insurance industry legend by saving Geico from the brink of bankruptcy in the 1970s and averting widespread financial damage, died on Thursday at his home in Etna, N.H. He was 80.

title: This Time, Nets Beat a Lowly Opponent
description: With the Atlantic Division-leading Knicks slogging through a Western trip, the second-place Nets are in Brooklyn with a chance to cut the Knicks lead in the standings before they begin their own long Western swing next week. On Tuesday, one day after a dismal defeat to lowly Philadelphia, the short-handed Nets rebounded with a thorough and systematic 108-98 victory over another last-place team, the New Orleans Hornets.

title: Contest to Name a Lawn Ends as It Gets Personal
description: It was supposed to be a playful contest, an opportunity for the public to name a lawn in Brooklyn Bridge Park, which is still under construction.

title: Howard Draws Boos, and Many Fouls
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Kobe Bryant had a simple message for Dwight Howard before Howards first game back in Orlando.

title: Letter From Grace Meng to Judge Allyne R. Ross
description: Read a letter from Grace Meng to the courts pleading for leniency in sentencing her father.

title: Ex-Queens Assemblyman Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: A former state assemblyman from Queens who pleaded guilty to participating in a bribery scheme was sentenced on Tuesday to serve one month in prison and ordered to pay a $30,000 fine, ending a case that had cast a cloud over his daughters political ascent to Congress.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2013

title: Venezuela: Panel Will Investigate Roots of Cancer That Killed Chvez
description: Venezuela will create a scientific panel to investigate the illness of Hugo Chvez, after an accusation by the interim president last week that the former presidents cancer was mysteriously caused by his enemies. We have this intuition that our Commander Chvez was poisoned by dark forces that wanted to get rid of him to destroy the Bolivarian revolution and strike at Latin America and the Caribbean, Nicols Maduro, the interim president, said Monday night. Mr. Chvez, a charismatic leftist, died last week after 14 years in office. The government has refused to say what type of cancer Mr. Chvez had, but Mr. Maduro said that it had behaved in a very unusual way. Mr. Maduro said that the United States and other countries had developed programs in the 1940s and 1950s to experiment with intentionally causing cancer, but he added, Im not accusing the United States at this moment. He did not say when the scientific panel would be created or who would be on it.

title: Mali: France Will Seek U.N. Force to Replace French-Led Coalition
description: France has told fellow United Nations Security Council members it intends to introduce a resolution this month that would authorize a peacekeeping force in Mali to replace the current contingents of African and French soldiers deployed in that country, diplomats said Tuesday. France, which has said publicly it wants to scale down its forces in Mali, plans to schedule a vote on such a resolution in April, with the goal of transferring peacekeeping responsibilities by July, the diplomats said. French forces intervened two months ago in Mali, a former French colony, to stop Islamist militants occupying the northern part of the country from expanding into the south. Since then, a combination of soldiers from France, Mali and neighboring African countries has helped drive the militants out of northern Malian cities deep into the hinterlands, but they remain a threat. The exact size of a United Nations peacekeeping force for Mali has yet to be determined, but Frances foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, was quoted by Agence France-Presse as telling lawmakers in Paris it could be as many as 10,000 soldiers.

title: Kelly Questioned on Stop-and-Frisk Tactic at Council Budget Meeting
description: Just before spring, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly fulfills an annual ritual, appearing before the City Council to outline his departments preliminary budget.

title: U.S. Will Provide Millions More in Storm Aid for New York
description: The federal government has agreed to spend an additional $436 million to repair dunes, beaches and sea walls in coastal communities in New York that were hammered by Hurricane Sandy, officials announced on Tuesday.

title: Jury Finds Tenant Guilty of Setting Deadly Fire at a Crowded Brooklyn Tenement in 2010
description: A Guatemalan immigrant from Brooklyn was convicted on Tuesday of murder, arson and assault for starting a fire in a crowded tenement three years ago that killed five other Guatemalan immigrants in one of the deadliest New York City blazes in years.

title: Senate Debate Introduces 3 Republicans to Massachusetts Voters
description: EASTON, Mass.  Massachusetts voters got their first look Tuesday night at the three largely unknown Republicans who are running to fill the Senate seat left vacant by John Kerry, now the secretary of state.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged With Killing 2 and Dumping Guns
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with murder in the killings of two men whose bodies were found badly burned in a Queens marsh last week, officials said Tuesday night.

title: When Exercise Stresses You Out
description: For most people, exercise elevates mood. Repeated studies with humans and animals have shown that regular workouts can increase stress resistance, decrease anxiety, lessen symptoms of depression and generally leave people cheerful.

title: Word of the Day | oblivion
description: oblivion \-bli-ve-n, o-, -\ noun

title: Virginia: Bolling Decides Not to Run for Governor
description: Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling announced Tuesday that he would not leave the Republican Party and run as an independent for governor this year. I was not confident I could raise enough money to run a winning campaign, Mr. Bolling said in a message posted online and sent to supporters. In November, Mr. Bolling said he would not run for the Republican nomination, clearing the way for Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the state attorney general. He cited the state partys nominating process, which would favor the more conservative Mr. Cuccinelli. Mr. Bolling has withheld an endorsement for either Mr. Cuccinelli or Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic Partys leading candidate.

title: Florida: Exhumations Sought at Reform School
description: State Attorney General Pam Bondi sought a court order on Tuesday to allow the exhumation of bodies thought to be buried at the Dozier School for Boys in Marianna, which closed in 2011. The reform school was dogged by reports that the staff beat, neglected and mistreated boys for decades. Forensic anthropologists have spent the past year using radar in the Boot Hill cemetery and have found 50 possible graves. Families of some of the dead boys have asked for exhumations so they can bring their bodies home and resolve questions about their deaths. The boys died between 1900 and 1952.

title: Dominican Republic Wins Again but Remains Wary of U.S.
description: MIAMI  As the Dominican Republic continues to buzzsaw its way through the World Baseball Classic, Manager Tony Pena talks of his team in reverent tones. They are on a mission, he says. There is a reason they are here. Maybe it would sound disingenuous if the Dominicans were not undefeated, if they were not so good.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (Discovery) UNDER SIEGE: AMERICAS NORTHERN BORDER Reporters go under cover with the Homeland Security Department to patrol the border with Canada, focusing on an 863-mile stretch on either side of the Ambassador Bridge linking Detroit to Windsor, Ontario. The area has narrow crossings, heavy boat traffic and many landing spots, which make it especially difficult to stem the flow of illegal money, guns and drugs. The show also looks inside the Operational Integration Center, where live data of the entire border streams from an enormous wall of monitors.

title: The Man Behind the 47 Percent Video Comes Forward
description: 10:48 a.m. | Updated  It was one of the enduring mysteries of the 2012 campaign: who was the source of the video that captured Mitt Romney saying at a private fundraiser that 47 percent of Americans are too dependent on government, a remark that haunted him through the remainder of the presidential race?

title: News Quiz | March 13, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: With 6,000 Dead Pigs in River, Troubling Questions on Food Safety
description: BEIJING  Pork buns and tap water may be off the menu in Shanghai, Chinas biggest city with more than 23 million people, after thousands of dead pigs were found floating in the Huangpu River, which flows through the city, and in upstream tributaries. About 6,000 animals have been fished out so far in an operation that began last Friday, according to the Shanghai authorities, with more still surfacing, though at a slower pace. (By early Sunday, four days after this was written, about 12,600 pigs had been fished out of rivers in Shanghai and upstream in Jiaxing, the South China Morning Post reported.)

title: Mohammad Aamir Khans 14 Lost Years
description: On a February night in 1998, Mohammad Aamir Khan, a resident of the Old Delhi area of Indias capital made his way to a chemist to buy medicine for a kidney stone problem. The deserted streets did not bother Mr. Khan, then 18, since he had lived in the neighborhood all his life and knew that there were likely to be very few people around at that time of the day.

title: Singapore Pledges Inquiry Into Death of an American Engineer
description: WASHINGTON  Singapores foreign minister has pledged that his country will investigate the death of an American engineer whose family rejects a Singaporean police finding that their son committed suicide.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 13

Anne Barnard reports from Beirut.

title: Young Scientists Compete at the Intel Science Talent Contest
description: Update: Winners have been chosen!  Read about the Colorado student who cultivated populations of algae under her loft bed and took home the grand prize.

title: Chinese Activist, Now in U.S., Says His Relatives Remain Under Surveillance
description: HONG KONG  Almost a year after the Chinese human rights advocate Chen Guangcheng made an audacious escape from detention in his home village, his family there remains under surveillance and his jailed nephew has said he was beaten and warned by officials not to challenge his conviction, Mr. Chen and his older brother say.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 13, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Fee, Fi, Fo, Fizzle: Jack Disappoints at the Box Office.

title: Ted Kennedy Jr. Is (Finally) Ready for the Family Business
description: In early December, Washingtons political class was in one of its episodic ventilations over who would fill the latest round of job openings. The intrigue of the moment involved Hillary Clintons replacement as secretary of state. Susan Rice, the U. S. ambassador to the United Nations and onetime front-runner, was taking a public battering, and the fallback candidate, Senator John Kerry, was looking more likely to get the job. This would in turn mean that another Massachusetts Senate seat would be up for grabs  the third election since the death of Ted Kennedy in 2009.

title: North Korea Hurls Barb at President of the South
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea issued a direct personal attack on the Souths new president for the first time since her inauguration two weeks ago, saying on Wednesday that her venomous swish of skirt was to blame for rising tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Daily Life in Syrias Civil War
description: Lynsey Addario entered Syria this year on assignment for The New York Times to show a broader, more human aspect of the conflict there. Her work took her to Aleppo Province, home to Syrias largest city and site of some of the fiercest fighting. In a phone conversation with James Estrin from London, Ms. Addario, 39, discussed her recent work. Their conversation has been edited.

title: Do Shame and Blame Work to Change Teenage Behavior?
description: The New York City mayors office has drawn fire for a campaign against teenage pregnancy that features a series of posters the office says sends a strong message directly to teenagers about the extremely negative, life-altering consequences of having a baby too young.

title: Corruption Charges Filed Against Former Air Chief
description: 5:27 p.m. | Updated

title: SXSW Music: Fame Is Just One Motivation in Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As the South by Southwest Music Festival got under way on Tuesday, Panache Booking, a Brooklyn agency, held a party at the Tillery Street Plant Company, letting their clients and a few friends fill the normally quiet and meditative nursery with raucous rock. For many bands on the bill it was the start of a long week.

title: Hidden Costs of the Minimum Wage
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: What (Not) to Ask on a Campus Tour
description: Martha C. Merrill is the dean of admission and financial aid at Connecticut College.

title: Technology Meets Art at Edinburgh
description: LONDON  The way that technology seizes and shifts our perceptions of a world is the theme of this years Edinburgh Festival, its director, Jonathan Mills, announced at a news conference this week in the Queens Gallery of Buckingham Palace. The festival, which will run from Aug. 9 to Sept. 1, offers its usual dense array of performances and genres, with more than 90 productions scheduled across all genres.

title: Daily Report: Google Concedes That Drive-by Prying Violated Privacy
description: Google acknowledged on Tuesday that it had violated peoples privacy during its Street View mapping project when it casually scooped up passwords, e-mails and other personal information from unsuspecting computer users, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times.

title: The Life and Soul of the Party
description: JERUSALEM  An entire Israeli political species may soon go extinct, now that Reuven Rivlin, its last senior member, has lost the support of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Suntech, Owing Millions, Faces a Takeover
description: One of the worlds largest manufacturers of solar panels, Suntech Power, has nearly run out of cash and is poised to be taken over partly or entirely by the municipal governments holding company in its hometown, Wuxi, China, solar industry executives and a Wuxi official said Wednesday.

title: The Darwin-Sartre Connection
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: Getting New Employees Off to a Good Start
description: In my last few posts, Ive described how H.Bloom uses its recruiting program and interview process to hire talent. After the second recruiting post, a commenter from Houston asked a great question about orientation for new employees. In this post, I want to help answer that question. Once you have hired these talented folks, how do you make sure they get off to a good start? I reached out to some really smart people who are building innovative companies in New York City to learn what they do.

title: Challenges Facing Next S.E.C. Chief
description: Mary Jo White got a friendly reception during testimony before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, moving closer to becoming the next leader of the Securities and Exchange Commission. But even her supporters on Capitol Hill highlighted the significant challenges that would await her in that role, DealBooks Ben Protess writes.

title: Club for Growth Leads Conservative Charge, Sometimes at Republicans
description: Representative Adam Kinzinger, Republican of Illinois, would seem to be just the kind of promising politician his party needs at this stage: a telegenic, 35-year-old former Air Force pilot, close to members of the House leadership and an effective campaigner who won easily in both 2010 and 2012.

title: For a Subway Seat, Weighing Pregnancy Against Infirmity
description: Dear Diary:

title: Some New Songs for a Side Career
description: The last time Justin Timberlake released an album, Barack Obama was the junior senator from Illinois, Jay-Z and Beyonc were not married, and iPhones did not exist. It was 2006, just a few weeks before Taylor Swifts debut album arrived, setting her on the path to become perhaps the last old-fashioned pop superstar. But since then rapid industry decline and atomization have all but eliminated the need for Justin Timberlakes, or Taylor Swifts, or certainly the opportunities to make new ones.

title: Opinion Report: The Ryan Budget
description: From the editorial page

title: More Companies Holding Annual Board Elections, Group Reports
description: When it comes to one of the oldest corporate takeover defenses around, more and more companies are saying no.

title: Wednesday Reading: When Exercise Stresses You Out
Night of the Living Alesina
description: Ah, remember the good old days of expansionary austerity? On both sides of the Atlantic, austerians seized on academic work by Alberto Alesina and Silvia Ardagna claiming that fiscal consolidation, if focused on spending cuts, would if anything lead to economic expansion. It wasnt because the paper was especially compelling  even a quick look suggested that the methodology for identifying austerity was seriously flawed. But A-A told people what they wanted to hear, and they went with it.

title: Q&A: Quieting a Noisy Facebook
description: Q.

title: After Financial Crisis, Prosecutors Navigate Tricky Waters
description: The question of whether large financial institutions can ever be held fully responsible for criminal conduct has again become a political controversy.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Anna Wintours New Role and NPR Appeals to the Tweet Set
description: Cond Nast plans to announce Wednesday that Anna Wintour, editor of Vogue for nearly a quarter-century, will take on the additional role of artistic director for the company, Eric Wilson reports. The move into Cond Nasts executive ranks ends speculation that Ms. Wintour might leave the company, and it makes her one of the most powerful women in magazine publishing. Ms. Wintours new role will assume some of the responsibility from S.I. Newhouse Jr., who has controlled editorial management as Cond Nasts chairman for more than three decades. Ms. Wintour described the position as almost like being a one-person consulting firm for other editors on directing their brands.

title: Europe Seeks Update of Law on Fliers Rights
description: PARIS  Denise McDonagh might have gotten her 1,100 settlement from Ryanair faster under new traveler-rights rules the European Union proposed for the airline industry on Wednesday. But she probably wouldnt have gotten nearly as much.

title: Car Talk
description: Lapo Elkann shares with his late grandfather Gianni Agnelli  the handsome playboy king of Fiat  a love of style and automobiles. As Elkann puts the finishing touches on an exhibit of Agnellis favorite custom cars, he recalls his grandfathers devotion to driving.

title: The Low-Rise Insanity Defense
The Benefits of Mobile Health, on Hold
description: The world now has 5 billion mobile phones  one for every person over 15. Africa has a billion people and 750 million phones, and mobile is growing so fast there that in a few years there will be more phones than people. In some countries this is already true  South Africa has 47 million people, but 52 million SIM cards.

title: The Gun Report: March 13, 2013
description: Take a close look at the first item here. It shows exactly how perverse the gun show loophole iswhich, of course, has been staunchly defended over the years by the National Rifle Association. The killer, a felon who had just been released from prison, actually researched gun shows either just before or just after he killed his grandparents so that he could buy a gun without a background check. It boggles the mind. But no state can prevent someone from buying a gun elsewhere and bringing it across state lines. And the beat goes on.

title: The 266th Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church
description: A gathering of cardinals picked a new pope from among themselves on Wednesday.

title: Happy Birthday, Jamie Dimon
description: DealBook readers, take note. Wednesday is birthday No. 57 for Jamie Dimon.

title: Britain and France Push for Arming Syrian Opposition
description: LONDON  Britain and France are putting pressure on their European partners to lift an embargo on weapons and ammunition to Syrian rebels in a conflict that has claimed 70,000 lives and created one million refugees.

title: Are India and Italy on a Collision Course?
description: NEW DELHI A serious diplomatic incident appears to be brewing between India and Italy, at least as seen from this side of the Arabian Sea.

title: Researchers Find 25 Countries Using Surveillance Software
description: Last May, two security researchers volunteered to look at a few suspicious e-mails sent to some Bahraini activists. Almost one year later, the two have uncovered evidence that some 25 governments, many with questionable records on human rights, may be using off-the-shelf surveillance software to spy on their own citizens.

title: National Gallery of Arts Renovation Plan Envisions Two New Tower Galleries
description: Buildings often start to age after 35 years, and generally its the unglamorous bits  the staircases or skylights  that need attention. Such is the case with the National Gallery of Arts renowned I.M. Pei-designed East Building. When we were beginning to look into things that required work, Perry Chin, who works with I. M. Pei, would say, If youre going to do this you might consider ,  recalled Earl A. Powell III, the Gallerys director.

title: Karma Hotspot Gives Out Free Data
description: I hate when products make me a shill by alerting everyone on Facebook when I use them. Maybe I dont want to share what pictures Ive viewed on EyeEm, and I certainly dont want Spotify telling anyone I listened to the Archies.

title: Boutique Wines Aloft
description: A number of airlines in recent years have hired famous chefs to develop their in-flight meals. The Japanese airline All Nippon Airways has taken the indulgence one step further; it has brought on Ned Goodwin, a holder of the Master of Wine title and former sommelier at the restaurant Veritas in New York City, to produce wines exclusively for its passengers. The wines, made from grapes from the Languedoc and Roussillon wine regions in France and blended and matured by the boutique winery Hecht & Bannier, will be served through August.

title: New York Performing Artists Share Inspiration on Made Here
description: Made Here, a documentary series and interactive Web site that gathers interviews, performances and other footage to showcase the lives of New York City performing artists, is headed into its third and fourth seasons.

title: Voter Turnout
description: On Monday the group Nonprofit VOTE released a report on turnout in the November election. Much of the information isnt newlike the fact that an estimated 58.7 percent of eligible voters actually went to the polls, below the 2008 benchmark but still above most elections from the last 40 years.

title: Up for a Vote, the Pay Phone of the Future
description: Meanwhile, in other voting news on Wednesday, a sensuous wraparound booth and a slender concave kiosk were leading a popularity contest on Facebook, the Reinvent Payphones Design Challenge, sponsored by the Bloomberg administration.

title: Commerzbank to Raise Capital and Repay Taxpayer Money
description: 11:41 a.m. | Updated

title: SXSW Music: Korean Pop With Its Own Special f(x)
description: Mystique does not thrive at South by Southwest. It is very rarely a festival where the polished pop star bestows a slick, remote performance on distant fans and then disappears back behind the veil of celebrity. The clubs where most gigs take place are too small and the stages are too low for that; audience members are close enough to see musicians eye to eye. They can probably run into them backstage, too, loading their own equipment into the van. Even at larger places, the stars dont get to bring their custom-built stages, lights and sound systems; they play in the existing setups, like the big, bumpy backyard of a barbecue place or a generic temporary stage in a warehouse or a vacant lot. Performers also experience the same Texas weather  summery even in March  that audiences do. Its a kind of leveler; who are you without your gimmicks, and how do your songs really hold up?

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: Twinkies get a new kind of preservative: a lifeline from two investment firms that have agreed to buy Hostess Brands. The likely new chief executive is the same guy who helped rescue another beloved brand, Pabst Blue Ribbon.  Patrick Farrell

title: Rates on Some Student Loans Again Set to Double
description: Its March, and its dj vu all over again as students and consumer advocates try to raise awareness of a coming increase in interest rates on some federal student loans.

title: Obama Says Budget Differences Could Be Too Wide for a Deal
description: 11:42 a.m. | Updated  President Obama, in an interview with ABC News released on Wednesday, said that the differences between Democrats and Republicans on spending and taxes may be too great to reach an agreement on the budget.

title: Catholics Speak: Global Diplomat
description: Catholics wonder whether the new pope should take a more political role on the world stage.

title: Animal Error
description: Sergio Ruzziers illustrations always manage to be soft and fluffy and kind toward children  without slipping into saccharine gauziness. In two new picture books, one written and illustrated by Ruzzier, the other written by Eve Bunting, Ruzziers spare pen-and-ink pictures charmingly enliven animal stories in just the way preschoolers like.

title: Short Term 12 and William and the Windmill Win SXSW Film Honors
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The South by Southwest grand jury award for best narrative feature was given to Short Term 12 on Tuesday night, while William and the Windmill received the grand jury award for best documentary.

title: Feeling For | Tods Satin Slipper
description: Fresh off the heels of fashion month, those who traipsed in towering stilettos should welcome this fresh flat from Tods. A nod to the understated smoking slippers for the boys, this version employs classic blue and white stripes and satin for a more feminine feel.

title: Algae Lover, Contest Winner
description: Sara Volz, Intel Science Talent Search winner, changed her sleep cycle and created a lab in her room for her first-place project.

title: Outdoor Channel Agrees to Higher Bid From Kroenke
description: Outdoor Channel Holdings said on Wednesday that it had accepted a $220.7 million takeover bid from Kroenke Sports and Entertainment, turning down an earlier offer from the media investor Leo Hindery Jr.

title: The War Comes Home to Indiana
description: In early March 1863, an officer in Terre Haute, Ind., ordered two veteran Army sergeants to cross into Clark County in nearby eastern Illinois to carry out a peculiar, though increasingly common, order: arrest a group of Union Army deserters. It wasnt an easy assignment: the men found swarms of deserters, but also met armed resistance from local residents who were fostering the runaway soldiers, and were even shot at a few times.

title: Seeking Funds for Movie, Creator of Veronica Mars Turns to Kickstarter
description: If a Veronica Mars movie doesnt happen now, there will be no mystery about who did it in  its loyal fans will be the culprits. Rob Thomas, the television producer and creator of Veronica Mars, the cult hit series that starred Kristen Bell as a crime-solving teenager, has thrown down a challenge to viewers who have long clamored for this show to be turned into a film, telling them that they had 30 days to help raise $2 million for the project and calling it our one shot to see it happen.

title: Man Sought in Upstate Shootings Is Killed
description: HERKIMER, N.Y.  A man suspected of shooting six people, killing four of them, in upstate New York before firing at the police and barricading himself in a building was killed early Thursday when the police stormed the place where he was hiding.

title: The Case for Shaking Up Hewletts Board
description: A breakup of Hewlett-Packard is both desirable and inevitable. But it requires new blood on the board.

title: Boom-and-Bust Diamondbacks Try for a Steady Approach
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: Obama Continues Evolving
description: President Obama has evolved yet again on gay rights and now seems to think that state bans on same-sex marriage are inherently unconstitutional.

title: Hellos and Goodbyes in the N.F.L.
description: In Philadelphia it was good riddance to Nnamdi Asomugha (The Eagles will pay Asomugha $4 million not to play for them in 2013 and that is the best bargain general manager Howie Roseman could have made, Phil Sheridan writes at The Inquirer.)

title: London Theater Journal: Alan Bennett, a Cozy Everywhere Man
description: LONDON  Dead-celebrity theater has long been a staple of the English-speaking stage. In New York these days, you cant turn a corner off Times Square without coming across some esteemed performer pretending to to be Ann Richards or Sue Mengers or even the tabloid columnist Mike McAlary. But this city, at the moment, likes em live.

title: Signature Theater Season to Include Premiere of New Albee Work
description: Edward Albees Laying an Egg, a new play by the Tony Award-winning writer of Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?, will have its world premiere this summer at Signature Theater, one of several productions that the company announced on Wednesday for its 2013-14 season.

title: Anger in East Flatbush Persists Over Teenagers Killing by the Police
description: First came the shooting: an armed teenager killed by police officers on a darkened Brooklyn street.

title: Scene City: A Bloodier D.C. on the Screen
description: Olympus Has Fallen premieres in New York.

title: Another Kind of White House Visit
description: Washington-bound visitors hoping to tour the White House got some bad news early this month when the Obama administration canceled all tours because of the sequestration. But for those still seeking a visit, a bloody action thriller opening next week called Olympus Has Fallen may be at least as exciting.

title: Get Ready to Talk Lean In
description: Lets put aside the egg, and talk chicken.

title: A Dozen Years of Justin Timberlake
description: Mr. Timberlake is releasing his first new album since 2006.

title: Secularism, the Arab Ways
description: CAIRO  Free Arabs,a new Web site run by a group of Arabs  some in the Middle East, others in the West  is causing a stir. Gathered under the slogan Democracy, Secularism, Fun, it lamentsthe fact that millions of Arabs have internalized the notion that secularism is tantamount to faithlessness, and is all about demonizing Islam and promoting a dissolute way of life.

title: Budget, Back and Forth
description: The Timess Jonathan Weisman on whether House and Senate plans on government spending can find convergence.

title: Lhota Makes a Strong Start in Fund-Raising
description: Joseph J. Lhota, a former deputy in the Giuliani administration who made a late entry into the race for New York City mayor, collected $730,000 in campaign contributions over the past two months, a robust show of financial muscle for a first-time candidate.

title: A New Art Direction
description: Two years ago Nate Hooper and Andy Hawgood decided to open a hybrid space in San Franciscos Tenderloin district. Part design agency and part gallery, the Popular Workshop is named after the 1960s French Situationist movement latelier populaire. The airy sprawling space, once a cable car factory, does double duty as a studio space for the partners (who specialize in creative direction for a variety of brands) and as a gallery for the eclectic events and edgy exhibitions that have put the Popular Workshop on the art scene map.

title: Having None of Having It All
description: David Brooks: As opinionators, this is the late winter of our discontent. The world just hasnt thrown up that many topics to generate passionate debate. Im not counting the new episodes of The Bachelor.

title: Detained, Deported and Determined
description: Almost every day of the week in places like Mesa, Ariz., federal authorities send planes filled with deportees back to Central America. Originally arrested for anything from traffic offenses to murder, they end up patted down and shackled with 100 others who had been in this country illegally. Even more are deported by land across the Mexican border.

title: U.S. Budget Deal in Doubt; Obamas Trip to Hill Reveals Split
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas meeting with a restive and resistant House Republican majority on Wednesday underscored their deep divisions over fiscal policy as both sides acknowledged that an overarching budget compromise was in doubt despite a new push by the White House.

title: Starter: Motorino Takes Its Pizza to Hong Kong
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

title: Delaying Retirement, for Love and for Money
description: In the latest Retirement special section, two articles explore topics of interest to readers of the Bucks blog.

title: At a Beach Club, a Battle to Rebuild After the Storm
description: In the 1984 film The Flamingo Kid, newly hired cabana boys at a beach club were made to jump off the end of a pier into the ocean below, as an initiation rite.

title: Shopping Snapshots: March 14
description: White shoes for spring; Spring showers? A new line of Illesteva umbrellas; a sun-bleached capsule collection of denim from Rebecca Taylor; and high-style sunglasses.

title: A Couple at Sea: A. L. Kennedy Talks About The Blue Book
description: A. L. Kennedys new novel, The Blue Book, is set on an ocean liner and involves a relationship between a man and a woman who used to work together as spiritual mediums. In The New York Times Book Review, Wendy Lesser wrote that the books mysterious strands come together in the end: There are no sleight-of-hand tricks practiced on us here: we are promised a certain kind of novelistic satisfaction, and Kennedy fully delivers. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Kennedy discussed what (if anything) shes learned from critics, the keys to writing about sex and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Congressional Committees Make Some Gun-Rights Provisions Permanent
description: WASHINGTON  With gun safety measures headed to the Senate floor, members of the House and Senate appropriations committees have quietly made permanent four formerly temporary gun-rights provisions largely favored by Republicans. Those provisions are part of a spending bill that would keep the government running through Sept. 30.

title: Even a Sock Cant Derail Penn State Wrestling
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.Matt Brown didnt know it was a penalty in wrestling to grab an opponents sock.

title: Netflix Allows Americans to Share Viewing Choices with Facebook Friends
description: You no longer have to ask your friends what they are watching on Netflix. Instead, you can now simply peer over their digital shoulder.

title: Updates on Election of New Pope
Marvel Signs Agreement to Take Superheroes on the Road
description: Young girls flock to Disney on Ice, touring shows that feature figure skaters dressed as cartoon characters. Will a live arena show featuring Marvel superheroes bring out older boys?

title: Cardinals Pick Bergoglio, Who Will Be Pope Francis
description: VATICAN CITY  With a puff of white smoke from the chimney of the Sistine Chapel and to the cheers of thousands of rain-soaked faithful, a gathering of Catholic cardinals picked a new pope from among their midst on Wednesday  choosing the cardinal from Argentina, the first South American to lead the church.

title: Image of the Day: March 13
Booking a Hotel in Asia? How to Plan
description: When planning a trip to Japan and Hong Kong with my boyfriend last winter  my first trip to Asia  I made what you might call rookie mistakes.

title: Witness List Set for Senate Hearing on JPMorgan Trading Loss
description: Congressional investigators have summoned current and former top executives of JPMorgan Chase, along with three regulators, to testify at a hearing Friday on the banks multibillion-dollar trading loss.

title: Not So Sweet: Investigating Science and Health Questions About Sugar and Our Bodies
description: Sugar and corn syrup have become a large part of the American diet. On average, teenagers get 17 percent of their daily calories from added sugar. Meanwhile, public health officials have taken note that more and more studies suggest a link between sugar consumption and health issues like obesity and diabetes. Some go so far as to say that sugar is toxic to our bodies, and as dangerous to our health as cigarettes.

title: Ex-Pimco Executive Backs Out of Lawsuit Contending Misconduct
description: A former executive at the Pacific Investment Management Company, the money management giant known as Pimco, has said that he was fired last year after reporting an array of misconduct at the firm to federal law enforcement officials.

title: Imagine Adjustable Prescription Glasses
description: Adlens is about to introduce a pair of inexpensive eyeglasses with both celebrity cachet and a technology that lets you adjust the prescription by just turning a knob.

title: White Smoke Rises
description: White smoke appears at the Vatican and signals that a new pope has been chosen.

title: A Poetry Grounded in Gravity and Air
description: Henri Labrouste: Structure Brought to Light, at the Museum of Modern Art, is elegant and astringent, like Labroustes work. The name may not ring a bell, but dont let that stop you from seeing the show. It is gorgeous.

title: Tortorellas (Latest) Greatest Rant
description: Rangers Coach John Tortorella has made a career of the unpredictable news conference and Tuesday night became the latest installment in that long-running series. After the Rangers lost, 3-1, to the Sabres in Buffalo, Tortorella unleashed his thoughts about a loss he found particularly disturbing. It was not the garden-variety blame-the-media rant. It was directed toward his own team.

title: New Hendrix Album Hits No. 2
description: Jimi Hendrix is dead but not forgotten. His posthumous album People, Hell and Angels, opened at No. 2 on the Billboard album chart this week, selling 72,000 copies more than four decades after he died. The last time one of Hendrixs albums charted so high was back in 1968, when Electric Ladyland spent two weeks at No. 1.

title: A Guide for Those Lost in the Aisles
description: My makeup routine has existed longer than many marriages. For the last 10 years, Ive swiped my cheeks and lids with a two-in-one blush and eye shadow from Nars, lined my eyes with Laura Merciers black liner and used DiorShow mascara on my lashes.

title: An Automotive Love Story: Reuniting a Car With Its Engine
description: Cars play major roles in many important novels, like F. Scott Fitzgeralds The Great Gatsby and Stephen Kings Christine. In a novel published this week, a car and an engine take center stage.

title: Speeding Through China
description: China recently began express train service from Beijing to Guangzhou, Xian and Luoyang, making it easier to visit the terra-cotta warriors, the Buddhist carvings at the Longmen Grottoes, and Hong Kong. The new rail service takes five and a half hours to Xian and four hours to Luoyang, which cuts travel time to each city from Beijing by more than six hours. A journey from Beijing to Hong Kong that previously took about 22 hours now takes half that on the new Beijing-Guangzhou express line.

title: Going to Tehran
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Showing | Within Sight
description: Ever wondered what surf magazine photography looks like on a large scale? Within Sight: Photographers for Recovery, curated by the New York surfer and filmmaker Mikey DeTemple, opens tomorrow and will showcase donated works by surf photographers including Dane Peterson, Nick LaVecchia and Todd Glaser.

title: Boeheim Reminisces, and Syracuse Advances
description: Seconds after the opening tipoff, Jim Boeheim adopted his signature sideline posture. He folded his arms and stood in front of the Syracuse bench.

description: To the Editor:

title: Worlds in Collision: After Tangle Over Physicists Book, Philosophers Invitation to a Debate Is Withdrawn
description: The annual Isaac Asimov Memorial Debate is the American Museum of Natural Historys biggest public event, drawing a sold-out crowd for an evening billed as bringing together the finest minds in the world to debate pressing questions on the frontiers of scientific discovery.

title: SXSW Music: Homegrown Talent in the Spotlight
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Day 1 is the first plunge into the South by Southwest miscellany, and its the warmup; the program book has only 3-1/2 pages of listings instead of the 8-1/2 or more from Wednesday through Saturday. One thing it offered me was a chance to hear performers that Austin can hear regularly, but the rest of us cant.

title: Google Puts Android and Chrome Under One Boss
description: 3:30 p.m. | Updated Added comments from Andy Rubin in letter to Android developers.

title: Googles Future Fight
description: Scott Cleland, a consumer watchdog, sees looming problems for Google after the company said it violated peoples privacy during a mapping project.

title: Parliament Rejects European Budget Agreement
description: BRUSSELS  The lawmakers of the European Union gave austerity a poke in the eye Wednesday by overwhelmingly rejecting the blocs proposed budget of 960 billion in its current form.

title: Capturing the Soul of a Business in a Single Photograph
description: Photos from readers that reveal something meaningful about the ups and downs, the grind and the rewards of building a business.

title: Henrik Fisker Resigns From Fisker Automotive
description: Fisker Automotive announced Wednesday that Henrik Fisker, its co-founder and executive chairman, had left the company because of disagreements with management. In a statement, the company said his departure was not expected to impact the companys pursuit of strategic partnerships and financing to support Fisker Automotives continued progress. The company declined requests for interviews.

title: For Cavaliers, Tristan Thompson Keeps Getting Better
description: When word surfaced Monday that Kyrie Irving could miss the remainder of the regular season with a left shoulder sprain, fans wondered if Clevelands appeal would take a hit.

title: Driver Indicted in Crash That Killed Expectant Couple
description: The man accused of causing a car accident that killed a young couple who were expecting their first child was indicted on Wednesday on a charge of leaving the scene of an accident.

title: The Small Picture: Preparing for the Big Night
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Catholics Speak: Filling the Pews
description: Catholics from around the world considered how Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina, now Pope Francis, will increase the size of the church during his papacy.

description: Rates

title: TiVo Goes Wandering, on the Road and at Home
description: You always remember the days that changed your life forever. Your first kiss. The birth of a child. The day you got a TiVo.

title: The Many Stages of Baking
description: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

title: Video Nostalgia at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  While the interactive leg of the South by Southwest festival touted the latest technological tools, select festival films were more comfortable basking in the nostalgic glow of tech history. These films either look back on, or involve, old video formats in their storytelling, in effect using the retro to usher in the new.

title: Speech by Pope Francis
description: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina is the first non-European leader of the church in more than 1,000 years.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photos from West Bank, Syria, Kashmir and Cambodia.

title: Manhattan School of Music Names New President
description: The Manhattan School of Music has appointed James Gandre as president, effective May 6. He succeeds the composer Robert Sirota, who stepped down last fall. Mr. Gandre is currently the provost and executive vice president of Roosevelt University, in Chicago, but he has worked at the Manhattan School before, as dean of enrollment and alumni from 1995 to 2000. He joined Roosevelt University in 2000, and held positions there as interim dean of the College of Education, and dean of the Chicago College of Performing Arts.

title: Twos Company, Threes a Tale
description: Actors must be thrilled when handed Michael Healeys play The Drawer Boy, no matter which of the three characters theyll be tackling. Its such a beautifully written piece, humorous and heart-wrenching but never overwrought, that all you have to do is ride the vehicle the author has provided. You can concentrate on your performance, not on dredging humor out of unfunny jokes or tears out of unconvincing moments.

title: Out of Time: The Sins of Immediacy
description: Present Shock is one of those invaluable books that make sense of what we already half-know. Playing on the title of Alvin Tofflers influential 1970 Future Shock, which sounded an alarm about what Mr. Toffler called a personal perception of too much change in too short a period of time, Douglas Rushkoff analyzes a very different phenomenon. The future arrived a little while ago, he posits  maybe with Y2K, maybe with Sept. 11. Now its here. And we are stuck with a diminishment of everything that isnt happening right now  and the onslaught of everything that supposedly is. Mr. Toffler warned that we would be unready for this onslaught. Mr. Rushkoff is more analytical than alarmist. He divides his thoughts into five sections addressing five kinds of profound change, and his biggest illustration of present shock has to do with the actual book itself. Because the present is more full of interruptions than the past was, it took him extra time to write. Because its ideas arent glib, he says, here I am writing opera when the people are listening to singles. And he realizes that data-swamped readers may take longer to finish books now. Coming from him the phrase thanks for your time has new meaning.

title: Scenes From South by Southwest Music
description: Images from the festival in Austin, Texas.

title: Subway Reads
description: The sight of subway commuters with their noses buried in books is one that transcends iPods, Angry Birds and any number of technological and cultural advances. Its only appropriate, then, that Penguin has teamed with Transport for London to create a series of 12 books, each inspired by a different tube line, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the London Underground. The publisher tasked a select group of straphangers  pulling from the citys literati and cultural tastemakers  with sharing their experiences of the English capital in 15,000 words or less.

title: U.S. Learns Gold Cup Opponents
description: The United States was placed in Group C, with Costa Rica, Belize and Cuba, in the draw for the 2013 Concacaf Gold Cup conducted Wednesday in Chicago, which will also host the final  at Soldier Field on Sunday, July 28.

title: Mother Leaps With an Infant and Dies
description: A woman leapt out an eighth-floor window with her infant son in Harlem on Wednesday, killing herself and critically injuring him, the police said.

title: Scenes From South by Southwest Music
description: A  slide show of images from the festival in Austin.

title: Portland, Ore., Approves Earned Sick Leave Policy
description: In Sheryl Sandbergs Lean In, she declares the problem of womens advancement in the workplace to be a classic chicken-and-egg problem. The chicken  her concern  is the impact of the choices women make that make career advancement harder. The egg is the impact of policies and society that push back, on women and all parents, as we work to both raise our families and financially support them. Without progress on both fronts, Ms. Sandberg argues, well never see workplace equality.

title: Bob Dylan to Be Honored by American Academy of Arts and Letters
description: The American Academy of Arts and Letters will go electric (sort of ) in May when it welcomes Bob Dylan as an honorary member at a ceremony at its Upper Manhattan headquarters. If he shows up, Mr. Dylan  the first rock musician honored by the group  will also be serenaded in words by the novelist Michael Chabon, who was elected as a regular member last year and is scheduled to give an address titled Rock n Roll.

title: Pop Glitter on Broadway
description: A look at the career of the singer Cyndi Lauper.

title: That Car in the Rear-View Mirror May End Up in Your Garage
description: A study suggests that a persons choice of what car to buy could be influenced by the type of vehicle a buyer sees most often.

title: Families May Gain From Observing CPR
description: It seems counterintuitive: allowing family members of deathly ill patients to watch while doctors try to restart the patients hearts. Wouldnt it be traumatic for the family to see? Couldnt it be distracting for the doctors?

title: Allergies Arent Just For Kids
description: Last weekends cover story hit home for me, not because I was an allergic child, but because I am an allergic adult. In my mid-20s I suddenly found myself toting an EpiPen and looking more closely at menus.

title: Dolphin Seen on an Apparently Healthy Swim in the East River
description: A dolphin was spotted swimming in the East River off the East 90s of Manhattan on Wednesday morning and was still there Wednesday afternoon.

title: Unnerved, Like All of Us, by Lifes Strangeness
description: LONDON  You need blinkers to navigate a big city, something to screen out the teeming surplus of ambient sights and sounds. Christopher Boone  the 15-year-old hero of the thrillingly staged adaptation of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time at the Apollo Theater  has no such apparatus at all. And on his first day in London, its a lack that threatens to pulverize him.

title: SandRidge Settles Fight With Hedge Fund
description: SandRidge Energy announced on Wednesday that it had settled with a hedge fund that had been calling for the removal of the oil companys chairman and chief executive, Tom L. Ward.

title: Cellphones as a Modern Irritant
description: If you have just read the same paragraph 12 times because the person sitting next to you on the bus is chatting on her cellphone, feel free to show her this: scientists have found another piece of evidence that overheard cellphone conversations are far more distracting and annoying than a dialogue between two people nearby.

title: Continuing Resolution, Continuing Dysfunction
description: The continuing resolution, now a seemingly permanent method of paying for the United States government, is also a continuing symbol of Congressional dysfunction. Lawmakers resort to C.R.s (as they are known) when they are unable to agree on a years worth of new spending priorities, and so simply keep what is already in effect, along with a few tweaks.

title: Radiation Raises Womens Risk of Heart Disease Only Slightly, Study Finds
description: Radiation treatment for breast cancer can increase a womans risk of heart disease, doctors have long known. But the size of the added risk has not been clear.

title: A Treasure Trove for Japanophiles
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: After the Mile
description: SAN DIEGO  It was to be a reunion of Southern Californias top high school runners, more than a hundred of them across six decades. National record-setters, state champions, a sprinkling of Olympians. Among them, a private man was going to make a rare public appearance. If Tim Danielson was not the guest of honor, exactly, he was the one everybody wanted to see.

title: The First Latin American and the First Francis
description: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina is known as a humble man who spoke out for the poor and led an austere life in Buenos Aires.

title: Racing Leap Into Rhythms and Romance
description: During Love Songs, a work by the British choreographer Tim Rushton, dancers dressed in everyday clothes swoop onto the stage like beams of light and swivel into deep lunges. Off-kilter steps send bodies gliding from one side of the stage to the other. The chief partnering motif involves a woman  often, the diminutive Maxim-Jo Beck McGosh  running at full speed into the arms of a man. Its athletic to the point of being clinical. Never once does your heart get caught in your throat.

title: Obama Appoints Church-State Law Expert to Head Faith-Based Office
description: As the world watched the Vatican for an announcement of a new leader for the Roman Catholic faithful, the White House quietly made a leadership appointment of its own on Wednesday, to the office responsible for outreach to religious organizations: Melissa Rogers will be the new director of the Office of Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships.

title: The Day the World Met Pope Francis
description: To the Editor:

title: Emotions Drawn Out and Magnified
description: In England, Vladimir Jurowski, the 40-year-old principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, is revered in equal measure for the fierce elegance of his conducting and the meticulously thought-out programs he puts together. At Royal Festival Hall in London last December he paired Mahlers Fifth Symphony with Quatre Chants Pour Franchir le Seuil, an apocalyptic song cycle by Grard Grisey; in November he contextualized Beethovens emancipatory Fifth with Holocaust-darkened works by Schoenberg and Nono.

title: A Look at Pope Francis
description: The Timess Rachel Donadio, reporting from Rome, and Ian Fisher on the new pontiffs selection.

title: Restaurant Report: Violet Oons Kitchen in Singapore
description: Before Joel Robuchon, Guy Savoy and Daniel Boulud came to Singapore, the country had its own homegrown celebrity chef  Violet Oon, sometimes referred to as the Julia Child of Singapore.

title: What You Get for ... $2.7 Million
description: CANNON BEACH, ORE.

title: Seating Schumann Cozily at the Center of His Universe
description: The pianist Jonathan Bisss excellent recital on Tuesday evening at Zankel Hall was part of his series Schumann: Under the Influence, a pop-album name for a thoughtful season-long immersion.

title: Kurdish Rebels Free 8 Turks, Fueling Peace Talks
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  A group of Turkish soldiers and civil servants who had been kidnapped and held in the mountains of northern Iraq by Kurdish militants was released to their families at a border crossing Wednesday in the latest sign that peace talks between Turkey and Kurdish rebels were gaining momentum.

title: Properties for $2.7 Million
description: A beach house in Oregon, a contemporary in Utah and a 2004 house in Vermont.

title: Columbia Acquires Dawn Powell Archives
description: Columbia University has negotiated to permanently retain the archives of the author Dawn Powell, the novelist who cast a gimlet eye on life in Manhattan, died in 1965 and has enjoyed an unlikely resurgence among readers in recent years.

title: Bunheads Fans Hope for More
description: As the end of the television season approaches, and odds are laid on the survival of prominent shows like Smash and The Good Wife, a handful of us are asking: What about Bunheads?

title: After a Divorce, Creeping Around Happiness
description: Lately Ive become a creeper. I didnt even know what this word meant until about a month ago, when my ninth-grade students enlightened me. We had just started reading Lord of the Flies, and on our first day of discussion, one student raised her hand. What are all these creepers all over the place? she asked. Other students chimed in with echoes of confusion. She continued: I mean, like, I thought there werent any other people on this island? I dont get it.

title: Twombly Foundation Complaint
description: The lawsuit filed on Wednesday in Delaware state court.

title: Video Shows Syrian Suicide Bombers Last Day
description: Jabhat al-Nusra, a Syrian rebel group accused of ties to Al Qaeda, posted a video online this week that documents the last day in the life of a suicide bomber who killed himself in an attack on a government checkpoint in January.

title: Turmoil at Cy Twombly Foundation
description: When Cy Twombly died in 2011 he left behind not only a legacy as one of the 20th centurys most important painters but also a vast estate, plump with paintings and other works and cash in the millions.

title: Germany Arrests 4 and Bans Groups Linked to Salafism
description: BERLIN  The German police announced Wednesday that they had arrested four men associated with the ultraconservative Islamic movement known as Salafism on suspicion of plotting to murder the leader of a far-right political party that has repeatedly taunted Muslims with caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad.

title: Daylight Saving Links
description: Junk Food and Diet News:

title: A Democracy of Style
description: In Minneapolis, letting the children have their way with decorating.

title: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 8
description: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

title: Red Bulls Miller: I Did It on Purpose
description: You have got to give Roy Miller credit for his honesty. After training on Wednesday at Montclair State University in Little Falls, N.J., Miller said that his act of encroachment during a penalty kick last Sunday at San Jose was intentional.

title: Sorting Out the Family Home, Laden With Possessions
description: I am not a hoarder. In fact, Im exactly the opposite: I would love to live in a minimalist house, and have strong opinions about disposing of or recycling old things.

title: Go to Your Room (and Decorate)
description: When Elizabeth Foy Larsen was growing up in the 1970s, she spent an enormous amount of time watching television. But now that she has three children of her own and a four-bedroom Mediterranean-style house filled with computers, TVs and iPads, Ms. Larsen finds herself waging an ongoing battle against screens.

title: San Francisco Symphony Musicians Go on Strike
description: Using a kind of brinkmanship that has become commonplace in contract negotiations of symphony orchestras, the musicians of the San Francisco Symphony went on strike on Wednesday, a week before a scheduled appearance at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra announced the cancellation of a concert at its home auditorium, Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall, that was scheduled for Thursday afternoon. The musicians contract expired in November but was extended to February when, by mutual agreement, the musicians continued talking and playing. On Wednesday the union rejected the administrations latest proposal for a three-year contract that, according to the administration, would have kept the musicians among the three highest-paid orchestras in the country (the others being the Chicago Symphony and the Los Angeles Philharmonic). The current average salary of the musicians is $165,000, the administration said. In addition to higher salaries, the musicians are seeking increases in benefits and pension contributions. A spokesman for the players could not immediately be reached. The administration said it had already notified the players that it would present a revised proposal on Thursday. It plans to go ahead with the presentation, it said, in hopes that San Francisco concerts can resume on Friday and an East Coast tour can proceed.

title: Rivera Is Taking Robinsons 42 to Its Last Stop
description: Mariano Riveras decision to retire after the 2013 season represents the end of an era for several reasons. The major leagues career leader in saves, he has been a cornerstone of the Yankees since winning his first championship ring with them, in 1996, and given his remarkable consistency and distinct lack of histrionics, he will be difficult, if not impossible, to replace.

title: Pope Francis I
description: So the oddsmakers were wrong, and we have an Argentine Jesuit as pope. This is one of those moments when humility is the better part of punditry: Despite having been the runner-up to Joseph Ratzinger in the last papal conclave, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio was no more on my radar screen over the last two weeks than he was on (almost) anyone elses, and it would be folly for me to pretend to know what his elevation portends. His age would suggest a kind of caretaker pope, but his name (evoking not only Francis of Assisi but the great Jesuit Francis Xavier as well) suggests a mix of humility and purifying zeal; his rich biography, meanwhile, offers enough material for multiple narratives, multiple hopes, and (of course) multiple lines of attack from the churchs many critics.

title: A Creative Turn for Watering
description: Paul Loebach, a Brooklyn-based industrial designer, has produced furniture, accessories, lighting and even wallpaper, but says that his latest creation, the X3 watering can for Kontextr, beats them all. Like much of Mr. Loebachs work, the can, which won the award for product-design excellence at the Accent on Design show in January, celebrates a vintage industrial aesthetic while looking new. It gets its name from a trick in its construction: a single metal tube is bent three times to create the handle and spout, then soldered onto the body. The X3 will be available in late April in solid copper ($99.95) and in white-, green-, blue- or red-painted steel ($49.95). Information: (614) 818-1446 or wabnitzeditions.com.

title: House Hunting in ... Uruguay
description: A CONTEMPORARY WITH FOUR BEDROOMS AND OCEAN VIEWS IN EL CHORRO, URUGUAY

title: Familiar Material, Postmodern Form
description: Against the Grain: Wood in Contemporary Art, Craft and Design, which opens Tuesday at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, is an exhibition of 80 contemporary wood pieces, some decorative, some functional and some in between.

title: Ocean Views on Uruguays Atlantic Coast
description: This four-bedroom home in El Chorro comes with an infinity-edge pool lined with royal blue tile.

title: A New Coast for the Future Perfect
description: Its been a decade since the Future Perfect was founded in Williamsburg as an early champion of the Brooklyn design scene; six years later, a second outpost opened in NoHo. But David Alhadeff, the owner, had always eyed the West Coast. Last week he opened his third shop, in the Pacific Heights neighborhood of San Francisco. Ive split my time between New York and San Francisco since 2011, and became very aware of the market here, Mr. Alhadeff said of the Bay Area. Its very progressive and smart. Among his items are the Future Perfects own line of furniture, as well as pieces by Piet Hein Eek and Russell Pinch; lighting by Lindsey Adelman and Charles de Lisle; and accessories from Lobmeyr, Artel, Michele Quan and Fort Standard. The Future Perfect is at 3085 Sacramento Street (Baker Street), (415) 932-6508, thefutureperfect.com.

title: Kick-Starting a Collection
description: Since he was fired from Gap in May 2011, and with still-fresh wounds from his days at Perry Ellis and Paco Rabanne, Patrick Robinson checked out of fashion for a while.

title: Taking a Cue From the Moulin Rouge
description: Nodus, the Italian rug manufacturer known for its collaborations with leading artists and designers, will introduce a collection next month in Milan, during the annual international furniture fair. Jupon, one standout, was designed by Sam Baron, the French artistic director of Fabrica, which is the creative studio of the fashion company Benetton. Jupon is French for a garment used to create volume under a dress or skirt, and Mr. Baron had in mind the rippling costumes of can-can dancers. The palette is Parisian: a soft gray like the citys mansard roofs and a pink like the legs of a Degas ballerina. The eight-foot-round wool rug is hand-tufted in India and is about $3,400. Information: 011-39-02-866-838 or nodusrug.it.

title: Sales at DwellStudio, Arhaus and Others
description: All upholstered furniture is 20 percent off Thursday through April 7 at DwellStudio (the Martine settee, shown, originally from $3,045, starts at $2,436); 77 Wooster Street (Spring Street), (646) 442-6000, dwellstudio.com.

title: Speak, Memory, Kvetch
description: On Friday, As It Were ... So to Speak, an exhibition of 276 works of Judaica, art and decorative objects, opens in New York. The pieces were selected by the artist Barbara Bloom from among 25,000 in the collection of the Jewish Museum and are arranged in a suite of ornate rooms in the early-20th-century Upper East Side house the museum occupies.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Sonic Resurgent and Inside a Pebble Watch
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Squeezing Out Cash Long After the I.P.O.
description: When the Berry Plastics Group, a container and packaging company, went public last October, it generated up to $350 million in tax savings. But the company wont collect the bulk of the benefits. Rather, Berry Plastics will hand over 85 percent of the savings, in cash, to its former private equity owners.

title: Call Your Mother and Tell Her Hes Back in Town
description: Last September, at the inaugural concert at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, Jay-Z brought out just one guest, Big Daddy Kane. It was the student offering the spotlight to the teacher: a show of respect, of civic pride (like Jay-Z, Big Daddy Kane is from Brooklyn) and a compliment. It was also an opportunity, one that Big Daddy Kane took advantage of, showing in just a few minutes why he was worthy of the gesture, and the stage.

title: Wrongfully Convicted and Seeking Restitution
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Robert Dewey spent almost 18 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. Now he spends his time waiting. Waiting for food stamps, or his monthly $698 disability check. Swallowing painkillers and waiting for his wrenched back to stop aching. Waiting for the state to repay him for lost time.

title: Building Blocks
description: Since the completion of the National September 11 Memorial in 2011, its designer, Michael Arad, has turned his attention back to buildings.

title: Shopping for Building Blocks
description: Michael Arad, designer of the National September 11 Memorial, looks for simple colorful blocks.

title: Diva Digs in to Cole Porter; Wagner Gets the Night Off
description: Near the end of the evening on Monday at Carnegie Hall the galloping strains of Wagners Ride of the Valkyries suddenly sounded. Give me a couple of weeks, the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe said in mock exhaustion.

title: Mountain or Molehill: A Measure of Anthonys Words
description: DENVER  Carmelo Anthony does many interviews, says many things. To his credit, seldom is he terse with reporters, and never confrontational. Genial would probably be the best way to describe most of his dealings with the news media.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. What can I do with a nonfunctional fireplace to make it look like an asset?

title: Networking Battles to Run the World
description: Cisco has a simple message: the world has bought so much of its equipment, why stop now?

title: Scouting Report
description: Shop for a Cause

title: Spring North American Championships
description: The American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships began Wednesday in St. Louis.

title: In Your Pocket, a Lost-and-Found
description: On a trip from my home in California to New York a few months ago, I experienced one of those big-city moments that always seem so charming in Woody Allen movies: I forgot my bag in the back of a yellow cab. The bag contained my laptop, iPad, phone charger, reporters notebook and house and car keys. I realized my error just as the cab pulled out of view, while I stood dumbly on the street, watching my property and data disappear into the night.

title: A Trainer to the Stars Whos a Star-to-Be
description: If theres a celebrity body you admire (Rihanna? Halle Berry? Ryan Gosling?), theres a good chance its the trainer and nutritionist Harley Pasternaks work, and it is equally likely that he has appeared in a magazine (ranging from People to Seventeen to Mens Health) or on television to describe how he does it.

title: Romance (and S&M) in the Shtetl
description: Give me a good thrashing because Im such a bad girl, says a young woman to her seductive male cousin. He later woos her with this sweet nothing: Here is my heart. Take it and gulp down my blood.

title: Art? Oh, Yeah. But Were Here to Party.
description: The Harlem hip-hop wunderkind ASAP Rocky was holding a party for his debut album, Long.Live.ASAP, in January, and as expected, a fashionable mob of his young disciples spilled onto the Bowery, a sea of black leather varsity jackets and Carhartt stocking hats.

title: Disney Delays Release of Video Game and Toy Initiative
description: LOS ANGELES  The introduction of Disney Infinity, an ambitious video game and toy initiative, has been pushed from June to late August, a retail window that Disney said on Wednesday was more favorable.

title: Bedside Manner
description: What goes on beside the bed.

title: Obama Discusses Computer Security With Corporate Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama met with an invited group of 13 chief executives at the White House on Wednesday to discuss growing concerns about cybersecurity and enlist them to get behind his proposed legislation to combat the threat of computer warfare and corporate espionage.
