title: The Bedside Battleground
description: Consider the bedside table, a modest domestic surface that nonetheless offers as concise a portrait of human aspirations, anxieties and appetites as one could hope for in 2013. Its a mess.

title: Pine Box Rock Shop
description: There are vegan restaurants, vegan cafes, even vegan boutiques. So why not a vegan bar? Thats the conceit behind the Pine Box Rock Shop, a scrappy taproom and music site in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: The Naked Man Doesnt Dance
description: On a recent Saturday, Amy Albright was celebrating her bachelorette party on West 14th Street. A table was filled with miniature cupcakes and glasses of pink Champagne. Nancy Sinatras These Boots Are Made for Walkin played on the stereo. A shirtless waiter took coats. The guests, mostly in their 30s, sat down, waiting for the main attraction: a nude male model.

title: From Loser to Hunk? The Clothes Help
description: One of the big surprises in Season 2 of Girls, the HBO show created by Lena Dunham that has its season finale this Sunday, has been the transformation of Charlie (Christopher Abbott) from lovesick loser to confident Web entrepreneur and possibly even sex symbol  an evolution that the shows costume designer has helped signal with subtle changes in his wardrobe.

title: Los Angeles Archdiocese to Pay $10 Million in Abuse Case
description: LOS ANGELES  While its former leader, Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, gathered with cardinals in Rome to choose the new pope, the Archdiocese of Los Angeles reached a $10 million settlement with four men who say they were abused by a former priest who has been criminally convicted in a separate case.

title: In Papal Elections, Are Long Shots the Rule?
description: Go in a pope, come out a cardinal.

title: One Last Block Party for Broken Angel House in Brooklyn
description: With the foreclosure process over, and an order of eviction waiting to be executed on Friday, the only thing left to do for Arthur Wood, the owner  or rather, former owner  of the Broken Angel art house, was to celebrate his departure with a block party.

title: A Conservative With a Common Touch
description: BUENOS AIRES  Like most of those in Argentina, he is a soccer fan, his favorite team being the underdog San Lorenzo squad. Known for his outreach to the countrys poor, he gave up a palace for a small apartment, rode public transportation instead of a chauffeur-driven car and cooked his own meals.

title: Wright and Cano Bring New York Flair to World Baseball Classic
description: MIAMI  While David Wright drove in five runs for the United States in the World Baseball Classic on Tuesday night, Robinson Cano went to the Miami Heat game with some of his Dominican Republic teammates. Cano sat courtside, underneath the basket near the Heat bench, and watched LeBron James generate 15 points, 7 rebounds and 7 assists on what was considered an off night.

title: Spinoff of Time Inc. Rattles Employees
description: It was an elite reception at a glittery Manhattan setting: prominent media figures like Gayle King and Lesley Stahl gathered on the 10th floor of the Time Warner Center on Monday night to toast Sheryl Sandberg, the Facebook executive who recently released a book about her life.

title: Henri Labrouste at MoMA
description: Henri Labrouste: Structure Brought to Light, an exhibition about the 19th century French architect, opened this week.

title: Competitive Fields for Council of Fashion Designers Awards
description: Board members of the Council of Fashion Designers of America met on Wednesday to decide the honorees and nominees for their annual fashion awards, and they came up with an unusually competitive lot. Often, fashion people can easily pick the winners based on who is most popular at the moment, but that may not be the case with this group, especially in the categories for younger designers.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,163 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: The Last Walk
description: The well-wishers came in waves, old friends and new colleagues, television bigwigs and college presidents, all in search of Mike Aresco, commissioner of the Big East Conference. (Or whats left of it. Before more teams are added and subtracted. Before they call it something else.)

title: F.D.A. Plans Looser Rules on Approving Alzheimers Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration plans to loosen the rules for approving new treatments for Alzheimers disease.

title: A Battle for Syria, One Court at a Time
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  When members of a fledgling court system in Aleppo, Syria, refused to hand over newly refurbished offices to the head of a Shariah Board last month, four vehicles filled with heavily armed fighters promptly roared through the fence surrounding the five-story concrete building.

title: U.S. General Puts Troops on Security Alert After Karzai Remarks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American commander in Afghanistan quietly told his forces to intensify security measures on Wednesday, issuing a strongly worded warning that a string of anti-American statements by President Hamid Karzai had put Western troops at greater risk of attack both from rogue Afghan security forces and from militants.

title: Big East Tournament: Day 2
description: Photos from the mens Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden, including victories by Syracuse and Villanova.

title: Private Equity Firms Fail in Effort to Have Antitrust Case Dismissed
description: A federal judge has dealt a blow to the private equity industry, refusing to dismiss a lawsuit that accused firms of colluding to drive down the prices of corporate takeovers during the buyout boom, setting the stage for a possible trial in the five-year-old case.

title: Death to Whistle-Blowers?
description: LAST month Pfc. Bradley Manning pleaded guilty to several offenses related to leaking hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks in 2010, a plea that could land him in jail for 20 years. But Private Manning still faces trial on the most serious charges, including the potential capital offense of aiding the enemy  though the prosecution is not seeking the death penalty in this case, only a life sentence.

title: Obama Meets Libyan Premier and Names Envoy
description: WASHINGTON  On the day he named a replacement for the United States ambassador slain at the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, in September, President Obama also met with Prime Minister Ali Zeidan of Libya and emphasized the need for his countrys help in finding the attackers who carried out the assault that led to death of the envoy and three other Americans.

title: Instability and Mediocrity at Arsenal
description: LONDON

title: Domestic Politics, Pyongyang-Style
description: OBERLIN, Ohio

title: A Pro-Gun Charitys Capitol Influence
description: Americans puzzled by the growing gap between popular support for gun controls and Washington lawmakers obeisance to the gun lobby should know about the Congressional Sportsmens Foundation. It is a private charity that enjoys considerable tax-deductible support from the firearms industry and has very close ties to more than 250 members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, those who make up the separate Congressional Sportsmens Caucus. A good part of its clout comes from Washington dinners, gala shootouts and junkets with lawmakers.

title: Madison Square Gardens Overreach
description: For decades now, New Yorkers have yearned for a grand entranceway to New York City to replace the dismal and inadequate Pennsylvania Station. One major obstacle has always been Madison Square Garden, the massive sports arena that is perched on top of the station and whose presence makes almost any rational redesign of the waiting rooms and tracks below virtually impossible. Architects, designers and a few visionary politicians have been trying to persuade the Gardens owners to move so that reconstruction can begin.

title: Awkward Choice in Kenya
description: Kenyas apparent decision to elect a president charged by the International Criminal Court at The Hague for crimes against humanity is deeply unsettling. But if Uhuru Kenyatta withstands an expected legal challenge by his opponent Raila Odinga, the United States and Europe are going to have to find a way to work with the new government, given Kenyas standing as a vital security ally and a regional economic power.

title: Last Pope and Next Budget
description: As long as were fixating on the new pope, we should talk about St. Malachy.

title: Anti-Bloomberg Bill in Mississippi Bars Local Restrictions on Food and Drink
description: The Mississippi Legislature wants to be the sole government body that controls its buffets, barbecue and sweet tea.

title: Stealing Books for the Poor
description: BEIJING

title: Inadequate Treatment of Ovarian Cancer
description: A new study has found widespread failure among doctors to follow clinical guidelines for treating ovarian cancer, which kills 15,000 women a year in this country. This disturbing news shows the kind of challenge that health care reformers are up against in improving medical care  even when cost is not the issue.

title: Obama Rallies Supporters and Donors to Keep His Campaign Agenda Alive
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama joined former campaign staff members and some of his most ardent supporters on Wednesday night, headlining a two-day meeting of an independent group, Organizing for Action, that is intended to bolster his agenda in Congress.

title: The U.S. Conference of Mayors, on Tax-Exempt Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: Is It Bullying, or Is It Just Bad Behavior?
description: To the Editor:

title: Failed Projects in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Rewarding Lawbreakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal for Sony Building Draws Attention to Its Buyer
description: For nearly 20 years, Joe Chetrit has sought to remain far outside the spotlight as he has bought and sold billions of dollars in property in New York City.

title: In Welker Breakup, Its Not Him; Its Them
description: It turns out that the New England Patriots true intentions for Wes Welker were revealed long ago, in September, before his quarterback and friend Tom Brady took a below-market contract extension to create salary-cap space to help his team keep critical parts, before the owner Robert K. Kraft said this week that he wanted Welker to be a Patriot for life.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 13, 2013

title: Floridas Lieutenant Governor Resigns Amid Inquiry Into Sweepstakes Firm
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The lieutenant governor of Florida, Jennifer Carroll, abruptly resigned on Tuesday, the result of a criminal investigation into an Internet sweepstakes company for which she once served as a consultant.

title: A Surprise Choice From Afar, Winning Over Some Skeptics
description: VATICAN CITY  Twenty minutes had passed, maybe 30, and the white smoke had finally stopped billowing out of the smokestack atop the Sistine Chapel, and the bells had stopped clanging. Outside St. Peters Basilica, thousands of people huddled under umbrellas, ensnared in a strange limbo, waiting to learn the identity of their new pope.

title: Bruce Feiler Plays 'Happy Families'
description: Bruce Feiler and wife Linda Rottenberg discuss what it's like when your spouse writes the book on 'happy families.'

title: New Pope Shifts Churchs Center of Gravity Away From Europe
description: ROME  The surprise selection on Wednesday of an Argentine, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, as the new pope shifted the gravity of the Roman Catholic Church from Europe to Latin America in one fell swoop, and served as an emphatic salute to the growing power of Latinos across the Americas.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Mar. 14, 2013
description: My brother cardinals have chosen one who is from far away, but here I am.

title: Nadal Renews Criticism of Hardcourt Schedule
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Professional tennis is getting harder and harder. At least on its surface.

title: Felton Braces for Boos in Return to Portland
description: DENVER  Raymond Felton spent 137 days in Portland, hardly long enough to find a good dry cleaner or to learn the names of all those bridges. But long enough, apparently, to have thoroughly alienated the Trail Blazers, their fans and the local news media.

title: For Cardinals, Advantages in Choosing an Older Pope
description: The selection of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina as the new pope, Francis, was largely unexpected by betting markets and Vatican experts, in part because of his advanced age. Cardinal Bergoglio, 76, is probably the ninth oldest of the 266 popes at the time of his election, accounting for some uncertainty because the age of many early popes remains unknown.

title: Private vs. Government Utilities
description: Some communities plan to lower utility rates.

title: Obamas Israel Itinerary Includes Some Standard Stops, but Not Others
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to visit the Church of the Nativity, but not the Western Wall, when he travels to Israel next week. He will speak at Jerusalems convention center, but not before the Knesset, Israels Parliament. And he will inspect a mobile missile-defense battery, though not one in the field, where they protect Israel from enemy rockets.

title: Corrections: March 14, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Wild Guesses
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Quote themes are rare in The New York Times, and with good reason. For one thing, most of them are either not great, or they just dont break up in a way that looks attractive in a grid that already has many constraints.

title: Its a Bumpy Ride, What With Bette Davis in the Drivers Seat
description: Lightning flickers, rain pelts against the windows, and an ominous thunderclap is heard shortly after Bette Davis  portrayed by Carol Kane  enters the slightly seedy house where The Lying Lesson, the new play by Craig Lucas, takes place. The year is 1981, and Davis has long since descended into, and not quite recovered from, her period of low camping as a gorgon in Grand Guignol B movies.

title: Both Sides in Syria Accused of Committing War Crimes
description: With fighting raging in Damascus and other cities in Syria on Wednesday, Amnesty International issued new reports detailing what the group called war crimes committed by both sides in the conflict.

title: Mets Expect Pitchers to Help Themselves at the Plate
description: VIERA, Fla.  The pitches darted toward home faster than he expected. Three fast ones, and it was over.

title: At NBC, a Struggle to Revive the Morning Magic
description: Staff members at NBCs Today show huddled for a performance review last month, 10 months after the longtime morning show leader first fell behind ABCs Good Morning America in the ratings. The mood was anxious, according to several attendees, as network executives discussed the findings from focus groups with hundreds of viewers.

title: In Struggling Spain, an Effort to Promote Optimism
description: MADRID  These would not seem to be the most opportune days to try to buff Spains image. The lingering economic crisis has crippled public morale, and young people despair of finding work. Corruption scandals have shaken peoples faith in their leadership.

title: Jeter Continues Rehabilitation, Back at Shortstop
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Five months to the day since he lay helpless on the infield dirt with a broken ankle, Derek Jeter returned to his position at shortstop, lending a bit of calm to a team troubled by bad injury news.

title: Veterans Testify on Rapes and Scant Hope of Justice
description: WASHINGTON  Choking back tears and in voices edged with rage, two women and a man who served in the American military told a Senate panel on Wednesday how they were raped by superiors and then ridiculed or ignored by military officials from whom they sought help.

title: Officials Urge Tougher Line on Kabul Bank Case Verdicts
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan attorney generals office said Wednesday that it planned to appeal the verdicts issued by a special court last week in the Kabul Bank fraud case, saying the sentences given were not in accordance with the original charges prosecutors filed.

title: Jurors Hear Man Confess to Killing a Therapist
description: Prosecutors played a videotaped confession on Wednesday from a man on trial for killing an Upper East Side psychologist five years ago, offering jurors their first opportunity to hear him describe the attacks in his own words.

title: Horse Meat Applicants Food Safety Is Questioned
description: The New Mexico company seeking to become the first slaughter house for horses in the United States since 2007 drew complaints over a two-year period from federal food safety inspectors and state regulatory authorities over its disposal of animal remains when it processed cattle for beef.

title: St. Johns Shows Fight but Is Still Knocked Out
description: St. Johns Coach Steve Lavin skittered up and down the sideline, whirling his arms, leaping, wringing the rolled-up statistics sheet in his hand like a soggy washcloth.

title: Cities Weigh Taking Over From Private Utilities
description: Across the country, cities are showing a renewed interest in taking over the electricity business from private utilities, reflecting intensifying concerns about climate change, responses to power disruptions and a desire to pump more renewable energy into the grid.

title: And the Nominees Are...
description: Board members of the Council of Fashion Designers of America met to decide the honorees and nominees for their annual fashion awards and came up with an unusually competitive lot.

title: Initial Tests of Battery by Boeing Fell Short
description: In an age of sophisticated computer modeling, Boeing engineers relied on the same test used for tiny cellphone batteries to gather data about the safety of the heftier lithium-ion battery on its new 787 jets: they drove a nail into it to see what happened.

title: Google Hastens to Show Its Concern for Privacy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley hates being told what to do. Better to seek forgiveness than permission is its unofficial slogan.

title: Solar Trade Group Reports Surge in U.S. Installations
description: Partly driven by an oversupply of cheaper panels from China, the domestic solar market had its best year in 2012, with the growth in installations outpacing that of the global market, according to an annual report to be released Thursday.

title: Tarloff Confession
description: This videotape of David Tarloffs confession to the 2008 killing of Kathryn Faughey, an Upper East Side psychologist, was played at his trial.

title: Entrenched Troubles at Vatican Await a New Pope
description: VATICAN CITY  By choosing the first pope from the New World, the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church sent a strong message of change: that the future of the church lies in the global south, and that a scholar with a common touch may be its best choice to inspire the faithful.

title: Schultz to Give Up Weekday Slot on MSNBC
description: One of MSNBCs most important and lucrative time slots, 8 p.m., is about to get a new host. But MSNBC wont name the person quite yet.

title: For Enclave of Rebel Artists, Much in Life Was Free, but Not Real Estate
description: PARIS  Illegal squats in Paris usually have a short life. After one year, perhaps two, they are either shut down or transformed into legal art centers with the support of the citys Socialist government. But not La Miroiterie, which has been a renowned artists squat for the past 14 years.

title: U.S. Citizens Join Illegal Immigrants in Pressing Lawmakers for Change
description: WASHINGTON  On her trip to Washington to push for an overhaul of immigration laws, Cindy Garcia on Wednesday went straight to the office of Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, to tell him about how the looming deportation of her husband had affected her family.

title: Pope Francis, Bowing to Crowds, Wins Hearts
description: They filled St. Peters Square on Wednesday night, thousands of people who endured steady rain and cold temperatures, awaiting the naming of the new pope of the Roman Catholic Church. When Pope Francis was introduced, the people responded to history in the making: the first pope from Latin America and the first non-European pope in centuries. Out in the crowds, people sang, shouted the name of the new pope and spoke about the significance of the moment. GAIA PIANIGIANI

title: Who Is Poor?
description: There are three ways of defining povertyin America: the officialCensusBureaumethod,whichusesa set of income thresholdsthat vary by family size and composition;an experimental income-based methodcalled theSupplemental Poverty Measurethatfactors ingovernment programs designed to help people with low incomes; and a consumption-based methodthatmeasureswhat households actually spend.By definingpovertyaccording to different criteria, these three methodscapturesurprisingly different populations of men, women and children. In a perfect world, these three methods would all tell us to do the same thing to alleviate poverty, but its not like that. Each methodsuggests a different approach toward how our government should direct its poverty-fighting resources.

title: Lessons for Detroit in a Citys Takeover
description: PONTIAC, Mich.  The mayor here has no decision-making power. The City Council still holds meetings every Thursday night, though no official business can be conducted. Afterward, the council members are locked out of City Hall until morning, escorted from the building by a janitor.

title: Egypt: Last Place on Tourism List
description: A report on the international travel industry has ranked Egypt the least safe and secure of 140 tourist destinations, putting it behind Pakistan, Yemen and Chad, evidence of the toll that two years of near-constant unrest has taken on the countrys once-lucrative tourist industry. Tourism  which has accounted for 11 percent of Egypts gross domestic product, economists say  has suffered more than any other industry from the street protests and political turmoil that have prevailed since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak two years ago. The report, released by the nonprofit World Economic Forum and publicized around the world, is unlikely to help. A Tourism Ministry official said the results were not a surprise, given the turmoil and the surveys methodology, which relied heavily on a survey of executives as well as statistics like traffic accidents. Both government and industry officials say, however, that there are signs of recovery, although mainly because of bargain-hunting Red Sea beachgoers, rather than the more profitable Sphinx-and-Pyramids circuit.

title: Iran: Oil Exports Rose, Report Says
description: Iranian oil shipments to foreign customers increased in February, a widely followed monthly report said Wednesday, despite a new regimen of American sanctions over Irans disputed nuclear program intended to further limit the countrys ability to sell petroleum, its most important export. The monthly report, by the International Energy Agency, a 28-nation group of oil-importing nations, said Irans exports rose to 1.28 million barrels a day, from 1.13 million barrels a day in January, suggesting that the impact of the new sanctions was either negligible or had not yet begun to be felt. Under an American sanctions law provision that took effect on Feb. 6, any country that buys Iranian oil must put the purchase money into a local bank account. Iran cannot repatriate the money and can only use it to buy goods within that country. Violators of the provision risk severe penalties in doing business with the United States.

title: Monarch Migration Plunges to Lowest Level in Decades
description: The number of monarch butterflies that completed an annual migration to their winter home in a Mexican forest sank this year to its lowest level in at least two decades, due mostly to extreme weather and changed farming practices in North America, the Mexican government and a conservation alliance reported on Wednesday.

title: Clamor to Be Spared the Pain as Budget Cuts Descend
description: WASHINGTON  Construction companies are lobbying the government to spare their projects from across-the-board cuts. Drug companies are pleading with the White House to use all the fees they pay to speed the approval of new medicines.

title: Yankees Take a Look at Boesch
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees are one of several teams who are looking into signing Brennan Boesch, the left-handed-hitting outfielder who was released by the Detroit Tigers on Wednesday. The Mets, who also are in need of outfielders, may have interest in Boesch as well.

title: NBC Moves Struggling Smash to Saturday Slot
description: NBCs ambitious effort to turn the creation of a Broadway musical into a television drama essentially ended Wednesday when the network announced it would move Smash to Saturday nights to play out the remainder of its second season.

title: Tests Show Key Safeguard Can Fail When Cars Rear-End Big Rigs
description: Passenger vehicles are designed to handle severe frontal crashes, but in some crashes into the back of large tractor-trailers, all bets could be off, according to recent crash tests done by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: Word of the Day | imperceptible
description: imperceptible \im-pr-sep-t-bl\ adjective

title: Senate Race May Be Last Chance for Cautious Congressman to Fulfill Dream
description: WASHINGTON  For years, Representative Frank Pallone Jr. of New Jersey has harbored a huge ambition: to become a member of one of the nations most exclusive clubs, the United States Senate.

title: Defense in Cannibal Case Faces Next Steps
description: During closing arguments in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the former New York police officer convicted of planning to kidnap, kill and eat women, the defense objected loudly when a prosecutor cited an example of potential terrorists wanting to hijack a plane.

title: Fewer People Are Abandoning the Bronx, Census Data Show
description: Danielle Jackson has lived all over New York City since she moved from New Jersey in 1998 to attend New York University. Last May, she moved from Flatbush to the South Bronx, where she co-founded a photography gallery a year earlier.

title: Man Admits Guilt in Plot to Kill Judge and Prosecutor
description: A Florida man pleaded guilty on Wednesday in New York to conspiring to murder the federal judge and prosecutor involved in the fraud conviction of his close business associate.

title: Assemblymans Ex-Aide Is Said to Plan Guilty Plea
description: The former chief of staff for William F. Boyland Jr., a Democratic assemblyman facing federal bribery charges, is scheduled to plead guilty on Thursday to playing a role in the bribery scheme, as part of an agreement with the government that could produce new evidence against Mr. Boyland, according to a law enforcement official close to the investigation.

title: Man With Stun Gun in His Carry-On Bag Is Arrested at Kennedy Airport
description: A 23-year-old Greek man who is a suspect in the rape of a woman in Queens was arrested Wednesday near a gate at Kennedy International Airport; he was carrying a stun gun in a carry-on bag, prosecutors said.

title: Merton D. Simpson, Painter, Collector and Dealer in African Art, Dies at 84
description: Merton D. Simpson, an artist who became a trailblazing collector and gallery owner specializing in African art, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Flix) THE DOOR IN THE FLOOR (2004) In this adaptation of John Irvings novel A Widow for One Year Jeff Bridges and Kim Basinger, above, portray Ted and Marion Cole, a long-married couple still reeling from the deaths of their two teenage sons in a car accident some years earlier. Elle Fanning is Ruth, their 4-year-old daughter, whose arrival was meant to help alleviate their grief. And Jon Foster is Eddie OHare, a boarding school student who has traveled to the familys home in the Hamptons to spend a summer working as an assistant to Ted, an author and illustrator of childrens books, but ends up sleeping with Marion. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this drama from Tod Williams was surely the best movie yet made from Mr. Irvings fiction. He added: It may even belong in the rarefied company of movies that are better than the books on which they are based. And above all, Jeff Bridges offers perhaps the wittiest and richest piece of screen acting by an American man so far this year.

title: Delhi Gang Rape Trial Progresses, Despite Recent Death
description: Ram Singh, the bus driver accused in the Delhi gang rape, was found hanging in his prison cell Monday, but the trial of four other men in the fatal attack on a young woman continues in a special fast-track court.

title: News Quiz | March 14, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Ieng Sary, Former Official of Khmer Rouge, Dies at 87
description: Ieng Sary, the former foreign minister of the Khmer Rouge who was one of three elderly leaders on trial on charges of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, died on Thursday in a hospital in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, where he had been taken from his holding cell. He was 87.

title: Knicks Routed in Denver; Anthony Will Have Knee Drained
description: DENVER  As it turns out, there are far worse things than being jeered mercilessly by 19,000 people who used to worship your every dribble, dunk and fadeaway. The boos and taunts? That much, Carmelo Anthony expected and perhaps even embraced in his first return to the city he rejected. That much was tolerable.

title: Ieng Sary, Dead Before Justice Is Done
description: BEIJING  Brother Number Three is dead.

title: Support for Srinagar Militants Mixes With Contempt on Twitter
description: As news broke about the attack on a police camp near a school in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir on Wednesday morning, not surprisingly it spread quickly on Twitter.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 14
description: NEWS With a puff of white smoke from the chimney of the Sistine Chapel and to the cheers of thousands of rain-soaked faithful, a gathering of Roman Catholic cardinals picked a new pope from among their midst on Wednesday  choosing Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio from Argentina, the first South American to lead the church. Rachel Donadio reports from Vatican City.

title: Introducing Francis, the First Pope From the New World
description: Marcus Mabry, editor of Rendezvous, speaks with Rachel Donadio in Vatican City about the election of Jorge Mario Bergoglio, 76, a Jesuit and Latin American, to be called Pope Francis, and with Ian Fisher about the cardinals choice.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 14, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Black Smoke From Conclave Signals No Pope on First Day.

title: Filling the Pews: Challenges for the New Pope
description: Roman Catholics around the world share their views on the leadership of the church, and Daniel J. Wakin reports from Rome.

title: Cardinals Select New Pope
description: In The New Pope: Bergoglio of Argentina,  Rachel Donadio reports on the cardinals selection of a new pope.

title: Photographers Oral History of the Iraq War
description: As the 10th anniversary of the Iraq wars start approaches, Lens highlights Photojournalists on War, an oral history of the conflict as recounted by those who documented it from the front lines. The book, published this month by the University of Texas Press, was written by Michael Kamber, who covered the war for eight years for The New York Times.

title: Big Banks Have a Big Problem
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Laws on Roads and Traffic Safety Are Sorely Lacking, W.H.O. Finds
description: Only 7 percent of the worlds population lives in countries that have comprehensive laws that address the five major risk factors for road traffic death and injury, according to a new report. And enforcement is often inadequate, even among some countries with strong laws, the report says.

title: With Simple Actions and Dress, New Pope Shifts Tone at Vatican
description: VATICAN CITY  He stopped to pay his hotel bill a day after becoming pope. He wore simple black shoes and an ordinary wristwatch with a thick black band to his first Mass as pontiff. He rode in a minivan to dinner with the cardinals who elected him, affectionately telling them, May God forgive you for what youve done.

title: What Was Your Most Precious Childhood Possession?
description: Did you have what psychologists call a transitional object as a child? That is, a special stuffed animal, blanket or toy that you took everywhere? If so, what was it, and what do you remember about its role in your life? If you didnt, what other important or beloved object do you remember from your childhood? Where is that object today?

title: Chinas New President Nods to Public Concerns, but Defends Power at Top
description: HONG KONG  Xi Jinping, the new leader of the Communist Party, assumed the presidency of China on Thursday, completing his formal transition to power. He did so at a legislative meeting that has signaled a more responsive approach to an impatient public, while defending the partys top-down control.

title: Seeking Your Questions on Paying for College
description: If you are a college-bound senior who has started receiving financial aid award letters, or a high school junior who is beginning to consider your college options more seriously, you have no doubt tried to answer two essential questions: How much will college cost, and what is the best way to pay for it?

title: To Be Prudent Is to Be Partial
description: NAIROBI  Over the years Ive come to view the Kenyan media with a mixture of respect and affection.

title: The Early Word: Two Steps Back
description: In Todays Times:

title: New Data to Consider in D.N.R. Decisions
description: Every year in the United States, about 100,000 hospital patients age 65 and older experience what is known in medical parlance as Code Blue. Their hearts stop, and a medical team is summoned to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

title: Netanyahu Near Accepting New Coalition
description: JERUSALEM  After six weeks of struggle, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appeared close Thursday night to finalizing a new governing coalition that may make significant changes on domestic issues like religious pluralism but is likely to be paralyzed on the Middle East peace process.

title: Kashmir Is on the Boil, Once Again
description: For many people in the Kashmir Valley, Wednesdays deadly attack on an Indian security camp, which left five security personnel and two militants dead, was not a surprise.

title: A Marvelous Rivalry, but With a Murky Future
description: A European reporter settled into his seat, turned to me and advised, Watch him. It was a warm spring night in 2004, and the worlds best tennis player was on court for a third-round match in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: The Unwilling Witness
description: We sped along a highway west from Baghdad on March 31, 2004. Our security adviser had called to inform us about an attack in Falluja against an American convoy. He had no details but warned us to be careful.

title: Do You Pay Employees to Exist or to Produce?
description: Last week I talked about treating your employees as experts at their jobs. Ive found this is the best way to help a work force develop personal responsibility. The next step in the process of creating value is thinking about how you compensate your people.

title: Leadership Change in Nepal Stirs Hopes of Stability
description: HYDERABAD, India  Nepals chief judge was sworn in as head of an interim government on Thursday morning in an effort by the countrys squabbling political parties to hold new elections.

title: Daily Report: Google Hastens to Show Concern for Privacy
description: Google executives are realizing that penalties for privacy breaches, like those it acknowledged involving its Street View project, do matter, if only because of the reputational risks, David Streitfield and Claire Cain Miller report in Thursdays New York Times.

title: UBS Pays Investment Bank Chief $26 Million
description: LONDON  UBS said on Thursday that it had awarded its new investment bank chief, Andrea Orcel, 24.9 million Swiss francs, or $26 million, in deferred cash and shares, to compensate him for pay he forfeited when he left Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

title: Tip of the Week: Saving Time and Typing With Google Chrome
description: Entering your contact information into Web forms is just as tedious on tablets and smartphones as it is on a regular computer, but the smaller screen sizes on the mobile devices can make data entry more of a physical challenge. For Android users  who also use Googles Chrome browser on the computer  the new mobile Chrome might save time and typing frustration.

title: Beijing Cautions New Pope on Meddling in China
description: HONG KONG  China congratulated Pope Francis on Thursday on his ascension to the papacy, but also warned the Vatican not to interfere in what China deems to be its internal affairs.

title: So Unusual for a Theater Tunesmith
description: I look like whats-her-butt, from Sunset Boulevard, Cyndi Lauper announced in her pipsqueak voice. She checked herself out in the mirror in her foyer, surrounded by framed platinum records. Though she talks with the panache of a 1940s movie moll crossed with a character from Goodfellas  all dames and broads and outer-borough curse words  she didnt resemble even a profane Norma Desmond. In head-to-toe black, save for a leopard-print sweater and a tight cap over her hot pink hair, Ms. Lauper, the singer of enduring hits like Girls Just Want to Have Fun and True Colors, mostly looked like what she is, a pioneering rocker.

title: A Deal on Chicken Sandwiches
description: Dear Diary:

title: Opinion Report: Congressional Sportsmen
description: From the editorial page

title: Dozens of Species Given New Trade Protections
description: HONG KONG  A major international meeting on wildlife trade ended on Thursday with final decisions to extend protections for dozens of animal and plant species  including five types of sharks  that have come under severe pressure from soaring demand and overfishing.

title: Private Equity Antitrust Lawsuit Goes Forward
description: A federal judge refused to dismiss a lawsuit accusing private equity firms of colluding to lower the prices of deals during the buyout boom, paving the way for a possible trial, DealBooks Peter Lattman reports. At the same time, though, Judge Edward F. Harrington of Federal District Court in Boston narrowed the lawsuit in his ruling on Wednesday, suggesting that the case was too broad and had serious flaws.

title: Text Messages at Center of Rape Trial Testimony
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio  In a case that came to light through social media, the second day in the trial of two high school football stars accused of raping a drunken 16-year-old girl was dominated by text messages unveiled Thursday by the prosecution, recounting the night of the alleged rape and the aftermath.

title: Thursday Reading: The Low-Rise-Jeans Insanity Defense
Fandango Creates a Movie Buzz Index
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie buzz is a heavily tilled field. Metacritic and Rotten Tomatoes track film reviews. The Internet Movie Database operates a heat index. Boxoffice.com offers charts based on Twitter and Facebook chatter.

title: A New Pope is Chosen
description: Francis, first pontiff from the Americas.

title: Talks in Britain on Press Regulation Break Down
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron announced on Thursday that cross-party talks with other political leaders on regulating Britains rambunctious press had broken down and that he would pursue his own proposal for a system of self-regulation after months of inquiries into the phone hacking scandal, mainly at Rupert Murdochs tabloid newspapers here.

title: At Ease | Steven Alan Goes Home
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Argentine Church Under the Shadow of the Dirty War
description: LONDON  The election of an Argentine to the papacy has revived a polemic about the role of the Roman Catholic Church during his countrys so-called dirty war and about his own dealings with a military junta that murdered up to 30,000 citizens.

title: Thanks for Not Calling: A Digital Etiquette Column Is a Disconnect for Readers
description: 2:41 p.m. | Updated When I called Nick Bilton  after an initial e-mail exchange  I didnt reach him right away.

title: At This Conference, Gensler Is Strictly Ballroom
description: 4:38 p.m., Monday, March 18, 2013 | Updated

title: The Breakfast Meeting: The Today Shows Popularity Woes, and Anxiety at Time Inc.
description: NBCs Today has continued to lag behind ABCs Good Morning America for 10 months now, a ratings slump that started just one week after its co-host, Matt Lauer, signed a contract with NBC said to be worth $25 million a year, the highest compensation ever on a morning show, Brian Stelter reports. Some Today staffers cite a lack of audience connection to Mr. Lauer as the root of the problem. Mr. Lauers popularity plummeted when his co-host, Ann Curry, was forced out last summer. Mr. Lauer, 55, started a belated image campaign this week, publicly stating that he thought his bosses had botched Ms. Currys departure, but it may be too late. Alex Wallace, the NBC News executive in charge of Today, said NBC wants Mr. Lauer to be host for years to come. The network has denied suggestions that it may replace him with a younger host like Willie Geist, 37, or David Gregory, 42.

title: Upstate Man Who Fatally Shot 4 Dies in Standoff; Motive Remains Unclear
description: ALBANY  The last 24 hours of Kurt R. Myerss life were punctuated by barrages of bullets.

title: Chris Hayes to Take Over 8 P.M. Slot on MSNBC
description: 1:16 p.m. | Updated Chris Hayes will take over the 8 p.m. time slot on MSNBC in the next month, the channel announced on Thursday, the day after the current host of that hour, Ed Schultz, said he was moving from the weekdays to the weekends.

title: Veronica Mars Movie Meets $2 Million Fund-Raising Goal in One Day
description: In its three seasons on the air Veronica Mars was never even one of televisions Top 100 most-watched series, but in its afterlife it has broken new ground. On Wednesday night fans and supporters of that show about a wisecracking young sleuth (played by Kristen Bell) pledged more than $2 million to produce a Veronica Mars movie, less than 12 hours after the fund-raising drive was announced on Kickstarter.

title: When Your Partner Writes the Book on Happy Families
description: It takes a lot to tolerate having a spouse (or a parent) who writes about family life, and it takes even more when that partner pulls a stunt like monthly This Life Styles columnist Bruce Feilers latest.

title: Recipe Lab Video Chat With Nigella Lawson
description: Attention home cooks: Its time to take your dish out of the oven and join us for a chat with Dinings own Julia Moskin and the cookbook author Nigella Lawson. We selected three Times readers to join the chat via Google+ Hangout after making the first Recipe Lab dish, Ms. Lawsons whole wheat pasta with brussels sprouts, cheese and potato. Ms. Moskin and Ms. Lawson, speaking from their kitchens in New York and London, respectively, discussed the recipe, Ms. Lawsons new cookbook, Nigellissima, and food in general with our three home cooks.

title: At the Corner of Broadway and Phish
description: Whether its superfluous kick lines or applause for the set or obligatory standing ovations, even the most die-hard Broadway zealot has a pet peeve.

title: U.S. Drops to No. 33 in FIFA Rankings
description: They are mostly for amusement purposes only, but the United States soccer brain trust cannot be amused by the release of the latest monthly FIFA mens rankings.

title: What Were Reading
description: Kickstarter: The oldest active fishing vessel in the United States, the Laurel, needs a new deck  and a few other things in order to become a floating oyster bar that plies local seafood at stops around Long Island Sound.  Julia Moskin

title: Poetry Pairing | Irish Poetry
description: In honor of St. Patricks Day on Sunday, this weeks Poetry Pairing matches Irish Poetry, a poem by Billy Collins, with Lost in Ireland by Matt Gross.

title: Full Frontal: Send Us Photos of Front-Yard Finery
description: Tattered couches. Elegant porch swings. Manicured lawns. Overgrown jungles. We want to put together a crowd-sourced gallery of the worlds most striking front yards, and we need your help. Submit a photo of the most interesting one youve seen. It could be yours. It could be your neighbors. (We wont scold you for coveting.) If you send us the picture by March 22, your work could be featured in the magazine. (The last time around, we asked to see your rooftops. We will also run a larger selection of images online.

title: Leading Off: The Patriot Highway
description: You do have to hand it to the Patriots. Because if there is going to be trend of heartlessly cutting the players your fans have grown attached to, well, the Patriots are going to be out in front of that. The most productive receiver in football wanted to come back for a reasonable salary? Gone. What, Tom Brady isnt happy either? The all-world quarterback who just restructured his contract, essentially returning armored trucks full of money to his team so it could sign guys like Welker, his football soul mate? Pffffttt.

title: A Diarist at War
description: With the invasion of Iraq just weeks away, Lt. Tim McLaughlin began a military ritual that dates back to Homer. He started a war diary. It was not a blog or e-mails sent from his waiting-to-invade base in the Kuwaiti desert, it was a plain notebook and pen with which he kept track of what was on his mind and what was in the cross hairs of his Abrams tank.

title: Night of the Living Alesina, Continued
description: So, while I was dealing with real life yesterday  sorry about the blog silence, but sometimes other things are more important  Paul Ryan weighed in. Now, Ryans status among the Very Serious People has taken a Very Steep Plunge; at this point Dana Milbank sounds a lot like, well, me back in 2010. (But that wont stop the VSPs from considering me unsound; I was prematurely anti-flimflam, you know.) Still, its worth spending a few seconds parsing his current position.

title: Papal Expectations
description: Representatives from the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops and DignityUSA, a Catholic group supporting G.L.B.T. rights, talk about what they want from Pope Francis.

title: The Gun Report: March 14, 2013
description: Gun advocates call it DGU. The initials stand for Defensive Gun Use. Gun proponents claim that such incidents  homeowners using guns to protect themselves against intruders  are extremely common, and that we dont work hard enough to include them in the Gun Report. (A reminder: we compile this daily report by typing shooting into Google News and looking at gun injuries and deaths from the past 24 hours. We dont favor any form of gun violence over any other form.) In any case, today we have three examples of DGU, along with one example of a 3-year-old shooting himself by accident. It is unclear whether the gun the child used was owned by someone in his home, but we have our suspicions.

title: Next in Mobile Banking: Photo Bill Payments
description: Now that many banking customers are used to depositing paper checks by snapping a photo with their cellphones, some banks are adding another feature: photo bill pay.

title: The Inscrutable Brilliance of Anne Carson
description: Anne Carson was uncomfortable with the idea of a traditional profile: a journalist following her around for a few days, like a private detective, noting her outfits and mannerisms, shadowing her on errands, making lists of furniture and wall decorations and pets, quizzing her students, standing behind her holding his breath while she tried to write in her journal. Carson is a private person. She prefers to be alone. (When her husband is traveling, Carson will call and tell him, I miss you, but Im having a great time.) Her book jackets have no author photo. Her back-flap biography  Anne Carson was born in Canada and teaches ancient Greek for a living  is so minimalist that it sounds like a parody of a back-flap biography. Carson told me that, years ago, she had a bad experience with the private-detective model of journalism and would prefer never to do it again. It took her publisher a couple of weeks to wear her down to the point that she would agree, even in a limited way, to participate in a profile. Carson later described those weeks as akin to water torture.

title: Lost in Transition: Nuggets Pass the Knicks
description: DENVER

title: Diskerud Stays in Norway but Still Has U.S. on His Mind
description: When the 2013 Tippeligaen season opens this weekend in Norway, midfielder Mix Diskerud will be looking to help bring Rosenborg BK back to the elite level of European soccer. But he will also be looking to attract the attention of the United States national team coaching staff.

title: The Wander Years
description: The irascible New York City cook Kenny Shopsin never met a curse word he didnt love, and the tirades from his cramped restaurants are the stuff of legend. His daughter Tamara, a graphic designer and sometime chef in the family kitchens, has inherited his fondness for the profane but shes also a romantic, and she shows these twin sides in her memoir, Mumbai New York Scranton. Through terse prose and charming illustrations, Tamara chronicles a year filled with drama yet also strange moments of grace, taking her from the rickshaw-clogged Indian city of Kochi to a hospital bed in New York to her unlikely second home in the Rust Belt: Im not sure what the people of Scranton do for a living. I know there is a ring-pop factory. Scribner, $25.

title: I Want My Music Videos: The Art Form Gets Its Own Museum Exhibition
description: Long before party-goers at New Jersey beaches and dudes who shock themselves with Taser guns were deemed worthy of their own television series, there was the music video: an art form so prolific and diverse that there were whole television channels that ran almost nothing but these short musical films, nearly 24 hours a day.

title: The Distance Between the Parties Budgets
description: Budgets proposed by House Republicans and Senate Democrats for the 2014 fiscal year.

title: Party-Line Vote in Senate Panel for Ban on Assault Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved a measure to reinstate a ban on assault weapons in the first major Congressional test of the issue since the law expired in 2004. But the ban remains unlikely to clear the full Senate.

title: How Creative Is Your Doctor?
description: What are you doing creatively these days?

title: India and Italy Share Blame in Marines Case, Analysts Claim
description: Indias Supreme Court on Thursday orderedthe ItalianambassadorDaniele Mancini to remain in the country whileIndia and Italy settle thedispute overthe latters refusal to send back twoItalian marines whoface murder charges in India.

title: Image of the Day: March 14
Undercover Inquiry Leads Gun Shows to Tighten Checks
description: ALBANY  An overwhelming majority of gun show operators in New York State have agreed to new procedures to ensure that criminal and mental health background checks are conducted on buyers.

title: Life of a Lizard Wrangler
description: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvards Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

title: Petition by Owner Prompts Recall of 183,000 Honda Vehicles
description: Hondas recall of about 183,000 vehicles that might apply the brakes on their own was prompted by a woman who was frightened by having that problem in her own Honda and angry that there wasnt a recall.

title: Touring Holly Golightlys New York
description: Its not hard to follow in the footsteps of the Breakfast at Tiffanys heroine.

title: Forever a Gamine at Tiffanys
description: FIFTY-FIVE years after stepping off the pages of Breakfast at Tiffanys Holly Golightly is starring in a Broadway play. So does that make her an ingnue or a trouper?

title: Stop Stealing From Our Kids
description: The sequesters arrival on March 1 has set off a raging debate over not only whether those immediate forced budget cuts are the right fiscal medicine, but also whether we should be trying to accomplish longer-term deficit reduction while the economy remains weak.

title: Sheryl Sandberg: By the Book
description: The chief operating officer of Facebook and author of Lean In doesnt like to use the iPad Kindle app on the elliptical. When you get sweaty, you cant turn the pages.

title: Sexual Harassment Lawsuit Filed Against Prominent Plaintiffs Lawyer
description: In recent years, the law firm Faruqi & Faruqi has given corporate America big headaches, filing a steady stream of shareholder lawsuits against companies related to executive pay as well as mergers and acquisitions.

title: The Case of My Missing Confidence
description: When I was 23, and living in San Francisco, I worked at a high-end design and jewelry store that not many people went into. One afternoon, as I was sitting at a desk with a phone that never seemed to ring, a man came in. He had a brown beard, a gas station cap and aviator sunglasses. A knapsack. He tripped over a stool, walked up to the desk, and pulled a nine-inch chefs knife from the waistband of his pants. Later I would wonder about this. How had he been carrying it around, comfortably?

title: At Least 18 Killed in Baghdad Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  Eighteen people were killed and 67 were wounded on Thursday when a suicide bomber blew himself up inside the Ministry of Justice compound, which he and other armed attackers had managed to infiltrate after a series of car bomb blasts nearby, the police said.

title: Deprecating the New York State Legislature API
description: On April 15, 2013, we will deprecate our New York State Legislature API. Were doing this for several reasons, but what influenced our decision most is that there is a better source for this information: the Open States Project, run by the Sunlight Foundation. The Open States Project has an excellent API and also offers bulk downloads of legislative data for many states, including New York. If youre interested in state legislative data, you can contribute.

title: The Codes of War
description: Years ago, when I was working on my masters degree in history at Louisiana Tech University, an acquaintance allowed me to use the Civil War diary of Joseph W. Ely as the basis for my thesis. Ely, a corporal in the 19th Michigan Infantry, was captured at Thompsons Station, Tenn., and spent time in the infamous Libby Prison before being exchanged. He had his left ring finger shot off in the Atlanta Campaign and survived the March to the Sea and the Carolinas Campaign to return home and live well into the 20th century.

title: Look of the Moment | Karolina Kurkova
description: The Look: Opposites Attract. A mod striped turtleneck balances out a flouncy mini. Booties with contrasting colored heels add a subdued edge.

title: Jets Deconstruct as Ryan Looks On
description: Pretend, for a second, that youre Rex Ryan.

title: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
description: Candice Childress, a student at Las Vegas Academy of International Studies, Performing and Visual Arts in Nevada, is preparing for several Advanced Placement exams.

title: A Catholic Comeback for Latin America?
SXSW Music: Punks Not Dead
description: Punk lives at South by Southwest: across generations, genders, wardrobes and skill sets. As Dr. Seuss never wrote, you can do it in a suit, you can do it in a dress, you can play it quite precisely, you can play it like a mess. Much of my Wednesday at SXSW was a blast of punk old and new, a testament both to indie-rocks archival pride and to the enduring alchemy of frustration and loud guitars.

title: The Censors Salon
description: LONDON  Pak Tea House, a caf that was home to Pakistans intelligentsia for decades and an icon of resistance to authoritarian rule, reopened last week in Lahore after being closed for 13 years.

title: Bugs
description: In the East Village, a tiny Japanese restaurant with a kooky spirit.

title: An Effort on Enforcement
description: The Timess Thomas Kaplan on gun show operators in New York State who have agreed to broader rules restricting firearms sales.

title: Keeping Score: Winning Is Just Another Constant for the Spurs
description: The San Antonio Spurs will enter Thursday nights matchup against the Dallas Mavericks one win short of 50 victories for the season. This is nothing new for the Spurs, who have won 50 or more games for the past 13 seasons, the longest such streak in N.B.A. history.

title: Are You Sticking With Expensive Financing Too Long?
description: I am currently involved in two loan transactions where the small-business owner stands to save substantial money by changing lenders. In both instances, these are relatively young companies that have been working with expensive private money lenders and factors, and their companies have grown to the point where they can now work with the asset-based lending departments at Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation-insured banks.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: 5:04 p.m. | Updated Anquan Boldin to the 49ers? Wes Welker to the Broncos? Darrelle Revis towhere, exactly? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers. Put your questions in the comments field and answers will appear on The Fifth Down next week.

title: Vocal Electrofolk in SoHo
description: We live increasingly, so the Miser is assured, in a remix culture, an age when new digital media and the Internet have conspired to collapse time and space. But doesnt it seem as if most of this mashing up were done by machines, issued as recordings, and consumed in private? Its a rare privilege to encounter performers musically skilled and culturally sympathetic enough to synthesize a global range of styles and periods before a live audience in real time and in an intimate space. Vocal Electrofolk: Africa to New York, a concert on Saturday night at the radio station WQXRs Jerome L. Greene Space in the South Village, could be such an occasion.

title: A Clash of Aesthetic Styles
description: Explore the updated campus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: A Night That Veers to Eccentric
description: THE MASHED POTATOES are cold, intentionally so, which doesnt make them any less baffling. Beneath warm hunks of pork belly, tender from a long soak in soy, sake and dashi, you do not expect to find a spongy glacier.

title: Security Forces Injure Citizens in Srinagar Attacks
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir Four Kashmiri youths said they were brutally attacked by government security forces on Wednesday after militants started firing at a Central Reserve Police Force base.

title: Six Things: Sagmeister & Walsh
description: For the past 10 years, the Austrian-born, New York-based designer Stefan Sagmeister has explored an appealing subject: happiness. Is it possible, he asks, to train our minds the same way we train our bodies? Can we make ourselves happier? His latest findings, the product of a collaboration with his recently acquired partner, Jessica Walsh, are presented in Six Things: Sagmeister & Walsh, an exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Jewish Museum and runs through Aug. 4.

title: A New Big East Is a Better Big East
description: After this week, the Big East will never be the same.

title: House of Nerds: What If You Crossed a Political Convention and SxSW?
description: If someone melts down on CNN, is that just one small gaffe or the natural order of things? Ashley Parker and David Carr recap episode six of House of Cards through the prism of politics and media. In this step back, we end up detouring through the South-by-Southwest festival in Austin Tex., where yes, people were talking about Frank Underwood and Zoe Barnes in addition to Dennis Crowley and Elon Musk.

title: Focusing on Violence Before It Happens
description: LOS ANGELES  In the days after the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn., Tony Beliz and his staff at the countys mental health department here made a series of calls.

title: N.H.L. Realignment Receives Final Vote of Approval
description: The Board of Governors on Thursday approved the N.H.L.s long-awaited realignment plan, including its first new playoff format since 1994.

title: Not Your Parents Mary Poppins at Art Fair in Maastricht
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  As a flood of collectors began pouring into the cavernous convention center here for the invitation-only opening of the European Fine Art Fair on Thursday afternoon, the first artwork they encountered was a bit confounding. Called Mary Poppins, it is a monumental and wildly colorful hanging creature with elongated arms and a strangely organic body that hangs, chandelier-like, at the fairs entrance.

title: A Life in Music
description: A look at the career of Luciano Pavarotti.

title: Is It Too Early for 2016 Polls?
description: There are more than 1,000 days before the 2016 Iowa caucuses, but several polls have already been released testing national support for prospective candidates for the Republican and Democratic nominations for president.

title: Boehner Says Losses in Election Wont Affect Budget Stance
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner said Thursday that election losses last November would not deter his party from pressing its vision of reducing the size of government and turning government health care programs largely over to the private sector  with no more tax increases.

title: Red Carpet at the 2009 Grammy Awards
description: Celebrities arriving at the annual music awards ceremony in Los Angeles.

title: Some Primitive Birds Flew With 4 Wings, Study Says
description: First, paleontologists spread the word that modern birds are actually living dinosaurs. Then came the news from China that some dinosaurs and related reptiles long ago seemed to be marvelous four-winged creatures, seemingly on standby at some runway for takeoff in flight as early birds.

title: White House Tour Outrage
description: Not since Benghazi  no, not since Fast and Furious has the G.O.P. seemed this intent on second-guessing the Obama administration. I refer, of course, to the matter of White House public tours.

title: Critic of Japans Central Bank Is Now Its Leader
description: TOKYO  In the late 1990s, in the thick of the Asian financial crisis, a top Japanese Finance Ministry official turned to his protg and found him engrossed not in policy documents, but in a chunky volume of the works of Aristotle.

title: Disney to Overhaul to Its Retail Complex in Orlando  Again.
description: LOS ANGELES  Disney blew its trumpets on Thursday and announced a splashy overhaul of its Downtown Disney retail complex in Orlando, Fla. The mall will double in size to 150 shops, restaurants and theaters and become Disney Springs.

title: Attorney General Urges N.F.L. to Battle Discrimination
description: After multiple reports by players interviewed at the N.F.L. combine indicated teams were trying to find out if prospective draft picks are gay, New York State attorney general Eric T. Schneiderman sent a letter to N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell urging the league to take a stronger stand against discrimination based on sexual orientation.

title: Anschutz Calls Off Sale of Entertainment Arm
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated The billionaire Philip F. Anschutz said on Thursday that he has called off efforts to sell the Anschutz Entertainment Group, a sports and live entertainment juggernaut that owns stakes in the Los Angeles Lakers and the Los Angeles Kings.

title: In Modern Singapore, Vintage Clothing Stores
description: Past the coffee-shop uncles having a good smoke with their afternoon beers, past the giant table of pungent durians, past the provision shop shelves crammed with sponges, incense and other household necessities, my friend Jeanette and I strolled, keeping our eyes peeled for signs of fashion.

title: Gagosian Gallery Settles Suit Filed Over Lichtenstein Painting
description: A bitter lawsuit in which the gallery owner Larry Gagosian was accused of selling a prominent collectors Roy Lichtenstein painting without her permission and making a huge commission on the deal has been settled.

title: Dolphins Still in East River. Whats Up With That?
description: The dolphin that turned up Wednesday morning in the East River has yet to return to sea, and while rescue experts are growing more concerned, they say that the animal, while on the thin side, does not appear to have any obvious health issues and is still swimming well.

title: Bankruptcy Lawyer Is Named to Manage an Ailing Detroit
description: A veteran lawyer who once worked on Chryslers bankruptcy has been handed what may prove to be his toughest case yet: to bring Detroit back from the edge of financial collapse.

title: War Is for the Living
description: Sylvia Wald and Po Kim Art Gallery

title: Conclave Over, Bakery Quickly Alters Its Menu
description: At Artuso Pastry Shop in the Bronx, the demand was there, but over on the supply side in the Vatican, the cardinals were not immediately obliging.

title: Joel Shapiro: Sculpture and Drawings 1969-1972
description: Craig F. Starr Gallery

title: Scuffles Set Up Brawl for Big East Rivals
description: For all the nostalgia at this Big East tournament, for all the highlight packages and 1980s retrospectives and flashes of past legends on the big screen, the actual on-court product in the first three days produced a whole bunch of missed shots.

title: Marcel Duchamp: Nude Descending a Staircase: An Homage
description: Francis M. Naumann Fine Art

title: Despina Stokou: bulletproof
description: Derek Eller

title: Seeking to Aid Rebels in Syria, France Urges End to Arms Embargo
description: BRUSSELS  France, joining Britain, is urging its European Union partners to meet this month and end an arms embargo on Syria, to allow weapons to be sent to the opposition there.

title: Market Sweep | The Transition Tote
description: With spring bloom approaching, sling on one of these color-block totes in a mix of rose, black and cream that will last until the first signs of fall foliage.

title: Access to the Yaeyamas
description: In March, an airport opened on Ishigaki Island in Japan, creating a bigger gateway for tourism to the tropical Yaeyama Islands in the southern Okinawa prefecture. The new airport, unlike the old one, can accommodate long-haul jets coming from more than 1,200 miles away in Tokyo. Now both Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways offer direct flights from Tokyo and other cities in Japan. From Ishigaki, travelers can snorkel among rare blue coral or catch a ferry to some of the nine other neighboring Yaeyamas, including Taketomi Island, home to traditional wooden houses.

title: Billie Joe Armstrong to Write Songs for Yale Repertory Theater Show
description: The Green Day frontman Billie Joe Armstrong will write new songs for Yale Repertory Theaters production of These Paper Bullets, a rock n roll updating of Much Ado About Nothing that will have its world premiere next March, the theater announced on Thursday.

title: Tibetan Manuscripts, Vintage Luggage Stickers and Quilts
description: TIBETAN TREASURES,

title: Scenes From Day 2 of South by Southwest Music
description: Images from the festival in Austin, Texas.

title: Pastor Pastry
description: In honor of the new pontiff, Artuso Pastry Shop in the Bronx has already issued Pope Francis cookies, updating the shortbread tributes it cooked for his predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI.

title: The Met and Crystal Bridges to Share a Trumbull Portrait
description: A TRUMBULL TO SPLIT TIME

title: Reselling E-Books and the One-Penny Problem
description: Theres so much to love about e-books. They weigh nothing, they remember your place, you can make the type larger.

title: Capturing Communities:  An Invitation to Photograph Your Hometown for the Lens Blog
description: Son, take a good look around. This is your hometown.

title: Boston Schools Drop Last Remnant of Forced Busing
description: BOSTON  The Boston School Committee, once synonymous with fierce resistance to racial integration, took a historic step Wednesday night and threw off the last remnants of a busing system first imposed in 1974 under a federal court desegregation order.

title: Bangkok, Where Extremes Coexist
description: Amid the citys chaos, visitors find charm and character.

title: SXSW Music: Scenes From Day Two
description: A slide show of images from the music festival, from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs to the Coo Coo Birds.

title: A Dozen Recipes for Slawless Cabbage
description: This St. Patricks Day, cabbage deserves better than to be boiled within a clovers width of its life.

title: Why Do My Knees Hurt?
description: Bend the knee, a triumphant Queen Cersei tells Eddard Stark after outfoxing the nettlesome Northerner in Game of Thrones.

title: The End of Google Reader Sends Internet Into an Uproar
description: 4:43 p.m. | Updated  to provide Google comment on why it shut down the service.

title: Denver in Overdrive
description: On Wednesday night in Denver the Knicks resembled the Eddy Curry era and the Nuggets won their 10th consecutive game in a typically swift fashion. Even when the Knicks scored, Ty Lawson and his athletic teammates repeatedly sprinted the other way for easy 2s. While Carmelo Anthonys unsatisfying return to Denver made headlines, the game also served as another snapshot of ideal play under Coach George Karl.

title: Keep Your Cabbage Vibrant
description: On St. Patricks Day you have a better shot at finding green beer than green cabbage, because most cabbage is served boiled to within a clovers-width of its life, turning from lovely green to what youd have to call gray. Its easy to overlook mushy and soggy cabbage when its served next to a giant hunk of corned beef and on the tail end of a couple (or five) of those beers, but cabbage deserves better. Here are a dozen ways to cook the vegetable so that it retains its vibrancy, flavor, all-important texture and appealing color.

title: Movie Review Aggregator to Shut Down
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie critics are about to lose one of their more avid online advocates.

title: The Pay Quandary for Banks
description: Andrea Orcels signing-on package shows the scale of the pay pickle facing banks.

title: Boston Phoenix to Cease Publication
description: 4:30 p.m. | Updated The Boston Phoenix, an alternative weekly newspaper known for its sharp political coverage and smart insight into culture and music, announced Thursday that it would fold.

title: At a Cocktail Classic, High-Tech Drinks, Sherry and a Tiki Safari
description: Sure, the highlight of the Manhattan Cocktail Classic in May is a Friday night gala on four floors of the elegant New York Public Library. But for the true fan of cocktails and of how theyre made, the five-day event will feature a seminar on the techniques and technologies that produce the high-tech cocktails at Booker and Dax in the East Village. And there will be not one, but two panels on sherry-based cocktails. One will delve into sherrys history as a mixer, and the other will look at the wines future in the mixology world.

title: Aaron Swartz to Be Honored by Library Association
description: The Internet activist Aaron Swartz will be awarded the American Library Associations James Madison Award on Friday as part of the groups Freedom of Information Day event at the Newseum in Washington, D.C.

title: Art and Architecture in Seoul, South Korea
description: The Seoul of today, said Doryun Chong, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, is far different from the one he left in 1992, the year South Korea elected its first civilian leader after three decades of military rule. Instead of student protesters and riot police, the city center now brims with museums, galleries and restaurants. And its transformation is still under way, said Mr. Chong, particularly where art and architecture are concerned: All of those what do you preserve, and what do you not? questions, as he put it.

title: A New G.O.P. Tack
description: The Timess Richard W. Stevenson on some party-evolving ideas being posed early at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

title: 36 Hours in Bangkok
description: Bangkok has hit the sweet spot. Its modern but far from antiseptic, filled with luxuries, pampering and great food  but still affordable. In the glare of the tropical sun it can be an ugly sprawl of tangled wires and broken pavement. Yet amid the chaos, visitors find charm and, above all, character. Somehow extremes coexist: skyscrapers and moldy tenements; high-end, cloth-napkin dining and tasty street food stalls; five-star hotels and fleabag guesthouses overflowing with backpackers; libidinous hedonism and Buddhist meditation. To travel across Bangkok is to see several worlds at once. Increasingly it is also convenient. The city of paralyzing traffic now has ample public transportation options ranging from boats to an expanding subway system. But if there is one reason visitors return again and again to Bangkok, it is the people. The anonymity and daily grind of urban life is slowly wearing away at the legendary Thai smile. Yet Bangkok remains one of the friendliest cities on the planet, still infused with the Thai village traditions of hospitality and graciousness.

title: Sailing in the Mergui Archipelago off Myanmars Coast
description: A charter boat, Sea Gipsy, ferries travelers among the islands of the Mergui Archipelago or Myanmar.

title: A Few Stray SXSW Thoughts
description: The best lost-love song with advanced-physics puns has to be Redshift by Darwin Deez, whose mission as a songwriter seems to involve merging the guitar-scrubbing light funk of the 1970s with the musicianly twistsgnarled harmonies, leaping and twisting melodiesof Frank Zappa. You loved all of my little quarks, so what went wrong?/Dont superstring me along, he lamented in a semblance of an R&B ballad. Wave or particle, I cant be both.

title: Sailing Among  Myanmars Islands of Mystery
description: I arrived on a chaotic pier in the border town of Ranong, Thailand, feeling as if I was about to throw up as I watched three-story fishing boats chug by. I had persuaded my two younger brothers and eight girlfriends to fly across the world and pool a large chunk of money so we could charter a live-aboard boat. The plan was to sail for six days through the Mergui Archipelago, a chain of 800 islands off Myanmars coast thats become the holy grail of sublime, empty beaches.

title: Once Again, Lenders Ask Greece for Additional Cuts
description: ATHENS  It has been so elaborately repeated that it almost borders on ritual: Greeces troika of lenders leaves Athens with disagreement over whether the country should receive billions of euros in fresh financial aid.

title: Danish Imports
description: Not too far from fellow Danish designer Henrik Vibskovs store, the team behind Han Kjobenhavn has opened their own flagship boutique in SoHo. The designers Tim Faith Hancock and Jannik Wikkelso Davidsen are the latest Copenhagen exports to find a foothold in New York, settling into a 850-square-foot space at 27 Prince Street.

title: The Real Rutherford
description: To the Editor:

title: He Didnt Start the Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Name Game
description: To the Editor:

title: European Leaders Stick to Austerity Course
description: BRUSSELS  Jeered by angry protesters demanding an end to austerity and shaken by a resounding rejection of their economic strategy from Italian voters, European leaders gathered for an economic summit meeting Thursday amid few signs that the blocs policies were healing the twin blights of rising unemployment and recession.

title: Food Company in Spain May Turn to Public Aid
description: MADRID  The regional government of Galicia said Thursday that it stood ready to provide economic help to Pescanova, an insolvent fishing company that has become the latest big corporate casualty of the Spanish debt crisis.

title: Geithner to Write Book on Financial Crisis
description: Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary who managed the Obama administrations response to the global financial crisis of 2008 and the recession that followed, will publish a book recounting that harrowing time, his publisher said Thursday.

title: In the Mens Game, a New Level of Noise
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Excessive grunting is often considered a problem only in womens tennis, but high-volume ball-striking has become increasingly voluminous on the mens side as well.

title: Hoping to Save Bees, Europe to Vote on Pesticide Ban
description: PARIS  Will Brussels try to give bees a break?

title: Breast-Feeding May Not Lead to Leaner Children
description: Breast-feeding is widely encouraged for its many positive health effects, but the claim that it reduces the risk for childhood obesity may be going too far. A randomized trial has found that even long-term exclusive breast feeding has no effect on obesity or stature in childhood.

title: Keeping a Closer Eye on Student Loan Servicing Firms
description: Companies that service student loans will get more scrutiny from the federal government under a new rule proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: Hidden Numbers Make Banks Even Bigger
description: It sounds like a simple question. How big is that bank?

title: At Vatican, the New Boss Is a Soccer Fan
description: The election of Cardinal Jorge Maria Bergoglio as the new pope on Wednesday sparked immediate  and quite serious  analysis about the future of the Roman Catholic Church, and about what it would mean for the churchs profile in the Americas. But in other corners of the Internet, there were also some less serious discussions, too.

title: Debauchery and the American Experience (Woo-Hoo!)
