description: GENEVA  The United Nations Human Rights Council is preparing to vote this week on a resolution that urges Sri Lanka to deliver on its promises to investigate allegations of mass civilian slaughter in the army campaign that crushed a rebel group in May 2009, and expresses growing international concern over a lengthy catalog of continuing atrocities.

title: Stolen Works
description: Two men disguised as police officers stole 13 works of art in 1990, including rare paintings by Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer, all of which have been valued at approximately $500 million.

title: 10 Years Later, an Anniversary Many Iraqis Would Prefer to Ignore
description: BAGHDAD  The war that arrived a decade ago is still too painful and too controversial to be taught to schoolchildren or subjected to serious academic study at universities, and the local news media are too busy reporting on the latest bombings, protests and political disagreements to care much about an anniversary.

title: Small Knives, Small Risk? Not Everyone Thinks So
description: HOW do flight attendants feel about allowing passengers to carry little knives on board? Well, I can always depend on Rene Foss, a flight attendant for over 25 years, to get right to the point.

title: Wanted Congolese Rebel Leader Turns Himself In to U.S. Embassy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Bosco Ntaganda, a Congolese rebel general accused of massacring civilians and building an army of child soldiers  considered one of Africas most wanted men  surprisingly turned himself in to the American Embassy in Rwanda on Monday, saying he wanted to be sent to the International Criminal Court.

title: Mets Harvey Delivers Another Strong Outing
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The Mets future hinges on the performances on a group of young arms in which the club has invested its resources and rested its hopes.

title: Style at SXSW
description: There was no shortage of perfectly worn in Converse, cut-off shorts and sundresses at SXSW this year.

title: Local Russian Hijab Ban Puts Muslims in a Squeeze
description: LEVOPADINSKY, Russia  The girls of the Salikhov family live in frontier country. Their road is dirt, punctuated by puddles and sheep, and their house does not have plumbing or running water. They had been hoping this would be the year the local authorities got around to hooking up natural gas.

title: American Honda Divides Its Biggest Ad Assignments
description: One of the largest recent reviews for an advertising account has ended with the incumbent agency keeping a significant part of the assignment, but relinquishing two large pieces to two other agencies.

title: Pennsylvania: Appoint Judges, Ex-Governors Say
description: Four former Pennsylvania governors called for eliminating elections for senior judges in favor of appointing them. Judges seeking campaign donations are open to corruption, the governors argued. The influence of money on judicial elections is pernicious, said Edward G. Rendell, a former Democratic governor, who joined with a fellow Democrat, George Leader, and two Republicans, Tom Ridge and Dick Thornburgh, in the unusual bipartisan appeal. Last month, a Pennsylvania Supreme Court justice, Joan Orie Melvin, was convicted on campaign corruption charges. Only six states select all judges in partisan elections, according to Pennsylvanians for Modern Courts, which wants the governor to fill the states three appellate benches. The change requires a constitutional amendment. Critics say it would introduce secretive back-room deals.

title: Man Says He Killed Tourist in Turkey After She Rebuffed Kiss
description: ANKARA, Turkey  The fatal encounter between a Staten Island woman and a homeless man in Istanbul earlier this year began when she resisted his attempt to kiss her, according to a two-page statement he gave to prosecutors.

title: Oh, California
description: Of all the things Ive been called in my time, the one that surprises me the most is California Writer. When I hear that, I look over my shoulder, certain that the phrase must apply to the writer behind me or to my left. Its the way I feel when I am addressed by my husbands last name. It takes me a moment to realize his mother is not in the room.

title: U.S. Drug Costs Dropped in 2012, but Rises Loom
description: Spending on prescription drugs nationwide has been slowing for years because of the increasingly widespread use of low-cost generics. But in 2012, something unheard-of happened: money spent on prescription drugs actually dropped.

title: Hughes Is Hit by Grounder in Return, but Says Hes Fine
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Tucked away in the corner of the Yankees minor league facility, on a day off for the team, three players who are key to the Yankees hopes this season toiled in relative obscurity Monday.

title: A New First Couple in Sports: Woods and Vonn
description: With eerily similar announcements to a combined Facebook and Twitter audience of nearly 6.5 million, Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn confirmed Monday that they are dating, then asked for privacy because they want to live, in Woodss words, as an ordinary couple.

title: Negotiators for Arms Trade Treaty Discuss Regulation of Ammunition
description: Negotiators at the United Nations began a final round of talks on Monday aimed at completing a treaty to regulate the international trade in conventional weapons. Objections by the United States and other major weapons exporters prevented an agreement. The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, lamented what he called the lack of regulatory controls for the import and export of conventional weapons, asking why there are common standards for the global trade in armchairs but not the global trade in arms. One of the most contentious issues was whether ammunition should be included in the scope of the treaty. Anna McDonald, a representative of Oxfam, which is pushing for strong treaty, said her group wanted strict and specific language that would regulate ammunition. Thomas Mason, a representative of the World Forum on Shooting Activities, a group that represents firearms makers and users, said the sheer volume of ammunition produced made such monitoring impractical.

title: China: More Pigs Found in River
description: The number of dead pigs found in a river near Shanghai rose to more than 13,000 over the weekend. Last Friday, the figure stood at about 7,500. The authorities, who are in the middle of a weeklong effort to collect the carcasses, are still trying to determine how the pigs died and why they ended up in the Huangpu River, which winds through Shanghai. The government has insisted that there is no evidence of an epidemic and that the food supply is safe. City officials also say the river meets national water quality standards. The authorities say they believe that many of the pigs came from the nearby city of Jiaxing, in Zhejiang Province, where there are major pig farms.

title: Former Calpers Chief Indicted Over Fraud
description: As head of the countrys largest pension fund, Federico R. Buenrostro wielded vast influence in the money management world.

title: Seeking Profit for Taxpayers in Potential of New Drug
description: WASHINGTON  With automatic spending cuts cascading through the government, lawmakers are calling for a review of federal policies they say have allowed businesses to profit on government research with limited return for taxpayers or consumers.

title: Bombs Strike Bus Station in Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Suicide bombers crashed an explosives-laden Volkswagen into a crowded bus on Monday as it was parked at a depot in Kano, northern Nigerias largest city, and officials said at least 20 people were killed, possibly many more, as the conflagration spread to four nearby buses.

title: Electronic Arts Chief Resigns
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The chief executive of Electronic Arts resigned on Monday, a victim of a troubled environment for the big video game companies as well as of internal missteps.

title: New Jersey Lawyer Guilty of Murder
description: NEWARK  For years Paul W. Bergrin eluded charges from his former colleagues in the United States attorneys office that he had become house counsel for gangs, using his criminal defense practice here as an elaborate front for prostitution, drug running and even the killing of witnesses.

title: ABC Works on an App for Live Streaming Shows to Mobile Devices
description: THE WALT DISNEY Company, while sorting out the future of the online video Web site Hulu, has an app in the works that may render Hulu pass for some people.

title: A Bank Levy in Cyprus, and Why Not to Worry
description: Never mind.

title: Its Move It or Lose It in Path of a Noreaster
description: PLUM ISLAND, Mass.  Barbara Murray walked her dog past a ribbon of the police tape that wound its way around sections of this scenic barrier island, about an hour north of Boston, where she has lived for 50 years.

title: Strategy in Scandal Makes Spanish Dukes Ex-Partner a Prisoner in Home
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Diego Torres, a onetime marketing guru, built a $2 million dream home outside Barcelona, but it has become a luxury bunker since he challenged the Spanish royal family by revealing its private e-mails as part of his legal defense in a corruption investigation.

title: A Young Man With Down Syndrome, a Fatal Encounter and a Cry for Understanding
description: You may not have heard of Robert Ethan Saylor, but his death in January should inspire something more lasting than a small-town police investigation.

title: A Cure, in Essence, for H.I.V. in Some Adults
description: Two weeks ago, American doctors reported that they had functionally cured a baby infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, with an aggressive treatment of drugs starting some 30 hours after the baby was born. Experts hailed the feat but cautioned that the findings might have little relevance to adults.

title: A War, Before and After, Part 3
description: This is the third part of a six-part series.

title: Should Depositors Save Cyprus's Banks?
Taxing Savers in Cyprus
description: A European plan could force Cyprus to tax bank depositors as a condition of a bailout in a way that would unfairly punish savers and could do lasting damage to confidence in banks in other euro-zone countries in financial crisis. The countrys leaders have a chance to change the agreement and should do so.

title: A Conversation With: Former Tihar Inmate Niranjan Kumar Mandal
description: NEW DELHI  The death of Ram Singh, one of the six defendants in the Delhi gang rape case who was found hanged in his cell, has raised speculation about its cause and questions about the management of Tihar Jail. While the post-mortem report suggested suicide, Mr. Singhs parents contend that the police murdered him, in part because both his arms were damaged from previous accidents.

title: The Andes Chronicles: A Ban on Hydraulic Fracturing
description: Once or twice a year I bring news from the small Catskills town of Andes, and usually the news concerns the ongoing battle to preserve the towns rural character in the face of incursions from entrepreneurial energy companies. A few years back Andes passed an ordinance banning wind turbines. Late last month the town board passed a law prohibiting heavy industry. The intended target of the law was hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, the technique by which natural gas is extracted from underground rock formations that have been subjected to the high velocity impact of chemically laced water.

title: Ranked No. 1, Lewis Keeps Expectations in Check
description: PHOENIX  As a teenager, Stacy Lewis spent 18 hours a day wearing a back brace to cope with scoliosis. That was hard.

title: A Pattern of Problems at a Hospital for Veterans
description: WASHINGTON  In an unusually strong letter sent to the White House on Monday, the office that handles complaints from federal whistle-blowers says it has found a pattern of problems at a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss., that raises serious questions about the hospitals management practices.

title: Vaticans Bureaucracy Tests Even the Infallible
description: VATICAN CITY  An Italian industrialist tried to curry favor by donating $100,000 worth of truffles. A Mercedes-Benz executive hoped for an audience to suggest improvements to the Popemobile. But in the final years of the papacy of Benedict XVI, others sent very different messages, too, desperate for the popes ear.

title: Arizonas Barrier to the Right to Vote
description: Arizonas Proposition 200, passed in 2004, prohibits local officials from registering any would-be voter who does not provide satisfactory evidence of United States citizenship. That requirement conflicts with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, also known as the Motor Voter Act, which set up a national registration system for federal elections.

title: Paul Ryans Ax Isnt Sharp Enough
description: Washington

title: The Progressive Shift
description: There is a statue outside theFederal Trade Commission of a powerful, rambunctious horse being reined in by an extremely muscular man. This used to be a metaphor for liberalism. The horse was capitalism. The man was government, which was needed sometimes to restrain capitalisms excesses.

title: Does China Have a Foreign Policy?
description: Shanghai

title: Falling Out of Love With China
description: Washington

title: Pre-K Provider Stole Millions, State Audit Says
description: One of New York Citys largest providers of special education services to preschoolers with disabilities illegally diverted millions in taxpayer financing to a girls religious school, summer camps and a kosher supermarket owned by the groups officers and board members, state auditors said on Monday.

title: Cyprus Bailout Incites Turmoil as Blame Flies
description: BRUSSELS  A plan to rescue the tiny European country of Cyprus, assembled overnight in Brussels, has left financial regulators, German politicians, panicked Cypriot leaders and a disgruntled Kremlin with a bailout package that has outraged virtually all the parties.

title: Lawyers for Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Brother Online
description: To the Editor:

title: Treating Early Alzheimers
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Cuts and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Busy for Dad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 18, 2013

title: Knowing Whats in the Food We Eat
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Mar. 19, 2013
description: "In a sense, were playing Russian roulette with the Sun.

title: For Colorado Governor, a Long Path to Gun Limits
description: DENVER  The wounds and rage from a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater were still raw one morning last July when Gov. John W. Hickenlooper went on national television to discuss grief and guns. Shaken and groping for answers, he nevertheless cast doubt on one idea: that tighter gun laws could have prevented the carnage.

title: More Charges Against Brooklyn Legislator
description: A New York lawmaker already facing bribery charges is now facing additional charges of falsely securing tens of thousands of dollars in travel reimbursements from the Assembly by submitting travel vouchers when he was not working on legislative business.

title: A Goal for Obama in Israel: Finding Some Overlap on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  If President Obamas most obvious goal on his trip to Israel this week is to forge a connection with the Israeli people, his challenge behind closed doors is to persuade Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he can rely on the United States to take care of Iran.

title: State Leaders Reach Deal to Raise Minimum Wage
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached a tentative agreement on Monday to increase the states minimum wage to $9 over the next three years.

title: In Womens Bracket, Top Seeds Are the Same but Baylor Leads the Way
description: If the only remarkable element of the N.C.A.A. mens tournament bracket was its parity, the opposite is true for the womens bracket, revealed Monday, with all roads leading again to Baylor, the Goliath out of the Big 12 that has lost once in two seasons.

title: Just You Wait
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome to another episode of True Stories, in which I regale you with a long-buried and potentially embarrassing story from my life that is unceremoniously dislodged from my brain by an entry in the puzzle.

title: Tennis Association Seeks Parkland, and Gets a Fight
description: It was two years ago that a match at the United States Open was interrupted because an 18-inch hairline crack developed along the service line in the middle of a game. Of course, it was all captured on TV, recalled Daniel Zausner, the chief operating officer of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens. It was an embarrassment.

title: How Blogger Helped the Steubenville Rape Case Unfold Online
description: On the day after two high school football players from Steubenville, Ohio, were found guilty of rape, Alexandria Goddard, a crime blogger whose early and dogged research helped bring national attention to the case, is still fending off criticism that she helped create an Internet lynch mob.

title: A Glut of Electronic Waste
description: As recently as a few years ago, broken monitors and televisions were being recycled profitably. But flat-screen technology has lowered demand, creating stockpiles of useless material across the country.

title: Nets Still Trying to Find Themselves
description: There is no shame in dropping a game to the Atlanta Hawks, even at home, but the Nets projected disappointment in the way they competed Sunday night in a puzzling 105-93 loss that bore a number of implications for playoff seeding.

title: Corrections: March 19, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Murder Conviction Tossed Out in Queens
description: A judge has thrown out the murder conviction of a man who already served more than 13 years in prison and granted him a new trial, saying that the Queens district attorneys office had failed to give the defense information that would have shown a crucial witness lied on the stand.

title: Unwanted Electronic Gear Rising in Toxic Piles
description: Last year, two inspectors from Californias hazardous waste agency were visiting an electronics recycling company near Fresno for a routine review of paperwork when they came across a warehouse the size of a football field, packed with tens of thousands of old computer monitors and televisions.

title: A Focus on 3 Encounters in a Stop-and-Frisk Trial
description: The first time the police stopped and then frisked him on his block in the Bronx, David Floyd remembered wanting only to get home and be in my own space. The second time it happened, Mr. Floyd testified, he was left with the impression that I needed to stay in my place, and my place was in my home.

title: The Senates Muckraker
description: Ill miss Carl Levin when he leaves the Senate after the next election  and you will, too.

title: Traffic Fatalities in City Increased in 2012, but Officials Point to Larger Picture
description: More than 270 people died in New York City traffic in 2012, the most traffic-related fatalities since 2008, officials said on Monday.

title: Court Is Asked to Drop Charges Against Kenyas President-Elect
description: PARIS  Lawyers for Kenyas president-elect, Uhuru Kenyatta, said Monday that the charges of crimes against humanity that he faces should be dropped because they were based on hearsay and were fundamentally flawed.

title: For Some, Spending Less on Drugs
description: As lower-cost generic drugs have become more widely prescribed, the dollar amount spent on drugs fell last year for the first time.

title: Abortion Doctors Murder Trial Opens
description: PHILADELPHIA  In opening statements in court on Monday, prosecutors charged that a doctor who operated a womens health clinic here killed seven viable fetuses by plunging scissors into their necks and snipping their spinal cords and was also responsible for the death of a pregnant woman in his care.

title: Injuries Leave Knicks With Odd Lineup
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Through 64 games this season, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson never had to construct his starting lineup out of pure desperation. Woodson did for Mondays nationally televised game against the Utah Jazz.

title: Erwin Harris, Ad Executive Who Seized Cuban Assets, Dies at 91
description: Erwin Harris left behind a respectable record of achievement as an advertising executive, an estimable collection of Chinese antiquities (his lifelong hobby), a loving family and a remarkable if little-remembered role in the tortured history of diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba in the early 1960s.

title: Nets Look Impressive in First Stop of Their Trip
description: AUBURN HILLS, MICH.  The Nets began their longest trip of the season  13 days away from home, which will most likely fall between a fascinating footnote and a season-defining stretch  by doing something they have routinely done all season: win against a mediocre team.

title: Olen Burrage Dies at 82; Linked to Killings in 1964
description: Olen Burrage, a Ku Klux Klan member who owned the Mississippi farm where the bodies of three slain civil rights workers were found in 1964, died on Friday in Meridian, Miss. He was 82.

title: A Justice Dept. Official Is Named to Lead Labor
description: WASHINGTON  With a few confirmation victories in his pocket, President Obama decided Monday to press ahead with another cabinet nominee in defiance of Republican opposition as he tapped an assertive civil rights regulator to be his next labor secretary.

title: Booth Gardner Dies at 76; Ex-Washington Governor
description: Booth Gardner, a two-term governor of Washington whose diagnosis with Parkinsons disease after he left office helped motivate him to lead a successful voter initiative to allow physician-assisted suicide, died on Friday at his home in Tacoma. He was 76.

title: A Guide to Watching Syrias War
description: Amateur video has been pivotal to the way the conflict in Syria is understood.

title: Ban on Gay Marriage Led Lawyers to Shift Role
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Nine years ago, city officials here sued to strike down a state ban on same-sex marriage. It was the first government challenge to such a law, and it set in motion a legal chain reaction that gave rise to a momentous Supreme Court case to be argued next Tuesday.

title: In Rare Move, Patriots Owner Gives Details of Welker Talks
description: PHOENIX  In a news conference that offered an unusual amount of detail from one of the N.F.L.s most tight-lipped organizations, the Patriots owner Robert K. Kraft said Monday that everyone in the organization wanted receiver Wes Welker to return. Welker signed a two-year contract with the Broncos last week for $6 million per year, and the Patriots signed Danny Amendola to replace him for about the same amount.

title: One Person One Vote (or Was That One Voter One Vote?)
description: WASHINGTON  With the exception of the Senate, where voters from states with small populations have vastly more power than those from, say, California or Texas, the rest of the American political system is committed to the bedrock principle of one person one vote.

title: In the Song of Egypt,  a Chord for Both Secular and Religious Jews
description: Hanina, the 5-year-old I baby-sit, loves to play pretend. When we come up with a story he enjoys, we play it over and over. Small children love repetition  if its fun the first time, itll be fun the second! (And the 22nd!) Haninas favorite books inspire many of our games. I cant count the number of times weve ridden the Magic School Bus as it made its interminable, fact-filled way through the local water works or blasted into outer space. Other games, like a recent one featuring a marauding army of killer cannibal princesses, Hanina dreams up on his own.

title: Q&A: Logging Out of Gmail From Another Computer
description: Q.

title: Celtics Give Heat All They Can Handle, but They Handle It
description: BOSTON  They trailed by 17 in the first half. They trailed by 13 with eight-plus minutes to play. They were hit by an offensive explosion like none they had seen all season, not from Kevin Durant, Kobe Bryant or Carmelo Anthony.

title: So Youre Extinct? Scientists Have Gleam in Eye
description: Until recently, the arrow of natural selection seemed to go only one way. A species could form, then it could flourish, then it could go extinct. And once it was extinct, it could not come back.

title: Word of the Day | guileless
description: guileless \gi(-)l-ls\ adjective

title: Small Infrastructure Gains Are Observed in Engineering Report
description: The nations infrastructure is crumbling a little bit less.

title: Bryants Roles Evolve From Peacemaker to Assistant Coach
description: LOS ANGELES  Having been many things to many people and everything to the Lakers over the last 17 years, Kobe Bryant emerged last week in a role no one expected: assistant coach.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Derails in Queens
description: A Long Island Rail Road train derailed Monday night west of Jamaica Station in the vicinity of Forest Hills, Queens, causing potential delays for the morning commute, but no injuries, the authorities said.

title: Fukushima Blackout Hints at Plants Vulnerability
description: TOKYO  The stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant this week experienced its worst power failure since the disaster there in 2011, and though the plants operator said all electricity was restored by early Wednesday, the problem underlined its continuing vulnerability.

title: Rangers Manage to Break Losing Streak, if Not Their Scoring Struggles
description: Marc Staal watched from a Madison Square Garden luxury box, attending his first game since taking a puck near the right eye in a frightening accident March 5. Staal did not speak to reporters, but obviously liked what he saw  a 2-1 shootout victory for the Rangers over the Carolina Hurricanes and his brothers Eric and Jordan on Monday night.

title: United States Facing Two Qualifying Games With Thin Roster
description: When United States national team Coach Jurgen Klinsmann called in attacking threats like Jozy Altidore, Herculez Gomez and Clint Dempsey for his latest roster, it was surely done with the hope that the United States would be able to score often in its two coming World Cup qualifying matches. Given the injuries and illness that have racked Klinsmanns group of defenders, he could hardly be blamed for thinking he will need as many goals as possible.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) SPLASH The Olympic gold medalist Greg Louganis, above, will tutor 10 celebrities  among them, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Louie Anderson, Drake Bell, Keshia Knight Pulliam and Kendra Wilkinson  in the art of diving before they try to flip, twist and spin off a regulation platform and springboard in this new competition series. The diver David Boudia and the director of the United States team, Steve Foley, will critique each dive. Chuy Bravo, Rory Bushfield, Nicole Eggert, Ndamukong Suh and Katherine Webb round out the roster of competitors; Joey Lawrence and Charissa Thompson host.

title: Dominican Republic Reaches World Classic Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO  No team has gone undefeated in a World Baseball Classic. The Japanese won it in 2006 and 2009 while losing three games the first time and two the second. Now, the Dominican Republic will take an unblemished record into the final game on Tuesday at AT&T Park.

title: News Quiz | March 19, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: The Rebels Loose Cannon
description: Steve Green had seen it all before. The hand gestures. The histrionics. The nonstop conversation Marshall Henderson was having with himself.

title: Thomas Helps Short-Handed Knicks Hold Off Jazz
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Kurt Thomas sat at his locker, his right foot in a bucket of ice, in the visitors locker room at EnergySolutions Arena. He had a smile on his face, appearing content to quietly reflect on his night.

title: Jets Sign a Pass Rusher
description: The Jets bolstered their pass rush Monday by signing outside linebacker Antwan Barnes to a three-year contract.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 19
description: NEWS President Nicos Anastasiades delayed a vote on a $13 billion deal that set off outrage for calling on Cypriot bank depositors to bear part of the cost, while stock markets faltered on concerns over the plan. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus, and Landon Thomas Jr. from London.

title: Francis Vows to Serve Poorest, Weakest and Urges Leaders to Offer Hope
description: VATICAN CITY  Striking a tone of radical humility that has already become his trademark, Pope Francis offered a passionate pledge in his installation Mass on Tuesday to serve the poorest, the weakest, the least important, urging world leaders to protect human life and the environment and use tenderness to inspire hope.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 19, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Sun Storm Forecast: Tiny Chance of Havoc.

title: British Newspapers Challenge New Press Rules
description: LONDON  A day after British lawmakers agreed to ground rules for a new press code, an array of newspapers protested on Tuesday against the attempt to impose stricter curbs on this countrys scoop-driven dailies following the phone hacking scandal that convulsed Rupert Murdochs media empire and much of British public life.

title: A Verdict in the Steubenville High School Rape Case
description: In Ohio Teenagers Guilty in Rape That Social Media Brought to Light, Richard A. Oppel Jr. writes about a case that drew wide attention for the way social media spurred the initial prosecution and later helped galvanize national outrage over the episode.

title: False Historical Consciousness
description: BEIJING  My courtyard home in the heart of old Beijing has a view of the Drum Tower, which for centuries helped citizens keep track of the time.

title: Should Computer Games Be Used for Classroom Instruction?
description: Some say the future of classroom learning should be digitized and gamified, so that students barely notice they are learning. Do students learn important skills and concepts playing computer games? What do you think?

title: Who Lives Longest?
description: A Swedish baby born in 1800 had a life expectancy of just 32 years. We know this because Sweden was one of the first countries to keep extensive records of births and deaths and, by 1800, had a reliable national system that allowed this morbid statistic to be calculated. That babys life may sound nasty, brutish and short, especially for a nation advanced enough to keep such detailed records, but before you imagine 19th-century Swedish teenagers suffering the regret and ennui of midlife crises, consider this: that same year, a 20-year-old Swede could reasonably expect to live another 37 years.

title: Where Home Is an Elusive Fantasy
description: A young man stands in a swimming pool, eyes covered, shoulders hunched, his head slightly bowed. A child bounces from bed to bed. A dainty green cupcake with confetti sprinkles occupies a place of honor on a paper plate.

title: Rejection of Deposit Tax Scuttles Deal on Bailout for Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  Lawmakers rejected a 10 billion euro bailout package on Tuesday, sending the president back to the drawing board to devise a new plan that might still enable the country to receive a financial lifeline while avoiding a default that could reignite the euro crisis.

title: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
description: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blogs Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

title: The Early Word: Goals and Challenges
description: Todays Times

title: Daily Report: Electronic Arts Chief Resigns
description: The chief executive of Electronic Arts resigned on Monday, a victim of a troubled environment for the big video game companies as well as of internal missteps, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Buyer for BBCs Book Unit on Travel
description: SERRAVAL, France  In 2007, when the British Broadcasting Corporation bought the Lonely Planet travel guidebooks, it drew criticism from rival media organizations in the private sector, which argued that a public television company had no business expanding into areas like book publishing.

title: Questioning the TOMS Shoes Model for Social Enterprise
description: After visiting Argentina and seeing the impact of poverty on some of its children,Blake Mycoskie was inspired to create aphilanthropic for-profit business that was sustainable and not reliant on donations.The result was Toms Shoes, which promised that for every pair of shoes it sold, it would give away another pair to a child in need.

title: Pakistan Arrests Militant Suspected in Daniel Pearl Killing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani officials have arrested a senior militant accused of involvement in the murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002.

title: Creating Canadas Quantum Valley
description: Showing how quickly an esoteric technology can become mainstream, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, who together founded BlackBerry, are establishing a $100 million venture fund for technologies that employ practical applications of quantum physics.

title: Many Israelis Unsure of Obama, but Are Ready to Listen During Visit
description: JERUSALEM  Obama administration officials have made it clear that the top agenda item for the presidents visit here this week is to win the hearts of the Israeli people. He has a lot of work to do.

title: The Politics of the 14th Amendment and the Debt Limit
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Finance Bill, Nearing Senate Passage, Would Protect Some Favored Programs
description: WASHINGTON  The worst of the federal cuts to a major infant nutrition program would be reversed. Embassy security and construction could be spared in the wake of the consulate attack in Benghazi, Libya. And child care subsidies, once seen as critical to the success of welfare reform, would take a haircut, not the hammer blow that President Obama once loudly warned was coming.

title: Assessing the Cyprus Bailout
description: The European plan to take money from bank depositors to help pay for a bailout of Cyprus has set off alarm bells among some analysts and politicians. But the move, far from setting a precedent for other countries, has a lot to do with the particulars of Cyprus, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

title: Allegations of War Crimes in Sri Lanka Shake Indian Government
description: NEW DELHI The Congress Party faced a new crisis on Tuesday after a southern political party threatened to withdraw from the governing coalition if India did not join an international push to investigate alleged war crimes in Sri Lanka.

title: In Performance: Judy Kuhn of Passion
description: Stephen Sondheim and James Lapines musical Passion, set in 19th-century Italy, tells an unlikely love story: Giorgio, a young army captain with a beautiful mistress, is changed by the obsessive love that Fosca, an invalid he meets while serving at a mountain outpost, has for him. In this number from the Classic Stage Company revival, Fosca, played by Judy Kuhn, sings Loving You, in which she tells Giorgio that her love for him is not a choice, and not much reason to rejoice. Ms. Kuhn is accompanied on cello by Mairi Dorman-Phaneuf; the arrangement is by Rob Berman, the shows musical director. Passion continues through April 19.

title: Subjunctivitis
description: The subjunctive mood is a bit more arcane than other entries on our list of favorite grammar gaffes, like subject-verb agreement. Still, its a sign of polish and precision to get this right. The subjunctive is most often used in contrary-to-fact conditions and for wishes and other hypothetical expressions.

title: Taxing Deposits in Cyprus
description: A plan to tax bank depositors in Cyprus sets off alarms.

title: Opinion Report: Cypriot Bank Deposits
description: From the editorial page

title: The Dunning-Kruger-Madoff Effect
description: Via Mark Thoma, Hale Stewart is bemused by John Hinderaker of PowerLine. As Stewart notes, Hinderaker begins by asserting that everyone knows that an economic crisis is coming  which apparently means everyone he talks to  then rolls out just about every one of the myths that have been proved wrong again and again by events, from the looming debt crisis to the imminent takeoff of inflation.

title: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: Music and Dance
description: The grand cities of Mumbai and New York differ from each other in a million ways, but are brought together by a few common strands  their entrepreneurial spirit, their dynamic always on-the-go nature, their lively sidewalks, their gorgeous coastlines, the diversity of their residents who bring unique culture and religion and their vibrant music scene.

title: Boeing and Ryanair Agree to a Deal for 175 New Jets
description: Boeing said on Tuesday that it had signed an order for 175 single-aisle 737s, its biggest deal so far this year, from the European low-cost carrier Ryanair.

title: Committed, Sort Of
description: Dear Diary:

title: Tuesday Reading: Lost Sleep Can Lead to Weight Gain
Cogan, Taylor, and the Confidence Fairy
description: Ugh. And I say that advisedly. John Cogan and John Taylor have a piece in the WSJ (where else) arguing that the latest Ryan budget would actually be expansionary, because confidence! Its as if all the experience of recent years, in which the confidence fairy has yet to make an appearance, hasnt happened.

title: Expat Fury at Cyprus Bank Raid
description: LONDON  Thousands of expatriates living in Cyprus may be having second thoughts about picking the Mediterranean island as their retirement home.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: ABC Works on a Streaming App and British Newspapers Protest Regulations
description: The Walt Disney Company is working on an app that would stream ABC programming to the tablets and phones of cable and satellite subscribers, Brian Stelter reports. ABC would be the first of the American broadcaster to provide such an app, and it is likely to result in a mixture of awe and fear from other networks. Disney already has streaming apps for content from ESPN and the Disney Channel, but special complexities exist for networks like ABC because of older contracts with companies that produce its shows and local stations, which might feel threatened by the app. It is not yet clear what the app would mean for online streaming services like Hulu, which does not require viewers to subscribe and has grown increasingly marginalized as its parent companies (including Disney) seek more lucrative revenue streams.

title: Malone Takes a Step Back Into Cable With Charter Stake
description: 10:12 p.m. | Updated

title: U.S. Says Laos Is Blocking an Inquiry Into 3 Missing Men
description: BANGKOK  The American ambassador to Laos said on Tuesday that the Laotian authorities had blocked a United States investigation into the disappearance of two citizens and a resident of the United States.

title: Southwest Broadens Approach in New Campaign
description: Southwest Airlines, for the first time in many years, is making major changes in how it presents itself to current and potential customers.

title: A Modest Proposal
description: Right now, covering up seems way sexier and far more modern than baring it all.

title: Paul Spells Out His Plan for Immigration Overhaul
description: Read an updated version of this post.

title: U.S. Treasury Secretary and Chinese President Meet
description: BEIJING  Jacob J. Lew, the American Treasury secretary, met with President Xi Jinping of China on Tuesday in the first high-level encounter between American and Chinese officials since Mr. Xi assumed the presidency, and one that recognized sticking points in a relationship that has drifted in the last few months.

title: Condoleezza Rice to Write Book for Henry Holt
description: Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is writing a book that will examine the creation of democracy at home and abroad, drawing upon stories from her career and personal life, the publisher Henry Holt & Company said Tuesday.

title: Times Names Berlin Chief and Editor for Europe
description: The New York Times on Tuesday announced changes to its European operations, saying that Alison Smale would become Berlin bureau chief and Richard W. Stevenson would become Europe editor.

title: Philippine Court Delays Law on Free Contraceptives for Poor
description: MANILA  The Philippine Supreme Court on Tuesday temporarily halted a landmark law that would provide free contraception to poor women.

title: Syria and Activists Trade Charges on Chemical Weapons
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government and Syrian rebels traded accusations about a lethal attack in the northern province of Aleppo on Tuesday, in which each side in the countrys two-year-old conflict said the other had used chemical weapons.

title: A San Francisco Classic: Vesuvios Bohemian Coffee
description: I had to tell people to stop. After I put out an informal call for San Francisco bar recommendations for this months Drink column, I simply couldnt visit the dozens of bars that people suggested. Im sure I had to omit some of your favorites  chime in and let me know what those are  but 20 bars in four days was all I could manage. This time.

title: Same-Sex Marriage and Political Savvy
description: Anyone wondering why Republicans such as Jon Huntsman and Rob Portman are suddenly announcing their support for gay marriage (and why the anti-gay marriage forum at the Conservative Political Action Convention last week was empty while the pro-marriage forum was packed) should take a look at this poll from ABC News and the Washington Post.

title: 7 Marines Killed in Nevada Training Exercise
description: WASHINGTON  Seven Marines were killed and several others were injured when a mortar round unexpectedly exploded during a live-fire training exercise at a weapons depot in western Nevada, the military said Tuesday.

title: A 1930s Beauty Contest With Shapely Horns and Fine Beards
description: You probably knew this already, but there was a time when there were regular goat beauty pageants in Central Park.

title: You Dont Dance With Your Face, or Do You?
description: In contemporary dance, the face is largely unexplored territory. A neutral expression is the default, so as not to distract from whats happening elsewhere.

title: Civil Disobedience
description: San Franciscos city attorney discusses why he challenged his states ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Q&A: Keeping Adobe Flash Player Secure
description: Q.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Jewish Daily Forward: What is kosher salt, exactly? And why do chefs like it so much?  Jeff Gordinier

title: Hitchcocks Earliest Films to Tour U.S.
description: With a film and TV movie about Alfred Hitchcock and even a new TV series based on his work, fans of the director have had a lot to check out recently. Now add nine more films, black-and-white silents that constitute his earliest-surviving work, which will be shown together on an American tour later this year.

title: Away From the Bronx, Cano Takes On a More Vocal Role
description: San Francisco

title: Another New Album Coming From Justin Timberlake
description: Justin Timberlake says he plans to release new music in the near future: a second volume to his just-released album, The 20/20 Experience.

title: A Gay Man at Midlife Ponders Being Lonely and Invisible
description: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Around the World in 60 Days
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  Since the beginning of February, Ive played in four states in the United States, three countries (soon to be four), and have reshuffled my suitcases almost as often as a casino worker shuffles cards. The sport might be called something different each place I travel, but the last two months of excitement have come together as fitting parts of my ascension to become a more complete player.

title: Dismissing Concerns, Panel Backs Whites S.E.C. Nomination
description: Mary Jo White cleared an important hurdle on her path to becoming a top Wall Street regulator when a panel of lawmakers overwhelmingly backed her nomination on Tuesday.

title: The Gun Report: March 19, 2013
description: Many readers have wondered when the gun violence death toll, post-Newtown, would surpass the death toll from the Sept. 11 attacks.It didnt take long. According to Slates gun-death tracker, which we link to each day, an estimated 2,793 people have died as a result of gun violence since December 14, 2012. The recorded death toll of the Sept. 11 attacks stands at 2,752.

title: Wanderlust in Repose
description: Part of the beauty of travel, stylistically speaking, is letting go of the restraints of the everyday for a more carefree look.

title: Posters for Chefs, the New Rock Stars
description: Whether were talking about San Francisco in the 1960s, during the early years of the Grateful Dead and Jefferson Airplane, or the alternative-rock scene that produced bands like Superchunk, Soundgarden and Pavement in the 1980s and 90s, rock music has long been a fertile breeding ground for visual art.

title: A Streak That Doesnt Take the Spotlight
description: About the only thing you can fault the Miami Heat on these days is their lousy timing. Yes, the Heats 23-game winning streak is one to behold, no matter the time of year and yes, it certainly is a reason to tune in to games when the regular season usually turns to unwatchable mush. But there is so much out there clamoring for fans attention these days, the Heat are struggling to get the hype machine pointed squarely in their direction.

title: Bringing Back the Dead
description: A Stanford professor discusses the science and ethics of resurrecting extinct species.

title: The States With the Highest Car Insurance Rates
description: If you want cheap car insurance rates, its best not to live in Louisiana. Or Michigan.

title: Queens Museum of Art to Be Renamed Amid Expansion
description: The 9,335-square-foot Panorama of New York City will still be there, but the familiar logo for the Queens Museum of Art will not. The cultural institution in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park is changing its name to the Queens Museum. The renaming accompanies a planned $65-million, 50,000-square-foot expansion that is scheduled to be finished in October.

title: Shorter Cyprus
description: So, a quick summary: The Germans dont want a Cyprus collapse / exit from the euro, but they also dont want the spectacle of German taxpayers bailing out Russian money-launderers. So what they did instead was blackmail Cyprus into having Cypriot depositors bail out Russian money-launderers. That way Germanys hands are clean.

title: In Charter, Malone Returns to His Roots
description: John C. Malone is returning to his roots.

title: Image of the Day: March 19
M.L.S. Plays On, Minus 38
description: Squeezed on all sides by scheduling conflicts and an unforgiving worldwide soccer calendar, Major League Soccer will play on with  eight games this weekend as leagues around the world take a break on two official FIFA dates for international matches.

title: A Witness to 4 Iraqi Wars, but No More
description: Mohammed Hussein is a former head of the newsroom in The New York Timess Baghdad bureau. He fled to Syria in 2007 at the height of the sectarian fighting, returned in 2008 when the situation improved, then moved to the United States with his family in 2010 under a program in which Iraqi interpreters working with Americans could receive special immigrant visas. His previous blog posts can be read here.

title: Judge Approves Sale of Rights to Hostess Brands, Including Twinkies
description: A federal bankruptcy judge on Tuesday approved the sales of several major Hostess Brands product lines, including Twinkies, fetching about $800 million for the various pieces of the bankrupt baking company and clearing the way for it to be eventually wound down.

title: Its Mr. Hell on the Line
description: The two men who founded the seminal proto-punk band Television in 1973 had almost everything young rockers need: ambition, attitude, brooding good looks and a modicum of talent. Heres what they lacked: names that evoked their malcontented essences.

title: Doctors Urge F.D.A. to Restrict Caffeine in Energy Drinks
description: A group of 18 doctors, researchers and public health experts jointly urged the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday to take action on energy drinks to protect adolescents and children from the possible risks of consuming high amounts of caffeine.

title: Hal Steinbrenner Plots New Course for Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  On Oct. 17, in the hours before Game 4 of the American League Championship Series was scheduled to begin, a steady, gloomy rain fell on Detroit. Sitting in his hotel room, Hal Steinbrenner watched the downpour and frowned. And then his phone rang.

title: Garbled Texting as a Sign of Stroke
description: Slurred and incoherent speech is one of the classic signs of a stroke. But new research finds that another symptom may be garbled and disjointed text messages, which could provide early clues to the onset of a stroke.

title: Marie Ponsot Wins Lucrative Poetry Prize
description: Marie Ponsot, a poet known for her bold reimaginings of traditional forms, has been awarded the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, one of the most prestigious (and richest) in poetry, which comes with a $100,000 award.

title: Demystifying Taylors Confidence Fairy (Wonkish)
description: I was wondering, but Noah Smith does the work.

title: Iraqis Pain Never Abates as Attacks Kill Dozens
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq closed a painful decade just as it began: with explosions reverberating around the capital.

title: Debevoise & Plimptons Trusts and Estates Group Finds a New Home
description: In December, the trusts and estates lawyers at Debevoise & Plimpton received shocking news. The law firms leadership said it had decided to eliminate its trusts and estates practice, and instructed the groups lawyers to look for a new home.

title: Settlement of Class Action Against Audi Gets Preliminary Approval
description: A federal judge has given preliminary approval to settling a class-action suit over transmission problems on about 64,000 of Audis most popular models.

title: Rand Paul to Speak at Iowa Republican Dinner
description: Senator Rand Paul will speak at the Iowa Republicans Lincoln Day Dinner in Cedar Rapids on May 10. The fund-raiser for the state party offers Mr. Paul an early chance to introduce himself to potential caucusgoers as he considers a bid in 2016.

title: Port Authority, With Eye on Income, Will Pick Firm for Trade Center Observatory
description: New Yorks newest and tallest observation deck will offer an interactive immersion in all things New York as it shuttles visitors 102 floors into the sky and provides panoramic views of the city and beyond, from the harbor to Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: The Right Wine for Halibut
description: Halibut is the chardonnay of the fish family, essentially neutral in flavor but brilliant in transmitting external influences. In David Taniss recipe for halibut skewers with yogurt sauce, the dominant flavors will be the Turkish spices, along with the lemon, onion and cooling herbs.

title: Samsung Speaks Up First About a Smart Watch
description: Samsung Electronics has made it clear that it is making a wristwatch, even as Apple is rumored to beworking on a smart watch itself. It is rare for a big tech company to voluntarily reveal a future product.

title: Anna Nicole, as in Smith, Is Part of City Operas Coming Season
description: New York City Opera announced on Tuesday that its 2013-2014 season would feature the American premiere of two operas, Anna Nicole, by Mark-Anthony Turnage, based on the paparazzi-filled life and death of Anna Nicole Smith, and Endimione, a little-known and rarely staged work composed by Johann Christian Bach in 1772.

title: Swirls of Stain, the Art of N.C.A.A. Branding
description: LAS VEGAS  The basketball court at the Mountain West Conference tournament was like no other, impossible to ignore, which is exactly the point. Stained in at least four hues of brown, it featured deep contrasts of arcs and boxes and jags, including a range of snow-capped peaks stretching the length of the floor.

title: Judge Proposes a National Lawyers Corps to Help Immigrants
description: As Congress takes up immigration reform, Robert A. Katzmann, a federal appellate judge in New York, has been looking beyond the debates and envisioning a crisis.

title: Transocean Chief Admits Crew Shortcomings in Oil Spill
description: NEW ORLEANS  The chief executive of the company that owned the Deepwater Horizon oil rig acknowledged in court on Tuesday that his crew should have done more to avert the 2010 oil well blowout that left 11 dead and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches along the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Rand Paul on Immigration
description: The Timess Michael D. Shear talks about Senator Rand Pauls proposals on immigration.

title: Its a Bag, Its a Desk, Its Got Geek Appeal
description: Considering its purpose  a bag that coverts to a standing desk for the iPad  shouldnt the Strotter Platforma look much, much nerdier?

title: Lesson Learned After Financial Crisis: Nothing Much Has Changed
description: People have learned their lesson.

title: The Truth About Working From Home
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about the pros and cons of allowing workers to do their jobs from home.

title: What If You Hate Mountains?
description: In a recent report from the World Economic Forum analyzing 140 countries competitiveness in travel and tourism, Switzerland (above) ranked first, and the United States was sixth. The factors that determined a countrys ranking include its tourism infrastructure, appeal to business travelers and friendliness (in that last category, Iceland scored high marks and Bolivia finished last).

title: Creamy Banana Pudding With Pistachio Crumble
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

title: New Guy, New Girl Joining Once
description: The Tony Award-winning Broadway musical Once is having a cast makeover. Sunday will mark the last scheduled appearance of the shows Tony-winning star, Steve Kazee, and his colleagues Cristin Milioti, Elizabeth A. Davis and Will Connolly.

title: These Chicks Are Not of the Easter Basket Variety
description: After about 70 days of carefully controlled incubation beneath deep river sand, heated electrically from below, three rare maleo chicks have hatched at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Jeter, His Ankle Still Stiff, Is Scratched From Lineup
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Derek Jeter described his mood as more frustrated than concerned, although the Yankees may feel otherwise. He complained Tuesday about more than the normal stiffness in his surgically repaired left ankle and was scratched from the starting lineup against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Broadway Cat Revival Cools at Box Office
description: This is the season of star vehicles on Broadway  Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson, Tom Hanks, Alec Baldwin, Bette Midler  but not all of them are burning rubber at the box office.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Psychiatric Diagnoses
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Stats Say About This Years Tournament
description: Last season, The Quad published a study that showed field goal percentage defense, assist-to-turnover ratio and rebounding margin are the three statistics most correlated to college basketball success. Using that information, we identified Duke, Missouri and Michigan as vulnerable teams entering the 2012 N.C.A.A. tournament. All three lost their first game.

title: Misunderstanding IS-LM (Wonkish and Unimportant)
description: Some readers have asked me to reply to this Steve Keen piece claiming that I dont understand the IS-LM model. Sigh. I really dont want to spend time fighting against people with whom I dont really have a current policy disagreement  and this is so silly, besides. But to satisfy those who are for some reason nervous, heres a brief explanation of why somebody doesnt understand IS-LM.

title: To Many Yogurt Fans, Its All Greek
description: You know Greek yogurt is having its moment when an artisan in Brooklyn is making it from an old family recipe, downtown mixologists are using it in a cocktail and chefs are pairing it with fried brussels sprouts and green cauliflower.

title: Blair Says Iraq Would Be Worse Than Syria Now, if Antiwar Critics Had Prevailed
description: Defending Britains participation in the American-led invasion of Iraq, former Prime Minister Tony Blair told the BBC that Iraq would look a lot more like Syria, and probably a lot worse than Syria, today if the war had not taken place.

title: Spam Texts Vex Me and Make Me Feel Old
description: I havent lived in Atlanta for several years. But my cellphone, which still has an Atlanta phone number, apparently maintains a very active social life there. Every weekend it gets invitations to wild parties throughout the city, including a hip place called The Mansion Elan.

title: Raising Children Who Will Speak Up to Prevent Rape, Not Defend It
description: I spent Sunday morning at a birthday party for one of my sons classmates. As the kids gathered around a paper-covered table to begin an art project, I stood off to the side, furiously typing away on my phone as I scoured my Twitter feed for news of the verdict in the Steubenville rape case.

title: Mariinsky Theater Plans Star-Studded Opening of New Opera House
description: The Mariinsky Theater in Russia announced on Tuesday plans for a three-day celebration to mark the opening of the new Mariinsky II opera house in St. Petersburg in May. An opening-night gala conducted by the theaters artistic and general director, Valery Gergiev, on May 2 will feature performances by an array of stars that include Plcido Domingo, Olga Borodina, Ekaterina Gubanova, Anna Netrebko, Ren Pape and Yekaterina Kondaurova.

title: For the G.O.P., Its Not Just the Message
description: The battering that Republican candidates suffered in 2012  particularly among women and minorities  seems finally to have worked its way into the partys cerebral cortex. For weeks, party leaders like Eric Cantor have talked about broadening the partys appeal, and on Monday, Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, unveiled a lengthy report that took the party to task for alienating large segments of the public.

title: House Ethics Panel Finds Cause to Investigate 2 Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  The House Ethics Committee has found credible evidence that two lawmakers  a Republican from Alaska and a Democrat from New Jersey  improperly used campaign money for personal expenses, among other abuses.

title: Solid as a Rock
description: In the rarefied world of haute couture jewelry, Taffins designer James de Givenchy offers a unique combination of elegance and edginess. Its a mix he loves, and lives by.

title: The Revolt of the (Republican) Elites
description: The Republican National Committees extended autopsy on the G.O.P.s 2012 defeat, which officially abjures policy recommendations but then goes on to nudge the party toward supporting comprehensive immigration reform and gay marriage, is the highest-profile distillation of what I described last week as the donorist view of how the Republican Party needs to change. As Ramesh Ponnuru suggests, this the party elites vision of domestic policy reform, reflecting the views of people who are already more likely to favor same-sex marriage and comprehensive immigration reform on principle, and who dont tend to have any major problems with the Republican economic agenda and do not believe it needs to be rethought in any serious way. Or to put it another way: If you believe that Mitt Romneys economic platform and you built that rhetoric would be the basis for a durable majority if they werent associated with the religious right and anti-immigration sentiment, then this is the vision of Republican reform for you.

title: MSNBC Announces Replacement for Chris Hayes
description: MSNBC on Tuesday named Steve Kornacki the new host of Up, a weekend morning panel discussion program that is about to be vacated by its original host, Chris Hayes.

title: A Closer Look at Obamas Plan to Pay for Energy Research With Drilling Fees
description: As was discussed here last Friday, President Obama has proposed using a tiny portion of federal revenues from offshore oil and gas production to build an Energy Security Trust to pay for the kinds of tough or longer-term energy research projects that the private sector tends to neglect. (A White House explanatory graphic is here.)

title: Former Governor Advances in South Carolina Race
description: The first chapter in a wild race to fill a Congressional seat in South Carolina was written Tuesday when former Gov. Mark Sanford staged something of a comeback in a Republican field crowded with 16 candidates, and Democrats overwhelmingly picked Elizabeth Colbert Busch, a businesswoman on leave from Clemson University.

title: Little Resistance on the Heats Path
description: BOSTON  LeBron James could not be slowed by the personal demons that once haunted him in the most hostile of N.B.A. arenas, or by the ghosts of famous Celtics past, or by a 43-point scorer suitably named Green.

title: College Groups Connect to Fight Sexual Assault
description: Frustrated and angry over the handling of sexual assault cases at Occidental College in Los Angeles, a group of students and faculty members recently decided to take the matter to the federal government as a civil rights case. Few people had explored this legal terrain, so the Occidental group reached out to women at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who had filed a similar complaint  which this month prompted a federal investigation  for insights on how to press their case.

title: European Art Fair May Join With Sothebys for Chinese Sales
description: In what might seem like a pairing of competitive bedfellows, the organizers of the European Fine Art Fair  that 10-day event going on through Sunday in Maastricht, the Netherlands  announced on Tuesday that they were in talks with Sothebys about holding a high-end art and antiques fair in China. The new event, which would be called Tefaf Beijing 2014, would be planned as a collaboration between Maastricht, the Netherlands-based event, and Sothebys recently forged joined venture with Chinas state-owned Beijing Ge-Hua Cultural Development Group, the European Fine Art Fair said in an e-mail.

title: Charges Upgraded in Hit-Run Crash That Killed Couple
description: A grand jury has indicted the driver accused in a fatal hit-and-run crash this month on new charges of second-degree manslaughter, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Tuesday.

title: A SWAT Team for Waterlogged Artwork
description: THE patient was in rough shape.

title: Inviting Tropical Fruits to Stick Around
description: The exotic tastes of tropical fruit evoke an endless summer of ocean breezes, sandy beaches and drinks with umbrellas. But just like their colder-climate cousins (say, blueberries and peaches), these fruits have their season.

title: Justices Permit Resale of Copyrighted Imports
description: WASHINGTON  In a pair of decisions issued on Tuesday, the Supreme Court made it easier to import textbooks and other copyrighted products from abroad and made it harder for plaintiffs in class-action suits to stay out of federal court.

title: An Interior Design Showroom Featuring Lalique Maison
description: Lalique has unveiled an interior design showroom in New York featuring Lalique Maison, a collection of furniture and accessories by Tina Green and Pietro Mingarelli. Lady Green is the wife of the British billionaire Sir Philip Green and the creative director of Argent, an interior design firm with offices in London and Monaco. She took on Lalique Maison after Silvio Denz, the chairman of Lalique, toured a yacht she had outfitted with a generous number of his products.

title: Living in the Columbia Street Waterfront District
description: The lively Brooklyn neighborhood lies west of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway, bound by it and a working harbor.

title: Between the Drink and the B.Q.E.
description: A cynic might call this Mosesville. Ever since the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel were built in the 1940s, courtesy of the powerful city planner Robert Moses, the semi-industrial strip of South Brooklyn now called the Columbia Street Waterfront District has been a skinny, scruffy island of a neighborhood cut off from adjacent areas.

title: Ducks Re-Sign Perry
description: Scratch Corey Perrys name off the list of trade rumors as the N.H.L.s April 3 deadline approaches. Anaheim signed Perry to an eight-year, $69 million contract extension late Monday night.

title: No Silver Bullet for Reaching Fuel and Emissions Goals, Study Says
description: The United States could possibly achieve the goal of an 80 percent reduction in oil use and greenhouse gas emissions from cars and small trucks by 2050, but it will not be easy, a National Research Council report said.

title: Say Goodbye to the Assault Weapons Ban
description: Fans of military-style assault weapons can stop worrying  their gun lobby has done its work, and all but assured that Congress will not pass a ban on their dangerous toys.

title: Decision Point: Understanding the U.S.s Dilemma Over North Korea
In Mayors Race, Sources of Contributions Shift
description: #nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1{position:relative;width:480px;height:495px;}.nytg-aiAbs{position:absolute;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 p{font-family:arial,helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:13px;line-height:18px;margin:0;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle0 {font-size:12px;line-height:16px;padding-bottom:3px;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle1 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;text-transform:uppercase;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle2 {font-size:11px;line-height:8px;text-transform:uppercase;text-align:center;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle3 {font-size:11px;line-height:8px;text-transform:uppercase;text-align:right;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle4 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;color:#231f20;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle5 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;font-weight:bold;text-transform:uppercase;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle6 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;text-align:center;color:#231f20;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle7 {font-size:10px;line-height:8px;text-align:right;color:#020200;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle8 {font-size:10px;line-height:8px;color:#020200;}

title: Malones Minority Report
description: John C. Malone has slipped through the door again. The American cable magnate is buying 27 percent of Charter Communications from three buyout firms for $2.6 billion. Hes no garden-variety minority owner, though. Even heavyweights like Rupert Murdoch and Barry Diller can attest to Mr. Malones cunning use of smaller stakes. Charter investors should keep their guards up.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: More Injuries for Knicks, but the News Isnt All Bad
description: The Knicks issued two more injury updates Tuesday, involving a bulging disk, a stress reaction and a stress fracture. In the context of this freakishly painful Knicks season, it practically qualified as a good-news report.

title: Off Broadway Theater To Be Named After Lynn Redgrave
description: The Culture Projects main stage theater at 45 Bleecker Street is being renamed the Lynn Redgrave Theater to honor the British actress, who died in 2010.

title: Senator Is Angry Over Bills Exclusion of Assault Gun Ban
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who 35 years ago discovered the bullet-riddled body of the gay activist Harvey Milk, reacted with anger on Tuesday that gun control legislation the Senate is to consider next month will not include the reinstatement of an assault weapons ban, a measure she had fought desperately to keep.

title: By The Numbers
description: We chart the success of the architect Peter Marino, who has been riding high since his work for Barneys New York twenty years ago.

title: Lizard Olympics
description: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvards Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

title: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
description: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Timess Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the mens basketball tournament.

title: U.S. Said to Look Into Microsoft Bribery Allegations
description: SEATTLE  Federal authorities are examining Microsofts involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry.

title: Michelle Shocked Draws Fire for Anti-Gay Remarks
description: Michelle Shocked, the punk folk-singer, liberal activist and born-again Christian, has drawn fire for an anti-gay tirade in San Francisco over the weekend, during which she said God hates homosexuals.

title: Turning Down a Deposit Tax
description: The Timess Liz Alderman discusses next steps after Cyprus rejects a proposed bailout for its troubled banks.

title: This Weeks Links
description: This is a weekly series in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

title: Photo Replay: March 19
description: A view of the day in sports, including wrestling in Tbilisi, Georgia, and curling in Riga, Latvia.

title: Baked Beans With Pomegranate Molasses, Walnuts and Chard
description: This Iranian-inspired rendition of baked beans is sweetened with pomegranate molasses, which you can find in Middle Eastern markets.

title: Leader of the Pack
description: Twenty years ago, the architect Peter Marino vaulted onto the style worlds A-list with his limestone-clad design for the Barneys New York flagship, helping ignite a mania for luxurious retail environments that endures to this day. Hundreds of boutiques later, for clients like Louis Vuitton and Dior, Marino has nearly doubled his business in the last two years and is riding higher than ever  more often than not on a Harley-Davidson.

title: Black-Eyed Pea Soup or Stew With Pomegranate and Chard
description: This is another dish inspired by a recipe in Louisa Shafias book The New Persian Kitchen. You can use more or less water, depending on whether you want the dish to have the consistency of a soup or a thick stew. Its hearty, and the most beautiful pink hue.

title: Statue of Liberty to Reopen by July 4
description: Updated, 4:52 p.m. | The Statue of Liberty, which has been closed to visitors since Hurricane Sandy struck and open for only one day since the fall of 2011, will reopen by the Fourth of July holiday, federal officials said Tuesday.

title: Snedeker Plans a Return at the Arnold Palmer
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The fastest starter out of the gate in 2013 returns to action at the Arnold Palmer Invitational this week after spending the past five weeks on his couch in Nashville.

title: Rebutting the Contention That Small Is Better for Banks
description: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm Paul Hastings and is writing The Crisis Not Wasted  The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.s First Five Hundred Days, a book on the creation of modern financial regulation during President Franklin Roosevelts first term of office.

title: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
description: FiveThirtyEights Nate Silver spoke with Megan Liberman on Tuesday about our forecast for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, strategies to win your tournament pool and the end of the overwhelming favorite in college hoops.

title: Record Ticket Sales for Bowie Exhibition in London
description: LONDON  David Bowie Is, a major retrospective of the British singers career and cultural influence, which opens at the Victoria and Albert Museum on Saturday, has sold over 42,000 advance tickets, more than double the amount generated by any previous exhibition at the museum.

title: Large White Bean, Tuna and Spinach Salad
description: You could use canned cannellini beans for this, but I love the size and texture of large white limas. I dont soak limas because the skins tend to detach and the beans fall apart when you cook them. You want them intact for this, but you also need to make sure to cook them all the way through.

title: The Retro-Lean-Back Snow Day
description: Its a snow day here.

title: Judge Sets Court Date in Spider-Man Trial
description: A federal judge has set a May 28 trial date for the director Julie Taymor, Bono and the Edge of U2, and the producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark to battle in court over a lawsuit stemming from the spectacular implosion of their years-long collaboration on the show.

title: Wheelies: The Make-Some-Noise Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Actresss Suit Against IMDb for Publishing Her Actual Age Can Go to Trial
description: LOS ANGELES  Junie Hoang, the actress who sued Amazon and its Internet Movie Database unit for posting her age, can take her complaint  or at least some of it  to a jury.

title: The House That Generosity Built: Staten Island Little League Plans Opener
description: Opening Day arrives two weeks late for Staten Island Little League this season, but after Hurricane Sandys knockdown pitch, having any season is cause for celebration.

title: Guggenheim Gets Grant to Commission Chinese Art
description: For years now the Guggenheim Museum has been broadening its scope far beyond the Western world to places like South and Southeast Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and North Africa. Now it is extending its reach even further, embracing the art of China.

title: Front Burner
description: To Shop: Chocolate for You, Coffee for Me

title: If Those Dusty Common Rooms Could Talk ...
description: Alison, in her 40s now, is having straight vodka with a former beau in a room that looks like the Harvard Club. They say if you marry money, you earn every cent of it, she observes.

title: Hit Men and Hurt Lovers Meet Minnesota Nice
description: A pair of sweet Scandinavian hit men in Minnesota grill a young woman under bright lights while serving her elderberry wine. In flashback, the woman talks to a new friend at a bar  about the weather, horses and the men who recently did them wrong.

title: Chez Sardine
description: Inside the restaurant where stoner Asian food meets fat-on-fat cuisine.

title: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Vatican, Argentina, Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Journalism Professor Sues Columbia, Claiming Misuse of Endowment Funds
description: A tenured professor at Columbias Graduate School of Journalism and co-director of that schools business program filed a lawsuit on Tuesday accusing the university of misdirecting $4.5 million in funds over the last decade.

title: 2 Cuisines, Both Full of Themselves
description: ONE MAJOR THEME of modern restaurants is what we might call Asian stoner food. This is the cuisines of Japan, Korea and other places as seen through bloodshot eyes, the cravings of a hipster whose late-night munchies send him out in search of tacos stuffed with bulgogi, pigs tails cooked in root beer and the like.

title: Panic in Cyprus
description: It comes as no surprise that the Parliament of Cyprus on Tuesday voted down a terrible plan to tax insured bank deposits as part of a deal to rescue its failing financial system. The countrys leaders and policy makers in Europe will now have to go back to the drawing board.

title: Mars Rover Is Repaired, NASA Says
description: A NASA official said Tuesday that engineers had resolved the latest problem with the Curiosity rover on Mars and that the laboratory-on-wheels should resume science operations this week after a three-week delay.

title: Revealing a Lot, Aromatic and Otherwise
description: The scent, my God: it is so indecent,"said the author and perfume blogger Denyse Beaulieu from Paris. She was speaking of Shocking, the 1937 Elsa Schiaparelli perfume dressed in hot pink: the original version, not a later reformulation.

title: Wistful Reflections but Very Few Regrets
description: It was fantastic! It was fantastic! Beyond belief!

title: Pop-Up Hotels: Rooms With a Fleeting View
description: POP-UP STORES. Pop-up restaurants. Pop-up lounges. Shouldnt this fascination with pop-ups  which are by definition ephemeral  have disappeared already?

title: Hotel Review: Pousada de Cascais in Cascais, Portugal
description: Rates

title: The Doctor Is In (Well, Logged In)
description: Surfing the Web in his all-white Dumbo loft, Dr. Jay Parkinson, 37, looks like any other young tech visionary. He has a trim beard and thick-framed glasses. He wears slim-fitting black outfits and jaunty scarves. He speaks with a measured, This American Life-like cadence. And hes a firm believer in the utopian promise of the Internet.

title: City Approves 700-Unit Rental Complex on Gowanus Canal
description: Gritty and offbeat as its reputation is, the Gowanus Canal may, in a few years, start becoming more bourgeois.

title: The Sound of Tango, the Story of Mary
description: There was no piano in Astor Piazzollas vacation home in Parque del Plata, Uruguay, where he spent the summer of 1968 working with the poet Horacio Ferrer on an operita, a little opera, so he composed on the bandonen.
