The resulting work, Mara de Buenos Aires, is an intense cocktail of poetry, tango music and dance that is performed by a folk contralto, an operatic baritone and one male actor. But its the fourth voice  the bandonen, the soulful South American accordion  that calls the shots and, to borrow Ferrers words, burns in the back of your throat.

title: Tongue-in-Cheek Commentary, With Arms and Legs
description: Paul Taylor made his dance Scudorama 50 years ago. After 10 years it fell out of his troupes repertory, not to be revived until 2007. Leading the matinee program on Saturday during the companys three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater, the work retained its odd fascination.

title: Building a Narrative Thats Explosive
description: In 2010 Tom Bissell  author of seven books, contributor to publications like The New Yorker and Harpers Magazine, darling of book reviewers who compare him to writers like Wells Tower and John Jeremiah Sullivan  announced that he was going to go game, in the way that prominent writers go Hollywood, in search of bigger paychecks and the challenges of a new form.

title: San Francisco Symphony Strike Darkens Halls
description: Carnegie Hall will remain dark on this Wednesday and Thursday evenings. Ditto the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark on Friday and the Kennedy Center Concert Hall in Washington on Saturday.

title: Crustacean Elation
description: The Red Hook Lobster Pound finally opened its doors in March after sustaining massive damage from flooding during Hurricane Sandy.

title: As ARM Chief Steps Down, Successor Talks About Body Computing
description: ARM Holdings, the specialist in low-power semiconductors, is looking to put computers everywhere around us, and even inside us.

title: Before Obama Trip, Polls Find Sympathy With Israel, and Doubts on Peace
description: New polls released just ahead of President Obamas trip to Israel this week find that Americans continue to sympathize more with Israel than with the Palestinians. But few want the United States to take a leading role in resolving the conflict there, and most do not anticipate that the trip will do much to ease regional tensions.

title: Businesses Return to the Neighborhood, and the People Follow
description: Crocuses are peeping out of tree pits in Red Hook, Brooklyn, once drowned by a briny soup of seawater and diesel fuel. At the newly reopened Fairway supermarket, bright piles of lemons, tomatoes and oranges pop almost luridly. Kevins, a beloved seafood restaurant, has a shiny new wood floor and a new bar built out of donated marble, and across the way in the back of the Red Hook Lobster Pound, gutted by Hurricane Sandy and since rebuilt, sits a shiny new deep fryer, a veritable symbol of marital compromise and rebirth.

title: The Best Easter Hams
description: The Dining section tasting panel tried a variety of hams that were wet cured, smoked over wood and minimally processed. Here are the results.

title: How to Pick an Easter Ham
description: I do not come from ham-eating people.

title: Playing at New Directors/New Films
description: Images of select films screening in the festival.

title: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
description: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Timess Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the mens basketball tournament.

title: More From The Times, and Elsewhere, on the 10th Anniversary of the Iraq War
description: I wrote Monday about The Timess relatively low-key approach to covering the Iraq wars 10th anniversary, contrasting it to more robust efforts in The Guardian and to its own efforts on the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: Eisenhower Memorial in Criticism Barrage
description: WASHINGTON  Simmering conflict over a $142 million memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower designed by the architect Frank Gehry for the National Mall here erupted into the open on Tuesday at a Congressional hearing on the future of the project.

title: West 22nd Street, 4:51 P.M.
True Story Inspires Tale of Sex Trade; in a Twist, a U.S. Marshal Is the Bad Guy
description: Enough films about human trafficking have been made in recent years that the outlines of Eden should be painfully familiar. But that familiarity doesnt cushion this movies excruciating vision of under-age women conscripted into sexual slavery by a criminal enterprise from which there is seemingly no escape.

title: Early Favorites in a Showcase for New Filmmakers
description: Killers and clowns, the quick and the dead roam through New Directors/New Films, the annual showcase of promising and confirmed cinematic talent that begins on Wednesday. Now in its 42nd year, the series was established to present work from emerging filmmakers from across the globe back when such festivals were rare. A joint venture of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, where all the screenings will be held, it remains a laudatory New York event.

title: A Model for Reducing Emissions
description: Who would have thought the United States would one day be a leader in cutting greenhouse gas emissions?

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Smart Shoes and the Top Social Network Among Teens
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Brazilian Billionaire Confirms Talks to Sell Stake in Energy Firm
description: SO PAULO, Brazil The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista confirmed on Tuesday that he was negotiating to sell part of his stake in MPX, his natural gas and electricity generation company that has over $3 billion in debt and several generation projects running behind schedule.

title: Israels Animated Diplomacy
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, 8:02 p.m. On the eve of President Obamas visit to the Middle East, Israels embassy in Washington rolled out the cartoon red carpet, in the form of an animated YouTube clip apparently designed to make light of reported tension between the two countries leaders.

title: Real Fur, Masquerading as Faux
description: The Stuart Weitzman ballet flats from Neiman Marcus sported sweet faux fur pom-poms. The Alice and Olivia coat was trimmed with a dark faux fur collar.

title: Online Comments in Ohio Rape Case Lead to Charges Against Two
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio  The rape trial that concluded here on Sunday with the conviction of two high school football stars has spurred calls in many quarters for expanding  or more aggressively enforcing  the legal obligations of those who know about a sexual assault, or who could be in a position to prevent one.

title: France: Court Says Head Scarf Is No Grounds for Firing
description: Frances highest court ruled Tuesday that a French Muslim woman was unjustly fired in 2008 for wearing a head scarf at work in a private child-care center in a Paris suburb. The court ruled that the dismissal violated the womans religious freedom. Religious symbols of all kinds are banned from public schools and institutions under French law, but the child-care center is private. The ruling overturned an appeals court decision, which had said the center had the right to set its own rules about religious neutrality. Interior Minister Manuel Valls told Parliament that the courts ruling was regrettable because it calls into question the principle of secular education.

title: Michigan States Toughness Starts With Its Nonconference Schedule
description: CHICAGO  Mark Montgomery never noticed this about Tom Izzo. Not that he could. Between playing for Michigan State when Izzo was an assistant, then serving as an Izzo assistant for 10 seasons until 2011, Montgomery had too much else going on to scrutinize Izzos sideline mannerisms.

title: Massachusetts: M.I.T. Will Release Documents in Hacking Case
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Tuesday announced that it would release documents related to the case against Aaron Swartz, the Internet activist who committed suicide in January, about a month before he was to go to trial on charges that he illegally downloaded academic articles from the universitys computer network. In a letter to the M.I.T. community, the university president, L. Rafael Reif, said lawyers for Mr. Swartz had requested in federal court that the institution make evidence related to the case public. Mr. Reif said M.I.T. planned to release those documents, with some information redacted, when it completed an investigation led by a computer science professor, Hal Abelson, into the universitys role in the case. Professor Abelson said in late January that he hoped to complete the investigation within a few weeks.

title: Ohio: Teenage Killer Gets Life
description: A defiant 18-year-old was sentenced Tuesday to spend the rest of his life in prison for a 2012 shooting at a high school cafeteria in Chardon, where he killed three students and wounded three others. Wearing a T-shirt with the word killer printed on it, T. J. Lane directed an obscene statement and gesture toward family members of the shooting victims when asked for a statement. He pleaded guilty last month to three counts of aggravated murder, two counts of attempted aggravated murder and one count of assault.

title: Britain: Girl Shot by Taliban Returns to the Classroom
description: Malala Yousafzai, the 15-year-old Pakistani campaigner for girls education who was gravely wounded by the Taliban in October, is back in school for the first time since the attack, according to a statement by her family. Ms. Yousafzai, shown with her father, is now enrolled full time at Edgbaston, a private girls high school in Birmingham, England, where her family now lives and where she underwent extensive medical treatment in recent months. I miss my classmates from Pakistan very much, but I am looking forward to meeting my teachers and making new friends here in Birmingham, she was quoted as saying in the statement.

title: Court Announces Early Release of Same-Sex Marriage Arguments
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court announced on Tuesday that it would release same-day audio recordings of oral arguments in two same-sex marriage cases scheduled to be heard next week.

title: Ian McKellen to Lead Wedding for Patrick Stewart
description: Sir Ian McKellen has announced that he will be officiating at the wedding ceremony of Sir Patrick Stewart, 72, and Sunny Ozell, 35, a singer and songwriter whom Mr. Stewart met in 2008 when he was performing in a production of Macbeth at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Jane Goodall Admits Borrowing Passages for New Book
description: A forthcoming book by Jane Goodall, the primatologist known for her research on chimpanzees, contains passages taken from Web sites without attribution, according to a published report.

title: Put Cigarettes Out of View? Its Been Tried
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg this week announced his latest salvo against smoking, his press office put out a news flash: City Would Be First in Nation to Keep Tobacco Products Out of Sight.

title: For Some Palestinians, Wariness on Eve of Obama Visit
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  There are no American flags lining the streets here, no banners bearing the official Unbreakable Alliance logo of President Obamas visit, as there are seven miles away in Jerusalem. Instead, dozens of posters warn the president not to bring his smartphone when he arrives in the West Bank because there is no 3G service, one of an untold number of complaints Palestinians have about their life under Israeli occupation.

title: N.R.C. Votes for Upgrades to Some Reactor Vents
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3 to 2 on Tuesday to require improvements to the emergency vents at 31 American reactors that share design similarities with the Japanese reactors that melted down two years ago. The agency stopped short, however, of requiring filters to scrub out radioactive particles coming through those vents.

title: Praising Griner Proves Far Easier Than Stopping Her
description: WACO, Tex.  Just in case anyone doubted Baylors confident intent to reach the womens Final Four in New Orleans, Coach Kim Mulkey wore a fleur-de-lis on her T-shirt as she watched the tournament pairings, while some fans wore Mardi Gras beads and sang, When the Saints Go Marching In.

title: Deal in Albany Would Extend Higher Taxes on Top Earners
description: ALBANY  Congress dodged the so-called fiscal cliff in part by raising taxes on high incomes. California voters addressed their states school budget troubles with a surcharge on big incomes. And now Albany has decided to raise revenue with a high income tax rate for people with seven-figure incomes.

title: StubHub Barred Near Yankee Stadium, for Now
description: The Yankees won a court order Tuesday temporarily preventing StubHub from opening a store near Yankee Stadium that is designed to allow customers to pick up their tickets before games.

title: Teenage Gunman in Ohio Mocks Victims Families
description: Thomas Lane wore a T-shirt with KILLER scrawled in black ink during his sentencing Tuesday in an Ohio courtroom for shooting and killing three students in a high school cafeteria and wounding two others last year.

title: A Decade Later, Stability Eludes Iraq
description: The first American bombs and missiles to hit Baghdad were four 2,000-pound bunker-busters dropped by two F-117 Nighthawk fighter-bombers and 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles, a thunderous volley aimed at killing Saddam Hussein and his two sons in a secret underground redoubt beside the Tigris River known as Dora Farms. The impacts, some missing their targets, came soon after first light on March 19, 2003.

title: JPMorgan Chase Is Reining In Payday Lenders
description: JPMorgan Chase will make changes to protect consumers who have borrowed money from a rising power on the Internet  payday lenders offering short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.

title: Banning the Big Gulp Ban
description: Neither I nor anyone else Ive read on last weeks judicial stay of New York Citys Big Gulp Ban is a lawyer. (We call it the Big Gulp Ban, though in fact it famously would not have banned 7-Elevens massive drinks.) But I doubt that our Board of Health was being capricious or arbitrary  those were the words of the ruling justice, Milton A. Tingling  when it decided last September, by a vote of 8 to 0 (you read that right), to forbid the sale, where it could, of super-size sugary drinks. (From this point on Ill just call them soda.)

title: 2nd Vote for Closing Long Island College Hospital
description: The board of the State University of New York voted on Tuesday, for the second time in several weeks, to close Long Island College Hospital, which was taken over by the university system two years ago, and which university officials say is losing $1 million a week.

title: A War, Before and After, Part 4
description: This is the fourth part of a six-part series.

title: Iraq Wars 10th Anniversary Is Barely Noted in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  A decade after the night that American bombs first rained down on Baghdad, the president joked about wearing a green tie for a belated St. Patricks Day celebration. Congress noisily focused on whether spending cuts would force the cancellation of the White House Easter egg roll. Cable news debated whether a show about young women has too much sex in it.

title: Ryan Tiptoes Around a Revis Question
description: PHOENIX  Jets Coach Rex Ryan, speaking at the A.F.C. coaches breakfast on Tuesday, perhaps played a game of semantics when he said that the Jets are not actively trying to trade cornerback Darrelle Revis, even as he acknowledged that the team would listen to offers.

title: Renovation Pays Off for a Chelsea Nonprofit
description: When the New York Foundling, one of the citys largest and oldest child welfare agencies, completes a $5.5 million renovation of its Chelsea headquarters this summer, it will squeeze more workers into less space and lease its top three floors, bringing in substantial revenue.

title: Developers Are Making Bets on a Rising East Harlem
description: Sharon Kahen and his partner Haim Levi are making a multimillion-dollar bet on East Harlem. The developers recently closed on a vacant parcel at 119th Street and Third Avenue where they plan to build a 60-unit market-rate rental building.

title: Joel Breitkopf
description: Mr. Breitkopf, 48, is a principal of Alchemy Properties, which specializes in boutique residential developments.

title: Britains Press Crackdown
description: In an attempt to rein in its reckless tabloid newspapers, Britains three main political parties this week agreed to impose unwieldy regulations on the news media that would chill free speech and threaten the survival of small publishers and Internet sites.

title: In Shift, Lobbyists Look for Bipartisan Support to Repeal a Tax
description: WASHINGTON  When executives from Cook Medical gathered last month to offer Representative Cheri Bustos a tour of their central Illinois medical equipment plant, they had good reason to expect a frosty reception from Ms. Bustos, a new Democratic congresswoman.

title: Was It Worth It?
A Decade of Despair
description: Baghdad

title: What America Learned in Iraq
description: Annapolis, Md.

title: Iraq: Where Terrorists Go to School
description: IRAQ, President George W. Bush said in 2003, was a central front in the war on terrorism. He was wrong, but prescient. Iraq has become a front for militant extremism  a front the United States created.

title: Sectarian Strains Pit Some Iraqis Against Their Own Leaders
description: RAMADI, Iraq  As Rafe al-Essawi, the embattled Sunni leader, sped south on a desert highway last week to attend the funeral of a political ally who was assassinated, his cellphone rang with a warning: Up ahead, Iraqi soldiers, backed by two helicopters hovering overhead, planned to arrest him.

title: Francis Ruddle, Who Led Transgenic Research, Dies at 83
description: Francis Ruddle, a Yale University geneticist who plumbed the DNA of mice and men, and from whose laboratory sprang the first transgenic mammal  a mouse with added foreign DNA  died on March 10 in New Haven. He was 83.

title: In a New Aisle, Energy Drinks Sidestep Some Rules
description: Fans of Monster Energy, the popular high-caffeine energy drink, may not notice the change: its ingredients will be the same and its familiar label bearing a green, clawlike monogram will change only slightly. But the drinks maker has decided after a decade of selling it as a dietary supplement to market it as a beverage, a switch that will bring significant changes in how it is regulated.

title: Democrats, Dragons or Drones?
description: On this 10th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq, three things are clear. First, whatever happens in Iraq, we overpaid for it in lives and treasure and focus. Second, you can overpay for something decent and you can overpay for total junk. What exactly we overpaid for in Iraq is not yet clear and will be decided by Iraqis. Third, as much as wed prefer to forget about Iraq, what happens there matters more than ever for the Middle East.

title: Ten Years After
description: Ten years after it began, the Iraq war still haunts the United States in the nearly 4,500 troops who died there; the more than 30,000 American wounded who have come home; the more than $2 trillion spent on combat operations and reconstruction, which inflated the deficit; and in the lessons learned about the limits of American leadership and power.

title: Murrey Marder, Early McCarthy Skeptic, Dies at 93
description: By certain journalistic lights, the reporter Murrey Marder was an editors nightmare. He wrote slowly and squeezed against deadlines. He debated with editors. His articles were long, often complicated and never laid claim to stylish writing.

title: Damage From Derailment to Slow L.I.R.R. Trains for Days
description: There will be minor delays and some cancellations of Long Island Rail Road trains until at least Friday, officials said, citing extensive damage that was caused by a train derailment.

title: Genetically Modified Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemency for Pollard, Jailed as a Spy for Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Affirmative Action: Looking at the Data
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Newspapers
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Mar. 20, 2013
description: I came in here as a 30-something with kids, a mother who was alive. This case killed my whole life.

title: Justices Explore Fine Line on Generic Drug Injuries
description: WASHINGTON  In 2010, a New Hampshire jury awarded Karen Bartlett $21 million for the ordeal she endured from taking a generic pain pill for an aching shoulder. It caused two-thirds of her skin to slough off, damaged her lungs and esophagus and rendered her legally blind.

title: On Gay Unions, a Pragmatist Before He Was a Pope
description: BUENOS AIRES  The very idea was anathema to many of the bishops in the room.

title: G.O.P. Opposition to Immigration Law Is Falling Away
description: WASHINGTON  Republican opposition to legalizing the status of millions of illegal immigrants is crumbling in the nations capital as leading lawmakers in the party scramble to halt eroding support among Hispanic voters  a shift that is providing strong momentum for an overhaul of immigration laws.

title: Used to Baghdads Battles, and Adjusting to New Yorks Bustle
description: In his first 48 hours in the Bronx, Omar al-Mashhadani caught a few echoes of the life that he and his family had left behind in Baghdad. Thousands of people were swarming along 161st Street, toward the hulking stadium on the other side of the El on River Avenue.

title: Protecting Their Own, Russians Offer an Alternative to the Cypriot Bank Tax
description: MOSCOW  When the European Union said it would bail out Cypriot banks by seizing a percentage of deposits, Cypriots erupted. Russian government officials also raged, on behalf of Cypruss many Russian depositors.

title: For Steinbrenner and Yankees, a Commitment to a New Order
description: For Yankee fans hoping Brian Cashman will trade a prospect or two to get a player like Justin Morneau from the Minnesota Twins to play first base until Mark Teixeira returns  if he returns  this season from a wrist injury, it might be useful to hear some recent comments from Hal Steinbrenner.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Fun House Cries
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  And now, directly from the Heavy Lifting Department: todays puzzle by Raymond C. Young, which is the first quadruple pangram SQUISHed inside a 15 x 15 grid.

title: Back in Connecticut, DiPietro Is Trying to Remain Positive
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  As the final buzzer sounded Sunday, Rick DiPietro looked toward the rafters, raised his gloved right hand in triumph and hugged his teammates.

title: Early Days of the Iraq War on The Timess Front Pages
description: A look at how The New York Times covered the initial, often confusing accounts of the American-led invasion in Iraq.

title: Father Describes Behavior of Son Accused of Murder
description: After enduring years of his sons bizarre behavior, Leonard Tarloff had grown accustomed to the alarming phone calls that indicated that something was once again amiss.

title: Using Sponsored Content to Keep Viewers Watching
description: TELEVISION networks and channels are becoming increasingly involved in the creation of commercials that appear during their shows, hoping to counter the growing penchant among viewers for zapping or zipping through conventional commercials.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 19, 2013

title: Melanoma Drug Succeeds in Late-Stage Trial
description: A cancer drug based on a tumor-killing virus has for the first time succeeded in a late-stage clinical trial, giving a lift to a technology that has long tantalized doctors and researchers.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Iraqs Fragile Future
description: When President Obama withdrew the last combat troops from Iraq in 2011, Iraqis became responsible for their own future. They continue to face political strife, sectarian violence and corruption and mismanagement. As a country in transition in the volatile Middle East, it still merits sustained American interest.

title: Cyprus Bailout Promises Crucial Test for Germany
description: BERLIN  The divisive international bailout deal for Cyprus, with its heavy burden for individual savers, has emerged as a potentially decisive test for the German-led push for discipline and austerity in the currency union.

title: Both Needing a Win, the Rangers Top the Devils
description: NEWARK  Last spring the Rangers and the Devils stood at the pinnacle of the East, battling in the conference finals for a chance at the Stanley Cup. On Tuesday night they stood at a far more modest place  along the playoff cut line  battling to salvage what has been a mediocre season for both teams.

title: Bishops Challenge Cuomo on Stronger Abortion Rights
description: ALBANY  As Roman Catholics worldwide celebrated the inauguration of Pope Francis, New York bishops traveled to Albany on Tuesday to meet with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose looming effort to strengthen abortion rights in the state has met with strong protests from Catholic and evangelical clergy.

title: Campaign Diets
description: On the campaign trail in New York, the path to City Hall leads past hundreds of social events, and thousands of restaurants. Candidates have their own ways of coping with the temptations of food.

title: No Merger for Los Angeles Museum
description: After several weeks of exploring a merger to shore up its weak financial status, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles appears to have decided to try to go it alone, releasing a statement on Tuesday announcing its intention to stay independent.

title: French Minister Steps Down in Swiss Bank Investigation
description: PARIS  Just hours after an announcement that he would be investigated on charges of tax fraud and money laundering, Budget Minister Jrme Cahuzac resigned from the French government on Tuesday evening, though he insisted he had done nothing wrong.

title: Next Campaign Stop: The Third Lunch Today
description: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, was greeting voters at an Upper West Side political club recently when, midschmooze, he picked up a chocolate-frosted doughnut and prepared to help himself to a sizable, sprinkled bite.

title: Administration Official Defends Release of Detainees
description: Under fierce questioning from Republicans at a hearing in the House of Representatives, the top Obama administration official in charge of immigration enforcement insisted Tuesday that the release of more than 2,200 immigrants from detention in February was solely a budgetary savings measure, and he disputed accusations that they had included many dangerous criminals.

title: Subway Worker Freed After Hours Stuck in Mud
description: A construction worker on the Second Avenue subway project who became stuck in mud up to his waist in a 75-foot-deep tunnel on Tuesday night was freed early Wednesday morning in a four-hour rescue involving more than 100 emergency workers, the authorities said.

title: Minority Groups Remain Outnumbered at Teaching Programs, Study Reports
description: Despite major changes in the racial makeup of American public school students, the people training to be teachers are still predominantly white.

title: Police Department Monitor Is Topic at a Mayoral Forum
description: Two central characters recurred in the Tuesday night mayoral debate over public safety and the future of the Police Department: one who is real and one who is, at least at this point, still notional.

title: Quest for Illegal Gain at the Sea Bottom Divides Fishing Communities
description: DZILAM DE BRAVO, Mexico  Whispers of high-speed boat chases, harpoon battles on the open sea and divers who dived deep and never re-emerged come and go around here like an afternoon gale.

title: Grocers Wont Sell Altered Fish, Groups Say
description: Several supermarket chains have pledged not to sell what could become the first genetically modified animal to reach the nations dinner plates  a salmon engineered to grow about twice as fast as normal.

title: New Worries About Heading the Soccer Ball
description: Heading a soccer ball can, on the plus side, score goals and impress fans. But it may also adversely affect a players ability to think, a new study of high school soccer players suggests.

title: Word of the Day | nonentity
description: nonentity \nn-en-t-te, -e-n-\ noun

title: At the Final Four, a Routine Sight of Green and White
description: Since 1995, when Tom Izzo became head coach at Michigan State, every incoming class has made at least one trip to the Final Four before graduating.

title: Zimbabwe: Constitution Passes by Wide Margin
description: Voters overwhelmingly approved Zimbabwes new Constitution, the Election Commission announced Tuesday, with more than three million people voting yes and fewer than 200,000 voting no. The new charter replaces the Constitution that has governed Zimbabwe since the end of white minority rule in 1980 and is a crucial step toward holding presidential elections this year to replace an uneasy power-sharing government installed after the violent 2008 election.

title: World-Class Pitching Carries Undefeated Dominicans to Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Horns beeped through the chilly air Tuesday night, and flags flapped through the raindrops. At a ballpark with a statue of Juan Marichal out front, the Dominican Republic reached the pinnacle of international baseball competition.

title: Cleaner Fuel Means Lower Emissions
description: Emissions of CO<sup>2</sup> into the atmosphere have dropped sharply. One of the main reasons has been the replacement of coal with natural gas for power generation.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (Science) THROUGH THE WORMHOLE WITH MORGAN FREEMAN In Is There a God Particle? Mr. Freeman, above, speaks with the scientists Joseph Incandela and Lyn Evans of CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research near Geneva. They discuss recent progress in the search for the Higgs boson, an elementary particle believed to supply mass to other particles.

title: News Quiz | March 20, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: The View From Oshima
description: Locals say Oshima has a better view of Japans most famous peak than anywhere else in the country.

title: David Rantas Statement to Court, 1991
description: Read David Rantas statement to the court when he was remanded on June 10, 1991.

title: Jailed Unjustly in the Death of a Rabbi, Man Nears Freedom
description: In the wintry darkness 23 years ago on a back street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a jewelry thief fleeing a botched robbery panicked and shot a Hasidic rabbi in the head.

title: India Moves Towards Stronger Law to Protect Women
description: Indias lower house of Parliament passed a bill Tuesday intended to better protect women from sex crimes, widely hailed as a step forward in Indias attempt to deter sexual offenders after the fatal gang rape of a young woman in Delhi in December sparked a nationwide movement to improve womens security.

title: China and Japan Spar Over War Trials, More Than 6 Decades On
description: BEIJING  What would international reaction be if Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, were to publicly cast doubt on the fairness of the Nuremberg Trials, which condemned top Nazis at the end of World War II?

title: Indias Foodie Web Sites Bring Gourmet Treats to Delhi Doors
description: With late nights at work the norm and the kirana (corner) stores displaying only shelves of dusty cans and dried beans, urban Delhiites with sophisticated palates are increasingly looking to the Internet to bring the market to them. Many of these sites that feature fresh, organic produce and gourmet products were started by young entrepreneurs who didnt want time constraints get in the way of a good home-cooked meal.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 20
description: NEWS Lawmakers rejected a 10 billion euro bailout package for Cyprus on Tuesday, sending the president back to the drawing board to devise a plan that might enable the country to receive a financial lifeline while avoiding a default that could reignite the euro crisis. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus.

title: Computer Networks in South Korea Are Paralyzed in Cyberattacks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Computer networks running three major South Korean banks and the countrys two largest broadcasters were paralyzed Wednesday in attacks that some experts suspected originated in North Korea, which has consistently threatened to cripple its far richer neighbor.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 20, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the Economix blog post Only Half of First-Time College Students Graduate in 6 Years.

title: Parading on the Edges
description: I love surreal-ness, said Nicole Bengiveno, staff photographer of The New York Times, who photographed the St. Patricks Day parade in New York on Saturday. You have men in skirts, you have people with shamrocks on their faces  I kept snapping pictures of people with these funny hats and green hair. Because theyre just really in the spirit. Followed by the freelance videographer Elaisha Stokes, Ms. Bengiveno demonstrates how, for the parade-going photographer, it is helpful to be drawn to strangeness. After all, if you have photographed as many parades as she has, an eye for the uncommon can be a gift. Likewise, a knack for sticking to the sidelines. I like to stay around the edges, Ms. Bengiveno said. I like the idea of being invisible.

title: Do You Ever Feel Guilty About What, or How Much, You Throw Away?
description: Americans throw away hundreds of millions of tons of trash every year. We throw away spoiled food, old sneakers, unwanted pianos and bulky televisions. Thats a lot of garbage.

title: The 10th Anniversary of the Iraq War
description: In this post we use several different Times pieces to help students understand this anniversary. Each question links to the piece in which an answer can be found.

title: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
description: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blogs Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

title: John Dillingers Terraplane Revisits His Childhood Home
description: An eight-cylinder 1933 Essex-Terraplane briefly used by the notorious bank robber and jail escapee John Dillinger is on display at the Indianapolis International Airport, where, according to airport representatives, it is attracting crowds of visitors.

title: How to Live in Assisted Living
description: Sometimes Martin Bayne speaks in little more than a whisper, like many people with advanced Parkinsons disease. But his voice has a way of carrying.

title: Forgiveness Formulas
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Seeking Lessons From the Iraq War. But Which Ones?
description: WASHINGTON  Stephen J. Hadley, who played a central role in the decision a decade ago to go to war in Iraq, recently described the cascade of misjudgments and inaccurate assumptions inside the Bush White House leading up to the war as a failure of imagination. His explanation of what went wrong is rife with lessons for two crises  one in Syria, another in Iran  that President Obama confronts as he lands in Israel on Wednesday morning.

title: Too Big Not to Fail
description: LISBON  Education policy isnt the Portuguese governments strong suit. There have been 28 education ministers since 1974. Only half of the countrys 25-to-34 year-olds have successfully completed high school; dropout rates are among the highest in Western Europe.

description: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

title: In Israel, Obama Seeks to Offer Reassurance of Unbreakable Bonds
description: JERUSALEM  It took four years and a second term, but President Obama traveled to Israel on Wednesday for a richly symbolic state visit, bearing a message of solidarity to a wary Israeli public, and a promise to defend Israel from threats near and far.

title: Deal Makers Foresee a Feast of Activity, Survey Finds
description: As deal makers prepare to head down to New Orleans for one of the biggest merger conferences of the year, many will do so with a spring in their step.

title: Business for Sale: A Long-Haul Trucking Company
description: Lets take a look at another business for sale. And once again, well consider the business from the point of view of a potential buyer, but we will also see what lessons this business might hold for owners of other businesses.

title: Becoming the All-Terrain Human
description: Kilian Jornet Burgada is the most dominating endurance athlete of his generation. In just eight years, Jornet has won more than 80 races, claimed some 16 titles and set at least a dozen speed records, many of them in distances that would require the rest of us to purchase an airplane ticket. He has run across entire landmasses (Corsica) and mountain ranges (the Pyrenees), nearly without pause. He regularly runs all day eating only wild berries and drinking only from streams. On summer mornings he will set off from his apartment door at the foot of Mont Blanc and run nearly two and a half vertical miles up to Europes roof  over cracked glaciers, past Gore-Texd climbers, into the thin air at 15,781 feet  and back home again in less than seven hours, a trip that mountaineers can spend days to complete. A few years ago Jornet ran the 165-mile Tahoe Rim Trail and stopped just twice to sleep on the ground for a total of about 90 minutes. In the middle of the night he took a wrong turn, which added perhaps six miles to his run. He still finished in 38 hours 32 minutes, beating the record of Tim Twietmeyer, a legend in the world of ultrarunning, by more than seven hours. When he reached the finish line, he looked as if hed just won the local turkey trot.

title: Happy International Happiness Day
description: LONDON  If you want to avoid the risk of being accosted by total strangers urging you to be happy, you should probably stay home on Wednesday.

title: American Realty Capital Offers to Buy Cole Credit for $5.7 Billion
description: American Realty Capital Properties said on Wednesday that it had offered to buy Cole Credit Property Trust III for $5.7 billion, in a deal that would create one of the biggest publicly traded real estate investment trusts.

title: Daily Report: U.S. Is Said to Scrutinize Microsoft Accusations
description: Federal authorities are examining Microsofts involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry, Nick Wingfield reports in The New York Times.

title: JPMorgans New Policy on Payday Lenders
description: JPMorgan Chase is moving to protect customers whose accounts are tapped by Internet-based payday lenders, planning to give those customers more power to stop withdrawals and close their accounts, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. Under the changes, to be announced on Wednesday, JPMorgan is also limiting the fees it charges customers when the withdrawals trigger penalties.

title: Waiting for Catastrophes: Aleksandar Hemon Talks About The Book of My Lives
description: In 1992, Aleksandar Hemon was visiting Chicago when war broke out in his home country, Bosnia. Chicago became his adopted home, and he soon became a highly praised writer of fiction. In 2004, he received a MacArthur genius grant. Mr. Hemons new book, The Book of My Lives, collects nonfiction pieces about his upbringing in Sarajevo and his life in America. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hemon discussed displacement, visiting Sarajevo now, the purpose of art and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Suntech Unit Declares Bankruptcy
description: HONG KONG  Suntech Power, a Chinese manufacturer that became the worlds largest producer of solar panels by 2011 only to be battered by plummeting prices, announced on Wednesday evening that its main operating subsidiary had been pushed into bankruptcy by eight Chinese banks.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Networks Embrace Content Marketing and Retailers Admit to Faking Faux Fur
description: Television networks and channels are becoming increasingly involved in making commercials, hoping to prevent audiences from skipping ads, Stuart Elliott writes. New efforts at content marketing (also called content advertising and native advertising) have become the norm as networks try to convince marketers to pay more for airtime. Scripps Networks Interactive, the parent of cable channels like DIY, Food Network and Travel Channel, is one of the leaders in the field. Jonathan LaConti, vice president for ad sales at the companys New York office, said that Scripps strives to make commercials that look really natural, particularly if they involve one of the networks hosts.

title: Wednesday Reading: Picking a Flavorful Easter Ham
Heating Oil Companies Face Inquiry on Purity of Fuel
description: State and federal authorities are investigating whether several New York heating oil businesses cheated tens of thousands of customers for years, selling fuel diluted with recycled or waste oil, according to law enforcement and city officials.

title: As Bailout Deadline Approaches, Cyprus Scrambles to Find Funds
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  Scrambling to placate international lenders, Cyprus late Wednesday proposed to nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and conduct an emergency bond sale to help raise the 5.8 billion the indebted country needs to secure a bailout.

title: Voters, Deficits, and Jobs
description: Update: On the other hand, via Greg Sargent, a huge majority of Americans  three quarters!  supports federal spending programs to create jobs. But we know that this is out of the question, because, well, because.

title: In One Simple Tool, Hope for H.I.V. Prevention
description: Two plastic rings, a rubber band, and a thread.

title: Two for the Road
description: With a clever bag and shoe combination, dressing for any destination can be shockingly simple.

title: The Tale of a Transgender 6-Year-Old Child Raises Reader Concerns
description: In Mondays New York Times, an article by the national reporter Dan Frosch examined a Colorado case involving a 6-year-old child, who is biologically male but identifies as a female. The article used the childs name, Coy Mathis, and two color photographs that showed her face clearly.

title: Psychiatric Patient Arrested in Beating Death at a Brooklyn Hospital
description: A 47-year-old psychiatric patient was beaten to death in a locked shower room at Interfaith Medical Center in central Brooklyn late on Tuesday, officials said, and another patient, a 20-year-old, has been charged with second-degree murder in the killing.

title: Joining the Toad Patrols of Britain
description: My latest Green column goes patrolling for toads in Britain. Toads are mostly terrestrial creatures but when they mature at the age of about three they return in early spring to the body of water in which they were born to spawn.

title: Round Trips to Cyprus
description: Still trying to wrap my head around the Cyprus situation; what makes it so interesting (as in may you live in interesting times) is the role of the island as a tax, regulation, and law enforcement haven.

title: Chinese Solar Panel Giant Is Tainted by Bankruptcy
description: HONG KONG  It was the Icarus of the solar power industry. And, on Wednesday, it fell to earth.

title: Australia Prime Minister Fights Own Party to Stay in Office
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The embattled prime minister of Australia, Julia Gillard, was fighting for her political life on Thursday after she accepted a public demand for a leadership ballot put forward by a senior lawmaker from her ruling Labor Party, who said that the partys only hope of prevailing in upcoming elections was to return to office the man Ms. Gillard deposed in a 2010 party coup.

title: Tip of the Week: Making an iTunes Wish List
description: The iTunes Store has millions of songs, videos and other digital goods that make it easy to run up the credit-card bill. If you find items you want to buy  but need to pace your spending  you can use the Wish List feature to set them aside for purchasing later. To use the Wish List when you are logged in and browsing the iTunes Store, click the triangle next to the price listed for a song, album, video, book or other content for sale, and choose Add to Wish List from the menu that appears.

title: With JPMorgan Settlement, MF Global Clients Move Closer to Payout
description: MF Global customers moved one step closer to recouping their missing money late on Tuesday when JPMorgan Chase released its claim to more than $500 million belonging to the bankrupt brokerage firm.

title: Colorado Reels After Killing of Top Official Over Prisons
description: DENVER  As Colorados governor signed a hard-won package of gun control measures on Wednesday, officials across the state were reeling from the seemingly inexplicable shooting death of the states prisons chief, who was gunned down at the front door of his home.

title: Study of Mens Falling Income Cites Single Parents
description: WASHINGTON  The decline of two-parent households may be a significant reason for the divergent fortunes of male workers, whose earnings generally declined in recent decades, and female workers, whose earnings generally increased, a prominent labor economist argues in a new survey of existing research.

title: Indias Weakened Government May Struggle For Reform
description: Indias government faced accusations Wednesday that it will be incapable of bringing about much-needed reforms after the withdrawal of its biggest ally Tuesday night, a southern political party that protested the governments stance on Sri Lankas alleged war crimes.

title: More Proof That Rules Alone Wont Save Threatened Wildlife
description: HONG KONG  A major international conference on wildlife trade last week added 343 animal and plant species to the list of roughly 34,000 that are considered threatened. Trade in these creatures is either banned or strictly monitored, and the outcome was widely welcomed by conservationists as an important development.

title: Downton Season 3 Sets PBS Record
description: The third season of Downton Abbey was even more popular than previously believed. The seasons seven episodes averaged 11.5 million viewers a week, PBS said Tuesday after it received updated Nielsen numbers that included digital video recorder playbacks. Earlier numbers suggested that seven million to eight million viewers had tuned in for each episode. The total audience  up about 65 percent from the second season  makes the third season of Downton the most popular drama ever televised by PBS. The shows online viewership was counted separately. But there, too, a record was set: The public broadcaster said there were 900,000 video streams on the Masterpiece Web site the day after the Season 3 finale, the most for the site.

title: What Were Reading
description: Southern Foodways Alliance: It must be spring: Hansens Sno-Bliz in New Orleans has started serving sno-balls again.  Julia Moskin

title: Afghans Compromise Over Ban on Elite U.S. Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzais government has agreed to compromise on his demand that American Special Operations forces immediately leave Wardak Province, according to statements from American and Afghan officials on Wednesday, breaking an increasingly acrimonious impasse.

title: Google Hosts Narendra Modi at Tech Summit
description: MUMBAI Gujarats controversial chief minister, Narendra Modi, will address a Google summit in New Delhi on Thursday to speak about how the Internet is changing politics in India.

title: Hugo Chvezs Unlikely Soccer Legacy
description: In death, Hugo Chvez may conjure more debate and split more opinions than he ever did in life. Whether the former Venezuelan leader is remembered as a man of the people who brought millions out of extreme poverty or castigated as a deranged autocrat who drove his country in to debt and hyperinflation, the true measure of his time as a president will lie in the legacy and future he has left for Venezuela.

title: The Rite of Spring
description: Its not surprising that Disney set a battle between astegosaurusand a Tyrannosaurus rex to a soundtrack of Stravinskys Rite of Spring in the 1940 film Fantasia. For most children, thats what the music is about. But few are probably aware that when the ballet made its debut at the Thtre des Champs-lyses in 1913, a near riot broke out in the audience.

title: The Gun Report: March 20, 2013
description: What if there were a technology that insured that only the person who owned a gun could shoot it?No child who stumbled across the gun could accidentally shoot his brother.No one could make use of a stolen gun.No one could buy a gun on someone elses behalf because it wouldnt work for anyone but the buyer.Such a technology would not eliminate gun violence, of course, but it certainly would decrease it.It would greatly diminish, and perhaps even eliminate, fatal accidents involving children finding guns in their homes, which I find the most wrenching stories to read in The Gun Report.Such a technology, it turns out, does exist.I plan to write about it soon.

title: Van Cliburn, My Nemesis
description: Dear Diary:

title: Robert Forster to Play Reagan in a New Play
description: The actor Robert Forster, a Rochester native (and Max Cherry in Quentin Tarantinos Jackie Brown), will portray Ronald Reagan at Rochesters Geva Theater Center in June, the theater announced.

title: Once So Mighty, Now Gone: Chinas Ministry of Railways
description: BEIJING  With nearly 100,000 kilometers of track, Chinas railway system is the second-largest in the world, according to Sheng Guangzu, the last minister of railways. Its nearly 9,400 kilometers of high-speed rail  rising fast as China invests heavily in the sector  is the largest.

title: The Power Breakfast: Andrew Jenks
description: The filmmaker Andrew Jenks sits down with The Timess Tanzina Vega at Delicatessen in New York City to discuss the latest season of his MTV show, World of Jenks, and the evolution of reality TV.

title: A New Purpose for an Old Telephone Building, but Its Dull Face Remains
description: When City Room last visited the bulky old telephone switching station at 375 Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan, it was poised to emerge  like a chrysalis  from its limestone shell and turn into a sleek glass-skinned office tower, putting at risk its standing as one of the uglier skyscrapers in New York.

title: Wisdom From Flyers With Nut Allergies
description: When Roxanne Palin of Manhattan travels by plane with her family, some of whom are allergic to tree nuts or peanuts, she has a standing battle plan. She books flights in advance so that the three with allergies can sit together, and makes sure they bring their own food and beverages. She swabs their seats and table trays with alcohol pads or baby wipes. She packs eight doses of self-injectable epinephrine, including back-ups, in case any of them has an allergic reaction.

title: Autonomy Questions for Hewlett-Packard
description: You didnt really think Mike Lynch would stay away from Hewlett-Packard, did you?

title: U.K. Takes Steps to Spur Stuttering Economy
description: LONDON  The British government was forced on Wednesday to seek new ways to revive the sputtering economy after acknowledging for the second time in three months that it would take longer than expected to meet its debt-reduction target.

title: Just 5 Banks Prohibit Use of Social Security Numbers
description: Despite the risk of fraud associated with the theft of Social Security numbers, just five of the nations largest 25 banks have stopped using the numbers to verify a customers identity after the initial account setup, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds.

title: The Master Fish Butcher of Tokyos Union Square
description: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

title: A Sophisticated Instagram Alternative
description: Maybe Instagrams privacy blunder took the bloom off the rose, but thats no reason to stop sharing photos through social media as Instagram alternatives continue to emerge.

title: Last Splash
description: A promenade outside of Mumbai adorned with a mural by Rouble Nagi. The prime season for tourism there is ending as temperatures rise ahead of monsoons.

title: Back in the Tournament, Butler Has a Challenge in Bucknell
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Butler mens basketball team is a No. 6 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournaments East Regional after a 67-56 loss in the semifinal round of the Atlantic 10 tournament to eventual champion St. Louis. The Bulldogs enter the N.C.A.A. tournament with a 26-8 record.

title: The Revisionist Eyes Broadway as It Extends Run
description: One of the hottest Off Broadway tickets, the Vanessa Redgrave-Jesse Eisenberg play, The Revisionist, is adding an extra week of performances before its new closing date of April 27, Rattlestick Playwrights Theater announced on Wednesday. The theaters leaders have also begun exploring transferring the production to Broadway during the 2013-14 season.

title: Rat Body Linked to Blackout at Atomic Site
description: TOKYO  The operator of the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant said Wednesday that it had found what it believed was the cause of an extended blackout that disabled vital cooling systems this week: the charred body of a rat.

title: An Insiders Tour of Chongqing Yields Frugal Gems
description: As we drove down the mountain from Lao Jun Dong, a Taoist temple perched above the smoggy mega-city of Chongqing, I tried to describe to YangYang, my host and a local magazine editor, the kind of restaurant where I wanted to eat that Sunday evening.

title: Pope Francis, the Pragmatist
description: The Timess Simon Romero explains how Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio navigated the politics of gay marriage.

title: Symbolic Visit
description: The Timess Isabel Kershner on what Israelis expect from a visit by President Obama.

title: For Kentucky, Theres Always Last Year
description: North Carolina A&T won an N.C.A.A. tournament game for the first time on Tuesday, a 73-72 victory over 20-loss Liberty. (Make that 21-loss Liberty.) And in pro basketball, the Denver Nuggets won their 13th straight.

title: 8 Filipinos Are Charged in Incursion on Borneo
description: MANILA  Eight Filipinos were charged on Wednesday in a Malaysian court with committing terrorism and waging war in connection with their recent incursion on the island of Borneo, according to the Malaysian state news agency Bernama.

title: To Save a Mans Life, a Muddy Tug of War With the Earth Itself
description: Deep below Second Avenue, where workers blast into Manhattans bedrock to build the first new subway line in New York City in decades, mud and muck are a fact of life.

title: Longing for the Test of War as a Young Man
description: The war began for me while I was sitting on a couch in a living room. Like many people, I watched it all commence on television. At a friends house on campus, I sat with a few college friends and drank Bud Ice from bottles. We werent drinking beer because of the war; we were drinking simply because, being in college, it was something we often did. White smoke from an explosion would burst up from the cityscape of Baghdad as the sound echoed through the dark. Yellow tracers from antiaircraft fire sprayed randomly into the sky. The ticker on the bottom of the screen euphemistically summarized what was happening (while adding some alliteration and a subtle rhyme): Large explosion rocks Iraqs capital.

title: Safety Agency Upgrades Inquiry on Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedans
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says it is upgrading an investigation into fuel leaks on about 250,000 Mercedes-Benz sedans, according to a report posted on the agency Web site. The investigation covers 2003-8 E-Class models.

title: Image of the Day: March 20
Matches as Memories
description: Everyone swipes the matches. They were once ephemera  written on, burned up in the space of a weekend  but theyre now a keepsake. Maybe they bring you back to the Hemingway Bar at the Ritz or remind you of the pink-and-white striped pool towels at the Beverly Hills Hotel. In a way, they are the perfect hotel souvenirs, and also the most anachronistic  having been left essentially unchanged since the bygone days of steamer trunks, Baedeker guides, swizzle sticks and, lets not forget, smoking.

title: Where NASAs Voyager Is a Musical Instrument
description: Instead of the usual warning to silence all electronic gadgets, the WNYC host John Schaefer asked the audience at Merkin Concert Hall, gathered on Thursday evening for Bang on a Cans 2013 Peoples Commissioning Fund Concert, to keep their phones on.

title: Questions Abound in Learning to Adjust to Health Care Overhaul
description: Baked in the Sun is a wholesale baker and distributor of freshly baked pastries near San Diego.

title: Mariam Farhat, Known as Mother of Martyrs, Dies at 64
description: Mariam Farhat, a Palestinian lawmaker known as the mother of martyrs after three of her sons died in attacks against Israel, one of which was a suicide mission that she encouraged in a homemade video, died on Sunday in Gaza City. She was 64.

title: PEN/Faulkner Fiction Award Goes to Benjamin Alire Senz
description: Joining a pantheon that includes Philip Roth, E.L. Doctorow and John Updike, Benjamin Alire Senz has won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for his short story collection, Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club, The Associated Press reported.

title: Should a Bakery With More Than 50 Employees Offer Health Insurance?
description: We just published a case study about Baked in the Sun, a wholesale bakery and distributor trying to decide how best to comply with the Affordable Care Act, which requires businesses with 50 or more employees to offer health insurance or pay a penalty. The company, owned by Rachel Shein and Steve Pilarski, who are married, started out making scones 16 years ago and expanded with the growth of coffeehouses. Baked in the Sun now produces nearly 20,000 items per day  almost 200 different products, including brownies, coffee cakes, muffins and cookies  and employs nearly 100 people in San Marcos, Calif.

title: A Challenge Grant From Weills to Spur Carnegie Hall Renovation
description: Carnegie Hall has received a $10 million challenge grant from its chairman, Sanford I. Weill, and his wife, Joan, and their Weill Family Foundation toward the completion of its $230 million renovation. The project, known as the Studio Towers Renovation, will create new spaces for music education on the landmark buildings upper floors and upgrade the concert halls backstage areas. It is scheduled to be completed in 2014.

title: From Morgan Stanley, Investing in Women on Corporate Boards
description: The lack of women on corporate boards has been a hot topic in financial circles recently, especially after a debate in Europe last year over imposing quotas.

title: HBO Cancels Enlightened
description: Despite some critical acclaim, a second-season ratings spike and a Golden Globe award for best actress, HBOs Enlightened will be no more. After two seasons, the series, created by Mike White and Laura Dern, who also starred, has been canceled, The Hollywood Reporter said.

title: All the Plan Bs for Cyprus Look Dreadful
description: The Cypriots have an expression, eninboro allo. It means: I cannot take any more of it.

title: Minds at War
description: Any attempt to calculate the carnage of the Civil War, the number of sick, wounded, dismembered and dead, leaves one numb in the struggle to make sense of it all. The conditions and horrors faced by those who fought the war exacted a horrific toll.

title: Outside the Citadel, Social Practice Art Is Intended to Nurture
description: In Detroit a contemporary-art museum is completing a monument to an influential artist that will not feature his work but will instead provide food, haircuts, education programs and other social services to the general public.

title: Seder in Paris: Readers Want to Correct and Connect
description: PARIS  Mastering Passover hasnt been easy. Ive just written my Letter From Paris column on learning to do a proper Seder  as a Roman Catholic married to a Jew, and as an American living in Paris, where people tend to keep their religious beliefs and rituals to themselves.

title: Trapped in the Muck
description: The Timess Marc Santora on the successful effort to rescue a worker on the Second Avenue subway construction site.

title: A Chefs Guide to Eating in Jerusalem
description: When the London-based chef and restaurateur Yotam Ottolenghi, who grew up in the Jewish west side of Jerusalem, crisscrossed his hometown to research a cookbook he was writing with his companys head chef, Sami Tamimi, from the Arab east, he became a specialist in the citys subtle culinary distinctions. From the spices preferred by Jews from Libya to the technique Palestinians perfected for boiling chickpeas, Jerusalem: A Cookbook contains recipes inspired by the many flavors of the citys shops and restaurants in tucked-away corners. Jerusalem should not be missed, Mr. Ottolenghi said. Especially, he added, if youre interested in those layers of the history, the people, the religions, the tensions.

title: Palmer Is Down on McIlroys Absence, Long Putters
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Despite good-natured needling by the tournament host, Arnold Palmer, the world No. 1 Rory McIlroy chose love over a legend.

title: How Viable Is Rand Paul for 2016?
description: Perhaps no Republican has had a better 2013 than Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator who drew attention and praise for his talking filibuster against the C.I.A. director nominee John Brennan, then last week won the straw poll at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington. Then, on Tuesday, as my colleague Ashley Parker reports, Mr. Paul gave a speech to the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, outlining his plan for immigration reform.

title: Havana, Art Deco Capital
description: Cuba is one of the worlds most significant but overlooked troves of Art Deco architecture, with many classic examples of the style in a state of disrepair.

title: Indian Government Gets Support From Unlikely Corner
description: Indias beleaguered governing Indian National Congress received an unexpected boost Wednesday evening when a political party that had withdrawn its support in September offered its backing  on foreign policy, at least.

title: And Snoring in 14E
description: Finnair began a new check-in service this month that allows passengers to share their Facebook profiles with others on board and even see whos seated next to them. It is the latest of a handful of carriers experimenting with social seating. The voluntary service is a boon for fliers looking to socialize, not for those hoping to take a nap.

title: A Sham Procedure Leads to Disappointing M.S. News
Who Has The Fastest LTE Service?
description: Which cellular carriers LTE data service is the fastest?

title: Republicans Ask Themselves What Went Wrong
description: Gail Collins: David, I recall that during the presidential primaries, you worried that the Republicans would nominate Mitt Romney, that Romney would lose and then the Tea Party would beat its chest and say that the only road to victory was through the far right. Last weekend, Senator Ted Cruz told a convention of conservatives: Were winning! It made me think about what a good predictor you are.

title: The Missing Piece
description: Landon Donovans self-imposed exile from soccer has often been described as unprecedented or unusual, but this is hardly true. There is a rich and compelling history of surprising celebrity sabbaticals, with a wide variety of outcomes.

title: Pope Meets Other Religious Leaders, Pledging Respect
description: ROME  Pope Francis promised friendship, respect and continued dialogue with other religious leaders on Wednesday, pledging cooperation with Orthodox churches, describing the spiritual bond between Catholics and Jews as very special and expressing gratitude to Muslim leaders.

title: Baby Steps on Gun Control
description: As gun-control opponents often argue, no single law will prevent any single act of gun violence. But hardly a day goes by without a reminder of how out-of-control our gun culture is, how much violence is committed with gunsand how tragic it is that the gun lobbies want to prevent the government from even trying to rein things in.

title: Keeping the World Safe for Art
description: The job of a museum guard demands long hours, constant vigilance and a reservoir of patience to put up with illicit picture takers, soda smugglers and pontificating amateur art critics, among other annoyances.

title: The Era of Deep Archiving Begins
description: As a Dartmouth student in the early 1970s, William McDonough went, somewhat casually, to hear a lecture by a visiting celebrity. Mr. McDonough had little idea beforehand who Buckminster Fuller was, but listening to the designer and futurist had a long-term effect.

title: Sudden Rise in Home Demand Takes Builders by Surprise
description: SACRAMENTO  After six years of waiting on the sidelines, newly eager home buyers across the country are discovering that there are not enough houses for sale to accommodate the recent flush of demand.

title: Young Opponents of Gay Marriage Undaunted by Battle Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  They hear that their cause is lost, that demographics and the march of history have doomed their campaign to keep marriage only between a man and a woman. But the young conservatives who oppose same-sex marriage  unlike most of their generation  remain undaunted.

title: Police Search I.M.F. Chiefs Home in French Financial Investigation
description: PARIS  The French police on Wednesday searched the Paris apartment of Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in connection with an investigation into her handling of a financial scandal when she was the French finance minister.

title: A Big Data Freeway for Scientists
description: The University of California, San Diego, this week plans to announce that it has installed an advanced optical computer network that is intended to serve as a Big Data freeway system for next-generation science projects in fields including genomic sequencing, climate science, electron microscopy, oceanography and physics.

title: Excerpt: 'Breakfast at Tiffany's'
description: Emilia Clarke and Cory Michael Smith in a scene from the new Broadway play at the Cort Theater.

title: Number of Hunger Strikers Surges at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  A hunger strike by detainees who have been held for years without trial at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has grown to involve at least 25 prisoners, the Defense Department disclosed Wednesday.

title: Moscow Court Rejects Punk Bands Appeal
description: MOSCOW  A Moscow appellate court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by three members of the punk group Pussy Riot who were jailed for hooliganism after they called for the Virgin Mary to rid Russia of President Vladimir V. Putin in a protest in a church last year.

title: Student Crossword | The Human Body
description: Play our crossword (PDF) to see what you know about the human body. And you can find the answers here.

title: Spring Training
description: Though men have been wearing their suits with running shoes and incorporating sweatshirts into work gear for a while now, the athletic look continues this spring. Miuccia Prada presented a collection of what seemed to be team uniforms for the future. Valentino, Bottega Veneta and Raf Simons showed the majority (if not all) of their looks with sneakers instead of proper oxfords. Some designers were even more specific with their sporty adaptions  as in the case of the young British designer Lou Dalton, who created this high-fashion take on a baseball shirt ($399; openingceremony.us).

title: What Argentine Priests Knew About the Dirty War
description: In 1975, I watched churches in Buenos Aires fill with distraught mothers praying futilely for news of missing sons and daughters. Troubled police officers frequented the confessionals. Most Argentines suspected that President Isabel Pern and her Rasputin, Jos Lpez Rega, were behind official death squads that made so many people disappear. Priests knew the details.

title: Dreams of Saving Art Deco Havana
description: HAVANA  Kathleen Murphy Skolnik gasped one recent morning as she gazed up into the stairwell of a 1939 downtown apartment building here and pointed at the chevron pattern in the ironwork, at the unpolished rust-pink marble and a simple alcove on the stairway crowned by a stepped arch.

title: Azzedine Alaa: Longer, and Shaping Up for a Big Year
description: Pictures of Azzedine Alaas latest collection dont adequately capture the three-dimensional quality of the knitting. Polka dots on a baby-doll dress, shown with matched leggings, are actually raised, like embroidery, and a series of vertically striped dresses are in fact ribbons of lacework backed by a shimmery knit. Other sophisticated techniques include honeycomb pleating, and most of the garments have a minimum number of seams. Its remarkable what Mr. Alaa is able to express through one form.

title: Chemicals Would Be Game Changer in Syria, Obama Says
description: JERUSALEM  Showing solidarity with Israels growing concern about chemical weapons in neighboring Syria, President Obama stated bluntly on Wednesday that if an investigation he had ordered found proof that the Syrian military had used such weapons it would be a game changer in American involvement in the civil war there.

title: Barclays Bankers Cash In on Past Bonuses
description: LONDON  It pays to be a Barclays banker.

title: Knicks Anthony Says He Is Ready to Return
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks slept in their own beds Tuesday night after being on the road for 10 days, the longest such stretch of the season. A brutal five-game western road trip, during which they were 1-4 and lost Carmelo Anthony, Tyson Chandler and Kurt Thomas to injury, is finally in the past.

title: At Hanjan, Its No Secret When the Chicken Died
description: For the most part, American restaurants are not keen on reminding their customers that the meat theyre about to eat comes from an animal that has, at some point along the way, been killed.

title: CBS Renews C.S.I.
description: CBS announced Wednesday that it has renewed the biggest television hit of the past decade, C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation, for a 14th season.

title: Justices Back Loggers in Water Runoff Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that logging companies and forestry officials in Oregon were not required to obtain permits from the Environmental Protection Agency for storm-water runoff from logging roads.

title: Cell Therapy Shows Promise for Acute Type of Leukemia
description: A treatment that genetically alters a patients own immune cells to fight cancer has, for the first time, produced remissions in adults with an acute leukemia that is usually lethal, researchers are reporting.

title: Exhibitions on View
description: A sampler of offerings at art museums across the country this spring and summer.

title: With Freddie Mac Suit, Banks Face Billions More in Libor Claims
description: The fallout from the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, has already cost banks $2.5 billion in penalties, not to mention loss of reputation.

title: Team on the Way to Collect Congo War Crimes Suspect
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  American officials on Wednesday said that a team from the International Criminal Court was on its way to Rwanda to collect a war crimes suspect who had turned himself in to the American Embassy and that they were hoping Rwanda would cooperate.

title: Fed to Maintain Stimulus Efforts Despite Jobs Growth
description: WASHINGTON  Employment has been increasing at a healthy clip for the last few months, but the Federal Reserve is not ready to relax just yet.

title: Backup Cat Out of Breakfast
description: Even as Breakfast at Tiffanys prepared to open on Broadway Wednesday night, one cat was out of the bag or at least, out of a job. The main cat understudy, Montie, a black-and-white male, has been fired for being, well, difficult. He didnt follow stage directions.

title: Single Parents: Unsupported, and Feeling the Blame
description: Sometimes research results are politically incorrect, or even offensive for some of us, and still worth talking about.

title: Ronald Dworkins Religious Atheism
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: Many Strands Make Up One Woman
description: A modernizing democrat or a kleptocrat in a Herms scarf? Pakistans daughter of destiny (the title of her autobiography) or puppet of the West? That Benazir Bhutto, a two-time prime minister of Pakistan educated at Harvard and Oxford, contained not merely multitudes but multitudes of contradictions, would seem to be the premise of the uneven one-woman show Shaheed: The Dream and Death of Benazir Bhutto, written and performed by Anna Khaja at the Culture Project.

title: Yankees Say Jeter May Not Be Ready for Opener
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Its Derek Jeter, so people automatically assume he will exceed normal standards. But it is possible that not even Jeter will be able to make the Yankees opening day lineup less than sixth months after fracturing his left ankle and needing surgery to repair it.

title: Chip Kelly Could Have Been a Giant
description: PHOENIX  Keep this in mind when the Giants and Eagles play: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin tried to hire new Eagles Coach Chip Kelly as a quality control coach not that long ago and was turned down. Kelly was the offensive coordinator at the University of New Hampshire, early in his meteoric rise, when the Giants came calling in 2006.

title: NIMBY Deficit Hawks
description: Jerry Moran often repeated the Republican partys magical incantation when he was running for senator from Kansas in 2010: We dont have a revenue problem  we have a spending problem. After he was elected, he continued the drumbeat, and supported using the debt ceiling as a threat to enact more budget cuts. He opposed the 2011 budget deal that led to the sequester, not because he was against the sequester but because it didnt cut spending enough.

title: Irans Support Emboldens Assad, Envoy Says
description: WASHINGTON  Iran is stepping up its military assistance to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, and the supplies have strengthened his belief that he can prevail in his struggle with the opposition, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.

title: Bon Jovi Bests Bowie on Album Chart
description: With the top of the Billboard album chart this week looking like a bit of a flashback to 1986, Bon Jovi is No. 1 and David Bowie has landed at No. 2 with his first new album in a decade.

title: Hands, Disfigured in Fire, Are Now Essential to Livelihood
description: On a recent Saturday, Sandy Yu, protected by a red parka, was one of the few sidewalk vendors who showed up along a normally jammed Fifth Avenue commercial strip in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

title: Stimulus Derangement Syndrome
description: Miles Kimball goes after John Taylors latest, and in the process reminds us of an earlier Taylor episode, in which JT argued that low interest rates are actually contractionary  a conclusion he reached by confusing the Feds setting of an interest rate target, which is achieved by buying bonds, with a rent-control-type price ceiling enforced by simply banning above-target transactions. It was an amazing thing for a highly credentialed macroeconomist to say. But it wasnt unique; just offhand I can think of multiple comparable flubs ever since we began monetary and fiscal stimulus to fight the Great Recession.

title: Test Run: Rdio vs. Spotify for Streaming Music
description: Talking about Spotify versus Rdio, two competing music streaming services, can be like arguing with someone in a bar over two baseball teams: People passionately love one or the other and will happily share their disdain for the rival. But Spotify often wins with its might and size, touting millions more users than Rdio.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Amazon-C.I.A. Deal, and Googling for GIFs
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Diverging Fortunes for Men and Women
description: In recent decades, men have lost ground to women in educational attainment, cutting into the real income of most males as prospects for those without a college education have worsened.

title: Tonight, With New Host, Set to Reclaim Its New York Roots
description: NBC has settled on two new stars for The Tonight Show: Jimmy Fallon and New York City.

title: Iraq: 10 Years and Counting
description: Americans try to understand the war as Iraqis live with its consequences.

title: A Simpler Way to Complain About Student Loan Collections
description: Borrowers who run into trouble with their federal student loans should have an easier time filing complaints about private collection agencies that work under contract to the government, a new report says.

title: The Nuggets Have a Streak of Their Own
description: With all eyes cast squarely upon the Miami Heats 23-game win streak, the Denver Nuggets have quietly put together a timely blitz of their own.

title: Blending Art and Technology
description: Though other museums have experimented with interactive technology, the extent of a program at the Cleveland Museum of Art is unprecedented.

title: Key Democrat Chides President and Senators on Pace of Immigration Bill
description: 6:46 p.m. | Updated As the Senate Judiciary Committee held its second hearing this week on overhauling the nations immigration laws, the committees chairman issued a frustrated plea for speeding up the overall pace of producing actual legislation.

title: No Comment Necessary: Rationalizing Iraq
description: Via Conor Friedersdorf at The Atlantic

title: Appeal Denied, Ex-Consultant Is Off to Jail
description: For 17 months, John F. Haggerty Jr., a former Republican political consultant, fought his conviction on charges of stealing campaign money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
