title: Michelle Shocked Says Comments on Gay Marriage Were Misunderstood
description: At least ten clubs and music halls have canceled concerts by Michelle Shocked since she went on an anti-gay tirade during a show in San Francisco on Sunday night.

title: Cyprus Shows How Not to Do a Bailout
description: Cyprus cant really be about Cyprus, can it? After all, the banking sector in that country pales in comparison to things like the London Whale trade and the amount of capital the big banks have to raise to meet Basel III.

title: Best-Selling Russian Writer Turns From Crime to History
description: MOSCOW  Grigory Chkhartishvili, the best-selling Russian writer known for his detective novels set in imperial Russia (written under the name Boris Akunin), and for his foray into opposition politics directed against Vladimir V. Putin announced that from now on he would devote himself to writing a multivolume history of Russia.

title: Hawk Cam Returns for Third Season
description: Updated, 4:58 p.m.,Thursday | The Hawk Cam, which has chronicled the lives of red-tailed hawks in Washington Square Park since 2011, has returned for a third season. The stars of the reality raptor drama, believed to be last years couple, Rosie and Bobby, are currently warming three eggs on a nest situated on the 12th-floor window ledge of New York Universitys president, John Sexton.

title: A Litany of Betrayals, Petty Yet Terrifying
description: The feminist Russian punk band Pussy Riot, some of its members recently imprisoned, stands for many things, notably opposition to the policies of Vladimir Putin. One of its best-known songs contains the line Virgin birth-giver of God, drive away Putin! Another is titled, depending on the translation, Putin Is Wetting Himself.

title: Devils Enjoying Surge in Attendance
description: The Devils have won only three of their last 10 games, but they are on a more successful run at the box office. Including Wednesday nights game against the Rangers at the Prudential Center in Newark, the Devils have sold out 14 of their last 16 home games this season and 25 of the last 27 games stretching back to last seasons playoffs.

title: She Cant Be Caged
description: Talk about revolving-door justice. On Monday, Lindsay Lohan struck a deal to spend 90 days in rehab instead of jail, after pleading no contest to reckless driving in a car crash last year along the Pacific Coast Highway. Twitter users were quick to judge.

title: Indian Motorcycles Revs Up a New App
description: Can you sell a nostalgic brand using a high-tech phone?

title: New Reasons to Change Light Bulbs
description: People sometimes have trouble making small sacrifices now that will reward them handsomely later. How often do we ignore the advice to make a few diet and exercise changes to live a longer, healthier life? Or to put some money aside to grow into a nest egg? Intellectually, we get it  but instant gratification is a powerful force.

title: If You Like Billie Holiday, Try Madeleine Peyroux
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Intertrust Sues Apple, Charging Patent Violations
description: Intertrust, a company that nabbed a huge settlement over patents in a lawsuit with Microsoft nearly a decade ago, has turned its focus to Apple, suing the technology giant on Wednesday and charging infringements of its security and content protection patents.

title: Site Where Man Was Pulled From the Mud
description: A diagram of the site in New York City where a worker was trapped in mud for four hours.

title: Monetary Policy Statement From the Federal Reserve
description: Following is the text of the Federal Reserves statement on Wednesday announcing it was holding its base federal funds target rate at a record low between zero and 0.25 percent:

title: 71 Years in New York City Is Enough for Elaine Stritch
description: Elaine Stritch is leaving the building.

title: Obama and Netanyahu Meet in Israel
description: President Barack Obama held a joint press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday in Israel.

title: The Prolific Willy Rizzo
description: FASHION WAS A CHALLENGING SUBJECT for a photojournalist like Willy Rizzo. He was already well established and living in Paris in the 1950s, his subjects having included politicians, playboys and a pontiff, when Alexander Liberman, then the art director of Vogue, asked him to shoot for the magazine.

title: Peru, Chile and the War of the Pacific
description: In many parts of the world, soccer equals history. Not a fan? Simply listening to the 40,000 fans at Estadio Nacional in Lima amplify the Peruvian national anthem blaring through the speakers before Friday nights South American World Cup qualifier with Chile might change things.

title: The Salary Bracket: This Is One Harvard Wins
Profit Down 31%, FedEx Cuts Outlook
description: Express shipping seems much less urgent these days.

title: Emphasizing Safety, N.F.L. Passes Rule on Helmet Hits
description: PHOENIX  Tom Coughlin has pulled players aside during games to remind them not to lower their heads when they strike a blow.

title: Scouting Report
description: Collaboration

title: Flexibility and Moxie Can Save West Side
description: New York is at a crossroads. After half a century a fleeting opportunity has finally arrived to address the disaster of Penn Station, the nations busiest and most appalling transit hub, and to reimagine a new West Side for Midtown Manhattan that could be a center for development and innovation.

title: Photo Replay: March 20
description: A view of the day in sports, including the womens European wrestling championships.

title: Mad for Museums in China
description: In China, museums  big, small, government-backed, privately bankrolled  are opening like mad. In 2011 alone, some 390 new ones appeared. And the numbers are holding.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Finance Government and Soften Spending Cuts
description: Read an updated version of this post.

title: Travel Essentials | Brussels
description: The short list on where to eat, sleep and view art in Belgiums capital.

title: Art Market | Big in Belgium
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Kreider Gets Another Chance at Sticking with Rangers
description: Chris Kreider, the Rangers rookie forward, will get a third try at sticking with the team this season after being recalled from the American Hockey League Wednesday. Kreider scored six goals in eight games for Connecticut, the Rangers A.H.L. affiliate, since his latest demotion on Feb. 28.

title: Shopping Snapshots: March 21
description: Fashion trend: transparent bags; Frame Denims skinny jeans; a wardrobe staple acquires some fresh looks; and Candela Turcos Pasionae Murano glass rings.

title: In City Hall, a One-Man Show That Ran for Three Terms
description: The man hated lawyers. He wiped out political corruption (Tammany Hall, anyway). He was a Republican who bonded with Franklin D. Roosevelt. On his first day at City Hall he cut his own salary in half. During a newspaper strike he read the comics on WNYC Radio.

title: Better Asteroid Detection Is Needed, Experts Say
description: Making a case for the need to detect asteroids before they hit Earth, a former astronaut said Wednesday that the number of casualties would have been enormous had the space rock that exploded in Russia last month blown apart directly over New York City instead.

title: Wheres Voyager 1? That Depends.
description: For about three hours on Wednesday, Voyager 1 had left the solar system  before a rewritten news release headline pulled it back in.

title: Stepping Back Into a Jazzy Tap-Dance Cabaret
description: This week the American Tap Dance Foundation is presenting two productions, one recreating taps past, one exhibiting taps present. Rhythm Is Our Business, the backward-looking show, opened at the Theater at the 14th Street Y on Tuesday with a video montage of great moments in tap from the 1930s through the 1950s that was oddly silent and so dimly projected you could barely see it. The live performances that followed were much more vivid, though a little faint too.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Israel, Syria, North Korea and Greece.

title: Camouflage on the Fall 2013 Runways
description: How camo can you go?

title: Canyons, Inspiring to the Eye, Capture the Ear, Too
description: The visionary French composer Olivier Messiaen and the citizens of Utah had a mutual appreciation. Messiaen, inspired to write his glittering Des Canyons aux toiles (From the Canyons to the Stars) after visiting the states parks in 1972, declared southern Utah the most mystical landscape he had ever seen. In gratitude, a mountain was renamed in his honor.

title: 60 Seconds With Pogue: LED Light Bulbs
description: LED bulbs are a gigantic improvement over incandescent bulbs and compact fluorescents. David Pogue tries out LED bulbs and kits from six manufacturers.

title: A Disguise for When You Want to Be Seen
description: No one saw it coming. The mens fashion collection that Dries Van Noten showed for spring was a cavalcade of camouflage.

title: Palestinian Protesters Set Up Camp in West Bank
description: AL-AZARIYA, West Bank  It was hardly the most visible place to stage an anti-Obama protest, on a stony hillside on the edge of this West Bank town just east of Jerusalem. But for the Palestinians, it was highly symbolic.

title: Sensuously Rippling Bodies, All There to Serve the Rhythm
description: The performers of DanceBrazil, as seen this week at the Joyce Theater, exist in a ravishing, hard-working paradise. Theyre barefoot; their attire (T-shirts, loose trousers, light dresses or skirts) has no hint of luxury. What matters here above all is the gorgeously full physicality of movement, allied to music. While spines continually plunge beneath the level of the waist, legs kick explosively above it or maintain powerful extensions like searchlights.

title: The Man of the Hour, or Four
description: After an enervating evening that was about to hit the four-hour mark and was driving some members of the audience to the exits, Madonna came on stage Saturday at the 24th Glaad Media Awards and reminded people exactly why shes a superstar.

title: Republican Council Members Endorse Lhota
description: All four Republican members of the City Council made an endorsement in the New York mayoral race on Wednesday, pledging their support to Joseph J. Lhota, a former deputy in the Giuliani administration and Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman.

title: Celebrating Philip Roth at 80
description: Mr. Roths native Newark celebrated his birthday with a daylong academic conference, a new photo exhibition, a bus tour and a party at the Newark Museum.

title: Countrys Straight-Talk Feminists
description: Country music fearmongers in the mid-2000s had their choice of invading btes noires. From one direction Taylor Swift arrived, a pop-friendly ingnue with sparkling songs and a killer instinct. From another, Miranda Lambert was stomping in, full of vitriol and skepticism, an alpha answering to no beta.

title: Goodbye, Newark, the Place Roth Never Left
description: NEWARK  Since he announced his retirement from writing, Philip Roth has been in an unusually good mood. On Tuesday he celebrated his 80th birthday here  a city where he no longer lives but never entirely left  by juking into a reception space at the Newark Museum behind marching-band drummers from Weequahic High School, his alma mater. There Mr. Roth, normally the most private of authors, was greeted with applause from 250 friends, relatives and invited guests, including members of the Philip Roth Society, scholars who specialize in his work.

title: Spring North American Championships
description: ST. LOUIS  At the Spring North American Championships here the Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was won on Sunday evening by Martin Fleisher of New York City and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J. They finished just over one board ahead of JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif., and Jeff Meckstroth of Clearwater Beach, Fla. Third were John Kranyak of Las Vegas and Vincent Demuy of Laval, Quebec.

title: Thorny Questions for Justices in Raisin Case
description: WASHINGTON  The current Supreme Court sometimes seems to relish a procedural puzzle.

title: A Feminist Illustrator Gets Her Due
description: Barbara Nessim is honored with a London retrospective.

title: At the Table, a Touch of Couture
description: In 2009, the fashion label Christian Lacroix suspended its couture and womens ready-to-wear activities and lost 90 percent of its staff, including Mr. Lacroix. But under Sacha Walckhoff, Lacroixs longtime creative director, the company continues to design vibrant, pattern-clashing items. Next month in the United States, it will introduce a 50-piece collection of china in four motifs. The tableware, made by Vista Alegre in Portugal, features polychromatic butterflies, roughly painted black stripes, a floral mosaic and a 19th-century engraving of the ancient Roman arena in Arles. The bold consumer is encouraged to combine any or all of these patterns.

title: Photographys New Prominence
description: Large numbers of exhibitions are being organized by museum photography departments across the country at a time when a new crop of photography curators have taken the helm at major museums.

title: Pushing the Boundaries of Scandinavian Design
description: Antik, which sold Scandinavian antiques in TriBeCa until May, has re-emerged in Greenwich Village as Hostler Burrows. When the shop opened in the late 90s, people knew Hans Wegner, Georg Jensen, Jens Risom  three Danish designers, said Kim Hostler, an owner with Juliet Burrows. The women have since introduced other 20th-century Scandinavians. Shown at top, the work of five Swedish designers: 1940s blue-gray chairs by Otto Schulz ($14,000 a pair), 1950s ivory chairs by Kerstin Horlin-Holmqvist ($12,500 a pair) and a table by Axel Einar Hjorth ($16,000). Above, 1950s porcelain vases by Berndt Friberg (from $2,200 each) and a 1939 rug by Sigvard Bernadotte ($28,000): (212) 343-0471, hostlerburrows.com.

title: Sculpture From the Storm
description: Most of the thousands of tree limbs and stumps left by Hurricane Sandy were sent to composting facilities and trash heaps. But some homeowners have embraced the wreckage by turning their downed trees into sculpture. Gregg Klewicki, a 45-year-old woodcarver in Huntington, N.Y., began his craft when he was 20. His first project, he said, was a giant nose that he placed on his front lawn. Within a few weeks, someone knocked on his door willing to pay $300 for it, so he started carving on the weekends. A few years later, Mr. Klewicki had enough commissions to quit his day job driving a beer truck. Last week, he laid down his chain saw long enough to talk to a reporter.

title: Sales at Ann Gish, Tom Dixon and Others
description: Bed and tabletop linens are up to 80 percent off at Ann Gish Thursday to Sunday (a queen-size Jack Stripe silk duvet cover by Ann Gish, shown, originally $1,165, is $350); 4 West 20th Street, (212) 727-2122, anngish.com.

title: Some Plants Deserve a Toast
description: Amy Stewart has a way of making gardening seem exciting, even a little dangerous, as she did with Wicked Plants, her best-selling book about poisonous and invasive vegetation. In The Drunken Botanist (Algonquin, $19.95), her latest, Ms. Stewart is once again out to show the sexier side of the garden, this time linking plants to alcoholic spirits.

title: Bavarian Castle, Moat Included
description: A 12th-century castle in Kipfenberg, Germany, is on the market for $7.4 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Germany
description: A 12th-CENTURY BAVARIAN CASTLE SURROUNDED BY A MOAT AND 27 ACRES

title: Cubes and Spheres at Work
description: The British designer Faye Toogood makes one-of-a kind, expressively minimal furniture. But Ms. Toogood, a former editor at The World of Interiors magazine, wanted to reach a broader audience and turned to batch production, making 10 to 100 pieces of a design at a time. Her Batch line was introduced in London last year and is now available in the United States at Matter, in SoHo. The collection includes the Element table, right, which has a tinted glass top that rests on a cube, sphere and cylinder, all made of solid ash. I have fabricated the table in many different materials before, she said. By simply changing the materials and the volume and void of the piece, it has seen many incarnations. This one is 39 inches square, 8 inches tall and $5,360. Information: (212) 343-2600 or mattermatters.com.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: Properties for $800,000
description: A four-bedroom co-op in Washington, D.C., a Gothic revival in Omaha, Neb., and a parlor floor condo in an 1894 townhouse in Savannah, Ga.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I want my home to stand out from the crowd. Which paint colors will make it look unique, but still clean and crisp?

title: Shopping for Paperweights
description: Andrew Zobler, the founder and chief executive of the Sydell Group, has amassed 100 or so paperweights since he was a boy.

title: Paperweights
description: SOME 8-YEAR-OLD BOYS collect Legos or baseball cards, but when Andrew Zobler was that age, he collected paperweights. It wasnt exactly his decision.

title: The Particular Puzzles of Being a Small Museum
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, 13 people gathered outside the Merchants House Museum on East Fourth Street in Manhattan. Each had paid $15 for a guided tour of the surrounding NoHo neighborhood, once a tony section of the city. Their guide: an expert from the museum.

title: Technology That Serves to Enhance, Not Distract
description: CLEVELAND

title: Progress Stalls in California on Earthquake Warnings
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Scientists at the Caltech Seismology Laboratory were at their computers last week when a warning popped up on the screen: Earthquake, earthquake! The initial magnitude of the quake, 100 miles away, was 5.2, the alert said, and a countdown clock warned that mild shaking would reach here in 40 seconds.

title: Leader Unafraid to Venture Outside of the Lines
description: THINK of the Society of Illustrators and the image likely to spring to mind is that of a quaint, august institution whose heyday coincided with that of The Saturday Evening Post. But this wasnt the picture the society presented one recent winter evening, when every floor of its building on East 63rd Street fairly blazed with activity.

title: Enshrining Art With a Permanent, and Personal, Home
description: RIVALING earlier American moguls who built elaborate edifices to house their art collections, magnates of the 21st century are pouring their fortunes into founding their own ambitious museums.

title: Examining Sargents Shift From Oil to Watercolors
description: BY the time John Singer Sargent reached his mid-40s at the beginning of the 20th century, he had long been saluted as the best society portrait painter of the Gilded Age. But he was having a midlife career crisis.

title: Renovation, Italian Style
description: Elisabetta Bruscolini and Giancarlo Astrologo are passionate collectors of friends, objects and, yes, homes.

title: Rothkos Journey to His Fields of Color, in Full View
description: FOR many art lovers, Mark Rothkos layered bands of misty color represent the apex of 20th-century abstraction. Here was an artist who painstakingly distilled the achievements of the painters who came before him and forever changed how we see the horizon line.

title: A Tribute for Turning Light Into Art
description: LIGHT is this thing we usually use to illuminate other things, said the artist James Turrell, who first considered the presence of a beam of light cast from a slide projector during art history class at Pomona College in the early 1960s. Im interested that light has thingness itself, so its not something that reveals something about other things youre looking at, but it becomes a revelation in itself.

title: Seeing the Art in Plastic Straws and Other Castoffs
description: THE contest challenge was to create outrageous art from unconventional materials. The students in Eileen Farrelly-Moyotls 11th-grade fashion design class at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan were up to it: one of them made a dress from plastic bags filled with floating fish.

title: Modern Wrapped in Tuscan Stone
description: An ancient Tuscan parish house, fitted with a sleek interior.

title: Art and History Among the Dead
description: ONE of New York Citys most unusual museums is not on Fifth Avenue or Madison Avenue, but on 400 acres of beautifully landscaped land at Webster Avenue and East 233rd Street in the Bronx.

title: In Rome Exhibition, a Poem to New York
description: NEW Yorks role as the ruling city of the art world has held steady since at least the middle of the 20th century. Next month, a new exhibition about the citys ever-growing and constantly shifting art scene is opening in the capital of a much older empire: Rome.

title: The Rijksmuseum, Reborn
description: AMSTERDAM

title: The Stories of the Holocaust
description: INGE OPPENHEIMER is accustomed to telling her story. How she watched her synagogue burn on Kristallnacht, survived the Nazi labor camps and immigrated to the United States, where she became a school librarian.

title: Grasping at Straw
description: Do you have bad dirt? No dirt? Is the earth in your garden actually a sidewalk?

title: Justin Timberlake Takes the Style Spotlight
description: Long gone and perhaps best forgotten is the boy-band alumnus with frosted curls and cornrows.

title: In Denver, Exhibits Interweave Genres
description: THIS summer, the Denver Art Museum is staging a blockbuster exhibition  make that exhibitions. Called Spun: Adventures in Textiles, it presents about a dozen exhibits, all variations on the theme, and is designed to address a chronic problem at museums: getting visitors to look at their permanent collections.

title: Justin Timberlake, Hes All Dressed Up
description: Have you ever seen the body? Tom Ford, the designer, said by telephone from London, referring to a broad-shouldered, narrow-hipped physique that might represent the universal standard for male models. He was talking about Justin Timberlake.

title: A Boston Palace Where Greenery Ties Old to New
description: BOSTON

title: Looking for Ways to Groom Repeat Visitors
description: ART museums, seeking the repeat and committed visitor, are experimenting with new ways to cultivate a closer relationship with the public  and, in essence, to become a welcoming extension of the living room, rather than a stiff, Sunday-best excursion.

title: Country Music Temple Stays in Financial Tune
description: VINCE GILL was there, singing about his wifes smile. Emmylou Harris started off with Love Hurts. Jason Aldean sang Big Green Tractor, and laughed about hitting the big time with a tune about a farm vehicle. Late last month, they and a handful of other country music stars were gathered in a Times Square theater for a guitar pull, an improvised concert at which anything might happen.

title: The Science of Moving Science Across Town
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Shrines for Locals Who Made Good
description: THE round birthday cake was small and simple  Happy Birthday Mario, it read. A little more than a dozen people showed up for the cold-cut spread and the operatic music piped into the little party room.

title: The Man Who Would Be Done
What Did You Do in the Civil War, California?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Brodeur Ready to Return to Struggling Devils
description: NEWARK  Goalie Martin Brodeur, whose monthlong absence triggered a tumble in the standings that has the Devils in danger of missing the playoffs, is expected to rejoin the lineup for Thursday nights game at the Carolina Hurricanes.

title: A Curmudgeons Home Remade
description: The results of a painful and ongoing renovation of the Hoboken, N.J., home owned by the editor of This Old House magazine.

title: Israeli Group Protests Detention of Palestinian Children Suspected of Throwing Rocks
description: The Israeli rights group BTselem protested the detention on Wednesday of 27 Palestinian children suspected of throwing rocks at settlers and soldiers in the West Bank city of Hebron.

title: Celebrating Fellini and Venice
description: The architect Peter Marino had an aversion to toga-and-sandal epics until he saw Satyricon, Federico Fellinis bawdy, episodic narration of Roman life in the age of Nero.

title: A Building Boom as Chinese Art Rises in Stature
description: After years of fevered activity, museum building and expansion in the United States have slowed to a crawl under a low-lying economic cloud. In Europe, where the climate is even stormier, venerable state-financed institutions go begging for cash.

title: The Lens Rises in Stature
description: ON a recent wintry afternoon, Jeff Rosenheim, the newly appointed head of the Metropolitan Museum of Arts photography department, stopped in at its special exhibition galleries. He was checking on the installation of a new acquisition: a 61-minute video called Street, by the British-born artist James Nares.

title: Varied Duties, and Many Facets, in a Guards Life
description: IN the 1990s, a technology company, Cybermotion, tried to sell museums on the concept of robot security guards.

title: On Exhibit, From Ancient Arts to Sound and Video
description: A sampling of the rich variety of art on view this spring and summer.

title: Anti-Fracking Group Criticizes Energy Nominee for Not Disclosing Industry Ties
description: A watchdog group that opposes fracking for natural gas released a report on Wednesday that criticizes the presidents choice to be energy secretary, Ernest J. Moniz, for failing to disclose in an energy study that he led his ties to the natural gas industry.

title: An Epic Gathering of Leviathans From the Deep
description: JOHN J. FLYNN invited me to slip my hand under the jaw of an ancient carnivore, a prize of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Beauty Spots
description: With its up-and-down temperatures, the transition from winter to spring can be tough on skin. Herein, a few products that will soothe confused complexions.

title: U.S. Open Increases Payout to Players
description: In response to players complaints about prize money and the tournament schedule, United States Open officials announced a huge increase in the overall payout to players and will permanently give the mens players a Sunday final and a day of rest after the semifinals, starting in 2015.

title: Parental Study Shows Rise in Autism Spectrum Cases
description: The likelihood of a school-aged American child receiving a diagnosis of autism, Asperger syndrome or a related developmental disorder increased 72 percent in 2011-12 from 2007, according to an analysis of a phone survey of parents released Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Health Resources and Services Administration.

title: Inside the Metropolitans Stage
description: Ahead of renovations, a look at the interior workings of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Zimbabwe Rights Lawyer Denied Bail
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  A magistrate judge denied bail to the human rights lawyer Beatrice Mtetwa on Wednesday, ordering her held on a charge of obstruction of justice until April 3.

title: Woods Is Smiling Now, and He Has Reasons
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  In the fall of 2011, golfs peak cast a Mount Kilimanjaro-like shadow over Tiger Woods, who found himself in the deepest valley of his career. Roughly a year after losing his No. 1 world ranking to Lee Westwood, Woods had tumbled to No. 58, his downward momentum snowballing under the weight of injuries, a swing change and upheaval in his personal life.

title: Housing Is Finally on the Mend
description: More than six years after the housing bubble burst, the industry is beginning to recover. With the available supply of homes down to levels not seen since 1999, prices have begun to rise and home builders are responding by planning to construct more homes than at any time in the last eight years. The trend is particularly pronounced in places like Sacramento, which was hit especially hard during the downturn.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,171 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Quickly Zeroing In on New Places to Call Home
description: Finding a new place to live used to be all about hunting through the real estate pages of local newspapers or endless hours working through an agents files. If you were lucky, you would find a house or apartment to buy or rent that matched your needs and your wallet. But it could be a thankless and time-consuming task.

title: Search Tool on Facebook Puts Network to Work
description: Most Internet users have become accustomed to using Facebook to keep up with friends  or at least, Facebook friends  while using more specialized sites and apps to search for restaurants, books and people. But if you have built up a network of friends on Facebook, those connections can now help you find people, places and things in the real world, in ways that more specialized sites like Google, Yelp and Amazon cannot.

title: Mayor Vows to Veto Inspector for Police
description: Less than a day after the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, endorsed a bill to create an inspector general to oversee the Police Department, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday vowed to veto the proposal, assailing it as disastrous for public safety.

title: Appreciation of the Horse, Well-Cooked
description: MOSCOW  Uryuk, a chain of Uzbek teahouse restaurants with a dozen locations here, offers two types of horse sausage on its appetizer menu.

title: Now a Coach, Drew Aims to Take Valparaiso on Another N.C.A.A. Run
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  About 400 students and fans gathered Sunday at the Valparaiso student union to see which giant the Crusaders would play this March. Projection screens were set up in ballrooms. The N.C.A.A. tournament selection show was on.

title: Arizona: Tucson Schools Chief Resigns
description: The superintendent of the Tucson Unified School District, which has been shaken by a dispute over its Mexican-American studies program, announced his resignation on Wednesday. The superintendent, John Pedicone, is leaving on June 30, a year before his contract ends. Mr. Pedicone, the districts fifth superintendent in 10 years, said the departure would allow the districts governing board to choose a replacement in a nonelection year. Internal disagreements over the way the district handled the states targeting of its Mexican-American studies program, banned by legislation that said it fostered hatred against white people, pushed other educational efforts off course, he said. The district eliminated the program last year under financial threat from the state, but it must now create culturally relevant courses as part of an agreement to lift a federal desegregation order.

title: Wright Still Has Sights Set on Opening Day
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  David Wright of the Mets was prescribed five days of rest and treatment Friday when he was diagnosed with a strained intercostal muscle in his left rib cage. Five days have passed, and Wright still cannot do much more than rest and receive treatment.

title: California: 5 Ex-Officials Guilty of Inflating Pay
description: Five former officials from Bell, one of the poorest cities in Los Angeles County, were convicted Tuesday of multiple counts of misappropriating public money in a scheme to pay themselves inflated salaries of up to $100,000. The former mayor of the working-class city of 36,000, Oscar Hernandez, and four former City Council members  Teresa Jacobo, George Mirabal, George Cole and Victor Bello  were acquitted on other counts. The five appointed themselves to an oversight board, which met only once but increased their pay by more than $10,000. Another former council member, Luis Artiga, was acquitted on all counts. Mr. Artiga joined the council later than his co-defendants, after members salaries had already been raised. The defendants accused the former city manager, Robert Rizzo, who made nearly $800,000 a year, of masterminding the scheme. He will be tried separately.

title: Berlin Wont Join Effort to Ban Far-Right Party
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels center-right government said Wednesday that it would not try to ban a far-right political party deemed racist, anti-Semitic and revisionist by domestic intelligence, choosing instead to focus on combating neo-Nazi extremism through other channels.

title: Bittersweet Exits From Conferences, This Time in Rinks
description: As reporters and fans rhapsodized and lamented last week about the end of an era for the Big East mens basketball tournament, two of the oldest conferences in mens college hockey were going through similarly bittersweet celebrations of rivalries and relationships.

title: Marcum Dealing With Shoulder Issue
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  The spring training health concerns continued to pile up Wednesday for the Mets, as the team announced the right-hander Shaun Marcum had flown to New York to receive a cortisone shot Tuesday for a shoulder impingement.

title: New York Governor Favors Easing Newly Passed Gun Law
description: ALBANY  In the wake of the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn., Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York pushed through the State Legislature gun control measures that included not only a tougher assault weapons ban but also a tighter restriction on the maximum legal capacity of gun magazines.

title: Student Loan Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: A Forewarning on Fracking
description: To the Editor:

title: Yearning for Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Women Have What It Takes to Lead?
Reflecting on Iraq, a Decade Later
A Humble Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: Ovarian Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Villagers Take On Taliban in Their Heartland
description: PISHIN GAN SAYEDAN, Afghanistan  An uprising against the Taliban that began last month in this southern Afghan village has now spread through dozens of others, according to residents and Afghan and American officials, in the most significant popular turning against the Islamist insurgents in recent years.

title: Biden and Mayor to Meet on Gun Policy
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will meet on Thursday with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and families of some of the shooting victims from the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn.

title: Hiding the Smokes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose antismoking policies have cut smoking rates substantially in New York City, now wants to ban open displays of cigarettes or tobacco in stores. It is hard to know whether hiding the products would really work to discourage smoking. But the hope is that keeping cigarettes out of sight could help prevent young people from developing this deadly habit.

title: Deterring Predatory Lending
description: JPMorgan Chase has instituted new policies intended to shield customers from predatory lenders who can charge 500 percent interest or more and who drain the borrowers bank account through automatic withdrawals.

title: Firearms and Domestic Violence
description: A man abuses and threatens his ex-wife. She tells a judge that she is frightened and that he is armed. The court orders him to stay away from her. Should it also order him to give up his guns?

title: In Praise of Priestly Marriage
description: Annapolis, Md.

title: My Prayer: Let Women Be Priests
description: Columbus, Ga.

title: Moving Day(s)
description: After 44 years the Exploratorium, San Franciscos interactive science museum, left its home at the Palace of Fine Arts for a new location along the citys eastern waterfront.

title: New Contract for New Mexicos Alford
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Before New Mexico began its N.C.A.A. tournament practice Wednesday, in preparation for its West Region game against Harvard, Coach Steve Alford got a raise. Some job security as well.

title: A War, Before and After, Part 5
description: This is the fifth part of a six-part series.

title: Wedding Bells
description: I was at the Library of Congress the other day, doing some research in Justice Harry A. Blackmuns collected papers there (an amazing gift that keeps on giving to anyone interested in the history of the Supreme Court in the last three decades of the 20th century). Thinking about the same-sex marriage cases that the court will hear next week, it occurred to me to see whether Justice Blackmun, who annotated nearly every piece of paper that came across his desk, had recorded any thoughts about a case that arrived at the court in 1971, Baker v. Nelson.

title: The Sequester Hits the Reservation
description: The Congressional Republicans who brought us the mindless budget cuts known as the sequester have shown remarkable indifference to life-sustaining government services, American jobs and other programs. So what do they make of the countrys commitments to American Indians, its longstanding obligations to tribal governments under the Constitution and treaties dating back centuries?

title: The War in Washington Square
description: LAST week the faculty of arts and science of New York University approved a no-confidence resolution against the universitys president, John Sexton. I had introduced the resolution in December, and in the ensuing months it generated one of the largest campus debates in recent memory. The final no-confidence vote, the first in N.Y.U. history, was decisive: 298 to 224.

title: Companies: Show Us the Money
description: ON Tuesday, the Senate Banking Committee gave Mary Jo White, President Obamas choice to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, a rousing show of support, voting 21 to 1 to send her nomination to the full Senate for a vote. Ms. White, who is likely to be confirmed as the S.E.C. chairwoman, will need that bipartisan backing as she takes on a host of challenges at the nations top financial regulator.

title: Reaching Those on the Wrong Side of the Digital Divide
description: THE Advertising Council and Connect2Compete, a nonprofit group whose goal is to eliminate the digital divide in the United States, are introducing a public service campaign to help those who are not digitally literate find free training to obtain these skills.

title: Yankees Aces Under Watchful Eyes
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Away from the spotlight that is always there when the Yankees play the Red Sox, even if it is a spring training game, the teams former and current pitching aces toiled under watchful eyes at the Yankees minor league training center Wednesday.

title: Manning Open to Redoing His Deal to Keep Cruz
description: Eli Manning compiled roughly a quarter of his 3,948 passing yards last season on completions to Victor Cruz. Manning tossed 10 of his 26 touchdown passes to the salsa-dancing Cruz, too. Now, as Cruzs status with the Giants remains at a contractual impasse, Manning has said he would be willing to sacrifice to keep Cruz as one of his top targets.

title: Man Charged With Plotting Against U.S. Abroad
description: A man who prosecutors said was an overseas operative of Al Qaeda during the years following the Sept. 11 attacks was charged in Brooklyn with a host of terrorism charges, in the latest example of a foreigner accused of acts of terrorism abroad being extradited to American courts.

title: The Kids Left Behind by the Boom
description: Lima, Peru

title: Syracuses Boeheim Plays Down Reports About Investigations
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim played down the latest reports about investigations into his basketball program, suggesting that there was nothing new to revelations on Wednesday, the day before the Oranges N.C.A.A. tournament opener against Montana.

title: Decrepit Stable in Queens Is Shut Down After 6 Horses Die
description: One horse died after becoming tangled in its head collar. Two horses in the barn died from old age, while another died shortly after it was born. Two more died of causes that could not be determined.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 20, 2013

title: Perus Poor
description: In an op-ed, Marie Arana writes:

title: Known for 3-Point Prowess, Underdog Expands Its Attack
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Rick Byrd became the basketball coach at Belmont in 1986, the same year the N.C.A.A. universally put in the 3-point line. Byrd considered himself a basketball purist, and still does. Initially, he did not care for the new rule or the strange arc.

title: Harry Reems, Star of Deep Throat Film, Dies at 65
description: Harry Reems, whose starring role in Deep Throat in 1972 made him Americas first bona fide male porn star  and whose life, more than most, embodied the time-honored American narrative of fame, failure and redemption  died on Tuesday in Salt Lake City, Utah. He was 65.

title: Neurosurgeons Speeches Have Conservatives Dreaming of 2016
description: BALTIMORE  Dr. Benjamin Carson was a political unknown just weeks ago.

title: Henry Bromell, Writer of TV Dramas, Dies at 65
description: Henry Bromell, who wrote short stories for The New Yorker 40 years ago and later stumbled into a career writing, directing and producing television shows, including Northern Exposure, Homicide: Life on the Street and the more recent hit Homeland, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 65.

title: Dempsey Named U.S. Captain
description: COMMERCE CITY, Colo.  Clint Dempsey will wear the captains armband on Friday night when the United States faces Costa Rica in a World Cup qualifying match.

title: Bobbie Smith, Voice of the Spinners, Dies at 76
description: Bobbie Smith, whose mellifluous vocals helped make the Spinners one of the leading soul acts of the 1970s, died on Saturday in Orlando, Fla. He was 76.

title: Corrections: March 21, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Cyberspace Space
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Puzzle blogging makes me hungry. Or maybe Im just too susceptible to subliminal suggestion. Its just that there are so many references to food in the puzzles, and when you sit all day and solve puzzles with food references in them, it starts to get to you.

title: More Waifish Than Wild, the Ingnue Returns
description: Holly Golightly does not. Go lightly, that is. The new stage adaptation of Breakfast at Tiffanys, Truman Capotes beloved portrait of a glamorous waif in 1940s New York, moves with a distinctly leaden step, as if it dreaded what might be waiting around every dark corner of the sinister city it portrays.

title: Fab Five, All Family
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  If the N.C.A.A. held a coed basketball tournament of families  your five against their five, all the way through the bracket  the Tinkles of Missoula, Mont., would be the runaway favorite, seeded first over all.

title: Canada: Possible Drug Use by Pilot Helped Cause Crash, Report Suggests
description: The impairment of a pilot and marginal weather led to the crash of a commercial flight of a small turboprop plane in Canadas far north that killed two people and injured two others, a report released on Wednesday said. The Transportation Safety Board said that urine, blood and lung fluid tests of the pilot, who died after the Air Tindi flight crashed in October 2011, showed levels of the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana that were well above those known to cause impairment.

title: Man Convicted in Rabbis Killing Faces Freedom With Apprehension
description: David Ranta once worked as a printer, though he is not certain that such jobs exist anymore.

title: Mandatory Use of Visors a Hot Topic
description: TORONTO  Mandatory visors, goalie equipment and a coachs review were the subjects that dominated nearly seven hours of the N.H.L. general managers meetings Wednesday and several recommendations will be made during the competition committee meetings at the Stanley Cup final.

title: The Face of Future Health Care
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  When people talk about the future of health care, Kaiser Permanente is often the model they have in mind.

title: Northern Ireland: Judge Holds 2 Liable in Bombing by I.R.A. Splinter Group
description: A Belfast judge ruled on Wednesday that two alleged leaders of the Real Irish Republican Army were liable for damages in the 1998 Omagh car bombing that killed 29 civilians and wounded 200 others. Justice John Gillen told a Belfast court the case against Colm Murphy and Seamus Daly was overwhelming. The police have failed to win any criminal convictions in the bombing, the most deadly single attack during the years of violence known as the Troubles.

title: H.P.s Board Wins Re-election, but Change May Be Coming Anyway
description: Members of Hewlett-Packards board dodged a bullet Wednesday.

title: James Madison Defeats L.I.U. to Advance
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Jim Boeheim played down the latest reports about investigations into his program, suggesting that there was nothing new to the revelations on Wednesday, the day before the Orange open the tournament against Montana.

title: Current Laws May Offer Little Shield Against Drones, Senators Are Told
description: WASHINGTON  Targeted killings have made drones controversial, but a new class of tiny aircraft in the United States  cheap, able and ubiquitous  could engage in targeted snooping that existing laws are inadequate to address, witnesses and members of the Senate Judiciary Committee said in a hearing on Wednesday.

title: China: Leader Says He Wants to Ease Tensions Between Two Koreas
description: Chinas newly appointed president, Xi Jinping, left, spoke to his South Korean counterpart, Park Geun-hye, by telephone on Wednesday, and told her that his government wanted to help ease tensions between the two Koreas. China has long served as the Norths political and economic mainstay, but it also seeks to keep close ties with the South, which is a much larger trade partner. The South and North are compatriots, and relations between them are of vital importance for the peninsula, Mr. Xi told Ms. Park, according to a statement by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. China is willing to provide the necessary assistance to encourage bilateral reconciliation and cooperation between the South and North. Relations between the Koreas have been especially tense since North Korea staged a nuclear test last month and the United Nations responded with sanctions, infuriating the North.

title: Stop-and-Frisk Trial Turns to Claim of Arrest Quotas
description: For the first two days, the trial focused on sidewalks and street corners from Harlem to Flatbush, as African-American men testified about how they were stopped by the police.

title: Four Share a History: Nobody Believed in Us
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The wily bracket-crafters on the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee missed a chance to create a blissful sort of havoc at Rupp Arena on Thursday afternoon. If only they had also slotted the tournament sweethearts Gonzaga and Virginia Commonwealth and Valparaiso and, why not, Northwestern State in a pod already teeming with upstarts.

title: Sacrifice Pays Off for Guard, and Iona
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.  Lamont Joness willingness to put family above all else has helped Iona reach the N.C.A.A. tournament in consecutive seasons for the first time since 2000 and 2001.

title: Late-Night Shuffle
description: A look at more than two decades of shifting schedules and fortunes in late-night talk shows.

title: Runner Who Died During Half Marathon Is Identified
description: The runner who collapsed and died in Sundays New York City Half, a 13.1-mile run around Manhattan, has been identified as John Tanner, 46, of Marlborough, Mass. He had a heart attack about 9:10 a.m. just past the races 12-mile marker, the police said.

title: As Senate Passes Spending Measure, Stark Budget Views Are on Display in House
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate passed a spending measure on Wednesday to keep the government financed through the end of September, resolving one contentious budget fight as Congress moved quickly to the next.

title: Sex Charges in Connecticut Are Dissected on Internet
description: It took nearly two weeks for the authorities in Connecticut to make the first arrests involving claims that athletes at Torrington High School had sexually assaulted 13-year-old girls.

title: Document Suggests Abbass Desire to Resume Israeli Talks
description: CAIRO  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority is so eager to return to peace talks with the Israelis that he may soften his demand that Israels president publicly pledge to halt construction of new settlements on Palestinian land before such negotiations can resume.

title: The Knicks World Looks Brighter After Anthony Returns
description: For the first time in three weeks, Carmelo Anthony left a basketball court with his head up, his right knee nimble, his smile bright and his team victorious. That was all the Knicks could have asked for Wednesday night, after a frightful month of diagnostic tests and doctor visits that ravaged the roster.

title: Ailing Knicks Content With Players They Have
description: You could call Knicks Coach Mike Woodson stubborn about the status of his roster as more and more of his players  especially the older ones  become injured. Or you could say Woodson is faithful to his players, especially the veterans he brought to New York.

title: Q. and A. on Obamas Trip to Israel
description: Last Updated, 12:11 p.m. Jodi Rudoren, Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times, answered questions from readers, including on Facebook and Twitter, on the first day of President Obamas trip to Israel as president. We distilled questions asked by several readers and included a few specific examples posed on the social networks.

title: Angles of Attack for Israels Iron Dome Missile System
description: Skeptics say the Israelis have exaggerated the success rate of the Iron Dome missile system and that the odds of destruction depend critically on how the interceptor approaches the rocket.

title: Weapons Experts Raise Doubts About Israels Antimissile System
description: After President Obama arrived in Israel, his first stop on Wednesday was to inspect an installation of Iron Dome, the antimissile system hailed as a resounding success in the Gaza conflict in November. The photo op, celebrating a technological wonder built with the help of American dollars, came with considerable symbolism as Mr. Obama sought to showcase support for Israel after years of tensions over Jewish settlements and how to curb Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: Physical Wichita State Team Looks to Exceed Expectations
description: SALT LAKE CITY  There are some unlikely N.C.A.A. tournament teams here. Southern qualifies. So does Harvard.

title: Resistance and Scant Support Sealed Fate of Push for Assault Weapons Ban
description: WASHINGTON  As she stood surrounded by gunshot victims and displays of firearms in January to announce her intention to renew the push for an assault weapons ban after the massacre in Newtown, Conn., Senator Dianne Feinstein all but conceded defeat.

title: Friend or Foe? For a Game, at Least, There May Be Confusion
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  Shaka Smart considers Keith Dambrot to be among his best friends. Dambrot joked this week that he and Smart knew each other so well, they could probably trade sidelines and coach each others teams.

title: Now in Pinstripes, Youkilis Greets His Former Team
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Kevin Youkilis knows what it is like to passionately root for a sports team. A native of Cincinnati, he has been a lifelong Bengals fan.

title: The Republican Autopsy Report
description: On Monday a Republican task force released a remarkably hard-headed diagnosis of the partys many liabilities: its ideological rigidity, its preference for the rich over workers, its alienation of minorities, its reactionary social policies and its institutionalized repression of dissent and innovation.

title: Rising Stars in Republican Party Compete for the Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  They are supposed to be natural allies: two relatively young conservatives from the Tea Party wing of the Republican Party who ascended to the Senate in the Republican sweep of 2010 and already figure prominently in the early chatter for 2016.

title: Rebooted Big East Makes a Splash in Manhattan
description: The new Big East could not have chosen a more appropriate site for its launch party: the Manhattan headquarters of News Corporation. The conferences seed money  and more  is coming from Fox Sports 1, News Corporations new sports network.

title: Louisville Starting Its Run in the Home of Its Rival
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The question about Kentucky was posed thus to Peyton Siva, the superlative senior point guard for Louisville: Is there part of you that kind of takes a little satisfaction  not only are you guys the No. 1 seed, but you are playing here, and theyre not even in the N.I.T. anymore?

title: Nets Win, With Points and Scowls to Spare
description: DALLAS  Brook Lopez, the Nets often overlooked 7-foot center, stroked a shot in the third quarter, holding his pose an extra second, as if he knew Wednesday night would be special.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Mar. 21, 2013
description: If you can separate two Siamese twins, maybe you can separate Democrats and Republicans in Washington.

title: The Art of the Dealer
description: Part shrewd salesman, part cultivated European, the gallery owner David Zwirner has built a blue-chip empire with a sharp eye and a steady hand.

title: Costly Bank Payday Loans Criticized in Report
description: Some of the nations largest banks continue to offer payday loans, pitched as advances on direct-deposit paychecks, despite growing regulatory scrutiny and mounting criticism about the short-term, high-cost loans.

title: Windfalls for Wall Street Executives Taking Jobs in Government
description: People usually say they go into government to perform public service. If they came from Wall Street, however, their former employers often provide another service.

title: From Sleep Study, Clues to Happiness
description: A little over a decade ago, scientists discovered that narcolepsy, the neurological disorder that leads to episodes of irresistible sleepiness, is caused by the loss of brain cells that produce hypocretin, a neurotransmitter that promotes wakefulness.

title: SFX Entertainment Buys Major Stake in Dutch Festival Promoter
description: As corporations hear the siren call of electronic dance music, the deals keep getting bigger.

title: Pediatrics Group Backs Gay Marriage, Saying It Helps Children
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics declared its support for same-sex marriage for the first time on Thursday, saying that allowing gay and lesbian parents to marry if they so choose is in the best interests of their children.

title: Word of the Day |  jaunt
description: jaunt \jnt, jnt\ noun and verb

title: Soccer Apps We Like
description: If you cannot get to the game, what could be better than having the game come to you on your smartphone or tablet or both. Most of the apps below also provide access to news, video and other content.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 9 P.M. (13) THE TEMPEST The British composer Thomas Ads conducts the Metropolitan Opera premiere of his English-language opera based on the Shakespeare play, in a production staged by Robert Lepage. Simon Keenlyside leads the cast as the exiled magician Prospero, who in this setting imagines himself an impresario of 18th-century opera and has recreated on his island the opera house La Scala, from his hometown, Milan. Isabel Leonard plays his daughter, Miranda; Alek Shrader is the shipwrecked prince, Ferdinand; Alan Oke (above), is the monstrous island native Caliban; and Audrey Luna is the spirit Ariel. Writing in The New York Times, Anthony Tommasini called the production, presented here by Great Performances at the Met, one of the most inspired, audacious and personal operas to have come along in years. Mr. Ads, he added, drew a textured, glittering and suspenseful account of his opera from the great Met orchestra.

title: News Quiz | March 21, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Farming a Beach
description: BORALAPAR, Assam  Jagot Chekanidhara, a 50-year-old local schoolteacher, mounds up a wall of sand. Nearby, his sister Lakhimi digs a row of holes. It looks like seaside fun-in-the-sun, but this is no beach and no childs play.

title: As Hacking Continues, Concerns Grow That Chinese-Americans May Suffer
description: BEIJING  As tensions build between Washington and Beijing over cyberattacks, with a growing body of evidence that much of the hacking is coming from China and that the United States is a major target, as The New York Times has reported, are Chinese-Americans feeling the pressure? Are they concerned that growing suspicions about Chinas intentions toward the United States may cause them to suffer greater discrimination?

title: IHT Quick Read: March 21
description: NEWS An uprising against the Taliban that began last month in a southern Afghan village has now spread through dozens of others, according to residents and Afghan and American officials, in the most significant popular turning against the Islamist insurgents in recent years. Carlotta Gall reports from Pishin Gan Sayedan, Afghanistan.

title: Australian Prime Minister Survives Ouster Attempt
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Julia Gillard on Thursday survived an effort by a senior lawmaker within her own party to oust her from her job, after her predecessor Kevin Rudd, whom she deposed in a 2010 party coup, unexpectedly declined to run against her.

title: Library of Congress Makes Room for Simon & Garfunkel, Van Cliburn and the Ramones
description: Whatever Simon & Garfunkel meant by Sounds of Silence, those sounds will now reverberate in perpetuity  whether silently or otherwise  along with works by Van Cliburn, Pink Floyd, the Ramones and many other artists whose musical creations will be added to the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress.

title: AstraZeneca Makes a Bet on an Untested Technique
description: The troubled drug giant AstraZeneca, which is overhauling its research operations, is betting at least $240 million that a novel but untested technology from a small biotechnology company can provide it with a huge array of new drugs.

title: The Legacies of Iraq: An Ailing Press and an Invade or Nothing Foreign Policy
description: American households will be blanketed this week by a torrent of coverage, commentary and regret about the 10th anniversary of the Iraq war. Liberals claim that Twitter  if it had existed  could have stopped the invasion. Conservatives argue that the links between Saddam Hussein and terrorism have, in fact, been underplayed.

title: Obama Urges Young Israelis to Lead the Push for Peace
description: JERUSALEM  President Obama, appealing to very disparate audiences to solve one of the worlds thorniest problems, moved closer on Thursday to the Israeli governments position on resuming long-stalled peace talks with the Palestinians, even as he passionately implored young Israelis to get ahead of their own leaders in the push for peace.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 21, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Subway Worker Freed After Hours Stuck in Mud.

title: A Strategy for Opposing Same-Sex Marriage
description: In Young Opponents of Same-Sex Marriage Undaunted, Ashley Parker writes about young people who want to reverse a seeming shift of public opinion in favor of gay marriage.

title: Toppling Saddam and a Wars Coverage
description: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: The London Whale, Richard Fisher and Cyprus
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: What Makes You Happy?
description: The United Nations declared March 20 the first International Day of Happiness, declaring that the pursuit of happiness is a fundamental human goal.

title: What Indias New Anti-Rape Bill Actually Says
description: NEW DELHIAfter clearing the Lok Sabha or lower house of Parliament earlier this week, a bill to toughen Indias laws on sexual offenses is being debated in the upper house on Thursday.

title: North Korea Threatens U.S. Military Bases in Pacific
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Thursday threatened to attack American military bases in Japan and on the Pacific island of Guam in retaliation for recent training missions by American B-52 bombers over South Korea.

title: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
description: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blogs Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

title: The Early Word: Elbows
description: In Todays Times:In Israel for the first time since he took office in 2009, President Obama intends to convey a message that he cares about Israel and will do whatever is necessary to protect its people from enemies, Mark Landler and Jodi Rudoren write. On Thursday, Mr. Obama is scheduled to meet with the president of the Palestinian Authority before giving a speech in Jerusalem that will address the need for a renewed peace effort.

title: The Doctors New Prescription: A Lawyer
description: Consider the geriatricians working at the Lakeside Senior Medical Center, an outpatient clinic at the University of California, San Francisco. Many of their patients, despite multiple chronic diseases and advanced age, have never filled out power-of-attorney documents or appointed someone to make health care decisions if they are unable to.

title: The (G)loved Ones
description: It has been a rough couple of weeks for a top American goalkeeper and national team stalwart.

title: Mood Darkens in Cyprus as Deadline Is Set for Bailout
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  As the European Central Bank threatened to shut off crucial financing for banks in Cyprus without a rapid accord on an international bailout, members of Parliament put off a vote on Thursday on yet another revamped formula. The vote was rescheduled for Friday.

title: Daily Report: New Reasons to Change Light Bulbs
description: For use in the lamps and light sockets of your home, LED bulbs have been slow to arrive, mainly because of their high price.

title: When You Hire the Right Person for the Wrong Position
description: The interview process had been exhaustive, and my co-founder and I were pleased. We had put an expert in pay-per-click-advertising through a series of tests, and he emerged on the other side of the process having demonstrated his deep proficiency in this customer-acquisition channel. After checking multiple references and having an additional meeting to ensure that he fit our culture, we hired our new expert in direct marketing.

title: The King of Cliftonia
description: LONDON  General Pervez Musharraf has announced his intention to return to Pakistan this Sunday. The countrys former president and army chief is coming home as a civilian politician to contest an ordinary parliamentary seat in elections scheduled for May.

title: Bollywoods Sanjay Dutt Will Go to Prison
description: Indias highest court upheld the conviction of the Bollywood star Sanjay Dutt on charges of illegal possession of guns supplied by the masterminds of the 1993 Mumbai bombings, but it reduced his prison sentence by a year to five years.

title: Obama in Israel
description: President Obama spruces up U.S.-Israeli ties.

title: Sectarian Clashes Are Reported in Central Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  At least five people have been killed in fighting between Buddhists and Muslims in central Myanmar, residents and a hospital official said Thursday, in another sign of a resurgence of communal violence that is testing the countrys fledgling democracy.

title: Deals Like Lews Arent Uncommon
description: Jacob J. Lew, the new Treasury secretary, was asked pointed questions during his confirmation hearing about a deal with his former employer, Citigroup, that guaranteed him preferential financial treatment if he left for government service. But according to a new study, such arrangements are not so unusual on Wall Street, DealBooks Susanne Craig reports.

title: Standard Chartered Chairman Retracts Comments on Sanctions Settlement With U.S.
description: LONDON  John W. Peace, chairman of the British bank Standard Chartered, on Thursday retracted statements about the banks recent settlement with American authorities over violations of sanctions laws.

title: Ken Levine Talks About His New Video Game
description: Through a combination of obsessive hard work, an affable personality and marketing savvy, Ken Levine has become one of the most beloved creators of narratively fulfilling, big-budget video games. Not only do his BioShock games sell well (the first sold more than five million copies), but they are also taught in colleges and parsed in the same way as, say, David Lynchs film Mulholland Drive was analyzed by critics.

description: Dear Diary:

title: The Nerd as Auteur in BioShock Infinite
description: QUINCY, MASS.  The office here that houses Irrational Games isnt listed on a building directory. The company door is unmarked and locked. And the maze of rooms that many people would want to see behind that door  the studio where one of the years most anticipated video games is being readied for release on Tuesday  is harder to find.

title: Opinion Report: The Indian Health Service
description: From the editorial page

title: Q&A: Seeing Ads on Twitter
description: Q.

title: Cyprus: The Sum of All FUBAR
description: At this point the Cyprus situation is pretty clear  and clarity does not bring reassurance. In fact, it looks as if Cyprus has managed to combine in one place everything that has gone wrong elsewhere.

title: Hezbollah Courier Found Guilty in Plot to Attack Israeli Tourists in Cyprus
description: BERLIN  In a decision that could have significant repercussions for Hezbollahs operations in Europe, a court in Cyprus on Thursday found a man guilty of participating in a plot to attack Israeli tourists there, part of a conspiracy similar to a deadly bombing last July in Bulgaria.

title: Thursday Reading: Finding Frugal Gems in Chongqing
Brother of Galleon Groups Rajaratnam Is Indicted on Insider Trading Charges
description: 6:41 p.m. | Updated

title: A Kurdish Spring on Many Fronts
description: LONDON  Abdullah Ocalan, the jailed leader of the rebel Kurdish Workers Party, or P.K.K., called for a ceasefire Thursday in the three-decade war between Kurdish rebels and the Turkish state, giving a new impetus to New Year celebrations by Kurds.

title: The End of War Stories
description: I cant remember the last time I told a real war story  the kind you recount with waving arms and an animated voice, impersonating friends you havent talked to in years. The kind you really get into.

title: Setting Themes of Humility, a New Archbishop of Canterbury Is Installed
description: LONDON  At his installation as archbishop of Canterbury on Thursday, Justin Welby, a former oil executive who made an unusually rapid rise to the leadership of the Anglican Church, used the ceremony in Canterburys nine-century-old cathedral to set themes of simplicity, modesty and innovation that echoed the tone Pope Francis has set for his week-old papacy.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Fallon to Become Host of Tonight and Ads Aim to Close Digital Divide
description: NBC has made a commitment to make Jimmy Fallon, the 38-year-old host of its Late Night show, the host of the Tonight show and to move the show from Burbank, Calif., back to New York, Bill Carter reports. Mr. Fallon would succeed Jay Leno, who will turn 63 next month and whose show still regularly leads the late-night ratings. The change would by fall 2014 at the latest. NBC has been desperate to avoid acrimony that often surrounds one of the biggest changes in late-night television; their attempt to replace Mr. Leno with Conan OBrien three years ago ended with recriminations and a reversal, as Mr. Leno was reinstated and NBC endured weeks of negative coverage.

title: Microsoft Releases Report on Law Enforcement Requests
description: Microsoft disclosed for the first time on Thursday the number of requests it had received from government law enforcement agencies for data on its hundreds of millions of customers around the world, joining the ranks of Google, Twitter and other Web businesses that publish so-called transparency reports.

title: House of Cards Recap, Episode 8: You Can Go Home Again, It Just Might Get Complicated
description: Deep into House of Cards and wondering what it all means? You are not the only one. Ashley Parker and David Carr read between the lines of episode eight in search of a deeper message.

title: Scientists Propose a New Architecture for Sustainable Development
description: As a United Nations working group negotiates a set of sustainable development goals, 10 scientists and development analysts, in a commentary published today in Nature, have proposed a fundamentally different way to frame this concept. (Click here for relevant Dot Earth posts.)

title: India Passes Sweeping Bill on Crimes Against Women
description: NEW DELHI  Less than three months after a New Delhi woman who was gang raped on a moving bus died from her injuries, Indias Parliament passed a comprehensive bill that imposes stronger penalties on men who attack women and criminalizes offenses like stalking and voyeurism.

title: Timeline on Irans Nuclear Program
description: Whether Iran is racing toward nuclear weapon capabilities is one of the most contentious foreign-policy issues challenging the West.

title: Parents of the Touch-Screen Generation, Dont Free Your iPad Yet
description: Every weekend morning, one or the other of my younger children appears early. He or she creeps to the side of my bed, and for a brief moment, I can feel the childs thoughtful, assessing gaze, but I dont move. There is usually a pause. Waking Mommy can be a dangerous proposition. But its worth it for the prize. Mommy, the child whispers, can I have your iPad?

title: Changing the Culture of College Application
description: When Central Magnet High School opened in Bridgeport, Conn., almost 30 years ago, few of its students thought about applying to selective colleges.

title: What Were Reading
description: NPR: Parents worried about their childrens weight often give them low-fat milk. But studies show that preschoolers who drank it were heavier than those who consumed whole milk.  Patrick Farrell

title: Linking Past and Present in Nuremberg
description: This will be easy to see, said Annelise, our guide, flipping off the lights in the chilly sandstone beer cellar that had been converted to an air-raid shelter during World War II. A small plaque on the wall glowed with electric-lime phosphorescence. It was, she told us, an emergency exit sign for the 50,000 civilians who had fled  two to a square meter  to these cellars-cum-bunkers during Allied firebombings.

title: Charlestons Cousin Gets in the Picture
description: An award from This Old House Magazine is just part of a new story being told in North Charleston, S.C.

title: Restaurant Report: Orquideas in Vieques, P.R.
description: With Caribbean Sea views and a soundtrack of lapping waves, its hard to deny the appeal of the Malecn, the esplanade in the village of Esperanza that traces Puerto Real, a bay on the southern shore of Vieques, P.R. So its no surprise that the Malecn is home to the islands highest concentration of restaurants. With such attractive real estate, they have to be only passable to be packed; for the same reason, those even a block from the water must be twice as good to garner equal attention.

title: Okay Expectations
description: The Federal Reserve has trimmed its forecast for growth in 2013, but not by much and not by as much as might have been expected given that Washington is forging ahead with ill-advised budget cuts. In these days of diminished expectations, that passes for good news.

title: A Tale of Two Frozen Lakes
description: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee in Antarctica.

title: Mexican New Yorkers Are More Likely to Live in Poor Households
description: People of Mexican descent in New York City are far more likely to be living in poor or near-poor households than other Latinos, blacks, whites or Asians, according to a study to be released on Thursday.

title: Executives Press European Antitrust Chief on Google
description: BERLIN  With the European antitrust inquiry into Googles search engine practices entering a third year, a group of 11 Web companies sent a joint letter to the top antitrust official in Europe on Thursday, asking him to compel Google to change its business practices to ensure that smaller rivals are not unfairly harmed.

title: Fran Warren, Singer in Big-Band Era, Dies at 87
description: Fran Warren, one of the last surviving singing stars of the big-band era, died at her home in Brookfield, Conn., on March 4, her 87th birthday.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Inviting Confusion

title: Marvels Age of Ultron  Features Controversial Angel
description: In Age of Ultron, a story currently being published by Marvel Comics, the Avengers and their allies are on the ropes against their archenemy Ultron, an artificial intelligence who has taken over the world. The story concludes in June and will feature a special guest star: the angel Angela, a character created by the writer Neil Gaiman and the artist Todd McFarlane for Spawn, published by Image Comics.

title: Court Says South Korean Dictator, Father of Current President, Violated Constitution
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Three emergency decrees issued in the 1970s by South Koreas dictator at the time, Park Chung-hee, were unconstitutional, the nations Constitutional Court ruled on Thursday, in a landmark verdict on the legacy of the current presidents father.

title: NBCs Late-Night Dream
description: The Timess Brian Stelter on NBCs hopes to win younger viewers by replacing the host of The Tonight Show, Jay Leno, with Jimmy Fallon.

title: The Gun Report: March 21, 2013
description: I was in Detroit on Wednesday, and as I passed the airport newsstand, I did a double-take when I saw the headline in the Detroit Free Press. Grandma Guilty of Murder, it read: Teens 911 cry for help sways jury. The article reported on the end of a murder trial in which Sandra Layne, a 75-year-old West Bloomfield woman, shot to death her 17-year-old grandson. Jonathan Hoffmans parents had moved to Arizona, where their daughter was undergoing multiple surgeries for a brain tumor. Their son had stayed behind in Michigan to finish high school, moving in with his grandparents.

title: Caroline Kennedy: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Poems to Learn by Heart loves books about the Inquisition and the crusades, but feels guilty reading bad things about the Catholic Church.

title: Girls in the Band
description: Mariachi Flor de Toloache, a New York band, may be the first all-female mariachi ensemble in the city.

title: Highlights and Analysis of N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin, Times editors and reporters break down the first full day of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Paul Rose, Quebec Separatist Involved in a Kidnapping and Murder, Dies at 69
description: Paul Rose, a strident Quebec separatist leader who in October 1970 helped kidnap and, he claimed, strangle a provincial official, inflaming a crisis that pitted terrorists against the Canadian prime minister, Pierre Trudeau, died March 14 in Montreal. He was 69.

title: Shes Not Impressed? Then Youre Not In
description: The timing of Admission, Paul Weitzs new comedy, is either clever or cruel  perhaps both. In the next few weeks, word will go forth from colleges across the land about who is in and who is out, as the American higher-education-industrial complex enacts its own Darwinian version of Project Runway. As the father of a high school junior, paying my tithe to the test prep gods while preparing to sacrifice most of my worldly goods on the altar of the liberal arts, I cant tell if Im part of the intended audience, or if the ratings board should issue a special warning for sensitive parents like me. How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?

title: Ai Weiwei to Let 1,000 Tents Bloom in Germany
description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei plans to create a major installation at a festival in Germany this summer consisting of 1,000 tents set up along the Emscher River, the BBC reported.

title: Citigroup Banker Says Its Too Early to Toast a Revival in M.&A.
description: NEW ORLEANS  While many of the lawyers gathered here may be ready to toast an upswing in deals, one prominent mergers banker thinks it is too early to plan a party.

title: The Liberation of Paris
description: A vibrant group of young, adventurous and international chefs are breaking down barriers and revolutionizing the citys age-old Michelin-guarded culinary scene.

title: Scenes From Two Days at the Met
description: Behind the curtain at the Metropolitan Opera. In order of appearance: setup for La Rondine, set assembly for LElisir dAmore, stage rehearsal of Rigoletto and setup for Le Comte Ory.

title: The Epic Ups and Downs of Peter Gelb
description: Most mornings Peter Gelb, the 59-year-old general manager of the worlds most prominent opera company, rises between 4 a.m. and 5 a.m. The elegant Upper West Side duplex he shares with his wife is four blocks from Lincoln Center. He puts on a bathrobe and pads downstairs to the kitchen, where he turns on his La Pavoni espresso machine with the hand-levered piston that allows him to feel, amid all he cant control at the Metropolitan Opera, that he can at least control the quality of his coffee.
