He fixes a skim-milk cappuccino with two shots of espresso, eats a banana and then sits down in his home office, where the walls are decorated with autographed scores by Verdi, Puccini and Shostakovich and the shelves are filled with hundreds of CDs, including some by his great-uncle, the renowned violinist Jascha Heifetz. Gelb himself has no particular musical gift, but his ability to remain alert while attending 280 or so opera performances and rehearsals a year on apparently very little sleep qualifies him as a virtuoso of some sort.

title: 3 Tibetans Sentenced in Immolation Cases
description: BEIJING  Three Tibetans from Qinghai Province have been given prison sentences for inciting state secession, according to a statement on an official provincial Web site. On Monday, a court in Haidong Prefecture sentenced the Tibetans  Kalsang Dhondup, Jigme Thabkey and Lobsang  to terms of six, five and four years, respectively. The online announcement said that the men used self-immolations by Tibetans for publicity purposes and circulated texts and photographs related to Tibetan independence, spreading bad influence locally and internationally. Since 2009, at least 109 Tibetans have set fire to themselves to protest Chinese rule, and most have died. To deter the act, Chinese officials are trying to prosecute people associated with those who commit self-immolation. Tibetans opposed to Chinese rule say those who self-immolated did it out of frustration with Chinese policies.

title: You Wont Win, but the Heat Probably Will
description: It is officially underdog day (Part 1), when America is united in rooting for a bunch of guys we have never heard of toiling for a university we cannot find on a map, the only acceptable exception being when that bunch of guys can totally ruin your bracket. (And even then, expect office ridicule if you start rooting loudly for Duke.) Because we are all about the underdog, the Round of 64 in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament tapping into that vein in our national character. Hey, back in 1776, England was the big-money team with the overpaid coach and look what we did then. That was our first 3-pointer at the buzzer.

title: Spend Sunday Online With Pink Floyd
description: Back in the 1970s, fans of Pink Floyd were known to gather in small groups around their stereos, often in darkened living rooms, imbibe their drug of choice and listen to The Dark Side of the Moon in its entirety.

title: Workers Still Uneasy About Retirement Finances
description: Americans remain uneasy about their retirement finances despite a brightening economic outlook  perhaps because it is dawning on them just how much they have to save, a long-running survey finds.

title: Robert Parker vs. Antonio Galloni
description: Just five weeks after the wine critic Antonio Galloni left Robert M. Parker Jr.s Wine Advocate to start his own Web venture, The Advocate is suing him in federal court on charges that include breach of contract and fraud, according to Courthouse News Service.

title: An All-Female Band, Making Its Way in the World of Mariachi
description: One is German, another a New Yorker of Egyptian descent. Others are Cuban-American, Colombian, Dominican and Argentine.

title: President May Be Quarterback, but Today Congress Plays a Different Game
description: WASHINGTON  Like quarterbacks in football, presidents are central to most Washington stories. So discussion of budget gridlock often revolves around whetherPresident Obama plays as effectively as his predecessors.

title: Poetry Pairing | Some keep the Sabbath going to Church
description: To mark the coming of Passover and Holy Week, our Poetry Pairing this week matches Some keep the Sabbath going to Church, by Emily Dickinson, with A Religious Ritual Attracts Even Nonbelievers by Mark Oppenheimer.

title: Image of the Day: March 21
Doctors and Their Online Reputation
description: When a doctor I know recently signed up for a Twitter account, his colleagues began teasing him. Are you going to tweet what you eat? one joked.

title: Door Shut on South Korea-Syria Match
description: It is hard to imagine in the midst of the bloody Syrian conflict anything happening other than the daily task of survival. Yet despite the descent into chaos, the Syrian national team has remained intact, escaping the implosion of its country.

title: Path to Citizenship for Immigrants Draws Support Across Party Lines, Survey Finds
description: Nearly two-thirds of Americans favor giving illegal immigrants in the country an opportunity for legal status with a path to citizenship, according to a poll published Thursday by the Public Religion Research Institute and the Brookings Institution. Support for an earned path to citizenship for those immigrants came from 71 percent of Democrats and also a majority, 53 percent, of Republicans, the poll found.

title: Lean In
description: To the Editor:

title: My New Office: A Parking Space
description: Before my fianc, James, and I bought our first car, we discussed money, fantasy vacation homes, insurance, pleather, climate control, climate change and unborn children. But perhaps more important was what we didnt discuss. And that was parking. We spent about 30 seconds on it.

title: House Passes Money Bill and Budget Blueprint
description: WASHINGTON  The House gave final approval on Thursday to legislation to keep government financed through September, and it also passed a Republican blueprint that enshrined the partys vision of a balanced budget that would substantially shrink spending, privatize Medicare and rewrite the tax code to make it simpler.

title: Senate Panel Approves Obamas Choice for Interior Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas nominee to lead the Interior Department, Sally Jewell, cleared her first hurdle on the way to confirmation on Thursday, winning approval of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee by a large bipartisan margin.

title: Redemptions Advocate
description: Most Americans dont think or talk much about the way prisons in this country are funded or run. We want a vague, blanket assurance that our politicians and their appointees are being tough on crime. We pay attention to verdicts and to sentences but not to what happens afterward, to the experience that a convicted criminal has over the years before he or she most likely reenters society. We forgetor we simply dont bother to recognizethat the nature of this experience has an effect on whether the criminal breaks the law again. We want to feel safe, and yet were utterly uneducated about, and inattentive to, a part of our criminal justice system that in fact has enormous bearing on our safety.

title: Transcript of Obamas Speech in Israel
description: Following is a complete transcript of President Obamas remarks in Jerusalem on March 21, 2013. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service).

title: Matilda Comes to Broadway
description: Patrick Healy interviewed the composer Tim Minchin about the challenges of bringing Roald Dahls work to Broadway.

title: U.N. to Investigate Chemical Weapons Accusations in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations will investigate accusations that chemical weapons were used earlier this week in Aleppo Province in northern Syria, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced on Thursday.

title: Its Mountain West vs. Pac-12
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  In the Mountain and Pacific time zones, the rise of the Mountain West Conference has turned it into the chief rival of the Pac-12 Conference

title: Dream Big, Girl
description: Matilda isnt just one of the most anticipated shows of the Broadway season. This new musical is the theaters latest shot at the dream of a global blockbuster, a rare glory that producers and audiences crave to offset all the duds that cross the stage each year.

title: The Rise of the Infernal Machines
description: On Dec. 12, 1862, the Union ironclad gunboat Cairo and a small group of support vessels moved cautiously through a bend in Mississippis sluggish Yazoo River. They sought torpedoes, what we now know as mines. Suddenly, Walter E.H. Fentress, an ensign sitting in a small boat some distance from the Cairo, heard an explosion and saw her anchor thrown up into the air. Onboard the Cairo, George Yost, a 14-year-old ships boy, wrote that the torpedoes crushed in the bottom of the boat so that the water rushed in like the roar of Niagara. The Cairo went down in 15 minutes. Fortunately, no lives were lost; most of the crew simply stepped into small boats as the ship sank  the first warship sunk by an underwater explosive.

title: Face-to-Face Talks
description: The Timess Jodi Rudoren discusses President Obamas visits with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.

title: Ris Stevens, 99, Stalwart at the Met for Decades in Carmen Role, Is Dead
description: Ris Stevens, the internationally renowned mezzo-soprano who had a 23-year career with the Metropolitan Opera, where she practically owned the role of Carmen during the 1940s and 50s, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.

title: Illustrating Her Own Narrative
description: Women who built careers as illustrators in Mad Men-era New York were few and far between, and one is Barbara Nessim. In the early 1960s she became known for brightly colored pop portraits of women, made with fluid, expressive lines, which appeared in Esquire, Harpers Bazaar and girlie magazines. During feminisms rise in the early 70s her focus on women and gender roles drew the interest of publications covering womens issues, like Ms. (Gloria Steinem was once her roommate), New York and Time. In the 80s Ms. Nessim became one of the first illustrators to work with computers, which may be how she is best known today.

title: Obama Lays Out Case for Israel to Revive Peace Talks
description: Laying out his case for a future Israel at peace with the Palestinians, President Obama delivered an enthusiastically welcomed speech on Thursday before an audience of youthful Israelis in Jerusalem, assuring them of Americas strong support but asking them to empathize with their Israeli-occupied neighbors and look at the world through their eyes.

title: Keeping Score: The Clippers Game Changer
description: LeBron James and Kevin Durant have received a lot of attention this season, and deservedly so. James and Durant are the two best players in the N.B.A., but there should be room in the spotlight for a player who is not too far behind: Chris Paul of the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: As New Drone Policy Is Weighed, Few Practical Effects Are Seen
description: CHICAGO  Under growing pressure to bring greater transparency and accountability to its use of targeted killing, the Obama administration is struggling to transform a program that was conceived under pressure, has operated in a secretive and often haphazard manner and has left the United States increasingly isolated even from its allies.

title: The Risks of Expanding Into Australia, Part 2
description: In my last post, I wrote about our plans to open our 22nd foreign office in Australia. We have checked the very important first few boxes in our process to conduct a successful foreign-office opening with limited risk and investment  including finding a general manager, Anna Minns, who will start drawing a salary as soon as we start invoicing. Most important, we have a few partnership deals that are close to closing.

title: The Red One, Next to the Fiat
description: The Hertz Corporation recently expanded its Supercar rental offerings in Europe, increasing the number of cars and models available in Britain and Spain, and adding Italy, France and (beginning in April) the Netherlands, to the countries where the premium cars can be rented. Renters can now choose brands including McLaren, Lamborghini (shown) and Aston Martin. What European financial crisis?

title: Playwrights Horizons Season To Range From Simpsons to Kama Sutra
description: Playwrights Horizons is once again putting women front and center in the companys 2013-2014 season, staging four plays by women, including two world premieres. Three of the first five plays the Off Broadway company announced on Thursday will also be directed by women.

title: The Renaissance Followed Him North
description: WASHINGTON  Albrecht Drer had it all: the eye of a Raphael, the brains of a Leonardo, the looks of a cleaned-up Kurt Cobain. He produced the earliest known self-portrait drawing in European art when he was 13, and some of the first stand-alone landscapes. He brought the pliant warmth of Italian Classical painting to the shivery Gothic north, and transformed the woodcut medium from semi-folk art to fine art, and very fine art indeed.

title: Wheelies: The Top 10 List Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: U.S. to Play Mexico in Ohio
description: U.S. Soccer on Thursday announced the venues for four home World Cup qualifying matches and confirmed that it will play a centennial match against Germany in Washington on June 2. Kickoff is scheduled for 2:30 p.m. Eastern. (Also as part of the federations 100th anniversary, the U.S. womens national team will play Canada at BMO Field in Toronto later that day, with the match scheduled to start at 4:30 p.m.)

title: The Envelope Please: Leobardo Espinoza
description: As college admission decisions begin to roll in, Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a senior at Topeka High School in Kansas, wonders whether now is the best time to take a break and travel abroad.

title: To Boaz Weinstein, Betting Against JPMorgans Trade Was Easy
description: JPMorgan Chase has been in an uncomfortable spotlight over the last week, after the release of a scathing Senate report related to its multibillion-dollar trading loss last year.

title: Recipe Lab | Nigella Lawson
description: Highlights from a live video discussion between cookbook author Nigella Lawson, the Times Julia Moskin, and three home cooks about a recipe from Ms. Lawsons new cookbook, Nigellissima.

title: States Urged to Expand Medicaid With Private Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is encouraging skeptical state officials to expand Medicaid by subsidizing the purchase of private insurance for low-income people, even though that approach might be somewhat more expensive, federal and state officials say.

title: Obama Heckled During Speech
description: A heckler interrupted President Barack Obama's speech to Israelis in Jerusalem on Thursday.

title: Photo Replay: March 21
description: The week in Pictures for Sports for March 21

title: New Mexico State Has a Canadian Pipeline
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  They have not changed their name to New Canada State, but the Aggies of New Mexico State have found an unlikely source of talent: Ontario.

title: Crave Fishbar
description: Inside a Midtown restaurant with the feel of an upscale canteen.

title: Senators Considering Plan to Double Visas for High-Tech Workers
description: A bipartisan group of eight senators is considering a plan that would double the number of visas available to highly skilled foreign workers, as well as sharply increase the number of green cards available to foreign students who graduate from an American university with a degree in science, technology, engineering or math, two people familiar with the negotiations said.

title: Our Fourth Annual New York Times Found Poetry Student Contest
description: Update: May 28:  Weve chosen our winners and will announce one each weekday from May 28 to June 12. Find them all here.

title: Market Sweep | Animal Instincts
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Lets Play 16
description: Images from the first full day of the 2013 N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Eastwood and Aronofsky, Live at Tribeca
description: Clint Eastwood and Darren Aronofsky will engage in a public dialogue about the art of film directing at this years Tribeca Film Festival, one of a score of panel discussions scheduled during the event, which runs from April 17 to April 28.

title: Gap Year Now or Study Abroad Later?
description: Last summer I had the opportunity to travel abroad. As a youth ambassador with the State Department, I was selected to travel to the small Central American country of Belize to learn more about American and Belizean diplomacy, civic engagement and volunteerism.

title: Latin American Nations Object to Sothebys Antiquities Auction
description: Four Latin American nations have objected to an auction this weekend in Paris by Sothebys because they say some of the 300 items of pre-Columbian art to be sold were illegally exported.

title: Emerging From the Deep
description: THE MENU AT Crave Fishbar reads like a come-on. First there is nori powder, a nutty dust with a fizz of brine; then vinegar made from fermented plantains; black garlic, syrupy and sour-sweet; burned lemon peel, a bartenders trick, applying flame to make the oils caramelize; and schmaltz, rendered chicken fat, at once motherly and wanton.

title: On Cooking With Fresh Chicken
description: We received a few questions from readers regarding Wednesdays Diners Journal item about the Fresh Killed Chicken offerings on the menu at Hanjan, the bustling new Korean tavern that the chef Hooni Kim has opened in the Flatiron district.

title: The Men in Late Night Dreams
description: I have noticed these days that reporters never talk to each other about sleeping with their subjects.

title: Obama Speaks in Israel
description: President Obama spoke to Israelis in Jerusalem on Thursday.

title: For Butlers Clarke, Shooting Is Mandatory
description: For the Butler sharpshooter Rotnei Clarke, practice makes 41.2 percent.

title: Jailed Leader of the Kurds Offers a Truce With Turkey
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey  The jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on Thursday called for a cease-fire and ordered all his fighters off Turkish soil, in a landmark moment for a newly energized effort to end three decades of armed conflict with the Turkish government.

title: Sweetening the Deal
description: M.&A. bankers and lawyers telling a public relations firm that specializes in deals that they expect to see more merger activity makes for sweet echo-chamber music. The survey released by the Brunswick Group to coincide with an annual American deal maker convention found three of four practitioners expecting more mergers and acquisitions globally this year than last. Theyre more bullish than ever about North America, with 97 percent anticipating growth in the region. A discount needs to be applied to all the optimism.

title: As Congress Votes to Avert One Fiscal Crisis, Boehner Moves On to Another
description: Just when it looked as if both political parties were ready to step off the bloody budget battlefield, the troops on Thursday began mustering for a new skirmish on an old issue: the debt ceiling.

title: Masked by Gibberish, the Risks Run Amok
description: Can anyone manage a big bank these days? Should anyone try?

title: Universe as an Infant: Fatter Than Expected and Kind of Lumpy
description: Astronomers released the latest and most exquisite baby picture yet of the universe on Thursday, one that showed it to be 80 million to 100 million years older and a little fatter than previously thought, with more matter in it and perhaps ever so slightly lopsided.

title: Norovirus Is Common in Children
description: Norovirus infection has become the leading cause of acute gastroenteritis in children under 5 in the United States.

title: Marcum Says Shoulder Issue Is Not New
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Shaun Marcum described his shoulder inflammation, which drove him to receive a cortisone injection Tuesday and forced him to miss his last Grapefruit League start, as part of his spring training routine.

title: Consumer Agency Warns Lenders on Bias in Auto Loans
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau laid out its authority over auto lenders on Thursday and warned them to comply with fair lending requirements. The agency said that it was issuing the new instructions in response to discriminatory practices that resulted in Hispanic and black borrowers illegally being charged higher rates than whites for auto loans.

title: Caffeine May Boost Driver Safety
description: Long-haul truck drivers who drink coffee or other caffeinated drinks are significantly less likely to have an accident than their uncaffeinated peers.

title: Gun Control and Speed Legislating
description: When Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York responded to the Newtown massacre by quickly pushing through the toughest gun control laws in the country, we congratulated him on our editorial page, but worried about the speed and secrecy with which he accomplished this feat.

title: Seeking Bracket Perfection? Fat Chance
description: As the bulk of the N.C.A.A. tournament action proceeds with the Round of 64 on Thursday and Friday, most people quickly abandon any thoughts of perfection. No, by the end of the first day, most amateur bracketeers are hoping their brackets arent dripping with corrective red ink and their Final Four picks survived unscathed.

title: Mapping the Big Bang
description: The Timess Dennis Overbye discusses a portrait of the universe as a young cosmos.

title: Endnotes | The Dover Bookshop
description: Since opening in 1986, the Dover Bookshop in London has catered to a discerning clientele that includes art directors, fashion designers and boldfaced bibliophiles like Helena Bonham-Carter, Terry Gilliam and Jimmy Page. In addition to supplying great books, the store became a go-to destination for royalty-free images pulled from Victorian-era womens magazines or 19th-century garden manuals that artists could incorporate into their work. For those who considered the shop a trove of ready-made inspiration, the news that it will close at the end of the month comes as a huge shock. The Charing Cross Road area of London has changed from a haven for small shops to an area for mainstream brands and fashion, the stores manager Tim Matthews wrote in an e-mail. Beyond that, though, image resources are increasingly found online and Dover Publications are moving steadily into that world. Among the brilliant, obscure volumes that made up the shops stock in trade were Gustave Dors illustrations of London; Jan Vredeman De Vriess book of 16th-century architectural engravings, Studies in Perspective; and Jim Harners collection of 1,000 black-and-white animal drawings.

title: Israeli Beauty Queen Next in Line to Press Obama to Release Spy
description: Last Updated, Friday, 9:19 a.m. As my colleague Isabel Kershner explained, Israeli politicians have taken turns this week pressing President Obama to release Jonathan Pollard, a former United States Navy intelligence analyst serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel.

title: A Jazz Pairing That Plays Outside the Lines
description: The Miser moved to New York in the mid-1990s mostly for love, its true, but also because of a growing interest in avant-garde jazz. And at the time, it was still possible to catch a pioneer like Cecil Taylor, Anthony Braxton or even Ornette Coleman in an intimate setting somewhere in downtown Manhattan.

title: Addressing Fears About LED Light Bulbs
description: In my Times column Thursday, I reviewed a new generation of LED light bulbs. They last 25 times as long as regular bulbs, use maybe one-eighth the electricity, work with dimmers, turn on instantly to full brightness and remain cool to the touch. A big drawback has always been cost, but now, I noted, the prices have fallen.

title: Pro-Assad Cleric Killed in Blast in Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A large explosion killed at least 42 people inside a central Damascus mosque on Thursday, including the top Sunni cleric in Syria, one of the major remaining Sunni supporters of President Bashar al-Assads embattled government in the civil war.

title: Iona Is Happy to Be Back, but No Rerun, Please
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.  A year ago, Iona suffered one of the most heartbreaking defeats in N.C.A.A. tournament history.

title: Rosneft Completes Acquisition of TNK-BP
description: LONDON  BP, the British oil company, said on Thursday that it had completed the sale of its 50 percent stake in the Russian affiliate TNK-BP. In a series of transactions, BP will receive about $12.5 billion in cash and will own 19.75 percent of Rosneft, the largest Russian oil company.

title: For Euro Zone, a Cyprus Exit Would Have Little Impact
description: A Cyprus exit from the euro union, if it comes to that, would have a devastating effect on the countrys citizens, who are among the most indebted in the euro zone. And for European unity and diplomacy, the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short-term disaster.

title: Nancy Dwyer: Painting and Sculpture, 1982-2012
description: Fisher Landau Center for Art

title: A Friendship, Interrupted
description: It wasnt until I got to know Anjali better that I realized how much it took for her to approach me in the waiting room at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center last summer.

title: Gianni Colombo
description: Greene Naftali

title: Ask About the Supreme Court Hearings on Same-Sex Marriage
description: The Supreme Court will hear oral arguments next week in a pair of cases challenging laws relating to same-sex marriage. On Tuesday, lawyers will argue a challenge to Californias gay marriage ban, Proposition 8, and the next day, the justices will hear a challenge to the federal law known as the Defense of Marriage Act.

title: Mapping the Early Universe
description: The Planck satellite has taken the most detailed images yet of the early universe.

title: Negotiator New to the Game Takes Blame for Cyprus Failure
description: BRUSSELS  Did the Cyprus bailout announced in the wee hours last Saturday fail because two central players were new to the complex game of European politics?

title: Sixers Can Measure Youngs Success by the Numbers
description: In his six years in the N.B.A., the Philadelphia 76ers Thaddeus Young has evolved into the kind of small-ball power forward who is supposed to be in the vanguard of the positional revolution.

title: Al Held: Alphabet Paintings
description: Cheim & Read

title: Zanele Muholi: Faces and Phases
description: Yancey Richardson Gallery

title: Ris Stevens Remembered
description: Images of the opera singer, who died on Wednesday at 99.

title: Apple Strengthens iCloud Security With 2-Step Authentication
description: Apple on Thursday rolled out a tool that strengthens password security for Apple accounts: two-step verification, a feature widely available for many Web services.

title: Man Jailed in 1990 Killing of a Rabbi Is Released
description: David Ranta walked out of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Thursday a free man, after spending more than two decades in a maximum-security prison for a crime he almost certainly did not commit.

title: His Lawyer Is Writing a Book About Johnny Carson
description: Johnny Carson and The Tonight Show have been extensively chronicled, including in books over the years from Carson himself and from his longtime co-host, Ed McMahon.

title: Ex-Horace Mann Students in Talks on Sex-Abuse Case
description: Thirty-two former students of the Horace Mann School have said they were sexually abused by teachers and staff members, and they have been meeting with school officials in the past two weeks to negotiate compensation, according to a person knowledgeable about the talks.

title: Virginia Overton
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: Mom and Dad, Midwest and Milan
description: Elizabeth and Misha, Alexander Stilles mother and father, met in May 1948 at a party for Truman Capote. She came to the party with her husband at the time, Bob, and left with Misha. Within a week, shed moved out of the apartment shed shared with Bob, and begun an intense romance with Misha. The pair would get married and stay married for more than four decades, but the marriage would be a fiercely tempestuous one, fueled by epic fights and threats of divorce  a marriage that their son describes as a toxic clash of civilizations. When he was a teenager, he says, it reminded him of Sartres line Hell is other people.

title: Global Ticket Sales for Movies Rise 6%
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie ticket sales around the world rose 6 percent last year, to $34.7 billion from $32.6 billion in 2011, as China became the worlds second-biggest market for theatrical films after the United States, according to statistics released by the Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday.

title: The Hard Math on Fossil Fuels
description: How close is the world to devastating climate upheaval? My column on Wednesday argued that the natural gas boom is helping the United States reduce its emissions of heat-trapping carbon into the air, encouraging power generators to switch to gas from the much dirtier coal. American CO2 emissions last year totaled about 5.25 billion tons  almost 13 percent less than in 2007.

title: Pollock and Andr Derain at Auction; Met Expands Hours
description: With deadlines for the spring auctions fast approaching, experts at Sothebys and Christies are scrambling to get top material for their sales. Its been a tough couple of months. No major estates are up for grabs, and most collectors are reluctant to sell a work unless they need cash. Slowly, however, a few significant works are beginning to come on the market for the sales, among them The Blue Unconscious, an early abstract canvas that Jackson Pollock painted in 1946.

title: Sather Has Surgery to Treat Prostate Cancer
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers president and general manager, had surgery to treat prostate cancer on Thursday at Weill-Cornell Medical Center in New York and was expected to be off the job for a few days.

title: Now Booking | Hotel de Nell in Paris
description: In Paris, the interior designer Jean-Michel Wilmotte and the hotelier Lisa Konckier-Abrat have created an elegant and supremely handsome 33-room hotel thats one of the best examples of big-city boutique lodgings on the Continent. Think luxe, calme et volupt.

title: Theater Talkback: The Season of the Sputtering Starlet
description: The geese who fly east from Hollywood on an annual basis, looking for a little Broadway luster to boost their showbiz stock, arent laying as many golden eggs as they normally do this season. As Patrick Healy noted recently, the box office at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where Scarlett Johansson is starring in a revival of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, has not exactly been inundated since the show opened to middling reviews in January. Nor did Katie Holmess ballyhooed return to Broadway after a tumultuous few years as constant tabloid fodder do much for Dead Accounts, the Theresa Rebeck play that closed quickly in the fall after opening to sour reviews and sluggish ticket sales.

title: She Makes Objects Speak, and They Wont Stop Arguing
description: Entering Barbara Blooms show at the Jewish Museum you must pass between pairs of painted eyes that peer out from masklike apertures in the wall. As you stand before these veiled portraits you will also hear argumentative voices: recordings from Annie Hall, Curb Your Enthusiasm and other television and movie sources.

title: States Vie to Conduct Commercial Drone Tests
description: LAS VEGAS  The state of Nevada recently joined the crowded bidding to be named a federal test site for the commercial use of pilotless aircraft under a program that will allow as many as six states to test the controversial but potentially lucrative technology for a five-year period.

title: Bill on Crime Against Women Passes in India
description: NEW DELHI  Indias Parliament passed a comprehensive bill on Thursday to impose stronger penalties on men who attack women and to criminalize offenses like stalking and voyeurism.

title: Uplift From a Gloomy Gus
description: Abandon hope, all ye who enter a Strindberg play. That Swedish writer steeped his characters in desperation and contempt, and he wasnt affable to his audience, either. If my tragedy depresses many people, it is their own fault, he wrote of his masterpiece, Miss Julie.

title: Draped in Red, White and Blue
description: SPRING CRIES OUT for a mellow brew, something to lift the spirit and reawaken the senses, buried so long under layers of winter protection.

title: Hes the Man of Steel, as Well as a Man of Song
description: Two-dimensional isnt usually an adjective that any self-respecting musical would want attached to its name. But the show that opened at City Center on Wednesday night seems perfectly contented  no, make that downright delighted  to exist entirely on a flat surface. And therein lies the not-to-be-dismissed charms of the winning Encores! concert production of Its a Bird ... Its a Plane ... Its Superman, which runs through Sunday.

title: Biden Joins Mayor and Newtown Families to Push for Gun Limits
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. joined Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and some families of the victims in the Connecticut school shootings on Thursday to push for new federal gun laws, just days after Senate Democrats dropped an assault weapons ban from a gun-regulation package they plan to consider next month.

title: Highlights From Obamas Speech in Israel
description: To view the complete video of President Obamas speech in Jerusalem on Thursday, click the play button. To jump to key passages, click on the time markers below.

title: Looks Like The Steven Tyler Act Is Sunk
description: We ran an editorial last month about a bill in the Hawaii Legislature to punish paparazzi for photographing celebrities like the rock god Steve Tyler, for whom the bill was named. (No joke: the sponsor, Senator Kalani English, is apparently a big Aerosmith fan who wanted to honor Steven Tylers contribution to the arts in Hawaii and throughout the world.)

title: Excerpt: 'Hands on a Hardbody'
description: A scene from the number "Joy" from the new Broadway musical at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: David Murdock of Dole Food Opens California Estate for a Concours
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  David Murdock, 89, chairman of the Dole Food Company, opened his 2,200-acre estate here for the first Ventura Farms Concours last Sunday, inaugurating an annual event that will tie in with St. Patricks Day and jubilantly asserting Californias need for yet another fancy car show.

title: A Morning and a Night and a Morning and a Night at the Opera
description: Stephen Mallon

title: Fun Down Under in Brisbane
description: See culture, grab a cocktail and get a little crazy in this trip around Australias third-largest city.

title: 36 Hours in Brisbane, Australia
description: With the Sunshine Coast to the north and the Gold Coast to the south, Brisbane has long been a natural waypoint for visitors seeking a slice of South Pacific paradise on Australias eastern shores. But the countrys third-largest city deserves to be a destination in its own right. Fans of fine art and live music will revel in the diversity of the citys offerings, and nature lovers will delight in discovering the local wildlife sanctuary filled with arguably the cutest creatures on the planet  koalas. Some new bars and restaurants have recently introduced big-city sophistication to this subtropical metropolis, but you neednt trade your flip-flops for formal footwear just yet. The warm and welcoming capital of Queensland, Australias Sunshine State, is still as casual and easygoing as ever.

title: A Strange Bank Holiday
description: The bank holiday continues in Cyprus. Banks are closed.

title: Pressured, Investment Firm Is Said to Skip Fees
description: Score one for private equity investors.

title: March Madness, the Other
description: No, it is not the road to the Final Four. Will the final 32 (31 plus host Brazil) do instead?

title: Show Puts Count Guglielmo Libri in an Unflattering Light
description: A COUNT WITH TASTE

title: Why Am I Out of Shape?
description: The first generation to grow up exercising.

title: A Monster With a Sweet Spot for Jazz
description: The Miles Davis Trumpet in-ear headphones by Monster may not give you the most sound quality for the dollar, but they are high on aesthetic value.

title: Painted on 21st Street
description: A look at the new Helen Frankenthaler exhibition at Gagosian.

title: Yankees-StubHub Hearing Delayed Until April
description: The battle between the Yankees and StubHub got a reprieve, sort of.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Bezos Raises Moon Rockets, and False Face of the Drone
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Grapefruit League for Jeter Ends on Technicality
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeters availability for the Yankees season opener on April 1 is still a question mark. But General Manager Brian Cashman said with an exclamation point Thursday that Jeter would not see any more action in major league spring training games.

title: In Space You Can Still Hear the Drones
description: Karlheinz Stockhausen, the avant-garde German composer who died in 2007, is on a roll at, of all places, the Park Avenue Armory, a building dedicated in 1880 as the headquarters of New Yorks Seventh Regiment, a volunteer outfit that catered to the citys silk-stocking set.

title: Ready in Case the Other Shoe Should Drop
description: I pay $189 a month ($2,268 a year) for my Single Girls Starter Kit. My Single Girls Starter Kit is a storage facility I keep in Brooklyn. I recently moved in with my boyfriend of seven years. Giving up my low-rent apartment in Park Slope is as serious a commitment as Ive ever made to any human being.

title: The Corpse in the Bedroom
description: First story collections, even good ones, tend to fall into two broad categories. On the one hand, there is the energetic but diffuse hodgepodge, the result, perhaps, of an eager mind fussing with the newly discovered tools of literary culture. Such books often contain a few terrific stories interspersed with failed experiments. On the other hand is the imitative, overly mannered matched set, wherein the author behaves like a traveler in a new country, trying to do as the natives do. Such a book may be skillfully made, but can feel staid or too careful.

title: Treading Gingerly
description: My sister and I are Jewish, but our family never went to temple or celebrated religious holidays. Now we have children of our own (though were no more religious). Last year, my young son went to an Easter egg hunt and had an absolute blast. So, next weekend, Im making one for him. When my sister found out, she excoriated me and told me I am a bad Jew. How should I proceed?

title: Staking a Claim in South America
description: THE BUZZ IS LOUD these days about South Americans buying Miami and New York condos at a furious pace, helping to stoke high-end residential boomlets in those cities. But back home, their own real estate markets have started to lure investment from big-name American real estate companies.

title: His Work Is the Cats Meow
description: NOT up for the big top? Coinciding with Ringlings run at Barclays Center in Brooklyn is something of a little top: the Popovich Comedy Pet Theater, which is playing two shows at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center in Manhattan March 30 (tribecapac.org).

title: Justin Timberlake Keeps it Retro
description: In pop music, hindsight is the key to relevance. There is the Warholian logic to the iTunes chart: the artist who appropriates a particular time period with the most cunning and skill feels the freshest. The Los Angeles-based musical duo Rhye have received critical acclaim recently for evoking the early-80s-era quiet storm of Sade. Azealia Banks channels the 1990s with her best Crystal Waters imitation with about the same success as Lady Gagas echoing of Blond Ambition-era Madonna. (Remember that?) The moody atmosphere of Drakes oeuvre picks up the pieces that Aaliyah left behind in 2001. And the dance-pop white noise that inhabits the radio today is, of course, a rehash of the Euro-pop and rave culture of yesteryear that Daft Punk helped foster. The French D.J. duo, who recently signed to Columbia and have a new album coming out in time for summer, are said to be working with the funk legend Niles Rodgers for their anticipated new release, situating themselves comfortably in the 1970s disco revival moment that has become a staple of underground night-life culture in Paris, London and New York.

title: Tribute to a Drummer Who Moved Jazz On
description: We are going to play one more song, Reid Anderson, the bassist in the Bad Plus, told an overflow crowd in a large tent at the most recent Newport Jazz Festival. Its another Paul Motian song, because we love Paul so much, and his music means so much to us. This statement met with a rumble of approval  a lot of yeahs punctuated the applause  as the band, joined for the occasion by the guitarist Bill Frisell, ventured on.

title: Larceny for the Sake of Art
description: Gimme the Loot, Adam Leons loose and rambunctious debut feature, tells the tale of two young artists scrambling to kick-start an ambitious project. Or, if you prefer, it follows a pair of vandals through a day of improvised criminality. Really, though, its both: a celebration of outlaw creativity and entrepreneurial gumption.

title: A Rendezvous With 1,000 Rooms
description: Whether you think of them as quotidian, or soaring masonry facades enlivened by decorative details, as does the New York Landmarks Conservancy, the network of 1910s and 1920s buildings erected over Grand Centrals sunken railroad yards was a remarkable development, unlike anything ever done in New York.

title: Pipes of Size and Salty Sentiments
description: Multiply the mouthy, flesh-jiggling early Bette Midler by one hundred, give her the super-plus-size figure and fashion sense of Divine, the John Waters diva, and the manners of a Flintstone, and youve got a rough approximation of Bridget Everett, the alt-cabaret star who roared around the stage of Joes Pub on Wednesday evening.

title: For Luck, Iona Coaches Decide to Sweat It
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Three weeks ago, before what was then Ionas biggest game of the season, Coach Tim Cluess asked his staff what they thought about dressing down a little on the sidelines. The idea was to raise awareness for the efforts of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, seeking a cure for the chronic lung disease that afflicts the nephew of two prominent Iona alums.

title: Loans for a Niche Market
description: If interest-only loans were issued too freely before the foreclosure crisis, their availability now is restricted to a privileged few.

title: Hes Weary, but Psyched to Save Democracy
description: The most recent Die Hard movie  which the record shows I reviewed a little more than a month ago, although I have no recollection of it  was terrible, but it turns out not to have been the worst Die Hard movie this year. That honor, for the moment at least (its only March!), belongs to Olympus Has Fallen, which is not, strictly speaking, part of the franchise at all. It is more a school of Die Hard production, in which a weary and battered law enforcement professional, severely constrained by time and space, fights off a ridiculous number of bad guys.

title: Comedy Listings for March 22-28
description: Comedy

title: U.N. Panel to Investigate Human Rights Abuses in North Korea
description: PARIS  The United Nations Human Rights Council voted on Thursday in Geneva to create a three-person commission to look into allegations of human rights violations in North Korea, including food deprivation, labor camps for political prisoners and torture.

title: Movie Listings for March 22-28
description: Movies

title: Jumbo Homecoming
description: FOR decades the ritual blooming of circus cotton candy each March has been a sure sign of spring for winter-weary New Yorkers.

title: Pop Music and Rock Listings for March 22-28
description: Pop

title: Gone Gone Gone (Woah Oh Oh)
description: Lana Clarkson is not a familiar figure anymore, but when she was found dead  shot through the mouth  in the California mansion of the pop-music impresario Phil Spector in 2003 that actress turned nightclub hostess finally won the moment of fame that had eluded her for so long.

title: Jazz Listings for March 22-28
description: Jazz

title: Theater Listings for March 22-28
description: Theater

title: Designing The Croods
description: A look at some of the designs from The Croods, with commentary by its production designer Christophe Lautrette.

title: Theres Something About That Boy
description: The Croods makes a better study of Stone Age sociology than it does a childrens movie. But its colorful and has an appealing central character and  who knows?  might even give the little ones something more challenging to think about than its tired main plot.

title: Music for a Season of Solemnity and Joy
description: A sampling of musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted otherwise, church choirs are featured in church concerts.) An expanded listing is available at nytimes.com.

title: A Young Colorist, Antennas Aquiver
description: On Oct. 26, 1952, a 23-year-old artist named Helen Frankenthaler made a painting on unstretched, unprimed canvas laid on the floor, using a freehand stain technique that owed a great deal to Jackson Pollock but was less systematic. She called it Mountains and Sea, and it became her best-known, most influential work. Its bounding scale, skirmish of pastel colors and charcoal lines, and mixture of landscape, still life and abstraction were distinctive. But most important was the way it fused color and canvas into a new, streamlined unity. Frankenthalers stain painting method, as it was sometimes called, was considered a breakthrough in many circles, the gateway to what would become Color Field abstraction.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for March 22-28
description: Classical

title: As Pollution Worsens in China, Solutions Succumb to Infighting
description: BEIJING  Chinas state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop. More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai. A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital, causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City.

title: Dance Listings for March 22-28
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for March 22-28
description: Art

title: Growing Fast, but Stumbling Along the Way
description: LPL Financial has grown in recent years to become one of the largest retail brokerage companies in the country, but the firm has run afoul of regulators unusually often.

title: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Myanmar, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Israel.

title: Money Requested for New Prison at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million to build a new prison building at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, for special detainees on top of other renovations it says are necessary since Congress has decided to keep it open indefinitely. That brings the potential taxpayer bill for upgrading the deteriorating facilities to an estimated $195.7 million, the military said on Thursday.

title: The Circus Comes to Brooklyn
description: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has a new show at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

title: Colorado Approves Same-Sex Unions
description: DENVER  With a stroke of the governors pen, Colorado on Thursday legalized civil unions for same-sex couples, a major shift for a Western state where voters outlawed same-sex marriages in 2006.

title: Spare Times for Children for March 22-28
description: SHADOW PLAY

title: Gun Bill Will Be Taken Up After Senate Recess
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate plans to begin debating a package of gun regulations next month when it returns from its Easter recess, said Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader. Mr. Reid began procedural motions late Thursday on a bill that seeks to enhance background checks for those who purchase guns, and to curb gun trafficking and increase money for school safety.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Mud, Sweat and Tears Pottery
description: The studios longtime home is a place you could spend a few hours, or while away the decades and watch Hells Kitchen become Clinton.

title: Spare Times Listings for March 22-28
description: Around Town

title: The Dark Side of the Expat Life
description: If you are a member of Rendezvouss  global tribe, home might be where your apartment, your work or your belongings  or even your family and friends  are. But it might also be a place where language and culture are confounding. And deep down, despite the thrills and invigorating challenges of an experience abroad, more often than not, we know its not a place well stay forever.

title: Seeing the World From Different Angles
description: Books of abstract art by Jay DeFeo, Per Kirkeby, Hassel Smith and Nico Luoma and from the Destroy the Picture exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago.

title: I.B.M. Research Points to Circuits That Mimic the Brains Design
description: I.B.M. scientists said Thursday that they had developed a fluidic electronic system that mimics the circuits in the human brain and potentially offers a new direction for ultra-low-power microelectronics and artificial intelligence.

title: Finding Beauty in Decay and Math
description: As I studied these five books of abstract art they made me think about a factory where I once worked that cleaned 55-gallon steel drums of oils, paints, solvents and more. One of the things I remember from those days in the 1970s is how beautiful some of the drum covers became on their industrial journey.

title: Pacinos Portrayals
description: Al Pacino is playing the eccentric title character in the HBO film Phil Spector, one of several in which the actor has embodied a real-life figure.

title: Defiant Souls and Hopeful Sounds of the 60s
description: The Sapphires tells the story of an all-female singing quartet on the way to stardom in the 1960s. As is usual in such tales, the group, known as the Cummeragunja Songbirds before their gemological rechristening, faces its share of obstacles, but in spite of internal disharmony and tough circumstances, the singers voices rarely falter.

title: Andy Cohens West Village Home
description: Pop culture artifacts fill the apartment of Andy Cohen, host of Watch What Happens Live.

title: Heres What Happens
description: Five nights a week on Bravo, Andy Cohen hosts the highly rated late-night talk show Watch What Happens Live in a studio filled with knickknacks and tokens of pop trivia. He sits in one of a set of Danish modern chairs that swivel and lean back; he sips from a highly toxic blend of Fresca and tequila, and shoots the breeze with celebrities ranging from LaToya Jackson to Meryl Streep.

title: O.K., Class, Lets Rock to Shakespeare
description: The British punk-rock explosion was only months from detonation in the early summer of 1976, the time of Marc Evanss high school musical, Hunky Dory. This sun-bleached, candy-colored movie is set in southern Wales, where Vivienne Mae (Minnie Driver), a passionate, feisty drama teacher, mobilizes her apathetic students to stage a rock opera based on Shakespeares Tempest in the final weeks of the school year. The score will consist of existing rock songs.

title: Progress Is Reported in Arms Talks With Russia
description: MOSCOW  Russian and American officials on Thursday reported progress in discussions about nuclear weapons reductions, in a sign that renewed cooperation may be under way just days after the United States canceled part of a Europe-based missile defense program that had infuriated the Kremlin.

title: Police Wound Armed Suspect in Brooklyn
description: Two plainclothes officers shot and wounded an armed suspect on Thursday on a Brooklyn street after he pulled a gun and fired at them, the police said.

title: Cheaper by the Gross
description: Im just a meat delivery guy and a terrible one at that, declares David Wozniak (Patrick Huard), a lovable oaf in Starbuck, Ken Scotts sloppy, feel-good French Canadian comedy. David, who is 42 and works in his fathers butcher shop, has one claim to fame, should he ever decide to shed his anonymity.

title: Drone Cameras May Be High Worry, but Theyre Not High Tech
description: The contrast between fast-moving technology and slow-moving laws was on full display on Wednesday at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on domestic use of drones. The issue was not arming them, because the Federal Aviation Administration bans weaponizing civil aircraft. (Several senators asked about drones outfitted with weapons, though, including nonlethal options like tear gas or stun grenades.)

title: A Strange Computer Promises Great Speed
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Our digital age is all about bits, those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code.

title: France: Sarkozy Faces Investigation
description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was informed Thursday that he would face a formal investigation into whether he abused the frailty of Liliane Bettencourt, 90, the heiress to the LOral fortune and Frances richest woman, to get funds for his 2007 presidential campaign. Mr. Sarkozy has denied accepting illegal campaign funds from Ms. Bettencourt, either personally or through his party treasurer at the time, ric Woerth, as alleged by her former butler. Mr. Sarkozys lawyer, Thierry Herzog, called the judges decision, which indicates that the judge believes that Mr. Sarkozy probably committed a crime, incoherent and unjust. The lawyer said he would appeal. The ruling does not necessarily mean that Mr. Sarkozy, who lost his re-election bid last May and with it his presidential immunity from prosecution, will stand trial.

title: Notre Dame Sits and Waits
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Notre Dame arrived here Wednesday night and practiced early Thursday evening, just as the action in the N.C.A.A. tournament was getting good. During team stretches in their locker room, they had the television set tuned to the final moments of the St. Marys-Memphis game, and they stole more than a few glances at it.

title: Where Dirty Hands Act as Therapy
description: A corner storefront glows warmly on a winter night. Inside, a stool and a friendly proprietor beckon. This is a place where you could spend a few hours, or wile away the decades, watch Hells Kitchen become Clinton.

title: Egyptian Activists Defend Riots Against an Unreformed Police Force
description: In their latest video, Why Riot?, the activists of Cairos Mosireen film collective argue that violent resistance to an unreformed police force is not only justified, but also necessary. They write, by way of introduction to the film: Two years after the start of the January 25 revolution we still riot because the ruling elite still exploit us, because the police still torture, maim and kill us and none of them are brought to justice.

title: Rainbow Becomes a Prism to View Gay Rights
description: WARSAW  The 30-foot-tall rainbow sculpture in downtown Savior Square here is looking somewhat the worse for wear these days, half covered in patches of artificial flowers and half bare from being set on fire. What was intended as a work of public art without an overt political message beyond the need for inclusiveness, according to the artist behind it, has instead become part of a culture war over homosexuality that has been brewing in one of Europes most Catholic countries.

title: Marketing Deal Gives a Small Town an Identity Crisis
description: DISH, Tex.  In this rural North Texas town, it is no coincidence that residents of Dish watch Dish.

title: Mets Make It Official: Wright Is Their Captain
description: David Wright has long been seen as the de facto leader of the Mets. He began his professional career as a member the organization, rose to stardom playing third base for the club and is the longest-tenured player on the current roster.

title: Maurice Barbash, Who Saved Fire Islands Terrain, Dies at 88
description: Maurice Barbash, a homebuilder and environmental activist who was instrumental in blocking two giant projects that threatened to radically alter Long Islands environment  a $6 billion nuclear power plant near completion on the North Shore, and a four-lane highway that Robert Moses proposed building along the spine of Fire Island  died on March 13 in Bay Shore, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Niese Will Pitch the Mets Opener
description: Jon Niese will start the Mets season opener against the San Diego Padres on April 1. The role was handed to Johan Santana at the start of camp, but Santana has not pitched a single game during spring training because of shoulder fatigue.

title: A Free Spirit and the Sculptor She Raised
description: Who is Leonie Gilmour and why does she rank her own biopic? For the writers of Leonie, Hisako Matsui (who also directed) and David Wiener, the short answer is that shes the mother of the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. And the long answer is this plodding film.Leonie (Emily Mortimer, who against all odds creates a credible character) meets and falls in love with a Japanese poet, Yone Noguchi, who is living in New York. She becomes his editor, lover and the mother of his child. For some reason  motivations in Leonie are either murky or too neatly explained  he dumps her when shes pregnant and moves back to Japan. She joins him there, but their relationship is over, and she strikes out on her own.

title: Jerry West Roots for the Heat, but Not Too Hard
description: Jerry West watched the Miami Heats incredible comeback Wednesday night, watched them obliterate a 27-point deficit, watched them take another step toward history  Wests history  and marveled at the sight.

title: Europe Weighs iPhone Sale Deals With Carriers for Antitrust Abuse
description: European Union regulators are examining the contracts Apple strikes with cellphone carriers that sell its iPhone for possible antitrust violations after several carriers complained that the deals throttled competition.

title: Learning From the Gardner Art Theft
description: Earlier this week, the F.B.I. announced that it had identified the two men who robbed the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston in March 1990, in the biggest art theft in American history. The F.B.I. said the criminals, whom it did not identify, had most likely moved their loot to Connecticut or the Philadelphia area.

title: For Sri Lanka, More Empty Words
description: New Delhi

title: Obamas Nixonian Precedent
description: Atlanta

title: Blackstone Studying Dell, but Decision Is Uncertain
description: The private equity giant Blackstone Group is weighing whether to make an offer for all or part of Dell as a Friday deadline looms, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

title: Recall Is Expensive Setback for Maker of Yoga Pants
description: Even novice shoppers know to wiggle around in a pair of pants before you buy them. But that was a lesson that Lululemon Athletica overlooked when it stocked too-sheer yoga pants, leading to a product recall, an expected hit of around $60 million in lost sales, and the risk that Lululemon  a widely envied retailer  has at last given competitors an opening.

title: From Scaling Windmills to Literary Editor
description: Excerpted from The Selected Letters of Willa Cather edited by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout. Copyright 2013 by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout. Excerpted by permission of Knopf, a division of Random House. All rights reserved.

title: Experimental Marketing
description: In 2005, the rural town Clark, Tex., agreed to change its name to Dish as part of a deal with the Dish Network satellite TV service.

title: The Dark and Light of East London
description: Death is always hovering just out of sight in My Brother the Devil, but theres nothing deadening about this engaging first feature from the Welsh-Egyptian filmmaker Sally El Hosaini.

title: To Live and Decorate in L.A.
description: Deb Dorfman (Sara Rue of the sitcom Malibu Country), 27 and single in Los Angeles, has had it with serving people. Among those placing demands are her widowed, irascible father, Burt (Elliott Gould), with whom she lives in the San Fernando Valley; her unhappily married brother, Daniel (Jonathan Chase), who employs her; and her hunky Web journalist friend Jay (Johann Urb), whom she secretly pines for and whose loft she has volunteered to house-sit and decorate while hes away for a week. But no one is taking care of her.

title: Amid Criticism, U.S. Coach Focuses on World Cup Qualifying Match
description: DENVER  The schedule leading up to an in-season international soccer match almost always feels quick.

title: A War, Before and After, Part 6
description: This is the final installment of the six-part series.

title: Burgers, Fries and Lies
description: The old adage  what will not kill you makes you only stronger  certainly doesnt apply to a bacon cheeseburger from Five Guys Burgers and Fries. This tasty gut bomb delivers two days worth of saturated fat and nearly 1,000 calories, a la carte. I hacked my way through one of these heart-stoppers the other day, and though I still have a pulse, it stayed with me in ways that would not please any doctor.

title: When Friends Collide
description: Oklahomas Lon Kruger and San Diego States Steve Fisher consider themselves good friends, so both men said it would difficult to coach against each other Friday at Wells Fargo Center.

title: His Arms Raise Up Him and His Audience
description: Unlike some nonfiction tales of grace under adversity, You Dont Need Feet to Dance leaves in the mundane obstacles rather than skipping to reassuring triumph. Low-key to a fault, Alan Govenars vrit documentary joins the Guinean-born drummer and dancer Sidiki Conde on his daily rounds and observes the added labor and gumption required of a working artist who cannot walk or stand.

title: Attempt to Win Hearts Is Tempered by a Challenge to Wary Israelis
description: JERUSALEM  With Hebrew phrases, testaments to Israels ancient roots, expressions of deep admiration and displays of empathy, President Obama has captured the hearts of many here over the past two days, appearing to erase years of skepticism and wariness overnight.

title: Recording Points to Race Factor in Stops by New York Police
description: For years, the debate over the New York Police Departments use of stop-and-frisk tactics has centered on whether officers engage in racial profiling. Now, a recording suggests that, in at least one precinct, a persons skin color can be a deciding factor in who is stopped.

title: In South Korea, Gangsters in Good Suits
description: Any film that opens with a snitch being force-fed a cement smoothie deserves some latitude to make its case, and the South Korean crime drama New World is no exception. Set in the scheming heart of a powerful crime syndicate, this stylish saga from Park Hoon-jung conjures a world where hardly anyone is who he seems.

title: I Speak to You as a Friend ...
description: Four years ago, President Obama used his Middle East trip to reach out to the Arab world and try to build a new basis for regional understanding to replace the Bush administrations post-Sept. 11 policies of fear and vengeance. Mr. Obama failed; skipping Israel and pursuing a poorly conceived peace initiative backfired.

title: Change of Heart for Vietnam War Buddies
description: Danny Mooneys Love and Honor is for anyone who thought Taking Woodstock was too hard-core. Set during the Vietnam War, this trifle about two soldiers who sneak away to America while on leave unfolds in a world about as realistic as a flashback on a sitcom. The film dresses up pretty young things in fatigues and retro T-shirts for a story so clichd and brainless that its almost more disturbing than laughable.

title: Apocalypse Fed
description: The animated Silver Circle is set in a dystopian Washington in 2019, when the Federal Reserve Police, in riot gear, are forcibly seizing houses from homeowners when they refuse to sell them to the government. At the same time, inflation runs amok, and working-class people turn to an underground economy, using silver for money. Societys ills, you see, stem from all that paper money circulating.

title: North Carolina Overreaches
description: Under the federal Medicaid statute, states must seek reimbursement for medical expenses if the beneficiary also receives money from an insurance company or another third party. This week, the Supreme Court correctly slapped down a North Carolina law that could squeeze far more from beneficiaries than they actually owe.

title: The Farm From Afar
description: Last week I got an e-mail from one of the two young farmers living at my small farm in upstate New York while Im teaching in Southern California for the semester. She mentioned green spears shooting out of the ground. The thought threw me into a vernal prolepsis, a mental flash-forward to spring, for which there must be a German word or a Chinese poem.

title: Alone in an Island of Creepy Kids
description: We have to run now! are five words no heavily pregnant woman ever wants to hear, though when the alternative is being beaten to a bloody pulp by a gang of feral children, a cumbersome belly seems the least of your problems.

title: Treasure Island Trauma
description: A couple of years ago, the journalist Nicholas Shaxson published a fascinating, chilling book titled Treasure Islands, which explained how international tax havens  which are also, as the author pointed out, secrecy jurisdictions where many rules dont apply  undermine economies around the world. Not only do they bleed revenues from cash-strapped governments and enable corruption; they distort the flow of capital, helping to feed ever-bigger financial crises.

title: Pac-12, a Dismissed Conference, Does Some Dismissing of Its Own
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  First Oregon, then California. Just like that, mens basketball in the Pacific-12 Conference does not seem so measly after all.

title: Fast-Growing Brokerage Firm Often Tangles With Regulators
description: The firm sounds like an upstart Merrill Lynch, the investment house that brought Wall Street to Main Street.

title: After the London Whale
description: For all the questions that were answered by the Senate inquiry into JPMorgan Chases $6.2 billion London Whale trading loss, one big question remains: What happens now?

title: The Man Behind the Doctors Mask
description: The title of Ana Piterbargs moody not-quite-a-thriller Everybody Has a Plan doesnt apply to its protagonist, Agustn (Viggo Mortensen). He has an acute, unmooring malaise that has left him almost blank. A pediatrician in Buenos Aires, he drops out of his life and holes up in his study, growing a beard and growing strange.

title: Posthumous Salute to a SEAL Team Leader
description: For the American military June 28, 2005, was a very bad day. A four-man Navy SEAL reconnaissance team in the Hindu Kush region of Afghanistan had been caught in a mountainside firefight with overwhelming Taliban forces, and the Special Operations helicopter sent to extract them was shot down. The 16 men aboard died, as did 3 of the 4 team members on the ground. (The one who lived, Marcus Luttrell, wrote a best-selling account, Lone Survivor; the major-motion-picture version, starring Mark Wahlberg, is scheduled for release next fall.)

title: Hallmark Joins Cable Networks Rush to Original Series
description: EFFORTS to significantly increase the amount of original programming on the Crown Media Family Networks two cable channels are already paying off with advertisers and viewers, senior executives of Crown Media said on Thursday.

title: Forecasting Fox
description: In 2006, Philip E. Tetlock published a landmark book called Expert Political Judgment. While his findings obviously dont apply to me, Tetlock demonstrated that pundits and experts are terrible at making predictions.

title: The Power of the Prenup
Taxing the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Shame Have a Place in Society?
description: To the Editor:

title: For-Profit Online College
description: To the Editor:

title: Influence of Small States
description: To the Editor:

title: The Church and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Said to Be Suing People Linked to Florida Clinic
description: Limited by their inability to compel people to cooperate with their investigators, Major League Baseball officials will open a new front in their battle against doping. They plan to file a lawsuit on Friday against a number of people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic, alleging that the individuals damaged the sport by providing some of the games biggest stars with performance-enhancing drugs, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Out of One Gram of Marijuana, a Manufactured Misdemeanor
description: For marijuana smokers in the right neighborhoods, there is no need to go out for supplies. A dealer-businessman will come right to the door, sit at the dining room table and open a box that looks as if it could be used to display herbal tea choices in restaurants. This particular case, however, is used to show varieties of cannabis  weed  and the businessman will annotate the flavor and potency of his offerings. Bought and smoked behind closed doors, the pot in such transactions has almost no risk of attracting attention from law enforcement.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 21, 2013

title: Suspect in Colorado Killing Is Shot in Texas
description: DENVER  A paroled Colorado inmate grievously wounded after a gun battle and high-speed chase with Texas law-enforcement officers on Thursday is suspected of being tied to the killing of the head of Colorados prison system.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Mar. 22, 2013
description: We reached the point where weapons should go silent and ideas speak.

title: The Cactus Commute
description: Cars on the New York City subway have been painted with saloon doors, wagon wheels and cactus plants as part of an advertising campaign to tempt sun-deprived New Yorkers into visiting Arizona.

title: Hockey Gear Is the Focus of a Tariff Cut in Canada
description: OTTAWA  Take a walk down an aisle at Pro Hockey Life, an emporium of the Canadian national sport here on the capitals southern fringe, and a customer comes away with a decidedly non-Canadian feel. Almost every pad, mask, stick and skate is made elsewhere  mostly in Asia, often by foreign-owned manufacturers.

title: Officials Concede Failures on Gauging Border Security
description: More than two years after Homeland Security officials told Congress that they would produce new, more accurate standards to assess security at the nations borders, senior officials from the department acknowledged this week that they had not completed the new measurements and were not likely to in coming months, as the debate proceeds about overhauling the immigration system.

title: Welcome to Scottsdale. Now, Watch the Doors.
description: We now interrupt this subway ride with a brief message from Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: O Revelations! Letters, Once Banned, Flesh Out Willa Cather
description: For decades Willa Cather has been a peculiar enigma in 20th-century American literature: beloved by ordinary readers for vivid evocations of frontier life in novels like O Pioneers! and My Antonia, but walled off from closer personal scrutiny by some of the tightest archival restrictions this side of J. D. Salinger.

title: Israelis Meet Obama Anew
description: President Obamas speech elicited appreciation and hope from Israelis at a viewing party in Tel Aviv, organized by a group called Peace Now.

title: Renewed Tax Credit Buoys Wind-Power Projects

title: A Home-Court Feeling for 2 Kansas Teams
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The selection committee didnt only do Kansas and Kansas State a travel favor by placing them in this Sprint Center pod. It may have ensured they both advance to the Round of 16.

title: Not in Eine Million Jahre
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This is the first time in my own solving history that I can honestly say that I was stumped by the entire top third of a puzzle. Its O.K.; I eventually finished, but I had to work my way back up, and even then, there were quite a few things I didnt know (Im looking at you, OTOMIS) or were fooled by in the cluing. If anyone else had a similar experience, this must be Friday, and this must be a Tim Croce puzzle.

title: Hope Is a Thing With Tires
description: You can hear the sound of America singing in Hands on a Hardbody, the daring new musical that opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Thursday night. With a bravado to match the gumption of its characters, a hard-pressed bunch of Texans hoping to beat the odds and win a truck in a grueling contest, this new show drives onto the Broadway lot without the high-gloss blandishments that adorn most big musicals: glittering sets and costumes, high-kicking chorines, megawatt star turns. Instead it concentrates its energies on giving voice to a story of average people fighting to hold onto hope in the face of fierce economic headwinds and bad breaks, not to mention buckling knees.

title: Lots of Food, Little Sleep, and Hope for Southern
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Twenty-four hours with the Southern University Jaguars, a full day in the life of a No. 16 seed at the N.C.A.A. tournament, included meetings, film review, a walk-through with an apple in place of a basketball, speeches, music, chess, backward cuff links, forgotten spandex, Law & Order and platters of meat. Nearly $1,200 worth of meat.

title: Dirty War Victim Rejects Popes Connection to Kidnapping
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A Jesuit priest whose kidnapping by the Argentine military raised questions about the actions of Jorge Mario Bergoglio, now Pope Francis, during that countrys so-called Dirty War said in a statement this week that Father Bergoglio did not initiate the detention by reporting him and another priest to the authorities.

title: Chicago Says It Will Close 54 Public Schools
description: CHICAGO  After weeks of uncertainty, principals at 54 public schools here officially learned from city officials on Thursday that their schools would close, with 11 more to share space with other schools. The closings represent the largest group of campuses to be shut down at one time by a city in recent memory.

title: Deal Will Give Cuomo Administration 12-Seat Suite at the Bills Stadium
description: ALBANY  The Buffalo Bills renovated stadium will feature a new entrance plaza and an 8,000-square-foot team store, as well as more restrooms and large video screens.

title: A Zigzag Offers a More Direct Route to a Park
description: It looks like something out of Tarzan, a wooden catwalk that snakes 450 feet through the air and moves gently up and down with each footfall. It is the long-awaited Squibb Bridge, which opened on Thursday and provides a new, faster way to access Brooklyn Bridge Park from Brooklyn Heights.

title: Aimed at Ecology, Park Groups Letter Offends Some Jews
description: It initially seemed like just an eco-friendly news release  a reminder to the public not to throw bread into Prospect Park Lake because it is not healthy for geese and other waterfowl.

title: Post Office Rebuffed Again on 5-Day Service
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service on Thursday received another setback in its attempts to stop delivering mail on Saturdays.

title: Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell
description: From Old Yellow Moon

title: Davidson Grants Marquette Last-Second Reprieve
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  When it was over Thursday night, after 39 bracket-busting minutes and one of pure mayhem, the Davidson Wildcats sat on their chairs, as if unwilling  or, perhaps, unable  to move. It was still all too fresh for them, how defeat was snatched from the jaws of victory, another monumental upset in the N.C.A.A. tournament filched with a second to spare.

title: City Health Officials Warn Some Men on Lethal Strain of Meningitis
description: It is a variant of a disease that can go from a fever and headache to a galloping rash and then to death within hours  so quickly that some victims have been found dead in bed before they could even get to a doctor. Over the last two years, it has appeared only among men, and they often got it, health officials say, through anonymous sexual encounters with other men found through Internet chat rooms or digital apps or at parties, making it all but impossible to trace the path of infection.

title: Commuter Cycling Stays Flat in 12
description: After years of growth in bike ridership, commuter cycling in New York remained flat in 2012 during the typical riding season, according to counts conducted by the city at six commuter locations last year.

title: In Budget, a Tax Break for Tonight to Relocate
description: ALBANY  The new state budget has a gift for NBC. A tax credit aimed at variety and talk shows, included in the new budget plan, will be an added incentive for NBC as it plots to relocate The Tonight Show to New York City. On Wednesday, The New York Times reported that the network plans to have Jimmy Fallon take over for Jay Leno next year.

title: Spending Cuts Put Damper on Trips by Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Official travel abroad by members of Congress  trips known universally on Capitol Hill by the shorthand term codels  has always been something of a sensitive topic.

title: Cano, the Classics M.V.P., Is Back in Camp
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Flashing one of his first-to-third smiles, Robinson Cano arrived at the Yankees spring training camp Thursday and said he wanted to keep the same momentum going from his successful stint in the World Baseball Classic.

title: Once Few, Women Hold More Power in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress, Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home. As Ms. Ayotte, a freshman Republican from New Hampshire, sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes, a doorman marched toward her with purpose.

title: For Albany, an Australian Pipeline to the Tournament
description: PHILADELPHIA  Shortly after the N.C.A.A tournament brackets were announced Sunday, Sam Rowley learned that his parents and his 19-year-old brother were working the phones to book flights so they could watch Albanys opening game here Friday afternoon.
