title: Funds Sought for New Guantnamo Jail
description: The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million for a new prison building at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, for special detainees, in addition to other renovations it says are necessary because Congress has decided to keep the prison open indefinitely. That brings the potential taxpayer bill for upgrading the deteriorating complex to $195.7 million, a spokesman for the command said Thursday. That is notably higher than an estimate of $150 million to $170 million provided by Gen. John F. Kelly, the commands leader, in Congressional testimony on Wednesday. The special facility was not included in a list of projects released by the Southern Command on Wednesday. The military has not given specifics about the facility, but it appears to be a replacement for Camp 7, which houses so-called high-value detainees like Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Frenetic Northwestern State Has Designs on an Upset
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  For a window into Northwestern States soul, look at Coach Mike McConathy as a player. He was a high school star in Bossier Parish, La., and was such a potent scorer at Louisiana Tech that his name remains scattered throughout the university record book.

(NBC) ROCK CENTER WITH BRIAN WILLIAMS Mr. Williams, above, interviews the Emanuel siblings: Ari, the talent agent and a chief executive of William Morris Endeavor; Rahm, the mayor of Chicago; and Zeke, a bioethicist, fellow at the Hastings Center and the author of Brothers Emanuel: A Memoir of an American Family. Ted Koppel investigates children who are kept in solitary confinement in adult prisons. And Kiran Chetry visits with 15 sets of twins in Lebanon, Tenn., and wonders if theres something in the water.

title: Seeking 90 Minutes of Peace for Two Teams and Their Fans

The match at Maksimir Stadium has long been feared as a potential flash point for fans with nationalist fervor and vivid memories of the ethnic clashes that brought war to the region in the 1990s.

title: Preserving a Famous American Racecar
description: The Ford Mark IV GT40 that Dan Gurney and A.J. Foyt drove to a historic victory at the 1967 24 Hours of Le Mans is going to be making a maintenance pit stop at Mr. Gurneys All American Racers shop in California. The swoopy red sports car belongs to the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., but made several appearances in Europe last year to commemorate the 45th anniversary of its Le Mans triumph. That tour of the continent proved somewhat taxing, and the car was slightly damaged, so the museum has asked the Gurney shop to perform a conservation  a process that will ensure the cars condition is the same as it was at the end of the race.

title: Blackstone Circles Dell
description: BLACKSTONE CIRCLES DELL | The Blackstone Group may yet emerge as a challenger to the proposed $24 billion buyout of Dell. With a deadline approaching at midnight Friday, the private equity firm is weighing whether to make an offer for all or part of the computer maker, though some people close to Blackstone are skeptical that any offer will materialize, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced reports. Still, among the parties that have looked at Dells books under a go-shop period run by a special committee of the companys board, Blackstone is considered the likeliest to make an offer, people briefed on the matter said.

Putin, to promote deeper cooperation with Russia while the United States has been shoring up ties with its own allies across the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Late Marriage and Its Consequences
description: On Wednesday I had the privilege of joining a Brookings Institution eventorganized around the new report Knot Yet: The Benefits and Costs of Delayed Marriage, which tries to tease out the social implications of the steadily rising age of first marriage now at 27 for women and 29 for men, both historic highs. Not surprisingly, a lot of the discussion focused on the impact of this trend on children, because the story of late marriage is entangled with the story of rising out-of-wedlock births, thanks to what the authors call the great crossover the fact that the age of first marriage,which was once about a year earlier than the average age at which the first child was born, now lags the average age of first birth by about a year. Hence the reports most attention-grabbing statistic:That 48 percent of overall first births, and 58 percent of first births to what the report calls Middle Americans women with a high school diploma and maybe some college, but no 4-year degree now take place outside of marriage,a trendwhose negative consequences for childrenprobablydont need to be rehearsed here.

Crown Media joins a lengthy list of media companies pursuing original programming rather than rerunning shows from broadcast networks. William J. description: QUANTICO, Va.  Three staff members of the Marines officer training school are dead after a gunman killed himself and two colleagues, a man and a woman, officials said on Friday.

title: The Apotheosis of the Tiger Man
description: In the trailer for Himmatwala (The Brave), a remake of a 1983 revenge drama that releases next Friday, Ajay Devgns title character stands outside a temple and swings, by long golden chains, massive temple bells in each hand as a crowd of 50 men armed with sickles and scythes charges toward him.

title: A Bridge for Two Bicentenary Rivals
description: WAGNER AND VERDI are destined to be linked forever, however awkwardly, since they were both born in 1813: Wagner in Leipzig, Germany, on May 22; Verdi in little Roncole, Italy, in the Duchy of Parma, on Oct. 9 or 10. (The records are not clear.)

title: Highlights and Analysis: N.C.A.A. Tournament, Round of 64, Day 2
description: O.K., O.K. So you probably didnt pick Harvard on Thursday night. Or Wichita State. But you had Oregons upset, right? And Cal?  Well, fine, but a lot of people disrespect the Pac-12, so your bracket is probably still alive in the office pool and you need to keep up with Fridays action. Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters will supply updates from around the country.

title: New Chief of Royal Opera Is a Manager, Not an Artist
description: LONDONWhen it was announced in November that Tony Hall, the chief executive of the Royal Opera House, would leave in April to run the BBC, speculation about who would replace him was immediately rife. Mr. Hall is a hard act to follow. In the 12 years that he has run the opera house, he has transformed it from an institution beset by a succession of artistic directors, funding problems and a reputation for elitest money-wasting, to a model of balanced budgets, expanded access and artistic stability.

title: Backer of an Open Internet Steps Down as F.C.C. Chief
description: The resignation on Friday of Julius Genachowskiafter four years as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission again raises a thorny issue forPresident Obama: whether it will be possible to get the F.C.C. or Congress to help him fulfill a campaign promise to guarantee that the Internet remains free and open to businesses and users.

title: Galloping Through Grand Central
description: The sight of 30 multicolored horses galloping through Grand Central Terminal would give pause to even the most jaded New Yorker. But dont worry; you wont be imagining things. From March 25 to March 31, at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. each day, a group of students from the Ailey School of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will put on horse costumes  which are actually the artist Nick Caves famous mixed-media Soundsuits  and move through the space, either as a herd or in smaller groups. The project, HEARD NY, which Cave has done in collaboration with the Chicago choreographer William Gill, is presented by Creative Time and MTA Arts for Transit to celebrate Grand Centrals centennial. Between performances, the Soundsuits will be on display in the terminals Vanderbilt Hall for closer inspection. The video above offers a glimpse of the dancers rehearsing on-site, as well as the reactions of passers-by.

title: In Mindfulness, a Method to Sharpen Focus and Open Minds
description: LIKE most people, I have my share of tension and anxiety. And Im happy to find ways to cope that dont involve illegal drugs. So when the term mindfulness began cropping up everywhere, I became intrigued.

title: What Were Reading
description: Smithsonian: No, its not Captain Nemo and his crew, its a team of researchers investigating the giant squid, and heres everything you ever wanted to know about the mysteries of this exceedingly rare tentacled creature. Tastes like chicken?  Glenn Collins

title: When Tonight Was a Lifeline to New York City
description: So we called Dick Cavett to ask what The Tonight Show had meant to New York when it originated from Midtown Manhattan. Our idea was to follow up on reports that NBC planned to bring Tonight back to New York after a 41-year exile in California and name Jimmy Fallon the host, replacing Jay Leno.

title: Ask Well: Fresh vs. Dried Blueberries
description: Question:

title: Global Study of Monsoons Finds Ocean Variations Have Driven Recent Shifts
description: [March 24, 11:10 p.m.: Apologies for the blog silence and slow comment moderation. Im camped on a beach with Pace University students making a film about efforts to balance fishing with marine conservation. ]

title: Senate Republicans Push to Slow Financial Rule-Writing
description: Congress cut a deal to keep the lights on in Washington. But new measures in the Senate may cut the power of financial regulators to curb Wall Street risk-taking.

title: Leading Off: The First Full Day, From Agony to Ecstasy
description: For so long, the two games were remarkably similar. No. 14 Davidson wasnt playing the plucky underdog trying to surprise No. 3 Marquette, it was dismantling the Golden Eagles, just as its bookend, No. 14 seed Harvard, would discombobulate No. 3 New Mexico. This was true parity on display, teams much more evenly matched than their seeds would ever suggest. Our country may be separated into the 1 percent and the 99 percent, but college basketball is one big mosh pit of nearly equal opportunity. Get into the N.C.A.A. tournament and almost anything can happen.

title: Ratings Fall for Anger Management, With 80 Episodes to Go
description: The cable channel FX raised a few eyebrows last August when it agreed to order 90 more episodes of Charlie Sheens comedy Anger Management, after only 10 episodes had been shown. It was an unusually large commitment to a new show, not often seen in television.

title: The Things She Carried
description: Mary Beth Keanes first novel, The Walking People, could stand as a historical sequel to her new novel, Fever. The earlier book is the story of two Irish sisters who immigrate to New York in the early 1960s, accompanied by a young man who belongs to the walking people, also known as the traveling people or tinkers. That novel is less about the anomalous position these itinerant peddlers occupy in Irish society than it is about the consequences of concealing from a child the circumstances of her birth. At the same time its a long, fond portrait of a family.

title: Ive Been Meaning to Tell You
description: The other day a headline, Female Prison Guard Pregnant by Cop Killer Inmate, came pulsing across the electronic ticker of a morning news show. Paging T. Coraghessan Boyle! I thought. The outsize combination of tragedy and brinkmanship, of hope and human folly, was straight out of a Boyle story. Several books in, we know exactly what we mean by a T. C. Boyle story  or a William Trevor story or an Antonya Nelson story. Indeed our pleasure is heightened by knowing the lay of the land because we can read for the new: how this particular Alice Munro story differs from what weve come to expect from an Alice Munro story.

title: Straight Through the Heart
description: As each semester begins at Grinnell College, a small liberal arts school nestled in the Iowa prairie, I get numerous e-mails from students pleading for a spot in my fiction workshop. The wait list is long, and as much as Id love to take credit for the courses popularity, Im learning its less about the teacher and more about the way fiction writers approach the teaching of literature.

title: Up Front
description: This winter, as we made our way through the usual stacks of upcoming titles on our shelves, we noticed an interesting trend: Many of the books that held our attention were written by first- or second-time authors who were relatively or entirely new to the scene. Apart from the unfamiliarity of the names on the title pages, not much united these works. There were novels, story collections, memoirs of food and art and unimaginable suffering. Their authors represented a range of backgrounds and sensibilities. And new didnt necessarily mean young  youth (or age, for that matter) being no indicator of talent. But all the voices were fresh, and all made us sit up a bit straighter before settling in for the journey. Call it an accident of timing, but publishings spring crop offers a tangible rebuke to the lament that books are endangered, and suggests that literatures future is in good hands.

title: Japan Leader Backs Move of U.S. Base on Okinawa
description: TOKYO  Seeking to remove a longstanding irritant in Japans ties with the United States, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Friday that his government would ask local officials on the island of Okinawa for a key permit to begin construction to relocate an unpopular American air base to another part of the island.

title: Inside the List
description: A BOARDROOM OF ONES OWN: Lean In, Sheryl Sandbergs polarizing manifesto about the role of women in the workplace, roars onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 1. Sandberg is the chief operating officer of Facebook, and her book has renewed longstanding debates about the paucity of female executives and the best way to remedy it. (Sandbergs answer, boiled down, is: Work harder, girls!) One sign that the book has touched a nerve is that, along with a steady stream of praise, it is also fielding criticism from across the ideological spectrum. On the one hand, in the biology is destiny camp, Christina Hoff Sommers recently charged in The Atlantic that Sandberg was mired in 1970s-style feminism with her earnest calls for consciousness-raising groups and her desire to liberate her fellow Americans from the stereotypes of gender. What if those stereotypes are innate, Sommers wondered, and women just arent interested in high-powered careers? In the pursuit of happiness, she wrote, men and women often take different paths.

title: Varieties of Disturbance
description: In the middle of Manuel Gonzaless lucid and confident first collection of stories, The Miniature Wife, he tells a tale from the point of view of a half-human, half-zombie with conflicting urges. Its one of the strongest (and funniest) in the collection, no small feat in our zombie-saturated cultural landscape. It also, in its way, sums up the central struggle of many of Gonzaless characters: When does one just sit by, and when do darker impulses bubble up and take over? When do we stand aside, and when do we act? These stories vary widely  an elegiac description of a plane circling Dallas for decades, a futuristic wake mourning the loss of Africa into the ocean, social science reportage about false anthropological claims  but they work best when the characters, for whatever reasons, succumb to a buried darkness. Inner zombie rises up.

title: Washed Away
description: Sonali Deraniyagalas extraordinary memoir, Wave, opens on the morning of Dec. 26, 2004, as the author putters around a Sri Lankan beach-side hotel with her family. By chapters end shes pantless, half-drowned, bleeding, bruised and numbly resistant to what shell soon be forced to know: The five people she loves most in the world are dead. Her two young sons. Her husband. Her parents. All of them killed by a force she cant yet comprehend, though she was caught up in it and nearly killed by it too. She only knows that something came for us. It was, as she and the world will soon learn, a tsunami of epic scale that took an estimated 230,000 lives across a dozen countries.

title: Swinging Back to the Heyday of the Rat Pack
description: She was a just toddler when her father, Pat Boone, was a Las Vegas headliner who hobnobbed with the Rat Pack. But the singer Debby Boone had her eyes and ears wide open, and she remembers things like the look of Sammy Davis Jr.s house and Dean Martins jokes about her fathers teetotaling. And on Tuesday evening at Caf Carlyle Ms. Boone, glamorized to the max, was the very picture of a tastefully attired Las Vegas babe as she devoted an entire program to songs of the Rat Pack era in a show titled Swing This. The swing was provided by an excellent nine-member band under the direction of John Oddo, the longtime musical director of Ms. Boones mother-in-law, Rosemary Clooney.

title: 186-Year-Old Vampire Haunts Carnegie Hall
description: Witches are an operatic staple, but vampire protagonists rarely appear in productions today. Heinrich Marschners Vampire is one of the several early-19th-century vampire-theme works that are now seldom performed.

title: House of Cards Recap, Episode 9: Alliances Crumbling on All Sides
description: If you have loyally stayed with us to this point, you know the drill. Ashley Parker and David Carr put the old gimlet eye on House of Cards with an emphasis on the optics and verisimilitude of the shows media and political angles. And if you are just arriving, you can catch up with recaps of episodes one, two,three, four, five, six,seven or eight. Lots of spoilers, so proceed with caution.

title: Vying for a Shot of the Wedding
description: To promote photo sharing at their wedding in Manchester, N.H., last month, Laura Bishop and Walter Carroll placed postcards on the tables with instructions for their guests on how to download an application called WedPics. After the reception, the couple immediately signed onto WedPics and found some 200 photographs.

title: For Photographers, Competition Gets Fierce
description: For professional photographers, advancements in technology pose an interesting predicament. Camera innovations have enabled them to take better photos, but its lowered the barrier to entry by competitors.

title: Q & A
description: Plumbers Permit Required

title: Mommy Highest
description: Nikki, the childhood incarnation of Domenica Ruta and the daughter of a sometimes charismatic, other times irascible Italian-American single mom, makes the following precocious observation early on in With or Without You. Even nature programs revealed to us the brutal world as we recognized it: sharks leaving flesh wounds as part of the courtship ritual, procreation by gang rape and, for the finale, intrauterine cannibalism! Shakespeare couldnt have done a finer job.

title: To Talk to You in Letters
description: With enough distance, its possible to be nostalgic about pretty much anything, even the gray-flannel decade the poet Robert Lowell, who spent part of it on Thorazine, called the tranquilized 50s. Ah, for the days of duck and cover, The Pajama Game and I Like Ike. Now Carlene Bauer, author of a precocious memoir, Not That Kind of Girl, about growing up evangelical in a secular age, has dug into the dawn of the Mad Men era for her first novel, about two young writers on the rise who meet at an artists colony modeled on Yaddo during the summer of 1957.

title: Saucy Dishes
description: Hold the presses! Not all Asian-Americans are studying math and practicing the piano. Some, like the young Eddie Huang, are busy shoplifting CDs, taking Ecstasy and getting thrown in the clink. Huangs rambunctious memoir boasts many classic adolescent moments  the employment of a SPAM launcher, for example, and the inevitable arrival of a Miss Lacey on the scene. There are tussles with his parents, tussles with his peers. There are cops and drugs. And of course, channeling his inner Holden Caulfield involves, well, language:

title: Everything in Its Path
description: Just before 1 oclock on the afternoon of March 18, 1925, over the farmland of southeastern Missouri, a column of air, spinning like a skater with her arms folded, came down from the clouds and touched ground. To prevent public panic, the word tornado had been officially banned from United States weather forecasts since 1887, so the regional forecast called only for rain and shifting winds. It was possibly the greatest understatement in the history of meteorology.

title: A Feast for the Senses
description: Ive managed to eat at Kenny Shopsins legendary restaurant and customer-hazing clinic only once, thanks to a regular who had passed muster and brought me along to breakfast. This was when Shopsins was still in Greenwich Village and felt like a crazed version of the general store it had once been; over the stack of plain pancakes that I ordered without knowing any better, I tried not to be too alarmed by the abusive banter in the kitchen between Shopsin and one of his sons  which sounded, to the uninitiated, like a job for 911. Could I call social services, I wondered, and still come back for more pancakes?

title: Beautiful Losers
description: A generous humanity and a fond wit animate Jim Gavins wonderful first collection, Middle Men. Gavins stories revolve around a familiar theme  men searching for identity and meaning  but theyre distinguished by his more specific concerns: how work shapes lives, and the differences in the way the young and the old confront the humbling problem of ambition and success. Gavins characters, most of whom live in down-at-the-heels neighborhoods of Los Angeles or in modest industrial towns south of the city, are sons of journeymen, low-paid assistants and traveling salesmen. These men know, or are beginning to suspect, that the mark they will make on the world is small. But Middle Men doesnt wallow in pessimism; with deft portraiture, nimble prose and an intimacy with the lives of his amiable characters, Gavin shows us that the real work of a life takes place not when the sale is made but when the salesman goes back home, looks in a half-empty refrigerator and considers his options.

title: Buffalo Noir
description: When it comes to great settings for a crime novel, theres no place like home. For Stephan Talty, thats Buffalo, which he has made both the locale and a major character in his first thriller, BLACK IRISH (Ballantine, $26). As viewed by Detective Absalom (Abbie) Kearney, lately returned to care for a father whose mind is going, Buffalo is a decaying place, sunk in despair, haunted by its illustrious past. The whole city was entombed by the artifacts of its glory days, she observes of the disintegrating waterfront, the bankrupt mills and silent smokestacks, the highways built for a population long gone. And nowhere is this sense of loss more keenly felt than in the section where Abbie grew up, a patch of Ireland in the wilds of America known as the County.

title: Women in the Upper Chamber
description: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota discusses the record number of women in the United States Senate.

title: The Gun Report: March 22, 2013
description: Last month, Joewrote about Jewelry For a Cause, which designs bracelets that were initially made from melted-down guns confiscated in long-forgotten Newark, N.J. criminal cases. The company has since donated $40,000 to the city of Newark to help pay for gun buybacks, with the idea that it would use the guns metal to make more bracelets. A virtuous cycle if ever there was one.

title: For the Caring Generation, a New Name in Luxury
description: The French luxury group PPR will henceforth be known as Kering. In a statement today, the group said its new moniker (pronounced caring) reflects the distinctive way in which we look after our brands, our staff, our customers and our stakeholders.

title: Stress of Cancer Scare May Last Years
description: The psychological fallout from a false positive mammogram test result can last up to three years, a new study has found.

title: Weekends Worse for Surgery
description: Emergency surgeries performed on a weekend may have poorer results than the same operation performed on a weekday, a new study concludes.

title: Ancient Art for a Modern World
description: Inside a rambling Victorian house in New Brighton, a part of Old Russia lives on. Most days, the Rev. John Walsted crouches over a worktable in his second-floor studio, dipping a slender brush into glistening pools of egg yolk and powdered pigment as he painstakingly creates Orthodox-style icons for churches and private collections.

title: Antidoping Lawsuit Cites Six People With Links to Florida Clinic
description: In its continuing fight to thwart the use of performance-enhancing drugs, Major League Baseball took the unusual step Friday of filing a lawsuit in Florida state court, accusing six people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic of damaging the sport by providing various players with prohibited substances.

title: Honda Recalling 76,000 Acura TSX Models for Stalling Problem
description: 3:14 p.m. | Updated Citing a problem first detected in Iceland in 2011, Honda is recalling about 76,000 of its 20048 Acura TSX models in the United States because of a stalling problem, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a report posted on the agencys Web site.

title: The Drink With No Name
description: During my San Francisco bar crawl, I was charmed by Big, a minuscule lounge. It has the finest virtues of great cocktail bars (foremost among them: thoughtful, unusual drinks prepared with great finesse) minus the stuffiness that sometimes suffuses such places.

title: Mar. 24  Mar. 30
description: Heroism Recalled In a Signature Piece

title: How My Sister Cured My Writers Block
description: So I call her on Sunday morning. I ask the usual questions about her week, and then I say, Im stuck. Send me just one sentence. Can be about anything. It doesnt matter.

title: Oy Vey, Christian Soldiers
description: Of all the surprises promised by the recent TLC reality show The Sisterhood, which followed the lives of five Atlanta preachers wives, the only one that truly amazed me was the Christian bar mitzvah, an event organized by Pastor Tara Lewis and her husband, Pastor Brian, for their son, Trevor. Brian was born to Jewish parents; Tara was not. Both are born-again Christians, and theyre of one mind about their sons bar mitzvah as a Christ-centered take on the traditional Jewish coming-of-age ceremony.

title: A Tax Lawyers Quandary
description: I am a tax lawyer. Is advising wealthy companies of ways to reduce their tax bills through sophisticated legal structures ethically permissible? The structures take advantage of legal loopholes in the tax legislation. NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: Mary Robinson Doesnt Need to Be Popular
description: In your memoir, Everybody Matters, you write that you were the third child amid four boys. Do you think having so many brothers affected your political path?  I do joke that this is the start of my belief in human rights and using my elbows. But more seriously, I had a stronger sense of myself as a young Irishwoman than many of my contemporaries. When I was elected president of Ireland in 1990, I was very conscious that I could use symbols in a way that would be harder, maybe, for a man. In my inauguration, I emphasized the word love, which is somehow easier for a woman to use.

title: Who Made Spring Break?
description: In 1958, Glendon Swarthout, an English professor at Michigan State University, overheard his students buzzing about their Easter-break trip to Fort Lauderdale. In that more-ecumenical era, students typically shuttled home to attend church services with their parents, but now word was spreading of another kind of spring break. Swarthout decided to tag along so that he could observe the rituals (pool-hopping, pith helmets, beatnik jazz) and capture the lingo (beaucoup beers, schizoid, babyroo). Upon his return, he dashed off a novel about coeds who cruise the beach and play house with boys from other colleges  a 1950s version of Girls Gone Wild. In a nod to the Easter season, he called his book Unholy Spring, but Hollywood executives persuaded him to change the title to Where the Boys Are. The result was a blockbuster book that was spun off into a movie  marketed with the phrase spring vacation  as well as a Connie Francis song.

title: The 3.10.13 Issue
description: THE ALLERGY BUSTER

title: Kate Atkinsons Groundhog Day Fiction
description: Imagine having the gift (or the curse) of continually dying and being reborn, so that you relive segments of your life again and again, differently each time, going down various paths and smoothing out rough areas until you get it right and can move on. Imagine, too, that you are not conscious that this is happening, but experience it as intermittent dj vu, a sometimes-inchoate dread, an inexplicable compulsion at sudden moments to do one thing rather than another.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE RIGHTEOUS MIND: Why Good People Are Divided by Politics and Religion,  by Jonathan Haidt. (Vintage, $16.) Why doesnt the other side listen to reason? Haidt, a social psychologist, charts the mental mechanisms that make us adept at promoting our groups interests, in competition with other groups, and explains why liberals and conservatives have such different intuitions about right and wrong. In Our Divided Political Heart: The Battle for the American Idea in an Age of Discontent (Bloomsbury, $18), the Washington Post columnist E. J. Dionne Jr. situates our current political dysfunction in the full sweep of American history. Americans disagree about who we are, he writes, because we cant agree about who weve been.

title: Pope Appeals for More Interreligious Dialogue
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis appealed for more intense dialogue with Islam on Friday, while calling on church leaders to renew diplomatic discourse with countries that do not have official ties with the Holy See, like China.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A 5-bedroom A-frame in Bridgwater, N.J. and a renovated 43-year-old home in Fairfield Conn.

title: Generations of Style by Coach
description: Coach features its spring collection of handbags and accessories in a series of videos that brings together young and old fashion icons to discuss what style means today.

title: Young Immigrants, Seeking Deferred Action Help, Find Unexpected Path
description: When Angy Rivera, an illegal immigrant, was a young girl in New York City, she was sexually abused by her mothers boyfriend. He was eventually convicted and imprisoned, but only recently did Ms. Rivera find out that her cooperation with investigators had qualified her for a special benefit: a visa for victims of serious crimes.

title: Image of the Day: March 22
Editors Choice
description: THE ACCURSED,  by Joyce Carol Oates. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.) Oatess extravagantly horrifying, funny and prolix postmodern Gothic novel purports to be the definitive account of a curse that infected bucolic Princeton, N.J., in 1905 and 1906.

title: As Profit Slips, Credit Suisse Increases C.E.O. Pay by 34%
description: LONDON  Even as the banks profit slipped, Credit Suisse increased pay for its chief executive, Brady W. Dougan, by 34 percent.

title: A Sticky Dashboard Mount That Holds Any Phone
description: The DashIT, a dashboard phone holder, may overstate its case as the cure for the affliction of the suction cup mount, but it is certainly an inexpensive alternative.

title: Cargo Ship Losses Weigh on European Banks
description: FRANKFURT  Can a ship float and be underwater at the same time? If it has been financed by a European bank, the answer may be yes.

title: Q&A: Picking an Audience for Your Facebook Updates
description: Q.

title: Taking Questions for Game of Thrones Creators
description: March 29 | Updated  Answers are posted here.

title: The Stealthy Solicitor General
description: At the 128th annual Gridiron Dinner in Washington, D.C., the other week, a white-tied gentleman told the N.A.A.C.P.s Benjamin Jealous that his colleague who argued at the Supreme Court in favor of upholding key parts of the Voting Rights had done a fine job.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A five-bedroom Midwood, Brooklyn home built in 1908, a Murray Hill Co-op with a solarium and a West Village prewar walk-up with a windowed staircase.

title: SXSW: A Boon for Bands or Brands?
description: Jon Caramanica debriefs Jon Pareles, a veteran of more than 20 South by Southwest Music Festivals, about last weeks edition.

title: Officials Release Details of Plan to Build Near Housing Projects
description: One public housing project, Frederick Douglass Houses on the Upper West Side, could eventually add as many as three apartment buildings  with a total of 794 units  on what are now parking spaces on its grounds. Another project, Alfred E. Smith Houses, could see as many as 1,151 apartments rise on a single parcel of land by the East River.

title: A Full Circle for Emmylou Harris
description: In her four-decade career, Emmylou Harris has earned a dozen Grammy Awards and a spot in the Country Music Hall of Fame. Her long list of collaborators includes Gram Parsons, Bob Dylan, Roy Orbison, George Jones, Willie Nelson, Neil Young, Dolly Parton, Linda Ronstadt and Rodney Crowell, an old friend and former band mate with whom she has just released a duets album, Old Yellow Moon.

title: Style Coaches
description: In a new digital project called Generations of Style, Coach features its spring collection of handbags and accessories in a series of videos that brings together young and old fashion icons to discuss what style means today. Ari Seth Cohen, the 31-year-old behind Advanced Style, orchestrated the one-on-one conversations between fashion bloggers in their 20s and women ranging in age from 65 to 92. I love these intergenerational projects that bring younger people into the same environment as older people to discuss things that they can both relate to and really show that there is a lot that they can learn from each other, he says. In one of the flicks, Cohen captures Leandra Medine (Man Repeller) playing dress up with the Off Broadway Boutique owner Lynn Dell and saying, I cant wait to turn 80!

title: In Guyana, Wildlife Makes a Slow Return
description: Dr. Lesley de Souza, a research biologist at John G. Shedd Aquarium, writes from Guyana, where she studies the regions rich aquatic wildlife, including the arapaima, one of the largest freshwater fishes in the world.

title: M.L.B. Turns to Young Stars to Reach New Fans
description: Trout, Harper, Posey, McCutchen and Price. Sounds like an advertising agency, or a law firm. Actually, the names are those of several of the young stars who will be the face of the effort from Major League Baseball to promote Opening Day 2013.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Downton Abbey has put a spotlight on all things British. Now the British tourism board, VisitBritain, is using that attention to showcase the country in a two-day pop-up shop, at 78 Mercer Street in SoHo, from noon to 6 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Everything from tea to gin-based cocktails will be featured.

title: Years Oddest Book Title: Goblinproofing Ones Chicken Coop
description: Imagine a book prize for which the finalists include titles like How Tea Cosies Changed the World, Was Hitler Ill? and Gods Doodle: The Life and Times of the Penis.

title: Common Core Practice | Drones, Stolen Art and Space Exploration
description: A few weeks ago, two teachers, Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen, our collaborators for this series of writing prompts, showed how they integrate STEM topics  science, technology, engineering and mathematics  into their humanities classroom by exploring environmental issues.

title: Funding Site to Designers: Leave the Business End to Us
description: The other day you may have read about Patrick Robinson, the former Gap creative director, who is producing a new line, Paskho, with money he hopes to raise on Kickstarter. Among crowd-funding sites, Kickstarter is the largest, with more 30,000 projects financed and $300 million in pledges. A virtue of these sites is that for a small sum an investor can feel included in the creative process, whether its a film or an amazing sweatshirt. If the project is successful, investors receive a reward or privilege.

title: Questions for the NoMads General Manager
description: Next Sunday, the Metropolitan section will introduce a Q. and A. series with New Yorkers whose behind-the-scenes jobs  from the service industry to city government  help keep the city humming.

title: Why Cyprus Will Pay Dearly
description: Cyprus will pay dearly for its sins. The Mediterranean island has committed many follies over the years  and is still making mistakes.

title: Walt Whitmans Boss
description: On the morning of March 20, 1863, Walt Whitman sat at his desk in a bustling office building in Washington and penned a letter to friends. At one point, he gazed out of his fifth-floor window at the wartime capital. After a long pause he resumed writing and described the vista.

title: A Vegan Passover
description: Holidays are often a challenge for vegans, who eschew all animal foods. But few holidays present more obstacles to vegan diners than Passover, which imposes a daunting set of dietary restrictions.

title: Tony Bennett to Record With Lady Gaga
description: Tony Bennett says he plans to record an album with the pop diva Lady Gaga. Speaking after he received a lifetime achievement award on Thursday in New York from the Amy Winehouse Foundation, the veteran jazz singer said he and Lady Gaga had yet to go into the studio, but had agreed to collaborate on a big swing album.

title: Eat Your Greens (With Beans)
description: Greens and beans are a natural combination in many parts of the world, but they havent necessarily caught on in the United States. In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman celebrates this healthful combination that can be turned into a hearty, high-protein, one-dish meal.

title: The Sweet Spot | Alt-Weekly Journalism
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott look at alternative weekly newspapers, which grew out of the counterculture and are now disappearing.

title: An Unexpected Apology
description: The Timess Mark Landler on a reconciliation between Israel and Turkey brokered by President Obama.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in North Carolina, London, San Antonio, Berlin
description: Beer Month, North Carolina Craft beer followers already pour into North Carolina because of its reputation as the Souths premier beer destination, with more breweries than any state south of Pennsylvania (73 and counting). In April, theres another reason to imbibe: the states inaugural North Carolina Beer Month. Among the highlights is the Hickory Hops festival on April 20, with 40-plus breweries, music and the Carolinas Championship of Beers.

title: Serbs and Croats Renew Soccer Hostilities
description: Last Updated, 3:04 p.m. The match has now concluded in Zagreb, with Croatia winning 2-0 and the coaches of the two national teams embracing in the center circle. Twitter updates filed by journalists from the stadium in Zagreb during the game are at the foot of this post.

title: Chinua Achebe and the Bravery of Lions
description: Chinua Achebe, the Nigerian writer who died on Thursday at 82, spent his life thinking deeply about his home country, Nigeria. After moving to the United States in 1990, he still kept a close eye on Nigeria and offered strong opinions about its leadership and politics.

title: The Sweet Spot: Ferociously Local
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott look at alternative weekly newspapers, which grew out of the counterculture and are now gradually disappearing.

title: Letter by Letter, Keeping a Catholic Outpost Alive
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill.  On a raw and windswept day in this forsaken place, as the rest of the worlds eyes turned to the cardinals assembling amid Vatican grandeur to select a new pope, Brother Norbert Karpfinger sat down to write a letter. It was late February, two weeks into Lent, a busy time for the correspondence that is his mission.

title: Vows: Jenn and Meadow
description: Jennifer Barron and Meadow Braun each wanted to experience proposing and being proposed to, so they popped the question twice.

title: Anticipation
description: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

title: Thailand: Deadly Fires Erupts at Refugee Camp
description: BANGKOK  A fire at a refugee camp in Thailand killed at least 30 people on Friday, a Thai firefighter said.

title: Starting With a Near Miss
description: Sometimes love starts with a bang.

title: The Awesome Journey of Coley the Osprey
description: A fish hawk named Coley reunited with his mate off the coast of Queens this week on the first day of spring. His spiky brown crest was slightly ruffled, but otherwise, he seemed surprisingly poised after completing his northern migration.

title: Minimalist Parenting, Manimalist Style
description: My wife is leaving for a conference tomorrow. The next five days will be the longest stretch of time Ive spent taking care of our twin, almost-4-year-old daughters without any backup.

title: Popcast: Does SXSW Benefit Bands or Brands?
description: Over the last 27 years, the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., has evolved from a smallish and legible festival highlighting up-and-coming music acts into a several-days-long extravaganza of branded showcases, afternoon concerts, breakaway parties and more.

title: Chinese Solar Giants Bankruptcy Presents a Test
description: The main operating company of Suntech Power Holdings is in bankruptcy in China, less than a week after attempting to win some sort of award for the oddest restructuring attempt ever.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jamie Quatro talks about I Want to Show You More; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Carlene Bauer discusses Frances and Bernard; and Gregory Cowles has best-sellers news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Suspects Ties to Other Killings Explored
description: DENVER  As investigators unravel the tangled and violent path of a Colorado parolee tied to the killing of the states prison chief, they are also examining whether he had connections to two other violent deaths, including the January killing of a Texas prosecutor.

title: Jeter Returns to Practice Determined to Play
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One day after the Yankees said they were shutting down shortstop Derek Jeter from playing in any more major league spring training games, he announced Friday that nobody should rule out anything.

title: What Are You Doing for World Water Day?
description: When you open your tap today and, as if by miracle (and thanks to a good deal of engineering), a stream of clean and drinkable water starts flowing, think of the millions of people for whom such basic access is not so simple.

title: Gibraltar Seeks to Woo Brazilian Hedge Funds and Private Equity
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Tiny Gibraltar is trying to cash in on Brazils rising wealth.

title: Bluebird Wine
description: From Old Yellow Moon

title: Among the Vines in Chile, Villas and Views
description: From my horse-top perch, I could view seemingly endless rows of green vines, stretching out across a wide valley floor. To the west, sharp mountains rose behind a glassy emerald lake reflecting slow-moving clouds; a family of herons roosted by the water. Other than the winemaker who rode next to me, a few workers, hundreds of cattle, those herons and millions of precious grapes, I was alone on this 11,000-acre Chilean estate.

title: Winter Is Prime in Puglia
description: Disappointment swept across the table. Daniela, our waitress, with tight jeans and dyed pink hair, hovered over our table, shaking her head. I trying to warn you, she scolded. There were dozens of bowls of antipasto unfinished, many of them untouched. She just shook her head some more. I leaving and you eating. Now. With a nod that smacked of finality, she turned and sashayed back to the kitchen.

title: Miami, My Way
description: We stood on the Everglades boardwalk, an hour south of Miami Beach, squinting in the sun, looking like fools. He was as white as milk and as gangly as Napoleon Dynamite, with a gaudy beach towel wed bought at aWoolworths tied around his neck. I was dressed head-to-toe in discount specials: a bright orange cover-up and plastic sandals three sizes too big. As we stood in our absurd get-ups, marring the blue-skied Florida backdrop, he told me I looked like a Dreamsicle.

title: Ready to Fight Gay Marriage at Court Door
description: WASHINGTON  As gay couples fight for the right to wed, a little-known but determined force is working to stop them: Brian S. Brown, a 39-year-old father of eight who has raised millions of dollars from religious conservatives  especially his fellow Roman Catholics  to become the nations leading opponent of same-sex marriage.

title: Judges Spat Strikes a Chord Among Deal Makers
description: Deal makers delivered a verdict on snarky judges at the annual M.&A. jamboree in New Orleans this week. The spectacle of Delaware jurists bashing the clever bromides and superfluous legal rulings of colleagues elicited hoots of delight from the assembled lawyers and bankers. The criticism is on target. To avoid any confusion, courts should stick to the facts and the law.

title: Hofstra Fires Basketball Coach
description: After a 7-25 season and a litany of player arrests, Hofstra fired its mens basketball coach, Mo Cassara, on Friday morning after three seasons.

title: In Defense of Palestinians
description: Back when Republicans senators and conservative commentators were consumed with trying to bury Chuck Hagels nomination as defense secretary, one of their patently false lines of attack was that he was anti-Israel.

title: New Leader Taps Mexican Discontent to Press Agenda of Change
description: MEXICO CITY  Few topics get Mexicans more worked up than their countrys cellphone service, especially that provided by the dominant carrier, Telcel.

title: A Mad Romance
description: For the shoe designer Christian Louboutin, the cinema of India has always been a magical, otherworldly, Technicolor fantasy. He heads to the Marrakesh film festival to meet his favorite stars of the screen.

title: Well Before Summer, Hamptons Luxury Real Estate Is Scorching
description: The emerald hedgerows that are a natural euphemism for Hamptons exclusivity (out here, good hedges, not good fences, make for felicitous neighbors) are hanging tight.

title: Immigration Talks Hit Snag Over Business and Labor Concerns
description: 9:01 p.m. | Updated On Friday evening, the group of eight senators who are working to produce bipartisan immigration legislation and racing to work out a final dispute between the business and labor communities before Congress left for a two-week recess hit yet another obstacle, when the four Republican senators in the group spurned what a major union described as a another attempt at compromise.

title: Shalom, Mr. President: Obama Tries to Charm Israelis With Hebrew
description: JERUSALEM  As one Israeli columnist put it, he had them at Shalom.

title: John Mayer to Tour This Summer
description: John Mayer announced on Friday he will mount a major concert tour this summer, his first in three years. The tour comes after a lengthy period of surgery and resting his voice to repair damage to his vocal cords.

title: Wanted: Hot- and Cold-Running Quiet
description: It was the street noise that made Crystal Wei want to leave her shared apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where she paid a rent of around $1,100 a month. A bus stop was nearby, as was a rowdy bar. Ms. Wei made an uneasy truce with the racket, but her mother, when she visited, couldnt sleep.

title: Book Review Podcast: Strange and Thrilling Stories
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, J. Robert Lennon admires Jamie Quatros collection of stories, I Want to Show You More, calling it an obsessive first collection that feels like a fifth or sixth. Mr. Lennon writes:

title: However Justices Rule, Issues Remain
description: If the Supreme Court strikes down the law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman, same-sex couples across the country will undoubtedly gain access to a broad range of federal benefits.

title: Another Day of Madness
description: The second day of the Round of 64 featured 16 more games on Friday, with many more upsets.

title: Does a No. 1 Seeds Margin of Victory Mean Anything for Its N.C.A.A. Title Hopes?
description: Southern almost pulled off the one upset that hasnt happened at the N.C.A.A. tournament. And although No. 1-seeded Gonzaga escaped the first loss to a No. 16 when it pulled away from the Jaguars at the end of its 64-58 win on Thursday, it is easy to question whether its close call could have implications in the long term.

title: Cruz, Patriots and Seahawks: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: Digitally Aided Education, Using the Students Own Electronic Gear
description: Educators and policy makers continue to debate whether computers are a good teaching tool. But a growing number of schools are adopting a new, even more controversial approach: asking students to bring their own smartphones, tablets, laptops and even their video game players to class.

title: Is Your Kitchen a Health Hazard?
description: OUR kitchens may be killing us  slowly. Not so much with radon or gas leaks, but with kindness and proximity.

title: The Financial Effects of a Court Ruling Recognizing Gay Marriage
description: This weeks Your Money column tries to envision how life may change for same-sex couples if the federal law that bans gay marriage is struck down.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 22
description: Subjects include a St. Patricks Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.

title: PPR to Show Breton Roots With Rebranding as Kering
description: PARIS  PPR is on the way out. The Paris luxury group, whose stable of brands includes Gucci, Balenciaga and Puma, said on Friday that it was changing its name to Kering.

title: Rebel Leader in Congo Is Flown to The Hague
description: NAIVASHA, Kenya  Bosco Ntaganda, a rebel commander accused of massacring civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was flown out of Rwanda on Friday bound for the International Criminal Court at The Hague, where he faces 10 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

title: Paris Auction Goes Forward Despite Heritage Claims
description: Sothebys in Paris went forward today with a two-day sale of pre-Columbian artifacts despite claims by four Latin American nations that many of the 313 items had been illegally exported.

title: Upscale, Downsized
description: With prices of roughly $30,000 to $50,000, a smaller class of luxury cars offers a less-is-more display of status.

title: Taking It to the Limit
description: The new documentary Peoples Park surveys the range of human activity in a bustling urban park in Chengdu, China. People stroll, snack, socialize, practice calligraphy and engage in a wide variety of song and dance, from Chinese opera to pulsing disco. Some ignore the camera; others play to it. The filmmakers, Libbie Dina Cohn and J. P. Sniadecki, are never seen, but their presence is felt, not least because of how they chose to portray the parks myriad denizens and activities: as a literal panorama of leisure and revelry, filmed in one long tracking shot.

title: Nets Clinch, and Owner Wants You to Know
description: Upon seeing his team clinch its first playoff berth in six years, Mikhail D. Prokhorov celebrated with the verbal equivalent of a Champagne shower.

title: Inside The Place Beyond the Pines
description: In this Anatomy of a Scene, the director Derek Cianfrance narrates his films opening sequence.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Brian K. Vaughan Talks About The Private Eye
description: New at No. 3 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is Season One: Avengers, a look back at the earliest days of Marvels premiere superhero team. The Season One books are conceived as a way of introducing new readers to Marvels biggest heroes without being weighed down by the decades of sometimes-convoluted history can sometimes be amassed.

title: Myth Making on Motorcycles
description: I never felt more like Janet Leigh in my life, Ryan Gosling said with his best straight face.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures for March 22
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including the return of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey to Brooklyn.

title: A Mary Tyler Moore Show Reunion, Via Cleveland
description: The cable channel TV Land lives on nostalgia for classic television and that will certainly reach a peak this summer in an episode of the sitcom, Hot in Cleveland. The show will reunite all of the major female stars from one of televisions most beloved comedies, The Mary Tyler Moore Show.

title: Waiting for War, and Working to Fit In
description: And here we had all been getting on so well.

title: When What Do You Do? Is Taboo
description: TALKING TO UNEMPLOYED friends and colleagues requires a certain delicacy. The question How was your day?, when leveled with what is perceived as an undue amount of concern, can cause steam to emerge from ears. Robert Reich, the secretary of labor under President Clinton, said, I dont ask What are you doing with yourself these days? or Hows the job search coming? unless its a good friend. I wait for him to bring it up. Being jobless is distressing enough without people asking about it.

title: How About a Little Luxury?
description: From tailfinned Cadillacs of the 1950s to three-ton S.U.V.s at the turn of the century, luxury vehicles have always pushed the limits of size and mass.

title: Buick Stakes a Claim in Munchkinland
description: WARREN, N.H.  Buicks image is so ingrained in the national consciousness that the name has become shorthand for an American road barge with ample proportions. That moose, someone may say, is as big as a Buick.

title: From the Andrews Sisters to Hip-Hop
description: AT 23 WILLY MOON is a throwback artist in the most contemporary mode, with an ear for melding early rock sounds with synthy production and hip-hop beats. Signed to a major label before he ever played a gig, Mr. Moon was noticed by Jack White, who released his single Railroad Track and took him on tour in England last year. His debut album, Heres Willy Moon, 12 propulsive songs that total less than 29 minutes, will be out April 2 on Cherrytree/Island; thanks to its use in an iPod commercial his single Yeah Yeah, which borrowed a Wu-Tang Clan sample, has already made the charts.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: The Tonight Show is expected to move back to New York City, and surging demand for homes has left some areas of the country with a shortage of inventory.

title: Short Season for a Rare Fish
description: Fishermen in Cagnes-Sur-Mer, in southeastern France, collect young fish in their nets on Thursday during the short poutine fishing season. Poutine, a type of baby sardines, are found between Antibes and Menton on the French Riviera for only about 45 days each year at the end of winter. Their price at market reflects their rarity: They will fetch about 30 euros, or $40, per kilogram.

title: JPMorgan Board Confirms Dual Role for Dimon
description: JPMorgan Chases board said on Friday that it was standing behind Jamie Dimon, the banks chairman and chief executive, in the face of calls from some investors that the two jobs be split.

title: A Voice That Leaps Between Genres
description: KINGSTON, N.Y.  Rebecca Martin and Larry Grenadier live in a house on a hill in this weathered Hudson Valley city, some 90 miles upriver from Manhattan. At a glance, their sturdy Victorian doesnt seem like the obvious hub of a small-batch initiative to redraw contemporary jazz singing. During one recent visit, there was snow on the ground and soup on the stove, and their 7-year-old son, Charlie, was home from school.

title: Shuffleboard? Oh, Maybe Lets Get High Instead
description: For Cher Neufer, a 65-year-old retired teacher, socializing with friends (all in their 60s) means using marijuana. Once a week they get together to play Texas Hold Em poker and pass around a doobie, Ms. Neufer said.

title: This Weeks Movies | March 22, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on "Admission," "Olympus Has Fallen" and "Gimme the Loot."

title: The Extreme (Existential) Makeover
description: AMONG the many unexpected downsides of increased longevity (running through ones retirement money; more years in an assisted-living facility; entertaining the possibility that we ourselves may suffer the consequences of global warming, even though we thought we were just passing the problem on to our children), one can now include the prospect of more time to sit on a park bench brooding about how we could have done it differently  been better than ourselves.

title: The Vehicular Side of the Vatican
description: As the newly installed pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis will often be seen greeting the world from the back of a rather peculiar vehicle. Its taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one weve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.

title: At 102, Margaret Dunning Looks Ahead to Next Concours
description: At 102, Margaret Dunning could be living a genteel, quiet life. Instead, Ms. Dunning, who owns a 1930 Packard 740, has become a doyenne of the show-car circuit and is often away from home.

title: Vatican City 1
description: Its taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one weve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 22
description: More photographs.

title: The Best Thing I Learned At SXSW Was From the Unabomber
description: Now that Im back and mostly recovered from South by Southwest, my friends, editors and fellow reporters keep asking me about the most interesting thing I saw in Austin.

title: Kyle Dake Is Going for Four
description: The Cornell senior Kyle Dake is looking to make wrestling history this weekend. If he wins the 165-pound weight class at the N.C.A.A tournament in Des Moines, Iowa, he will be the only collegiate wrestler to have won four titles in four different weight classes.

title: Big Ticket | Baronial Show House Sold for $22.85 Million
description: A magisterial limestone town house on one of the Upper East Sides most moneyed blocks sold for $22.85 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Finding Their Next Facebook
description: As you sit across from Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, it is easy to lose track of whom exactly youre talking to. Tall, blue-eyed and each built as broad-shouldered as a fridge, the twins are identical right down to their entrees: a pair of lobster rolls, with potato chips. Each has an espresso; neither eats the biscotti it comes with. And while the restaurant around them is spinning with chatter on this February night, the twins are each laser focused on getting their message across.

title: Obama Withdraws Judicial Nomination After Second G.O.P. Filibuster
description: President Obama has withdrawn the nomination of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to serve on an important federal appeals court in Washington, blaming Republicans for blocking her confirmation twice.

title: Scheduling Conflict Forces Ravens to Open on Road
description: The Baltimore Ravens, the defending Super Bowl champions, will open the season on the road because the N.F.L. and Major League Baseball could not work out a scheduling conflict with the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Heartbreaking News, Heavenly Exhortations and Lonely Sentiments
description: Chvrches

title: A Sitcom That Some Find, Well, Alien
description: In her 30-year acting career Jami Gertz has never heard a negative peep from her parents about her projects. It could go straight to video, she said, and my father will be like, You were the best thing in it.

title: Movie Review | 'Admission'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Admission."

title: A Familys Secrets Bared, on Camera
description: It took a powerful, disturbing dream from which she awoke sobbing to convince Robin Charboneau, an Oglala Sioux and member of North Dakotas Spirit Lake tribe, that I needed to open my mouth, and I needed to speak. So she let the documentary filmmaker David Sutherland follow her for more than three years as she struggled to raise her family as a single mother while confronting her alcoholism and the scars of being sexually abused as a child.

title: Another Look at Natural Gas
description: After my column on Wednesday about how the nations natural gas boom is helping reduce emissions of heat-trapping carbon, I received a bunch of e-mail arguing that gas obtained by hydraulic fracturing could, on the contrary, worsen climate change.

title: Visors Should Be Mandatory, Says Player Who Lost an Eye
description: For a true advocate for mandatory visor use in the N.H.L., talk to a hockey player who lost an eye playing the game.

title: Movie Review | 'Olympus Has Fallen'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Olympus Has Fallen.

title: BlackBerry Z10 Goes on Sale in U.S.
description: An after-midnight sale at a 24-hour Best Buy store in New Yorks Union Square was the site of the American debut of the BlackBerry Z10 smartphone on Friday.

title: Big as a Buick? Not This One
description: The Encore is a bold move from a brand once known for cautious conservatism.

title: Suddenly, Theyre All Gone
description: Caring for the old is just like parenting an infant, only on really bad acid. Its all there: the head-spinning exhaustion, the fractured brain, the demands and smells. Only this time with the knowledge that it wont get better.

title: Dressing Up for a Special Occasion
description: THESE DAYS WE ARE constantly surrounded by sweet baked goods, but once upon a time they were really considered quite special. Daily bread was usually brown and meant for sustenance; only for holidays, Easter in particular, was it rich and extravagant, made with fancy white flour, milk, butter and eggs, and studded with candied fruit.

title: At The New Republic, Even Firings Enter the Digital Age
description: Just one year after the Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes bought The New Republic, the magazine confirmed it had fired one of its top editors.

title: Gay Conversion Therapy
description: New Jerseys Governor Chris Christie is apparently agonizing over whether he should sign a bill that would outlaw so-called reparative therapy.

title: A Forgers Impressions of Impressionism
description: On a sunny weekday morning in a cafe in Brooklyn the French director Gilles Bourdos is flipping through his laptops gallery of international art. Theres a charcoal study of Czanne card players; Picassos inkblot Don Quixote, tilting his lance at the Spanish sun; and a blue-hued, Old World fantasy, bearing the kaleidoscopic hallmarks of Marc Chagall.

title: A Secret-Agent Premiere for a New Range Rover
description: A conventional news conference would hardly suffice for the debut of the 2014 Range Rover Sport, Land Rover executives thought, so on March 26, the night before the New York auto show opens for two days of press previews, the new S.U.V. is to be revealed in a Hollywood-caliber video.

title: Plug and Play for Internet Connections
description: Far too often, drivers of older vehicles try to add the services available in new Internet-connected cars by balancing smartphones in their laps. But smartphones  aside from the obvious distraction they present  cannot do things like monitor the cars location when someone else is using it or send a maintenance reminder based on miles traveled.

title: Arab Student Explains Why He Heckled Obama in Jerusalem
description: The 24-year-old student from Israels Arab minority who interrupted President Obamas speech in Jerusalem on Thursday explained his comments and why he made them in an interview with The Lede on Friday.

title: Little Support for Idea of Medicare Payments That Vary
description: Medicare should not adjust payments on a broad regional basis to reward hospitals and doctors that spend less to achieve high-quality care, an interim report issued Friday by the Institute of Medicine concluded.

title: Cuban Dissident Calls to End Embargo
description: Blogger and activist Yoani Snchez regularly condemns the Cuban regime from her home in Havana. On her first trip abroad in nearly a decade, she also called for an end to the American embargo.

title: Cultural Capital
description: This issue starts off in America, or at least an idea of America. Brooklyn, N.Y., has, as we all know, become a bastion of handcrafted, locally sourced, small-scale-production everything, from bikes to beer. The irony is that this passion for authenticity, diversity and a longing for realness have now turned what was once just a borough into a global brand, one that is vigorously being exported around the world: France, Russia, the United Arab Emirates. The local has gone global, or in other words, anti-homogenization is itself now being homogenized: In Paris you find food trucks, in Gorky Park a snack kiosk called Williamsburg, there is a Brooklyn Diner in Dubai, and even the native beer, Brooklyn Brewery, is planning an outpost in Stockholm  how local is that? When a value system based on unscalability starts to scale, it may be time to turn to other locales for a sense of uniqueness and locally grown culture.

title: Ribaldry Before the Code
description: BERT WHEELER and Robert Woolsey made 21 feature films together (and a couple separately) between 1929 and 1937. They were one of the most popular comedy teams of a decade that knew several great ones, and yet today they are almost unknown, except to cinephiles who make a habit of exploring the uncharted overnight territory of the Turner Classic Movies channel.

title: Bausch & Lomb Plans I.P.O.
description: Bausch & Lomb, the eye-care company primarily owned by Warburg Pincus, filed documents on Friday to go public again.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Israel, Myanmar and Cyprus.

title: This Weeks Movies: March 22
description: In this weeks video, Times critics offer their thoughts on Admission, Olympus Has Fallen and Gimme the Loot. See all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Nigerians React to News of Achebes Death
description: LAGOS, Nigeria The news of the death of Chinua Achebe, the influential Nigerian author renowned for his novel Things Fall Apart, reverberated across the countrys cultural and political circles on Friday. I must say its a most painful death for me, said Odia Ofeimun, a poet and the former president of Association of Nigerian Authors. Just when we were learning to argue with him, he died.

title: Ch-Ch-Ch Changes of David Bowie
description: LONDON  A photograph hangs inconspicuously near the entrance of David Bowie Is, a Victoria and Albert Museum exhibition opening on Saturday that has already sold a record number of tickets. It shows the young man who began life as David Jones, seated, in a dark suit and tie, with a leg propped up on his chair, beneath which sits a drum bearing the name of his band, the Kon-rads. One hand grips a saxophone, the other rests delicately against his face, and he looks out at the world with a mesmerizing blend of reserve and come-hither allure.

title: Israeli Students Reflect on Obamas Speech
description: President Obama gave a fervent address to students from universities in Israel on Thursday during his first presidential trip to the country. Some of the students shared their views of the speech with The Times.

title: Yoko Ono Details Why She Posted Lennons Bloodied Glasses on Twitter
description: On what would have been her 44th wedding anniversary Wednesday, Yoko Ono said, she walked through a park, remembering how much she and her husband, John Lennon, had laughed and smiled on their wedding day. Then I felt the emptiness more acutely because of the beautiful memory, she said.

title: Bowie on Display
description: A look back at a David Bowie career retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London in 2013.

title: The Hall, a Player as Important as the Strings
description: The Bach Variations festival, which the New York Philharmonic is presenting through April 6, is built on a question: Should large symphony orchestras still play Bach, now that there are so many ensembles specializing in the historically informed performance of Baroque music? With four conductors from different backgrounds  Alan Gilbert, Andras Schiff, Masaaki Suzuki and Bernard Labadie  the Philharmonic also looks at the question of how. What they failed to address is the where.

title: Obama in the Mideast: Sampling the Reviews
description: To the Editor:

title: Comeuppance of a Reprobate, With Hints of Glucks Glory to Come
description: Among the 50-odd operas written by Gluck, to say nothing of myriad variants and other hybrid entertainments, only a handful tend to show up on the modern stage. Almost invariably these are the so-called reform works of Glucks later years, like Orfeo ed Euridice, Alceste and the two Iphignie operas, all composed between 1762 and 1779.

title: Low-Income Students and Elite Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Fastidious Percussion With Plenty of Electronics
description: Five pedestals stood in the atrium of the Guggenheim Museum on Thursday night: perforated, metallic-looking bases, lighted from within, supporting oval platforms, each large enough to hold one musician surrounded by equipment. It was the architect Uffe Surland Van Tamss setup for Tyondai Braxtons Hive, billed as part installation/part band by the Guggenheims Works & Process series and Wordless Music, which presented it.

title: Coyote Hunting in Utah
description: A $50 bounty to control the coyote population in Utah has hunters excited, environmentalists crying foul and state wildlife administrators stuck somewhere in the middle.

title: Amid Kill Chants, Croatia and Serbia Set Peaceful Example
description: ZAGREB, Croatia  For all the talk of conciliation, for all the pleas for tolerance before the game and for all the statements from players and coaches that the war should take a back seat to the soccer, the crowd at the Maksimir Stadium in Zagreb found it harder to forget and forgive on Friday.

title: Interview With Cuban Blogger Yoani Snchez
description: Last Updated, Saturday, 9:10 p.m. Yoani Snchez stepped out of a coffee shop in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York and quickly pulled a winter hat over her head, covering about three inches of her waist-length brown hair. This is my disguise, she said, Its not working.

title: A Plan to Demolish Libraries to Save Them
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sameness of Their Differences
description: In the darkness the sound might be crying or laughter. Brightening lights reveal a woman sitting in a pile of feathers. She laughs hysterically. She hyperventilates. One fit subsides, only to be followed by another. Pain seems to rack her body, as if she were giving birth. She screams.

title: The Sly Coyote Becomes a Bounty Hunters Target in Utah
description: OGDEN, Utah  Spencer Glauser, who started hunting as a boy perched on his fathers shoulders, is an unabashed coyote hater. Ones too many to have roaming the mountains and encroaching on towns, he said.

title: No Disciplinary Hearing for Nash; Rangers Waive Halpern
description: Rick Nash, the Rangers top scorer, will not face suspension for the leaping elbow he delivered to the back of Tomas Kopeckys head in a 3-1 loss to the Florida Panthers on Thursday night.

title: Movie Review | 'Gimme The Loot'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Gimme The Loot."

title: T Spring Travel 2013
description: America and Beyond is the theme of the spring travel issue of T. Start off locally with Modernism Is the Message, a look at fashions new minimalism, as seen through the eyes of the photographer Mario Sorrenti. Then read Simon Romeros piece on how So Paulo, Brazils largest city, is being redefined. Theres also a report on Seoul, the South Korean capital that is becoming the fashionable intrigue of the Far East, and an essay on the exportation of Brooklyn, which has transformed the borough from landmass into global phenomenon. As you hopscotch around the globe, dont forget to read Alexandra Marshalls dispatch on the young chefs revolutionizing Paris, Christian Louboutins travel diary of his visit to the Marrakesh film festival or Matches as Memories, which rounds up the perfect hotel souvenirs that may also be the most anachronistic: matchbooks.See more from the issue >>

title: Creating Cosmos
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking It Down: Nieminen vs. Nalbandian
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.The match was over.

title: Tower at OHare May Be a Victim of Federal Cuts
description: CHICAGO  Up 14 stories by elevator and two more by stairs, Adonna Prior, an air traffic controller, watched for airplanes emerging as specks in the sky from her perch at the top of OHare International Airports sleek $40 million north tower.

title: Theres a Word for a Movie Like This
description: Sometimes a movie is so awful that the word awful is not up to the task of conveying its awfulness. The awful InAPPropriate Comedy is such a movie. It is memorably awful. It is stunningly awful. It is so awful that we are fortunate that awful has an adverbial use that means very or extremely. This movie is awfully awful.

title: Cholera in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Goes Well With Swagger
description: DURING THIS BRIEF LULL between New Yorks two dueling monster art fairs, the recent Armory Show and the forthcoming Frieze, one wonders about the accuracy of the genteel, old-fashioned term, the art world.

title: Major League Baseball v. Biogenesis of America
description: Major League Baseball ton Friday of filed a lawsuit in Florida state court that accuses six people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic of damaging the sport when they provided various players with performance-enhancing substances.

title: Obsessed? Youre Not Alone
description: Sharing an Amtrak car recently with four chatty debutantes on their way to a cotillion in Boston, powerless not to eavesdrop, I started cataloging all the vernacular expressions they emphatically overused, transcribing the choicest dialogue to Facebook. (Theyre just jealous of her. Theyre jealous. Because shes pretty. And has a nice personality. Shes pretty. So jealous.) But the short phrase that so got my attention was Im obsessed.

title: Week in Pictures for March 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a St. Patricks Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.

title: A Weekend in the Country: Britains Power Elite at Play
description: Chipping Norton, England  The power centers of British politics and media may reside in London, but their tentacles extend to a tiny working-class market town with rows of glistening stone buildings, 17th-century pubs and a medieval church.

title: Wealthy Russians Ensnared as Cyprus Crisis Deepens
description: MOSCOW  Two decades ago, Dmitry E. Rybolovlev was a small-town hustler hoping to strike it rich amid the collapse of the Soviet Union. Today, he is one of the wealthiest men in the world, with a penthouse in Monaco, a yacht named My Anna worth more than $100 million, and two of the most expensive private residences in the United States.

title: Words and War: Toni Morrison at West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  As thousands of hungry West Point cadets streamed into the mess hall for their 20-minute lunch break here on Friday, they paused from the rush to the tables to give a rousing group cheer to a guest who has received hundreds of accolades, but perhaps none this thunderous.

title: Some Sour Music for Horwitz
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jay Horwitz, the Mets public relations director got into some hot water with fans this week because of something he posted on his new Twitter account.

title: Sheepsquatch, Pulling the Wool Over Your Eyes
description: Televisions baser purveyors cant get enough of the endlessly futile search for bigfoots, extraterrestrials and ghosts, but credit the newest show in the genre, Monsters and Mysteries in America, with at least recognizing that those Big Three have received a disproportionate amount of attention. It seems to realize that we havent heard nearly enough about the sheepsquatch infestation.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Netflix TV, and Bitcoins for Drugs
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Doctors and a Prescription for Trouble
description: Will the last woman in Atlanta who is not being followed by a camera crew please raise her hand?

title: Relics of the Bygone (and the Illegal)
description: Someone knocked on the door of the basement apartment on East 115th Street on March 13. A man let him in. A detective watched, and arrested the man who had opened the door.

title: After Withdrawing, Harvard Star Roots From Afar
description: Plenty of college basketball fans across the country were rooting for Harvard on Thursday night when it upset third-seeded New Mexico, 68-62, in the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 64. There was no bigger supporter than Brandyn Curry, who was watching the game with his family in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Quarterfinals
description: ST. LOUIS  The Rockwell Mixed Pairs here on Wednesday evening were won by a married couple, Paul and Linda Lewis of Las Vegas. They finished one-third of a board ahead of Barbara Lehman of Glenview, Ill., and Craig Jacobson of Skokie, Ill. Third were Jenni Carmichael of Kennesaw, Ga., and Greg Humphreys of Charlottesville, Va.

title: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops
description: I was going to post something substantive, but first I had tech problems (an hour on the phone with NY Times support), then internet access problems, so enough for today. Heres some cheerful stuff from a group people have been telling me to give a listen.

title: Where Citizenship Went to Die
description: Harare, Zimbabwe

title: Orders Cut, as Publisher and Retailer Quarrel
