description: A standoff over financial terms has prompted the bookstore chain Barnes & Noble to cut back substantially on the number of titles it orders from the publishing house Simon & Schuster, raising fears among other publishers, agents and authors that the conflict may harm the publishing industry as a whole.

title: Pennsylvania: Environment Secretary Resigns
description: Michael Krancer, the state environment secretary, will step down next month to return to private law practice, Gov. Tom Corbett said Friday. Since taking office in January 2011, Mr. Krancer, 55, has been accused by environmentalists of lax regulation of Pennsylvanias booming oil and gas industry, and of reporting incomplete results of water tests from private wells near gas sites. Mr. Corbett, a Republican, praised Mr. Krancers efforts to stop gas companies from sending wastewater to treatment plants that were not equipped to process it, as well as his role in keeping open three refineries that were in danger of being closed.

title: Ex-President of Pakistan to End Exile in Bid to Regain Influence
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani military lore is obsessed with the romance of the daredevil commando, parachuting into hostile territory and taking the fight to the enemy despite daunting odds.

title: Pope Cancels Newspaper Delivery Back Home in Argentina
description: Pope Francis, apparently working down his to-do list since taking his new position, made a call to his local newspaper kiosk in Buenos Aires this week to cancel his daily delivery and send his greetings, according to a report from the Catholic News Agency.

title: Bill Cunningham | Wild Ones
description: At the Paris fashion shows earlier this month, the bikers jacket was prominent on many in the audience.

title: Boeheim Still Defiant, Whether or Not End Is Near
description: San Jose, Calif.

title: Italys President Asks Center-Left Party to Form Government
description: ROME  A month after national elections failed to yield a clear result, President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy on Friday asked the leader of the Democratic Party to try to form a government, but only if he meets the challenge of mustering a strong enough majority to govern.

title: Girls Excel in the Classroom but Lag in Entry to 8 Elite Schools in the City
description: In the United States, girls have outshined boys in high school for years, amassing more As, earning more diplomas and gliding more readily into college, where they rack up more degrees  whether at the bachelors, masters or doctoral levels.

title: Waking Up to the Enduring Memory of Rape
description: Memphis

title: A Look at Pablo Bergers Blancanieves
description: The black-and-white silent film Blancanieves sets the story of Snow White amid a bullfighting milieu in Seville, Spain, in the 1920s.

title: For Musicians, the Most Prized Violins Are for Borrowing, Not Buying
description: The din inside the Metropolitan Pavilion in Chelsea recently was that of any crowded trade fair, except for the snippets of music that wove in and out of the roar of voices.

title: Tonight Show to New York? Local Comics Applaud
description: Even though the influence, buzz and relevance of network talk shows has waned, make no mistake, The Tonight Show still matters, particularly to comedy.

title: The Bullpen Bloomberg Built: Candidates Debate Its Future
description: It is the ultimate symbol of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs management style, borrowed from Wall Street, plunked incongruously into the middle of City Hall and studied by everyone from M.B.A. students to visiting heads of state.

title: Bud Palmer, Jump Shot Pioneer, Dies at 91
description: Bud Palmer gained fame as a sports telecaster, covering everything from the Olympics to dog shows. He was Mayor John V. Lindsays official greeter, welcoming dignitaries to the city. He was the first writer of Glamour magazines Ask Jake column, offering women advice from a mans viewpoint. (Dont show up drunk for a dinner date.) And he was the first captain of the New York Knicks.

title: The Rat Pack, Fondly Recalled
description: She was a just toddler when her father, Pat Boone, was a Las Vegas headliner who hobnobbed with the Rat Pack. But the singer Debby Boone had her eyes and ears wide open, and she remembers things like the look of Sammy Davis Jr.s house and Dean Martins jokes about her fathers teetotaling. And on Tuesday evening at Caf Carlyle Ms. Boone, glamorized to the max, was the very picture of a tastefully attired Las Vegas babe as she devoted an entire program to songs of the Rat Pack era in a show titled Swing This. The swing was provided by an excellent nine-member band under the direction of John Oddo, the longtime musical director of Ms. Boones mother-in-law, Rosemary Clooney.

title: Tight Deadlines and Lagging Funds Bedevil Obama Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  It was another turbulent week for President Obamas health care law. Congress rejected a White House request for nearly $1 billion to carry out the law, even as federal responsibilities increased to include the supervision of insurance markets in more than half the states. Then, on Friday, Republican attacks on the law continued in the Senate, where Democrats beat back Republican proposals to repeal the law and many of its tax increases.

title: Artistic Touches in Mexican Food
description: The last great Mexican meal I ate was in 2004, at La Super-Rica Taqueria in Santa Barbara, Calif., whose most famous patron was Julia Child. The lines were endless.

title: Police Storm Squatters at Rio Stadium Site
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Brazilian police on Friday stormed the work site of Maracan, the venerable soccer stadium under renovation ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics, in an attempt to end a standoff with more than 20 indigenous protesters who had squatted for years in an adjacent building that once housed Brazils first Indian Museum.

title: Opening With a Clang, a Rebel Recovers
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The 3-point attempt clanged high off the rim, again, and the standout Mississippi shooting guard Marshall Henderson ran downcourt shaking his head. Great, he thought. Im finally playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and now I stink.

title: Egypt: Dozens Injured in Protests
description: Dozens of people were injured Friday when thousands of supporters and opponents of the ruling Muslim Brotherhood clashed outside the groups Cairo headquarters, many of them armed with weapons like meat cleavers, cattle prods and pistols. The police fired tear gas as protesters tried to approach the headquarters. Anti-Brotherhood protesters also attacked the offices of the Freedom and Justice Party, the Brotherhoods political wing, in Alexandria and Mahalla, according to local reports. The confrontations in Cairo were among the most violent between Brotherhood supporters and opponents since deadly clashes outside the presidential palace in December. For months, opposition groups and protesters have called on President Mohamed Morsi, above, a former Brotherhood leader, to make political concessions, including replacing his cabinet with a national unity government. Mr. Morsi has resisted those calls, deepening Egypts political stalemate.

title: Bearing Witness, With Words
description: If you dont like someones story, Chinua Achebe told The Paris Review in 1994, write your own.

title: Sectarian Violence Spreads in Myanmar
description: Clashes between Buddhists and Muslims spread to villages outside a city in central Myanmar on Friday.

title: Williamss Star Shined in Knicks Guard Tandem
description: Ray Williams and Micheal Ray Richardson parted ways years ago, not by choice, and in Richardsons mind, much too soon.

title: Left Behind: Johan Santana
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla  Johan Santana will continue conditioning his arm at the Mets spring training facility here when the rest of his teammates depart for New York at the end of the month, Manager Terry Collins said Friday.

title: At Virginia Commonwealth, a Defense That Is Called Havoc
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  To end practice Wednesday, Shaka Smart stood at midcourt and had his Virginia Commonwealth team  players, assistant coaches, trainers, everyone else  line up in the paint.

title: Man Killed in Brooklyn Shooting; Three Are Wounded
description: Four people were shot  one fatally  in an apartment at a Coney Island housing project on Friday afternoon, the police said.

title: Eager Rebounder From Iran Powers Oregon With Double-Doubles
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Arsalan Kazemis father owns a candy factory, churning out gaz, a nougat-and-pistachio concoction that visitors to Esfahan, Iran, buy as a souvenir. When Kazemi comes home in the summer, for just a week or so, his father gives him some to bring back to the United States.

title: World Cup Qualifying: U.S. vs. Costa Rica
description: It was wild, and it was wintry, but it was a win. The United States national team righted its teetering World Cup qualifying campaign with a 1-0 win over Costa Rica on Friday night in Commerce City, Colo., in a game that nearly descended into farce as inch after inch of snow piled up.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Is Leaving Without Car, Job or Regrets
description: LOS ANGELES  Antonio R. Villaraigosa has been a mayor whom this city loves to love and loves to hate. The red carpets. The late-night parties. The lofty promises, many met and some not. The disintegration of a marriage and a relationship with a television reporter while in office, all covered with the flashbulb ferocity befitting a Hollywood personality.

title: Lebanese Premier Resigns as Syrian War Fuels Sectarian Split
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanons prime minister resigned on Friday and called for a national unity government to rescue the country from deepening sectarian divisions over the war in neighboring Syria, which threatens to spill over the border. Lebanons most powerful political factions back opposite sides in the Syrian conflict.

title: A Menu in Harmony With the Cocktails
description: Since it opened in 2007, 116 Crown, a hip, urban place in Ninth Square in New Haven, has been known for its striking onyx bar and inventive cocktails. Now, with the help of a new chef, it is quietly reinventing itself as a first-class restaurant. John Ginnetti, who owns 116 Crown with his wife, Danielle, said he knew it would be a challenge: When you walk in, theres this giant glowing bar. We knew that would work against us as a dinner place.

title: Prestigious High Schools, Testing and Gender
description: New York City high schools that rely entirely on the eighth-grade Specialized High School Admissions Test tend to have fewer female students.

title: A Rare Dive Into His Own Songbook
description: The pianist George Cables ended his first set at the Iridium on Wednesday night with My Muse, a compact tune with the kind of crisp, sunny melody that might have made it a staple in the age of jukeboxes and roller rinks. Over a percolating rock beat, he played the theme jauntily, saving all his flash for a cascading solo that started fast and never flagged. If the song carried a burden of sentiment, he wasnt about to let it show.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 22, 2013

title: Senate Democrats Offer a Budget, Then the Amendments Fly
description: An updated version of this article can be found here.

title: Darlings of Yore Hear the Cheers, but Not for Them
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The N.C.A.A. tournament unfolded here as if in some sort of parallel universe: the conversation dominated by Gonzaga, the spotlight stolen by Harvard.

title: Beyond the Cheese, a Quirky World of Flavors
description: Mint Premium Foods began life as a gourmet food shop, and when entering the Tarrytown restaurant one is met by a display case containing huge chunks of delicious cheese, bowls of salty, fragrant olives and shelves of imported sauces, pastas and crackers. If youre lucky, the elegant proprietor, Hassan Jarane, will offer you a slice of Pickwick Cheddar with caramelized onion, a pesto basil Gouda or a subtle truffle cheese from Tuscany.

title: Walking While Black in New York
description: The New York City Police Department has a long history of violating constitutional rights by stopping, questioning or frisking people on the streets without legal justification. The city has steadfastly denied that the detentions  made under its increasingly unpopular stop-and-frisk program  have been based on race.

title: Watchman at the Waters Edge
description: Two bird-watchers moved camera-ready through the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge last week, grateful that the first ospreys had arrived at their familiar nests after flying 2,600 miles from winter roosts in South America. The fish hawks hungrily plied the bays resources as jetliners traversed the horizon across the way at Kennedy Airport. But the birders were more intent on investigating worrisome breaches in the refuges earthen walls caused by Hurricane Sandy. Would that affect the comings and goings this year of the multitudes of aquatic and meadow birds that favor the 13,000-acre preserve?

title: Keep Guns Out of Criminal Hands
description: The Senate, at long last, will take up a package of gun-control measures when it returns from recess next month. On Thursday, the majority leader, Harry Reid, announced that one of those measures will require almost all gun buyers to undergo a background check. This is a vital step that would help keep guns out of the wrong hands, and it deserves far more bipartisan support than it has received.

title: Overdue Reconciliation
description: President Obama concluded a successful visit to Israel on Friday by helping broker an end to the self-defeating standoff between two American allies, Israel and Turkey. The breakthrough is a credit to both prime ministers, Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, but it is also a sign that Mr. Obama, criticized as leading from behind on foreign policy, is prepared to engage more directly in international affairs.

title: A Favorite Is One of the First to Go
description: PHILADELPHIA  The final two and a half minutes were, in Andy Enfields estimation, the longest two and a half minutes of his life. The game could not end soon enough, not with the way Georgetown was making 3-pointers and chipping away at Florida Gulf Coasts lead.

title: Among 200 Wines, Local Reds Shine
description: LONG ISLAND REDS shone when eight of the Islands producers joined 32 vintners from other wine regions on Monday in New York Drinks New York, a public tasting of more than 200 wines.

title: Corrections: March 23, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Spiral-Horned Antelope
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  This one was a brain-breaker for me, but it was ultimately doable.

title: Mary and the Zombies: Consciousness Revisited
description: Thanks to the nearly 800 readers who submitted comments on last weeks column, Mary and the Zombies: Can Science Explain Consciousness? Together they produced over 100,000 words (a good sized book). The column summarized two widely discussed arguments against understanding consciousness as entirely physical: the Mary Argument and the Zombie Argument.

title: North Dakota to Put End to Abortions on the Ballot
description: North Dakota lawmakers passed a resolution on Friday to allow the public to decide whether the State Constitution should assert that life begins at conception, a move that would essentially ban all abortions in the state.

title: Iceland: Prosecutor Issues Charges Over Collapse of 2 Banks in 2008
description: A special prosecutor in Iceland issued indictments this week against the chief executives and 14 other employees of two banks whose spectacular collapse during the financial crisis of 2008 sent the Icelandic economy into a tailspin. In one of the worlds most ambitious prosecutions stemming from the crisis, the 16 people are being charged with manipulating the financial markets and with putting their institutions in jeopardy by flouting internal rules. Among other things, the indictment says they issued loans to friendly companies that in turn used the loans to buy shares in the banks, elevating their stock prices. The people charged could face up to six years in prison if convicted.

title: A Lifelong Colorado State Fan, From Horns to Tail
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  At the Stank family home in Greeley, Colo., there is a picture of a 6-month-old Justin lodged in the mouth of a bulldog.

title: Saving Children From Guns
description: For nearly two months, my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I have been publishing a daily blog in which we aggregate articles about shootings from the previous day. Of all the stories we link to, the ones I find hardest to read are those about young children who accidentally shoot themselves or another child. They just break my heart. Yet Jennifer and I find new examples almost every day.

title: The G.O.P.s Bachmann Problem
description: The current intramural squabbling on the right is just too delicious for words. At least for nice words.

title: Database Is Shut Down by NASA for a Review
description: WASHINGTON  NASA has shut down a large public database and is limiting access to agency facilities by foreign citizens as part of a broader investigation into efforts by China and other countries to get information about important technology.

title: Teeing Off at Edge of the Arctic? A Chinese Plan Baffles Iceland
description: GRIMSSTADIR, Iceland  Struggling to stand upright against a howling wind, Bragi Benediktsson looked out over his familys land  a barren expanse of snow and ice that a Chinese billionaire wants to turn into a golf course  and laughed. Golf here is difficult, said Mr. Benediktsson, a 75-year-old sheep farmer.

title: Looking Beyond a Restaurants Charm
description: A breakfast and lunch spot called Two Blondes and a Stove, which opened in August in Huntington Village, N.Y., changed its name and its ambitions within six months or so of its opening. Now called BlonDees Bistro and Bar, it is also serving dinner.

title: New Jersey Wins Fight Against a Tiny Invader
description: LINDEN, N.J.  The enemy forces were numerous, numbering in the thousands. They were particularly adept at hidden warfare. The fight, which endured for more than a decade, was complicated by the difficulty of detection, with the invader measuring an inch and a half, tops.

title: Kansas Survives Against 16th Seed; La Salle Upsets Kansas State
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The 7-footer Jeff Witheys shot-blocking and inside scoring in the second half Friday enabled Kansas to hold off Western Kentucky, 64-57, and avoid the upset of upsets as the first No. 1 seed to lose to a No. 16 in the mens N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: State Defends Immigrant License Limits
description: PHOENIX  At a hearing on Friday on a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of an order that would keep some young immigrants from getting drivers licenses, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona again found herself trying to prove that her policies are not discriminatory.

title: Man Pleads Guilty in Theft at Masa
description: A former bookkeeper for Masa, one of the most expensive and well-reviewed restaurants in New York, pleaded guilty on Friday to stealing almost $100,000 from the business over the course of a year.

title: Mets Latest Weapon, So They Hope
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The mysterious apparatus sits high above the home plate seats at Tradition Field, the spring training home of the Mets. Dark, glossy and rectangular, it resembles an expensive flat-screen television.

title: Comic Book Fundamentals
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  Back to basics could be the theme of the third installment of Asbury Park Comic Con, to be held at Convention Hall on the Boardwalk here on March 30.

title: Rivals Fault Quinns Block of a Vote on Sick Time
description: Two Democratic candidates for mayor challenged Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on her home turf on Friday, for blocking a vote over paid sick-leave legislation.

title: Horace Mann Reaches Settlement With Former Students
description: The Horace Mann School has reached a settlement worth hundreds of thousands of dollars with most of the former students who have said they were sexually abused by staff members there, a person familiar with negotiations said Friday.

title: To Wealthy Plain Jane With Poor Boyfriend: Be Careful
description: THE APARTMENT, WITH its marble floors, gratuitously high ceilings and unaffordable modern art, is what you would expect as the Manhattan home of a wealthy author and television financial expert. The experts daughter is less glamorous. But that seemingly plain, dull and easily pushed-around daughter finally lashes out.

title: With New Pope, Spotlight Returns to a Mild but Rebellious Priest
description: VIENNA

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Anthonys 37 Points Help Knicks Secure a Playoff Berth
description: TORONTO  It was little more than a week ago that a doctor stuck a needle in the back of Carmelo Anthonys stiff right knee and drained the fluid that had dampened his game. It was only days ago that Anthony returned, gingerly, to the Knicks lineup, his knee still a source of curiosity and concern.

title: A Broader Field of Abstract Expressionists
description: ART HISTORY HAS OFTEN been accused of being overly concerned with the canon, the significant artists and masterpieces within the field, and that concern becomes even more complicated where living artists and recent history are involved.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Suspect in Knifing
description: Police officers shot and killed a man Friday night who they said had stabbed his roommate in Brooklyn and then threatened the officers with a knife, a spokesman for the New York Police Department said.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: An Artists Eye at Work
description: GREENWICH, CONN.  In the photograph Crystal Fantasy, in the Bruce Museums Avant-Garde Persuasion: The Photographs of Harold Haliday Costain, drinking glasses and decanters of all shapes and sizes rise from a fishbowl filled with water. Shimmering with points of light, they float diagonally against a rippling background as if lured by a mysterious force.

title: Stars of a Violent Rap Video Are Found Guilty of Violent Crimes in Real Life
description: The slick rap video had all the trappings of a hit: guns, gritty urban setting, armed robbery and a flashy getaway car. But, as it turned out, the video found its true potential not on YouTube, but in federal court.

title: First Visor Wearer Remains Advocate
description: For a true advocate of mandatory visor use in the N.H.L., talk to a hockey player who lost an eye playing the game.

title: A Different School Bus
description: Earlier this month, a beat-up school bus from Wassaic, N.Y., rolled into Queens Village, and a team of public school students, parents and members of advocacy groups descended upon it. They covered its sun-washed green paint with sky blue, ripped out its seats and any traces of its former life  which at one point included transporting a 30-piece marching band and dance ensemble to play at demonstrations and other social- justice activities.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. Along Madison and Fifth Avenues at 44th and 45th Streets, the lampposts have basketlike structures encircling the posts above head height, with some kind of soft-looking material inside. What are they used for? Nests?

title: This Mayors Decree: Smile
description: EVERY NEIGHBORHOOD in New York City has its unofficial mayor, and Morningside Heights has Bobby Fibel.

title: Song of the Sanitation Worker
description: GARBAGE IN, GARBAGE OUT, the saying goes. Robin Nagle defies that maxim in Picking Up: On the Streets and Behind the Trucks With the Sanitation Workers of New York City (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, $28), an entertaining tribute to the unheralded municipal employees who remove your trash.

title: Peace Prevails on the Pitch
description: Croatia defeated Serbia to enhance its prospects of qualifying for the World Cup, but Fridays match was about much more than soccer.

title: In Search of the Perfect Espresso Bean
description: Curt Ellis, 33, is executive director and a founder of FoodCorps, a nonprofit organization started in 2010 to improve schoolchildrens diets by placing volunteers in their communities for a year of service. He also was a maker of the documentary King Corn, which won a Peabody Award. Mr. Ellis lives with his wife, Caitlin Boyle, 31, the founder and president of film.sprout, a distributor of documentaries; and their 8-week-old son, Oliver, in a 390-square-foot fifth-floor walk-up in the East Village. Mr. Ellis, an Oregon native, likes to run on Sundays, visit a farmers market and cook.

title: Building High Anxiety
Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 23, 2013
description: Nobody knows what the devil they are up to.

title: Local Stop: Elmhurst, Queens
description: The rows of identical single-family homes belie the broader cultural and architectural mix of the neighborhood.

title: Gauchos, Kung Fu and a Paraboloid
description: A bright yellow banner advertising a Kung Fu Training School hangs in front of Elmhursts oldest church, a simple clapboard structure built in 1734, when the Queens neighborhood was still the independent town of Newtown. Despite rows of seemingly uniform single-family houses, signs of the areas diversity are everywhere, particularly in the streets crowded with Asian and Latin American shops.

title: Creighton Aces the Drill, Defeating Cincinnati
description: PHILADELPHIA  Coach Greg McDermott has punctuated nearly every one of his teams practices this season with a free-throw drill. His players must make 10 in row, sometimes more, before they can head home. If it looks as if he might have to turn out the lights on them, he puts a couple of minutes on the clock. Once time runs out, the loners who are left behind line up and run.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Costa Rica (0)
description: No frills. Lots of snow. Three points. Is there anything else we need to know?

title: Wintry Weather and U.S. Team Throw Blanket Over Costa Rica
description: COMMERCE CITY, Colo.  The temperatures were freezing. The winds were battering. The snow was coming down sideways.

title: The Mayors Geek Squad
description: It was a case for a digital Sherlock Holmes. Last fall, the citys Department of Environmental Protection wanted, finally, to crack down on restaurants that were illegally dumping cooking oil into sewers in their neighborhoods  congealed yellow grease is responsible, the department says, for more than half of New Yorks clogged drains. The question, of course, was how to find the culprits?

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) SPARKLE (2012) Whitney Houston, above, who died before this film was released, portrays Emma, a performer turned prim church lady in late-1960s Detroit in this remake of the 1976 movie starring Irene Cara and Lonette McKee, with a score by Curtis Mayfield. The American Idol winner Jordin Sparks plays Sparkle, Emmas youngest daughter, who breaks free from the ranks of the girl group she has formed with her sisters (Carmen Ejogo and Tika Sumpter) and ascends to stardom against her mothers wishes. Houston dominates the new Sparkle and gives its most compelling vocal performance in her rendition of His Eye Is on the Sparrow, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Her vocal stamina was considerably diminished by the time she filmed the movie, but her disciplined, slightly hoarse rendition of that gospel standard gives Sparkle much of its heart. He added: If the new songs on the soundtrack are effective Motown pastiches, most of them pale beside their prototypes. But diluted Motown is better than none.

title: Marriage and the Supremes
description: IM not sure Ive ever seen advocates of gay rights  of equal rights, I should say  as revved up as they are right now, with the Supreme Court poised, on Tuesday and Wednesday, to consider same-sex marriage in two separate cases.

title: IHT Quick Read: March 23
description: NEWS Lawmakers in Cyprus took steps late Friday to revise a formula for obtaining a bailout of the countrys banks but faced strong signals that the plan would not pass muster with international lenders. The Parliament put off until later this weekend a vote on a crucial new proposal that would confiscate 22 to 25 percent of uninsured deposits above 100,000 through a new tax on account holders in one of the nations most troubled banks. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Assailants suspected of being terrorists killed an 18-year-old boy in the Sopore district on Tuesday night, IBNLive reported. Initial investigations have pointed to the involvement of the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba. The attack came on the heels of a suicide attack on a Central Reserve Police Force camp in Bemina last week. The police have arrested four people, including a Lashkar-e-Taiba operative, in connection with that attack, according to NDTV.

title: Senate Passes $3.7 Trillion Budget, Setting Up Contentious Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON  After an all-night debate that ended just before 5 a.m., the Senate on Saturday adopted its first budget in four years, a $3.7 trillion blueprint for 2014 that would provide a fast track for passage of tax increases, trim spending modestly and leave the government still deeply in the red a decade from now.

title: The Weekend Word: The Crucible
description: In Todays Times

title: Kidnapped Australian Is Freed in Southern Philippines
description: MANILA  An emaciated 54-year-old Australian man held for 15 months by a kidnap-for-ransom group in the southern Philippines was released Saturday, officials said.

title: Poverty Blamed for Bulgarias Suicide Wave
description: LONDON  Bulgarias caretaker government will introduce a plan on Monday to try to tackle an epidemic of suicides that is afflicting the impoverished East European nation.

title: The Economics of Evil Google
description: Updated below

title: Psychological Roots of Austerity
description: Simon Wren-Lewis has a thoughtful post on the reasons for austerity mania, in which he accepts the role of special interests but argues that there are also psychological roots. Specifically, he suggests that politicians know that they are often irresponsible, and

title: (Not a) Model-Morphosis
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of real women, with professional makeup by Tina Turnbow. Here, the fashion and beauty blogger Kristin Booker in a look Turnbow created just for her.

title: U.S. Tweets Come In From the Snow
description: Some reactions, via Twitter, from U.S. players after Friday nights 1-0 Snow Bowl victory over Costa Rica in a World Cup qualifying match in Commerce City, Colo.:

title: The Attachment That Still Makes Noise
description: DO you have a stapler?

title: Obama Has Lost Advantage Over G.O.P. on Economy
description: During the debate over the so-called fiscal cliff in December, public opinion surveys showed more Americans trusted President Obama than trusted Republicans in Congress when it came to handling the nations economy. The New Years Day deal to avoid going over the cliff, which included higher marginal tax rates on high earners  something Mr. Obama had campaigned on and lobbied for  was largely seen as a victory for the president.

title: Costa Rica Considering Protest to FIFA
description: Costa Rican soccer officials said they planned to file a protest with FIFA on Saturday after Friday nights 1-0 loss to the United States in a World Cup qualifying match played in a blizzard.

title: Updates and Analysis: N.C.A.A. Tournament, Round of 32, Day 1
description: Top seeded Gonzaga is out of the N.C.A.A. tournament thanks to No. 9 Wichita State and No. 3 Marquette ends the run of No. 6 Butler. Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters detail Saturdays action from the N.C.A.A. Tournament.

title: The Gun Report: March 23, 2013
description: Today, Joe is devoting his column to smart gun technology, which includes biometric gun locks that ensure only a guns owner can fire it. States including New Jersey and California would like to make gun personalization technology, as it is called, required for all legally owned firearms. Many Second Amendment absolutists believe that any refinement to current gun laws is an infringement on their rights. Why should legal gun owners suffer background checks when such a small percentage of people use guns to kill? they ask.

title: Security Cameras on East Coast Capture Meteor
description: Security cameras on the East Coast captured a flash in the sky Friday night that appears to have been a small meteor.

title: Behind Image of Seamless Transition, Vatican Navigates Uncharted Waters
description: VATICAN CITY  Sharing lunch is rarely historic, except perhaps when the two people eating are a pope and his predecessor.

title: A Once-Vibrant City Struggles as Panama Races Ahead on a Wave of Prosperity
description: COLN, Panama  On one end of the Panama Canal, the nations capital gleams with new skyscrapers; a subway, the first in Central America, is under construction; and new malls and restaurants fill with patrons. The city fancies itself a mini-Dubai on the Pacific.

title: Blackstone and Icahn Are Said to Make Preliminary Bids for Dell
description: 9:34 p.m. | Updated

title: France Confirms the Death of a Qaeda Leader in Mali
description: France on Saturday officially confirmed the death of the regional Qaeda leader Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, weeks after he was reported to have been killed in fighting in northern Mali at the end of February.

title: Variety: A Collectible Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Todays quote comes from essayist ANNE FADIMAN, who writes of Vladimir NABOKOVs tendency to hoard rare words that seem otherworldly to us now. And man, this was a hard one! I tend to solve Acrostics by toggling back and forth between guessing the clues and filling in the words as they take shape. But how do you do that when some of the words are IRIDULE or LEMNISCATE? Its like Eugene Maleska came back to life and wrote an acrostic.

title: As His Recovery Lags, Santana Stays Positive
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There appears to remain a long road ahead for the left-hander Johan Santana, who has not pitched in a spring training game and will not join his teammates for the start of the regular season next month.

title: Just Freed, Cleared Man Has a Heart Attack
description: On his second day of freedom after serving 23 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, David Ranta suffered a serious heart attack Friday night, his lawyer said.

title: Chinas Leader Argues for Cooperation With Russia
description: MOSCOW  President Xi Jinping of China made a case on Saturday for closer economic and foreign policy cooperation with Russia, using a speech at a university here to argue that the countries have converging goals, including an expansion of the oil and gas trade, as they pursue dreams of national revival and seek to offset the influence of the developed West.

title: Cyprus Makes Plan to Seize Portion of High-Level Deposits
description: An updated version of this story is here.

title: McIlroy and Wozniacki Striving, With Some Success, for Ordinary
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  The day after Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn posted formal, studio-quality photographs on their Facebook and Twitter accounts to show that they were dating, the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki posted her own sports power-couple shot on Twitter.

title: In Snowstorm, U.S. Finds Remedy for a Cold Spell
description: They continued the soccer match during a snowstorm Friday night near Denver for a very good reason.

title: A Tireless Connoisseur of Texas Barbecue Gets Ready for the Main Course
description: DALLAS  Daniel Vaughn stood at the counter at Lockhart Smokehouse here, ordering dinner. Lockhart serves smoked meat the way butchers serve raw meat  wrapped in a large rectangle of butcher paper  and its customers are encouraged to eat it the way cowboys used to, or maybe Neanderthals, without sauce, forks or even plates.

title: How Much Electricity Comes From Renewable Sources
description: Circles are sized according to the electricity use per capita for a selection of countries.

title: Bands Go Beyond the Music
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  What you do not always see during the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament on television is this: a bass trombone player who hops around on stilts before the game, a band director who rips off his dress shirt and conducts in a tank top, and a tuba player who shimmies out of his pants at halftime, revealing American-flag boxers and tights.

title: Mohsin Hamid
description: Mohsin Hamid, a Pakistani writer, is the author, most recently, of How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia. The film adaptation of his best-selling book, The Reluctant Fundamentalist, will be in theaters April 26.

title: The Ambiguous Island
description: For over 20 years, photographer Alex Webb has been documenting street life in Cuba.

title: For Blacks in Cuba, the Revolution Hasnt Begun
description: Havana

title: The Obama Era, Brought to You by the Iraq War
description: WHEN prominent people in Washington spend an anniversary apologizing for being catastrophically, unforgivably wrong about a decade-old decision, you might expect that the decision in question had delivered their party to disaster or defeat. But last weeks many Iraq war mea culpas were rich in irony: one by one, prominent liberals lined up to apologize for supporting a war thats responsible for liberalisms current political and cultural ascendance.

title: Where Battier Goes, Winning Streaks Follow
description: The question of whether it is better to be loved or hated may never be answered satisfactorily, but when it comes to Shane Battier, there is no need to choose. He is loved and hated with equal passion, based almost entirely on how one feels about Duke basketball.

title: In India, Womens Issues Are Finally Out Front
description: Having recently returned to the United States from a four-year assignment in India, Im often asked about events in that country. And so it was with the brutal rape and murder of a 23-year-old student in New Delhi in December that set off big protests across India and was covered widely around the world. Why has this particular rape inspired so much outrage, people ask, when sexual violence is, sadly, so pervasive and commonplace there?

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, the Sequel
description: LAST week, scientists sequenced the genome of cells taken without consent from a woman named Henrietta Lacks. She was a black tobacco farmer and mother of five, and though she died in 1951, her cells, code-named HeLa, live on. They were used to help develop our most important vaccines and cancer medications, in vitro fertilization, gene mapping, cloning. Now they may finally help create laws to protect her familys privacy  and yours.

title: Israel: Bits, Bytes and Bombs
description: READING the news from the wider Middle East and then watching President Obama visiting Israel triggered this thought: The president looked as if he were visiting an atoll in the Pacific, or maybe New Zealand  but definitely some kind of island state surrounded by roiling seas.

title: Imprisoned by Innovation
description: PRISONS  those bastions of routine and tradition  are finally ripe for disruption. Such is the rosy conclusion of Beyond the Bars, a provocative report from management consultants at Deloitte published earlier this month.

title: St. Johns Weathered a Season of Changes
description: St. Johns will host Dayton on Sunday at Carnesecca Arena in making its fourth consecutive appearance in the N.C.A.A. Division I womens basketball tournament, an accomplishment that does not begin to suggest the turbulence the Red Storm encountered.

title: The Timess Work in Progress
description: SINCE I started as The Timess fifth public editor last September, Ive taken up topics from false balance in news articles to negative arts criticism to government secrecy. After six months, 16 Sunday columns and close to 100 blog posts to the Public Editors Journal, I thought it would be worthwhile to see where some of the issues I have written about stand now.

title: Report Card on Health Care Reform
description: Republican leaders in Congress regularly denounce the 2010 Affordable Care Act and vow to block money to carry it out or even to repeal it. Those political attacks ignore the considerable benefits delivered to millions of people since the laws enactment three years ago Saturday. The main elements of the law do not kick in until Jan. 1, 2014, when many millions of uninsured people will gain coverage. Yet it has already thrown a lifeline to people at high risk of losing insurance or being uninsured, including young adults and people with chronic health problems, and it has made a start toward reforming the costly, dysfunctional American health care system.

title: Shrinking Prisons, Saving Billions
description: The mandatory sentencing craze that gripped the country four decades ago drove up the state prison population sevenfold  from under 200,000 in the early 1970s to about 1.4 million today  and pushed costs beyond $50 billion a year. Until recently, it seemed that the numbers would keep growing. But thanks to reforms in more than half the states, the prison census has edged down slightly  by just under 2 percent  since 2009. A new analysis by the Pew Charitable Trusts shows that the decline would have been considerably larger had the other states not been pulling in the opposite direction.

title: Heightened Scrutiny
description: One of the central questions in the two gay marriage cases to be argued before the Supreme Court this week is whether gays and lesbians are a protected class under the Constitution. Under longstanding principles, government actions that fall heavily on discrete and insular minorities historically subject to prejudice and stigma are to be given particular scrutiny.

title: Unhappy? Clean House
description: London

title: Your Phone vs. Your Heart
description: CAN you remember the last time you were in a public space in America and didnt notice that half the people around you were bent over a digital screen, thumbing a connection to somewhere else?

title: Buck Gives Mets Pitchers a Mentor Behind the Plate
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Catcher John Buck meant no offense, but his sense of plain-spoken realism had developed over nearly a decade as a major leaguer.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Defining Mental Illness
description: Readers discuss criticisms of how conditions are diagnosed.

title: Pity Earths Creatures
description: Edgartown, Mass.

title: A Plan To Fix Cancer Care
description: This year, more than 1.6 million Americans  0.5 percent of the population  will receive a diagnosis of cancer. Their treatment will consume at least 5 percent of the countrys health care spending, at a cost that is growing faster than all other areas of medicine. Doctors and patients recognize that this is unsustainable and that we need to change the way we deliver care.

title: Coln Struggles as Rest of Panama Races Ahead
description: Wedged between a busy port and a handsome cruise ship terminal, Coln is a crowded, cacophonous city of 220,000, with street after street of faded colonial facades.

title: A Baseball Education Under the Sun
description: We are in the family car, sometime in the 1950s, somewhere south of the Mason-Dixon line. Burma Shave signs still marked the two-lane highways between New York and Florida, and the South of the Border motel had beds that vibrated for 25 cents and were the highlight of the drive to spring training for a bored child on this annual three-day trip.

title: Acceptance by Example, on the Field and at Home
description: My three young daughters, like most kids, are curious and ask a lot of questions. My wife and I are as open and honest with them as possible. But theres one question Im not prepared to answer: Why arent Clare and Lesa married?

title: Tipped Off
description: The first time it happened was at a Fourth of July picnic in New Hampshire. Id just turned in my book manuscript to the copy editor and was in a celebratory mood until a friend tugged at my elbow. Shed found a thick stack of letters written by my subjects, three New England sisters of the 19th century, in a trunk in her attic. Did I want to read them?

title: Life After Oil and Gas
description: WE will need fossil fuels like oil and gas for the foreseeable future. So theres really little choice (sigh). We have to press ahead with fracking for natural gas. We must approve the Keystone XL pipeline to get Canadian oil.

title: Mortgages Future Looks Too Much Like the Past
description: IN a perfect world, policy makers, legislators and concerned Americans would have spent the last few years conducting an honest dialogue about two important issues: how to resolve Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-owned mortgage finance giants, and how to create a housing finance system that would serve borrowers without imperiling taxpayers.

title: A Bosss Challenge: Have Everyone Join the In Group
description: This interview with  David Rock, director of the NeuroLeadership Institute, was conducted and edited by  Adam Bryant.

title: No Krstic or Jefferson, but the Nets Can Play On
description: LOS ANGELES  The last time the Nets made the playoffs, the idea of moving to Brooklyn had been hatched, but the team was nowhere near ready to leave New Jersey. Led by Jason Kidd, Vince Carter and Richard Jefferson, the Nets won 10 of their final 13 games in the regular season and entered the 2007 postseason as a .500 team, one of three Eastern Conference playoff teams that season to win either 41 or 40 games.

title: Russian Oligarch and Critic of Putin Dies in Britain
description: MOSCOW  Boris A. Berezovsky, once the richest and most powerful of the so-called oligarchs who dominated post-Soviet Russia, and a close ally of Boris N. Yeltsin who helped install Vladimir V. Putin as president but later exiled himself to London after a bitter falling out with the Kremlin, died Saturday.

title: A Gamble With No Regrets, So Far
description: Phoenix

title: Another Name for Death
description: In the winter of 1862-3, William Clarke Quantrill traveled from Missouri to Richmond, Va., to request a colonelcy from Confederate Secretary of War James A. Seddon. Normally, men fighting for the Confederacy wouldnt have had to make such a trip, or had the temerity to do so. But Quantrill was no ordinary soldier. He made his request under the provisions of the Partisan Ranger Act, passed by the Confederate Congress in 1862 to organize and promote unconventional warfare along the western border. When Seddon asked Quantrills opinions about the war, Quantrill replied, in the florid rendering of the Confederate sympathizer John N. Edwards, one of his biographers, I would wage such a war  as to make surrender forever impossible. I would cover the armies of the Confederacy all over with blood.  I would exterminate.

title: Big Data Is Opening Doors, but Maybe Too Many
description: IN the 1960s, mainframe computers posed a significant technological challenge to common notions of privacy. Thats when the federal government started putting tax returns into those giant machines, and consumer credit bureaus began building databases containing the personal financial information of millions of Americans. Many people feared that the new computerized databanks would be put in the service of an intrusive corporate or government Big Brother.

title: In Havana, Remembering a Minor League Championship
description: HAVANA  When the Havana Sugar Kings were mentioned to Asdrubal Bar, a smile crept across his wrinkled face, revealing missing teeth. Seated in a wheelchair on the balcony of his Havana apartment surrounded by cactus plants, he said, I must show you something.

title: Theres a Reason for Deposit Insurance
description: FOR all the criticism of bailouts since the financial crisis struck, virtually no one has suggested that depositors in banks be made to suffer along with their investors, employees and customers. Until this week, when the euro zone proposed that, in return for a bailout of the failing banking system in Cyprus, depositors pay a tax of 6.75 percent of their deposits  9.9 percent for deposits above 100,000 euros.

title: Obama Shows Talent for Arm-Twisting, and Raises Hopes on Peace Effort
description: AMMAN, Jordan  There is little doubt that President Obama can deliver a memorable speech, as he did in Jerusalem last week about the need for peace. The big surprise on his trip to Israel and Jordan, which ended here on Saturday, is that he can also twist arms.

title: Michigan Beats Press in a Rout of V.C.U.
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  The first half was winding down, and Trey Burke, again, swerved past his defender, into the paint, into the heart of Virginia Commonwealths defense. It was helpless with Burke there. He lofted the ball toward the rim.

title: Witnesses Deny Rebel Gains in Central African Republic
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  There were conflicting reports on Saturday about a rebel advance on the capital of the Central African Republic, with some saying the rebels had entered the city, but with witnesses in the capital and the presidents spokesman denying it.

title: Automatic Cuts Are Felt at Nations Air Shows
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla.  A screaming comes across the sky. Again and again, all day long.

title: At Florida Gulf Coast, Party Extends Beyond the Beach
description: Florida Gulf Coast University has its own beach. And it may come in handy this weekend.

title: A Winding Road to Benefits From Long-Term Care Insurance
description: OUR episode about Whirlpools grudging approach to customer service, as illuminated by the tale of a faulty microwave, prompted more than a dozen e-mails of the oh-you-think-thats-bad? variety. Most were mundane variations on a theme of Whirlpool indifference, incompetence or both. But one stood out. It came from Shira London, a librarian in Baltimore, and the owner of a Whirlpool refrigerator that makes a very loud buzzing noise.

title: Demoted Last Season, Cervelli Emerges as Yankees Starting Catcher
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Francisco Cervellis blue eyes peer with a perpetual state of wonder, open and expressive, as if he is seeing the world for the first time. Perhaps it was not surprising, then, that the thought of being the Yankees opening-day catcher seemed to startle him.

title: In IndyCar, Racing in the Streets
description: The 2013 IndyCar Series season begins Sunday in Florida with the Honda Grand Prix of St. Petersburg, one of six street courses on the 19-race schedule. Target Chip Ganassi Racing will be trying to reclaim the series title after Ryan Hunter-Reay, 32, of Andretti Autosport ended Ganassis five-year run of championships. The Ganassi teammates Dario Franchitti, 39, a four-time series champion and three-time Indianapolis 500 winner, and Charlie Kimball, 28, the winner of the Tony Renna Rising Star Award last year and the first IndyCar driver with diabetes, talked recently to New York Times reporters and editors about their hobbies, IndyCars movie moment and the perfect street course.

title: Apple Plugs Password Security Hole
description: Apple has fixed a security hole that made it easy for someone to seize another persons Apple account, which controls access to iCloud, iTunes and other Apple services.

title: Attacking Success
description: OK, this is rich. Or actually, its anti-rich. Or anti-rich liberal. Or something.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 24
description: As Congress heads off for a two-week recess, the Sunday shows take a look at the fight over gun control and the scheduled Supreme Court arguments over same-sex marriage.

title: Funeral Is Held for Brooklyn Teenager Killed by Police
description: There were two vigils in Brooklyn on Saturday.

title: Grand Exits That Never Earn Applause
description: I QUIT!

title: Answering Calls to Serve
description: MY father, who was born and raised in Panama, became an American citizen by joining the Army when the United States operated the Panama Canal. He moved to the United States in the early 1950s, attended Howard University, met my mother and became a successful architect.

title: Not Even a Squabble Between Teammates Can Slow the Spartans
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  Michigan State was trying to fend off Memphis, trying to do what it does almost every March and advance to the Round of 16, when two of its best players, who are also best friends, got into a spat during a second-half timeout.

title: Mixing Freedoms in a 32-Ounce Soda
description: ON narrow technical grounds, a New York State court recently rejected Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposed curbs on large sodas and other sugary drinks. The ruling is being appealed, but many people who viewed the proposal as a step down a slippery slope to a nanny state were quick to celebrate the courts move.

title: How to Unlock That Stashed Foreign Cash
description: HERES a novel way to drive up a companys share price: Pay billions of dollars in additional taxes.

title: JPMorgans Trading Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Supplements and Sellers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Ann Steinhagen Is Dead at 83; Shot a Ballplayer
description: On the night of June 14, 1949, a young woman gave an enormous tip  $5  to a bellhop at the Edgewater Beach Hotel in Chicago to deliver a note to another guest, Eddie Waitkus, the first baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, who were in town to play the Cubs. The two had never met, but she needed to see him, she explained in the note, in which she called herself Ruth Anne Burns. Could he come to her room?

title: Excitement of Deadline Day Has Potential to End With a Thud
description: As with all things in this shrunken N.H.L. season, which began slightly more than two months ago, the April 3 trade deadline is coming fast. Canadas all-sports television networks like TSN began showing specials on it 30 days before the deadline, have dedicated Web pages to it and will, as always, devote at least nine hours of live programming on deadline day for an audience that includes viewers of the NHL Network in the United States.

title: New York in His Blood, Winning on His Mind, Obstacles in His Way
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  John Davidson was reminiscing about his three decades in New York as a Rangers goaltender and a television announcer.

title: Youll Know It When You See It
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Well, if we didnt know what art was before, we definitely know it now.

title: Mayors Against Illegal Guns Ad: Father
description: The $12 million national advertising campaign that focuses on trying to persuade senators to support a pending package of federal regulations to curb gun violence.

title: Bloombergs TV Blitz on Guns Puts Swing Senators on the Spot
description: The commercial is an unambiguous appeal to gun owners: a middle-aged hunter, shotgun in hand, vows that he will fight to protect the Second Amendment. But in a sensible, father-of-the-house tone, he also urges voters to support comprehensive background checks, so criminals and the dangerously mentally ill cant buy guns.

title: Mayors Against Illegal Guns Ad
description: The ads, in a dozen states, will blanket those senators districts during an Easter Congressional recess that is to be followed by debate over gun legislation.

title: Tackling Concerns of Independent Workers
description: SOON after landing a job at a Manhattan law firm nearly 20 years ago, Sara Horowitz was shocked to discover that it planned to treat her not as an employee, but as an independent contractor.

title: In Dealing With Injuries, Collins Takes the Long View
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets could begin the season without two key infielders, but Manager Terry Collins would prefer to be safe for the short term rather than risk any long-term absences.

title: U.S. and Afghans Reach Deal on Bagram Prison Transfer
description: WASHINGTON  After months of delays and recriminations by American and Afghan officials, the Pentagon announced Saturday that a deal had been reached to transfer control of Bagram Prison to the Afghan government.

title: What Drought? Just Dont Tread on Our Green Grass
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Critics of State Bill Say It Would Restrict Abortions
description: A bill advancing through the Texas Legislature could drastically decrease the number of legal abortion facilities in the state.

title: With Political Savvy, A&M Chancellor Charts a Smooth Course for Big Changes
description: COLLEGE STATION  When the Texas A&M University System was looking for a new chancellor in 2011, alumni groups told Richard Box, the chairman of the Board of Regents, that the board should conduct a nationwide search of academics.

title: A Restaurateur Builds Up His Austin Enterprise
description: Larry McGuire, Austins prolific restaurateur, sits down to lunch at his newest restaurant, Josephine House, in the central Clarksville neighborhood. With impeccably clean hands, he straightens his Rag & Bone shawl-collar cardigan and unfolds a crisp napkin, which he places over his lap.

title: Venus Williams Withdraws From Sony Open
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Just minutes before she was supposed to take the court Saturday against Sloane Stephens, Venus Williams withdrew from the Sony Open with a lower back injury.

title: Russian Ties Put Cyprus Banking Crisis on East-West Fault Line
description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus  Andreas Marangos, a Porsche-driving lawyer here, had just woken up when he heard the news that threatened to destroy his and Cypruss most lucrative business: setting up shell companies and providing financial services for wealthy Russians.

title: After 3 Days of Violence, City in Myanmar Counts the Dead
description: BANGKOK  Army units restored order on Saturday to a city in central Myanmar devastated by three days of religious rioting and arson attacks.

title: Jeter Plays, but Not in the Field
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Derek Jeter made it back into a game Saturday, his first since he was scratched from Tuesdays game due to soreness in his surgically repaired left ankle.

title: So Much for That Week of Rest
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  This was going to be the week Chris Stroud recharged his batteries and doted on his two young daughters. Instead, a single phone call set into motion one of the more exhausting weeks of Strouds seven-year PGA Tour career.

title: Dr. Jacquelin Perry, Surgeon Who Aided Polio Victims, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Jacquelin Perry, a physician and researcher who shed light on the complexities of walking, and was a leader in treating polio victims in the 1950s and again in the 80s when the symptoms of some returned, died on March 11 at her home in Downey, Calif. She was 94.

title: Long Shots and Long Road Converge at Site of Long-Ago Title
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Municipal Auditorium, the most historic place in La Salle University mens basketball, still stands at the corner of West 13th and Wyandotte Streets here. A breathtaking mix of art deco and curving forms, it remains home to the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (N.A.I.A.) Division I national championship and other events. On Saturday, it hosted a cheerleading competition.

title: In Syrias Civil War, Doctors Find Themselves in Cross Hairs
description: GAZIANTEP, Turkey  Six months after Syrian secret police officers led Dr. M. Nour Maktabi away from his Aleppo clinic, the morgue at the university hospital summoned his family to collect his corpse.

title: Pakistani Cricket Star Tries Again to Turn Adulation Into Political Support
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Imran Khan, a Pakistani cricket star turned politician, kicked off his populist campaign for national elections with a huge rally here on Saturday, a national holiday, in a symbolic move timed to tap into surging nationalist sentiment and bolster his political party, which has never won more than a single seat in Parliament and is flagging in the polls.

title: From LeBron James to Buckeyes, a Coach Brings His Shooting Touch
description: DAYTON, Ohio  When second-seeded Ohio State bulldozed Iona in its West Region opener Friday, shooting 48 percent from the floor, one Buckeyes assistant took no small amount of personal satisfaction.

title: Helen Kutsher, Pampering Matriarch of a Grand Borscht Belt Resort, Dies at 89
description: Helen Kutsher, the matriarch of the last of the grand Catskill resorts, who greeted guests with a Welcome home, made sure the regulars got rooms facing the lake, entertained them with comedians and filled them with blintzes and stuffed cabbage, died on Tuesday in Philadelphia. She was 89 and lived most of her life in Monticello, N.Y., in a house on the grounds of the hotel.

title: A Blur of Steals and Scoring for Louisville
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  There was red, so much red at Rupp Arena on Saturday night. There was noise, so much noise. And there was pressure, so much pressure. Louisville welcomed it, thrived in it, inflicted it. Until Thursday morning, Larry Eustachy, the Colorado State coach, did not know a single player on Louisvilles team, let alone Russ Smith or Peyton Siva, whose names he is as familiar with now as his wedding anniversary.

title: Change in Title Format Forces Switch in Strategies
description: The Candidates Tournament to select a challenger to face Viswanathan Anand for the world chess championship began on March 15 in London, and it has proved one thing: A single event beats the elimination matches that have most often been used since 1965.

title: Expectations Elevated, But Harvard Is Humbled
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Brawn battered brains on Saturday. Hope was swallowed by Arizonas size. There went Harvard, among the darlings of this N.C.A.A. tournament, a life powerhouse turned basketball underdog whose charmed appearance here ended on the wrong end of a blowout.

title: Joe Weider, Creator of Bodybuilding Empire, Dies at 93
description: Joe Weider, a scrawny youngster who sculptured himself with bodybuilding during the Great Depression and created an empire of muscle magazines, fitness equipment, doubtful dietary supplements and Olympic-style contests featuring Arnold Schwarzenegger, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Yankees Bring Back an Old Hand
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Yankees announced they signed Chien-Ming Wang, their own former pitcher, to a minor league contract to provide pitching depth. He is scheduled to work out on Monday.

title: For Shelter-Seeking Syrians, Home Is a Cave
description: As President Bashar al-Assads military continues to pound neighborhoods aligned with the rebels, uncountable Syrian families are waiting out the violence in the caves of bygone times.

title: Jammed in Roman Caves, Ducking Syrias War
description: SARJAH, Syria  Abdulkader Darwish did not go far after a Syrian military aircraft dropped a bomb near his house last year, prompting him to gather his family and flee. He ventured with a shovel into the local olive groves. There he dug through the sealed entrance to an abandoned Roman cave.

title: Detroit Waits, Apprehensive, for Manager to Take Over
description: DETROIT  The City Council is both anxious and defiant. Public employees unions are bracing for a showdown. Protests and lawsuits are promised. Meanwhile, the mayor has simply stopped talking about what is on nearly everyones mind in this troubled city.

title: No, Miami Isnt Surprised
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  It was a perfectly lobbed question. Shane, were you surprised Florida Gulf Coast

title: Woods Takes Usual Place at Bay Hill
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The electricity in the air made the hairs stand on peoples necks, but it was not because of the thunderstorms in the area. The force of nature bearing down on Bay Hill Club and Lodge on Saturday was Tiger Woods. Trailing Justin Rose, the 36-hole co-leader, by five when he made the turn, Woods carded two birdies and an eagle on the back nine on his way to a six-under-par 66 that vaulted him into the lead at the Arnold Palmer Invitational.

title: Coach Keeps Heart in Mind at Iowa State
description: DAYTON, Ohio  It was well past midnight by the time Iowa State Coach Fred Hoiberg had finished his news media obligations and walked back out to the court, where his team was still celebrating Fridays victory over Notre Dame.

title: Man Detained in Fatal Coney Island Shooting
description: The police on Saturday detained a man suspected of shooting four people  one fatally  in an apartment at a Coney Island housing project on Friday.

title: Martin Puts Spring in Knicks Step
description: From the beginning, it seemed this Knicks season would be defined by age  its benefits, its limitations and its consequences, with the precise weight of each effect to be determined by the 82-game schedule.

title: How the Court Could Rule on Same-Sex Marriage
description: The Supreme Court is set to release decisions in two cases about same-sex marriage.

title: Shadow of Roe v. Wade Looms Over Ruling on Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  When the Supreme Court hears a pair of cases on same-sex marriage on Tuesday and Wednesday, the justices will be working in the shadow of a 40-year-old decision on another subject entirely: Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling that established a constitutional right to abortion.

title: Immigrants Held in Solitary Cells, Often for Weeks
description: WASHINGTON  On any given day, about 300 immigrants are held in solitary confinement at the 50 largest detention facilities that make up the sprawling patchwork of holding centers nationwide overseen by Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials, according to new federal data.

title: Oregon Ends Emotional Run by St. Louis
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The end for St. Louis started simply, with one 3-pointer, then another, bombs to break apart a game clogged by tight defense. And when Oregon made another to bookend a 20-4 run to end the first half, the highly regarded Billikens, wearing patches on their uniforms to commemorate the December death of their coach, finally found themselves in a situation they could not overcome.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 13
description: Animals, like wolves, refuse to live in such places. But we have to accept this.

title: For Surprise No. 1, Its Two Games and Out
description: SALT LAKE CITY  They shuffled down the corridor at EnergySolutions Arena, first the Gonzaga cheerleaders, then Coach Mark Few and three of his players, then the band. No one said a word. It resembled a funeral procession.

title: Pettitte Still Likes the Yankees Chances
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The growing sentiment around baseball takes a dim view of the Yankees chances in 2013, what with the losses of key players like Nick Swisher, Russell Martin and Rafael Soriano, plus injuries to Mark Teixeira, Curtis Granderson, Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter.

title: Corrections: March 24, 2013.
description: EDITORS NOTE

title: A Birthday Kidd Wont Forget
description: Jason Kidd was with his teammates when one of them, Chris Copeland, started walking to midcourt just before tipoff of the Knicks game against the Toronto Raptors on Saturday at Madison Square Garden. Kidd did not know what Copeland was doing, why he was alone or why he was holding a microphone.

title: Marquette Rallies Again to Survive Butler
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Back and forth they went, Butler and Marquette, their game  less a basketball matchup, more a war of attrition  coming down to the final possession, the final moment, because it had to. Every made shot, every rebound, every defensive stop was met in kind.

title: Shannon Nees and Reid Ravin
description: Dr. Shannon Nichole Nees, a daughter of Donna and Kevin Nees of Hatfield, Pa., was married Saturday in Bensalem, Pa., to Dr. Reid Armstrong Ravin, a son of Claudia and Dr. Neil Ravin of Hampton, N.H. The Rev. Christopher M. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Pen Ryn Mansion.

title: Katherine Lamper, Alex Radetsky
description: Katherine Sophia Lamper and Alex Radetsky were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated.

title: Jennifer Barron and Meadow Braun
description: Jennifer Nicole Barron and Meadow Sylvia Braun were married Saturday at the Galapagos Art Space, an event space in Brooklyn. Alice L. Soloway, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated.

title: Sally King and Adam McBride
description: Sally Hoagland King and Adam Gregory McBride were married Saturday by the Rev. James B. Lemler at Christ Church Greenwich in Greenwich, Conn.

title: JiWon Kim and Francis Kim
description: Dr. JiWon Kim and Dr. Francis Young-Gyu Kim were married Saturday afternoon at the Broadway Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Danny Han, a senior pastor with Joy Christian Fellowship Church, performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Meisels, Matt Halliday
description: Jessica Kotlen Meisels and Matt Brendt Halliday were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Resort in Wailea, Hawaii. Robert Gilman, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Paula Miller, Eric Weil
description: Paula Lynn Miller and Eric Victor Weil were married Saturday evening at BallenIsles Country Club in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Joel L. Levine officiated.

title: Elizabeth Epstein, Benjamin Mundel
description: Elizabeth Robin Epstein, a daughter of Bonnie Newman Epstein and Dr. Mark A. Epstein of Coral Springs, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Milton Mundel, a son of Elinor Stoff Mundel and Randolph S. Mundel of Uniontown, Pa. Rabbi Noah Fabricant officiated at the Fairfax at Embassy Row, a hotel in Washington.

title: Hilary Shpeen, Joshua Brownstein
description: Hilary Rachel Shpeen and Joshua Nachum Brownstein were married Saturday evening at Congregation Beth Emeth in Albany. Rabbi Randi Musnitsky officiated, and her husband, Rabbi Ronald W. Kaplan, participated.

title: Shannon Carey, Christopher Fazzolari
description: Shannon Marie Carey and Christopher Fazzolari were married Saturday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Mara Raphael, John Mendell Jr.
description: At a Farewell, Romance Begins

title: Justin Figari, Jason Garcia
description: Justin David Figari and Jason Scott Garcia were married Saturday evening at the Glasshouses, an event space in the Chelsea Arts Tower in New York. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Alexa von Tobel and Michael Ryan Jr.
description: Alexa Leigh Marie von Tobel and Michael Clifford Ryan Jr. were married Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton in Amelia Island, Fla. Dr. Brandon Z. von Tobel, a brother of the bride and a notary public, officiated.

title: Mindy Borisoff, Steven Balet
description: Mindy Jacqueline Borisoff and Steven Craig Balet were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Edward Schecter at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in White Plains.

title: Emily Whitfield, Robert Fader
description: Emily Anne Whitfield and Robert Innes Fader are to be married Sunday at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Harold Zernike, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

title: Sharon Otterman, Rajiv Agashiwala
description: Sharon Otterman and Dr. Rajiv Mahesh Agashiwala were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerks office, officiated.

title: CeCe Barfield, William Thompson III
description: Carolyn Claire Barfield and William McIlwaine Thompson III were married Saturday by the Rev. Patrick Gahan III, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Episcopal Church in San Antonio.

title: Julia Fefferman and Matthew Jacobs
description: Social Media Aids Modern Romance

title: With Its Shots Awry, Syracuse Uses an On-Target Defense to Advance
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  There might not be another team in the N.C.A.A. tournament that can go more than 12 minutes without a field goal in the second half of a game and extend its lead.

title: Where Parity Rules, a Florida Gulf Coast Can Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA  Before his team faced Mercer in the Atlantic Sun Conference tournament final March 9, Andy Enfield, the coach at Florida Gulf Coast, regaled his players with another story. Enfield has lots of stories. One for every occasion, some for no occasion at all.

title: Nets Cant Slow Paul, Falling to Clippers Late
description: LOS ANGELES  The Nets will extend their longest trip of the season to Phoenix on Sunday with the knowledge of how close they came to victory Saturday night.

title: Womens N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 23
description: In the first full day of the womens N.C.A.A. tournament, 12th-seeded Kansas upset fifth-seeded Colorado and 10th-seeded Creighton held off No. 7 Syracuse.

title: Larkin and Scott Spark Miami From the Backcourt
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The drill immediately stokes their competitive fire. When Miami Coach Jim Larranaga calls out five minutes of 3s at practice, his players respond with an energy and alacrity reflected in Larranagas tone.

title: U.S. and China Relations
description: A new surprise for Uncle Sam.

title: World Dream, Business on Chinese Presidents First Overseas Trip
description: BEIJING  Even as President Barack Obama was wrapping up a Mideast trip  his first to Israel as president  during which he discussed war and peace, a new world leader, Xi Jinping, had begun his first overseas trip as the Chinese president, amid talk of dreams, business and even a new type of inter-power relations.

title: Mens N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 23
description: Wichita State upset No. 1 Gonzaga and fourth-seeded Michigan defeated fifth-seeded V.C.U. in Saturdays tournament action.

title: In Spirited Talks, Kerry Tells Iraq to Help Stop Arms Shipments to Syria
description: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State John Kerry told Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, the prime minister of Iraq, on Sunday that Iraq must take steps to stop Iran from shipping arms to Syria through Iraqi airspace. But an hour and 40 minutes of discussions here, which Mr. Kerry said were sometimes spirited, failed to yield a breakthrough on the issue.

title: When Hope Tramples Truth
description: Apollo granted to his Trojan priestess Cassandra the gift of prophecy. But because she resisted his advances he punished her by ensuring that nobody would ever believe what she said. Such has been the fate of pessimists down the ages. Those who interrupt the good cheer of their fellows with the thought that the things about which they are all agreed might go badly wrong are either dismissed as madmen or condemned as fools.

title: Musharraf Greeted in Pakistan by Threats and Small Crowds
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans onetime military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, ended four years of self-imposed exile on Sunday in hopes of carving out a political future, but he received an unremarkable welcome as he landed at the airport in Karachi.

title: As Deadline Nears, Cyprus Scrambles to Devise a Bailout
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders convenedemergency meetings here Sunday night hoping to devise a bank bailout package that would enable Cyprus to stay in the euro zone and rebuild its devastated economy.

title: At West Point, Morrison Gets at Truths of War in Fiction
description: Our colleague Abigail Meisel writes that the author Toni Morrison received a heros welcome at West Point, where cadets greeted her Friday with a rousing group cheer during their 20-minute lunch break in the dining hall.

title: When Family Stories Are Hard to Tell
description: Ive been thinking hard about family stories.

title: Myanmars Ethnic Minorities Grow Pessimistic About Peace
description: BANGKOK  Ethnic conflicts have been described as Myanmars original sin, a legacy of hatred and mistrust that fueled more than six decades of intermittent civil war.

title: Syrian Opposition Leader Quits His Post
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Moaz al-Khatib, the president of the main coalition of the Syrian opposition in exile, declared Sunday that he was resigning, and he complained bitterly about foreign powers that he said were withholding aid from the Syrian rebels while trying to control their every move.

title: Once the King of Harlem Hairdressers, Now Nearly Forgotten
description: In 1983, Glenn Caldwell, a music teacher from Maryland, was playing saxophone in a South Carolina bar and began talking with a singer whose dapper outfit and slick hair seemed from a bygone era.

title: Disruptions: F.A.A. May Loosen Curbs on Fliers Use of Electronics
description: If youre sitting on a plane at the gate and reading this column on an electronic gadget, youre about to hear eight dreaded words: Please power down your electronic devices for takeoff. But this time next year, you might hear something very different: Please put your devices on airplane mode for takeoff.

title: In Seattle, Public Art With an Interactive Twist
description: A finished piece of architecture is typically thought to be immutable, and the same is true of an artwork, an object fixed to its particular moment of creation; or, in the case of video, repeating itself.

title: President Is Said to Flee as Rebels Seize Capital of the Central African Republic
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  Rebels entered Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, on Sunday morning, seizing control of the city in the culmination of a lengthy uprising in one of the worlds weakest and most impoverished states. The countrys president was reported to have fled.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Analysis, Round of 32, Day 2
description: The field of the mens N.C.A.A. tournament is whittled down to the final 16. Can the upset parade continue? Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters covered Sundays action.

title: Foreign Businesses in Cyprus Grind to a Standstill
description: LIMASSOL, CYPRUS  It is not just about rich Russians and Cypriot retirees.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M.
