(HBO) PHIL SPECTOR (2013) A wigged-out Al Pacino reunites with the writer and director David Mamet(Glengarry Glen Ross) to portray the music producer and songwriter charged with the 2003 shooting death of Lana Clarkson inside his home in Alhambra, Calif. Helen Mirren, right with Mr. Pacino, plays the lawyer Linda Kenney Baden, who represented Mr. Spector alongside Bruce Cutler (Jeffrey Tambor) at his first trial, in 2007, which resulted in a hung jury. (He was convicted in 2009 and is serving 19 years to life.) The movie has already set off controversy: Mr. Spectors wife, Rachelle, has complained about the films depiction of her husband as a foul-mouthed megalomaniac. Edward Lozzi, a former publicist for Ms. Clarkson, has taken exception to the films focus on the defenses argument that she killed herself. The film is a work of fiction, Mr. Mamet said in an HBO interview, spun from his fascination with Mr. Spectors character and the mythological possibilities. The focus on the tender and respectful bond between lawyer and client looks a lot like a revisionist re-enactment and maybe even absolution, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. Everyone has a right to the best available defense, but not everyone deserves to be played by the best available actor.

title: A Line at the Supreme Court, and Some Are Paid to Be There
description: Nearly 30 people formed a line in front of the Supreme Court over the weekend, hoping for one of the roughly 50 seats reserved for the public to witness arguments in the landmark same-sex marriage case that begins on Tuesday. With thousands of tourists streaming into Washington for the Easter break and the National Cherry Blossom Festival, gawkers and passers-by alike paused to ask what the line was about or to offer their opinions on the case.

title: After Other States Moves, Connecticut Is Still Working on Stricter Gun Law
description: HARTFORD  The original goal of producing legislation before the end of February has long passed. So has the next target, a bill within three months of the massacre of 20 children and 6 educators at the Sandy Hook Elementary School on Dec. 14.

title: Moviegoers Welcoming Animation And Thriller
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood finally lured moviegoers out of their caves.

title: N.R.A. Chief Says He Will Counter Bloombergs Gun Control Campaign
description: The chief executive of the National Rifle Association said Sunday that his organization would lead a national campaign against efforts by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to persuade Congress to adopt stricter gun controls.

title: Breaking It Down: Murray Vs. Tomic
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.Bernard Tomic will not be leaving Miami with a new trophy but he did reinforce his nickname  Tomic the Tank Engine.

title: Ohio State Survives on a Buzzer-Beater Out of a Childs Daydream
description: DAYTON, Ohio  The West Region is in shambles. The one, three, four, five, seven and eight seeds will not be going to Los Angeles for the regional semifinals this week.

title: Jeter, Still Sore, Appears Headed for the D.L.
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Brian Cashman explained that additional soreness in Derek Jeters surgically repaired ankle would most likely force Jeter onto the disabled list, which would ensure that he would miss opening day. Moments later, Cashman, the Yankees general manager, was asked if everything else was all right.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Thompson Names 2 Aides for Mayoral Bid
description: When William C. Thompson Jr. ran unsuccessfully against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2009, he relied chiefly on longtime local loyalists to guide his campaign.

title: Tennessee Race for Medicaid: Dial Fast and Try, Try Again
description: NASHVILLE  Two nights a year, Tennessee holds a health care lottery of sorts, giving the medically desperate a chance to get help.

title: Hed Probably Help With Your Science Project, Too
description: You can almost hear the conversation that must have transpired at some point between the conception of the Metropolitan Operas current production of Gounods Faust and the debut of that staging, offered last season. The kernel is elementary: The physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, widely credited as the father (or at least a father) of the atomic bombs dropped on Japan near the end of World War II, has been said to have made a Faustian bargain to secure wartime victory for America.

title: A Metric for News Apps
description: OpenNews fellow Brian Abelson recently pondered some deep questions on his blog: How do you define success for a news app? And how can you measure reader engagement? The Timess Red Carpet Project serves as a case study. (Bonus: math and graphs!)

title: Pushing and Pulling Between Opposites to Zones in Between
description: Who in the world is Paul Taylor? Every year this impossible question comes around with the New York season of his dance company; this years, a three-week affair at the David H. Koch Theater, ended on Sunday.

title: A Spectacle With Something for Everyone, Even Poor Neglected Pluto
description: Toward the end of the first half of Friday evenings performance of Planetarium at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, during a string quartet arrangement of a song called Year of the Boar by the singer-songwriter Sufjan Stevens, the violinist Ben Russell let loose with a wild riff. His finger slithered up and down the fingerboard producing electric guitarlike squeals while the other members of the quartet  Nadia Sirota (viola), Clarice Jensen (cello) and Rob Moose (violin)  provided an accompaniment of crunchy rhythmic chords that were subtly amplified and altered through giant speakers on each side of the stage.

title: Art Adds a Dimension to Biblically Inspired Melody
description: In the first full season she has planned as the general manager of concerts and lectures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Limor Tomer has tried to link music programs to the museums exhibitions and collections. A concert on Friday night put that goal into practice. The Salzburg Chamber Soloists performed Haydns ruminative masterpiece The Seven Last Words of Christ on the Cross, an hourlong work in nine movements, including seven slow movements called sonatas that reflect the final phrases Jesus spoke during the Crucifixion.

title: North American Championships in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS  Three major titles were won Friday at the North American Bridge Championships here.

title: Irregular Trial Venue
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I was going to start todays post with an old joke about a famous ships CAPTAIN and his propensity for wearing a red shirt and brown pants, but decided that it was far too juvenile and inappropriate for this blog. As Ive said many a time, far be it from me to contribute anything that might not be sophisticated in concept, and

title: Something in the Air? It Must Be the Headliner
description: The Truth About Love Tour, which stopped at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, is built on a suspension of disbelief, but maybe not the one youre bracing for. It isnt about the way that Pink, the tours vocal dynamo and principal object in motion, defies logic and the laws of gravity during her unstoppable two-hour show. The aerial acrobatics, the taut cables and spinning cages, the whole business of soaring around an arena like a pop-punk Peter Pan: by now she has trained her audiences to expect this species of amazement in concert. Its a condition of her current reality.

title: Economy Is Woeful, and the Sex Even Worse
description: After recent excursions into Americana with the radio play of Its a Wonderful Life, rural nostalgia with Donnybrook! and 20th-century institutional repression with Airswimming, the Irish Repertory Theater switches into high contemporary gear with For Love, a riotously tart and fiercely energetic production that opened on Tuesday. Billed as a dark blue romantic comedy, the play  a dramedy, really, only fleetingly romantic  plunges straight into Irelands fraught urban present.

title: Still an Ecstatic Rebel Spirit, but Easing Up on Shock
description: Lil Wayne has long been one of hip-hops loosest cannons, but his narrative changed dramatically in 2010 after his release from Rikers Island jail, where he spent eight months on a weapons charge. For three years at least, sobriety was to be his sidekick. As part of a plea agreement in a separate drug possession case, he consented to regular drug tests.

title: A Man of Many Realms, Most Recently Daytime TV
description: Steve Harvey and Ted Harbert go way back  all the way to 1994, when Mr. Harbert, then president for entertainment at ABC, ordered a Harvey-led sitcom called Me and the Boys. The sitcom failed, as most do. But in 2011, when my name came across his desk, he remembered me, Mr. Harvey said this month, sounding appreciative still.

title: Aggressive Play Catches Up to Mets Prospect
description: 6:48 p.m. | Updated PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Matt den Dekkers audacious outfield play has earned him many plaudits during this spring training, and his spectacular catches have kept many wondering whether the Mets would start him at the major leagues solely for his glove.

title: Masters Blueprint, Born of Revolution
description: The Russian Revolution upended the lives of Vladimir Nabokov and his family. Leaving behind an aristocratic world of colossal wealth and privilege (a world about which he could speak of the smallest and oldest of our gardeners), Nabokov would become an exile in Berlin, where he supported himself as a tutor, teaching French, English and tennis. On March 28, 1922, his father, a liberal politician, was shot and killed at a Berlin lecture while trying to protect another man from an assassin  a loss that would reverberate throughout Nabokovs life and fiction.

title: A Late 3-Pointer Falls, Ensuring That No. 1 Indiana Does Not
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Indianas Christian Watford, Remy Abell and Yogi Ferrell watched Gonzaga lose to Wichita State from their hotel room Saturday night, enjoying the way the Shockers hit shots and felled a top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournaments opening weekend.

title: Watch Out for the Horses on Your Way to the Train
description: Commuters in Grand Central Terminal will encounter a new obstacle to making the train on time this week: 30 dancing horses.

title: Escaping the Cross for a Spiritual Quest
description: Barabbas, the man the crowd spared from crucifixion instead of Jesus, makes only a brief appearance in the Bible, but in more recent times his bit part has been expanded into a full-fledged Easter event.

title: With Shovels and Science, a Grim Story Is Told
description: MALVERN, Pa.  They laid his bones in a bed of Bubble Wrap, with a care beyond what is normally given to fragile things. They double-boxed those bones and carried them last month to the United Parcel Service office on Spruce Street in Philadelphia. Then they printed out the address and paid the fee.

title: American Dance Festival Unveils Summer Season
description: The American Dance Festival has announced the 80th edition of its summer season, from June 13 to July 27 in Durham, N.C., and New York City. The festival is to feature nine world premieres, including two by the dance troupe Pilobolus. The first is a collaboration with the choreographer Trish Sie set to original music by the Nortec Collective Presents Bostich + Fussible, a Latin fusion group. The second will highlight the illusionists Penn and Teller. Another world premiere is to be Twyla Tharps 130th work, which she has created for American Dance Festival students and set to a score by the music producer David Kahne. The festival is to include 47 performances by 25 companies, including Shen Wei Dance Arts, Paul Taylor Dance Company, Trisha Brown Dance Company, the Brenda Angiel Aerial Dance Company from Argentina, Mark Haim, Kyle Abraham/Abraham.In.Motion and Faye Driscoll. Among those presenting for the first time at the festival are Camille A. Brown & Dancers, the 605 Collective from Canada and Ponydance from Ireland. The festival plans to start a social-media campaign in honor of its anniversary, called 80 Years  80 Stories, in early May.

title: With Woods Leading, Rain and Wind Push Final Round to Monday
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  After Tiger Woods birdied the second hole to increase his lead at the Arnold Palmer Invitational to three strokes, it seemed that only an act of nature could prevent him from winning his 77th PGA Tour title, and his record-tying eighth in a single tournament.

title: The Difficult Choices Ahead for the Dell Board
description: Reports that both the Blackstone Group and Carl C. Icahn have submitted preliminary bids for Dell now set off a highly choreographed dance of next steps. And the developments highlight the difficult choices that the Dell board now faces.

title: Yankees Working on a Deal to Acquire Vernon Wells from Angels
description: 10:03 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees were working to sort out the final details Sunday of a trade that would bring them outfielder Vernon Wells from the Los Angeles Angels.

title: Trimming the Field to 16
description: Florida Gulf Coast became the first No. 15 seed to reach the Round of 16, while higher seeds fended off upset challenges.

title: Catcher dArnaud Among Six Trimmed From Mets Roster
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets demoted six players from their major league camp on Sunday.

title: French Protest as Gay Marriage Bill Nears Passage
description: PARIS  Hundreds of thousands of protesters marched in the French capital on Sunday in opposition to a gay marriage bill sponsored by President Franois Hollande.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Why I am on Hunger Strike in Bahrain
description: This is a letter that Zainab al-Khawaja, a human rights activist and political prisoner in Bahrain, wrote from jail. I wrote about her in a column examining the regimes repression of protesters. The United States is a leading backer of the Bahrain government and sells it weapons. Zainab went on a hunger strike recently, after being denied family visits in jail.  Nicholas D. Kristof

title: Chinas First Lady Strikes Glamorous Note
description: BEIJING  Peng Liyuan, Chinas new first lady, is glamorous, fashionable and one of her nations best-known singers, a startling contrast to her dour-looking predecessors. As she accompanies her husband, President Xi Jinping, on his first trip abroad as Chinas leader, Ms. Peng appears ready to carve out a new role for herself.

title: Libya Transferring $2 Billion to Egypts Bank
description: CAIRO  Libyas transitional government is completing an agreement with Egypt to deposit $2 billion in the Egyptian central bank, an official briefed on the talks said Sunday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Economic data to be released include durable goods for February, the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller housing price index for January, new home sales for February and consumer confidence for March (Tuesday); pending home sales for February, weekly jobless claims, fourth-quarter gross domestic product (revised) and the Chicago P.M.I. for March (Thursday); personal income and spending for February and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

title: Permit Allowing a Few Pints Tests a Tolerance for Drunken Driving
description: KILGARVAN, Ireland  Nestled in the shadow of the picturesque southern mountain range Macgillycuddys Reeks, home to Irelands three highest peaks, Kilgarvan is little more than a blink-and-you-miss-it blip on the busy road between the tourist towns of Killarney and Kenmare: a single street, a straggle of houses, a shop, two bars, a church and a graveyard. But it became the center of an international media frenzy this winter when the local council voted to legalize drunken driving.

title: Ex-Ranger Kovalev Wants to Keep Playing
description: Alexei Kovalev, the last player still active from the Rangers 1994 Stanley Cup championship team before his retirement last week, said Sunday that he intends to play in Europe next season.

title: In Leak Case, State Secrecy in Plain Sight
description: Reporters covering the governments prosecution of Pfc. Bradley Manning, who is being court-martialed for conveying secret information to WikiLeaks, have spent a year trying to pierce the veil of secrecy in what is supposed to be a public proceeding.

title: Pension Funds Wary as Bankrupt City Goes to Trial
description: Wall Street is taking Americas biggest pension fund to court this week, for a long-awaited battle over who takes the losses when a city goes bust  workers and retirees, municipal bondholders, or both.

title: Violence Brings an Identity Crisis in a Free-Spirited California Beach Town
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.  Keep it weird? Or keep it safe and clean?

title: Successful Four-Year Run Ends in Double-Overtime Loss for St. Johns
description: The most accomplished senior class in the history of womens basketball at St. Johns suffered an agonizing end by falling to Dayton, 96-90 in double overtime, in a first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game at Carnesecca Arena.

title: Ads That Speak the Language of Social Media
description: MADISON AVENUE is offering consumers a status update on just how pervasive social media have become.

title: A Last Smile and a Wave for Bay Area Commuters
description: SAN FRANCISCO  To hear Jackie Dean tell it, it all started more than 18 years ago with her cousin Peachess beat-up Lincoln, a tip from her friend Gayle and possible betrayal by her own mother. But, really, it may have actually started back in the second grade, in Mr. Johns class, when Jackie and her classmates read the most books in their school in Oakland and won a choice of a field trip.

title: Bringing In Help, Mayor Bows Out in Style at Annual Revue
description: He has descended to the stage as Spider-Man, pretended to smoke a joint as a hippie from Hair, and offered up satirical lessons in How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.

title: Pennsylvania Study Finds Halfway Houses Dont Reduce Recidivism
description: The federal government and states across the country have spent billions of dollars in recent years on sprawling, privately run halfway houses, which are supposed to save money and rehabilitate inmates more effectively than prisons do.

title: Thrills, and Hope, on Opening Day
description: Arriving at 8:30 the night before the ride was supposed to reopen for the season, Mr. Cyclone  otherwise known as Eric Knapp, 47  had claimed the first spot in line to ride the Cyclone, Coney Islands famed wooden roller coaster, and more than 15 hours later, he was still excited. Very excited.

title: As SpinMedia, Web Firm Aims to Lift Smaller Sites
description: In the race for Internet advertising, could a few dozen runner-up blogs win in the end?

title: Hot Money Blues
description: Whatever the final outcome in the Cyprus crisis  we know its going to be ugly; we just dont know exactly what form the ugliness will take  one thing seems certain: for the time being, and probably for years to come, the island nation will have to maintain fairly draconian controls on the movement of capital in and out of the country. In fact, controls may well be in place by the time you read this. And thats not all: Depending on exactly how this plays out, Cypriot capital controls may well have the blessing of the International Monetary Fund, which has already supported such controls in Iceland.

title: Tragedies of Past Offer a Guide as Newtown Aid Goes Unspent
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  Almost as soon as the shooting stopped, the aid began. It came from groups large and small, established and impromptu.

title: Three Cheers for the Nanny State
description: Brunswick, Me.

title: Kansas Surges Past North Carolina and Williams
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  North Carolina Coach Roy Williams walked out of the tunnel last, well after his players and assistants, a police officer beside him until he reached the hardwood floor. Slowly, politely, Kansas fans at Sprint Center stood and cheered for Williams, a former Jayhawks coach.

title: ABC Creates Commercial to Save Its Happy Endings
description: The impulse among television superfans to create save our show campaigns for every imperiled sitcom and drama has been co-opted by one of the very networks that shows have to be saved from.

title: States Gone Wild
description: NO sooner had Arkansas adopted the countrys most regressive abortion law earlier this month  a ban after about 12 weeks of pregnancy  than North Dakota lowered its limit to as early as six weeks. Both measures are expected to be ruled unconstitutional, but heres my question: Is North Dakota that much more conservative than, say, South Dakota, where abortions are permitted up to 24 weeks?

title: No Longer Will News Lap at Miami Heralds Door
description: MIAMI  One Herald Plaza rises like a boxy behemoth on Biscayne Bay, an industrial-looking rectangle that is not so easy to like but hard to ignore. A fitting trait, it turns out, for a daily newspaper.

title: Kerry Appeals to Laos in Case of a Missing Man
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  On the 100th day since the disappearance of a prominent American-educated Laotian agriculture specialist, Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday urged the government here to make public the results of an investigation into what had happened to him, and to return him to his family.

title: A Magazine Article on Race Sets Off an Outcry
description: Few subjects appear to provoke from readers as much debate, and anger, as race does. Since Philadelphia Magazine published its article Being White in Philly: Whites, race, class, and the things that never get said in late February, it has drawn a public rebuke by the citys mayor, the threat of a boycott by the local African-American Chamber of Commerce and at least two forums where the magazines editor and the articles writer answered angry questions.

title: Willful Ignorance
description: Automatic spending cuts are a mindless way to budget, and they will leave the nation in the dark. Heres how: Under the cuts, the Census Bureau budget will be $845 million, well below the Obama administrations $970 million request. That will force the bureau to delay completion of the Economic Census, an immense survey done every five years that provides the benchmark measurements for economic growth and other vital indicators, including inflation and productivity. Without such data, policy makers, business leaders, investors, economists and social researchers will be at a disadvantage.

title: The Credit-History Pariah Class
description: Research has shown that someone with a poor credit history is not automatically a poor job prospect. Nevertheless, millions of Americans who have emerged from the recession with medical debts or a record of late payments are at risk of being denied jobs by companies that use credit histories to screen applicants. Several states have placed limits on this practice. But until the federal government engages the issue more aggressively, employers will consign otherwise qualified applicants to a kind of pariah class that gets shut out of the job market.

title: Is the Estate Tax Doomed?
description: Under the deal struck by President Obama and Congress to avert the fiscal cliff, the estate tax  long targeted for elimination by Republicans  survived, but in a substantially diminished form.

title: For Homesick Russian Tycoon, Instant of Ruin Came in Court
description: LONDON  The moment of ruin for Boris A. Berezovsky, the exiled Russian oligarch who was found dead on Saturday outside London, came not when he fell out with the Kremlin, or when his latest long-term relationship broke up, or even when Russia sentenced him to prison in absentia.

title: Justices to Look at Deals by Generic and Branded Drug Makers
description: WASHINGTON  Just about anyone who has gone to a pharmacy and paid for a prescription knows that a generic copy costs much less than the brand-name drug. The makers of those two versions of a drug, therefore, usually compete fiercely for market share and profits.

title: Time to Strengthen Family Immigration
description: The momentum in Washington for immigration reform has been growing with amazing speed in recent weeks, and it seems that the question now is not whether Congress will try to fix the immigration system this year, but how big and effective the repairs will be. We hope that whatever bill emerges will continue to protect and unite families, preserving and strengthening a bedrock value of Americas immigration system.

title: Wichita State Put Attitude on Display Against Gonzaga
description: SALT LAKE CITY

title: Europe Caps Bank Bonuses
description: European policy makers are imposing new restrictions on bonuses paid to bankers in an attempt to reduce incentives that encourage them to take imprudent risks. Unfortunately, the rule is unlikely to make bank executives and financial traders more accountable or the financial system more sound.

title: Academic Filmmaking for Profit
description: Venture philanthropy? Social entrepreneurship? Robert L. Bassett, dean of the Dodge College of Film and Media Arts at Chapman University in Orange County, Calif., said he still wasnt sure how to label it.

description: To the Editor:

title: E.U. Officials Agree to a Deal Rescuing Cyprus
description: BRUSSELS  Struggling into the early-morning hours to avoid a collapse of Cypruss banking system, European Union leaders on Monday agreed on a bailout package intended to keep Cyprus in the euro zone and rebuild its devastated economy.

title: 2 Rivals Complicate Deal for Dell
description: Two rival bids for Dell Inc. have emerged, threatening to complicate or change  or upend  an effort to take the embattled computer maker private in a $24 billion deal under the leadership of Michael S. Dell.

description: In weighing a bid for The Los Angeles Times, Rupert Murdoch finds himself in a familiar role: waiting for rule changes from the government. With the resignation last week of Julius Genachowski, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, he may have to wait a little longer.

title: New Efforts to Make a Scenic California Highway Less Perilous
description: PACIFICA, Calif.  After a half-century of debate, motorists early Tuesday will be able to drive onto a bridge suspended 300 feet above land and through a tunnel dug into a verdant mountain 20 miles south of San Francisco. The federally financed $439 million project skirts the treacherous Devils Slide slice of California Highway 1 in one of the most scenic stretches of highway in the world.

title: An Ex-Gambler Weighs the Cost of Addiction
description: Sure he knows when he made his last wager, Stephen M. Block said. It was on May 10, 1975, a lifetime ago.

description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Florida has proved equal parts fragile and unflinching this season, frittering away tight games that a program of its stature is expected to dominate or handing opponents demoralizing defeats.

description: LOS ANGELES  If ever there were a Cinderella of tech, Sophia Amoruso might be it.

title: This Time, Paul Is Winner in Point Guard Battle
description: PHOENIX  Whether the Nets are beating bad teams and losing to better opponents, feasting on the Eastern Conference while struggling against teams in the West, matchups have often dictated results in the teams inaugural season in Brooklyn. In the Nets 101-95 loss to the Los Angeles Clippers, the matchup theme unfolded in a variety of interesting battles on the court, like a series of skits in a Saturday night showcase.

title: NBC Risks Its Late-Night Dominance With a Tonight Gamble
description: The Green Bay Packers had a long, successful run with Brett Favre until they decided in 2008 that it was time to give the quarterback job to a rising talent  Aaron Rodgers  even though the future Hall of Famer was still winning games. Now NBC is following the same script in another hugely competitive arena: late-night television.

title: Arms Airlift to Syria Rebels Expands, With Aid From C.I.A.
description: With help from the C.I.A., Arab governments and Turkey have sharply increased their military aid to Syrias opposition fighters in recent months, expanding a secret airlift of arms and equipment for the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, according to air traffic data, interviews with officials in several countries and the accounts of rebel commanders.

title: Womens N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 24
description: In the second full day of womens games, No. 14 Albany gave No. 3 North Carolina a scare and No. 10 St. Johns fell to No. 7 Dayton in double overtime.

title: Luring Young Web Warriors Is Priority. Its Also a Game.
description: WASHINGTON  In the eighth grade, Arlan Jaska figured out how to write a simple script that could switch his keyboards Caps Lock key on and off 6,000 times a minute. When friends werent looking, he slipped his program onto their computers. It was all fun and games until the program spread to his middle school.

title: As Chicagos Wait for Rose Continues, Weight Grows Heavier
description: CHICAGO  When Derrick Rose sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in the first round of last years N.B.A. playoffs, Chicago Bulls fans immediately began counting the days until his return. Eleven months later, they are still counting, but are also fully engaged in hand-wringing, anxious uncertainty and perhaps even prayer as the waiting continues and Roses return this season is no longer a question of when, but if.

title: An Arms Pipeline to the Syrian Rebels
description: More than 160 military cargo flights for Syrias rebels, mostly from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, have landed in Turkey and Jordan since January 2012.

title: Bebo Valds, a Force in World of Cuban Music, Dies at 94
description: Bebo Valds, a pianist, arranger and composer who was a musical lightning rod in Havana during the evolution of the mambo and, after a long fallow period, a million-selling success in his last two decades, died on Friday in Stockholm, his primary residence since 1963. He was 94.

title: A Human Touch
description: On Wednesday, Jackie Dean, who began working on the Golden Gate Bridge 18 years ago, will be one of more than two dozen toll collectors who will be replaced by a completely automated system.

title: 15th Seed Makes Round of 16 for First Time
description: PHILADELPHIA  After pregame player introductions, Florida Gulf Coasts Sherwood Brown began to dance as his teammates, their arms interlocked, spun in a circle around him, their speed building and building until they broke apart and scattered.

title: Ray Williams Dies at 58; Itinerant in Pros and Life
description: Ray Williams could seemingly do it all on a basketball court. He had an outstanding shooting touch, he possessed superb body control, and he could make a timely pass. He teamed with Micheal Ray Richardson in the Knicks backcourt to dazzle the crowds at Madison Square Garden in the late 1970s and early 80s.

title: Malachi Throne, Actor on TV, Dies at 84
description: Malachi Throne, a character actor best known for playing Robert Wagners boss on the ABC spy series It Takes a Thief and a villain on Batman, died on March 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Gaining Point Eases the Sting of a Loss
description: Going into Sundays game against the Washington Capitals, Henrik Lundqvist had won 44 shootouts, more than any other N.H.L. goalie, and his .765 save percentage was better than that of any goalie who had been in 20 or more shootouts.

title: James Herbert, British Horror Novelist, Dies at 69
description: James Herbert, a British novelist who wrote supernatural thrillers and horror stories and whose menagerie of marauding rats, serial killers, evil spirits, ghosts and ghost hunters filled books that sold millions of copies and frightened readers around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Sussex, England. He was 69.

title: Cal Whipple, 94, Dies; Won 1943 Fight to Print Photo of War Dead
description: A. B. C. Whipple held high posts in the Time-Life publishing empire and wrote extensively about the sea. But he counted among his proudest achievements the role of tenacious young intermediary in a fight by Life magazine against the military censorship of a single photograph during World War II  a fight that went all the way to the White House.

title: Eddie Bond, Elvis Contemporary, Dies at 79
description: Eddie Bond, a rockabilly singer and radio host who once told a teenage Elvis Presley that he would be better off driving a truck than trying to make it in music, died on Wednesday at his home in Bolivar, Tenn. He was 79.

title: Pushed to the End, Miami Finds Its Rhythm and Holds Off Illinois
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The Miami Hurricanes start four seniors, and their lone underclassman, the sophomore guard Shane Larkin, happens to be the Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year.

title: What Causes Hearing Loss
description: Noise, not age is the leading cause of hearing loss. Unless you take steps now to protect to your ears, sooner or later many of you  and your children  will have difficulty understanding even ordinary speech.

title: Infants Are Fed Solid Food Too Soon, C.D.C. Finds
description: Despite growing warnings from pediatricians about feeding newborns anything other than breast milk or formula, many mothers appear to be introducing solid food well before their babies bodies can handle it, says a study published Monday in the journal Pediatrics.

title: Pro-Obama Group Enters Immigration Fray
description: WASHINGTON  Organizing for Action, the political group that grew out of President Obamas successful re-election campaign machinery, will jump into the immigration debate this week with an aggressive online effort to highlight the personal stories of immigrants.

title: Sounders Have Found Something in Yedlin
description: When Major League Soccer created the homegrown player rule in 2008, it was an attempt to offer an incentive for teams to invest in youth development by allowing clubs to directly sign their academy players instead of having them go potentially to other teams through the SuperDraft.

description: optician \p-ti-shn\ noun

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) 180 DAYS: A YEAR INSIDE AN AMERICAN HIGH SCHOOL This two-part report follows a year in the life of the first graduating class of Washington Metropolitan High School in the District of Columbia, a public school where only 7 percent of students are deemed proficient in math and 19 percent in reading. Still, its outspoken young principal, Tanishia Williams Minor, remains optimistic that her charges will succeed despite low test scores and numerous personal and academic obstacles. Among the students are Raven Coston, 17, above, who was displaced from New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina and is raising a baby and working part time; Raven Quattlebaum, 18, who grew up in foster care and spent her days robbing and assaulting people before becoming determined to go to college; Rufus McDowney, 16, who has been in and out of the juvenile justice system for three years; Tiara Parker, 18, an aspirational senior who maybe not be able to afford college; and Delaunte Bennett, 18, a sophomore who was kicked out of several schools because of fighting and now lags two years behind his peers.

title: Mother of 4 Is Said to Be 110th Tibetan to Self-Immolate
description: BEIJING  A mother of four, Kal Kyi, set fire to herself on Sunday afternoon in Aba, a Tibetan area of Sichuan Province in China, becoming the 110th Tibetan to self-immolate in protest over Chinese rule since 2009, according to a report on an India-based Tibetan Web site, Phayul.com.

title: Nets Regain Their Road Momentum
description: PHOENIX  One team was missing its sweet-shooting guard. The other got an unexpected explosion from an erratic shooting guard of the same surname. With the Nets Joe Johnson sidelined, a 3-point barrage  four in the final 2 minutes 12 seconds of the third quarter  from Wesley Johnson helped Phoenix erase a 16-point third-quarter deficit.

description: PHILADELPHIA  It seemed perfectly appropriate for Dukes Tyler Thornton to bank in a 3-pointer at the halftime buzzer. It was that kind of game Sunday night at Wells Fargo Center. Lots of inartistic shooting. Lots of fouls. Lots of floor burns and whistles. So many whistles.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: What Are You Doing to Fix Indias Broken Education System?
description: It is now almost four years since I first walked through a series of winding by-lanes in a Mumbai slum toward my new job as a teacher at a low-income school. I was forced to confront Indias educational inequities squarely in the eye. Students filed into a dilapidated old school building, and my own musty classroom, crammed with cupboards, barely left any room to move.

description: In Jerusalems Old City, priests and others carried palm fronds early Sunday at the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, believed by many to be the site of the crucifixion and burial of Jesus Christ.

title: Indias Rotten Diplomacy in Sri Lanka Breeds Loathing
description: As a rule, living in Sri Lanka means encountering some of the friendliest people on earth. But since the civil war ended in 2009, it must be said, there is a startlingly consistent loathing for India, and a doubled such loathing for Tamils from India. This manifests all in the abstract, for the most part, but it is there nonetheless.

description: Its another typical day: theres a commute, work, people in the street; its been done before, and it can be expected to happen again tomorrow. But for Stephen McLaren, these seemingly humdrum routines are packed with weirdness.

description: The United States national team arrived in Mexico City on Sunday without midfielder Jermaine Jones, who returned home to Germany to nurse a foot injury that will keep him out of Tuesday nights World Cup qualifier against Mexico.

description: Chip Brown, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of this weeks cover story about Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. Brown last wrote for the magazine about the oil boom in North Dakota.

title: The Man Behind Putin
description: MOSCOW  The oligarch Boris Berezovsky, who died near London on Saturday, would have enjoyed watching Russians react to his death. He reportedly suffered from depression in the last few months of his life, and I know he was plagued by the nagging sense that he could no longer make himself relevant to Russian politics. Not only has his death dominated every media outlet and every conversation in Moscow, but President Vladimir Putins press secretary, Dmitri Peskov, stated that Berezovsky wrote to Putin a couple of months ago asking forgiveness and requesting permission to return to the motherland.

title: Britain Pledges to Curtail Benefits for Immigrants
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron promised more stringent rules Monday to reduce outsiders access to social, health and housing benefits, reflecting a fraught debate in Britain over the potential impact of increased immigration from southeast Europe that could fuel a rightist threat to his Conservative Party.

title: Karzai Has Nothing but Praise for U.S. Upon Bagram Prison Transfer
description: BAGRAM, Afghanistan  Within hours of the American militarys formally transferring all but a small number of the Afghan prisoners at the Bagram Prison to the Afghan government, President Hamid Karzai held a friendly news conference with Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday that stood in stark contrast to his recent acrimonious tone toward the United States.

title: 10 Ways to Teach the Joys of Spring
description: Visit the City Room blogs 2012 Spring Time series, which tracked the season in a patch of Staten Island forest. Above, photographs show the changes from Week 1 to Week 14.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Murdoch Weighs a Newspaper Deal and Steve Harvey Surprises Daytime TV
description: Rupert Murdoch finds himself in a familiar predicament as he considers a bid for The Los Angeles Times: awaiting rule changes from the government, Amy Chozick reports. Mr. Murdoch has increased his lobbying efforts to revise a media ownership rule that prevents companies from owning both television stations and newspapers in the same local market (News Corporation owns KTTV and KCOP in the Los Angeles area). Mr. Murdoch has given mixed signals about his interest in The Los Angeles Times, which the Tribune Company plans to sell. The resignation last week of the Federal Communications Commission chairman, Julius Genachowski, could further slow the process. Mr. Genachowski had proposed allowing a rule change to allow a single company to own both a TV station and newspaper in a top-20 market provided the station was not in the top four in audience size.

title: Ego, Image, and Sin
description: The excellent Kathleen Geier  give this woman a bigger job!  has a terrific piece on pundit sins in the runup to the Iraq war, which has applicability to lots of other issues too.

description: Richard Schulze, who explored and then abandoned a possible buyout bid for Best Buy, is returning to the electronics chain he founded.

description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The disappointment spread plainly across Pedro Felicianos face and flattened his voice as he spoke.

title: Leading Off: An Injection of Joy
description: They have sprung to life like bright flowers in a desert, their sheer exuberance breaking the bleak landscape around them. The Florida Gulf Coast players laugh. They do the chicken dance. They throw preposterous passes for alley-oop dunks in the tense moments of games. They celebrate like this moment is all that matters, the only one guaranteed them, or any of us. And we laugh along with them. Because we can. And we should. Its as if they were dialed up by the sporting gods for this N.C.A.A. tournament to remind us this is supposed to be fun. This is what joy looks like.

title: Producers and Set Designer to Get Lifetime Achievement Tonys
description: The theater producers Bernard Gersten and Paul Libin and the set designer Ming Cho Lee will receive lifetime achievement honors at this years Tony Awards, the organizers of the event have announced.

title: After Doping Ban, Odesnik Focuses on Second Phase of Career
description: When the International Tennis Federation announced this month that it was advancing its drug-testing protocols to incorporate the biological passport program, Wayne Odesnik, one of the sports most notorious names, advanced through the draw at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif.

title: Evaluating the Odds for Florida Gulf Coast and the Rest of the Final 16 Teams
description: The story of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament is Florida Gulf Coast University, which on Sunday became the first No. 15 seed ever to reach the Round of 16, despite having become a full Division I member only last season. Just how unlikely was its accomplishment? Does the team have a chance of advancing much further? And what about the other teams in the Round of 16?

title: Rival Bids for Dell
description: | RIVAL BIDS FOR DELL The bidding war for Dell is heating up. The computer maker confirmed on Monday that it had received preliminary takeover proposals by the private equity giant Blackstone Group and the investor Carl C. Icahn. As expected, the companys special committee determined that both proposals could reasonably be expected to result in superior proposals and intended to keep negotiating with Blackstone and Mr. Icahn, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced reports.

title: Really? The Claim: The Flu Shot Can Worsen Asthma
description: THE FACTS

title: Can Earth Hour Help Save the Planet?
description: THE HAGUE  Camera, lights off, action!

title: After Conquering Snow, U.S. Now Faces Altitude
description: MEXICO CITY  The Iditarod will not break out here Tuesday when the United States faces Mexico in a World Cup qualifying match. There will be a significant increase in elevation, smog and opponents skill level. But snowplows will not be on standby at Estadio Azteca. The only white stuff likely to fall is confetti.

title: Now Showing | The Abraham Archives
description: Though Paris was undisputedly the world capital of fashion in the immediate postwar period, one of its more important, if lesser-known, suburbs was Zurich, the home of the exclusive textile firm Abraham, which kept the couture houses of Christian Dior, Hubert de Givenchy, Cristbal Balenciaga et al supplied with intricately printed, ultraluxurious Lyon silk. Abraham and its creative director, Gustave Zemsteg, who called on artist friends like Joan Miro and Marc Chagall to design prints, are the subjects of a new exhibition at Antwerps Mode Museum. Zemstegs most fruitful partnership was with his close friend Yves Saint Laurent, whom he met at the funeral of another client, Christian Dior. I wouldnt call their correspondence love letters, but they are certainly affectionate, says the shows curator, Karen Van Godtsenhoven. It was a friendship as well as a business relationship. Saint Laurent, then the newly appointed Dior heir, went on to use Abraham silk throughout his career; his last couture collection, in 2002, was the firms death knell. Faced with a dwindling market for its ultra-upscale fabrics, it closed its doors and donated its meticulous archive to the Swiss National Museum. The bold flower prints, the fabrics with gold  what they did was incredibly opulent, Van Godtsenhoven says.

title: Cyprus Losses, European Gains
description: An American University professor of international finance discusses how a deal to aid Cyprus will affect the global market.

title: Dont Mention the Flimflam
description: Ed Kilgore points us to a Politico piece on Paul Ryans apparently declining profile, and has fun mocking the writing. Indeed, the piece is written as if it were a teen magazine discussing Justin Bieber.

title: Anthony Lewis, Supreme Court Reporter Who Brought Law to Life, Dies at 85
description: Anthony Lewis, a former New York Times reporter and columnist whose work won two Pulitzer Prizes and transformed American legal journalism, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.

title: Supreme Court Takes New Case on Affirmative Action, From Michigan
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday added a new affirmative action case to its docket. It is already considering a major challenge to the University of Texas race-conscious admissions program.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Atlantic: Behold: the radish as an aphrodisiac (and you thought you were tired of reading about root vegetables).  Melissa Clark

title: Write a Short Story With Kate Atkinson!
description: 1:39 p.m. | Updated  Read the full story below.

title: Tracking Your Finances, One Number at a Time
description: I think its true that if I want to improve my performance in something, I need to measure and track it. As Thomas Monson, an author and president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, said: When performance is measured, performance improves. When performance is measured and reported back, the rate of improvement accelerates.

title: Was Lincoln a Tyrant?
description: When Abraham Lincoln took office in March 1861, the executive branch was small and relatively limited in its power. By the time of his assassination, he had claimed more prerogatives than any president before him, and the executive branch had grown enormously.

title: In Death as in Life, Berezovsky Remains a Puzzle
description: In death as in life, Boris A. Berezovsky, the former tycoon who amassed billions of dollars and enormous political influence in post-Soviet Russia, remained true to Winston Churchills depiction of his land as the supreme enigma.

title: What You Need to Know About Credit Card Processing
description: Starting on Tuesday morning, I am going to publish a series of posts about my search for an honest and affordable processor of credit card transactions. It was not an easy search, but I learned a lot  much of which I never wanted to know but some of which I think may be helpful to other business owners.

title: Building a Better Sandwich
description: Health professionals, scientists, and chefs all agree that the American diet is short on vegetables. They are working together to address the problem, which is at the heart of the health and obesity crisis facing our country. A couple of weeks ago I brought you burgers that were made with a mix of meat and vegetables. What I didnt talk about was how you could build on that burger, with layers of different lettuces, tomatoes, peppers, onions, pickles and even cooked greens.

title: Going to Tehran
description: To the Editor:

title: Know When to Hold Em: Making Family Time Work for Teens
description: When my children were little, it was easy to create connected family time. I called it incubation, when wed shut out the rest of the world and go off on our own, just the kids and my husband and me. Wed make a plan, pack up some snacks, load everyone in the car or strollers, and head out to some near or far-off state park or nature area, where we could run, play, climb and be as loud as a family of six people is sometimes wont to be.

title: Nissan Recalls NV Commercial Vans for Transmission Shifter
description: Nissan is recalling all the NV commercial vans it built for the last two years because of a problem with the automatic transmission shifter, according to a report from the automaker posted on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Starbucks Is Headed for the Port Authority
description: They may have to rename it the Port Authority Buzz Terminal.

title: At High-Priced Corner, a Building Forlorn
description: The corner of Christopher Street and Waverly Place, in the heart of Greenwich Village, is one of the most sought after slices of Manhattan. The stoops are tidy, the restaurants are lavish and a town house down the block sold last year for $11.5 million.

title: Anna Quindlen and Andrew Solomon Join Discussion About Media and Transgender Children
description: My blog post last week  about Coy Mathis, the 6-year-old transgender Colorado child  drew some strong responses from readers. On Twitter, I immediately heard from those who sharply questioned my suggestion that the willingness of the child be considered, along with parental approval, in deciding to name her and use photographs of her. As many of these critics (some of whom were parents) noted, young children are willing to do many things they might regret later; they dont have the maturity to know how their actions will play out.

title: Image of the Day: March 25
Mushroom Melt With Parsley Pesto, Kale and Arugula
description: This vegetarian sandwich can be made in the oven, a toaster or in a panini grill. I use the toaster.

title: The Gun Report: March 25, 2013
description: The new meme among gun absolutists appears to be hammers. Why did you elect to report on guns as a choice of weapon, when according to current F.B.I. stats, bear claw hammers and baseball bats are the number 1 and number 2 choice of weapon? wrote a pro-gun reader: Guns are 3rd.When I was interviewing Second Amendment absolutists for Saturdays column, I heard the same thing. So of course, Jennifer Mascia and I looked into it.Guess what?It doesnt appear to be true, as Slate reported in February. According to F.B.I. data, if you add up all the non-gun methods used to kill people in 2011 (fire, drowning, poison, strangling, hammers, etc.), you get 4,081 non-gun homicides. Thats fewer than half of the F.B.I.s reported 8,583 gun homicides in 2011. Guns killed more than 17 times more people than hammers and are responsible for nearly 70 percent of total murders. Indeed, Slate reported, only 496 people were killed by blunt objects, a category that includes not just hammers and baseball bats but crowbars, rocks, paving stones, statuettes, and electric guitars.

title: Attorney General Picks Ex-Bloomberg Aide to Be Chief of Staff
description: ALBANY  The state attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has hired a former aide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to serve as his chief of staff.

title: Companies Get Strict on Health of Workers
description: Employers are increasingly trying to lower health care costs by using incentives to persuade workers to make better lifestyle choices, a new survey shows, but what remains less clear is whether a reward is better than a punishment  or whether the programs work at all.

title: Zimbabwe: Human Rights Lawyer Released From Jail
description: JOHANNESBURG  After more than a week in jail, the human rights lawyer Beatrice Mtetwa was released Monday after a high court judge overruled a lower courts decision that she be held without bail on a charge of obstruction of justice.

title: Hong Kong Court Denies Residency to Domestics
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kongs highest court ruled unanimously on Monday that a woman from the Philippines who had lived and worked here for nearly 27 years as a domestic helper was not entitled to permanent residency, ending an acrimonious legal fight over the immigration rights of migrant workers.

title: A Breakup Letter From My Chemical Romance
description: My Chemical Romance  a band known for its dense, intensely strained instrumental textures, darkly poetic if often mysterious lyrics and elaborately theatrical performance style  announced its breakup on Friday evening after a 12-year career that produced four highly regarded studio albums (most notably The Black Parade) as well as two live discs and a handful of EPs.

title: Breaking It Down: Isner Vs. Dodig
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.The beauty of tennis is that there are so many different ways to win a match.

title: The Improbable Life of Paul Erds
description: This week we celebrate the life ofthe most published mathematician in history, Paul Erdos (AIR-dosh), who was born 100 years ago on March 26. Dr.Erdos, who has been called the worlds greatest problem poser and solver, collaborated with over 500 mathematicians before his death in 1996.

title: Sending a Message for Backpedaling on Settlements
description: When a company accepts a deferred prosecution agreement to resolve a criminal investigation, one requirement is that it cannot backtrack on an admission of guilt. Standard Chartered learned the hard way that prosecutors take these agreements quite seriously when an executive tries to soft-pedal any corporate wrongdoing.

title: BioShocks Latest: Civil War in a City in the Sky
description: During the long development of BioShock Infinite  the first release by the Massachusetts studio Irrational Games since the original BioShock transfixed players more than five years ago  there were open fears on blogs, in discussion forums and in conversations among video game journalists that the new BioShock game just wouldnt be any good.

title: Single-Serving Wine for Sipping Small
description: Buy me some pinot and Cracker Jack! Pinot grigio, California merlot, cabernet sauvignon and chardonnay are now sold in sealed single-serve plastic goblets. Next month, Zipz, the company behind this new format, will introduce them at baseball stadiums, including Citi Field (hear that, Mets fans?), and at wine shops.

title: Street Style: Boyfriend Jeans
description: The best of readers photos from the week of March 18.

title: Spotify, New to Advertising, Says Ive Got the Music in Me
description: The field of digital music services is getting as crowded as CBGB was when the Ramones played. So major competitors are spending large sums on advertising campaigns that are meant to generate awareness, consideration and trial.

title: The Hotel del Coronados Past Lives
description: As anyone whos walked the grounds of the famed Hotel del Coronado knows all too well, the past has a way of catching up with you. Theres the ghost of Kate Morgan, whose dead body was found on Nov. 29, 1892, five days after shed checked in under the alias Lottie A. Bernard. The San Diego coroner ultimately determined that the gunshot wound to her head was self-inflicted. Today, those who stay in her room (3327, previously No. 302)  the most requested one in the hotel  continue to report paranormal activity, including a television set that randomly turns on. Ms. Morgan is not the only famous name on the hotels guest register. Previous guests have included Frank Sinatra, Lucille Ball, Desi Arnaz, Charlie Chaplin, Charles Lindbergh and Marilyn Monroe, whose film Some Like It Hot, was shot here. This year, the hotel celebrates its 125th anniversary with a series of events and a new commemorative book, Hotel del Coronado History.

title: Drone Disdain
description: Each time a reporter or an elected official questions the Obama administration about its theory that the president may order the killing of an American citizen that he considers an actual or even potential terrorist threat, the same thing happens. The administration reacts with ill-concealed disdain.

title: Paul Rose, Quebec Separatist Involved in Kidnapping, Dies at 69
description: Paul Rose, a strident Quebec separatist leader who in October 1970 helped kidnap and, he claimed, strangle a provincial official, inflaming a crisis that pitted terrorists against the Canadian prime minister, Pierre Trudeau, died on March 14 in Montreal. He was 69.

title: Cornell Wrestler Savors 4th Title in 4th Weight Class
description: By winning the 165-pound weight class at the N.C.A.A. wrestling championships in Des Moines over the weekend, Kyle Dake became the first collegiate wrestler to win four national titles in four weight classes and the third to win four titles over all.

title: Q. and A.: A Decisive Moment on Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear an hourlong argument on Tuesday morning over the constitutionality of Proposition 8, Californias ban on same-sex marriage. Here is a look at the background of the case, Hollingsworth v. Perry, No. 12-144; the issues it raises; the lawyers who will argue it; and the possible outcomes.

title: Obama Presides Over Swearing In New Americans
description: President Obama presided over a ceremony swearing in new American citizens at the White House on Monday as part of his pitch for legislation that would overhaul the nations immigration laws.

title: Indian Car Ad Goes Viral, Not in a Good Way
description: Perhaps putting the maxim that there is no such thing as bad publicity to a new test, Ford Motor Company was forced to apologize Monday for an ad posted online last week promoting its Indian hatchback with a cartoon showing three bound and gagged women in the rear of a vehicle driven by Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister.

title: Worries Over Violence Prompt Shutdown in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  A major commercial area of Yangon, Myanmars largest city, shut down on Monday after rumors spread there of sectarian attacks on Muslims. The shutdown reflected the nervous mood in the country after deadly rioting last week by Buddhist mobs.

title: Cyprus Rescue Deal Addresses Important Principles
description: Cypruss economy is going to suffer terribly in the next few years. Some of that is inevitable given how bloated its banking system has become. But the disastrous handling of the crisis, especially in the last week, will make things much worse.

title: Advice to Researchers and Reanimating Dead Mice
description: BOOK

title: Supreme Court Preview
description: The Timess Adam Liptak lays out the key issues in the same-sex marriage cases this week.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: New Suitors for Dell Raise Specter of Founders Loss
description: 8:43 p.m. | Updated

title: Best N.B.A.Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble highlights three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: In an Area Plagued by Violence, a God Squad Hits the Streets
description: The Rev. Gilford Monrose was asleep in his Brooklyn apartment on March 9, when a text message from another pastor knocked him from his slumber: BROOKLYN: *POLICE SHOOTING* E52 ST X SNYDER AVE, LEVEL 1 MOBILIZATION CALLED. It was 11:39 p.m., and Mr. Monrose was about to begin the most trying week of his life.

title: House of Cards Episode 10, the Recap: Frank Forgets How to Count and Peter Tumbles
description: We are now officially headed toward end-of-season recess on House of Cards and Ashley Parker and David Carr take a look at episode 10. If you like reading their take on the political and media dimensions of the rest of the season, you can find episode one, two,three, four, five, six,seven , eight or nine here. Spoilers are thicker than plots on House of Cards, so consider yourself warned.

title: Chinas Leader Tries to Calm African Fears of His Countrys Economic Power
description: HONG KONG  Chinas new president, Xi Jinping, sought to assure African countries on Monday that his government would heed complaints that relentlessly competitive Chinese companies were suffocating African efforts to nurture industry and jobs, and he promised aid, scholarships and technology transfers in an effort to counter those fears.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Paul Caine joined Dial Global, New York, a radio syndication company, as chief executive. He succeeds Spencer Brown, who is leaving, the company said. Mr. Caine had been executive vice president and president for advertising, as well as chief revenue officer, at Time Inc., New York, part of Time Warner.

title: The Flick Prompts an Explanation From Playwrights Horizons
description: The artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, a leading Off Broadway company that produces new American plays, took the unusual step on Saturday of e-mailing 3,000 of the theaters subscribers to explain his decision to produce Annie Bakers new play The Flick, whose three-hour length and periods of long silence have infuriated some audience members.

title: MTV Video Music Awards Show Coming to Brooklyn
description: Some things just get better when they move to Brooklyn  Walt Whitman; Arthur Miller; the former New Jersey Nets  and MTV is hoping that one of its signature institutions will benefit from the aura exuded by the borough of Spike Lee, Chris Rock, Coney Island and artisanal pickles. On Monday the network said that its 2013 MTV Video Music Awards will be held on Aug. 25 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, marking the 30th year of that program, which in recent years has been held either in Manhattan or Los Angeles.

title: New Roku Box Makes Streaming TV Even Easier
description: Rokus new streaming media player, the Roku 3, looks remarkably like its predecessors: a hockey puck. Instead of upgrading the appearance, the company has improved the way the device works, while keeping the price at $100.

title: Temp Tee Urges Shoppers to Whip Up Passover Dishes
description: Decades ago, ads pitched Geritol tonic as the cure for tired blood. Now, a dairy product is being proposed as the antidote to matzah fatigue. Matzah fatigue could be classified as among Passover problems, the puzzles that perplex Jews who celebrate the eight-day holiday, which begins at sunset on Monday. It is a fanciful expression, to be sure, but it does address what is, for many, an issue each year: Around the third day, the palate often begins to rebel against a steady diet of foods that are kosher for Passover like matzah, the unleavened bread also known as matzo or matzoh.

title: First Hint of Spring Links
description: Diet News: The Mediterranean diet is not just good for your health, but also improves food security. Is there nothing this way of eating cant do? Less encouraging is that Mississippi, the most obese state in the nation, is banning Bloomberg-style portion control. No, really the bill is called the The Anti-Bloomberg Bill.

title: To Whom It May Concern
description: Q. Do the spacecraft we have sent to investigate the universe carry any identification of their human and earthly origin?

title: Swinton Under Glass: New Offering From MoMA
description: Among the second-floor contemporary-art galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, visitors on Monday were happening upon an unexpected sight: the actress Tilda Swinton lying on a mattress in a glass box, apparently asleep. Ms. Swinton, an Oscar winner for the 2007 film Michael Clayton, has brought her performance piece The Maybe to MoMA, 18 years after she first performed it for a week in the Serpentine Gallery in London.

title: Dining Calendar
description: At Brushstroke, 30 Hudson Street in TriBeCa, Isao Yamada, the chef, and Eric Hastings, the sommelier, are putting together an eight-course tasting menu for dinner on Wednesday that includes old-world wines and artisanal sake. The meal is $250 per person, and reservations can be made online.

title: Free Checking Still Widespread at Credit Unions
description: Nearly three-quarters of the countrys largest credit unions still offer no-strings-attached free checking accounts, a new report from Bankrate.com finds.

title: A Sea Change in Less Than 50 Years as Gay Rights Gained Momentum
description: WASHINGTON  The struggle for African-Americans rights, symbolized by the bloody 1965 Selma march, is as old as the nation. The effort for American womens rights began at Seneca Falls, N.Y., more than 150 years ago.

title: Scalias Gay Marriage Problem
description: With the Supreme Court set to hear oral arguments tomorrow and Wednesday in a pair of same-sex marriage cases, there are two questions preoccupying legal writers: How will Justice Anthony Kennedy, the courts wild card, vote, and how will Justice Antonin Scalia behave?

title: Chandler Practices, a Little, and Eyes Knicks Return
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Tyson Chandler spent a few minutes on the court Monday morning, practicing post defense and testing his sore neck. But it was for only a few minutes.

title: An Old Prescription for Sour Faces
description: When the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus made its first appearance at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last week, it marked a return to the borough where it was born in the 19th century. The circus revived another tradition on Monday, when it staged a performance for young patients, staff members and other guests at the Brooklyn Hospital Center.

title: Leader of Central African Republic Fled to Cameroon, Official Says
description: JOHANNESBURG  A day after being ousted by rebel forces, President Franois Boziz of the Central African Republic surfaced in Cameroon on Monday, according to a statement read on state radio by a senior Cameroonian official. He will remain there until he finds a more permanent refuge, said the official, Ferdinand Ngoh Ngoh.

title: Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis Knocks at Australias Door
description: Australias first death from XDR-TB  extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, which is nearly incurable  has alarmed health officials and added new heat to a debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous diseases. That debate echoes one on the United States southern border.

title: The Secret May Be in the Coffee
description: People who live on the Greek island of Ikaria are known to have remarkably high life expectancies, and researchers have been studying them carefully to learn why. Now a new report suggests that one reason may be the coffee they drink.

title: Malaysia to Relocate Residents of Contested Areas
description: MANILA   The Malaysian authorities will resettle residents of remote coastal areas near the southern Philippines amid fighting that has killed more than 70 people, officials said Monday.

title: Made in L.A. | Modernism at Sunset
description: A residence made mostly of glass and wood, surrounded by trees, tucked neatly behind a modernist building. The interior designer and writer David Netto leads a tour of the VDL Research House, the former home and studio of Richard Neutra located on Silver Lake boulevard in Los Angeles. Netto describes Neutra, the architect originally from Austria, as the shaper of the future of California, and demonstrates how the house reflects the architects point of view.

title: Portmans Son Describes Personal Side of Senators Shift on Same-Sex Marriage
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated When Senator Rob Portman, the Ohio Republican, announced his support for same-sex marriage, he said his sons admission that he was gay prompted the change of heart. But the timeline left some puzzled: If the son, Will, came out two years ago, why did the senators announcement come 10 days ago?

title: Is It Ever O.K. for Christian Kids to Have a Bar Mitzvah?
description: In this weeks Riff essay, Maud Newton writes about the popularity of traditional Jewish rituals among American evangelical Christians  specifically, but not limited to, holding bar mitzvahs for their kids. Here, in a bonus to Riff, Newton explains a bit of her own back story and provides further explanation of this curious, and controversial, phenomenon. Newton has previously written Riff essays on the lingering linguistic influence of David Foster Wallace and the best-selling book Heaven Is Real.

title: A Clearer View of the Space Bullet That Grazed Russia
description: Using an eclectic mix of crowd-sourced video, information from Google Earth and data from nuclear test-ban sensors, scientists have gotten a much more accurate picture of the small asteroid that exploded near the Russian city of Chelyabinsk last month.

title: Prisoner X of Israel Is Said to Have Exposed Top Spies
description: JERUSALEM  Israel has revealed very little about the man known as Prisoner X, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed here in 2010 after apparently getting caught in a web of espionage and intrigue, other than how he died: alone, by asphyxiation, after hanging himself in the shower of his cell.

title: Photo Replay: March 25
description: A view of the day in sports, including a car rally in Saudi Arabia and Tiger Woods at Bay Hill.

title: Decoded: Steve Harveys Daytime Success
description: The Timess Brian Stelter decodes Steve Harveys talk show success.

title: Tibetan Mother of 4 Self-Immolates to Protest Chinese Rule
description: A Tibetan mother of four killed herself by self-immolation on Sunday to protest Chinese rule, according to a report on Monday by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government. The report said Kalkyi, 30, set fire to herself near a monastery in the county of Dzamthang in Ngaba Prefecture, which has been a focal point of the wave of Tibetan self-immolations that began in 2009. At least 110 people in Tibetan regions of China have set fire to themselves, and the vast majority have died. Ms. Kalkyis self-immolation took place around 3:30 p.m. Sunday, and her body was taken by locals to the Jonang monastery, according to Radio Free Asia, which cited sources inside Tibet. Ms. Kalkyi had three sons and one daughter, all under the age of 15. Radio Free Asia said that Ms. Kalkyi was the 16th woman to self-immolate since 2009. On March 13, a woman, Konchog Wangmo, 31, killed herself by self-immolation in Ngaba Prefecture, and her husband, Drolma Kyab, was later detained by the authorities, the news service reported.

title: Bankia Stock Value Is Nearly Wiped Out Under Recapitalization Plan
description: MADRID  Shares in Bankia, the giant Spanish mortgage lender whose collapse last year led to a banking crisis in Spain, slumped Monday in the first day of trading after regulators wiped out most of the stocks value.

title: Rice Pudding
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make rice pudding that is simple, luscious and creamy.

title: Back at No. 1, Woods Shifts Gaze to Augusta
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  A few miles from Bay Hill Club and Lodge, Tiger Woods ran into a fire hydrant, and out gushed sordid details of his private life. Two years later, in November 2011, he reached rock bottom in his professional life, dropping to No. 58 in the world rankings.

title: How Many Vietnam Veterans Are Still Alive?
description: The approximate percentage of Vietnam-era veterans who are still alive in 2013 is 75.

title: Hachette Delaying Goodall Book With Borrowed Passages
description: After revelations that Jane Goodalls forthcoming book Seeds of Hope contains passages copied from various Web sites, the Hachette Book Group has decided to delay its publication. The book was set to be published April 2. No new date has been set.

title: Fold Up Your Handkerchiefs: Books Have Gotten Less Emotional, Study Says
description: If you find youre crying less while reading and throwing fewer books across the room, there may be a good reason. English-language books became steadily less emotional over the 20th century, according to a new study crunching billions of words via Googles Ngram database.

title: Qatalyst Hires Morgan Stanley Banker
description: Qatalyst Group, the West Coast boutique advisory firm led by Frank Quattrone, has hired Marcie Vu as a partner.

title: The Tournaments Biggest Surprise? La Salle
description: Right now, Florida Gulf Coast is everybodys darling.

title: Sale of Pre-Columbian Art Falls Short of Expectations
description: Sothebys weekend sale in Paris of pre-Columbian artifacts earned about $13.3 million, well below the pre-sale estimate of $19 million to $23 million, according to the auction house.

title: France Seeks Slower Pace of Negotiations for a U.S.-Europe Trade Pact
description: PARIS  If anyone thought working out a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union was going to be easy, France has a message: Slow down.

title: The Iraq War and Domestic Politics
description: There was a lot of pushback, much of it from liberals, to my column yesterday arguing that the Obama era as we know it has been made possible by George W. Bushs decision ten years ago to launch an invasion of Iraq. Some of this pushback, on Twitter and elsewhere, reflects a slight misreading of my point, so let me clarify: I was not arguing that absent the Iraq War, the Democratic Party would necessarily still be in the minority today, or that the Democratic presidential nominee would necessarily have lost the elections of 2008 and 2012. As I said at the top of the piece, its entirely plausible that in a world with no Iraq invasion we would be presently entering Hillary Clintons second term, and I agree (and have acknowledged many times before) that the current Democratic advantage is founded on deep demographic and social trends as well as the accidents of politics.

title: In Praise of Pale Food
description: ITS ONE OF THE FIRST THINGS people mention when they learn I have a 4-year-old daughter.

title: Looking for Evidence That Therapy Works
description: Mental-health care has come a long way since the remedy of choice was trepanation  drilling holes into the skull to release evil spirits. Over the last 30 years, treatments like cognitive-behavioral therapy, dialectical behavior therapy and family-based treatment have been shown effective for ailments ranging from anxiety and depression to post-traumatic stress disorder and eating disorders.

title: Look of the Moment | Charlotte Casiraghi
description: The Girl: The Monaco royal at the Bal de la Rose du Rocher in Monte-Carlo, Monaco.

title: A Rice Pudding for Anyone
description: As an ardent fan of rice pudding, Ive made many versions over the years, most involving an egg custard and many baked in a water bath. While none are difficult, they are all more elaborate than the simple pudding I wanted for this weeks column about white food.

title: Suit Offers a Peek at the Practice of Inflating a Legal Bill
description: 8:52 p.m. | Updated

title: Monday Motorsports: Kyle Busch Wins as Hamlin and Logano Wreck
description: Feuding former teammates Denny Hamlin and Joey Logano crashed into each other while battling for the lead on the final turn, and Kyle Busch squeezed past them to take the victory in Sundays 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Auto Club Speedway in California.

title: Channing Tatum Has the Most Anagrammable Name in Hollywood
description: As a recurring bonus to the Riff essay, we sporadically present Five-Ku: five haiku poems about a current celebrity or cultural phenomenon. (Past examples include haikus about Susan Sarandon, Russell Crowe and classic horror films.)

title: In Performance: Tina Packers Women
description: Tina Packer plays Queen Margaret in a scene from Shakespeares Henry VI (Part III), part of her show Women of Will.

title: Following Your Bliss, Right Off the Cliff
description: SO you want to be a writer. Or an artist. Or to open a cupcake shop. What youll hear, often, is that you should pursue your dream. Follow your passion. Quit your job and live the life you want.

title: Brother of a Fallen Hedge Fund King Pleads Not Guilty
description: 5:10 p.m. | Updated

title: Made in L.A. | The House of Neutra
description: The interior designer and writer David Netto takes a tour of VDL Research House on Silver Lake boulevard in Los Angeles.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra to Collaborate With Opera on Salome
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra has programmed a concert performance of the Strauss opera Salome for next season. Now, they are calling in the experts. The orchestra said on Monday it would be collaborating with Opera Philadelphia to create a semistaged version of the work, to be performed in May 2014. Kevin Newbury is to direct and Vita Tzykun will design the production, to be performed in the orchestras home, Verizon Hall at the Kimmel Center, which has no proscenium. Its a bit of a feat to try to imagine a theatrical mash-up, if you will, said Allison Vulgamore, the orchestras chief executive and president.

title: Minnesota Womens Hockey Wins 49 in a Row to Win Title
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins have won 12 games in a row. The Miami Heat have won 26 in a row. The Baylor womens basketball team has won 31 in a row. But they have a ways to go to catch the University of Minnesota womens hockey team. The Gophers completed a 41-0 season Sunday by winning their second straight national championship with a 6-3 victory over Boston University.

title: Nick Cave: HEARD NY
description: For a week at Grand Central station, students from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will move through the station wearing Nick Cave's Soundsuits as part of the station's centennial celebration.

title: A Renaissance Globemakers Toolbox
description: Introduction

title: Why America Is Called America
description: A DECADE AGO, the Library of Congress paid $10 million to acquire the only known original copy of a 1507 world map that has been called the birth certificate of America. The large map, a masterpiece of woodblock printing, has been a star attraction at the library ever since and the object of revived scholarly fascination about the earliest cartography of the New World.
