title: If the Dancing Shoe Fits
description: When Broadway princesses need new glass slippers, they turn to Worldtone Dance, the citys go-to place for theatrical and dancesport shoes.

title: Donovan, Sabbatical Over, Is Eager to Return to the U.S. Team
description: Lest anyone think that Landon Donovans recent sabbatical from soccer diminished his desire to play for the United States, Donovan said Thursday that he would even be willing to change positions if it meant being called in by Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.

title: Subaru WRX Concept: A Pocket Rocket That Looks the Part
description: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: Subaru WRX Concept

title: Pentagon Reduces Furlough Days for Civilian Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of thousands of Defense Department civilian employees will get a partial reprieve from the work furloughs imposed by the automatic across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester, with their number of unpaid days off reduced to 14 from 22 between now and October.

title: Amazon to Buy Social Site Dedicated to Sharing Books
description: Amazon, the dominant online bookseller, said late Thursday that it would buy Goodreads, the most visited social media site built around sharing books. The companies did not disclose a purchase price or other conditions of the sale, which will close in the next quarter.

title: For a Musician, Life Was a Song
description: Depicting the unconventional life of the Chilean musician and folk artist Violeta Parra, Violeta Went to Heaven unfolds as a poetic sine wave of celebration and defeat.

title: Most Childrens Meals at Large Restaurant Chains Are Still Unhealthy, a Study Finds
description: A new study of the nutritional quality of meals for children on the menus of the nations largest chain restaurants has found that 91 percent do not even meet the standards set by the National Restaurant Associations Kids LiveWell program.

title: The Setting Is Juvenile, the Problems Are Not
description: Few things can be more embarrassing than being arrested while performing cunnilingus, as the 16-year-old Davis (Shane Kippel) can attest. Nabbed in his bedroom for drug possession while enthusiastically pleasuring his girlfriend, Davis is soon joining fellow teenage offenders Angel (Mateo Morales) and Butch (Adam Butcher) as the newest inmates of a juvenile prison in Montana.

title: Dealing With a Lot, and Nothing at All
description: Somebody Up There Likes Me is a 24-hour film. That is, 24 hours after you see it, its still lingering in your mind. But 48 hours after? Gone.

title: His Truck Is Stuck. Really Stuck.
description: Without knowing how much the actor Neil Hopkins was paid to perform in Detour, Im guessing it wasnt enough. Like Ryan Reynolds in Buried, Mr. Hopkins must convey hunger, thirst, physical injury and slow asphyxiation in a confined space; unlike Mr. Reynolds, he must do so within the constraints of a barrel-scraping budget. As his character, Jackson Alder, says at one point, That cant be good.

title: Mystery Malady Kills More Bees, Heightening Worry on Farms
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  A mysterious malady that has been killing honeybees en masse for several years appears to have expanded drastically in the last year, commercial beekeepers say, wiping out 40 percent or even 50 percent of the hives needed to pollinate many of the nations fruits and vegetables.

title: A Disastrous Year for Bees
description: For Americas beekeepers, who have struggled for nearly a decade with a mysterious malady called colony collapse disorder that kills honeybees en masse, the last year was particularly bad.

title: E.P.A. Plans Stricter Limit for Sulfur in Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency will propose a rule on Friday that will cut the amount of sulfur allowed in gasoline by two-thirds to improve the performance of the catalytic converters in engines that fight smog, the agency has told refiners and clean-air advocates.

title: Holocaust Heroism in the Philippines
description: The fascinating documentary Rescue in the Philippines: Refuge From the Holocaust, with narration by Liev Schreiber, recounts a little-known chapter of World War II heroism that is as heartbreaking as it is courageous. While much of the world was reluctant to help early victims of Nazi Germany, an effort devised in Manila during late-night poker games eventually delivered more than 1,200 European Jews to safety in the tropics.

title: Old Enough to See the Glass as Half-Full
description: The title of Maren Grainger-Monsen and Nicole Newnhams film happens to evoke the function of many documentaries: enlighten audiences about world problems and make them feel a bit more hopeful now that someone with initiative is taking care of things. Centered on a neighborhood in Kolkata lacking potable water, The Revolutionary Optimists puts a spin on this tendency because these caretakers of the future are youngsters with a surprising knack for talking points.

title: Stoudemire Happy After Surgery, but Playoffs Are Uncertain
description: Amare Stoudemire of the Knicks spoke Thursday about his rehabilitation from the surgery he had on his right knee three weeks ago. Stoudemire said the procedure, called a debridement, which he also had on his left knee before the season began, was successful.

title: California Beaming
description: SAN SIMEON, Calif.  To take in the gardens of Italian cypress and perfumed citrus, to sit at poolside under a Roman temple front, to stare at the infinity of the Pacific from 1,600 feet above the water is to realize that Hearst Castle was much more than the Xanadu that entombed a tragic giant in Citizen Kane.

title: Bob Teague, WNBC Reporter Who Helped Integrate TV News, Is Dead at 84
description: Bob Teague, who joined WNBC-TV in New York in 1963 as one of the citys first black television journalists and went on to work as a reporter, anchorman and producer for more than three decades, died on Thursday in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 84.

title: Russia: Opposition Activists Trial to Begin in April
description: The trial of the opposition activist Aleksei A. Navalny, who is accused of embezzling $500,000 from a timber company, will begin between April 15 and 19, and may be lengthy, court officials in Kirov now say. An aide to Mr. Navalny, Anna Veduta, said he had not been officially notified of the date. Mr. Navalny, the most recognizable face of the antigovernment protests that began in 2011, faces several criminal cases opened over the past year. In the embezzlement case, he is accused of organizing a conspiracy to steal timber from KirovLes, a state-owned company, while he served as an adviser to Kirovs governor four years ago. Mr. Navalny has said he expects to be sent to prison.

title: A Brief Stop That Altered Everything
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The video of Dana Altmans most embarrassing professional moment is on YouTube, shot by a hand-held camera directed at a computer screen, viewed nearly 18,000 times. It was 55 seconds that forever changed Altmans career.

title: A New High
description: The S. & P. 500 overtook its previous 2007 high on Thursday, to close at 1,569.15

description: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: Volvo V60 R-Design Wagon

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is looking at the field of politicians jockeying to replace him, and he says he does not like what he sees.

description: WILMETTE, Ill.

title: Izzos Son Sides With Krzyzewski
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Luckily, Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo thinks this is funny. So he tells the story himself.

description: WASHINGTON  They came to an opening night beer blast at the National Air and Space Museum, 4,000 strong in baseball caps and T-shirts, to look at the Wright Brothers airplane and drink Citizen by DC Brau, which also makes a wryly named hometown brew, Corruption.

title: Ex-Soldier Is Charged With Aiding Terrorist Group
description: WASHINGTON  A former American soldier was charged Thursday with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad, whose ouster the United States has sought for nearly two years.

title: Drug-Sniffing Dogs and the Fourth Amendment
description: The Supreme Court correctly ruled this week that using a drug-sniffing police dog on a suspects property without a warrant violates the Fourth Amendments protection against unreasonable searches. The ruling was not surprising; the split among the justices was.

title: Wealth That Comes of Tragedy
description: No one should envy the civic leaders of Newtown, Conn., as they attempt to bring order and transparency to distributing most of the $15 million in donations that has poured into town since the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre of 20 children and six adults last December. The money was given through 40 ad hoc groups, many of them pursuing separate causes from helping families to building a local memorial, even an angel atop the town flagpole.

title: Terror in Tahrir Square
description: Cairos Tahrir Square once symbolized the hope Egyptians felt when they overthrew Hosni Mubarak and began building a democracy. But this iconic rallying point for protesters has today also come to symbolize the terror and contempt women increasingly face since the Muslim Brotherhood came to power and the country descended into turmoil.

title: Jayhawks Seeking Better Guard Play
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On the floor of Cowboys Stadium, Kansas guard Ben McLemore could not wait to take shots. McLemore let the ball fly from 15 feet, then 20, and immediately called for another ball. He flicked his wrist over and over, keeping his elbow up to provide the necessary arc.

title: Cheating Our Children
description: So, about that fiscal crisis  the one that would, any day now, turn us into Greece. Greece, I tell you: Never mind.

title: Victim and Prosecutor Back Death Row Inmates Bid for Resentencing
description: HOUSTON  One morning in July 1995, Phyllis Taylor stood inside her best friends house here, face to face with her stepbrother. He was holding a .22-caliber rifle, his eyes bloodshot red. Then he pulled the trigger.

title: The Empirical Kids
description: Twelve years ago, I wrote a piece for The Atlantic, called The Organization Kid, about the smart, hard-working, pleasant-but-cautious achievatrons who thrive in elite universities. Occasionally, somebody asks me how students have changed since then. I havent been perceptive enough to give a good answer.

title: A Scene Stealer Isnt Ready to Give Up the Spotlight
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The team from so-called Dunk City had yet to rattle a rim or shake a backboard, and about 2,000 fans at Cowboys Stadium appeared bored as they watched a practice filled with drills of floating jumpers, entry passes and  gasp!  free throws.

title: Palestinians Fight Prison Sentences for Mocking Their President on Facebook
description: A Palestinian court on Thursday upheld a one-year jail sentence for a journalist convicted of insulting President Mahmoud Abbas with a pastiche image posted on Facebook. Another Palestinian was given the same sentence last month for posting a humorous caption beneath an image of Mr. Abbas kicking a soccer ball on the social network.

title: Sprint Nears a U.S. Deal to Restrict China Gear
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to address national security concerns, Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to enter an agreement with American law enforcement officials that will restrict the combined companys ability to pick suppliers for its telecommunications equipment and systems, government officials said on Thursday.

title: Malicious Obstruction in the Senate
description: Earlier this month, during one of his new across-the-aisle good-will tours, President Obama pleaded with Senate Republicans to ease up on their record number of filibusters of his nominees. He might as well have been talking to one of the statues in the Capitol. Republicans have made it clear that erecting hurdles for Mr. Obama is, if anything, their overriding legislative goal.

title: A Safety-First Message Aimed at Getting More Youths Behind the Wheel
description: MADISON AVENUE and the automotive industry are fretting over a growing trend involving the important demographic group of young Americans known as millennials or Generation Y: more of them are just not that into driving, car culture or the lure of the open road.

title: The Lanzas Ammunition Inventory at a Glance
description: A look at the assortment of ammunition and other items listed in the search warrants from Adam Lanzas home.

title: A Dying Art Gets a Rare Exhibition
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Lets get this straight: that hook shot Dukes Mason Plumlee used against Albany in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament was not a Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sky hook. Close, but not quite.

title: Manslaughter Charges for Doctor Who Gave Liposuction to Transplant Recipient
description: A doctor who prosecutors said recklessly performed liposuction on a woman with a transplanted heart, leading to her death, was arraigned Thursday on charges including manslaughter and falsification of records.

description: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013 2014 Mitsubishi Mirage

title: Beloved but Ill, Boston Mayor Wont Run Again
description: BOSTON  Some of the most enduring myths of this city are starting to crumble. Whitey Bulger, the notorious gangster who was on the lam for 16 years, is behind bars. The thieves who snatched priceless art from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in 1990 were identified this month.

description: "I know Syria needs us right now. But  enough. I give up.

description: The medical history forms that Dr. Oleg Davie filled out for Isel Pineda have the same date, but differ considerably in other ways.

title: For Obama, Tricky Balancing Act in Enforcing Defense of Marriage Act
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama decided that his administration would no longer defend the Defense of Marriage Act in court, he was presented with an obvious question with a less obvious answer: Would he keep enforcing a law he now deemed unconstitutional?

title: Divided Parliament Stymies Efforts to Form New Government in Italy
description: ROME  The leader of Italys center-left coalition acknowledged on Thursday that he had been unable to cobble together a governing majority in nearly a week of dramatic and difficult talks with representatives of the political parties in Parliament.

description: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: Shelby Raptor 44 pickup truck

title: Pro-Cuomo Group Repeats as Top Spender on Lobbying
description: ALBANY  For the second consecutive year, a coalition of business leaders supportive of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spent more money on lobbying in New York State last year than any other group, according to a report the state ethics commission released on Thursday.

title: Sabathia Sets Sights on Opener, and the Red Sox
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As the Yankees finish up their final two spring training games in two locales  Washington and West Point, N.Y.  they inch tantalizingly closer to opening day. But for one player, the regular season has already begun.

title: Cackling Loon
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Hey, we got us a Friday with a theme, sort of. Not only that, but its a super clean, fun solve. Nicely done, Josh Knapp and Will Shortz. This puzzle was a very pleasant end-of-week surprise.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Fay Kanin, Writer for Film and Stage, Dies at 95
description: Fay Kanin, half of the husband-and-wife team that wrote the Clark Gable-Doris Day comedy Teachers Pet and the writer of television movies including Emmy-winning vehicles for Maureen Stapleton and Carol Burnett, died on Wednesday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 95.

title: Long Prison Term Is Less So Thanks to Judges Regrets
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  When Denise Dallaire was arrested at age 26 on charges of selling a few ounces of crack cocaine here a decade ago, she was sentenced to prison for more than 15 years. Last month, shackled inside the same court and facing the same judge, she received an apology and was set free.

title: Study Links 2011 Quake to Technique at Oil Wells
description: A damaging earthquake in central Oklahoma two years ago most likely resulted from the pumping of wastewater from oil production into deep wells, scientists say.

title: Damascus University: A Snapshot
description: The state-financed Damascus University is the largest and oldest institution of higher education in Syria. The university has persevered in offering classes despite the encroaching war, and many students continued to attend in an effort to go on with their lives. On Thursday, the sense of normalcy  was shattered when mortar shells hit an outdoor student cafe. Here are some facts about the university, which at one time was considered Syrias most prestigious.

title: Heat Distinguished, and Distanced, Themselves
description: Most coverage of the Miami Heats 27-game winning streak focused on LeBron James and his ability to take over games.

title: Health Care Law Will Raise Some Premiums, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  A study commissioned by the State of California says that the new federal health care law will drive up individual insurance premiums, but that subsidies will offset most of the increase for low-income people.

title: Taliban Spread Terror in Karachi as the New Gang in Town
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  This seaside metropolis is no stranger to gangland violence, driven for years by a motley collection of armed groups who battle over money, turf and votes.

title: In Politics, Never Say Never to an Aggie
description: Familiar with the never-always problem? Thats when you lay down a hard and fast rule, and then eat your words when an exception comes along.

title: Memphis Drops Confederate Names From Parks, Sowing New Battles
description: MEMPHIS  Two bright metal signs long welcomed visitors here to the grassy bluffs overlooking the Mississippi River, near a cluster of Civil War cannons and historical plaques.

title: Another 3-Pointer Falls, and Ohio State Escapes Again
description: LOS ANGELES  For Ohio State, the end felt so four days ago. Here came the Buckeyes, in another tied game in the N.C.A.A. tournament, with the ball in the final seconds.

title: Tom Boerwinkle, Who Had Night to Remember as a Rebounder, Dies at 67
description: Tom Boerwinkle, a stalwart center for the Chicago Bulls in the 1970s who once used his 7-foot frame to grab 37 rebounds in a game known both for that feat  a team record that still stands  and for the frigid conditions in which it was played, died on Tuesday at his home near Chicago. He was 67.

title: Cases of Fever Caused by Fungus Rise
description: Cases of valley fever in the American Southwest have risen sharply in the last decade for unknown reasons, federal health officials said Thursday. The fever is caused by inhaling a fungus that thrives in desert soil. The disease resembles flu or pneumonia. Though the illness is rarely fatal, more than 40 percent of known patients are hospitalized. From 1998 to 2011, cases went from 5 per 100,000 population in the region  Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico and Utah  to 43 per 100,000, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The increase may be due to changing weather patterns or to excavation for new housing. Those who are often outside appear slightly more likely to get it, said Dr. Benjamin J. Park, the C.D.C.s chief epidemiologist for fungal diseases, but people who work in office buildings have gotten it, and theres one case of someone who just passed through the Phoenix airport.

title: Often Overlooked, Marquette Overwhelms No. 2 Seed Miami
description: WASHINGTON  There is no mistaking Marquette Coach Buzz Williamss disgust for how others have assessed his team during the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: In Doubles, Lisa Raymond and Laura Robson Cover the Age Spectrum
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Less than two months after Laura Robson was born on Jan. 21, 1994, a 20-year-old Lisa Raymond played in the Sony Open for the first time.

title: Donovan Speaks About a National Team Return, and More
description: Landon Donovan spoke with reporters on Thursday for the first time since announcing he would return to Major League Soccers Los Angeles Galaxy this week. Sam Bordens article for The Times dealt mostly with the one question on the mind of most fans when he walked away from the game after winning last years M.L.S. title: is he planning to return to the United States national team?

title: From Todays Paper: Water Line Break and Flood Homes in Hoboken
description: Workers at Willow Avenue and 8th Street in Hoboken, N.J., the site of one of two water line breaks just a few blocks apart. The other was at Willow and 14th. Many in the city lost water pressure, and an advisory was issued warning residents to boil water.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 11:30 A.M. (AMC) HACKERS (1995) Two New York high school students (played by Angelina Jolie and Jonny Lee Miller) use their hacking skills for mischiefmaking until they stumble upon a corporate extortion scheme and are charged for computer crimes they did not commit. Only through copious in-line skating, frenzied typing and obsolete tech lingo can their names be cleared. Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times about this 90s time capsule directed by Iain Softley, said, A lot of attention has gone into the films video games, computer imagery and costumes, to the point where simply watching these artifacts is half the fun.

title: A Time as  Fleeting as Waxwings
description: I wrote this piece about six years ago, thinking back on a particular morning and piecing together the events of that day through old e-mails. I am 55 now and divorced, and think wistfully about the brief constellation that was our family. Studies of divorce rates among parents of autistic children contradict one another, citing rates as low as 24 percent and as high as 80 percent.

title: Syracuse Smothers No. 1 Seed Indiana
description: WASHINGTON  Indiana could not have looked more lost. The Hoosiers missed layups, dribbled into defenders and threw passes that sailed into the Syracuse bench, as if a gust of wind had suddenly swept through Verizon Center. And that was just the first few possessions.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Londons Dynamic Duo of Theatrical Dames
description: LONDON  Is that a theatrical dame you see before you? Very likely this season in London, where the twin titans that are Helen Mirren and Judi Dench have opened in new West End plays within three weeks of each other.

title: Wichita State Muscles Past La Salle Into the Round of 8
description: LOS ANGELES  For about 10 minutes Thursday night, as part of its pregame warm-up in the Round of 16, La Salle practiced rebounding. First, the Explorers shadowed one another and boxed out. Then, one by one, as Coach John Giannini tossed basketballs at the rim, they maneuvered around one person, grabbed the rebound and shot the ball, over another, taller person, in the paint.

description: India in 1983 was still in its infant stages of economic development; however, like today, it was a popular destination among Westerners with its marketable poverty, a lingering sense of spirituality, mysticism and a rich history.

title: Freed of a Secrets Burden, a Soccer Player Looks Ahead

Robbie Rogers, a former member of the United States national team and a professional soccer player in England, wrote it one night last December, pounding on his keyboard while sitting in bed. When he finished, he saved it on the main screen of his laptop and it stayed there, for more than two months, while Rogers alternately pondered it, ignored it and agonized over whether he could make it public.

description: JOHANNESBURG  After a second night in a hospital being treated for a recurrent lung infection, former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa was in good spirits on Friday, enjoying breakfast and making steady progress, according to the office of President Jacob Zuma, who had earlier urged his compatriots not to panic.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korean state media said Friday that the countrys leader, Kim Jong-un, had ordered his missile units to be ready to strike the United States and South Korea, which South Korean officials said could signal either preparations for missile tests or just more blustering.

title: The Stalemate in Syria
description: ALEPPO, Syria  Syrias largest city sits in a valley down from a hill with an old citadel. Over the centuries, the massive stone fortress has hosted Romans, Mongols and Ottomans; these days, its home to the soldiers of President Bashar al-Assad. The rebels occupy the eastern portion of the old city, a maze of alleyways and courtyards down below. Its an ideal terrain for urban guerrilla: Tanks cannot enter the narrow passages, and the thick stone walls act as shields against artillery and air strikes.

title: Daily Report:  The Attacks Have Changed From Espionage to Destruction
description: American Express customers trying to gain access to their online accounts on Thursday were met with blank screens or an ominous ancient type face. The company confirmed that its Web site had come under attack, David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth report on Friday in The New York Times.

title: Choosing a Credit Card Processor (and Drawing Some Conclusions)
description: My search for a credit card processor started last April and dragged on through the end of January. Like many small-business owners, I have plenty of things to keep me busy, so my search was an on again/off again thing. As it progressed, I found that the more carefully I looked at the terms I was agreeing to, the less I liked them.

title: App Smart Extra: For the Garden
description: This week, App Smart was all about gardening because spring has sprung, or is about to. There are many apps that can help you in the garden, like plant reference guides or advice about garden bugs, and even apps that can help you manage your garden and its plants over time.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Awkwardness at NBC, and Barbara Walters Retirement
description: Networks never seem to absorb lessons of lineup changes gone bad, NBC most of all, Alessandra Stanley writes. Matt Lauer, the host of NBCs Today show, who may be on the way out, was admirably suave onscreen despite reports that NBC may be seeking a new host. Mr. Lauers problems began with his succession last year, when many viewers blamed him when his co-anchor Ann Curry was clumsily cast aside. The drama is not new. More than 20 years ago, NBC replaced Jane Pauley with the younger Deborah Norville; that Today show shakeup became a founding fiasco of morning television, and Ms. Norvilles career never recovered.

description: OTTOBRUNN, GERMANY  Like the farmers tilling the fields that surround its sprawling German offices south of Munich, European Aeronautic Defense & Space, the parent company of Airbus, is making preparations for new beginnings.

description: BOSTON  NPR is ending the 21-year-old call-in radio show Talk of the Nation and will encourage local stations to replace it with an expanded version of Here and Now, an afternoon news broadcast that is produced here, the organization announced on Friday.

title: The Vulnerable Side of an Invincible Heroine
