title: Kristallnacht in Myanmar
description: MEIKTILA, Myanmar  Not one bullet was fired, not one smoke bomb was dropped as scores of Muslims were attacked and some were burnt alive in Myanmar last week. The security forces just looked on. In a country where they routinely use brute force against political dissidents, villagers who protest land grabs and even monks, their passivity was sadly revealing.

title: The Gun Report: March 29, 2013
description: There was a lot of gun news yesterday. An inventory of Adam Lanzaa possessions was released by police. According to the Times, they included several firearms, more than 1,600 rounds of ammunition, 11 knives, a starter pistol, a bayonet, 3 samurai swords, as well as photographs of what appeared to be a corpse smeared in blood and covered in plastic, as well as a newspaper clipping that chronicled a vicious shooting at Northern Illinois University.

title: We Do Not Want to Go Home Again
description: John Swan was acutely aware of what his apartment on the Upper East Side lacked  a living room.

title: A Man of His Time
description: The Karl Marx depicted in Jonathan Sperbers absorbing, meticulously researched biography will be unnervingly familiar to anyone who has had even the most fleeting acquaintance with radical politics. Here is a man never more passionate than when attacking his own side, saddled with perennial money problems and still reliant on his parents for cash, constantly plotting new, world-changing ventures yet having trouble with both deadlines and personal hygiene, living in rooms that some might call bohemian, others plain slummy, and who can be maddeningly inconsistent when not lapsing into elaborate flights of theory and unintelligible abstraction.

title: This Weeks Movies: The Host, Renoir and The Place Beyond the Pines
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review The Place Beyond the Pines, The Host and Renoir.

title: The Cowgirl Way
description: Junior rodeos in the Texas Panhandle.

title: Editors Choice
description: WAVE,  by Sonali Deraniyagala. (Knopf, $24.) Deraniyagalas unforgettable account of her struggle to carry on living after her husband, sons and parents were killed in the 2004 tsunami isnt only as unsparing as they come, but also defiantly imbued with light.

title: Its a Natural Gas, Gas, Gas
description: Im a biologist with a federal agency. My family owns land in northeast Pennsylvania. A portion is owned outright by my mother, who has entered into a contract with a natural-gas company to allow drilling on the property. Royalties from the gas extraction allow her to live comfortably in retirement. My mother made the arrangements for the gas drilling without my support. Im not in favor of increasing fossil-fuel dependence. In light of the anticipated royalties, my mother was advised by her lawyer to establish a corporate partnership with my brother and me, for liability protection. This would mean a portion of the royalties will be mine. If I intend to work on any future climate-change projects professionally, should I decline the partnership with my mother? If I do not support natural-gas drilling, is that another reason to decline the partnership? And is this decision different from eventually inheriting money related to drilling? RICHARD, WASHINGTON

title: A Modest Proposal for More Back-Stabbing in Preschool
description: Late last week, I was driving my daughter to her play-based, shoe-optional, sugar-free preschool  a magical Arcadia where an actual chicken is free to roam and grow fat off Pirates Booty, and where the major areas of academic focus revolve around turn-taking, problem-solving and the life story of Rosa Parks  when I experienced a moment of self-doubt so paralyzing I almost had to pull over. The radio in my car was tuned to an NPR show, on which callers were debating the decision by the C.E.O. of Yahoo, Marissa Mayer, to ban employees from working from home. Id been thinking about Mayer since early that morning, having fallen down an Internet rabbit hole that plunged me deep into her art collection, her exclusive wardrobe and her estimated $300 million net worth. Specifically, I was thinking about the rather highhanded, Marie Antoinette-ish way in which she dismissed the need for extended maternity leave, as if it hadnt occurred to her that building an en suite nursery for her newborn next to her office basically elided the need for it, since the baby could remain within a few feet of her all day long.

title: A Brief Resurrection
description: I was sitting next to my husband in our neighborhood pub on a spring afternoon, munching on fish and chips. I reached for my beer and looked out the window, and there he was: a 30-something fellow in a scruffy beard. My ex-husband.

title: Tony Visconti Will Lie for David Bowie
description: You produced David Bowies new album, The Next Day, which was recorded in total secrecy. How did you keep it under wraps?  It wasnt difficult. Most of us had been with him for decades, myself the longest, 45 years. Maybe one or two people said, Is David Bowie making a new album? and then Id have to lie.

title: The 3.17.13 Issue
description: IS THIS WHERE THE THIRD INTIFADA WILL START?

title: Paperback Row
description: OUR LADY OF ALICE BHATTI,  by Mohammed Hanif. (Vintage, $15.) Alice Bhatti, a Karachi nurse with mysterious healing powers, is at the center of Hanifs blistering comedy, which delivers a broadside on the socially sanctioned butchery of women and girls in Pakistan. Working miracles at Sacred Heart Hospital for All Ailments, a cesspit of incompetence, Alice is beloved, but not even her supernatural skill set can stem the tide of dead women.

title: Get Yer Yeah Yeah Yeahs Out
description: The fall of 2000 felt like end times for rock n roll in New York City. On the radio it was all boy bands and Britney Spears, and there hadnt been a vital rock scene since punk in the 1970s. But on a Sunday night at a tiny club in Lower Manhattan, something was happening. There were four acts on the bill at the Mercury Lounge; the Yeah Yeah Yeahs were the openers, and it was still light out when they took the stage. The band was elemental: guitar and drums, no bass. But the singer, who called herself Karen O, was otherworldly. She was dressed in a kind of Clockwork Orange burlesque, with cutout hearts as pasties. Before the show, she doused herself in olive oil. Onstage, she danced around like a lunatic, manically grinning and flinging droplets of oil from her hair into the crowd. The guitar player, Nick Zinner, had seen this side of her. But the drummer, Brian Chase, had practiced with the band only once, and this was their first gig. The only thing to do, Chase remembers thinking, is just be like, Whoa.

title: Who Made That Learjet?
description: In the early 1960s, William Lear invited potential buyers to tour the jet that he designed as a hot rod for the sky. The plane was sleek and narrow, with a cabin ceiling so low that you had to take care not to bang your head. When one man complained that he couldnt stand up inside this so-called luxury plane, Lear groused, Youre absolutely right  and you cant stand up in your [expletive] Rolls-Royce, either.

title: Bobby Cannavale, Broadways Hottest Outsider
description: It was a miserable morning, rainy, cold and Wednesday, so Barney Greengrass was mostly empty. Bobby Cannavale was there having breakfast with the actor Richard Kind. Cannavale buttered a bialy as Kind endured a vegetable omelet. Ive been dieting for 45 years, he said mournfully. Cannavale took his arm. You look great, man, he said. The two friends share a trainer.

title: Summary Judgment
description: Sandra Day OConnor retired from the Supreme Court in 2006, but she still turns up for the occasional argument, sitting off to the side in one of the seats reserved for important guests. She can look a little grim, and with reason. The court has been busy disassembling her work.

title: Yes Man
description: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia begins under a bed. With you  yes, you  under a bed. Once you quit cowering, youll be the hero of this novel written in the second person, although theres nothing remotely heroic about you at the moment; youre so sick you can scarcely speak. The only remedy at hand is a large white radish, which your mother cooks up in a foul brew.

title: Masters and Slaves
description: On a trip to Paris, I recently had the same shocked realization that Andrea Stuart describes in her astounding new book, Sugar in the Blood.

title: Peculiar Institutions
description: One of the challenges white writers face in creating black characters is the avoidance of caricature and stereotype. If cultural appropriation must take place, the thinking goes, then authors should treat black narratives  often the products of American history, and thus as sacred as the Constitution itself  with kid gloves. If they fail even in the slightest, readers are sure to voice criticism and, maybe justifiably, rain down judgment and reckoning.

title: Asylum Seekers
description: What does a political refugee notice when arriving in, say, Los Angeles? Is he shocked by the quotidian displays of flesh? Troubled by the angry jumble of a city he has known only in its varnished Saturday matinee form? Unbalanced by discordant echoes of home, like the Venice Beach busker whose turban appears native to the old country?

title: Prince of Punk
description: Richard Hell was partly responsible for the phenomenon of punk, a visionary whose style Malcolm McLaren imported to England and impressed upon his pet project, the Sex Pistols, who popularized and cashed in on Hells spiky hair, torn clothes and audacious attitude  embodied in his seminal record of 1977, Blank Generation. In his new autobiography, I Dreamed I Was a Very Clean Tramp, Hell admits to resenting the Sex Pistols for failing to acknowledge how much they lifted from him. But in a moment that speaks to this punk-icon-turned-accomplished-writers commitment to an objective distance from himself, he rhetorically asks, How many kids were going to get excited about calling themselves blank? The concept of anarchy was just as disgusted and contrary but a lot more fun.

title: Mother of the Movement
description: Beautiful Rosa Parks sits alone in the Montgomery, Ala., city bus she desegregated, an image endlessly replicated, most recently on an American postage stamp issued in February to commemorate Black History Month and what would have been Parkss 100th birthday. By the time she died in 2005, Parks had become an American saint. President Bill Clinton gave her a Medal of Freedom in 1996; Congress awarded her a Gold Medal in 1999 (passed nearly unanimously  only Representative Ron Paul of Texas dissented); and after her death, her body lay in the Capitol Rotunda. She was the first woman to be so honored, and the first black woman to have a statue in her likeness placed in the National Statuary Hall of the Capitol. It was unveiled this year and positioned, House Speaker John Boehner pointed out, right in the gaze of Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy.

title: What Now for Gun Control?
description: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and other Democratic leaders in Congress folded their tents on comprehensive gun control fast  dropping a ban on assault weapons and limits on the size of magazines as they watered down the official bill that will hit the Senate floor.

title: When Worlds Collide
description: Its tempting to invest the remnants of the past  the letters, the heirlooms, the junk  with tremendous explanatory power, especially when the stuff is your familys. The clich about the dustbin of history is almost too apt when Alexander Stille walks into his aunt Lallys apartment. Buried in the stacks of clothes, receipts, lottery tickets and old balls of yarn, there are fantastic photographs, a letter from the proto-Fascist poet Gabriele dAnnunzio and all the living room furniture Lallys parents had taken with them when the family fled Russia for Italy and then Italy for the United States.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE HONORED SOCIETY  A Portrait of Italys Most Powerful Mafia.  By Petra Reski. Translated by Shaun Whiteside.Nation Books, paper, $16.99.

title: Undue Process
description: As we commemorate the 50th anniversary of Gideon v. Wainwright, the landmark Supreme Court decision that gave poor defendants the right to counsel, it would be nice to celebrate. That case, taken together with the 1967 decision In re Gault, which gave juveniles the same rights in court as adults, stands for the principle that process matters in our system of justice; when faced with the awesome power of the state, the accused  rich or poor, old or young  must be properly armed.

title: Irish Legacy of Leniency on Mortgages Nears an End
description: DUBLIN  Ben Gilroy, one of tens of thousands who over-borrowed in the giddy property boom that preceded Irelands economic collapse, has made no mortgage payments for two years. But he says he does not worry that he will lose his home any time soon.

title: By Night in Chile
description: In a summary, most literary careers nowadays  in New York or Zagreb  can look eerily similar. Take, for instance, the case of Alejandro Zambra. Zambra is a Chilean who has so far written three novels. He was born in 1975, and teaches literature at the Diego Portales University in Santiago. He has figured on Grantas list of best young Spanish-language novelists, and the Bogot39 project. His career, in other words, has the usual global vibe. But if you held his novels in your hand, then something much stranger would be immediately apparent. Bonsai, his first, takes up only 86 miniature pages. His second, The Private Lives of Trees, requires 98. His third, Ways of Going Home, which has just been published in a translation by Megan McDowell, uses a comparatively gargantuan 139. All of them are marked by a uniquely manic brevity.

title: A Crack in the Darkness
description: That old dictum, write what you know? Ive always thought that was terrible advice. Most of us dont know much. And what we do know can feel shopworn in the retelling. Shopworn or just divested of emotional content. Sometimes, the things were closest to  our lives, for instance  are the very things we least want to examine with rigor.

title: Attacca Quartet Plays John Adams on Fellow Traveler
description: Fellow Traveler: The Complete String Quartet Works of John Adams

title: Screening History
description: Narrative imagination is its own thing: the muscular yet uncanny gift of the storyteller. It is distinct from useful, more rational elements like the psychology of characters, rich details of settings, pungent dialogue, clever plots, memorable images  all remain mechanical unless animated by the pure mastery of and then, the mysterious, proliferating other-life of narrative conviction. In the kind of narrative I mean, incidents themselves are prolific. That teeming germ-culture thrives notably in the writing of the Israeli novelist A. B. Yehoshua.

title: Mozart Piano Concertos Performed by Jan Lisiecki
description: Mozart: Piano Concertos Nos. 20 in D minor, 21 in C

title: Rachmaninoffs All-Night Vigil
description: Rachmaninoff:

title: Glass Lewis Urges MetroPCS Investors to Reject T-Mobile Deal
description: MetroPCS, at least you have Egan-Jones.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jonathan Sperber talks about his new biography of Karl Marx; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Parul Sehgal discusses Mohsin Hamids new novel, How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Sam Tanenhaus.

title: Male Roles? Yes, but Ready for Divadom
description: You dont want to see me after a rehearsal, said the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote, looking stylish during a recent prerehearsal interview at the Metropolitan Opera. Im sweating and disgusting. I have to sing while being physically active and rolling around the floor and leaping around with guns.

title: Spring Festival as Rite of Refreshment
description: MOSCOW  The scandal surrounding the 1913 Paris premiere of The Rite of Spring, by Serge Diaghilevs Ballets Russes, is legendary. The performance of Vaslav Nijinksys modernist choreography, based on pagan ritual and set to Stravinskys dissonant score, shocked audiences and changed the course of dance.

title: Lil Wayne, Sobriety and the Damage Done
description: Jon Caramanica and host Ben Ratliff talk about Lil Waynes I Am Not A Human Being II, the third in his theoretically drug-free era  he has consented to regular, court-ordered drug tests since 2010  and talk about Wayne (again, theoretically) pre- and post-sobriety.

title: What Pet Owners Must Do to Get New York Apartments
description: In a seemingly endless game of cat-and-mouse, pet owners do many things to ease their way into the apartment of their dreams  legitimate and not so.

title: Leading Off: The Joyless Round
description: For everyone who giggled through last weekends N.C.A.A. tournament games, Thursdays Round of 8 games hit like a bucket of ice water. Fun? Apparently it was outlawed since Sunday. In its place came the Big Easts antijoy squad, Jim Boeheim and Buzz Williams, who preach defense in their sleep and wring the life out of games as if their last breaths depended on it.

title: Can Lines Messaging App Crack the American Market?
description: Line, the mobile messaging application that has built up more than 110 million customers around the world, particularly in Asia, is hoping to make similar inroads in the United States.

title: A Triplex at the Pierre Hotel
description: A look inside what is considered one of the most important and historic luxury apartments in the country.

title: Womens Tennis Serves Up No. 1 vs. No. 2
Opulent, at a Price to Match
description: The penthouse at the distinctive apex of the Pierre Hotel, a triplex confection graced by a grand black-marble staircase, arched cathedral windows that replicate a Versailles chapel, 23-foot ceilings, and fireplaces embraced by mantels designed in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries is poised for a return to the market at a price that reflects its irreplaceable heritage; if met, it would set another record for trophy residences in New York City.

title: Safety Agency Opens Inquiry on Hyundai Sonata Suspension Failures
description: Almost four years after Hyundai had to recall about 600,000 vehicles for corrosion problems, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has started investigating possible corrosion-related rear suspension failures on an estimated 393,000 2006-8 Hyundai Sonatas, according to a report posted on Friday on the agency Web site.

title: Popcast: Lil Wayne, Sobriety and the Damage Done
description: This week, Jon Caramanica and the host, Ben Ratliff, talk about Lil Waynes I Am Not a Human Being II, his third album since he theoretically stopped using drugs  he has consented to regular, court-ordered drug tests since 2010  and about Wayne (again, theoretically) before and during his enforced sobriety.

title: More Choices for Healthy Fish Dishes
description: Trying to include more fish and seafood in your diet can be confusing. Fish is healthy and nourishing, and I love to cook and eat it. But whenever I think about the environmental impacts of both farming and overfishing I feel torn. I am not the only one with these concerns, as was made clear by the recent Too Few Fish in the Sea Room For Debate feature.

title: One on One: Jerry Weissman, Silicon Valleys Storyteller
description: Jerry Weissman may produce more revenue than almost any director in history. His big successes havent been plays or movies, though. For more than two decades, Mr. Weissman, a former television and stage director, has coached the executives of technology companies on the theater of the initial public offering.

title: New Phone by Facebook to Showcase Its Network
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Tests Start for Patients of Dentist in Inquiry
description: The unsanitary practices of a dentist in Tulsa, Okla., may have exposed thousands of patients to H.I.V. and hepatitis, forcing him to close his offices while health officials investigate and test about 7,000 people who had visited him since 2007.

title: In the Round: Mitsubishi Mirage
description: The Mitsubishi Mirage at the New York auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

title: Bad Directors and Why They Arent Thrown Out
description: In the annals of shareholder democracy, its hard to imagine a more compelling case against a companys directors than those who presided over the serial management calamities that have plagued the computer giant Hewlett-Packard in recent years.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A restored home from 1712, the oldest in Newark, N.J., and a four-bedroom clapboard colonial in Nassau County, Long Island.

title: Cost of Environmental Damage in China Growing Rapidly Amid Industrialization
description: BEIJING  The cost of environmental degradation in China was about $230 billion in 2010, or 3.5 percent of the nations gross domestic product  three times that in 2004, in local currency terms, an official Chinese news report said this week.

title: Abbas Pardons Journalist Sentenced for Insulting Him
description: The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, has pardoned a Palestinian journalist whose one-year prison sentence for insulting him on Facebook was upheld by a West Bank appeals court on Thursday, the presidents legal adviser said in a statement. The journalist, Mamdouh Hamamreh, was arrested in 2009 after Palestinian intelligence officers said they saw a photograph portraying Mr. Abbas as a traitor on Mr. Hamamrehs Facebook page. The Palestinian Center for Development and Media Freedoms, a nongovernmental organization based in the West Bank, said that Mr. Hamamreh was not the person who had posted the photograph, nor did he share or like it. The presidents legal adviser said that Mr. Abbas respected freedom of opinion and expression and that he had not personally filed a complaint against the journalist.

title: Money Advice for Doctors and Lawyers and the Rest of Us
description: IN most places in America, doctors and lawyers are at the top of the career pyramid. Theyre often the top earners in town. And they usually live in the nicest neighborhoods and drive expensive cars.

title: Your Game of Thrones Questions, Answered
description: Previously we heard from the creators of Modern Family, Homeland, Justified and New Girl.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A condo in Hells Kitchen with private outdoor spaces, a Greenwich Village loft in a prewar cast iron building and a Boerum Hill row house with an upper-floor rental.

title: What the Yeah Yeah Yeahs Listened to When They Were Kids
description: Back in the early 2000s, Karen O had a crush on a lame dude. For whatever reason at that point in my life I was like yeah. I was totally into it, she told me when I was reporting this weekends article about her and her band, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. Out one night at the Cooler, a now-defunct venue in the Meatpacking district in New York, the guy was ignoring her, and she was drowning her sorrows when she saw Debbie Harry at the bar. I go up to her and Im like, Yeah, um, Im in a band and sometimes I just feel like a girl in a boys world. She says, Honey, just enjoy it while it lasts. At the time, Karen O, whose last name is Orzolek, was horrified. It felt condescending. But she has a different take on it now. Shes right as rain . . . I am a girl in a boys world but . . . it doesnt really matter, just enjoy it!

title: An Aromatic Advantage From Olive Oil?
description: The Timess Anahad OConnor explains why scientists suggest you dont have to eat olive oil to benefit from it.

title: Whats the Value of Media?
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download, and what entertainment is worth.

title: The Bundesligas Soft Underbelly
description: There are a number of ways to measure the strength of a domestic league in European soccer: the number of challengers for the title; the ability of the league to promote and produce quality young players; or the likelihood of the sides within that league to compete for continental honors. Each statistic tells its own story, and grants a small insight in to the overall health of the league in question.

title: Mar. 31  April 6
description: That Filipina Diva Kicks Up Her Heels

title: After the Diagnosis, the Get-Togethers
description: Three years ago, Kennard Lehmann walked out of a neurologists office in Sacramento, Calif., newly diagnosed with early-stage Alzheimers disease, a prescription in hand and absolutely no idea where to turn for help.

title: A Simple Way to Send Poor Kids to Top Colleges
description: WASHINGTON

title: Look of the Moment | Ryan Gosling
description: The Guy: The actor at the premiere of The Place Beyond the Pines in New York.

title: Inside the List
description: JERSEY BOYS: In all the recent hoopla over Philip Roths 80th birthday, nobody much remarked on the existence of another follicle-challenged Jewish novelist born in Newark, 29 years after Roth. But Harlan Coben  whose latest thriller, Six Years, goes straight to No. 1 in its first week on the hardcover fiction list  was in a forgiving mood when I reached him on the phone recently. Ive read every book Philip Roth has ever written, he said. Hes my favorite writer. In fact, when I was growing up in Livingston, N.J., a woman who lived down the street from us was rumored to have been the girl from Goodbye, Columbus. I think my mother was the one who told us that. It seemed very exciting and scandalous.

title: Suit Claims Ford Failed to Protect Vehicles From Unintended Acceleration
description: A class-action suit filed against the Ford Motor Company on Thursday asserted that the automaker knew its vehicles were vulnerable to sudden unintended acceleration events, but failed to equip them with a system so that the brake pedal would always overrule the gas pedal.

title: Florida Gulf Coast, From Plucky Underdog to Chic Pick
description: ESPN analysts Digger Phelps and Bruce Pearl have picked Florida Gulf Coast to beat Florida. They did so matter-of-factly, too, like a 15th seed knocking off a No. 3 in the round of 16 is as common as pouring milk on cereal.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Paris, Scotland and New York City
description: Paris Haute Couture, Paris Theres vintage, and then theres historic couture. This show of 100 dresses is the latter. The selection from the Muse Galliera collection  from late-19th-century Worth evening gowns (a 1925 Jean Patou dress is shown right) to an intricately embroidered outfit by John Galliano for Christian Dior  is on view at Pariss City Hall through July 6.

title: Voting Irregularities in Kenya Election Are Confirmed, Adding Fuel to Dispute
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The landmark legal challenge to Kenyas presidential election wrapped up on Friday, and the last bits of evidence confirmed what many had suspected from the beginning: there were definitely voting irregularities, but were they big enough to change the outcome?

title: A Romance Guided by Stars, Planets and Telescopes
description: When the call came in April 2004, it was hard for Kenneth Launie to contain his enthusiasm. An amateur collector and restorer of telescopes, he had seen the instrument before, but only behind the glare of a glass case at Harvard. Then, out of nowhere, came the offer: Bring your white gloves and your screwdriver, and take apart the telescope that had been used by John Winthrop, a Harvard professor and descendant of the Massachusetts Bay Colony founder, to observe the transit of Venus in 1769.

title: U.S. May Sell Airwaves That Help Broadway Sing
description: An hour before curtain at Mamma Mia! at the Winter Garden Theater on Broadway, Craig Cassidy, the head sound man, starts his nightly ritual of testing the wireless microphones that the performers wear hidden in their white spandex bell bottoms.

title: In Ratings Race, The Voice Gains on Idol
description: 3:51 p.m. | Updated Time, and maybe the presence of The Voice, seem to be catching up with the great TV ratings titan of the last decade, American Idol.

title: Federal Complaint Against Harroun
description: Eric Harroun, a former American soldier, was charged with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syrias government.

title: The Sweet Spot: Pay to Play
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download and what entertainment is worth.

title: Landslide Near Seattle Followed Years of Shift
description: The violent energy of the earth can sometimes feel predictable. An earthquake striking a steep slope of gravel or boulders creates an outcome that even a nongeologist could foresee. Volcanoes can literally move mountains.

title: You Are Feeling Very ... Uncertain
description: AUSTIN, TEX.  Danny Boyle has always been something of a cinematic hypnotist. He has a knack for guiding moviegoers across disparate cinematic terrain using colorful, kinetic visuals and throbbing electronic soundtracks, conjuring immersive worlds that viewers easily fall into.

title: Good News: U.S. Traffic Is Getting Worse
description: American traffic delays are rising for the first time in years. Thats an indication that the economy is getting healthier, according to an analysis by Inrix, a data firm.

title: Infections Tied to Cognitive Decline
description: A new study adds to the evidence that chronic infection, known to be associated with vascular disease, is also associated with poorer performance on tests of mental ability.

title: As Economy Heats Up, Traffic Backs Up
description: TRAFFIC is getting worse in the United States, according to a company that monitors driving time by tracking cellphones and GPS devices in cars and trucks.

title: Not Buying (or Bankrolling) the Easter Bunny
description: When a friend of mine who knows that Im a Santa Claus denier, a Valentines Day objector and a St. Paddys Day agnostic asked me what I thought about the Easter Bunny, I launched into a rant about traditions where we celebrate joy and wonderment by deceiving our children.

title: Bentley Showcases Its Craftsmanship at an Atelier
description: With an almost Dickensian air of Bob Cratchit sitting at his tall desk, two craftsmen from Bentleys bespoke studio in Crewe, England, occupied a space on Greenwich Street in Manhattan on Tuesday. They had been transported to Lower Manhattan to showcase the American introduction of the companys new car, the Flying Spur sedan.

title: Breaking It Down: Haas vs. Djokovic
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Tommy Haas had a game plan.

title: Letter to Patients and Complaint Against Dr. W. Scott Harrington
description: The Oklahoma Board of Dentistry accused Dr. Harrington of being a menace to the public health by using unsafe and unsanitary practices.

title: Ayanbadejo, Kluwe to Be Honored for Equality Efforts
description: The former N.F.L. commissioner Paul Tagliabue will present an award to players Brendon Ayanbadejo and Chris Kluwe next week, honoring their support of equality for the gay and lesbian community.

title: Hit or Flop? Expert on Broadway Musicals to Write History Explaining Why
description: Jack Viertel, the artistic director of New York City Center Encores!, has signed a deal with Farrar, Straus & Giroux to write a book about the structure and inner workings of Broadway musicals and why some shows succeed and others falter, the publisher and Mr. Viertel said this week. The book, tentatively titled: The Secret Life of the Broadway Musical: How Broadway Shows are Built, is scheduled for publication in winter 2016.

title: Syria, Iran and the N.R.A. Versus Everybody
description: It was always wishful thinking to expect that all of the United Nations 193 member states would approve the treaty regulating global trade in conventional weapons that was negotiated in New York this week. But the conclusion reached on Thursday was stark: On one side, opposing the new pact, were three of the worlds pariah states  Syria, Iran and North Korea. On the other side, favoring the new pact, was  everybody else.

title: Many Film Languages
description: Images of Hollywood actors in non-English films.

title: Bilingualism Steps Into a Leading Role
description: In his latest movie, a noir thriller called Everybody Has a Plan, Viggo Mortensen plays twin brothers, one a doctor in a midlife crisis, the other a neer-do-well mixed up in all kinds of shady business. In her newest offering, In the House, Kristin Scott Thomas is cast as an art gallery director whose marriage starts to teeter when her husband, a high school literature teacher, takes an undue interest in a pupil.

title: Some Veteran Rockers Help to Pass the Torch
description: With Alice Cooper approximating Jim Morrisons trademark alternation of growling intensity and meditative sultriness, and Robby Krieger reprising his vintage guitar solos, a starry band dominated by glam-metal veterans worked their way through the Doors classics Back Door Man and Break On Through (To the Other Side) on Thursday evening in Sioux Falls, S.D., as part of a concert to benefit the citys new Brennan Rock & Roll Academy.

title: Fresh Kicks
description: Vans, a favorite of surfers and skaters, goes for an Asian punk brightly colored look this season. The Kenzo designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim emblazoned the canvas kicks with motifs culled from their spring 2013 collection, which was inspired by a trip to Thailand. While the collections colorful leopard spots and bursts of floral prints may be a challenge to pull off on a head-to-toe look, the exuberant pops of pattern on these Vans feel just right. $125; openingceremony.us (beginning Monday).

title: Weekend Fare
description: While many Easter workshops may be for children, Neuhaus, the luxury Belgian chocolatier at 500 Madison Avenue in Midtown, is offering one for adults, from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday and 9 to 11 a.m. Saturday. Guests will decorate their own chocolate Easter egg shells and choose pralines to take home in a houndstooth-wrapped package. The class is $75 a person and includes all materials and beverages. Call (212) 644-4490 to make a reservation.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Earth 2 at No. 1
description: There is an embarrassment of riches on our hardcover and paperback graphic books best-seller lists this week.

title: Who Wanted to Take the Case on Gay Marriage? Ask Scalia
description: WASHINGTON  Why did the Supreme Court agree in December to hear a major same-sex marriage case and then seem to think it had made a terrible mistake on Tuesday when it came time for arguments?

title: Why Are Boomers Getting S.T.D.s?
description: Some time back, researchers writing in The New England Journal of Medicine decided to ask older Americans about their sex life and discovered something interesting: very often, they have one.

title: Strikeouts on the Rise
description: Last season, teams struck out at a rate never before seen. Theories as to why hitters are striking out in ever-increasing numbers reflect changes in both pitching and hitting.

title: In Paris, Mixing the Contemporary With the Classics
description: While many world capitals feed off the energy of modernity, Paris is loved because it represents an escape from it. So when most people visit the city, their agenda involves visiting monuments like the Louvre, the Htel de Ville and Notre Dame. The baby of the group is the Eiffel Tower, built in 1887.

title: Hiking Beyond Borders in the Balkans
description: The seasons were changing fast, and the warmth Id taken for granted had vanished as night mustered in the hills. I gathered the blanket around my neck and listened to the dogs barking below. It was now long past midnight, with only a few hours until the morning call to prayer.

title: A Book Doctor in Dallas Patches Up Well-Loved Bibles
description: DALLAS  Well find hair clippings, Candice McKay, owner of the Book Doctor in Dallas, said last week. And palm leaves from Palm Sunday. Its not uncommon.

title: Into the Albanian Alps
description: Towering peaks, rustic inns and views that span countries on a trek through the Balkans.

title: Guest Workers Are at Crux of Groups Deal on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top business and labor groups were near agreement Friday on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants, closing in on a deal that would eliminate one of the last significant obstacles to a new proposal for a broad overhaul of immigration laws, officials involved in the talks said.

title: Why Strikeout Rates Are Soaring
description: As their strikeout totals piled up last summer, the pitchers for the Milwaukee Brewers hardly noticed. The team was struggling to reach .500, and the rotation had been in flux all year. It did not feel as if the pitching staff was closing in on the record for strikeouts in a season.

title: Vegetables Make the Sandwich
description: Sandwiches are often about the meat or the cheese between two slices of bread, but with a simple shift of focus, a sandwich can be a healthful showcase for vegetables, as Martha Rose Shulman writes in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: In the Round: Kia Sorento SXL V-6
description: The Kia Sorento SXL V-6 at the New York auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

title: Relative of Jailed Chinese Laureate Faces Fraud Charges
description: HONG KONG  The brother-in-law of Liu Xiaobo, Chinas jailed Nobel Peace Prize winner, is likely to face trial soon on fraud charges that a lawyer for the family said on Friday lacked sufficient evidence and that supporters said appeared to be an effort to deter Mr. Lius wife from defying house arrest.

title: Making Big Money, Finally, for Not Striking Out
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Jeff Keppinger is playing for his seventh major league team in 10 years. He has never reached double figures in home runs or stolen bases, has never played in the postseason and has never, until now, played on more than a one-year contract.

title: On a Cold Night in Brooklyn  a Daredevil Bike Race
description: If you were just about to compete in a fixed-gear bike race, in the dark, in the cold, on a course with some very sharp turns and 30 or so other competitors, your nerves would show, right? At the Red Hook Criterium last year, the photographer Benedict Evans decided to find out. The idea, Evans, an avid cyclist himself, told me, was to set up a kind of portable studio outdoors near the track, but it rained on the day, so I ended up renting the biggest U-Haul truck I could afford, covering the inside of it with black paper, driving it up next to the finish line and coaxing people inside it to be photographed. I figured that anyone willing to ride brakeless bikes around an intricate course in the dark of night would make for an interesting subject. You can see some of his portraits here, among them that of Dan Chabanov, a bike messenger who has won three of the five races held so far.

title: Investing as an Art Form, Not a Science
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at the investing prowess of doctors and lawyers  the people who often live in the fanciest houses in town and drive the most expensive cars.

title: Mets Leave Camp Upbeat Despite Santanas Injury
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A day after Johan Santana learned that he had retorn a capsule in his pitching shoulder, all but ending his career with the Mets, his agent insisted that Santana was not done pitching.

title: Savage Versus Sumptuous in a Season of Viennese Opera
description: VIENNA  Performances of Wagners Parsifal, with its Christian themes and Good Friday finale, start to swell toward the beginning of the year and crest in the Easter season.

title: Big Ticket | Terraced Duplex, Sold for $17.75 Million
description: A sprawling duplex co-op on prim Park Avenue that had been owned by Hassan Nemazee, who apparently lived a tad too large before being sentenced in 2010 to 12 years in prison for $292 million in bank fraud, was sold by the federal government for $17.75 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Cutting Up Fennel
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to cut up fennel to use both the bulb and the fronds.

title: A Childhood Favorite Grows Up
description: The childhood pleasure of tomato soup with a side of grilled cheese had been enshrined in my mind since Id last had it, decades ago. A tart, bright tomato soup and a crispy sandwich with an oozing interior: no wonder they are an iconic match.

title: Judge Says Cambodian Statue Case Can Go Forward
description: A federal judge ruled Friday that the United States government has enough evidence to move forward in court with its effort to seize a 10th century Cambodian statue that Sothebys had hoped to sell for $3 million.

title: For N.C.A.A., AT&T Calls on Pro Basketball Stars
description: A popular series of television commercials is getting stretched out, literally and figuratively.

title: The Original Digital Pet Returns for a New Generation
description: Making the most of a recent nostalgia trend in technology that has brought back brands like Furby and Pac-Man, Bandai is reintroducing Tamagotchi, the digital pet from the 1990s, as a lifestyle brand called Tamagotchi L.I.F.E. (for Love Is Fun Everywhere).

title: Game of Thrones and the Fantasy Authors Challenge
description: Just in time for this weekends premiere of season 3 of Game of Thrones, John Lanchester has a fineLondon Review of Books essay on the show, the George R.R. Martin books, and fantasy fictions place in literary culture today. I recommend reading the whole piece (so long as you dont mind significant spoilers), but I was struck by this meditation on fantasys longstanding segregation from more respectable forms of fiction:

title: Grandfathers Age Linked to Autism
description: Older paternal age has been linked to autism in a mans offspring, but now researchers have found that the older a man is when his child is born, the greater the risk for autism in his grandchild.

title: Designer Fashion, but Only So Much
description: Bobbi Brown, 55, is the founder and chief creative officer of the makeup line that bears her name. A Chicago native and mother of three sons, Ms. Brown lives in Montclair, N.J., with her husband, Steven Plofker, a real estate developer.

title: After Photo Goes Viral, Dufnering Becomes a Thing
description: HUMBLE, Tex.  Everywhere you looked at the Houston Open, golfers were holding their poses Friday. Not their follow-throughs after textbook swings but their imitations of their fellow touring professional Jason Dufner.

title: Movie Review | 'The Host'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Host."

title: Shoe Tossed at Musharraf Misses Mark, Video Shows
description: Pakistans former military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, narrowly escaped being struck in the head by a shoe hurled at him outside a courtroom in Karachi on Friday, video of the incident showed.

title: Prince of Broadway Is Becoming King of Delays
description: 5:37 p.m. | Updated

title: Fennel Frond Pesto and More
description: In this weeks video I demonstrate how to dismember a fennel bulb. Then I use both the bulb and some of the fronds in a tomato soup recipe in this weeks column.

title: Toys R Us Withdraws I.P.O.
description: The stock market may be on a roll, but Toys R Us will not be joining the fun.

title: A Last Chance for Happy Endings
description: The ABC comedy Happy Endings returns on Friday night after a two-month hiatus, with back-to-back episodes that may be the shows last chance for salvation.

title: The Emily Posts of the Digital Age
description: Are manners dead? Cellphones, Twitter and Facebook may be killing off the old civilities and good graces, but a new generation of etiquette gurus, good-manner bloggers and self-appointed YouTube arbiters is rising to make old-fashioned protocols relevant to a new generation.

title: Obama Pushes Plan to Build Roads and Bridges
description: MIAMI  President Obama came to the congested ocean port here on Friday to promote his plans to rebuild the nations raggedy roads, bridges, schools and other infrastructure with a marriage of public and private investment.

title: Her Gig Canceled After Tirade, Michelle Shocked Plays Outside in Protest
description: After the punk-folk singer-songwriter Michelle Shocked made remarks critical of homosexuality and same-sex marriage while performing in San Francisco two weekends ago, clubs around the country responded by canceling bookings they had made with her. But that hasnt stopped her: Thursday night she turned up outside one such club with her face covered and her mouth taped shut to protest the way she is being treated.

title: Movie Review | 'Renoir'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Renoir."

title: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Central African Republic, Iraq, North Korea and Kashmir.

title: Free to Ride, Roam and Design Handbags
description: Flipping through a recent issue of The New Yorker, I noticed an ad for a handsome-looking bag in brown tooled leather. What caught my eye was the low-key design and dark hue but also the brand: the King Ranch of Texas.

title: Against Top-Ranked Errani and Vinci, Raymond and Robson Keep Winning
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  One more world No. 1 has been toppled at the Sony Open, this time on the womens doubles side.

title: Filing Shows Twisting Path to Three-Way Race for Dell
description: Though the race for Dell Inc. has narrowed to three contestants, many more arose over a month ago.

title: Movie Review | 'Place Beyond the Pines'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Place Beyond the Pines."

title: No Comment Necessary: Background Checks and Breakfast
description: Via Think Progress

title: Photo Replay: March 29
description: A view of the day in sports, including Euroleague postseason basketball in Berlin and preseason baseball in Florida.

title: Lessons Learned in Investing in Rental Properties
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the pros and cons of investing in rental properties.

title: Rental Investment May Seem Safer Than It Really Is
description: Investing in a tangible asset like real estate may seem to offer a greater sense of control. You can walk through a house, after all, which somehow feels safer than subjecting your savings to the whims of the stock market.

title: Feeling For | Pucci Dragon Clutch
description: To celebrate this Sundays premiere of the third season of HBOs Game of Thrones, unleash the dragons with a clutch worthy of a Khaleesi.

title: The Coast Along Whidbey, Before and After the Earth Moved
description: A landslide that struck an island 50 miles north of Seattle sent the equivalent of 40,000 dump-truck loads of earth heaving toward Puget Sound.

title: Week in Pictures for March 29
description: Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration bullpen at City Hall.

title: Blood, Guts and Hair Spray
description: IT PROBABLY SEEMED LIKE a good idea at the time for the members of the British glam-metal band Wrathchild to be so peacockishly come-hither on the cover of their 1984 album Stakk Attakk. With songs like Trash Queen and Too Wild to Tame, no doubt they took pride in their toweringly teased locks, baby-doll lips and strappy S-and-M gear. But nearly 30 years later the image doesnt quite scream Beasts of Metal. It more whispers, Lady Clown.

title: Timeline: How Michael Dells Takeover Bid Got Hatched
description: Shareholders may still be irate over the $13.65 a share that Michael S. Dell has bid for the company that bears his name.

title: Who Are the Best Voices in the History of Metal?
description: Raining Blood may not be Harlem Shake, but to Howie Abrams and Sacha Jenkins it might as well be. Slayers popular 1986 song is No. 4 on the list Our Favorite Songs by the Best Metal Bands, one of several indexes the authors compiled for The Merciless Book of Metal Lists, set for release this month by Abrams Image. The book features scores of compilations of bests (songs, drummers, bass tones), worsts (10 Heavy Metal Fashion Faux Pas) and the only-in-metal (10 Illegible Black Metal Logos).

title: Students Nod to Forefathers of Styles
description: For a few decades now, some of the top ballet schools and companies of various nations have brought their foremost students and apprentices together in exchanges and public sharings. The results in performance can be enchanting, fascinating, perplexing, frustrating  sometimes all at once. On Tuesday, when the Royal Ballet School and American Ballet Theaters Studio Company shared a program at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, all the young dancers were very appealing; some rose to their challenges with particular skill.

title: Southern Town in Syria Is Seized by Rebel Fighters
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Syrian antigovernment activists reported the rebel seizure of a strategically important town in southern Syria on Friday only a few miles from the Jordanian border, which if confirmed would represent a new setback for government forces, who have already ceded territory to the insurgency in the north and east.

title: Reimagining a Brawny Jeep for a Less Rugged Landscape
description: On Wednesday, Jeep came to New York, of all places, to take the wraps off a new S.U.V. with an old name: the Cherokee.

title: Jeep Opts for Sleek
description: Boxy, rough-riding S.U.V.s have faded in favor of car-based crossovers aimed at younger, more suburban customers. To keep up with that trend, Jeep gave its 2014 Cherokee a softer look.

title: Another Sport Franchise for Ford
description: TESTED 2013 Ford Explorer Sport

title: Fast-Food Union Organizers Get Some Historical Perspective
description: When Alvin Turner and Baxter Leach joined a strike in Memphis in 1968, they were two sanitation workers protesting the abuse of black employees and demanding higher wages and the recognition of their union. They recalled being beaten and assaulted with tear gas by the police during marches. But after more than 60 days, the strike ended with the city granting many of their demands.

title: Something Borrowed From the Past
description: The latest wedding fashions are inspired by a couple who didnt work out so well and by a television series that has been a resounding success.

title: A Swagger Retooled for 1908
description: JEREMY PIVEN IS BEST KNOWN as the venal, tantrum-throwing superagent Ari Gold on HBOs hit comedy Entourage; as an alumnus of the Piven Theater Workshop in Chicago, founded by his parents, Joyce and Byrne Piven; and as the center of a highly publicized 2009 breach-of-contract dispute after he left a Broadway production of Speed-the-Plow two months early, citing exhaustion and mercury poisoning. (Mr. Piven won in arbitration.)

title: Drive by Wire, an Aerospace Solution
description: So long as their car moves when the pedal is pressed, there is little reason for drivers of newer cars to care whether electronics have replaced the physical connection between the accelerator and the engine.

title: Beyond All-Wheel Drive, All-Wheel Steering
description: The notion of making vehicles turn better by steering all four of their wheels has inspired engineers for decades. The United States Army experimented with all-wheel-steering jeeps during World War II, and the benefits to maneuverability of rear-steering have long been known to firefighters assigned to hook-and-ladder trucks.

title: Celebrating With Beer, Not Bubbly
description: Shrinking unemployment, healthy sales, shoppers flexing their tire-kicking legs: carmakers selling in the revived North American market have much to celebrate at the New York International Auto Show, which opened on Friday.

title: A Big Gulp in the Czech Republic
description: A representative of the Guinness World Records measures a giant bottle of wine in Cejkovice, in southern Czech Republic. At more than two meters in height, and containing 200 liters of wine, it has been declared the largest wine bottle in the Czech Republic.

title: A Few Thoughts on Her Shoes
description: Its not only about the dress. For some brides these days, the shoes are commanding as much attention as the gown. Brides are kicking aside the classic white or ivory pumps in favor of bright pops of color, floral patterns, those bedazzled with bling, accentuated with feathers and lace, and even their own customized pair.

title: Your Favorite Bowls
description: Consider the bowl, the most common of household objects. We asked readers to send images of their favorite bowls and tell us what makes them special.

title: Vows: Vintage-Inspired Style
description: The wedding style guru Mark Ingram and the Styles reporter Bee-Shyuan Chang discuss the 1920s style wedding trend and offer ways to incorporate a little Daisy Buchanan into your wedding-day look.

title: Wedding Gowns That Evoke A Bygone Era
description: Bridal gowns that recall the look of The Great Gatsby are growing increasingly popular this wedding season.

title: The Pictures from the Week in Culture, March 29
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including performances by Taylor Swift and Sigur Ros.

title: Bipartisan Rebuke for Republican Congressman Who Used Slur
description: Under pressure from Congressional leaders and advocacy groups, Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, has apologized for describing Hispanic farm workers who picked tomatoes on his fathers ranch as wetbacks in an interview.

title: Listening to the Leukocytes and Moving Beyond James Brown
description: Steve Coleman and Five Elements

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 29
description: More photographs.

title: 'Game of Thrones' Fans Flourish
description: The Times's Dave Itzkoff on why a fantasy television show set in medieval times is catching fire with a broad audience.

title: Ex-Schools Chief in Atlanta Is Indicted in Testing Scandal
description: During his 35 years as a Georgia state investigator, Richard Hyde has persuaded all sorts of criminals  corrupt judges, drug dealers, money launderers, racketeers  to turn states evidence, but until Jackie Parks, he had never tried to flip an elementary school teacher.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Ugly Photos, and Delivery by Google
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: In Relocating, a Bar Will Lose No Claim to Celluloid Fame
description: The Emerald Inn, the Upper West Side bar that was the setting for a scene in the movie The Apartment, is moving to the site of a bar that figured in another, much darker, movie, Looking for Mr. Goodbar.

title: Fogging Up the Windows of a Big Store
description: Mr. Selfridge is an eight-part, roughly eight-hour mini-series about the American businessman who opened the revolutionary London department store Selfridges in 1909. Its also a soldier in the current bloody war for period-drama domination between the British television networks ITV and BBC, whose combatants include Downton Abbey and Mr. Selfridge, on ITV, and Call the Midwife and The Paradise, on BBC. (Already dead: BBCs flat-footed Upstairs Downstairs sequel.)

title: The Rewards of Being Very Serious
description: A while back, before moving to Slate, Matthew Yglesias had what I considered a brilliant insight into the incentives facing small-country political leaders:

title: One Woman, Multiplying Identities
description: It may not be entirely clear to you from the first episode why BBC America is billing Orphan Black, its new suspense series, as part of its Supernatural Saturday programming block, alongside Doctor Who. But by the end of the second episode, this tasty show starts to reveal that it is not just another identity-swapping story. Something creepily sci-fi is definitely going on.

title: A Robot for Part of the Pit Crew
description: The Pentagon, in an effort to develop low-cost artificial hands, has built a robot that can take a tire off a car. Putting it back on is another problem altogether.

title: Justin Bieber and Youths New Wilderness
description: Justin Bieber has had it rough of late. Even before this weeks news that his neighbor was accusing him of battery, the 19-year-old Canadian superstar endured a public breakup with his girlfriend, Selena Gomez; was photographed supposedly reveling with codeine-spiked cough syrup and marijuana, and was snubbed by the Grammys. He retaliated with a live-stream Internet performance that hit technical snags.

title: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Modern Man
description: My late-in-life odyssey through current music began when Arcade Fires The Suburbs won the Grammy for best album, and I decided for some reason to give them a listen  and was shocked to discover that good music didnt end in the 1970s. Since then Ive found many bands I love, but I do keep coming back to AF  and I keep finding new depths in that album. Heres a quiet one:

title: Still Dancing Freely at 50, in 50 Birthday Duets
description: The number 50 figures prominently in the choreographer and teacher Lance Griess new video installation, which he created in honor of his 50th birthday. For it he asked 50 dancers to each join him for a 50-minute improvisatory duet.

title: F.D.A. Approves a New Diabetes Drug From J.&J.
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first of a new class of medicines to treat diabetes.

title: The Dark Stuff, Distilled
description: When Joseph Weisberg was training to be a case officer for the C.I.A. in the early 1990s, he soon learned that deception was a crucial skill, one that involved lying to his family on a regular basis.

title: AIDS Memorial Loses Plants and Gains Supporters
